author: Abi Adams
title: The Dynamics of Abusive Relationships
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Domestic abuse encompasses a range of damaging behaviors beyond physical violence, including economic and emotional abuse. We analyze the impact of cohabiting with an abusive partner on victims’ economic outcomes. In so doing, we highlight the systematic role of economic suppression in such relationships. Using Finnish administrative data and a matched-control event-study design, along with a within-individual comparison of outcomes across relationships, we document three new facts. First, women who begin relationships with (eventually) physically abusive men suffer large and significant earnings and employment falls immediately upon cohabiting with the abusive partner. Second, the decline in economic outcomes is non-monotonic in women’s pre-cohabitation outside options. Third, men who are violent against women in any capacity impose economic costs on all their female partners, even those who do not report physical violence. To rationalize these findings, we develop a new dynamic model of abusive relationships where women do not perfectly observe their partner’s type, and abusive men have an incentive to use economic suppression to sabotage women’s outside options and their ability to later exit the relationship.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of cohabiting with an abusive partner on victims' economic outcomes, and what role does economic suppression play in abusive relationships?
answer: Women who begin relationships with physically abusive men suffer large and significant earnings and employment falls immediately upon cohabiting, with the decline being non-monotonic in women's pre-cohabitation outside options, and abusive men impose economic costs on all their female partners through economic suppression to sabotage women's outside options and ability to exit the relationship.
positioning_statement: This paper expands the understanding of domestic abuse beyond physical violence to include economic and emotional abuse, highlighting the systematic role of economic suppression, and develops a new dynamic model where women do not perfectly observe their partner's type and abusive men strategically use economic suppression.

author: Abi Adams
title: Consume Now or Later? Time Inconsistency, Collective Choice, and Revealed Preference
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a revealed preference methodology that allows us to explore whether time inconsistencies in household choice are the product of individual preference nonstationarities or the result of individual heterogeneity and renegotiation within the household. An empirical application to household-level microdata highlights that an explicit recognition of the collective nature of household choice enables the observed behavior to be rationalized by a theory that assumes preference stationarity at the individual level. The methodology created in this paper also facilitates the recovery of theory-consistent discount rates for each individual within particular household under study. (JEL E24, F13, F16) </jats:p>
research_question: Are time inconsistencies in household choice caused by individual preference nonstationarities or by individual heterogeneity and renegotiation within the household?
answer: Time inconsistencies in household choice can be explained by individual heterogeneity and renegotiation within the household rather than individual preference nonstationarities, allowing observed behavior to be rationalized under the assumption of preference stationarity at the individual level.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new revealed preference methodology that explicitly recognizes the collective nature of household choice, distinguishing itself from existing literature by separating individual-level preference issues from household-level decision-making dynamics and enabling recovery of theory-consistent discount rates for individuals within households.

author: Abi Adams
title: Violence against Women at Work
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We link every police report in Finland to administrative data to identify violence between colleagues and the economic consequences for victims, perpetrators, and firms. This new approach to observe when one colleague attacks another overcomes previous data constraints limiting evidence on this phenomenon to self-reported surveys that do not identify perpetrators. We document large, persistent labor market effects of between-colleague violence on victims and perpetrators. Male perpetrators experience substantially weaker consequences after attacking female colleagues. Perpetrators’ relative economic power in male-female violence partly explains this asymmetry. Turning to broader implications for firm recruitment and retention, we find that male-female violence causes a decline in the proportion of women at the firm, both because fewer new women are hired and current female employees leave. Management plays a key role in mediating the effects on the wider workforce. Only male-managed firms lose women. Female-managed firms exhibit a key difference relative to male-managed firms: male perpetrators are less likely to remain employed after attacking their female colleagues.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the economic consequences of violence between colleagues for victims, perpetrators, and firms, and how do these effects vary by gender?
answer: Violence between colleagues has large, persistent labor market effects on both victims and perpetrators, with male perpetrators experiencing substantially weaker consequences when attacking female colleagues. Male-female violence causes firms to lose women employees through reduced hiring and increased departures, but only in male-managed firms. Female-managed firms are more likely to terminate male perpetrators who attack female colleagues.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new methodological approach by linking police reports to administrative data to identify violence between colleagues, overcoming previous data constraints that limited evidence to self-reported surveys that could not identify perpetrators.

author: Abi Adams
title: Revealed Beliefs and the Marriage Market Return to Education
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a new methodology to estimate subjective beliefs from hypothetical-choice data. Our identification approach is based on the novel insight that by varying the amount of information on future realizations of stochastic variables, discrete-choice experiments can identify not only preferences but also subjective beliefs. We formally prove this result in a general setting and apply it to design a strategic survey instrument to measure Rajasthani parents’ subjective beliefs over the joint distribution of girls’ age of marriage, education, and marriage match quality. Our approach allows us to quantify the importance of perceived marriage market returns to education and youth, and perform various counterfactual simulation exercises. We find that eliminating the perceived marriage market return to education causes a 60% drop in the number of girls still in school at age 16, and almost none continue their education by age 18. Responses to our strategic survey instrument allow us accurately to predict realized schooling trajectories in follow-up data we collect from the same sample five years after our experimental data collection.</jats:p>
research_question: How can subjective beliefs about marriage market returns to education be measured and what is their impact on girls' educational decisions?
answer: The paper develops a novel methodology using hypothetical-choice data with varying information levels to identify subjective beliefs, and finds that eliminating perceived marriage market returns to education would cause a 60% drop in girls remaining in school at age 16, with almost none continuing education by age 18.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a new methodological approach to measuring subjective beliefs from discrete-choice experiments by varying information availability, which allows identification of both preferences and beliefs - a novel insight not previously established in the literature.

author: Adam M. Rosen
title: What Do Instrumental Variable Models Deliver with Discrete Dependent Variables?
abstract: <jats:p> We compare nonparametric instrumental variables (IV) models with linear models and 2SLS methods when dependent variables are discrete. A 2SLS method can deliver a consistent estimator of a Local Average Treatment Effect but is not informative about other treatment effect parameters. The IV models set identify a range of interesting structural and treatment effect parameters. We give set identification results for a counterfactual probability and an Average Treatment Effect in a IV binary threshold crossing model. We illustrate using data on female employment and family size (employed by Joshua Angrist and William Evans (1998)) and compare with their LATE estimates. </jats:p>
research_question: What do instrumental variable models deliver with discrete dependent variables, and how do they compare to linear models and 2SLS methods?
answer: Nonparametric IV models with discrete dependent variables can set identify a range of structural and treatment effect parameters beyond what 2SLS can provide, while 2SLS can only deliver consistent estimates of Local Average Treatment Effects but is not informative about other treatment effect parameters.
positioning_statement: This paper extends beyond the limitations of existing 2SLS methods by showing that nonparametric IV models can identify a broader range of parameters when dependent variables are discrete, building on and comparing with established work like Angrist and Evans (1998) while providing set identification results for counterfactual probabilities and Average Treatment Effects in IV binary threshold crossing models.

author: Adam M. Rosen
title: Finite Sample Inference for the Maximum Score Estimand
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We provide a finite sample inference method for the structural parameters of Manski's semiparametric binary response model under a conditional median restriction. This is achieved by exploiting distributional properties of observable outcomes conditional on the observed sequence of exogenous variables. Moment inequalities conditional on the size n sequence of exogenous covariates are constructed, and the proposed test statistic is a monotone function of violations of the corresponding sample moment inequalities. The critical value used for inference is provided by the appropriate quantile of a known function of n independent Bernoulli random variables and does not require the use of a cube root asymptotic approximation employing a point estimator of the target parameter. Simulation studies demonstrate favourable finite sample performance of the test in comparison to several existing approaches. Empirical use is illustrated with an application to the classical setting of transportation choice.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a finite sample inference method for the structural parameters of Manski's semiparametric binary response model under a conditional median restriction?
answer: The paper develops a finite sample inference method by exploiting distributional properties of observable outcomes conditional on observed exogenous variables, constructing moment inequalities conditional on the sequence of exogenous covariates, and using a test statistic based on violations of sample moment inequalities with critical values from quantiles of Bernoulli random variables.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing an alternative to existing cube root asymptotic approximation methods that require point estimators of target parameters, offering superior finite sample performance compared to several existing approaches for inference in Manski's maximum score model.

author: Adam M. Rosen
title: Generalized Instrumental Variable Models
abstract: This paper develops characterizations of identified sets of structures and structural features for complete and incomplete models involving continuous or discrete variables. Multiple values of unobserved variables can be associated with particular combinations of observed variables. This can arise when there are multiple sources of heterogeneity, censored or discrete endogenous variables, or inequality restrictions on functions of observed and unobserved variables. The models generalize the class of incomplete instrumental variable (IV) models in which unobserved variables are single‐valued functions of observed variables. Thus the models are referred to as generalized IV (GIV) models, but there are important cases in which instrumental variable restrictions play no significant role. Building on a definition of observational equivalence for incomplete models the development uses results from random set theory that guarantee that the characterizations deliver sharp bounds, thereby dispensing with the need for case‐by‐case proofs of sharpness. The use of random sets defined on the space of unobserved variables allows identification analysis under mean and quantile independence restrictions on the distributions of unobserved variables conditional on exogenous variables as well as under a full independence restriction. The results are used to develop sharp bounds on the distribution of valuations in an incomplete model of English auctions, improving on the pointwise bounds available until now. Application of many of the results of the paper requires no familiarity with random set theory.

author: Abi Adams
title: What do Consumers Consider Before They Choose? Identification from Asymmetric Demand Responses
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Consideration set models generalize discrete-choice models by relaxing the assumption that consumers consider all available options. Determining which options were considered has previously required either survey data or restrictions on how attributes affect consideration or utility. We provide an alternative route. In full-consideration models, choice probabilities satisfy a symmetry property analogous to Slutsky symmetry in continuous-choice models. This symmetry breaks down in consideration set models when changes in characteristics perturb consideration. We show that consideration probabilities are constructively identified from the resulting asymmetries. We validate our approach in a lab experiment where consideration sets are known and then apply our framework to study a “smart default” policy in Medicare Part D, wherein consumers are automatically reassigned to lower-cost prescription drug plans with the option of opting out. Full-consideration models imply that such a policy will be ineffective because consumers will opt out to avoid switching costs. Allowing for inattention, we find that defaulting all consumers to lower-cost options produces negligible welfare benefits on average, but defaulting only consumers who would save at least $300 produces large benefits.</jats:p>
research_question: How can researchers identify which options consumers actually consider when making choices, without relying on survey data or restrictive assumptions about how attributes affect consideration or utility?
answer: Consideration probabilities can be constructively identified from asymmetries in demand responses that arise when changes in product characteristics perturb consideration, breaking down the symmetry property that holds in full-consideration models.
positioning_statement: This paper provides an alternative methodological route to existing approaches for identifying consideration sets in discrete-choice models, which previously required either survey data or restrictions on how attributes affect consideration or utility, by exploiting asymmetric demand responses that violate the symmetry property of full-consideration models.

author: Abi Adams
title: Measuring Workplace Sexual Harassment: A Review
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>Measurement is a key challenge in studying sexual harassment. People's understanding of harassment varies across cultural and legal contexts, and there are many factors contributing to under‐reporting. We review the psychology literature on the measurement of sexual harassment and assess the techniques employed in economics in this light. Using an online survey of the US workers, we show that survey methods that provide explicit behavioral examples or detailed definitions of sexual harassment identify higher prevalence rates, especially for black workers and men. We show that measures of the willingness to pay to avoid harassment vary according to which behaviors are specified.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different survey methods and measurement techniques affect the identification and reporting of workplace sexual harassment across different demographic groups?
answer: Survey methods that provide explicit behavioral examples or detailed definitions of sexual harassment identify higher prevalence rates, especially for black workers and men, and measures of willingness to pay to avoid harassment vary according to which specific behaviors are specified in the survey.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as bridging psychology and economics literature by reviewing psychology literature on sexual harassment measurement and assessing how economics research techniques compare, while addressing the key challenge that people's understanding of harassment varies across cultural and legal contexts with significant under-reporting issues.

author: Adi Sunderam
title: Financial Market Risk Perceptions and the Macroeconomy*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We provide evidence that financial market risk perceptions are important drivers of economic fluctuations. We introduce a novel measure of risk perceptions: the price of volatile stocks (PVSt), defined as the book-to-market ratio of low-volatility stocks minus the book-to-market ratio of high-volatility stocks. PVSt is high when perceived risk directly measured from surveys and option prices is low. Using our measure, we show that high perceived risk is associated with low risk-free interest rates, a high cost of capital for risky firms, and future declines in output and real investment. Perceived risk as measured by PVSt falls after positive macroeconomic news. These declines are predictably followed by upward revisions in perceived risk, indicating that fluctuations in investor risk perceptions are not fully rational.</jats:p>
research_question: Are financial market risk perceptions important drivers of economic fluctuations?
answer: Yes, financial market risk perceptions are important drivers of economic fluctuations. High perceived risk is associated with low risk-free interest rates, high cost of capital for risky firms, and future declines in output and real investment. Additionally, fluctuations in investor risk perceptions are not fully rational, as they predictably reverse after initial responses to macroeconomic news.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel measure of risk perceptions (PVSt - the price of volatile stocks) that complements existing measures from surveys and option prices, providing new evidence on the relationship between risk perceptions and macroeconomic outcomes that was not previously established in the literature.

author: Adriana Lleras-Muney
title: The Lifetime Impacts of the New Deal's Youth Employment Program
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the lifetime effects of the first and largest American youth employment and training program in the United States—the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), 1933–1942. We match newly digitized enrollee records to census, World War II enlistment, Social Security, and death records. We find that longer service in the CCC led to improvements in height, health status, longevity, geographic mobility, and lifetime earnings but did not improve short-term labor market outcomes, including employment and wages. We address potential selection into CCC duration using several approaches, most importantly two newly developed control-function approaches that leverage unbiased estimates of the short-term effects of a randomized controlled trial of Job Corps (the modern version of the CCC). Our findings suggest that short- and medium-term evaluations of employment programs underestimate effects because they fail to capture lifetime effects and often ignore or underestimate health and longevity benefits that increase in magnitude at later ages.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the lifetime effects of the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), America's first and largest youth employment and training program from 1933-1942?
answer: Longer service in the CCC led to improvements in height, health status, longevity, geographic mobility, and lifetime earnings, but did not improve short-term labor market outcomes like employment and wages.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the literature by demonstrating that short- and medium-term evaluations of employment programs underestimate effects because they fail to capture lifetime effects and often ignore or underestimate health and longevity benefits that increase in magnitude at later ages.

author: Adriana Lleras-Muney
title: The Negligible Effect of Free Contraception on Fertility: Experimental Evidence from Burkina Faso
abstract: <jats:p> We conducted a randomized trial among 14,545 households in rural Burkina Faso to test the oft-cited hypothesis that limited access to contraception is an important driver of high fertility rates in West Africa. We do not find support for this hypothesis. Women who were given free access to modern contraception for three years did not have lower birth rates; we can reject even modest effects. We cross-randomized additional interventions to address inefficiencies that might depress demand for free contraception, specifically misperceptions about the child mortality rate and social norms. Free contraception did not significantly influence fertility even in combination with these interventions. (JEL D12, J13, J16, J18, O12) </jats:p>
research_question: Does limited access to contraception drive high fertility rates in West Africa?
answer: Free access to modern contraception for three years did not significantly reduce birth rates among women in rural Burkina Faso, even when combined with interventions addressing misperceptions about child mortality and social norms.
positioning_statement: This paper tests the oft-cited hypothesis that limited access to contraception is an important driver of high fertility rates in West Africa, providing experimental evidence that challenges this commonly held belief in the literature.

author: Adi Sunderam
title: Using Models to Persuade
abstract: <jats:p> We present a framework where “model persuaders” influence receivers’ beliefs by proposing models that organize past data to make predictions. Receivers are assumed to find models more compelling when they better explain the data, fixing receivers’ prior beliefs. Model persuaders face a trade-off: better-fitting models induce less movement in receivers’ beliefs. Consequently, a receiver exposed to the true model can be most misled by persuasion when that model fits poorly, competition between persuaders tends to neutralize the data by pushing toward better-fitting models, and a persuader facing multiple receivers is more effective when he can send tailored, private messages. (JEL C50, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How do model persuaders influence receivers' beliefs by proposing models that organize past data to make predictions, and what trade-offs do they face in this process?
answer: Model persuaders face a fundamental trade-off where better-fitting models induce less movement in receivers' beliefs. Key findings include: receivers can be most misled when the true model fits data poorly, competition between persuaders neutralizes persuasion by pushing toward better-fitting models, and persuaders are more effective with tailored private messages to multiple receivers.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a novel framework for understanding persuasion through model selection, contributing to the literature on information economics and strategic communication by examining how the quality of model fit affects persuasive power and belief formation.

author: Adi Sunderam
title: A Quantity-Driven Theory of Term Premia and Exchange Rates
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a model in which specialized bond investors must absorb shocks to the supply and demand for long-term bonds in two currencies. Since long-term bonds and foreign exchange are both exposed to unexpected movements in short-term interest rates, a shift in the supply of long-term bonds in one currency influences the foreign exchange rate between the two currencies, as well as bond term premia in both currencies. Our model matches several important empirical patterns, including the comovement between exchange rates and term premia, and the finding that central banks’ quantitative easing policies affect exchange rates. An extension of our model links spot exchange rates to the persistent deviations from covered interest rate parity that have emerged since 2008.</jats:p>
research_question: How do supply and demand shocks to long-term bonds in different currencies affect term premia and exchange rates, and what explains the comovement between these financial variables?
answer: A shift in the supply of long-term bonds in one currency influences both the foreign exchange rate between currencies and bond term premia in both currencies, because long-term bonds and foreign exchange are both exposed to unexpected movements in short-term interest rates and must be absorbed by specialized bond investors.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a quantity-driven theoretical framework that explains empirical patterns that existing literature has documented but not fully explained, including the comovement between exchange rates and term premia, the exchange rate effects of quantitative easing policies, and the persistent deviations from covered interest rate parity observed since 2008.

author: Adi Sunderam
title: Perceptions About Monetary Policy
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We estimate perceptions about the Federal Reserve’s monetary policy rule from panel data on professional forecasts of interest rates and macroeconomic conditions. The perceived dependence of the federal funds rate on economic conditions varies substantially over time, in particular over the monetary policy cycle. Forecasters update their perceptions about the Fed’s policy rule in response to monetary policy actions, measured by high-frequency interest rate surprises, suggesting that they have imperfect information about the rule. Monetary policy perceptions matter for monetary transmission, as they affect the sensitivity of interest rates to macroeconomic news, term premia in long-term bonds, and the response of the stock market to monetary policy surprises. A simple learning model with forecaster heterogeneity and incomplete information about the policy rule motivates and explains our empirical findings.</jats:p>
research_question: How do professional forecasters perceive the Federal Reserve's monetary policy rule, and how do these perceptions affect monetary policy transmission?
answer: Perceptions about the Fed's policy rule vary substantially over time and across the monetary policy cycle. Forecasters update their perceptions in response to monetary policy actions, indicating imperfect information about the rule. These perceptions significantly affect monetary transmission by influencing interest rate sensitivity to macroeconomic news, term premia in long-term bonds, and stock market responses to monetary policy surprises.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by empirically estimating time-varying perceptions of monetary policy rules using professional forecast data and demonstrating their importance for monetary transmission, supported by a learning model with forecaster heterogeneity and incomplete information.

author: Adrien Auclert
title: Monetary Policy and the Redistribution Channel
abstract: <jats:p> This paper evaluates the role of redistribution in the transmission mechanism of monetary policy to consumption. Three channels affect aggregate spending when winners and losers have different marginal propensities to consume: an earnings heterogeneity channel from unequal income gains, a Fisher channel from unexpected inflation, and an interest rate exposure channel from real interest rate changes. Sufficient statistics from Italian and US data suggest that all three channels are likely to amplify the effects of monetary policy. (JEL E21, E31, E43, E52) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of redistribution in the transmission mechanism of monetary policy to consumption?
answer: Three redistribution channels amplify the effects of monetary policy on aggregate spending: an earnings heterogeneity channel from unequal income gains, a Fisher channel from unexpected inflation, and an interest rate exposure channel from real interest rate changes, with empirical evidence from Italian and US data suggesting all three channels likely amplify monetary policy effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the monetary policy transmission literature by identifying and quantifying redistribution as a key mechanism through which monetary policy affects consumption, using sufficient statistics methodology to evaluate three distinct redistribution channels.

author: Adriana Lleras-Muney
title: The Long-Run Impact of Cash Transfers to Poor Families
abstract: <jats:p> We estimate the long-run impact of cash transfers to poor families on children's longevity, educational attainment, nutritional status, and income in adulthood. To do so, we collected individual-level administrative records of applicants to the Mothers' Pension program—the first government-sponsored welfare program in the United States (1911–1935)—and matched them to census, WWII, and death records. Male children of accepted applicants lived one year longer than those of rejected mothers. They also obtained one-third more years of schooling, were less likely to be underweight, and had higher income in adulthood than children of rejected mothers. (JEL I12, I14, I18, I32, I38, J16, N32) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the long-run impact of cash transfers to poor families on children's longevity, educational attainment, nutritional status, and income in adulthood?
answer: Cash transfers to poor families have significant positive long-term effects: male children of families receiving transfers lived one year longer, obtained one-third more years of schooling, were less likely to be underweight, and had higher adult income compared to children whose families were rejected for transfers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing novel long-run evidence on the effects of cash transfers using historical data from the first government-sponsored welfare program in the United States (Mothers' Pension program, 1911-1935), utilizing individual-level administrative records matched across multiple data sources including census, WWII, and death records.

author: Adrien Auclert
title: Aggregate Demand and the Top 1 Percent
abstract: <jats:p> There has been a large rise in US top income inequality since the 1980s. We merge a widely studied model of the Pareto tail of labor incomes with a canonical model of consumption and savings to study the consequences of this increase for aggregate demand. Our model suggests that the rise of the top 1 percent may have led to a large increase in desired savings and can explain a 0.45pp to 0.85pp decline in long-run real interest rates. This effect arises from both a wealth effect at the top and increased precautionary savings from declines lower in the income distribution. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the consequences of the large rise in US top income inequality since the 1980s for aggregate demand?
answer: The rise of the top 1 percent led to a large increase in desired savings and can explain a 0.45pp to 0.85pp decline in long-run real interest rates, driven by both wealth effects at the top and increased precautionary savings from income declines lower in the distribution.
positioning_statement: This paper merges a widely studied model of the Pareto tail of labor incomes with a canonical model of consumption and savings to study inequality's impact on aggregate demand.

author: Adrien Auclert
title: The Intertemporal Keynesian Cross

author: Adrien Auclert
title: Using the Sequence‐Space Jacobian to Solve and Estimate Heterogeneous‐Agent Models
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a general and highly efficient method for solving and estimating general equilibrium heterogeneous‐agent models with aggregate shocks in discrete time. Our approach relies on the rapid computation of<jats:italic>sequence‐space Jacobians</jats:italic>—the derivatives of perfect‐foresight equilibrium mappings between aggregate sequences around the steady state. Our main contribution is a fast algorithm for calculating Jacobians for a large class of heterogeneous‐agent problems. We combine this algorithm with a systematic approach to composing and inverting Jacobians to solve for general equilibrium impulse responses. We obtain a rapid procedure for likelihood‐based estimation and computation of nonlinear perfect‐foresight transitions. We apply our methods to three canonical heterogeneous‐agent models: a neoclassical model, a New Keynesian model with one asset, and a New Keynesian model with two assets.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a general and highly efficient computational method for solving and estimating general equilibrium heterogeneous-agent models with aggregate shocks in discrete time?
answer: The paper develops a fast algorithm based on sequence-space Jacobians that enables rapid computation of derivatives of perfect-foresight equilibrium mappings, which can be systematically composed and inverted to solve for general equilibrium impulse responses and perform likelihood-based estimation.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses computational challenges in heterogeneous-agent modeling by proposing a novel methodological approach that significantly improves efficiency compared to existing methods, demonstrated through application to three canonical models in the literature.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: Does Incomplete Spanning in International Financial Markets Help to Explain Exchange Rates?
abstract: <jats:p> We assume that domestic (foreign) agents, when investing abroad, can only trade in the foreign (domestic) risk-free rates. In a preference-free environment, we derive the exchange rate volatility and risk premia in any such incomplete spanning model, as well as a measure of exchange rate cyclicality. We find that incomplete spanning lowers the volatility of exchange rate, increases the risk premia but only by creating exchange rate predictability, and does not affect the exchange rate cyclicality. (JEL E32, F31, F44, G15) </jats:p>
research_question: Does incomplete spanning in international financial markets help to explain exchange rate behavior, specifically exchange rate volatility, risk premia, and cyclicality?
answer: Incomplete spanning lowers exchange rate volatility, increases risk premia (but only through creating exchange rate predictability), and does not affect exchange rate cyclicality.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining exchange rate dynamics under the assumption that domestic and foreign agents can only trade in each other's risk-free rates when investing abroad, using a preference-free analytical framework to derive theoretical results about exchange rate properties in incomplete spanning models.

author: Adrien Bilal
title: The Geography of Unemployment
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Unemployment rates differ widely across local labor markets. I offer new empirical evidence that high local unemployment emerges because of elevated local job-losing rates. Local employers, rather than local workers or location-specific factors, account for most of the spatial gaps in job stability. I propose a theory in which spatial differences in job loss emerge in equilibrium because of systematic differences between employers across local labor markets. The spatial sorting decisions of employers in turn shape heterogeneity across locations. Labor market frictions induce productive employers to overvalue locating close to each other. The optimal policy incentivizes them to relocate toward areas with high job-losing rates, providing a rationale for commonly used place-based policies. I estimate the model using French administrative data. The estimated model accounts for over three-quarters of the cross-sectional dispersion in unemployment rates and for the respective contributions of job-losing and job-finding rates. Inefficient location choices by employers amplify spatial unemployment differentials fivefold. Both real-world and optimal place-based policies can yield sizable local and aggregate welfare gains.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do unemployment rates differ widely across local labor markets, and what drives these spatial differences in unemployment?
answer: High local unemployment emerges primarily because of elevated local job-losing rates, which are mainly driven by local employers rather than local workers or location-specific factors. Spatial differences in job loss arise from systematic differences between employers across local labor markets and their spatial sorting decisions, with labor market frictions causing productive employers to overvalue locating close to each other.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new empirical evidence on the drivers of spatial unemployment differences by identifying that local employers, rather than workers or location factors, account for most spatial gaps in job stability. It proposes a novel theory linking employer spatial sorting decisions to unemployment differentials and provides theoretical justification for place-based policies, estimating that inefficient employer location choices amplify spatial unemployment differentials fivefold.

author: Adrien Bilal
title: Firm and Worker Dynamics in a Frictional Labor Market
abstract: <jats:p>This paper integrates the classic theory of firm boundaries, through span of control or taste for variety, into a model of the labor market with random matching and on‐the‐job search. Firms choose when to enter and exit, whether to create vacancies or destroy jobs in response to shocks, and Bertrand‐compete to hire and retain workers. Tractability is obtained by proving that, under a parsimonious set of assumptions, all worker and firm decisions are characterized by their joint surplus, which in turn only depends on firm productivity and size. The job ladder in marginal surplus that emerges in equilibrium determines net poaching patterns by firm characteristics that are in line with the data. As frictions vanish, the model converges to a standard competitive model of firm dynamics. The combination of firm dynamics and search frictions allows the model to: (i) quantify the misallocation cost of frictions; (ii) replicate elusive life‐cycle growth profiles of superstar firms; and (iii) make sense of the failure of the job ladder around the Great Recession as a result of the collapse of firm entry.</jats:p>
research_question: How do firm boundaries and dynamics interact with labor market frictions, random matching, and on-the-job search to determine worker and firm behavior?
answer: Under a parsimonious set of assumptions, all worker and firm decisions can be characterized by their joint surplus, which depends only on firm productivity and size, creating a job ladder in marginal surplus that determines net poaching patterns consistent with empirical data.
positioning_statement: This paper integrates classic theory of firm boundaries (span of control or taste for variety) into labor market models with search frictions, extending beyond standard competitive models to create a tractable framework that converges to competitive models as frictions vanish while explaining phenomena like superstar firm growth and Great Recession job ladder collapse.

author: Adrien Auclert
title: New Pricing Models, Same Old Phillips Curves?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that in a broad class of menu cost models, the first-order dynamics of aggregate inflation in response to arbitrary shocks to aggregate costs are nearly the same as in Calvo models with suitably chosen Calvo adjustment frequencies. We first prove that the canonical menu cost model is first-order equivalent to a mixture of two time-dependent models, which reflect the extensive and intensive margins of price adjustment. We then show numerically that in any plausible parameterization, this mixture is well approximated by a single Calvo model. This close numerical fit carries over to other standard specifications of menu cost models. Thus, for shocks that are not too large, the Phillips curve for a menu cost model looks like the New Keynesian Phillips curve, but with a higher slope.</jats:p>
research_question: Do menu cost models generate fundamentally different aggregate inflation dynamics compared to Calvo models, or do they produce similar Phillips curve relationships?
answer: Menu cost models produce nearly identical first-order inflation dynamics to Calvo models with appropriately chosen adjustment frequencies, resulting in Phillips curves that look like the New Keynesian Phillips curve but with a higher slope.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges the gap between two major pricing model frameworks in macroeconomics by demonstrating that despite their different microeconomic foundations, menu cost models and Calvo models yield remarkably similar aggregate outcomes, suggesting that the choice between these modeling approaches may be less consequential for aggregate analysis than previously thought.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: The Cross Section of Foreign Currency Risk Premia and Consumption Growth Risk: Reply
abstract: <jats:p> The consumption growth beta of an investment strategy that goes long in high interest rate currencies and short in low interest rate currencies is large and significant. Consumption risk price differs significantly from zero, even after accounting for the sampling uncertainty introduced by the estimation of the consumption betas. The constant in the regression of average returns on consumption betas is not significant. Additionally, this investment strategy's consumption and market betas increase during recessions and times of crisis, when risk prices are high, implying that the unconditional betas understate its riskiness. JEL: C58, E21, F31, G11, G12 </jats:p>
research_question: Does consumption growth risk explain the cross-section of foreign currency risk premia, particularly for carry trade strategies that go long high interest rate currencies and short low interest rate currencies?
answer: Yes, consumption growth risk significantly explains foreign currency risk premia. The carry trade strategy has a large and significant consumption growth beta, consumption risk price is significantly different from zero even after accounting for sampling uncertainty, and the strategy's risk exposure increases during recessions and crises when risk prices are high.
positioning_statement: This paper serves as a reply to existing literature, defending and reinforcing the role of consumption-based asset pricing models in explaining foreign currency returns against previous criticisms or alternative explanations.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: The Cross Section of Foreign Currency Risk Premia and Consumption Growth Risk

author: Adrien Bilal
title: Location as an Asset
abstract: <jats:p>The location of individuals determines their job and schooling opportunities, amenities, and housing costs. We conceptualize the location choice of individuals as a decision to invest in a “location asset.” This asset has a current cost equal to the location's rent, and a future payoff through better job and schooling opportunities. As with any asset, savers in the location asset transfer resources into the future by going to expensive locations with high future returns. In contrast, borrowers transfer resources to the present by going to cheap locations that offer few other advantages. Holdings of the location asset depend on its comparison to other assets, with the distinction that the location asset is not subject to borrowing constraints. We propose a dynamic location model and derive an agent's mobility choices after experiencing income shocks. We document the investment dimension of location and confirm the core predictions of our theory using French individual panel data from tax returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How can individual location choices be understood as investment decisions in a 'location asset,' and how do income shocks affect mobility patterns when location is treated as an asset?
answer: Location functions as an asset where individuals make investment decisions by trading off current costs (rent) against future returns (better job and schooling opportunities). Savers invest in expensive locations with high future returns, while borrowers choose cheap locations to transfer resources to the present. Unlike other assets, the location asset is not subject to borrowing constraints, and mobility choices respond predictably to income shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel conceptual framework by treating location choice as an asset investment decision, extending traditional location choice models by incorporating dynamic investment theory and explicitly modeling how individuals use location decisions to transfer resources across time periods.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: The Cross Section of Foreign Currency Risk Premia and Consumption Growth Risk
abstract: <jats:p> Aggregate consumption growth risk explains why low interest rate currencies do not appreciate as much as the interest rate differential and why high interest rate currencies do not depreciate as much as the interest rate differential. Domestic investors earn negative excess returns on low interest rate currency portfolios and positive excess returns on high interest rate currency portfolios. Because high interest rate currencies depreciate on average when domestic consumption growth is low and low interest rate currencies appreciate under the same conditions, low interest rate currencies provide domestic investors with a hedge against domestic aggregate consumption growth risk. (JEL E21, E43, F31, G11) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do low interest rate currencies not appreciate as much as the interest rate differential and why do high interest rate currencies not depreciate as much as the interest rate differential?
answer: Aggregate consumption growth risk explains these currency movements - high interest rate currencies depreciate when domestic consumption growth is low while low interest rate currencies appreciate under the same conditions, making low interest rate currencies a hedge against domestic consumption growth risk.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a consumption-based risk explanation for the cross-section of foreign currency risk premia, explaining the carry trade puzzle through the lens of domestic aggregate consumption growth risk rather than other existing theoretical frameworks.

author: Alessandra Voena
title: Yours, Mine, and Ours: Do Divorce Laws Affect the Intertemporal Behavior of Married Couples?
abstract: <jats:p>This paper examines how divorce laws affect couples' intertemporal choices and well-being. Exploiting panel variation in US laws, I estimate the parameters of a model of household decision-making. Household survey data indicate that the introduction of unilateral divorce in states that imposed an equal division of property is associated with higher household savings and lower female employment, implying a distortion in household assets accumulation and a transfer toward wives whose share in household resources is smaller than the one of their husband. When spouses share consumption equally, separate property or prenuptial agreements can reduce distortions and increase equity. (JEL D13, D14, D91, J12, J16, K36)</jats:p>
research_question: How do divorce laws affect couples' intertemporal choices and well-being?
answer: The introduction of unilateral divorce in states with equal property division leads to higher household savings and lower female employment, creating distortions in asset accumulation and transfers toward wives who have smaller shares in household resources compared to their husbands.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using panel variation in US divorce laws to estimate parameters of a household decision-making model, providing empirical evidence on how legal frameworks affect intertemporal household behavior and suggesting that separate property arrangements or prenuptial agreements can reduce distortions when spouses share consumption equally.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: Long Run Risk, the Wealth-Consumption Ratio, and the Temporal Pricing of Risk
abstract: Representative agent consumption based asset pricing models have made great strides in accounting for many important features of asset returns. The long run risk (LRR) models of Ravi Bansal and Amir Yaron (2004) are a prime example of this progress. Yet, several other representative agent models, such as the external habit model of John Y. Campbell and John H. Cochrane (1999) and the variable rare disasters model of Xavier Gabaix (2008), seem to be able to match a similar set of asset pricing moments. Additional moments would be useful to help distinguish between these models. Hanno Lustig, Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh, and Adrien Verdelhan (2009) argue that the wealth-consumption ratio is such a moment. A comparison of the wealthconsumption ratio in the LRR model and in the data is favorable to the LRR model. This is no small feat because the wealth-consumption ratio is not a target in the usual calibrations of the model, and the LRR is—so far—the sole model able to reproduce both the equity premium and the wealth-consumption ratio. The LRR model matches the properties of the wealth-consumption ratio despite the fact that it implies a negative real bond risk premium. This is because it generates quite a bit of consumption cash flow risk to offset the negative discount rate risk. Long Run Risk, the Wealth-Consumption Ratio, and the Temporal Pricing of Risk

author: Aislinn Bohren
title: Learning With Heterogeneous Misspecified Models: Characterization and Robustness
abstract: <jats:p>This paper develops a general framework to study how misinterpreting information impacts learning. Our main result is a simple criterion to characterize long‐run beliefs based on the underlying form of misspecification. We present this characterization in the context of social learning, then highlight how it applies to other learning environments, including individual learning. A key contribution is that our characterization applies to settings with model heterogeneity and provides conditions for entrenched disagreement. Our characterization can be used to determine whether a representative agent approach is valid in the face of heterogeneity, study how differing levels of bias or unawareness of others' biases impact learning, and explore whether the impact of a bias is sensitive to parametric specification or the source of information. This unified framework synthesizes insights gleaned from previously studied forms of misspecification and provides novel insights in specific applications, as we demonstrate in settings with partisan bias, overreaction, naive learning, and level‐k reasoning.</jats:p>
research_question: How does misinterpreting information impact learning, particularly in environments with heterogeneous misspecified models?
answer: The paper develops a simple criterion that characterizes long-run beliefs based on the underlying form of misspecification, showing how different types of bias and model heterogeneity lead to specific learning outcomes including conditions for entrenched disagreement.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified framework that synthesizes insights from previously studied forms of misspecification while extending the analysis to settings with model heterogeneity, offering a general characterization that applies across multiple learning environments (social learning, individual learning) and various specific applications (partisan bias, overreaction, naive learning, level-k reasoning).

author: Alan Moreira
title: Whatever It Takes? The Impact of Conditional Policy Promises
abstract: <jats:p> At the announcement of a new policy, agents form a view of state-contingent policy actions and impact. We develop a method to estimate this state-contingent perception and implement it for many asset-purchase interventions worldwide. Expectations of larger support in bad states—“policy puts”—explain a large fraction of the announcements' impact. For example, when the Fed introduced purchases of corporate bonds in March 2020, markets expected five times more price support had conditions worsened relative to the median scenario. Perceived promises of additional support in bad states alter asset prices, risk, and the response to future announcements. (JEL E52, E58, G12, G13, G14, G21, G28) </jats:p>
research_question: How do agents form expectations about state-contingent policy actions when new policies are announced, and what is the impact of these conditional policy promises on financial markets?
answer: Expectations of larger policy support in bad economic states ('policy puts') explain a large fraction of policy announcements' impact on markets. For example, when the Fed introduced corporate bond purchases in March 2020, markets expected five times more price support in worsened conditions compared to median scenarios. These perceived conditional promises significantly alter asset prices, risk, and responses to future announcements.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel method to estimate state-contingent policy perceptions and applies it to asset-purchase interventions worldwide, contributing to the literature on policy announcement effects by quantifying how markets price in conditional policy support across different economic states.

author: Adrien Verdelhan
title: The Term Structure of Currency Carry Trade Risk Premia
abstract: <jats:p> Fixing the investment horizon, the returns to currency carry trades decrease as the maturity of the foreign bonds increases. Across developed countries, the local currency term premia, which increase with the maturity of the bonds, offset the currency risk premia. Similarly, in the time-series, the predictability of foreign bond returns in dollars declines with the bonds’ maturities. Leading no-arbitrage models in international finance do not match the downward term structure of currency carry trade risk premia. We derive a simple preference-free condition that no-arbitrage models need to reproduce in the absence of carry trade risk premia on long-term bonds. (JEL E43, G12, G15) </jats:p>
research_question: How do currency carry trade risk premia vary across different bond maturities, and what explains this term structure pattern?
answer: Currency carry trade returns decrease as the maturity of foreign bonds increases, creating a downward-sloping term structure of carry trade risk premia. This occurs because local currency term premia, which increase with bond maturity, offset the currency risk premia.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a gap in existing no-arbitrage models in international finance, showing that leading models fail to match the observed downward term structure of currency carry trade risk premia, and derives a new preference-free condition that such models need to satisfy.

author: Aislinn Bohren
title: Systemic Discrimination: Theory and Measurement
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Economists often measure discrimination as disparities arising from the direct effects of group identity. We develop new tools to model and measure systemic discrimination, capturing how discrimination in other decisions indirectly contributes to disparities. A novel experimental design, the iterated audit, identifies systemic discrimination. We illustrate these new tools in two field experiments. The first experiment shows how racial discrimination can accumulate across multiple rounds of hiring through the interaction of two forces: greater discrimination against inexperienced workers, which affects the opportunity to obtain experience, and high subsequent returns to experience. The second experiment shows how gender-based differences in the language of recommendation letters can translate into systemic gender discrimination in STEM hiring. We discuss how our findings qualify previous results on direct discrimination and how our tools can be used to target policy interventions.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we model and measure systemic discrimination that captures how discrimination in other decisions indirectly contributes to disparities, beyond just direct effects of group identity?
answer: The paper develops new tools including a novel 'iterated audit' experimental design that identifies systemic discrimination, demonstrating through two field experiments that discrimination can accumulate indirectly - through racial discrimination against inexperienced workers affecting opportunity to gain experience, and through gender-based differences in recommendation letter language translating into STEM hiring discrimination.
positioning_statement: This paper extends beyond existing economics literature that typically measures discrimination only as disparities from direct effects of group identity, by developing new theoretical and empirical tools to capture indirect, systemic forms of discrimination that accumulate across multiple decisions and contexts.

author: Albert Menkveld
title: Equilibrium Bid-Price Dispersion
abstract: If bidding in a pure common-value auction is costly and bidders do not know how many others are also bidding, all equilibria are in mixed strategies. Participation is probabilistic, and bid prices are dispersed. The symmetric equilibrium is unique and yields simple analytic expressions. We use them to, for example, show that bid prices exhibit negative skewness. The expressions are further used to estimate the model based on bidding on a Standard & Poor’s 500 security. We find that the number of bidders declined over time, making liquidity supply fragile.

author: Alessandra Voena
title: Compulsory Licensing: Evidence from the Trading with the Enemy Act
abstract: <jats:p> Compulsory licensing allows firms in developing countries to produce foreign-owned inventions without the consent of foreign patent owners. This paper uses an exogenous event of compulsory licensing after World War I under the Trading with the Enemy Act to examine the effects of compulsory licensing on domestic invention. Difference-in-differences analyses of nearly 130,000 chemical inventions suggest that compulsory licensing increased domestic invention by 20 percent. (JEL D45, L24, N42, O31, O34) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of compulsory licensing on domestic invention?
answer: Compulsory licensing increased domestic invention by 20 percent, as evidenced by analysis of nearly 130,000 chemical inventions following the exogenous event under the Trading with the Enemy Act after World War I.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on compulsory licensing by using a unique historical natural experiment (the Trading with the Enemy Act after WWI) to provide causal evidence on the relationship between compulsory licensing and domestic innovation, addressing the challenge of identifying exogenous variation in compulsory licensing policies.

author: Aislinn Bohren
title: The Dynamics of Discrimination: Theory and Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> We model the dynamics of discrimination and show how its evolution can identify the underlying source. We test these theoretical predictions in a field experiment on a large online platform where users post content that is evaluated by other users on the platform. We assign posts to accounts that exogenously vary by gender and evaluation histories. With no prior evaluations, women face significant discrimination. However, following a sequence of positive evaluations, the direction of discrimination reverses: women’s posts are favored over men’s. Interpreting these results through the lens of our model, this dynamic reversal implies discrimination driven by biased beliefs. (JEL C93, D83, J16, J71) </jats:p>
research_question: How can the dynamics of discrimination over time identify the underlying source or mechanism driving discriminatory behavior?
answer: The evolution of discrimination can reveal its underlying source - specifically, when discrimination reverses direction based on performance history (from anti-women bias with no evaluations to pro-women bias after positive evaluations), this indicates the discrimination is driven by biased beliefs rather than other mechanisms.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the discrimination literature by developing a theoretical model that links the dynamics of discrimination to its underlying sources, and provides novel empirical evidence using a field experiment that can distinguish between different mechanisms of discrimination through observing how discriminatory behavior changes over time.

author: Alessandra Voena
title: German Jewish Émigrés and US Invention
abstract: <jats:p> Historical accounts suggest that Jewish émigrés from Nazi Germany revolutionized US science. To analyze the émigrés' effects on chemical innovation in the United States, we compare changes in patenting by US inventors in research fields of émigrés with fields of other German chemists. Patenting by US inventors increased by 31 percent in émigré fields. Regressions which instrument for émigré fields with pre-1933 fields of dismissed German chemists confirm a substantial increase in US invention. Inventor-level data indicate that émigrés encouraged innovation by attracting new researchers to their fields, rather than by increasing the productivity of incumbent inventors. (JEL J15, L65, N62, O31, O34) </jats:p>
research_question: What were the effects of Jewish émigrés from Nazi Germany on chemical innovation and patenting in the United States?
answer: Jewish émigrés from Nazi Germany significantly increased US chemical innovation, with patenting by US inventors increasing by 31 percent in émigré fields. The émigrés encouraged innovation primarily by attracting new researchers to their fields rather than by increasing the productivity of existing inventors.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical quantitative analysis to test historical accounts that suggest Jewish émigrés from Nazi Germany revolutionized US science, specifically focusing on chemical innovation through patent data analysis.

author: Alessandra Voena
title: Traditional Beliefs and Learning about Maternal Risk in Zambia
abstract: <jats:p> Maternal mortality remains very high in many parts of the developing world, especially in sub-Saharan Africa. While maternal deaths are observable, it may not be straightforward for individuals to learn about risk factors. This paper utilizes novel data on male and female perceptions of maternal risk in Zambia to document that superstitions about causes of maternal mortality are pervasive and to uncover evidence that such beliefs impede learning about maternal health risk levels and correlates. In our data, people who hold traditional beliefs disregard past birth complications completely in assessing future risk, unlike those who hold modern beliefs. </jats:p>
research_question: How do traditional beliefs and superstitions affect individuals' ability to learn about maternal health risk factors and mortality in developing countries?
answer: Traditional beliefs and superstitions about maternal mortality are pervasive and significantly impede learning about maternal health risks - people who hold traditional beliefs completely disregard past birth complications when assessing future risk, unlike those with modern beliefs.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on maternal mortality in developing countries by focusing on the previously understudied role of belief systems in risk perception and learning, utilizing novel data on both male and female perceptions of maternal risk to show how traditional beliefs create barriers to understanding actual risk factors.

author: Alessandra Voena
title: Bride Price and Female Education
abstract: We document an important consequence of bride price, a payment made by the groom to the bride’s family at marriage. Revisiting Indonesia’s school construction program, we find that among ethnic groups without the custom, it had no effect on girls’ schooling. Among ethnic groups with the custom, it had large positive effects. We show (theoretically and empirically) that this is because a daughter’s education, by increasing the amount of money parents receive at marriage, generates an additional incentive for parents to educate their daughters. We replicate these findings in Zambia, a country that had a similar large-scale school construction program.

author: Alessandra Voena
title: Age of Marriage, Weather Shocks, and the Direction of Marriage Payments
abstract: <jats:p>We study how aggregate economic conditions affect the timing of marriage, and particularly child marriage, in Sub‐Saharan Africa and in India. In both regions, substantial monetary or in‐kind transfers occur with marriage: bride price across Sub‐Saharan Africa and dowry in India. In a simple equilibrium model of the marriage market in which parents choose when their children marry, income shocks affect the age of marriage because marriage payments are a source of consumption smoothing, particularly for a woman's family. As predicted by our model, we show that droughts, which reduce annual crop yields by 10 to 15% and aggregate income by 4 to 5%, have opposite effects on the marriage behavior of a sample of 400,000 women in the two regions: in Sub‐Saharan Africa they increase the annual hazard into child marriage by 3%, while in India droughts reduce such a hazard by 4%. Changes in the age of marriage due to droughts are associated with changes in fertility, especially in Sub‐Saharan Africa, and with declines in observed marriage payments. Our results indicate that the age of marriage responds to short‐term changes in aggregate economic conditions and that marriage payments determine the sign of this response. This suggests that, in order to design successful policies to combat child marriage and improve investments in daughters' human capital, it is crucial to understand the economic role of marriage market institutions.</jats:p>
research_question: How do aggregate economic conditions affect the timing of marriage, particularly child marriage, in regions with different marriage payment systems (bride price vs dowry)?
answer: Weather shocks (droughts) have opposite effects on child marriage depending on the direction of marriage payments: in Sub-Saharan Africa (bride price system), droughts increase child marriage hazard by 3%, while in India (dowry system), droughts reduce child marriage hazard by 4%. Marriage payments serve as consumption smoothing mechanisms, and the direction of payments determines whether families accelerate or delay marriages during economic hardship.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that marriage market institutions, specifically the direction of marriage payments, are crucial for understanding how economic shocks affect marriage timing and that successful policies to combat child marriage must account for the economic role of these institutions.

author: Alessandro Bonatti
title: Consumer Scores and Price Discrimination
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the implications of aggregating consumers’ purchase histories into scores that proxy for unobserved willingness to pay. A long-lived consumer interacts with a sequence of firms. Each firm relies on the consumer’s current score–a linear aggregate of noisy purchase signals—to learn about her preferences and to set prices. If the consumer is strategic, she reduces her demand to manipulate her score, which reduces the average equilibrium price. Firms in turn prefer scores that overweigh past signals relative to applying Bayes’ rule with disaggregated data, as this mitigates the ratchet effect and maximizes the firms’ ability to price discriminate. Consumers with high average willingness to pay benefit from data collection, because the gains from low average prices dominate the losses from price discrimination. Finally, hidden scores—those only observed by the firms—reduce demand sensitivity, increase average prices, and reduce consumer surplus, sometimes below the naive-consumer level.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the implications of firms using consumer scores that aggregate purchase histories to proxy for unobserved willingness to pay in price discrimination?
answer: Strategic consumers reduce demand to manipulate their scores, leading to lower average equilibrium prices; firms prefer scores that overweight past signals to mitigate the ratchet effect and maximize price discrimination ability; consumers with high willingness to pay benefit from data collection due to gains from lower average prices; and hidden scores reduce consumer surplus by decreasing demand sensitivity and increasing average prices.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on price discrimination and consumer data by analyzing the strategic interactions between consumers and firms when purchase histories are aggregated into scores, examining how this differs from standard Bayesian learning with disaggregated data and exploring the welfare implications of different scoring mechanisms.

author: Alessandra Voena
title: Traditional Institutions in Modern Times: Dowries as Pensions When Sons Migrate
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper uses newly collected data on the allocation of dowry to examine its role in resolving intergenerational frictions around migration in India. Migration disrupts traditional elderly support structures, in which sons live near their parents and care for them in old age. We develop a model in which dowry can promote migration by allowing sons to make upfront transfers to their parents and ease constraints on income sharing. To test this hypothesis, we collect two new data sets that measure the distribution of dowry between family members. We document for the first time that net transfers of dowry to a man’s parents are common but far from universal. Consistent with using dowry for income sharing, such transfers occur more often when sons migrate, especially when they work in higher-earning occupations. In nationally representative data, migration rates are higher in areas with stronger historical dowry traditions. Finally, exploiting a large-scale highway construction program, we show that men from areas with stronger historical dowry traditions migrate more when migration costs fall. Our findings provide some clues as to why dowry persists despite its well-documented adverse consequences.</jats:p>
research_question: How does dowry function as a mechanism to resolve intergenerational frictions around migration in India, particularly in facilitating elderly support when sons migrate away from their parents?
answer: Dowry serves as a pension-like mechanism that promotes migration by enabling sons to make upfront transfers to their parents, with net transfers to parents occurring more frequently when sons migrate to higher-earning occupations, and men from areas with stronger historical dowry traditions showing higher migration rates when migration costs fall.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel economic explanation for the persistence of dowry practices by examining their role in facilitating migration and intergenerational income sharing, offering new insights into why dowry continues despite its well-documented adverse consequences, using newly collected data that documents for the first time the distribution patterns of dowry transfers between family members.

author: Alessandro Bonatti
title: Data, Competition, and Digital Platforms
abstract: <jats:p> A monopolist platform uses data to match heterogeneous consumers with multiproduct sellers. The consumers can purchase the products on the platform or search off the platform. The platform sells targeted ads to sellers that recommend their products to consumers and reveals information to consumers about their match values. The revenue-optimal mechanism is a managed advertising campaign that matches products and preferences efficiently. In equilibrium, sellers offer higher qualities at lower unit prices on than off platform. The platform exploits its information advantage to increase its bargaining power vis-à-vis the sellers. Finally, privacy-respecting data-governance rules can lead to welfare gains for consumers. (JEL D11, D42, D44, D82, D83, M37) </jats:p>
research_question: How does a monopolist platform use data to facilitate matching between heterogeneous consumers and multiproduct sellers, and what are the implications for competition, pricing, and welfare?
answer: The revenue-optimal mechanism is a managed advertising campaign that matches products and preferences efficiently, leading to sellers offering higher qualities at lower unit prices on-platform compared to off-platform, while the platform exploits its information advantage to increase bargaining power, and privacy-respecting data governance can improve consumer welfare.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on digital platforms by analyzing how data advantages affect platform competition and market outcomes, specifically examining the role of targeted advertising and information revelation in platform-mediated markets with both on-platform and off-platform competition options.

author: Alessandro Bonatti
title: The Politics of Compromise
abstract: <jats:p> An organization must select among competing projects that differ in their payoff consequences for its members. Each agent chooses a project and exerts effort affecting its completion time. When one or more projects are complete, the agents select which one to adopt. The selection rule for multiple projects that maximizes ex post welfare leads to inefficiently high polarization; rules that favor later proposals improve upon ex post optimal selections. The optimal degree of favoritism increases in the cost of effort and discount rate. This trade-off informs the design of process rules in standard-setting organizations and helps explain their performance. (JEL C78, D23, D71, D72, D83, L15) </jats:p>
research_question: How should organizations design selection rules when choosing among competing projects proposed by members with different preferences, given that the selection rule affects both agents' effort incentives and the degree of polarization in project proposals?
answer: Selection rules that maximize ex post welfare lead to inefficiently high polarization in project proposals; rules that favor later proposals can improve upon ex post optimal selections, with the optimal degree of favoritism increasing with effort costs and discount rates.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on organizational decision-making and standard-setting by analyzing the trade-off between ex post efficiency and ex ante incentives in project selection, providing insights into the design of process rules in standard-setting organizations and explaining their performance.

author: Alessandro Bonatti
title: Collaborating
abstract: <jats:p> This paper examines moral hazard in teams over time. Agents are collectively engaged in a project whose duration and outcome are uncertain, and their individual efforts are unobserved. Free-riding leads not only to a reduction in effort, but also to procrastination. Collaboration among agents dwindles over time, but does not cease as long as the project has not succeeded. In addition, the delay until the project succeeds, if it ever does, increases with the number of agents. We show why deadlines, but not necessarily better monitoring, help to mitigate moral hazard. (JEL D81, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How does moral hazard affect team collaboration and effort over time when agents work collectively on projects with uncertain duration and outcomes?
answer: Free-riding in teams leads to both reduced effort and procrastination, with collaboration declining over time but not ceasing entirely until project success, and project completion delays increasing with team size. Deadlines help mitigate moral hazard more effectively than better monitoring.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the moral hazard literature by examining the temporal dynamics of team collaboration, specifically focusing on how free-riding affects both effort levels and timing decisions in uncertain duration projects, which has not been comprehensively addressed in existing team moral hazard studies.

author: Alessandro Bonatti
title: The Design and Price of Information
abstract: <jats:p> A data buyer faces a decision problem under uncertainty. He can augment his initial private information with supplemental data from a data seller. His willingness to pay for supplemental data is determined by the quality of his initial private information. The data seller optimally offers a menu of statistical experiments. We establish the properties that any revenue-maximizing menu of experiments must satisfy. Every experiment is a non-dispersed stochastic matrix, and every menu contains a fully informative experiment. In the cases of binary states and actions, or binary types, we provide an explicit construction of the optimal menu of experiments. (JEL D42, D81, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How should a data seller optimally design and price a menu of statistical experiments (information products) for a data buyer who already has some private information and faces a decision problem under uncertainty?
