answer: The revenue-maximizing menu of experiments must satisfy specific properties: every experiment must be a non-dispersed stochastic matrix, every menu must contain a fully informative experiment, and for cases with binary states/actions or binary types, explicit optimal menu constructions can be provided.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the information design literature by analyzing the optimal selling mechanism when buyers have heterogeneous private information quality, extending beyond existing work that typically assumes buyers start with no information or homogeneous information endowments.

author: Alessandro Bonatti
title: Dynamic Oligopoly with Incomplete Information
abstract: We consider learning and signalling in a dynamic Cournot oligopoly where firms have private information about their production costs and only observe the market price, which is subject to unobservable demand shocks. An equilibrium is Markov if play depends on the history only through the firms’ beliefs about costs and calendar time. We characterize symmetric linear Markov equilibria as solutions to a boundary value problem. In every such equilibrium, given a long enough horizon, play converges to the static complete information outcome for the realized costs, but each firm only learns its competitors’ average cost. The weights assigned to costs and beliefs under the equilibrium strategies are non-monotone over time. We explain this by decomposing incentives into signalling and learning, and discuss implications for prices, quantities, and welfare.

author: Alessandro Bonatti
title: How Do Digital Advertising Auctions Impact Product Prices?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We present a model of digital advertising with three key features: (1) advertisers can reach consumers on and off a platform, (2) additional data enhances the value of advertiser–consumer matches, and (3) the allocation of advertisements follows an auction-like mechanism. We contrast data-augmented auctions, which leverage the platform’s data advantage to improve match quality, with managed-campaign mechanisms that automate match formation and price-setting. The platform-optimal mechanism is a managed campaign that conditions the on-platform prices for sponsored products on the off-platform prices set by all advertisers. This mechanism yields the efficient on-platform allocation but inefficiently high off-platform product prices. It attains the vertical integration profit for the platform and the advertisers, and it increases off-platform product prices while decreasing consumer surplus, relative to data-augmented auctions.</jats:p>
research_question: How do digital advertising auctions impact product prices?
answer: The platform-optimal mechanism is a managed campaign that conditions on-platform prices for sponsored products on off-platform prices set by all advertisers. This mechanism yields efficient on-platform allocation but inefficiently high off-platform product prices, increases off-platform product prices while decreasing consumer surplus compared to data-augmented auctions.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a novel model of digital advertising that incorporates three key features not simultaneously addressed in existing literature: advertisers' ability to reach consumers both on and off platform, the value enhancement from additional data in advertiser-consumer matches, and auction-like allocation mechanisms. The paper contrasts data-augmented auctions with managed-campaign mechanisms to analyze their differential impacts on pricing and efficiency.

author: Alex Gershkov
title: Optimal Auctions: Non-expected Utility and Constant Risk Aversion
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study auction design for bidders equipped with non-expected utility preferences that exhibit constant risk aversion (CRA). The CRA class is large and includes loss-averse, disappointment-averse, mean-dispersion, and Yaari’s dual preferences as well as coherent and convex risk measures. Any preference in this class displays first-order risk aversion, contrasting the standard expected utility case which displays second-order risk aversion. The optimal mechanism offers “ full-insurance” in the sense that each agent’s utility is independent of other agents’ reports. The seller excludes less types than under risk neutrality and awards the object randomly to intermediate types. Subjecting intermediate types to a risky allocation while compensating them when losing allows the seller to collect larger payments from higher types. Relatively high types are willing to pay more, and their allocation is efficient.</jats:p>
research_question: How should optimal auctions be designed when bidders have non-expected utility preferences that exhibit constant risk aversion (CRA)?
answer: The optimal mechanism offers 'full-insurance' where each agent's utility is independent of other agents' reports, excludes fewer types than under risk neutrality, awards the object randomly to intermediate types, and results in efficient allocation for relatively high types while allowing the seller to collect larger payments.
positioning_statement: This paper extends auction design theory beyond the standard expected utility framework by analyzing a large class of non-expected utility preferences (CRA) that includes loss-averse, disappointment-averse, mean-dispersion, and Yaari's dual preferences, contrasting with standard expected utility which displays second-order risk aversion by focusing on preferences that exhibit first-order risk aversion.

author: Alex Gershkov
title: Gainers and Losers in Priority Services
abstract: We analyze the implications of priority service (PS) on customers’ welfare. In monopoly markets, PS can often decrease consumer surplus and can even yield a loss of welfare to all consumers. This happens despite its efficiency gains, as monopolists levy in revenue more than the total efficiency gains. PS can increase consumer surplus if it expands the consumption coverage—that is, if it introduces new customers who would not purchase the service otherwise. In duopoly markets, the price competition over PS can be severely eroded. Under homogeneity, firms act as if they were monopolists serving half of the market.

author: Alex Gershkov
title: Optimal Voting Rules

author: Alex Gershkov
title: Optimal Insurance: Dual Utility, Random Losses, and Adverse Selection
abstract: <jats:p> We study a generalization of the classical monopoly insurance problem under adverse selection (see Stiglitz 1977) where we allow for a random distribution of losses, possibly correlated with the agent’s risk parameter that is private information. Our model explains patterns of observed customer behavior and predicts insurance contracts most often observed in practice: these consist of menus of several deductible-premium pairs or menus of insurance with coverage limits–premium pairs. A main departure from the classical insurance literature is obtained here by endowing the agents with risk-averse preferences that can be represented by a dual utility functional (Yaari 1987). (JEL D81, D82, D86, D91, G22) </jats:p>
research_question: How does allowing for random distribution of losses (possibly correlated with private risk parameters) and dual utility preferences affect optimal insurance contract design under adverse selection?
answer: The model explains observed customer behavior and predicts commonly observed insurance contracts in practice, specifically menus of deductible-premium pairs or coverage limits-premium pairs, when agents have risk-averse preferences represented by dual utility functionals.
positioning_statement: This paper generalizes the classical monopoly insurance problem under adverse selection (Stiglitz 1977) by incorporating random loss distributions and departing from classical insurance literature through the use of dual utility functional preferences (Yaari 1987) instead of traditional expected utility.

author: Alex Rees-Jones
title: Measuring “Schmeduling”
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>What mental models do individuals use to approximate their tax schedule? Using incentivized forecasts of the U.S. Federal income tax schedule, we estimate the prevalence of the “schmeduling” heuristics for constructing mental representations of nonlinear incentive schemes. We find evidence of widespread reliance on the “ironing” heuristic, which linearizes the tax schedule using one’s average tax rate. In our preferred specification, 43% of the population irons. We find no evidence of reliance on the “spotlighting” heuristic, which linearizes the tax schedule using one’s marginal tax rate. We show that the presence of ironing rationalizes a number of empirical patterns in individuals’ perceptions of tax liability across the income distribution. Furthermore, while our empirical framework accommodates a rich class of other misperceptions, we find that a simple model including only ironers and correct forecasters accurately predicts average underestimation of marginal tax rates. We replicate our finding of prevalent ironing, and a lack of other systematic misperceptions, in a controlled experiment that studies real-stakes decisions across exogenously varied tax schedules. To illustrate the policy relevance of the ironing heuristic, we show that it augments the benefits of progressive taxation in a standard model of earnings choice. We quantify these benefits in a calibrated model of the U.S. tax system.</jats:p>
research_question: What mental models do individuals use to approximate their tax schedule?
answer: 43% of the population relies on the 'ironing' heuristic, which linearizes the tax schedule using one's average tax rate, while there is no evidence of reliance on the 'spotlighting' heuristic that uses marginal tax rates.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces and measures the prevalence of 'schmeduling' heuristics for understanding nonlinear tax schedules, contributing new empirical evidence to the literature on tax perception and behavioral responses to taxation by identifying specific mental models individuals use to simplify complex tax systems.

author: Alex Gershkov
title: Learning about the Future and Dynamic Efficiency
abstract: <jats:p> We study an allocation problem where a set of objects needs to be allocated to agents arriving over time. The basic model is of the private, independent values type. The dynamically efficient allocation is implementable if the distribution of agents' values is known. Whereas lack of knowledge about the distribution is inconsequential in the static case, endogenous informational externalities arise if the designer gradually learns about the distribution by observing present values. These externalities may prevent the implementation of the dynamically efficient allocation. We provide necessary and sufficient conditions for the efficient allocation to be implementable. (JEL D11, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions can a dynamically efficient allocation be implemented when a designer must allocate objects to agents arriving over time while gradually learning about the distribution of agents' values?
answer: The dynamically efficient allocation may not be implementable due to endogenous informational externalities that arise when the designer learns about the value distribution by observing present values, unlike in static cases where lack of distributional knowledge is inconsequential.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the standard private, independent values allocation model by introducing a dynamic learning component, showing that the transition from static to dynamic settings creates new implementation challenges through informational externalities that do not exist in static environments.

author: Alex Gershkov
title: A Theory of Auctions with Endogenous Valuations
abstract: We derive the symmetric, revenue-maximizing allocation of several units among agents who take costly actions that influence their values. The problem is equivalent to a reduced-form model where agents have nonexpected utility. The uniform-price auction and the discriminatory pay-your-bid auction with reserve prices that react to both demand and supply constitute symmetric, optimal mechanisms. We also identify a condition under which the overall optimal mechanism is indeed symmetric and illustrate the structure of the optimal asymmetric mechanism when the condition fails. The main tool in our analysis is an integral inequality based on Fan and Lorentz (1954).

author: Alex Gershkov
title: Dynamic Contracts with Moral Hazard and Adverse Selection

author: Alex Rees-Jones
title: Mistaken Play in the Deferred Acceptance Algorithm: Implications for Positive Assortative Matching
abstract: <jats:p> Recent literature has documented failures of truthful preference reporting in the strategy-proof deferred acceptance algorithm. I consider the implications of these strategic mistakes for a common welfare consideration: the ability of the mechanism to sort the best students to the best schools. I find that these mistakes have the potential to significantly help or significantly hinder sorting. Through this channel, the presence of mistaken play may have widely varying welfare effects. I discuss related considerations in the welfare evaluation of mistaken play in the deferred acceptance algorithm and the implications for “nudges” that correct these mistakes. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the implications of strategic mistakes (non-truthful preference reporting) in the deferred acceptance algorithm for positive assortative matching between students and schools?
answer: Strategic mistakes in the deferred acceptance algorithm can significantly help or hinder the sorting of the best students to the best schools, leading to widely varying welfare effects depending on the nature of these mistakes.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on recent literature that has documented failures of truthful preference reporting in the strategy-proof deferred acceptance algorithm, but extends this work by specifically examining the welfare implications of these mistakes for assortative matching rather than just documenting their existence.

author: Alex Rees-Jones
title: Quantifying Loss-Averse Tax Manipulation

author: Alex Gershkov
title: Optimal Security Design for Risk-Averse Investors
abstract: <jats:p> We use the tools of mechanism design combined with the theory of risk measures to analyze how a cash-constrained owner of an asset with known, stochastic returns raises capital from a population of investors who differ in their risk aversion and budget constraints. The issuer partitions the asset’s cash flow into several asset-backed securities, one for each type of investor. The optimal partition conforms to the commonly observed practice of tranching into senior debt, junior debt, and equity. Tranching arises endogenously due to the differences in risk appetites among agents and in the budget constraints they face. (JEL D81, D82, G12, G41, G51) </jats:p>
research_question: How should a cash-constrained asset owner optimally design securities to raise capital from investors who differ in their risk aversion and budget constraints?
answer: The optimal security design involves partitioning the asset's cash flow into tranched securities (senior debt, junior debt, and equity) with each tranche targeted to different investor types based on their risk appetites and budget constraints.
positioning_statement: This paper combines mechanism design tools with risk measure theory to provide a theoretical foundation for the commonly observed practice of tranching, showing that it arises endogenously from investor heterogeneity rather than being an ad hoc market convention.

author: Alex Rees-Jones
title: Behavioral Economics in Education Market Design: A Forward-Looking Review
abstract: The rational choice framework for modeling matching markets has been tremendously useful in guiding the design of school-assignment systems. Despite this success, a large body of work documents deviations from the predictions of this framework that appear influenced by behavioral economic phenomena. We review these findings and the body of behavioral theories that have been presented as possible explanations. Motivated by this literature, we lay out paths for behavioral economists to be directly useful to education market design.

author: Alex Rees-Jones
title: Attention Variation and Welfare: Theory and Evidence from a Tax Salience Experiment

author: Alex Rees-Jones
title: What Do You Think Would Make You Happier? What Do You Think You Would Choose?
abstract: <jats:p> Would people choose what they think would maximize their subjective well-being (SWB)? We present survey respondents with hypothetical scenarios and elicit both choice and predicted SWB rankings of two alternatives. While choice and predicted SWB rankings usually coincide in our data, we find systematic reversals. We identify factors—such as predicted sense of purpose, control over one's life, family happiness, and social status—that help explain hypothetical choice controlling for predicted SWB. We explore how our findings vary by SWB measure and by scenario. Our results have implications regarding the use of SWB survey questions as a proxy for utility. (JEL D03, I31) </jats:p>
research_question: Would people choose what they think would maximize their subjective well-being (SWB)?
answer: While choice and predicted SWB rankings usually coincide, there are systematic reversals where people make choices that differ from what they predict would maximize their subjective well-being. Factors such as predicted sense of purpose, control over one's life, family happiness, and social status help explain these choice deviations.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on the relationship between subjective well-being and utility by providing empirical evidence that challenges the assumption that SWB survey questions can serve as a direct proxy for utility, showing that people's choices systematically deviate from their predicted well-being maximization.

author: Alex Rees-Jones
title: Can Marginal Rates of Substitution Be Inferred from Happiness Data? Evidence from Residency Choices
abstract: <jats:p> We survey 561 students from US medical schools shortly after they submit choice rankings over residencies to the National Resident Matching Program. We elicit (i) these choice rankings, (ii) anticipated subjective well-being (SWB) rankings, and (iii) expected features of the residencies (such as prestige). We find substantial differences between choice and anticipated-SWB rankings in the implied trade-offs between residency features. In our data, evaluative SWB measures (life satisfaction and Cantril's Ladder) imply trade-offs closer to choice than does affective happiness (even time-integrated), and as close as do multimeasure SWB indices. We discuss implications for using SWB data in applied work. (JEL D12, I31) </jats:p>
research_question: Can marginal rates of substitution be inferred from happiness data, and how do different subjective well-being measures compare to revealed preferences in capturing trade-offs?
answer: There are substantial differences between choice rankings and anticipated subjective well-being rankings in implied trade-offs between residency features. Evaluative SWB measures (life satisfaction and Cantril's Ladder) imply trade-offs closer to actual choices than affective happiness measures, and perform as well as multimeasure SWB indices.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on using subjective well-being data in applied economics by providing empirical evidence on which SWB measures best approximate revealed preferences, with implications for how researchers should use SWB data in applied work.

author: Alex Smolin
title: Persuasion and Welfare
abstract: Information policies such as scores, ratings, and recommendations are increasingly shaping society’s choices in high-stakes domains. We provide a framework to study the welfare implications of information policies on a population of heterogeneous individuals. We define and characterize the Bayes welfare set, consisting of the population’s utility profiles that are feasible under some information policy. The Pareto frontier of this set can be recovered by a series of standard Bayesian persuasion problems. We provide necessary and sufficient conditions under which an information policy exists that Pareto dominates the no-information policy. We illustrate our results with applications to data leakage, price discrimination, and credit ratings.

author: Alexi Savov
title: Craft beer revolution: formation of a new segment in Slovakia
abstract:
<jats:p>Research background: Globalization has significantly affected the brewing sector worldwide during the last three decades. The industry consolidation and many acquisitions led to a reduced number of breweries and consequently to the homogenization of beer. It was an important factor affecting the significant decline in beer consumption in the world. However, over the years, this negative phenomenon also brought a new wave ? the development of craft breweries, and resulted in the formation of a new segment with specific preferences in the market.
Purpose of the article: As a result of the craft beer revolution in the world and the wider offer on the beer market, customer preferences changed, and a new segment was subsequently formatted. In the past, lagers were the preferred choice, but due to the new wider range of beers offered in the market, they are about to lean towards other types of beer. Therefore, the purpose of this paper is to identify a new segment of craft beer consumers based on characteristics such as age, gender, education, income, residence, marital status, work, and leisure activities.
Methods: For data collection, a questionnaire was used as a tool and, therefore, we analyzed the answers of 685 respondents from Slovakia. The questionnaire is evaluated through dependency analysis using nonparametric methods (Kruskal-Wallis Test, Mann-Whitney Test) to identify the differences between groups of customers and to describe the characteristics of a typical consumer of craft beer.
Findings & value added: The craft beer revolution in the world brought a formation of a new segment, which considers the taste and quality more compared to price. Our research has confirmed that this segment consists of highly educated men (26?40 years old), with above average income. However, it is important for beer producers to know this segment more to meet its requirements. Nevertheless, deeper studies of this segment were missing. Therefore, our research was focused on other parameters of the segment and according to our findings, these consumers are from bigger cities, working more mentally, and doing sports in leisure time.</jats:p>
venue: Equilibrium. Quarterly Journal of Economics and Economic Policy
research_question: What are the characteristics of the new segment of craft beer consumers that has emerged from the craft beer revolution?
answer: The new craft beer consumer segment consists of highly educated men aged 26-40 years old with above average income, who live in bigger cities, work in mentally demanding jobs, and engage in sports during leisure time. This segment prioritizes taste and quality over price.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the literature by providing deeper studies of the craft beer consumer segment that were previously missing, building on the understanding that globalization and industry consolidation led to beer homogenization and declining consumption, which subsequently sparked a craft beer revolution and the formation of new market segments with specific preferences.

author: Alexander Willén
title: When Parents Decide: Gender Differences in Competitiveness
abstract: Parents make important choices for their children in many areas of life, yet the empirical literature on this topic is scarce. We study parents’ competitiveness choices for their children by combining two large-scale artifactual field experiments with high-quality longitudinal administrative data. We document three main sets of findings. First, parents choose more competition for their sons than daughters. Second, this gender difference can largely be explained by parents’ beliefs about their children’s competitiveness preferences. Third, parents’ choices predict children’s later-in-life educational outcomes. Taken together, these findings provide novel evidence on the role of parents in shaping children’s long-term outcomes.

author: Alexander Willén
title: Does Your Doctor Matter?

author: Alexei Onatski
title: Spurious Factor Analysis
abstract: <jats:p>This paper draws parallels between the principal components analysis of factorless high‐dimensional nonstationary data and the classical spurious regression. We show that a few of the principal components of such data absorb nearly all the data variation. The corresponding scree plot suggests that the data contain a few factors, which is corroborated by the standard panel information criteria. Furthermore, the Dickey–Fuller tests of the unit root hypothesis applied to the estimated “idiosyncratic terms” often reject, creating an impression that a few factors are responsible for most of the nonstationarity in the data. We warn empirical researchers of these peculiar effects and suggest to always compare the analysis in levels with that in differences.</jats:p>
research_question: What happens when principal components analysis is applied to high-dimensional nonstationary data that contains no true factors?
answer: Principal components analysis of factorless high-dimensional nonstationary data produces spurious results that mimic the presence of true factors - a few principal components absorb nearly all variation, standard tests suggest factor presence, and unit root tests on estimated idiosyncratic terms often reject, creating a false impression of factor structure.
positioning_statement: This paper draws parallels to the classical spurious regression literature by identifying a similar spurious relationship problem in factor analysis, warning empirical researchers about these misleading effects when applying principal components analysis to nonstationary data.

author: Alexei Onatski
title: Alternative Asymptotics for Cointegration Tests in Large VARs
abstract: Johansen's (1988,1991) likelihood ratio test for cointegration rank of a vector autoregression (VAR) depends only on the squared sample canonical correlations between current changes and past levels of a simple transformation of the data. We study the asymptotic behavior of the empirical distribution of those squared canonical correlations when the number of observations and the dimensionality of the VAR diverge to infinity simultaneously and proportionally. We find that the distribution weakly converges to the so‐called Wachter distribution. This finding provides a theoretical explanation for the observed tendency of Johansen's test to find "spurious cointegration."

author: Alex Smolin
title: The Design and Price of Information
abstract: <jats:p> A data buyer faces a decision problem under uncertainty. He can augment his initial private information with supplemental data from a data seller. His willingness to pay for supplemental data is determined by the quality of his initial private information. The data seller optimally offers a menu of statistical experiments. We establish the properties that any revenue-maximizing menu of experiments must satisfy. Every experiment is a non-dispersed stochastic matrix, and every menu contains a fully informative experiment. In the cases of binary states and actions, or binary types, we provide an explicit construction of the optimal menu of experiments. (JEL D42, D81, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How should a data seller optimally design and price a menu of statistical experiments (information products) for a data buyer who already has some private information and faces a decision problem under uncertainty?
answer: The revenue-maximizing menu of experiments must satisfy specific properties: every experiment must be a non-dispersed stochastic matrix, every menu must contain a fully informative experiment, and for cases with binary states/actions or binary types, explicit optimal menu constructions can be provided.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the information design literature by analyzing the optimal selling mechanism when buyers have heterogeneous private information quality, extending beyond existing work that typically assumes buyers start with no information or homogeneous information endowments.

author: Alexi Savov
title: The Deposits Channel of Monetary Policy*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We present a new channel for the transmission of monetary policy, the deposits channel. We show that when the Fed funds rate rises, banks widen the spreads they charge on deposits, and deposits flow out of the banking system. We present a model where this is due to market power in deposit markets. Consistent with the market power mechanism, deposit spreads increase more and deposits flow out more in concentrated markets. This is true even when we control for lending opportunities by only comparing different branches of the same bank. Since deposits are the main source of liquid assets for households, the deposits channel can explain the observed strong relationship between the liquidity premium and the Fed funds rate. Since deposits are also a uniquely stable funding source for banks, the deposits channel impacts bank lending. When the Fed funds rate rises, banks that raise deposits in concentrated markets contract their lending by more than other banks. Our estimates imply that the deposits channel can account for the entire transmission of monetary policy through bank balance sheets.</jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy transmit through the banking system via deposit markets, and what role does bank market power play in this transmission mechanism?
answer: When the Fed funds rate rises, banks with market power widen deposit spreads and experience deposit outflows, which constrains their lending. This 'deposits channel' can account for the entire transmission of monetary policy through bank balance sheets, with effects being stronger in concentrated deposit markets.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a new channel for monetary policy transmission - the deposits channel - that complements existing literature by focusing on how banks' market power in deposit markets affects both household liquidity and bank lending when monetary policy changes.

author: Ali Yurukoglu
title: Trends in Competition in the United States: What Does the Evidence Show?

author: Ali Yurukoglu
title: Quantitative Analysis of Multiparty Tariff Negotiations
abstract: <jats:p>We develop a model of international tariff negotiations to study the design of the institutional rules of the GATT/WTO. A key principle of the GATT/WTO is its most‐favored‐nation (MFN) requirement of nondiscrimination, a principle that has long been criticized for inviting free‐riding behavior. We embed a multisector model of international trade into a model of interconnected bilateral negotiations over tariffs and assess the value of the MFN principle. Using 1990 trade flows and tariff outcomes from the Uruguay Round of GATT/WTO negotiations, we estimate the model and use it to simulate what would happen if the MFN requirement were abandoned and countries negotiated over discriminatory tariffs. We find that if tariff bargaining in the Uruguay Round had proceeded without the MFN requirement, it would have wiped out the world real income gains that MFN tariff bargaining in the Uruguay Round produced and would have instead led to a small reduction in world real income relative to the 1990 status quo.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the value of the most-favored-nation (MFN) principle in international tariff negotiations, and how would abandoning this GATT/WTO requirement affect global welfare outcomes?
answer: The MFN principle is highly valuable for global welfare - abandoning it would have eliminated all world real income gains from the Uruguay Round negotiations and instead led to a small reduction in world real income relative to the 1990 status quo.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the long-standing criticism that the GATT/WTO's most-favored-nation requirement invites free-riding behavior by developing a quantitative model that demonstrates the principle's positive welfare effects, contrary to existing critiques of the MFN system.

author: Ali Yurukoglu
title: Bias in Cable News: Persuasion and Polarization
abstract: <jats:p> We measure the persuasive effects of slanted news and tastes for like-minded news, exploiting cable channel positions as exogenous shifters of cable news viewership. Channel positions do not correlate with demographics that predict viewership and voting, nor with local satellite viewership. We estimate that Fox News increases Republican vote shares by 0.3 points among viewers induced into watching 2.5 additional minutes per week by variation in position. We then estimate a model of voters who select into watching slanted news, and whose ideologies evolve as a result. We use the model to assess the growth over time of Fox News influence, to quantitatively assess media-driven polarization, and to simulate alternative ideological slanting of news channels. (JEL D72, L82) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the persuasive effects of slanted news on voting behavior and how do viewers' tastes for like-minded news contribute to political polarization?
answer: Fox News increases Republican vote shares by 0.3 points among viewers who watch an additional 2.5 minutes per week due to channel position variation, and the model shows that viewers select into watching slanted news while their ideologies evolve as a result, contributing to media-driven polarization.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on media bias and political persuasion by using cable channel positions as an exogenous instrument to identify causal effects of slanted news consumption, developing a structural model that accounts for both selection into viewership and ideological evolution, and providing quantitative assessments of media-driven polarization over time.

author: Ali Yurukoglu
title: Dynamic Natural Monopoly Regulation: Time Inconsistency, Moral Hazard, and Political Environments

author: Ali Yurukoglu
title: The Welfare Effects of Bundling in Multichannel Television Markets
abstract: <jats:p> We measure how the bundling of television channels affects short-run welfare. We estimate an industry model of viewership, demand, pricing, bundling, and input-market bargaining using data on ratings, purchases, prices, bundles, and input costs. We conduct simulations of à la carte policies that require distributors to offer individual channels for sale to consumers. We estimate that negotiated input costs rise by 103.0 percent under à la carte. These higher input costs offset consumer benefits from purchasing individual channels. Mean consumer and total surplus change by an estimated —5.4 to 0.2 percent and —1.7 to 6.0 percent, respectively. (JEL D12, L11, L51, L82, M31) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the bundling of television channels affect short-run welfare in multichannel television markets?
answer: Bundling generally improves welfare compared to à la carte policies because while consumers benefit from purchasing individual channels under à la carte, negotiated input costs rise by 103.0 percent, which offsets these consumer benefits. Mean consumer surplus changes by -5.4 to 0.2 percent and total surplus changes by -1.7 to 6.0 percent under à la carte policies.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical measurement of welfare effects in multichannel television markets through an industry model that incorporates viewership, demand, pricing, bundling, and input-market bargaining, offering quantitative evidence on the welfare implications of bundling versus à la carte policies.

author: Ali Yurukoglu
title: The Evolution of Market Power in the U.S. Automobile Industry
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We construct measures of industry performance and welfare in the U.S. automobile market from 1980 to 2018. We estimate a demand model using product-level data on market shares, prices, and attributes, and consumer-level data on demographics, purchases, and stated second choices. We estimate marginal costs assuming Nash-Bertrand pricing. We relate trends in consumer welfare and markups to trends in market structure and the composition of products. Although real prices rose, we find that markups decreased substantially, and the fraction of total surplus accruing to consumers increased. Consumer welfare increased over time due to improved product quality and improved production technology.</jats:p>
research_question: How has market power evolved in the U.S. automobile industry from 1980 to 2018, and what are the implications for industry performance, consumer welfare, and markups?
answer: Despite rising real prices, markups in the U.S. automobile industry decreased substantially from 1980 to 2018, the fraction of total surplus accruing to consumers increased, and consumer welfare improved due to enhanced product quality and better production technology.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by constructing comprehensive measures of industry performance and welfare in the automobile market using both product-level data (market shares, prices, attributes) and consumer-level data (demographics, purchases, stated preferences), combined with demand modeling and Nash-Bertrand pricing assumptions to estimate marginal costs.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: Rational Inattention to Discrete Choices: A New Foundation for the Multinomial Logit Model
abstract: <jats:p> Individuals must often choose among discrete actions with imperfect information about their payoffs. Before choosing, they have an opportunity to study the payoffs, but doing so is costly. This creates new choices such as the number of and types of questions to ask. We model these situations using the rational inattention approach to information frictions. We find that the decision maker's optimal strategy results in choosing probabilistically in line with a generalized multinomial logit model, which depends both on the actions' true payoffs as well as on prior beliefs. (JEL D11, D81, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How do individuals optimally choose among discrete actions when they have imperfect information about payoffs and face costly information acquisition?
answer: The decision maker's optimal strategy results in probabilistic choices that follow a generalized multinomial logit model, which depends on both the actions' true payoffs and prior beliefs.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a new foundation for the multinomial logit model by applying the rational inattention approach to information frictions in discrete choice situations, extending beyond traditional models to incorporate costly information acquisition decisions.

author: Ali Yurukoglu
title: The Welfare Effects of Vertical Integration in Multichannel Television Markets
abstract: We investigate the welfare effects of vertical integration of regional sports networks (RSNs) with programming distributors in U.S. multichannel television markets. Vertical integration can enhance efficiency by reducing double marginalization and increasing carriage of channels, but can also harm welfare due to foreclosure and incentives to raise rivals' costs. We estimate a structural model of viewership, subscription, distributor pricing, and affiliate fee bargaining using a rich data set on the U.S. cable and satellite television industry (2000–2010). We use these estimates to analyze the impact of simulated vertical mergers and divestitures of RSNs on competition and welfare, and examine the efficacy of regulatory policies introduced by the U.S. Federal Communications Commission to address competition concerns in this industry.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: The Role of Automatic Stabilizers in the U.S. Business Cycle
abstract: Most countries have automatic rules in their tax‐and‐transfer systems that are partly intended to stabilize economic fluctuations. This paper measures their effect on the dynamics of the business cycle. We put forward a model that merges the standard incomplete‐markets model of consumption and inequality with the new Keynesian model of nominal rigidities and business cycles, and that includes most of the main potential stabilizers in the U.S. data and the theoretical channels by which they may work. We find that the conventional argument that stabilizing disposable income will stabilize aggregate demand plays a negligible role in the dynamics of the business cycle, whereas tax‐and‐transfer programs that affect inequality and social insurance can have a larger effect on aggregate volatility. However, as currently designed, the set of stabilizers in place in the United States has had little effect on the volatility of aggregate output fluctuations or on their welfare costs despite stabilizing aggregate consumption. The stabilizers have a more important role when monetary policy is constrained by the zero lower bound, and they affect welfare significantly through the provision of social insurance.

author: Ali Yurukoglu
title: Pricing Power in Advertising Markets: Theory and Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> Existing theories of media competition imply that advertisers will pay a lower price in equilibrium to reach consumers who multi-home across competing outlets. We generalize and extend this theoretical result and test it using data from television and social media advertising. We find that the model is a good match, qualitatively and quantitatively, to variation in advertising prices across demographic groups, outlets, platforms, and over time. We use the model to quantify the effects of competition within and across platforms. (JEL G34, K21, L13, L82, M37) </jats:p>
research_question: How does consumer multi-homing behavior across competing media outlets affect the pricing power of advertising platforms and the prices advertisers pay to reach those consumers?
answer: Advertisers pay lower prices in equilibrium to reach consumers who multi-home across competing outlets, and this theoretical prediction matches well with empirical variation in advertising prices across demographic groups, outlets, platforms, and over time in both television and social media markets.
positioning_statement: This paper generalizes and extends existing theories of media competition that predict lower advertising prices for multi-homing consumers, providing both theoretical advancement and empirical validation using comprehensive data from television and social media advertising markets.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: Simple Market Equilibria with Rationally Inattentive Consumers
abstract: <jats:p> We study a market with rationally inattentive consumers who are unsure of the terms of the offers made by firms, but can acquire information about the terms at a cost. In a symmetric equilibrium, the price set by firms is continuously increasing in the cost of information for consumers and decreasing in the number of firms operating. In addition, favorable a priori information about a firm leads it to set a higher price, and a new entrant can increase demand for incumbents. When consumers have heterogeneous costs of information, firms selling low-quality products may choose to set the highest prices. </jats:p>
research_question: How do rationally inattentive consumers who face costs of acquiring information about firm offers affect market equilibrium pricing and firm behavior?
answer: In symmetric equilibrium, firms set prices that increase with consumers' information costs and decrease with the number of competing firms. Additionally, firms with favorable prior information set higher prices, new entrants can increase demand for incumbents, and with heterogeneous information costs, low-quality firms may set the highest prices.
positioning_statement: This paper extends traditional market equilibrium models by incorporating rational inattention theory, where consumers face costly information acquisition about firm offers, rather than assuming perfect or costless information as in standard models.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: Optimal Automatic Stabilizers
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Should the generosity of unemployment benefits and the progressivity of income taxes depend on the presence of business cycles? This paper proposes a tractable model where there is a role for social insurance against uninsurable shocks to income and unemployment, as well as business cycles that are inefficient due to the presence of matching frictions and nominal rigidities. We derive an augmented Baily–Chetty formula showing that the optimal generosity of the social insurance system depends on a macroeconomic stabilization term. This term pushes for an increase in generosity when the level of economic activity is more responsive to social programmes in recessions than in booms. A calibration to the US economy shows that taking concerns for macroeconomic stabilization into account substantially raises the optimal unemployment insurance replacement rate but has a negligible impact on the optimal progressivity of the income tax. More generally, the role of social insurance programmes as automatic stabilizers affects their optimal design.</jats:p>
research_question: Should the generosity of unemployment benefits and the progressivity of income taxes depend on the presence of business cycles?
answer: Yes, the optimal design of social insurance programs should account for their role as automatic stabilizers. Taking macroeconomic stabilization into account substantially raises the optimal unemployment insurance replacement rate, while having negligible impact on optimal income tax progressivity.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the existing Baily-Chetty formula for optimal social insurance by adding a macroeconomic stabilization term, bridging the literature on social insurance design with macroeconomic stabilization policy in a tractable model that incorporates both uninsurable individual shocks and inefficient business cycles due to matching frictions and nominal rigidities.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: What Can Time‐Series Regressions Tell Us About Policy Counterfactuals?
abstract: <jats:p>We show that, in a general family of linearized structural macroeconomic models, knowledge of the empirically estimable causal effects of contemporaneous and news shocks to the prevailing policy rule is sufficient to construct counterfactuals under alternative policy rules. If the researcher is willing to postulate a loss function, our results furthermore allow her to recover an optimal policy rule for that loss. Under our assumptions, the derived counterfactuals and optimal policies are robust to the Lucas critique. We then discuss strategies for applying these insights when only a limited amount of empirical causal evidence on policy shock transmission is available.</jats:p>
research_question: Can time-series regressions of policy shocks be used to construct valid policy counterfactuals that are robust to the Lucas critique?
answer: Yes, knowledge of empirically estimable causal effects of contemporaneous and news shocks to the prevailing policy rule is sufficient to construct counterfactuals under alternative policy rules, and these counterfactuals are robust to the Lucas critique under the paper's assumptions.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental limitation in macroeconomic policy analysis by showing how to use empirical evidence from policy shock transmission to construct policy counterfactuals that overcome the Lucas critique, providing a bridge between reduced-form empirical work and structural policy analysis.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: Lumpy Durable Consumption Demand and the Limited Ammunition of Monetary Policy
abstract:
<jats:p>The prevailing neo‐Wicksellian view holds that the central bank's objective is to track the natural rate of interest (
            <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>
            <jats:sup>*</jats:sup>), which itself is largely exogenous to monetary policy. We challenge this view using a fixed‐cost model of durable consumption demand, in which expansionary monetary policy prompts households to accelerate purchases of durable goods. This yields an intertemporal trade‐off in aggregate demand as encouraging households to increase durable holdings today leaves fewer households acquiring durables going forward. Interest rates must be kept low to support demand going forward, so accommodative monetary policy today reduces 
            <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>
            <jats:sup>*</jats:sup> in the future. We show that this mechanism is quantitatively important in explaining the persistently low level of real interest rates and 
            <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>
            <jats:sup>*</jats:sup> after the Great Recession.
          </jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy affect the natural rate of interest through durable consumption demand, and can this explain persistently low real interest rates after the Great Recession?
answer: Expansionary monetary policy creates an intertemporal trade-off in aggregate demand by prompting households to accelerate durable goods purchases, which reduces future demand and requires persistently low interest rates, thereby endogenously reducing the natural rate of interest in future periods. This mechanism quantitatively explains the persistently low real interest rates and natural rate after the Great Recession.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the prevailing neo-Wicksellian view that the central bank's objective is to track an exogenous natural rate of interest, instead arguing that monetary policy endogenously affects the natural rate through its impact on durable consumption demand with fixed costs.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: Forward Guidance and Durable Goods Demand
abstract: <jats:p> We study the monetary transmission mechanism in a quantitative fixed-cost model of durable goods demand. We show that aggregate demand is substantially more sensitive to contemporaneous interest rates than to forward guidance about future interest rates. Reducing the real interest rate one year from now increases output by only 41  percent as much as reducing the real interest rate today. The power of forward guidance declines further at longer horizons. We show analytically and quantitatively that this result is driven by the sensitivity of the extensive margin of durable adjustment to the contemporaneous user cost. (JEL D52, E21, E43, E52) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the effectiveness of forward guidance about future interest rates compare to contemporaneous interest rate changes in influencing durable goods demand and aggregate output?
answer: Forward guidance is substantially less effective than contemporaneous interest rate changes - reducing the real interest rate one year from now increases output by only 41 percent as much as reducing the real interest rate today, with effectiveness declining further at longer horizons due to the extensive margin of durable adjustment being sensitive to contemporaneous user cost.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the monetary transmission mechanism literature by developing a quantitative fixed-cost model of durable goods demand to analyze the relative effectiveness of forward guidance versus current interest rate policy, providing both analytical and quantitative evidence for the limited power of forward guidance through the lens of durable goods adjustment decisions.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: The Power of Forward Guidance Revisited
abstract: <jats:p> In recent years, central banks have increasingly turned to forward guidance as a central tool of monetary policy. Standard monetary models imply that far future forward guidance has huge effects on current outcomes, and these effects grow with the horizon of the forward guidance. We present a model in which the power of forward guidance is highly sensitive to the assumption of complete markets. When agents face uninsurable income risk and borrowing constraints, a precautionary savings effect tempers their responses to changes in future interest rates. As a consequence, forward guidance has substantially less power to stimulate the economy. (JEL E21, E40, E50) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the power of forward guidance as a monetary policy tool depend on market completeness assumptions, particularly when agents face uninsurable income risk and borrowing constraints?
answer: Forward guidance has substantially less power to stimulate the economy when agents face uninsurable income risk and borrowing constraints, as a precautionary savings effect tempers their responses to changes in future interest rates, contrary to standard monetary models that assume complete markets.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges standard monetary models that assume complete markets and predict that forward guidance has huge effects that grow with the guidance horizon, by showing that these effects are highly sensitive to market completeness assumptions and are substantially reduced under more realistic incomplete market conditions.

author: Alp Simsek
title: Speculation and Risk Sharing with New Financial Assets*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>I investigate the effect of financial innovation on portfolio risks when traders have belief disagreements. I decompose traders’ average portfolio risks into two components: the uninsurable variance, defined as portfolio risks that would obtain without belief disagreements, and the speculative variance, defined as portfolio risks that result from speculation. My main result shows that financial innovation always increases the speculative variance through two distinct channels: by generating new bets and by amplifying traders’ existing bets. When disagreements are large, these effects are sufficiently strong that financial innovation increases average portfolio risks, decreases average portfolio comovements, and generates greater speculative trading volume relative to risk-sharing volume. Moreover, a profit-seeking market maker endogenously introduces speculative assets that increase average portfolio risks.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of financial innovation on portfolio risks when traders have belief disagreements?
answer: Financial innovation always increases speculative variance through generating new bets and amplifying existing bets, and when disagreements are large, it increases average portfolio risks, decreases portfolio comovements, and generates greater speculative trading volume relative to risk-sharing volume.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by decomposing portfolio risks into uninsurable variance (risks without belief disagreements) and speculative variance (risks from speculation), providing a novel framework to analyze how financial innovation affects risk through speculation rather than just risk-sharing mechanisms.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Equivalence Between Out-of-Sample Forecast Comparisons and Wald Statistics
abstract: We demonstrate the asymptotic equivalence between commonly used test statistics for out‐of‐sample forecasting performance and conventional Wald statistics. This equivalence greatly simplifies the computational burden of calculating recursive out‐of‐sample test statistics and their critical values. For the case with nested models, we show that the limit distribution, which has previously been expressed through stochastic integrals, has a simple representation in terms of *X<sup>2</sup>*‐distributed random variables and we derive its density. We also generalize the limit theory to cover local alternatives and characterize the power properties of the test.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Estimation and Testing of Forecast Rationality under Flexible Loss

author: Alp Simsek
title: Liquidity Trap and Excessive Leverage
abstract: <jats:p> We investigate the role of macroprudential policies in mitigating liquidity traps. When constrained households engage in deleveraging, the interest rate needs to fall to induce unconstrained households to pick up the decline in aggregate demand. If the fall in the interest rate is limited by the zero lower bound, aggregate demand is insufficient and the economy enters a liquidity trap. In this environment, households' ex ante leverage and insurance decisions are associated with aggregate demand externalities. Welfare can be improved with macroprudential policies targeted toward reducing leverage. Interest rate policy is inferior to macroprudential policies in dealing with excessive leverage. (JEL D14, E23, E32, E43, E52, E61, E62) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of macroprudential policies in mitigating liquidity traps?
answer: Macroprudential policies targeted toward reducing leverage can improve welfare and are superior to interest rate policy in dealing with excessive leverage that leads to liquidity traps.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining how households' ex ante leverage and insurance decisions create aggregate demand externalities in liquidity trap environments, demonstrating that macroprudential policies are more effective than traditional interest rate policy for addressing excessive leverage.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Forecasting Time Series Subject to Multiple Structural Breaks
abstract: This paper provides a novel approach to forecasting time series subject to discrete structural breaks. We propose a Bayesian estimation and prediction procedure that allows for the possibility of new breaks over the forecast horizon, taking account of the size and duration of past breaks (if any) by means of a hierarchical hidden Markov chain model. Predictions are formed by integrating over the hyper parameters from the meta distributions that characterize the stochastic break point process. In an application to US Treasury bill rates, we find that the method leads to better out-of-sample forecasts than alternative methods that ignore breaks, particularly at long horizons.

author: Alon Brav
title: Asset Pricing with Heterogeneous Consumers and Limited Participation: Empirical Evidence

author: Alp Simsek
title: Financial Innovation and Portfolio Risks
abstract: <jats:p> I illustrate the effect of financial innovation on portfolio risks by using an example with risk-sharing needs and belief disagreements. I consider two types of innovation: product innovation, formalized as an expansion of new financial assets; and process innovation, formalized as a reduction in transaction costs. When belief disagreements are large, both types of innovation increase portfolio risks. Moreover, endogenous financial innovation is directed towards speculative assets that increase portfolio risks. </jats:p>
research_question: How does financial innovation affect portfolio risks?
answer: When belief disagreements are large, both product innovation (expansion of new financial assets) and process innovation (reduction in transaction costs) increase portfolio risks, with endogenous financial innovation being directed towards speculative assets that further increase portfolio risks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by illustrating the effect of financial innovation on portfolio risks through a framework that incorporates both risk-sharing needs and belief disagreements, examining two distinct types of innovation (product and process) and their impact on portfolio risk outcomes.

author: Allan Timmermann
title: Runs on Money Market Mutual Funds
abstract: <jats:p> We study daily money market mutual fund flows at the individual share class level during September 2008. This fine granularity of data allows new insights into investor and portfolio holding characteristics conducive to run risk in cash-like asset pools. We find that cross-sectional flow data observed during the week of the Lehman failure are consistent with key implications of a simple model of coordination with incomplete information and strategic complementarities. Similar conclusions follow from daily models fitted to capture dynamic interactions between investors with differing levels of sophistication within the same money fund, holding constant the underlying portfolio. (JEL D14, G11, G23) </jats:p>
research_question: What investor and portfolio holding characteristics are conducive to run risk in money market mutual funds, and how do these characteristics manifest during periods of financial stress?
answer: Cross-sectional flow data during the Lehman failure week are consistent with a coordination model featuring incomplete information and strategic complementarities, with dynamic interactions between investors of differing sophistication levels within the same fund driving run behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new insights to the literature by using fine granularity daily data at the individual share class level, which allows for analysis of investor coordination dynamics and strategic complementarities in money market fund runs that previous studies could not capture.

author: Alisdair McKay
title: Housing Wealth Effects: The Long View
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We provide new time-varying estimates of the housing wealth effect back to the 1980s. We use three identification strategies: ordinary least squares with a rich set of controls, the Saiz housing supply elasticity instrument, and a new instrument that exploits systematic differences in city-level exposure to regional house price cycles. All three identification strategies indicate that housing wealth elasticities were if anything slightly smaller in the 2000s than in earlier time periods. This implies that the important role housing played in the boom and bust of the 2000s was due to larger price movements rather than an increase in the sensitivity of consumption to house prices. Full-sample estimates based on our new instrument are smaller than recent estimates, though they remain economically important. We find no significant evidence of a boom–bust asymmetry in the housing wealth elasticity. We show that these empirical results are consistent with the behaviour of the housing wealth elasticity in a standard life-cycle model with borrowing constraints, uninsurable income risk, illiquid housing, and long-term mortgages. In our model, the housing wealth elasticity is relatively insensitive to changes in the distribution of loan-to-value (LTV) for two reasons: first, low-leverage homeowners account for a substantial and stable part of the aggregate housing wealth elasticity; second, a rightward shift in the LTV distribution increases not only the number of highly sensitive constrained agents but also the number of underwater agents whose consumption is insensitive to house prices.</jats:p>
research_question: How has the housing wealth effect on consumption changed over time, particularly comparing the 2000s housing boom-bust period to earlier decades?
answer: Housing wealth elasticities were actually slightly smaller in the 2000s than in earlier periods, meaning housing's important role in the 2000s boom-bust was due to larger price movements rather than increased sensitivity of consumption to house prices. There is no significant boom-bust asymmetry in housing wealth elasticity.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new time-varying estimates of housing wealth effects using multiple identification strategies and extends the analysis back to the 1980s, offering a longer historical perspective than recent estimates. The authors also contribute a new theoretical framework using a life-cycle model with borrowing constraints that explains why housing wealth elasticity remains relatively stable despite changes in loan-to-value distributions.

author: Alp Simsek
title: A Model of Fickle Capital Flows and Retrenchment
abstract: We develop a model of gross capital flows and analyze their role in global financial stability. In our model, consistent with the data, when a country experiences asset fire sales, foreign investments exit (fickleness), while domestic investments abroad return home (retrenchment). When countries have symmetric expected returns and financial development, the benefits of retrenchment dominate the costs of fickleness and gross flows increase fire-sale prices. Fickleness, however, creates a coordination problem since it encourages local policy makers to restrict capital inflows. When countries are asymmetric, capital flows are driven by additional mechanisms—reach for safety and reach for yield—that can destabilize the receiving country.

author: Alp Simsek
title: Monetary Policy with Opinionated Markets
abstract: <jats:p> We build a model in which the Fed and the market disagree about future aggregate demand. The market anticipates monetary policy “mistakes,” which affect current demand and induce the Fed to partially accommodate the market’s view. The Fed expects to implement its view gradually. Announcements that reveal an unexpected change in the Fed’s belief provide a microfoundation for monetary policy shocks. Tantrum shocks arise when the market misinterprets the Fed’s belief and overreacts to its announcement. Uncertainty about tantrums motivates further gradualism and communication. Finally, disagreements affect the market’s expected inflation and induce a policy trade-off similar to “ cost-push” shocks. (JEL D83, E12, E31, E43, E44, E52, E58) </jats:p>
research_question: How do disagreements between the Federal Reserve and financial markets about future aggregate demand affect monetary policy implementation and market outcomes?
answer: When the Fed and markets disagree about future demand, markets anticipate policy 'mistakes' which affects current demand and forces the Fed to partially accommodate market views, leading to gradual policy implementation, communication strategies to avoid tantrum shocks, and inflation expectations that create cost-push-like trade-offs.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a microfoundation for monetary policy shocks through disagreements between policymakers and markets, extending existing literature by modeling how market anticipation of policy mistakes creates feedback effects that influence Fed decision-making and introduces tantrum shocks as a distinct phenomenon arising from market misinterpretation of Fed communications.

author: Alp Simsek
title: A Risk-Centric Model of Demand Recessions and Speculation*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We provide a continuous-time “risk-centric” representation of the New Keynesian model, which we use to analyze the interactions between asset prices, financial speculation, and macroeconomic outcomes when output is determined by aggregate demand. In principle, interest rate policy is highly effective in dealing with shocks to asset valuations. However, in practice monetary policy faces a wide range of constraints. If these constraints are severe, a decline in risky asset valuations generates a demand recession. This reduces earnings and generates a negative feedback loop between asset prices and aggregate demand. In the recession phase, average beliefs matter because they not only affect asset valuations but also determine the strength of the amplification mechanism. In the ex ante boom phase, belief disagreements (or heterogeneous asset valuations) matter because they induce investors to speculate. This speculation exacerbates the crash by reducing high-valuation investors’ wealth when the economy transitions to recession, which depresses (wealth-weighted) average beliefs. Macroprudential policy that restricts speculation in the boom can Pareto improve welfare by increasing asset prices and aggregate demand in the recession.</jats:p>
research_question: How do asset prices, financial speculation, and macroeconomic outcomes interact when output is determined by aggregate demand, particularly in the context of demand recessions?
answer: A decline in risky asset valuations can generate demand recessions through negative feedback loops between asset prices and aggregate demand when monetary policy is constrained. Average beliefs matter in recessions by affecting both asset valuations and amplification mechanisms, while belief disagreements in boom phases drive speculation that exacerbates crashes by reducing high-valuation investors' wealth. Macroprudential policy restricting speculation during booms can improve welfare by supporting asset prices and aggregate demand during recessions.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a continuous-time 'risk-centric' representation of the New Keynesian model, offering a new framework to analyze the interactions between financial markets and macroeconomic outcomes that emphasizes the role of risk, speculation, and belief heterogeneity in demand-driven recessions.

author: Alp Simsek
title: A Note on Temporary Supply Shocks with Aggregate Demand Inertia
abstract: <jats:p> We study optimal monetary policy during temporary supply contractions when aggregate demand has inertia and the central bank is concerned about future constraints on expansionary policy. In this environment, it is optimal to run the economy hot until supply recovers. However, the policy does not remain loose throughout the low-supply phase. Overall, when the initial aggregate demand is low, the goal is to frontload the rate cuts to raise demand in anticipation of the recovery of supply. If inflation also has inertia, the central bank still overheats the economy during the low-supply phase but gradually cools it down over time. (JEL E12, E21, E23, E31, E43, E52) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal monetary policy during temporary supply contractions when aggregate demand has inertia and the central bank is concerned about future constraints on expansionary policy?
answer: It is optimal to run the economy hot until supply recovers, but policy should not remain loose throughout the entire low-supply phase. When initial aggregate demand is low, central banks should frontload rate cuts to raise demand in anticipation of supply recovery. If inflation also has inertia, the central bank should still overheat the economy during the low-supply phase but gradually cool it down over time.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on optimal monetary policy during supply shocks by incorporating the novel consideration of aggregate demand inertia and central bank concerns about future constraints on expansionary policy, providing new insights into the timing and sequencing of monetary policy responses.

author: Amanda Friedenberg
title: Bargaining Under Strategic Uncertainty: The Role of Second‐Order Optimism
abstract:
<jats:p>This paper shows that bargainers may reach delayed agreements even in environments where there is no uncertainty about payoffs or feasible actions. Under such conditions, delay may arise when bargainers face direct forms of strategic uncertainty—that is, uncertainty about the opponent's play. The paper restricts the nature of this uncertainty in two important ways. First, it assumes 
            <jats:italic>on‐path strategic certainty</jats:italic>: Bargainers face uncertainty only after surprise moves. Second, it assumes Battigalli and Siniscalchi's (2002) 
            <jats:italic>rationality and common strong belief of rationality</jats:italic> (RCSBR)—a requirement that bargainers are “strategically sophisticated.” The main result characterizes the set of outcomes consistent with on‐path strategic certainty and RCSBR. It shows that these assumptions allow for delayed agreement, despite the fact that the bargaining environment is one of complete information. The source of delay is 
            <jats:italic>second‐order optimism</jats:italic>: Bargainers do not put forward “good” offers early in the negotiation process because they fear that doing so will cause the other party to become more optimistic about her future prospects.
          </jats:p>
research_question: Can bargainers reach delayed agreements in complete information environments where there is no uncertainty about payoffs or feasible actions?
answer: Yes, delayed agreements can occur in complete information bargaining environments due to 'second-order optimism' - bargainers avoid making good offers early because they fear this will make their opponent more optimistic about future prospects, leading to strategic delay even without payoff uncertainty.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing bargaining theory by showing that delay can arise from direct strategic uncertainty (uncertainty about opponent's play) rather than traditional sources like payoff uncertainty, while building on Battigalli and Siniscalchi's (2002) framework of rationality and common strong belief of rationality (RCSBR) and introducing the novel concept of 'on-path strategic certainty.'

author: Alp Simsek
title: Stock Market Wealth and the Real Economy: A Local Labor Market Approach
abstract: <jats:p>We provide evidence of the stock market consumption wealth effect by using a local labor market analysis. An increase in local stock wealth driven by aggregate stock prices increases local employment and payroll in nontradable industries and in total, with no effect on employment in tradable industries. In a model of geographic heterogeneity in stock wealth, these responses imply an MPC of 3.2 cents per year and that a 20 percent increase in stock valuations, unless countered by monetary policy, increases the aggregate labor bill by at least 1.7 percent and aggregate hours by at least 0.7 percent two years after the shock. (JEL E21, E24, E52, G12, G51, R22, R23 )</jats:p>
research_question: What is the magnitude and mechanism of the stock market wealth effect on real economic activity, particularly employment and consumption?
answer: The stock market wealth effect operates through local consumption demand, with an MPC of 3.2 cents per year. A 20% increase in stock valuations increases the aggregate labor bill by at least 1.7% and aggregate hours by at least 0.7% two years after the shock, with effects concentrated in nontradable industries that serve local demand.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the wealth effect literature by using a novel local labor market approach to identify causal effects, exploiting geographic heterogeneity in stock wealth exposure to overcome identification challenges that have limited previous aggregate-level studies.

author: Alp Simsek
title: A Welfare Criterion For Models With Distorted Beliefs*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article proposes a welfare criterion for economies in which agents have heterogeneously distorted beliefs. Instead of taking a stand on whose belief is correct, our criterion asserts that an allocation is belief-neutral efficient (inefficient) if it is efficient (inefficient) under any convex combination of agents’ beliefs. Although this criterion gives an incomplete ranking of social allocations, it can identify positive- and negative-sum speculation driven by conflicting beliefs in a broad range of economic environments.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we evaluate welfare in economies where agents have heterogeneously distorted beliefs without taking a stand on whose belief is correct?
answer: The paper proposes a 'belief-neutral efficient' welfare criterion that deems an allocation efficient (inefficient) if it remains so under any convex combination of agents' beliefs, which can identify positive- and negative-sum speculation driven by conflicting beliefs across various economic environments.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the challenge of welfare evaluation in models with distorted beliefs by proposing a belief-neutral approach that avoids the need to determine which agents have correct beliefs, offering a new framework for assessing allocations when agents hold conflicting views.

author: Amanda Friedenberg
title: Admissibility in Games
