title: Admissibility in Games

author: Amanda Pallais
title: Labor Supply and the Value of Non-Work Time: Experimental Estimates from the Field
abstract: <jats:p> We estimate the marginal value of non-work time (MVT) using a field experiment. We offered job applicants randomized wage-hour bundles. Choices over these bundles yield estimates of the MVT as a function of hours, tracing out a labor supply relationship. The substitution effect is positive. Individual labor supply is highly elastic at low hours and more inelastic at higher hours. For unemployed applicants, our preferred estimate of the average opportunity cost of a full-time job due to lost leisure and household production is 60 percent of after-tax marginal product, and 72 percent when including fixed costs of employment and child-care costs. (JEL C93, J22, J24, J31, J64, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the marginal value of non-work time and how does it vary with hours worked?
answer: The marginal value of non-work time varies significantly with hours worked - individual labor supply is highly elastic at low hours and more inelastic at higher hours. For unemployed applicants, the average opportunity cost of a full-time job due to lost leisure and household production is 60 percent of after-tax marginal product (72 percent when including fixed costs of employment and child-care costs).
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the labor supply literature by using a novel field experimental approach to directly estimate the marginal value of non-work time, offering randomized wage-hour bundles to job applicants to trace out labor supply relationships and overcome limitations of previous observational studies.

author: Amanda Pallais
title: Inefficient Hiring in Entry-Level Labor Markets
abstract: <jats:p> Hiring inexperienced workers generates information about their abilities. If this information is public, workers obtain its benefits. If workers cannot compensate firms for hiring them, firms will hire too few inexperienced workers. I determine the effects of hiring workers and revealing more information about their abilities through a field experiment in an online marketplace. I hired 952 randomly-selected workers, giving them either detailed or coarse public evaluations. Both hiring workers and providing more detailed evaluations substantially improved workers' subsequent employment outcomes. Under plausible assumptions, the experiment's market-level benefits exceeded its cost, suggesting that some experimental workers had been inefficiently unemployed. (JEL J23, J24, M51) </jats:p>
research_question: Do firms hire too few inexperienced workers in entry-level labor markets due to information externalities, and what are the effects of hiring workers and revealing information about their abilities?
answer: Yes, firms hire too few inexperienced workers. Both hiring workers and providing more detailed public evaluations substantially improved workers' subsequent employment outcomes, with market-level benefits exceeding costs, suggesting some workers had been inefficiently unemployed.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the theoretical prediction that when hiring generates public information about worker abilities that firms cannot be compensated for, it leads to inefficient under-hiring of inexperienced workers, using a novel field experimental approach to empirically test this market failure.

author: Amanda Pallais
title: Valuing Alternative Work Arrangements
abstract: <jats:p> We employ a discrete choice experiment in the employment process for a national call center to estimate the willingness to pay distribution for alternative work arrangements relative to traditional office positions. Most workers are not willing to pay for scheduling flexibility, though a tail of workers with high valuations allows for sizable compensating differentials. The average worker is willing to give up 20 percent of wages to avoid a schedule set by an employer on short notice, and 8 percent for the option to work from home. We also document that many job-seekers are inattentive, and we account for this in estimation. (JEL J22, J31, J80, L84) </jats:p>
research_question: What is workers' willingness to pay for alternative work arrangements (scheduling flexibility and work-from-home options) relative to traditional office positions?
answer: Most workers are not willing to pay for scheduling flexibility, though some workers have high valuations that allow for sizable compensating differentials. The average worker is willing to give up 20% of wages to avoid employer-set short-notice scheduling and 8% of wages for work-from-home options.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using a discrete choice experiment in an actual employment process to estimate the willingness to pay distribution for alternative work arrangements, while also accounting for job-seekers' inattentiveness in the estimation process.

author: Amanda Pallais
title: Why the Referential Treatment? Evidence from Field Experiments on Referrals

author: Amanda Pallais
title: Discrimination as a Self-Fulfilling Prophecy: Evidence from French Grocery Stores*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Examining the performance of cashiers in a French grocery store chain, we find that manager bias negatively affects minority job performance. In the stores studied, cashiers work with different managers on different days and their schedules are determined quasi-randomly. When minority cashiers, but not majority cashiers, are scheduled to work with managers who are biased (as determined by an implicit association test), they are absent more often, spend less time at work, scan items more slowly, and take more time between customers. This appears to be because biased managers interact less with minorities, leading minorities to exert less effort. Manager bias has consequences for the average performance of minority workers: while on average minority and majority workers perform equivalently, on days where managers are unbiased, minorities perform significantly better than do majority workers. The findings are consistent with statistical discrimination in hiring whereby because minorities underperform when assigned to biased managers, the firm sets a higher hiring standard for minorities to get similar average performance from minority and nonminority workers.</jats:p>
research_question: How does manager bias affect the job performance of minority workers, and what are the mechanisms and consequences of this relationship?
answer: Manager bias negatively affects minority job performance through reduced interaction, leading to lower effort from minority workers. This creates a self-fulfilling prophecy where minorities underperform when working with biased managers, resulting in firms setting higher hiring standards for minorities to achieve equivalent average performance.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the discrimination literature by providing direct evidence of how bias creates self-fulfilling prophecies in workplace performance, linking manager bias to statistical discrimination in hiring practices, and demonstrating that minority underperformance is conditional on manager bias rather than inherent ability differences.

author: Amanda Pallais
title: ‘Acting Wife’: Marriage Market Incentives and Labor Market Investments
abstract: <jats:p> Do single women avoid career-enhancing actions because these actions signal undesirable traits, like ambition, to the marriage market? While married and unmarried female MBA students perform similarly when their performance is unobserved by classmates (on exams and problem sets), unmarried women have lower participation grades. In a field experiment, single female students reported lower desired salaries and willingness to travel and work long hours on a real-stakes placement questionnaire when they expected their classmates to see their preferences. Other groups' responses were unaffected by peer observability. A second experiment indicates the effects are driven by observability by single male peers. (JEL C93, D82, J12, J16, J31) </jats:p>
research_question: Do single women avoid career-enhancing actions because these actions signal undesirable traits, like ambition, to the marriage market?
answer: Yes, single women do avoid career-enhancing actions when observed by potential marriage market partners. Single female MBA students have lower participation grades when performance is observable, report lower desired salaries and reduced willingness to travel/work long hours when they expect classmates to see their preferences, with effects specifically driven by observability by single male peers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel empirical evidence to the literature on marriage market effects on labor market behavior by using field experiments and observational data from MBA students to demonstrate that single women strategically underinvest in career-enhancing activities when these investments are observable to potential romantic partners, thereby providing direct evidence for the 'acting wife' phenomenon.

author: Amanda Starc
title: Externalities and Benefit Design in Health Insurance
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Insurance benefit design has important implications for consumer welfare. In this article, we model insurer behaviour in the Medicare prescription drug coverage market and show that strategic private insurer incentives impose a fiscal externality on the traditional Medicare program. We document that plans covering medical expenses have more generous drug coverage than plans that are only responsible for prescription drug spending, which translates into higher drug utilization by enrolees. The effect is driven by drugs that reduce medical expenditure and treat chronic conditions. Our equilibrium model of benefit design endogenizes plan characteristics and accounts for asymmetric information; the model estimates confirm that differential incentives to internalize medical care offsets can explain disparities across plans. Counterfactuals show that strategic insurer incentives are as important as asymmetric information in determining benefit design.</jats:p>
research_question: How do strategic private insurer incentives create fiscal externalities on the traditional Medicare program through insurance benefit design in the Medicare prescription drug coverage market?
answer: Plans covering medical expenses have more generous drug coverage than plans only responsible for prescription drug spending, leading to higher drug utilization. This effect is driven by drugs that reduce medical expenditure and treat chronic conditions. Strategic insurer incentives are as important as asymmetric information in determining benefit design.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on insurance benefit design by developing an equilibrium model that endogenizes plan characteristics and accounts for asymmetric information, specifically focusing on how differential incentives to internalize medical care offsets can explain disparities across insurance plans in the Medicare market.

author: Amanda Pallais
title: Evaluating Econometric Evaluations of Post-Secondary Aid
abstract: <jats:p> In an ongoing evaluation of post-secondary financial aid, we use random assignment to assess the causal effects of large privately-funded aid awards. Here, we compare the unbiased causal effect estimates from our RCT with two types of non-experimental econometric estimates. The first applies a selection-on-observables assumption in data from an earlier, nonrandomized cohort; the second uses a regression discontinuity design. Selection-on-observables methods generate estimates well below the experimental benchmark. Regression discontinuity estimates are similar to experimental estimates for students near the cutoff, but sensitive to controlling for the running variable, which is unusually coarse. </jats:p>
research_question: How do non-experimental econometric methods for evaluating post-secondary financial aid compare to unbiased causal effect estimates from randomized controlled trials?
answer: Selection-on-observables methods significantly underestimate the true causal effects compared to experimental benchmarks, while regression discontinuity estimates are similar to experimental estimates for students near the cutoff but are sensitive to how the running variable is controlled for.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the methodological literature on causal inference in education economics by providing a rare direct comparison between experimental and non-experimental approaches using the same intervention, offering empirical evidence on the reliability of commonly used econometric methods for evaluating financial aid programs.

author: Amanda Starc
title: Ask Your Doctor? Direct-to-Consumer Advertising of Pharmaceuticals

author: Amanda Starc
title: Heuristics and Heterogeneity in Health Insurance Exchanges: Evidence from the Massachusetts Connector
abstract: <jats:p> We examine heuristic decision rules in consumer choice on health insurance exchanges using data from the Massachusetts Connector. Consumers may have difficulty making optimal choices in a complex environment. The heuristic “choose the cheapest plan” is suggested by the decision context, previous research, and the data: about 20% of enrollees choose the cheapest plan possible. We find evidence of this heuristic in many models, but while heuristics may play a role, preference heterogeneity is also important. Our most flexible models find an insignificant heuristic effect. In part because holding context fixed, this heuristic is observationally equivalent to extreme price sensitivity. </jats:p>
research_question: Do consumers use heuristic decision rules, specifically 'choose the cheapest plan', when making choices on health insurance exchanges?
answer: While there is some evidence that consumers use the 'choose the cheapest plan' heuristic (about 20% of enrollees choose the cheapest plan), preference heterogeneity is also important and the most flexible models find an insignificant heuristic effect, as this heuristic is observationally equivalent to extreme price sensitivity.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on previous research suggesting heuristic decision-making in complex choice environments, but contributes by showing that what appears to be heuristic behavior may actually reflect preference heterogeneity and extreme price sensitivity rather than simplified decision rules.

author: Amanda Pallais
title: Marginal Effects of Merit Aid for Low-Income Students
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Financial aid from the Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation (STBF) provides comprehensive support to a student population similar to that served by a host of state aid programs. In conjunction with STBF, we randomly assigned aid awards to thousands of Nebraska high school graduates from low-income, minority, and first-generation college households. Randomly assigned STBF awards boost bachelor’s (BA) degree completion for students targeting four-year schools by about 8 points. Degree gains are concentrated among four-year college applicants who would otherwise have been unlikely to pursue a four-year program. Degree effects are mediated by award-induced increases in credits earned toward a BA in the first year of college. The extent of initial four-year college engagement explains differences in impact by target campus and across covariate subgroups. The projected lifetime earnings effect of awards exceeds marginal educational spending for all of the subgroups examined in the study. Projected earnings gains exceed funder costs for urban students and for students with relatively weak academic preparation.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the marginal effects of comprehensive merit aid on college completion and lifetime earnings for low-income, minority, and first-generation college students?
answer: Randomly assigned merit aid increases bachelor's degree completion by about 8 percentage points for students targeting four-year schools, with degree gains concentrated among students who would otherwise have been unlikely to pursue four-year programs. The projected lifetime earnings effects exceed marginal educational spending costs for all subgroups examined, and exceed funder costs for urban students and those with weaker academic preparation.
positioning_statement: This study contributes to the literature on state aid programs by using a randomized controlled trial design with the Susan Thompson Buffett Foundation to examine comprehensive financial aid effects on a student population similar to that served by existing state aid programs, providing causal evidence on merit aid effectiveness for underserved populations.

author: Amanda Starc
title: Measuring Consumer Valuation of Limited Provider Networks
abstract: <jats:p> We measure the breadth of insurance networks in the Massachusetts health insurance exchange. Using our measures, we estimate consumer willingness-to-pay for broad and narrow networks. We find that consumers have a wide range of plans available with dramatically different networks. While consumers value broader networks, their willingness-to-pay is smaller than the brand premium, indicating an additional role for brand preferences. Consumers place additional value on star hospitals, which may affect upstream negotiations. Finally, we find significant geographic heterogeneity in the value of broad networks. </jats:p>
research_question: What is consumer willingness-to-pay for broad versus narrow provider networks in health insurance plans?
answer: Consumers value broader networks but their willingness-to-pay is smaller than the brand premium, indicating brand preferences play an additional role beyond network breadth. Consumers place extra value on star hospitals, and there is significant geographic variation in how much consumers value broad networks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing new measures of insurance network breadth in health insurance exchanges and quantifying consumer preferences for network size, revealing that brand effects beyond network breadth influence consumer choice.

author: Amanda Starc
title: Does Entry Remedy Collusion? Evidence from the Generic Prescription Drug Cartel
abstract: <jats:p> Entry represents a fundamental threat to cartels. We study the extent and effect of this behavior in the largest price-fixing case in US history, which involves generic drug manufacturing. We link information on the cartel’s internal operations to regulatory filings and market data. There is a substantial increase in entry after cartel formation, but regulatory approvals delay most entrants by two to four years. We estimate a structural model and simulate counterfactual equilibria. Absent entry, cartel profits would be dramatically higher. Correspondingly, reducing regulatory delays by just 1–2 years equates to consumer compensating variation of $612  million–$1.5  billion. (JEL L12, L13, L25, L51, L65, M31, O34) </jats:p>
research_question: To what extent does entry threaten cartels and remedy collusion, specifically examining how market entry affects cartel operations and consumer welfare in the generic prescription drug industry?
answer: Entry substantially threatens cartels - there was a significant increase in entry after cartel formation, and absent this entry, cartel profits would have been dramatically higher. However, regulatory delays of 2-4 years limit entry's effectiveness. Reducing these delays by just 1-2 years would generate $612 million to $1.5 billion in consumer benefits.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on cartel behavior and market entry by providing empirical evidence from the largest price-fixing case in US history, linking internal cartel operations data with regulatory filings and market data to quantify the actual impact of entry on cartel effectiveness.

author: Amanda Starc
title: Mortality Effects and Choice Across Private Health Insurance Plans
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Competition in health insurance markets may fail to improve health outcomes if consumers are not able to identify high-quality plans. We develop and apply a novel instrumental variables framework to quantify the variation in causal mortality effects across plans and measure how much consumers attend to this variation. We first document large differences in the observed mortality rates of Medicare Advantage plans in local markets. We then show that when plans with high mortality rates exit these markets, enrollees tend to switch to more typical plans and subsequently experience lower mortality. We derive and validate a novel “fallback condition” governing the subsequent choices of those affected by plan exits. When the fallback condition is satisfied, plan terminations can be used to estimate the relationship between observed plan mortality rates and causal mortality effects. Applying the framework, we find that mortality rates unbiasedly predict causal mortality effects. We then extend our framework to study other predictors of plan mortality effects and estimate consumer willingness to pay. Higher-spending plans tend to reduce enrollee mortality, but existing quality ratings are uncorrelated with plan mortality effects. Consumers place little weight on mortality effects when choosing plans. Good insurance plans dramatically reduce mortality, and redirecting consumers to such plans could improve beneficiary health.</jats:p>
research_question: Do consumers in health insurance markets identify and choose high-quality plans that improve health outcomes, and how much do plan quality differences actually affect mortality?
answer: Good insurance plans dramatically reduce mortality and mortality rates unbiasedly predict causal mortality effects, but consumers place little weight on mortality effects when choosing plans, suggesting market competition fails to improve health outcomes due to consumer inability to identify high-quality plans.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in understanding whether competition in health insurance markets improves health outcomes by developing a novel instrumental variables framework using plan exits to measure causal mortality effects, extending beyond existing literature that has not adequately quantified the relationship between plan quality variation and consumer choice behavior.

author: Amir Kermani
title: Asset Specificity of Nonfinancial Firms
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We develop a new data set to study asset specificity among nonfinancial firms. Our data cover the liquidation values of each category of assets on firms’ balance sheets and provides information across major industries. First, we find that nonfinancial firms have high asset specificity. For example, the liquidation value of fixed assets is 35% of the net book value in the average industry. Second, we analyze the determinants of asset specificity and document that assets’ physical attributes (e.g., mobility, durability, and customization) play a crucial role. Third, we investigate several implications. Consistent with theories of investment irreversibility, high asset specificity is associated with less disinvestment and stronger effects of uncertainty on investment activities. We also find that the increasing prevalence of intangible assets has not significantly reduced firms’ liquidation values.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the extent of asset specificity among nonfinancial firms, what determines it, and what are its implications for firm behavior?
answer: Nonfinancial firms have high asset specificity (liquidation value of fixed assets is only 35% of net book value on average), which is primarily determined by assets' physical attributes like mobility, durability, and customization. High asset specificity leads to less disinvestment and stronger effects of uncertainty on investment activities, consistent with investment irreversibility theories.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on investment irreversibility by developing a new comprehensive dataset on asset liquidation values across industries and providing empirical evidence on the determinants and implications of asset specificity, addressing a gap in understanding how physical asset characteristics affect firm investment behavior.

author: Amir Kermani
title: How Quantitative Easing Works: Evidence on the Refinancing Channel
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We document the transmission of large-scale asset purchases by the Federal Reserve to the real economy using rich borrower-linked mortgage-market data and an identification strategy based on mortgage market segmentation. We find that central bank QE1 MBS purchases substantially increased refinancing activity, reduced interest payments for refinancing households, led to a boom in equity extraction, and increased aggregate consumption. Relative to QE-ineligible jumbo mortgages, QE-eligible conforming mortgage interest rates fell by an additional 40 bp and refinancing volumes increased by an additional 56% during QE1. We estimate that households refinancing during QE1 increased their durable consumption by 12%. Our results highlight that the transmission of unconventional monetary policy to the real economy depends crucially on the composition of assets purchased and the degree of segmentation in the market.</jats:p>
research_question: How does quantitative easing transmit to the real economy, specifically through the refinancing channel in mortgage markets?
answer: QE1 MBS purchases substantially increased refinancing activity by 56%, reduced mortgage rates by an additional 40 basis points for eligible mortgages, led to increased equity extraction, and boosted durable consumption by 12% for refinancing households, demonstrating that QE transmission depends on the composition of assets purchased and market segmentation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on unconventional monetary policy transmission by providing empirical evidence on the refinancing channel using rich borrower-linked mortgage data and an identification strategy based on mortgage market segmentation, highlighting that QE effectiveness depends crucially on asset composition and market structure.

author: Amir Kermani
title: Interest Rate Pass-Through: Mortgage Rates, Household Consumption, and Voluntary Deleveraging
abstract: <jats:p> Exploiting variation in the timing of resets of adjustable-rate mortgages (ARMs), we find that a sizable decline in mortgage payments (up to 50 percent) induces a significant increase in car purchases (up to 35 percent). This effect is attenuated by voluntary deleveraging. Borrowers with lower incomes and housing wealth have significantly higher marginal propensity to consume. Areas with a larger share of ARMs were more responsive to lower interest rates and saw a relative decline in defaults and an increase in house prices, car purchases, and employment. Household balance sheets and mortgage contract rigidity are important for monetary policy pass-through. (JEL D12, D14, E43, E52, G21, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How does interest rate pass-through affect household consumption behavior, particularly through adjustable-rate mortgage payment changes, and what role does voluntary deleveraging play in this relationship?
answer: Significant declines in mortgage payments (up to 50%) lead to substantial increases in car purchases (up to 35%), but this effect is reduced by voluntary deleveraging. The impact is stronger for borrowers with lower incomes and housing wealth, and areas with more ARMs show greater responsiveness to interest rate changes with improved economic outcomes.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the monetary policy transmission literature by demonstrating that household balance sheets and mortgage contract rigidity are important mechanisms for monetary policy pass-through, using novel variation in ARM reset timing to identify causal effects on consumption.

author: Andra Ghent
title: The Work-From-Home Technology Boon and its Consequences
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the impact of widespread adoption of work-from-home (WFH) technology using an equilibrium model where people choose where to live, how to allocate their time between working at home and at the office, and how much space to use in production. Motivated by cross-sectional evidence on WFH, we model WFH as a complement to work at the office. Simulations of the model indicate that the pandemic induced a large change to the relative productivity of WFH that substantially increased home prices and will permanently affect incomes, income inequality, and city structure.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of widespread adoption of work-from-home (WFH) technology on residential location choices, time allocation between home and office work, spatial production decisions, and their effects on home prices, incomes, income inequality, and city structure?
answer: The pandemic induced a large change to the relative productivity of work-from-home that substantially increased home prices and will permanently affect incomes, income inequality, and city structure, with work-from-home serving as a complement to (rather than substitute for) office work.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing an equilibrium model that incorporates the complementary relationship between work-from-home and office work (motivated by cross-sectional evidence), allowing for endogenous choices of residential location, time allocation, and spatial production to analyze the comprehensive economic effects of WFH technology adoption.

author: Andra Ghent
title: Complexity in Structured Finance

author: Andreas Fuster
title: To Buy or Not to Buy: Consumer Constraints in the Housing Market
abstract: <jats:p> We use a strategic household survey to study the sensitivity of intended homeownership decisions to financing constraints. We find that the average stated likelihood of buying a home is strongly sensitive to the size of the required down payment, which we vary exogenously across three scenarios. This sensitivity is particularly high for respondents that appear more liquidity constrained based on observable characteristics (including current renters, or owners with low savings or low home equity). For renters, expectations of future rent inflation and of improvements to their personal financial situation also predict intention to buy. </jats:p>
research_question: How sensitive are intended homeownership decisions to financing constraints, particularly down payment requirements?
answer: The average stated likelihood of buying a home is strongly sensitive to the size of the required down payment, with this sensitivity being particularly high for liquidity constrained respondents such as current renters, owners with low savings, or low home equity.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a strategic household survey approach to directly examine the relationship between financing constraints and homeownership intentions, contributing empirical evidence on how down payment requirements affect housing purchase decisions across different types of households based on their liquidity constraints.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: Entry and Exit in OTC Derivatives Markets
abstract: We develop a parsimonious model to study the equilibrium and socially optimal decisions of banks to enter, trade in, and possibly exit, an OTC market. Although we endow all banks with the same trading technology, banks' optimal entry and trading decisions endogenously lead to a realistic market structure composed of dealers and customers with distinct trading patterns. We decompose banks' entry incentives into incentives to hedge risk and incentives to make intermediation profits. We show that dealer banks enter more than is socially optimal. In the face of large negative shocks, they may also exit more than is socially optimal when markets are not perfectly resilient.

author: Andrea Eisfeldt
title: The Value and Ownership of Intangible Capital
abstract: <jats:p> Intangible capital which relies on essential human inputs, or 'organization capital,' presents a unique challenge for measurement. Organization capital cannot be fully owned by firms' financiers, because it is partly embodied in key labor inputs. Instead, cash flows must be shared with key talent and thus neither book nor market values will fully capture its value. Measurement of organization capital requires a model featuring these unique property rights. We use accounting data along with a simple example of such a model to measure the fraction of the US capital stock which is missing from book and market values. </jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure the fraction of the US capital stock that is missing from book and market values due to organization capital that cannot be fully owned by firms' financiers?
answer: Organization capital that relies on essential human inputs cannot be fully captured in book or market values because it is partly embodied in key labor inputs, requiring cash flows to be shared with key talent, and measurement requires a model that accounts for these unique property rights.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a unique challenge in measuring intangible capital by focusing specifically on 'organization capital' that presents property rights issues not fully addressed in existing literature, requiring a new modeling approach that accounts for the shared ownership between firms and key talent.

author: Andrea Vedolin
title: Model Complexity, Expectations, and Asset Prices
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper analyses how limits to the complexity of statistical models used by market participants can shape asset prices. We consider an economy in which the stochastic process that governs the evolution of economic variables may not have a simple representation, and yet, agents are only capable of entertaining statistical models with a certain level of complexity. As a result, they may end up with a lower-dimensional approximation that does not fully capture the intertemporal complexity of the true data-generating process. We first characterize the implications of the resulting departure from rational expectations and relate the extent of return and forecast-error predictability at various horizons to the complexity of agents’ models and the statistical properties of the underlying process. We then apply our framework to study violations of uncovered interest rate parity in foreign exchange markets. We find that constraints on the complexity of agents’ models can generate return predictability patterns that are simultaneously consistent with the well-known forward discount and predictability reversal puzzles.</jats:p>
research_question: How do limits to the complexity of statistical models used by market participants shape asset prices?
answer: When agents use lower-dimensional approximations that don't fully capture the intertemporal complexity of the true data-generating process, this creates departures from rational expectations that generate return and forecast-error predictability patterns. These model complexity constraints can simultaneously explain violations of uncovered interest rate parity, the forward discount puzzle, and predictability reversal puzzles in foreign exchange markets.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a framework that links bounded rationality through model complexity constraints to asset pricing anomalies, specifically offering a unified explanation for well-known puzzles in foreign exchange markets (forward discount puzzle and predictability reversal) that have previously been studied separately.

author: Andreas Fuster
title: Expectations as Endowments: Evidence on Reference-Dependent Preferences from Exchange and Valuation Experiments *

author: Andreas Fuster
title: Home Price Expectations and Behaviour: Evidence from a Randomized Information Experiment
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Home price expectations are believed to play an important role in housing dynamics, yet we have limited understanding of how they are formed and how they affect behaviour. Using a unique “information experiment” embedded in an online survey, this article investigates how consumers’ home price expectations respond to past home price growth, and how they impact investment decisions. After eliciting respondents’ priors about past and future local home price changes, we present a random subset of them with factual information about past (one- or five-year) changes, and then re-elicit expectations. This unique “panel” data allows us to identify causal effects of the information, and provides insights on the expectation formation process. We find that, on average, year-ahead home price expectations are revised in a way consistent with short-term momentum in home price growth, though respondents tend to underpredict the strength of momentum. Revisions of longer-term expectations show that respondents do not expect the empirically-occurring mean reversion in home price growth. These patterns are in line with recent behavioural models of housing cycles. Finally, we show that home price expectations causally affect investment decisions in a portfolio choice experiment embedded in the survey.</jats:p>
research_question: How are consumers' home price expectations formed in response to past home price growth information, and how do these expectations affect investment behavior?
answer: Home price expectations are revised to reflect short-term momentum in price growth (though consumers underpredict momentum strength) and fail to account for empirically-occurring mean reversion in longer-term growth. These expectations causally affect investment decisions in portfolio choices.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses limited understanding of home price expectation formation and behavioral effects by using a unique randomized information experiment methodology, with findings that align with and support recent behavioral models of housing cycles.

author: Andreas Fuster
title: What Would You Do with $500? Spending Responses to Gains, Losses, News, and Loans
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use survey questions about spending in hypothetical scenarios to investigate features of propensities to consume that are useful for distinguishing between consumption theories. We find that (1) responses to unanticipated gains are vastly heterogeneous (either zero or substantially positive); (2) responses increase in the size of the gain, driven by the extensive margin of spending adjustments; (3) responses to losses are much larger and more widespread than responses to gains; and (4) even those with large responses to gains do not respond to news about future gains. These four findings suggest that limited access to disposable resources, and frictions in adjusting consumption, are important determinants of consumption behaviour. We also find that (5) households do not respond to the offer of a one-year interest-free loan, suggesting that this is not a consequence of short-term credit constraints; and (6) people do cut spending in response to news about future losses, suggesting that neither is this a consequence of myopia. A calibrated precautionary savings model with utility costs of changing consumption, and a sufficient fraction of low-wealth households, can account for these features of propensities to consume on both the extensive and intensive margins.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the key features of propensities to consume that can help distinguish between different consumption theories, particularly regarding responses to gains, losses, news, and loans?
answer: The study finds six key features: (1) vastly heterogeneous responses to unanticipated gains (either zero or substantially positive), (2) responses increase with gain size driven by extensive margin adjustments, (3) responses to losses are much larger and more widespread than to gains, (4) even high-gain responders don't respond to news about future gains, (5) households don't respond to interest-free loan offers, and (6) people do cut spending in response to news about future losses. These findings suggest that limited access to disposable resources and consumption adjustment frictions are important determinants of consumption behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the consumption theory literature by using survey questions about hypothetical spending scenarios to identify distinguishing features between consumption theories, showing that a calibrated precautionary savings model with utility costs of changing consumption and a sufficient fraction of low-wealth households can account for the observed patterns on both extensive and intensive margins.

author: Andreas Fuster
title: Regional Heterogeneity and the Refinancing Channel of Monetary Policy*
abstract: We argue that the time-varying regional distribution of housing equity influences the aggregate consequences of monetary policy through its effects on mortgage refinancing. Using detailed loan-level data, we show that regional differences in housing equity affect refinancing and spending responses to interest rate cuts, but these effects vary over time with changes in the regional distribution of house price growth. We build a heterogeneous household model of refinancing with mortgage borrowers and lenders and use it to explore the monetary policy implications arising from our regional evidence. We find that the 2008 equity distribution made spending in depressed regions less responsive to interest rate cuts, thus dampening aggregate stimulus and increasing regional consumption inequality, whereas the opposite occurred in some earlier recessions. Taken together, our results strongly suggest that monetary policy makers should track the regional distribution of equity over time.

author: Andreas Fuster
title: What Goes Up Must Come Down? Experimental Evidence on Intuitive Forecasting
abstract: <jats:p> Do laboratory subjects correctly perceive the dynamics of a mean-reverting time series? In our experiment, subjects receive historical data and make forecasts at different horizons. The time series process that we use features short-run momentum and long-run partial mean reversion. Half of the subjects see a version of this process in which the momentum and partial mean reversion unfold over ten periods (“fast”), while the other subjects see a version with dynamics that unfold over 50 periods (“slow”). Typical subjects recognize most of the mean reversion of the fast process and none of the mean reversion of the slow process. </jats:p>
research_question: Do laboratory subjects correctly perceive the dynamics of a mean-reverting time series?
answer: Subjects recognize most of the mean reversion when dynamics unfold quickly (over 10 periods) but fail to recognize any mean reversion when dynamics unfold slowly (over 50 periods).
positioning_statement: This paper contributes experimental evidence on intuitive forecasting behavior, specifically examining how the speed of mean-reverting dynamics affects subjects' ability to perceive and forecast time series patterns.

author: Andreas Fuster
title: Pay-as-you-go Social Security and the Distribution of Altruistic Transfers

author: Andreas I. Mueller
title: Separations, Sorting, and Cyclical Unemployment
abstract: <jats:p> This paper establishes a new fact about the compositional changes in the pool of unemployed over the US business cycle. Using microdata from the Current Population Survey for the years 1962–2012, it documents that in recessions the pool of unemployed shifts toward workers with high wages in their previous job and that these shifts are driven by the high cyclicality of separations for high-wage workers. The paper finds that standard theories of wage setting and unemployment have difficulty in explaining these patterns and evaluates a number of alternative theories that do better in accounting for the new fact. (JEL E24, E32, J31, J63, J64) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the composition of the unemployed pool change over the US business cycle, particularly in terms of workers' previous wage levels?
answer: During recessions, the pool of unemployed shifts toward workers with high wages in their previous job, and these compositional shifts are driven by the high cyclicality of separations for high-wage workers.
positioning_statement: This paper establishes a new empirical fact about cyclical unemployment that standard theories of wage setting and unemployment have difficulty explaining, requiring evaluation of alternative theories to account for these previously undocumented patterns.

author: Andreas I. Mueller
title: The Nature of Long-Term Unemployment: Predictability, Heterogeneity, and Selection

author: Andreas I. Mueller
title: Time Use, Emotional Well-Being, and Unemployment: Evidence from Longitudinal Data
abstract: <jats:p> This paper provides new evidence on the time use and emotional well-being of unemployed individuals in the weeks before and after starting a new job. The major findings are: (1) time spent on home production drops sharply at the time of re-employment, even when controlling for individual fixed effects; (2) time spent on leisure-related activities, which the unemployed find less enjoyable, drops on re-employment, but less so when controlling for individual fixed effects; (3) the unemployed report higher levels of sadness during specific episodes of the day than the employed; and (4) sadness decreases abruptly at the time of re-employment. </jats:p>
research_question: How do time use patterns and emotional well-being change for unemployed individuals in the weeks before and after starting a new job?
answer: Upon re-employment, individuals sharply reduce time spent on home production, moderately reduce time on less enjoyable leisure activities, and experience an abrupt decrease in sadness levels during daily episodes.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new evidence on the time use and emotional well-being dynamics of unemployment transitions using longitudinal data with individual fixed effects controls.

author: Andreas I. Mueller
title: Vacancy Durations and Entry Wages: Evidence from Linked Vacancy–Employer–Employee Data
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article explores the relationship between the duration of a vacancy and the starting wage of a new job, using linked data on vacancies, the posting establishments, and the workers eventually filling the vacancies. The unique combination of large-scale, administrative worker, establishment, and vacancy data is critical for separating establishment- and job-level determinants of vacancy duration from worker-level heterogeneity. Conditional on observables, we find that vacancy duration is negatively correlated with the starting wage and its establishment component, with precisely estimated elasticities of −0.07 and −0.21, respectively. While the negative relationship is qualitatively consistent with search-theoretic models where firms use the wage as a recruiting device, these elasticities are small, suggesting that firms’ wage policies can account only for a small fraction of the variation in vacancy filling across establishments.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between the duration of a vacancy and the starting wage of a new job?
answer: Vacancy duration is negatively correlated with starting wages, with elasticities of -0.07 for overall starting wage and -0.21 for the establishment component, but these effects are small, suggesting wage policies account for only a small fraction of variation in vacancy filling across establishments.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to search-theoretic models by using a unique combination of large-scale, administrative data linking vacancies, establishments, and workers to separate establishment- and job-level determinants from worker-level heterogeneity, which is critical for identifying the true relationship between vacancy duration and wages.

author: Andreas I. Mueller
title: Wage Dispersion and Search Behavior: The Importance of Nonwage Job Values
abstract: We use a rich new body of data on the experiences of unemployed job seekers to determine the sources of wage dispersion and to create a search model consistent with the acceptance decisions the job seekers made. We identify the distributions of four key variables: offered wages, offered nonwage job values, job seekers’ nonwork alternatives, and job seekers’ personal productivities. We find that, conditional on personal productivity, the standard deviation of offered log wages is moderate, at 0.24, whereas the dispersion of the offered nonwage component is substantially larger, at 0.34. The resulting dispersion of offered job values is 0.38.

author: Andreas I. Mueller
title: Job Seekers’ Perceptions and Employment Prospects: Heterogeneity, Duration Dependence, and Bias
abstract: <jats:p> This paper uses job seekers’ elicited beliefs about job finding to disentangle the sources of the decline in job-finding rates by duration of unemployment. We document that beliefs have strong predictive power for job finding, but are not revised downward when remaining unemployed and are subject to optimistic bias, especially for the long-term unemployed. Leveraging the predictive power of beliefs, we find substantial heterogeneity in job finding with the resulting dynamic selection explaining most of the observed negative duration dependence in job finding. Moreover, job seekers’ beliefs underreact to heterogeneity in job finding, distorting search behavior and increasing long-term unemployment. (JEL D83, E24, J22, J64, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the sources of the decline in job-finding rates by duration of unemployment, and how do job seekers' beliefs about job finding contribute to this phenomenon?
answer: The decline in job-finding rates is primarily explained by substantial heterogeneity in job finding and resulting dynamic selection rather than true duration dependence. Job seekers' beliefs have strong predictive power but are subject to optimistic bias and underreact to heterogeneity, which distorts search behavior and increases long-term unemployment.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on unemployment duration dependence by using a novel approach of analyzing job seekers' elicited beliefs to disentangle the sources of declining job-finding rates, providing new evidence on the role of heterogeneity versus true duration dependence and identifying how biased beliefs affect search behavior.

author: Andreas I. Mueller
title: Job Search Behavior Among the Employed and Non‐Employed
abstract: <jats:p>We develop a unique survey that focuses on the job search behavior of individuals regardless of their labor force status and field it annually starting in 2013. We use our survey to study the relationship between search effort and outcomes for the employed and non‐employed. Three important facts stand out: (1) on‐the‐job search is pervasive, and is more intense at the lower rungs of the job ladder; (2) the employed are at least three times more effective than the unemployed in job search; and (3) the employed receive better job offers than the unemployed. We set up a general equilibrium model of on‐the‐job search with endogenous search effort, calibrate it to fit our new facts, and find that the search effort of the employed is highly elastic. We show that search effort substantially amplifies labor market responses to productivity shocks over the business cycle.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between search effort and outcomes for employed versus non-employed individuals, and how does this affect labor market dynamics?
answer: On-the-job search is pervasive and more intense at lower job levels; employed workers are at least three times more effective than unemployed workers in job search and receive better job offers; search effort of the employed is highly elastic and substantially amplifies labor market responses to productivity shocks over the business cycle.
positioning_statement: This paper fills a gap in existing literature by developing a unique survey that studies job search behavior across all labor force statuses (both employed and non-employed), rather than focusing primarily on unemployed job seekers, and incorporates these empirical findings into a general equilibrium model with endogenous search effort.

author: Andreas Moxnes
title: R&D, International Sourcing, and the Joint Impact on Firm Performance
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies the impact of an R&D cost shock on R&D investments, imported inputs, and their joint impact on firm performance. We introduce imported inputs into a model of R&D and endogenous productivity, and show that R&D and international sourcing are complementary activities. Exploiting the introduction of an R&D tax credit in Norway in 2002, we find that cheaper R&D stimulated not only R&D investments but also imports of intermediates, quantitatively consistent with the model. An implication of our work is that improved access to imported inputs promotes R&D investments and, ultimately, technological change. (JEL D92, F14, G31, H25, L25, O32, O33) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of an R&D cost shock on R&D investments, imported inputs, and their joint impact on firm performance?
answer: R&D and international sourcing are complementary activities - cheaper R&D stimulates not only R&D investments but also imports of intermediates, and improved access to imported inputs promotes R&D investments and technological change.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces imported inputs into a model of R&D and endogenous productivity, extending existing literature by examining the complementary relationship between R&D and international sourcing activities.

author: Andreas Moxnes
title: The Margins of Multinational Production and the Role of Intrafirm Trade

author: Andreas Moxnes
title: Production Networks, Geography, and Firm Performance
abstract: This paper examines the importance of buyer-supplier relationships for firm performance. We develop a model in which firms outsource tasks and search for suppliers. Lower search and outsourcing costs lead firms to search more and find better suppliers, which in turn drives down marginal costs. We test the theory by exploiting the opening of a high-speed train line in Japan, which lowered the cost of passenger travel but left shipping costs unchanged. Using an exhaustive data set on firms’ buyer-seller linkages, we find significant improvements in firm performance as well as creation of buyer-seller links, consistent with the model.

author: Andreas I. Mueller
title: Growth Dynamics: The Myth of Economic Recovery: Comment
abstract: <jats:p> This comment highlights different ways of coding crisis episodes in Cerra and Saxena (2008) (CS). The comment shows that the coding used for civil war implies a misrepresentation of its impact. A correct coding of civil war reveals that the average civil war leads to a loss in output of 18 percent. This makes civil wars more devastating than all other crisis studied by CS. </jats:p>
research_question: How does the correct coding of civil war episodes affect the measurement of their economic impact compared to other types of crises?
answer: When civil war episodes are correctly coded, they lead to an average output loss of 18 percent, making civil wars more economically devastating than all other types of crises studied.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as a correction to Cerra and Saxena (2008), identifying coding errors in their crisis episode classification that led to misrepresentation of civil war's economic impact relative to other types of crises.

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: The Distributional Consequences of Large Devaluations
abstract: <jats:p> We study the impact of large exchange rate devaluations on the cost of living at different points on the income distribution. Poor households spend relatively more on tradeable product categories and consume lower-priced varieties within categories. Changes in the relative price of tradeables and of lower-priced varieties affect the cost of living of low-income relative to high-income households. We quantify these effects following the 1994 Mexican devaluation and show that they can have large distributional consequences. Two years post-devaluation, the cost of living for the bottom income decile rose 1.48 to 1.62 times more than for the top income decile. (JEL D12, D31, E31, F31, O12, O19, O24) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of large exchange rate devaluations on the cost of living at different points on the income distribution?
answer: Large devaluations have significant distributional consequences, with the cost of living rising disproportionately more for poor households - two years after the 1994 Mexican devaluation, the cost of living for the bottom income decile rose 1.48 to 1.62 times more than for the top income decile.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by quantifying the distributional effects of exchange rate devaluations through the lens of heterogeneous consumption patterns across income levels, specifically examining how poor households' greater spending on tradeable goods and lower-priced varieties makes them more vulnerable to devaluation-induced price changes.

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: Multinational Firms and International Business Cycle Transmission*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate how multinational firms contribute to the transmission of shocks across countries using a large multicountry firm-level data set that contains cross-border ownership information. We use these data to document two novel empirical patterns. First, foreign affiliate and headquarter sales exhibit strong positive comovement: a 10% growth in the sales of the headquarter is associated with a 2% growth in the sales of the affiliate. Second, shocks to the source country account for a significant fraction of the variation in sales growth at the source-destination level. We propose a parsimonious quantitative model to interpret these findings and to evaluate the role of multinational firms for international business cycle transmission. For the typical country, the impact of foreign shocks transmitted by all foreign multinationals combined is non-negligible, accounting for about 10% of aggregate productivity shocks. On the other hand, since bilateral multinational production shares are small, interdependence between most individual country pairs is minimal. Our results do reveal substantial heterogeneity in the strength of this mechanism, with the most integrated countries significantly more affected by foreign shocks.</jats:p>
research_question: How do multinational firms contribute to the transmission of shocks across countries?
answer: Multinational firms serve as a significant channel for international business cycle transmission, with foreign shocks transmitted by all foreign multinationals combined accounting for about 10% of aggregate productivity shocks for the typical country, though bilateral interdependence between most individual country pairs remains minimal due to small bilateral multinational production shares.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel empirical evidence using a large multicountry firm-level dataset with cross-border ownership information to document previously unestablished patterns of comovement between foreign affiliate and headquarter sales, and proposes a quantitative model to evaluate multinational firms' role in international business cycle transmission.

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: Country Size, International Trade, and Aggregate Fluctuations in Granular Economies

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: Large Firms and International Business Cycle Comovement
abstract: <jats:p> This paper investigates the role of the top 100 firms in France in aggregate business cycle comovement. We establish that the top 100 firms (i) are important in aggregate; (ii) exhibit stronger international linkages than the rest of the economy; and (iii) contribute substantially to aggregate comovement. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of the top 100 firms in France in aggregate business cycle comovement?
answer: The top 100 firms in France are important in aggregate, exhibit stronger international linkages than the rest of the economy, and contribute substantially to aggregate comovement.
positioning_statement: This paper investigates the specific role of large firms in international business cycle comovement, focusing on how the largest firms contribute to aggregate economic synchronization across countries.

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: International Comovement in the Global Production Network
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article provides a general framework to study the role of production networks in international GDP comovement. We first derive an additive decomposition of bilateral GDP comovement into components capturing shock transmission and shock correlation. We quantify this decomposition in a parsimonious multi-country, multi-sector dynamic network propagation model, using data for the G7 countries over the period 1978–2007. Our main finding is that while the network transmission of shocks is quantitatively important, it accounts for a minority of observed comovement under the estimated range of structural elasticities. Contemporaneous responses to correlated shocks in the production network are more successful at generating comovement than intertemporal propagation through capital accumulation. Extensions with multiple shocks, nominal rigidities, and international financial integration leave our main result unchanged. A combination of TFP and labour supply shocks is quantitatively successful at reproducing the observed international business cycle.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of production networks in international GDP comovement, and how much of observed comovement is due to shock transmission through networks versus correlated shocks?
answer: While network transmission of shocks is quantitatively important, it accounts for a minority of observed international GDP comovement. Contemporaneous responses to correlated shocks in the production network are more successful at generating comovement than intertemporal propagation through capital accumulation.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a general framework to study production networks' role in international GDP comovement by deriving an additive decomposition that separates shock transmission from shock correlation effects, quantified through a parsimonious multi-country, multi-sector dynamic network propagation model.

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: The “Collapse in Quality” Hypothesis
abstract: <jats:p> This paper evaluates the hypothesis that during the 2008–2009 collapse in international trade, imports of higher quality goods experienced larger reductions compared to low-quality imports, using data on US imports disaggregated by HS-10 product category and source country. We find little, if any, robust econometric evidence in support of this hypothesis. </jats:p>
research_question: Did imports of higher quality goods experience larger reductions compared to low-quality imports during the 2008-2009 collapse in international trade?
answer: There is little, if any, robust econometric evidence supporting the hypothesis that higher quality goods experienced larger import reductions during the 2008-2009 trade collapse.
positioning_statement: This paper directly tests and challenges the existing 'collapse in quality' hypothesis regarding the 2008-2009 international trade collapse by providing empirical evidence using disaggregated US import data.

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: Foreign Shocks as Granular Fluctuations
abstract: This paper uses a dataset covering the universe of French firm-level value-added, imports, and exports and a quantitative multicountry heterogeneous firm model to study the propagation of foreign shocks to the domestic economy. Foreign shocks are transmitted primarily through large firms as they are the most likely to trade internationally. At the micro level, the majority of the GDP impact of foreign shocks is accounted for by the “foreign granular residual,” a statistic capturing larger firms’ greater responsiveness to foreign shocks. At the macro level, firm heterogeneity attenuates the GDP impact of foreign shocks relative to a homogeneous firm counterfactual.

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: The Micro Origins of International Business-Cycle Comovement
abstract: <jats:p> This paper investigates the role of individual firms in international business-cycle comovement using data covering the universe of French firm-level value added and international linkages over the period 1993–2007. At the micro level, trade and multinational linkages with a particular foreign country are associated with a significantly higher correlation between a firm and that foreign country. The impact of direct linkages on comovement at the micro level has significant macro implications. Without those linkages the correlation between France and foreign countries would fall by about 0.098, or one-third of the observed average correlation of 0.291 in our sample of partner countries. (JEL F14, F23, F44, F62, L14) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of individual firms in international business-cycle comovement, specifically how do firm-level trade and multinational linkages affect correlations between domestic and foreign business cycles?
answer: Individual firms with trade and multinational linkages to foreign countries exhibit significantly higher correlations with those countries' business cycles, and these micro-level linkages have substantial macro implications - without direct firm linkages, the correlation between France and foreign countries would fall by about 0.098, representing one-third of the observed average correlation of 0.291.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the international business-cycle comovement literature by providing micro-level evidence using comprehensive firm-level data, investigating how individual firm linkages aggregate to explain macro-level international correlations, rather than focusing solely on aggregate-level relationships.

author: Andrei Levchenko
title: The Long and Short (Run) of Trade Elasticities
abstract: <jats:p>When countries change most favored nation (MFN) tariffs, partners that trade on MFN terms experience plausibly exogenous tariff changes. Using this variation, we estimate the trade elasticity at short and long horizons with local projections. We find that the elasticity of tariff-exclusive trade flows is −0.76 in the short run, and approximately −2 in the long run. Our long-run estimates are smaller than typical in the literature, and it takes 7 to10 years to converge to the long run, implying that (i) the welfare gains from trade are high and (ii) there are substantial convexities in the costs of adjusting exports. (JEL C51, F13, F14)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the short-run and long-run trade elasticities when countries change their most favored nation (MFN) tariffs?
answer: The trade elasticity of tariff-exclusive trade flows is -0.76 in the short run and approximately -2 in the long run, with convergence taking 7 to 10 years, implying high welfare gains from trade and substantial convexities in export adjustment costs.
positioning_statement: This paper's long-run trade elasticity estimates are smaller than typical estimates found in the existing literature, contributing new evidence on the dynamics of trade adjustment and welfare implications.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Salience and Asset Prices
abstract: <jats:p> We present a simple model of asset pricing in which payoff salience drives investors' demand for risky assets. The key implication is that extreme payoffs receive disproportionate weight in the market valuation of assets. The model accounts for several puzzles in finance in an intuitive way, including preference for assets with a chance of very high payoffs, an aggregate equity premium, and countercyclical variation in stock market returns. </jats:p>
research_question: How does payoff salience affect investors' demand for risky assets and asset pricing?
answer: Extreme payoffs receive disproportionate weight in market valuation of assets, which explains several finance puzzles including preference for high-payoff assets, equity premium, and countercyclical stock market returns.
positioning_statement: The paper presents a simple model that accounts for several existing puzzles in finance in an intuitive way, suggesting it provides a unifying explanation for previously unexplained phenomena in asset pricing literature.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title:
Finance and the Preservation of Wealth
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We introduce the model of asset management developed in Gennaioli, Shleifer, and Vishny (“Money Doctors,” Journal of Finance , forthcoming 2015) into a Solow-style neoclassical growth model with diminishing returns to capital. Savers rely on trusted intermediaries to manage their wealth (claims on capital stock), who can charge fees above costs to trusting investors. In this model, the ratio of financial income to GDP increases with the ratio of aggregate wealth to GDP. Both rise along the convergence path to steady state growth. We examine several further implications of the model for management fees, unit costs of finance, and the consequences of shocks to trust and to the capital stock.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the relationship between financial income and GDP evolve as economies grow, particularly in the context of asset management with trusted intermediaries who can charge fees above costs?
answer: The ratio of financial income to GDP increases with the ratio of aggregate wealth to GDP, and both ratios rise along the convergence path to steady state growth in economies where savers rely on trusted intermediaries for wealth management.
positioning_statement: This paper builds upon the asset management model from Gennaioli, Shleifer, and Vishny's 'Money Doctors' work by integrating it into a Solow-style neoclassical growth framework with diminishing returns to capital, extending the analysis to examine how financial sector dynamics evolve during economic growth and convergence.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Coarse Thinking and Persuasion<sup>*</sup>

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: The Market for News
abstract: <jats:p> We investigate the market for news under two assumptions: that readers hold beliefs which they like to see confirmed, and that newspapers can slant stories toward these beliefs. We show that, on the topics where readers share common beliefs, one should not expect accuracy even from competitive media: competition results in lower prices, but common slanting toward reader biases. On topics where reader beliefs diverge (such as politically divisive issues), however, newspapers segment the market and slant toward extreme positions. Yet in the aggregate, a reader with access to all news sources could get an unbiased perspective. Generally speaking, reader heterogeneity is more important for accuracy in media than competition per se. </jats:p>
research_question: How does the market structure for news affect accuracy and bias in media reporting when readers have confirmation bias and newspapers can slant stories?
answer: Competition alone does not ensure media accuracy - when readers share common beliefs, competitive media will slant toward those shared biases; however, when reader beliefs diverge, newspapers segment the market toward extreme positions, which can provide aggregate unbiased information if readers access multiple sources. Reader heterogeneity is more important for media accuracy than competition itself.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the media economics literature by formally modeling how reader confirmation bias and newspaper slanting interact with market competition, showing that the conventional wisdom about competition improving quality does not necessarily apply to news markets.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Salience and Consumer Choice
abstract: We present a theory of context-dependent choice in which a consumer’s attention is drawn to salient attributes of goods, such as quality or price. An attribute is salient for a good when it stands out among the good’s attributes relative to that attribute’s average level in the choice set (or, more broadly, the choice context). Consumers attach disproportionately high weight to salient attributes, and their choices are tilted toward goods with higher quality/price ratios. The model accounts for a variety of disparate evidence, including decoy effects and context-dependent willingness to pay. It also suggests a novel theory of misleading sales.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Salience Theory of Choice Under Risk
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We present a theory of choice among lotteries in which the decision maker's attention is drawn to (precisely defined) salient payoffs. This leads the decision maker to a context-dependent representation of lotteries in which true probabilities are replaced by decision weights distorted in favor of salient payoffs. By specifying decision weights as a function of payoffs, our model provides a novel and unified account of many empirical phenomena, including frequent risk-seeking behavior, invariance failures such as the Allais paradox, and preference reversals. It also yields new predictions, including some that distinguish it from prospect theory, which we test.</jats:p>
research_question: How can decision-making under risk be explained by attention being drawn to salient payoffs, and what are the implications for choice behavior among lotteries?
answer: Decision makers exhibit context-dependent choice behavior where attention to salient payoffs leads to distorted decision weights that favor those salient outcomes, providing a unified explanation for risk-seeking behavior, invariance failures like the Allais paradox, and preference reversals.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a novel theory that provides a unified account of empirical phenomena in choice under risk by specifying decision weights as a function of payoffs, offering new predictions that distinguish it from existing theories like prospect theory.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Salience in Experimental Tests of the Endowment Effect
abstract: <jats:p> We provide a novel account of experimental evidence for the endowment effect using the salience mechanism (Bordalo, Gennaioli, and Shleifer, 2011). The two-stage procedure implemented in experiments implies that the endowed good and other goods are evaluated in different contexts. We describe conditions under which the standard effect occurs, but also account for recent evidence such as a reverse endowment effect for bads and a role for reference prices in modulating the WTA-WTP gap. </jats:p>
research_question: How can the salience mechanism explain experimental evidence for the endowment effect?
answer: The two-stage procedure in endowment effect experiments causes the endowed good and other goods to be evaluated in different contexts, which through the salience mechanism can explain both standard endowment effects and anomalous findings like reverse endowment effects for bads and the role of reference prices in modulating the WTA-WTP gap.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel account of existing experimental evidence for the endowment effect by applying the salience mechanism framework of Bordalo, Gennaioli, and Shleifer (2011), offering a unified explanation for both standard findings and recent contradictory evidence that previous theories could not adequately explain.

author: Andrei Shleifer
title: Memory, Attention, and Choice*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Building on a textbook description of associative memory (Kahana 2012), we present a model of choice in which a choice option cues recall of similar past experiences. Memory shapes valuation and decisions in two ways. First, recalled experiences form a norm, which serves as an initial anchor for valuation. Second, salient quality and price surprises relative to the norm lead to large adjustments in valuation. The model unifies many well-documented choice puzzles, including the attribution and projection biases, inattention to hidden attributes, background contrast effects, and context-dependent willingness to pay. Unifying these puzzles on the basis of selective memory and attention to surprise yields multiple new predictions.</jats:p>
research_question: How do memory and attention mechanisms influence choice and valuation decisions?
answer: Memory shapes valuation and decisions through two key mechanisms: (1) recalled experiences from similar past situations form a norm that serves as an initial anchor for valuation, and (2) salient quality and price surprises relative to this norm lead to large adjustments in valuation.
positioning_statement: This paper unifies many well-documented choice puzzles (including attribution and projection biases, inattention to hidden attributes, background contrast effects, and context-dependent willingness to pay) under a single framework based on associative memory and attention to surprise, building on established memory research while generating multiple new predictions.

author: Andrei Shleifer

An attribute is salient for a good when it stands out among the good’s attributes relative to that attribute’s average level in the choice set (or, more broadly, the choice context). Consumers attach disproportionately high weight to salient attributes, and their choices are tilted toward goods with higher quality/price ratios. The model accounts for a variety of disparate evidence, including decoy effects and context-dependent willingness to pay. It also suggests a novel theory of misleading sales.
