Second, we characterize the conditions under which full implementation is possible via direct mechanisms, that only elicit payoff relevant information, and the transfer schemes which achieve it whenever possible. The full implementation results obtain from showing that the problem can be transformed into one of designing a network of strategic externalities, subject to suitable constraints which are dictated by the incentive compatibility requirements.</jats:p>
research_question: How can robust mechanism design be achieved in environments where agents believe others' types are identically distributed, but the actual distribution is unknown to both the designer and agents?
answer: Full implementation is possible via direct mechanisms that only elicit payoff relevant information by transforming the problem into designing a network of strategic externalities subject to incentive compatibility constraints, with specific characterizations provided for incentive compatible transfers and conditions enabling full implementation.
positioning_statement: This paper extends robust mechanism design literature by addressing the case where agents have common beliefs about identical distributions without requiring common knowledge of the actual distribution or designer knowledge of it, using a novel network-based approach to solve implementation problems.

author: Antonio Penta
title: Full Implementation and Belief Restrictions
abstract: <jats:p> Multiplicity of equilibria and the dependence on strong common knowledge assumptions are well-known problems in mechanism design. We address them by studying full implementation via transfer schemes, under general restrictions on agents' beliefs. We show that incentive-compatible transfers ensure uniqueness—and hence full implementation—if they induce sufficiently weak strategic externalities. We then design transfers for full implementation by using information on beliefs in order to weaken the strategic externalities of the baseline canonical transfers. Our results rely on minimal restrictions on agents' beliefs, specifically on moments of the distribution of types, that arise naturally in applications. (JEL D62, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How can mechanism design achieve full implementation (unique equilibrium) under general restrictions on agents' beliefs, addressing the well-known problems of equilibrium multiplicity and dependence on strong common knowledge assumptions?
answer: Incentive-compatible transfers can ensure uniqueness and full implementation if they induce sufficiently weak strategic externalities, and this can be achieved by designing transfers that use information on beliefs to weaken the strategic externalities of baseline canonical transfers.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses well-known problems in the existing mechanism design literature—specifically multiplicity of equilibria and dependence on strong common knowledge assumptions—by proposing a solution that relies on minimal restrictions on agents' beliefs (moments of type distributions) rather than the strong assumptions typically required in prior work.

author: Antonio Penta
title: Endogenous Depth of Reasoning

author: Arash Nekoei
title: Does Extending Unemployment Benefits Improve Job Quality?
abstract: <jats:p> Contrary to standard search models predictions, past studies have not found a positive effect of unemployment insurance (UI) on reemployment wages. We estimate a positive UI wage effect exploiting an age-based regression discontinuity design in Austria. A search model incorporating duration dependence predicts two countervailing forces: UI induces workers to seek higher-wage jobs, but reduces wages by lengthening unemployment. Matching-function heterogeneity plausibly generates a negative relationship between the UI unemployment-duration and wage effects, which holds empirically in our sample and across studies, reconciling disparate wage-effect estimates. Empirically, UI raises wages by improving reemployment firm quality and attenuating wage drops. (JEL J31, J64, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: Does extending unemployment benefits improve job quality, specifically through effects on reemployment wages?
answer: Yes, unemployment insurance raises wages by improving reemployment firm quality and attenuating wage drops, with the positive effect identified through an age-based regression discontinuity design in Austria.
positioning_statement: This paper reconciles the contradiction between standard search model predictions (which suggest UI should increase wages) and past empirical studies (which have not found positive wage effects) by proposing that matching-function heterogeneity creates a negative relationship between UI's unemployment-duration and wage effects, which explains the disparate findings across different studies.

author: Antonio Penta
title: Rationalizability, Observability, and Common Knowledge
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the strategic impact of players’ higher-order uncertainty over the observability of actions in general two-player games. More specifically, we consider the space of all belief hierarchies generated by the uncertainty over whether the game will be played as a static game or with perfect information. Over this space, we characterize the correspondence of a solution concept which captures the behavioural implications of Rationality and Common Belief in Rationality (RCBR), where “rationality” is understood as sequential whenever the game is dynamic. We show that such a correspondence is generically single-valued, and that its structure supports a robust refinement of rationalizability, which often has very sharp implications. For instance, (1) in a class of games which includes both zero-sum games with a pure equilibrium and coordination games with a unique efficient equilibrium, RCBR generically ensures efficient equilibrium outcomes (eductive coordination); (2) in a class of games which also includes other well-known families of coordination games, RCBR generically selects components of the Stackelberg profiles (Stackelberg selection); (3) if it is commonly known that player $2$’s action is not observable (e.g. because $1$ is commonly known to move earlier, etc.), in a class of games which includes all of the above RCBR generically selects the equilibrium of the static game most favourable to player $1$ (pervasiveness of first-mover advantage).</jats:p>
research_question: What is the strategic impact of players' higher-order uncertainty over the observability of actions in general two-player games?
answer: The paper finds that Rationality and Common Belief in Rationality (RCBR) under uncertainty about observability creates a robust refinement of rationalizability that generically produces single-valued solutions with sharp implications: (1) efficient equilibrium outcomes in zero-sum and coordination games, (2) Stackelberg profile selection in coordination games, and (3) first-mover advantage when one player's action is commonly known to be unobservable.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the rationalizability literature by incorporating higher-order uncertainty about game structure (static vs. dynamic with perfect information) and develops a solution concept that refines existing rationalizability concepts through the lens of sequential rationality when games are dynamic.

author: Arash Nekoei
title: How Do Inheritances Shape Wealth Inequality? Theory and Evidence from Sweden
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article aims to measure and understand the role of inheritances in shaping wealth inequality. We use a quasi-experimental design and Swedish administrative data to document that the average heir depletes her inheritance within a decade while the inheritances of wealthy heirs remain intact. These different depletion rates are not due to different consumption or labour supply responses but due to different rates of return on inherited wealth. Upon their receipt, inheritances reduce relative measures of wealth inequality, such as top shares or percentile ratios. Theoretically, this reduction in inequality could be due to either a compressed inheritance distribution or similar chances of having wealthy parents (high intergenerational mobility). Empirically, the first force is more significant in Sweden. Within a decade, however, the effect is reversed: inheritances increase wealth inequality since the different depletion rates widen the inequality in inherited wealth over time. This implies that inheritance taxation can reduce long run wealth inequality only through the taxation of wealthy heirs.</jats:p>
research_question: How do inheritances shape wealth inequality?
answer: Inheritances initially reduce wealth inequality upon receipt due to a compressed inheritance distribution, but within a decade they increase wealth inequality because wealthy heirs maintain their inheritances while average heirs deplete theirs due to different rates of return on inherited wealth, not different consumption or labor supply responses.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using quasi-experimental design and Swedish administrative data to empirically measure inheritance effects on wealth inequality, distinguishing between short-term and long-term impacts and identifying the mechanisms (different rates of return rather than consumption/labor responses) that drive wealth inequality changes over time.

author: Arash Nekoei
title: Recall Expectations and Duration Dependence
abstract: <jats:p> Using novel administrative data from Austria, we investigate the nature of temporary layoffs and recalls. We find that on average jobs ending in temporary layoffs lasted shorter but paid higher wages. The majority of temporarily laid-off workers return to their previous employer, but also one-fifth of those permanently laid-off are recalled. Compared to job switchers, recalls have shorter unemployment spells and do not experience wage losses. Negative duration dependence of unemployment only appears once recall exits are excluded for temporary and permanent layoffs. However, for temporary layoffs, the aggregate pattern masks significant heterogeneity by pre-unemployment tenure. Additional survey evidence suggests a lower average search level for temporary layoffs. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the nature of temporary layoffs and recalls, and how do recall expectations affect unemployment duration dependence?
answer: Jobs ending in temporary layoffs are shorter but higher-paid; most temporarily laid-off workers return to previous employers while one-fifth of permanently laid-off workers are also recalled; recalls have shorter unemployment spells without wage losses; negative duration dependence in unemployment only appears when recall exits are excluded, with significant heterogeneity by pre-unemployment tenure for temporary layoffs.
positioning_statement: This paper uses novel administrative data from Austria to provide new empirical evidence on temporary layoffs and recalls, contributing to the literature on unemployment duration dependence by showing how recall expectations mask underlying patterns when not properly accounted for.

author: Arash Nekoei
title: Risk-Based Selection in Unemployment Insurance: Evidence and Implications
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies whether adverse selection can rationalize a universal mandate for unemployment insurance (UI). Building on a unique feature of the unemployment policy in Sweden, where workers can opt for supplemental UI coverage above a minimum mandate, we provide the first direct evidence for adverse selection in UI and derive its implications for UI design. We find that the unemployment risk is more than twice as high for workers who buy supplemental coverage. Exploiting variation in risk and prices, we show how 25–30 percent of this correlation is driven by risk-based selection, with the remainder driven by moral hazard. Due to the moral hazard and despite the adverse selection we find that mandating the supplemental coverage to individuals with low willingness-to-pay would be suboptimal. We show under which conditions a design leaving choice to workers would dominate a UI system with a single mandate. In this design, using a subsidy for supplemental coverage is optimal and complementary to the use of a minimum mandate. (JEL D82, G22, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: Can adverse selection rationalize a universal mandate for unemployment insurance?
answer: Despite finding evidence of adverse selection in unemployment insurance (with unemployment risk more than twice as high for workers who buy supplemental coverage), mandating supplemental coverage to individuals with low willingness-to-pay would be suboptimal due to moral hazard effects. A design that leaves choice to workers, combined with subsidies for supplemental coverage and a minimum mandate, can dominate a single universal mandate system.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first direct evidence for adverse selection in unemployment insurance by exploiting a unique feature of Sweden's unemployment policy where workers can opt for supplemental coverage above a minimum mandate, filling a gap in the literature that previously lacked direct empirical evidence of risk-based selection in UI markets.

author: Arash Nekoei
title: Mandatory Notice of Layoff, Job Search, and Efficiency
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>In all OECD countries, mandatory notice (MN) policies require firms to inform workers in advance of a layoff. In our theoretical framework, MN helps workers avoid unemployment and find better jobs by encouraging them to search for a new job while still employed, thereby increasing future production. The magnitude of this production gain depends on the relative effectiveness of search while employed versus unemployed. But on-the-job search and diminished work incentives reduce current production. If future gains outweigh current production losses, longer advance notice improves production efficiency. If not, Coasian bargaining predicts that firms offer a larger severance instead of longer notice. With bargaining, the sole efficiency loss of MN is due to delayed separations of unproductive job matches. We test these predictions using novel Swedish administrative data on layoff notifications. Workers eligible for extended MN receive longer notice and larger severance, resulting in less exposure to nonemployment spells and higher-paying jobs. These favorable labor market outcomes are solely due to longer notice; in contrast, larger severance delays job finding and has no impact on wages. We also show that advance notice replaces job search while unemployed with more effective search while employed. On the production side, we document a productivity drop among notified workers and estimate a production loss due to delayed separations. Using our estimates of production gains and losses to evaluate the overall production efficiency, we conclude that the gains of MN seem to outweigh the losses.</jats:p>
research_question: How do mandatory notice policies affect job search efficiency, labor market outcomes, and overall production efficiency when firms are required to inform workers in advance of layoffs?
answer: Mandatory notice policies improve production efficiency overall because the gains from helping workers find better jobs through more effective on-the-job search outweigh the losses from reduced current productivity and delayed separations of unproductive matches.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on employment protection by developing a theoretical framework that incorporates Coasian bargaining between firms and workers regarding notice versus severance trade-offs, and by providing novel empirical evidence using Swedish administrative data on layoff notifications to test predictions about the relative effectiveness of job search while employed versus unemployed.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: Social Networks, Reputation, and Commitment: Evidence From a Savings Monitors Experiment
abstract: We conduct an experiment to study whether individuals save more when information about the progress toward their self‐set savings goal is shared with another village member (a “monitor”). We develop a reputational framework to explore how a monitor's effectiveness depends on her network position. Savers who care about whether others perceive them as responsible should save more with central monitors, who more widely disseminate information, and proximate monitors, who pass information to individuals with whom the saver interacts frequently. We randomly assign monitors to savers and find that monitors on average increase savings by 36%. Consistent with the framework, more central and proximate monitors lead to larger increases in savings. Moreover, information flows through the network, with 63% of monitors telling others about the saver's progress. Fifteen months after the conclusion of the experiment, other villagers have updated their beliefs about the saver's responsibility in response to the intervention.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: A Network Formation Model Based on Subgraphs
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We develop a new class of random graph models for the statistical estimation of network formation—subgraph generated models (SUGMs). Various subgraphs—e.g. links, triangles, cliques, stars—are generated and their union results in a network. We show that SUGMs are identified and establish the consistency and asymptotic distribution of parameter estimators in empirically relevant cases. We show that a simple four-parameter SUGM matches basic patterns in empirical networks more closely than four standard models (with many more dimensions): (1) stochastic block models; (2) models with node-level unobserved heterogeneity; (3) latent space models; and (4) exponential random graphs. We illustrate the framework’s value via several applications using networks from rural India. We study whether network structure helps enforce risk-sharing and whether cross-caste interactions are more likely to be private. We also develop a new central limit theorem for correlated random variables, which is required to prove our results and is of independent interest.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a new statistical model for network formation that better captures empirical network patterns than existing approaches?
answer: The paper develops Subgraph Generated Models (SUGMs) where networks are formed by generating various subgraphs (links, triangles, cliques, stars) and taking their union. A simple four-parameter SUGM matches basic patterns in empirical networks more closely than four standard models with many more dimensions: stochastic block models, models with node-level unobserved heterogeneity, latent space models, and exponential random graphs.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as offering a superior alternative to existing network formation models by developing SUGMs that outperform four standard approaches (stochastic block models, node-level heterogeneity models, latent space models, and exponential random graphs) while using fewer parameters and better matching empirical network patterns.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: When Less Is More: Experimental Evidence on Information Delivery During India’s Demonetisation
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>In disseminating information, policymakers face a choice between broadcasting to everyone and informing a small number of “seeds” who then spread the message. While broadcasting maximises the initial reach of messages, we offer theoretical and experimental evidence that it need not be the best strategy. In a field experiment during the 2016 Indian demonetisation, we delivered policy information, varying three dimensions of the delivery method at the village level: initial reach (broadcasting versus seeding); whether or not we induced common knowledge of who was initially informed; and number of facts delivered. We measured three outcomes: the volume of conversations about demonetisation, knowledge of demonetisation rules, and choice quality in a strongly incentivised policy-dependent decision. On all three outcomes, under common knowledge, seeding dominates broadcasting; moreover, adding common knowledge makes seeding more effective but broadcasting less so. We interpret our results via a model of image concerns deterring engagement in social learning, and we support this interpretation with evidence on differential behaviour across ability categories.</jats:p>
research_question: When disseminating policy information, is it more effective for policymakers to broadcast information to everyone or to inform a small number of 'seeds' who then spread the message?
answer: Seeding (informing a small number of people who then spread information) is more effective than broadcasting when there is common knowledge of who was initially informed, leading to better outcomes in conversation volume, knowledge of policy rules, and decision-making quality.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on information dissemination by providing both theoretical and experimental evidence that challenges the assumption that maximizing initial reach through broadcasting is optimal, instead showing that targeted seeding can be superior under certain conditions involving common knowledge and social learning dynamics.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: Testing Models of Social Learning on Networks: Evidence From Two Experiments
abstract: <jats:p>We theoretically and empirically study an incomplete information model of social learning. Agents initially guess the binary state of the world after observing a private signal. In subsequent rounds, agents observe their network neighbors' previous guesses before guessing again. Agents are drawn from a mixture of learning types—Bayesian, who face incomplete information about others' types, and DeGroot, who average their neighbors' previous period guesses and follow the majority. We study (1) learning features of both types of agents in our incomplete information model; (2) what network structures lead to failures of asymptotic learning; (3) whether realistic networks exhibit such structures. We conducted lab experiments with 665 subjects in Indian villages and 350 students from ITAM in Mexico. We perform a reduced‐form analysis and then structurally estimate the mixing parameter, finding the share of Bayesian agents to be 10% and 50% in the Indian‐villager and Mexican‐student samples, respectively.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different types of agents (Bayesian vs DeGroot) learn in social networks under incomplete information, what network structures lead to learning failures, and what is the distribution of these agent types in real populations?
answer: The study finds that only 10% of Indian villagers behave as Bayesian learners while 50% of Mexican students do, with the remainder following DeGroot averaging behavior. Certain network structures can lead to asymptotic learning failures, and these problematic structures do exist in realistic networks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the social learning literature by introducing an incomplete information model that incorporates a mixture of learning types (Bayesian and DeGroot agents) and provides empirical validation through field experiments, addressing gaps in understanding how heterogeneous learning behaviors affect information aggregation in networks.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: Using Gossips to Spread Information: Theory and Evidence from Two Randomized Controlled Trials
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Can we identify highly central individuals in a network without collecting network data, simply by asking community members? Can seeding information via such nominated individuals lead to significantly wider diffusion than via randomly chosen people, or even respected ones? In two separate large field experiments in India, we answer both questions in the affirmative. In particular, in 521 villages in Haryana, we provided information on monthly immunization camps to either randomly selected individuals (in some villages) or to individuals nominated by villagers as people who would be good at transmitting information (in other villages). We find that the number of children vaccinated every month is 22% higher in villages in which nominees received the information. We show that people’s knowledge of who are highly central individuals and good seeds can be explained by a model in which community members simply track how often they hear gossip about others. Indeed, we find in a third data set that nominated seeds are central in a network sense, and are not just those with many friends or in powerful positions.</jats:p>
research_question: Can we identify highly central individuals in a network without collecting network data by asking community members, and does seeding information via such nominated individuals lead to significantly wider diffusion than via randomly chosen people?
answer: Yes to both questions - community members can effectively identify highly central individuals without network data collection, and seeding information through these nominated individuals leads to 22% higher vaccination rates compared to random selection, with nominees being genuinely central in network terms rather than just popular or powerful.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the information diffusion literature by demonstrating that community nomination can substitute for costly network data collection in identifying optimal information seeds, and provides a theoretical model explaining this phenomenon through gossip-based tracking of centrality that goes beyond simple measures of friendship or social position.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: Using Aggregated Relational Data to Feasibly Identify Network Structure without Network Data
abstract: <jats:p> Social network data are often prohibitively expensive to collect, limiting empirical network research. We propose an inexpensive and feasible strategy for network elicitation using Aggregated Relational Data (ARD): responses to questions of the form “how many of your links have trait k ?” Our method uses ARD to recover parameters of a network formation model, which permits sampling from a distribution over node- or graph-level statistics. We replicate the results of two field experiments that used network data and draw similar conclusions with ARD alone. (JEL C81, C93, D85, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How can researchers feasibly identify network structure and recover network formation model parameters without collecting expensive social network data?
answer: Aggregated Relational Data (ARD) - responses to questions like 'how many of your links have trait k?' - can successfully recover parameters of network formation models and permit sampling from distributions over network statistics, as demonstrated by replicating results from two field experiments using ARD alone.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a key limitation in empirical network research by proposing an inexpensive alternative to costly social network data collection, positioning itself as a methodological contribution that makes network analysis more accessible and feasible for researchers.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: Naïve Learning with Uninformed Agents
abstract: <jats:p> The DeGroot model has emerged as a credible alternative to the standard Bayesian model for studying learning on networks, offering a natural way to model naïve learning in a complex setting. One unattractive aspect of this model is the assumption that the process starts with every node in the network having a signal. We study a natural extension of the DeGroot model that can deal with sparse initial signals. We show that an agent’s social influence in this generalized DeGroot model is essentially proportional to the degree-weighted share of uninformed nodes who will hear about an event for the first time via this agent. This characterization result then allows us to relate network geometry to information aggregation. We show information aggregation preserves “wisdom” in the sense that initial signals are weighed approximately equally in a model of network formation that captures the sparsity, clustering, and small-world properties of real-world networks. We also identify an example of a network structure where essentially only the signal of a single agent is aggregated, which helps us pinpoint a condition on the network structure necessary for almost full aggregation. Simulating the modeled learning process on a set of real-world networks, we find that there is on average 22.4 percent information loss in these networks. We also explore how correlation in the location of seeds can exacerbate aggregation failure. Simulations with real-world network data show that with clustered seeding, information loss climbs to 34.4 percent. (JEL D83, D85, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does social learning work in networks when only some agents initially have information signals, and what determines information aggregation quality in such sparse signal environments?
answer: An agent's social influence is proportional to the degree-weighted share of uninformed nodes who first hear about an event through that agent. Information aggregation can preserve 'wisdom' under certain network conditions, but real-world networks show 22.4% information loss on average, rising to 34.4% with clustered initial signals.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the DeGroot model of naïve learning by addressing a key limitation - the unrealistic assumption that all network nodes initially have signals - offering a more realistic alternative to standard Bayesian learning models for complex network settings.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: Not a Benign Market: An Analysis of Food Price Inflation and Volatility
abstract: <jats:p> Food inflation in India for the past few years has been at a historic high. However, the evidence suggests that higher food prices, while adversely affecting those who spend most of their income on food, have not necessarily been helpful to smallholder farmers. The volatility of food prices at the wholesale and retail levels has also remained high, creating uncertainties for consumers and producers. This article reviews recent trends in food prices in India, examines the sources of food price increases and volatility, separates the relative roles of demand–supply imbalances, cost-push factors and speculation and draws out some of the implications of those factors. </jats:p>
venue: Agrarian South: Journal of Political Economy: A triannual Journal of Agrarian South Network and CARES
research_question: What are the sources and implications of food price inflation and volatility in India, and how do these factors affect different stakeholders including consumers and smallholder farmers?
answer: Food price inflation in India has reached historic highs with high volatility at both wholesale and retail levels. While higher food prices adversely affect consumers who spend most of their income on food, they have not necessarily benefited smallholder farmers. The price volatility creates uncertainties for both consumers and producers.
positioning_statement: This paper reviews recent trends in food prices in India and examines the relative roles of demand-supply imbalances, cost-push factors, and speculation in driving food price increases and volatility, contributing to the literature on food price dynamics in emerging markets.

author: Arun Chandrasekhar
title: Network Structure and the Aggregation of Information: Theory and Evidence from Indonesia
abstract: <jats:p> We use unique data from over 600 Indonesian communities on what individuals know about the poverty status of others to study how network structure influences information aggregation. We develop a model of semi-Bayesian learning on networks, which we structurally estimate using within-village data. The model generates qualitative predictions about how cross-village patterns of learning relate to network structure, which we show are borne out in the data. We apply our findings to a community-based targeting program, where citizens chose households to receive aid, and show that the networks that the model predicts to be more diffusive differentially benefit from community targeting. (JEL D14, D83, D85, I32, O12, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does network structure influence information aggregation, specifically regarding individuals' knowledge about the poverty status of others in their communities?
answer: Network structure significantly affects information aggregation through semi-Bayesian learning processes, with networks predicted to be more diffusive showing better performance in community-based targeting programs where citizens choose aid recipients.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing and structurally estimating a model of semi-Bayesian learning on networks using unique community-level data, providing both theoretical predictions and empirical validation of how network structure affects information diffusion in real-world policy applications.

author: Ashley Langer
title: Policy Uncertainty in the Market for Coal Electricity: The Case of Air Toxics Standards

author: Ashley Langer
title: Escalation of Scrutiny: The Gains from Dynamic Enforcement of Environmental Regulations
abstract: <jats:p> The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) uses a dynamic approach to enforcing air pollution regulations, with repeat offenders subject to high fines and designation as high priority violators (HPV). We estimate the value of dynamic enforcement by developing and estimating a dynamic model of a plant and regulator, where plants decide when to invest in pollution abatement technologies. We use a fixed grid approach to estimate random coefficient specifications. Investment, fines, and HPV designation are costly to most plants. Eliminating dynamic enforcement would raise pollution damages by 164 percent with constant fines or raise fines by 519 percent with constant pollution damages. (JEL Q52, Q53, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the value of the EPA's dynamic enforcement approach to air pollution regulations, where repeat offenders face escalating penalties and high priority violator designation?
answer: Dynamic enforcement is highly valuable - eliminating it would either increase pollution damages by 164% (if fines remain constant) or require fines to increase by 519% (to maintain constant pollution damages).
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the environmental regulation literature by developing and estimating a dynamic model that quantifies the specific value of escalating enforcement mechanisms, moving beyond static analyses to capture how the threat of increased scrutiny affects plant investment decisions in pollution abatement technologies.

author: Attila Lindner
title: Who Pays for the Minimum Wage?
abstract: <jats:p> This paper provides a comprehensive assessment of the margins along which firms responded to a large and persistent minimum wage increase in Hungary. We show that employment elasticities are negative but small even four years after the reform; that around 75 percent of the minimum wage increase was paid by consumers and 25 percent by firm owners; that firms responded to the minimum wage by substituting labor with capital; and that disemployment effects were greater in industries where passing the wage costs to consumers is more difficult. We estimate a model with monopolistic competition to explain these findings. (JEL J23, J24, J31, J38, L13) </jats:p>
research_question: How do firms respond to minimum wage increases across different margins, specifically examining who bears the cost burden of minimum wage policy?
answer: Around 75 percent of minimum wage increases are passed on to consumers through higher prices, while 25 percent is absorbed by firm owners; employment effects are negative but small even four years after implementation; firms substitute labor with capital; and disemployment effects are larger in industries where it's harder to pass costs to consumers.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a comprehensive assessment of firm responses to minimum wage increases by examining multiple adjustment margins simultaneously, using a large and persistent minimum wage reform in Hungary as a natural experiment and developing a monopolistic competition model to explain the empirical findings.

author: Attila Lindner
title: Reallocation Effects of the Minimum Wage
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate the wage, employment, and reallocation effects of the introduction of a nationwide minimum wage in Germany that affected 15% of all employees. Based on identification designs that exploit variation in exposure across individuals and local areas, we find that the minimum wage raised wages but did not lower employment. It also led to the reallocation of low-wage workers from smaller to larger, from lower- to higher-paying, and from less to more productive establishments. This worker upgrading accounts for up to 17% of the wage increase induced by the minimum wage. Moreover, at the regional level, average establishment quality increased in more affected areas in the years following the introduction of the minimum wage.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the wage, employment, and reallocation effects of the introduction of a nationwide minimum wage in Germany?
answer: The minimum wage raised wages without lowering employment and led to reallocation of low-wage workers from smaller to larger, lower- to higher-paying, and less to more productive establishments, with worker upgrading accounting for up to 17% of the wage increase.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the minimum wage literature by focusing on reallocation effects and worker upgrading mechanisms, using the introduction of Germany's nationwide minimum wage as a natural experiment to examine effects beyond traditional wage and employment outcomes.

author: Aureo de Paula
title: A Dialética Valores e Preços
abstract: <jats:p>RESUMO A maior parte do debate sobre o chamado “problema de transformação”; que deriva da crítica de Böhm-Bawerck ao terceiro volume do Capital, tem um quadro de referência que atribui pressupostos e uma metodologia a Marx mais adequada à teoria Walrasiana. Este artigo discute essa questão visando dois objetivos diferentes. Ele aponta as consequências problemáticas para a teoria marxista de valores e preços da aceitação dos pressupostos da abordagem do equilíbrio. Por outro lado, oferece um argumento para enfrentar o “problema de transformação” de um ponto de vista estritamente dialético.</jats:p>
research_question: How should the Marxist transformation problem be approached from a dialectical perspective rather than through Walrasian equilibrium assumptions?
answer: The transformation problem should be addressed using a strictly dialectical approach that avoids the problematic consequences of accepting equilibrium theory assumptions, which are inappropriate for Marx's methodology.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself against the mainstream debate on the transformation problem that incorrectly applies Walrasian theoretical assumptions and methodology to Marx's work, arguing instead for an approach consistent with Marx's own dialectical method.

author: Attila Lindner
title: Reference-Dependent Job Search: Evidence from Hungary*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a model of job search with reference-dependent preferences, with loss aversion relative to recent income (the reference point). In this model, newly unemployed individuals search hard since consumption is below their reference point. Over time, though, they get used to lower income and thus reduce their search effort. In anticipation of a benefit cut, their search effort rises again, then declines once they get accustomed to the lower postcut benefit level. The model fits the typical pattern of exit from unemployment, even with no unobserved heterogeneity. To distinguish between this and other models, we use a unique reform in the unemployment insurance (UI) benefit path. In 2005, Hungary switched from a single-step UI system to a two-step system, with overall generosity unchanged. The system generated increased hazard rates in anticipation of, and especially following, benefit cuts in ways the standard model has a hard time explaining. We estimate a model with optimal consumption, endogenous search effort, and unobserved heterogeneity. The reference-dependent model fits the hazard rates substantially better than plausible versions of the standard model, including habit formation. Our estimates indicate a slow-adjusting reference point and substantial impatience, likely reflecting present-bias.</jats:p>
research_question: How do reference-dependent preferences with loss aversion relative to recent income affect job search behavior and unemployment duration patterns?
answer: The reference-dependent model with loss aversion explains unemployment exit patterns better than standard models - newly unemployed individuals search hard when consumption is below their reference point, reduce effort as they adapt to lower income, then increase search effort again before benefit cuts and decline afterward as they adjust to new benefit levels.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes an alternative to standard job search models by incorporating reference-dependent preferences and loss aversion, demonstrating that this approach fits observed unemployment hazard patterns substantially better than existing models including habit formation, even without relying on unobserved heterogeneity.

author: Attila Lindner
title: The Effect of Minimum Wages on Low-Wage Jobs*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We estimate the effect of minimum wages on low-wage jobs using 138 prominent state-level minimum wage changes between 1979 and 2016 in the United States using a difference-in-differences approach. We first estimate the effect of the minimum wage increase on employment changes by wage bins throughout the hourly wage distribution. We then focus on the bottom part of the wage distribution and compare the number of excess jobs paying at or slightly above the new minimum wage to the missing jobs paying below it to infer the employment effect. We find that the overall number of low-wage jobs remained essentially unchanged over the five years following the increase. At the same time, the direct effect of the minimum wage on average earnings was amplified by modest wage spillovers at the bottom of the wage distribution. Our estimates by detailed demographic groups show that the lack of job loss is not explained by labor-labor substitution at the bottom of the wage distribution. We also find no evidence of disemployment when we consider higher levels of minimum wages. However, we do find some evidence of reduced employment in tradeable sectors. We also show how decomposing the overall employment effect by wage bins allows a transparent way of assessing the plausibility of estimates.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of minimum wage increases on employment of low-wage jobs?
answer: The overall number of low-wage jobs remained essentially unchanged over the five years following minimum wage increases, with no evidence of significant job loss, while average earnings increased due to direct wage effects and modest wage spillovers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the extensive minimum wage literature by using a novel methodological approach that decomposes employment effects by wage bins and compares excess jobs at/above the new minimum wage to missing jobs below it, providing a more transparent way to assess the plausibility of employment effect estimates using 138 prominent state-level minimum wage changes from 1979-2016.

author: Axelle Ferriere
title: The Heterogeneous Effects of Government Spending: It’s All About Taxes
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Historically, large changes in U.S. government spending induced fiscal efforts that were not all alike, with some using more progressive taxes than others. We develop a heterogeneous-agent New Keynesian model to analyse how the distribution of taxes across households shapes spending multipliers. The model yields empirically realistic distributions in marginal propensities to consume and labour elasticities, which result in lower responsiveness to tax changes for higher-income earners. In turn, multipliers are larger when spending is financed with higher tax progressivity—that is, when the tax burden falls more heavily on higher-income earners. This result is historically material. We estimate that, on average, tax rates increased more for top-income than for bottom-income earners after a spending shock. Thus, the typical U.S. spending shock was financed with higher tax progressivity. We further exploit the historical variation in the financing of spending to estimate progressivity-dependent multipliers, which we find consistent with the model.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the distribution of taxes across households shape government spending multipliers?
answer: Spending multipliers are larger when government spending is financed with higher tax progressivity (i.e., when the tax burden falls more heavily on higher-income earners), because higher-income earners have lower responsiveness to tax changes due to their lower marginal propensities to consume and labor elasticities.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on government spending multipliers by highlighting that the heterogeneous effects depend on the progressivity of tax financing, exploiting historical variation in U.S. fiscal efforts where spending shocks were typically financed with higher tax progressivity, and using a heterogeneous-agent New Keynesian model that generates empirically realistic distributions of household responses.

author: Axelle Ferriere
title: On the Optimal Design of Transfers and Income Tax Progressivity
abstract: We study the optimal design of means-tested transfers and progressive income taxes. In a simple analytical model, we show that adding a transfer to a log-linear tax induces welfare gains almost as large as in the second-best allocation. Transfers allow for more progressive average than marginal tax and transfer rates, achieving redistribution while preserving efficiency. In a rich dynamic model, we quantify the optimal fiscal plan. We use new flexible functions featuring targeted transfers and progressive income taxes, delivering a good empirical fit across the income distribution. Transfers should be larger than currently in the United States and financed with moderate income tax progressivity.

author: B. Kelsey Jack
title: Pay as You Go: Prepaid Metering and Electricity Expenditures in South Africa
abstract: <jats:p> High rates of customer default on utility bills present a barrier to the expansion of electricity access in the developing world. Pre-paid electricity metering offers a technological solution to ensuring timely payment. Using an eleven-year panel of pre-paid electricity customers in Cape Town, South Africa, we describe patterns of purchase behavior across property values, our measure of socioeconomic status. Poorer households buy electricity more often, in smaller increments, and are most likely to buy on payday. These patterns suggest difficulties smoothing income, and reveal a preference for small, frequent purchases that is incompatible with a standard monthly electricity billing cycle. </jats:p>
research_question: How do prepaid electricity metering systems affect electricity purchase behavior patterns across different socioeconomic groups, and what do these patterns reveal about income smoothing difficulties and payment preferences?
answer: Poorer households buy electricity more frequently in smaller increments and are most likely to purchase on payday, indicating difficulties with income smoothing and a preference for small, frequent purchases that is incompatible with standard monthly billing cycles.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the barrier of high customer default rates on utility bills that impede electricity access expansion in developing countries by examining prepaid metering as a technological solution, using detailed behavioral data to reveal previously undocumented patterns in electricity purchasing behavior across socioeconomic groups.

author: B. Kelsey Jack
title: Seasonal Liquidity, Rural Labor Markets, and Agricultural Production
abstract: <jats:p> Rural economies in many developing countries are characterized by a lean season in the months preceding harvest, when farmers have depleted their cash and grain savings from the previous year. To identify the impacts of liquidity during the lean season, we offered subsidized loans in randomly selected villages in rural Zambia. Ninety-eight percent of households took up the loan. Loan eligibility led to increases in on-farm labor and agricultural output, driving up wages in local labor markets. Larger effects for poorer households suggest that liquidity constraints contribute to inequality in rural economies. (JEL O13, O15, O18, Q11, Q12, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the impacts of liquidity constraints during the lean season on agricultural production and rural labor markets in developing countries?
answer: Providing subsidized loans during the lean season increases on-farm labor and agricultural output, drives up local wages, and has larger effects for poorer households, demonstrating that liquidity constraints contribute to inequality in rural economies.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the understudied issue of seasonal liquidity constraints in rural developing economies by using a randomized controlled trial to identify causal impacts on agricultural production and labor markets, contributing to literature on rural finance, agricultural productivity, and inequality in developing countries.

author: B. Kelsey Jack
title: Poor and Rational: Decision-Making under Scarcity
abstract: We investigate the link between poverty and decision-making in a sample of farmers in Zambia, who were given the opportunity to exchange randomly assigned household items for alternative items of similar value. Analyzing a total of 5,842 trading decisions and leveraging multiple sources of variation in financial constraints, we show that exchange asymmetries decrease in magnitude when participants are more constrained. This result is robust to experimental procedures and is not mediated by changes in cognitive performance. Consistent with the interpretation that scarcity leads to more rational decisions by increasing the utility loss from forgone trading, we show that trading probabilities go up when the market value of the items is exogenously increased.

author: B. Kelsey Jack
title: Money (Not) to Burn: Payments for Ecosystem Services to Reduce Crop Residue Burning
abstract: <jats:p> We test whether payments for ecosystem services (PES) can curb the highly polluting practice of crop residue burning in India. Standard PES contracts pay participants after verification that they met a proenvironment condition (clearing fields without burning). We randomize paying a portion of the money up front and unconditionally to address liquidity constraints and farmer distrust, which may undermine the standard contract’s effectiveness. Incorporating partial up-front payment into the contract increases compliance by 10 percentage points, which is corroborated by satellite-based burning measurements. The cost per life saved is $3,600–$5,400. The standard PES contract has no effect on burning. (JEL D86, O13, Q12, Q15, Q18, Q53, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: Can payments for ecosystem services (PES) effectively reduce crop residue burning in India, and does incorporating partial up-front payment improve contract effectiveness compared to standard PES contracts?
answer: Standard PES contracts have no effect on crop residue burning, but incorporating partial up-front payment into PES contracts increases compliance by 10 percentage points, with a cost per life saved of $3,600–$5,400.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the payments for ecosystem services literature by testing a novel contract design modification (partial up-front payment) to address liquidity constraints and farmer distrust that may undermine standard PES contract effectiveness, specifically in the context of reducing crop residue burning pollution in India.

author: Benjamin Faber
title: Trade Integration, Market Size, and Industrialization: Evidence from China's National Trunk Highway System
abstract: Are falling trade costs a force for the diffusion of production to peripheral regions or do they reinforce the concentration of production in space?

author: Benjamin Faber
title: Tourism and Economic Development: Evidence from Mexico’s Coastline
abstract: <jats:p> Tourism is a fast-growing services sector in developing countries. This paper combines a rich collection of Mexican microdata with a quantitative spatial equilibrium model and a new empirical strategy to study the long-term economic consequences of tourism both locally and in the aggregate. We find that tourism causes large and significant local economic gains relative to less touristic regions that are in part driven by significant positive spillovers on manufacturing. In the aggregate, however, these local spillovers are largely offset by reductions in agglomeration economies among less touristic regions, so that the national gains from trade in tourism are mainly driven by a classical market integration effect. (JEL L60, L83, O14, O18, R11, Z31, Z32) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-term economic consequences of tourism both locally and in the aggregate?
answer: Tourism causes large and significant local economic gains with positive spillovers on manufacturing, but in the aggregate these local spillovers are offset by reduced agglomeration economies in less touristic regions, so national gains are mainly driven by market integration effects rather than spillovers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the tourism and economic development literature by combining rich Mexican microdata with a quantitative spatial equilibrium model and a new empirical strategy to distinguish between local versus aggregate effects of tourism development.

author: Benjamin Faber
title: Firm Heterogeneity in Consumption Baskets: Evidence from Home and Store Scanner Data
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A growing literature has documented the role of firm heterogeneity within sectors for nominal income inequality. This article explores the implications for household price indices across the income distribution. Using detailed matched U.S. home and store scanner microdata, we present evidence that rich and poor households source their consumption differently across the firm size distribution within disaggregated product groups. We use the data to examine alternative explanations, propose a tractable quantitative model with two-sided heterogeneity that rationalizes the observed moments, and calibrate it to explore general equilibrium counterfactuals. We find that larger, more productive firms sort into catering to the taste of richer households, and that this gives rise to asymmetric effects on household price indices. We quantify these effects in the context of policy counterfactuals that affect the distribution of disposable incomes on the demand side or profits across firms on the supply side.</jats:p>
research_question: How does firm heterogeneity within sectors affect household price indices across the income distribution, given that households of different income levels source their consumption differently across firms of varying sizes?
answer: Larger, more productive firms sort into catering to the taste of richer households, which creates asymmetric effects on household price indices across the income distribution, with differential impacts on rich versus poor households' consumption costs.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the growing literature documenting firm heterogeneity's role in nominal income inequality by extending the analysis to examine the consumption side implications, specifically how firm heterogeneity affects household price indices across income levels - an area that has received less attention in existing research.

author: Benjamin Faber
title: Retail Globalization and Household Welfare: Evidence from Mexico
abstract: What are the implications of foreign retail entry for household welfare in developing countries?

author: Benjamin Faber
title: Connecting the Countryside via E-Commerce: Evidence from China
abstract: <jats:p> This paper estimates the impact of the first nationwide e-commerce expansion program on rural households. To do so, we combine a randomized control trial with new survey and administrative microdata. In contrast to existing case studies, we find little evidence for income gains to rural producers and workers. Instead, the gains are driven by a reduction in cost of living for a minority of rural households that tend to be younger, richer, and in more remote markets. These effects are mainly due to overcoming logistical barriers to e-commerce rather than additional investments to adapt e-commerce to the rural population. (JEL I31, L81, O12, O18, P25, P36) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of the first nationwide e-commerce expansion program on rural households in China?
answer: The program provided little evidence for income gains to rural producers and workers, but instead generated gains through reduced cost of living for a minority of rural households that tend to be younger, richer, and in more remote markets, primarily by overcoming logistical barriers rather than through additional investments to adapt e-commerce to rural populations.
positioning_statement: In contrast to existing case studies, this paper uses a randomized control trial combined with new survey and administrative microdata to provide more rigorous evidence on e-commerce impacts in rural areas, challenging previous findings that suggested broader income benefits.

author: Benjamin Handel
title: Adverse Selection and Inertia in Health Insurance Markets: When Nudging Hurts
abstract: <jats:p> This paper investigates consumer inertia in health insurance markets, where adverse selection is a potential concern. We leverage a major change to insurance provision that occurred at a large firm to identify substantial inertia, and develop and estimate a choice model that also quantifies risk preferences and ex ante health risk. We use these estimates to study the impact of policies that nudge consumers toward better decisions by reducing inertia. When aggregated, these improved individual-level choices substantially exacerbate adverse selection in our setting, leading to an overall reduction in welfare that doubles the existing welfare loss from adverse selection. (JEL D82, G22, I13) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of policies that reduce consumer inertia (nudging) on adverse selection and welfare in health insurance markets?
answer: Nudging policies that reduce consumer inertia and improve individual-level choices substantially exacerbate adverse selection, leading to an overall reduction in welfare that doubles the existing welfare loss from adverse selection.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on consumer inertia in health insurance markets by investigating the previously understudied interaction between inertia-reducing policies and adverse selection, using a major change in insurance provision at a large firm to identify and quantify these effects.

author: Benjamin Handel
title: Wearable Technologies and Health Behaviors: New Data and New Methods to Understand Population Health
abstract: <jats:p> We study a randomized control trial in a large employer population of access to “wearable” technologies and the associated planning and monitoring tools on improved health behaviors (sleep and exercise). Both ITT and IV estimates based on actual plan enrollment for the treatment group suggest statistically significant but economically small changes in behavior after three months. We then implement machine learning-based models to assess treatment effect heterogeneity. We find little evidence for heterogeneous treatment effects base on observables. We also present detailed data on sleep patterns underscoring the value of this new data source to researchers. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of access to wearable technologies and associated planning and monitoring tools on health behaviors (sleep and exercise) in a large employer population?
answer: Wearable technologies lead to statistically significant but economically small changes in health behaviors after three months, with little evidence for heterogeneous treatment effects based on observable characteristics.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using new data sources (wearable technology data) and new methods (machine learning-based models) to understand population health behaviors, specifically highlighting the value of detailed sleep pattern data as a new data source for researchers.

author: Benjamin Faber
title: Measuring Welfare and Inequality with Incomplete Price Information
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We propose and implement a new approach that allows us to estimate income-specific changes in household welfare in contexts where well-measured prices are not available for important subsets of consumption. Using rich but widely available expenditure survey microdata, we show that we can recover income-specific equivalent and compensating variations from horizontal shifts in what we call “relative Engel curves”—as long as preferences fall within the broad quasi-separable class (Gorman 1970, 1976). Our approach is flexible enough to allow for nonparametric estimation at each point of the income distribution. We apply the methodology to estimate inflation and welfare changes in rural India between 1987 and 2000. Our estimates reveal that lower rates of inflation for the rich erased the real income convergence found in the existing literature that uses the subset of consumption with well-measured prices to calculate inflation.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure income-specific changes in household welfare and inequality when well-measured prices are not available for important subsets of consumption?
answer: The authors develop a new approach using 'relative Engel curves' from expenditure survey microdata that can recover income-specific equivalent and compensating variations under quasi-separable preferences, revealing that lower inflation rates for the rich erased real income convergence in rural India between 1987-2000.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in existing literature by providing a methodology that works when well-measured prices are unavailable for important consumption categories, contrasting with existing studies that rely only on subsets of consumption with well-measured prices and may therefore miss important distributional effects.

author: Benjamin Handel
title: Health Insurance for “Humans”: Information Frictions, Plan Choice, and Consumer Welfare
abstract: <jats:p> Traditional models of insurance choice are predicated on fully informed and rational consumers protecting themselves from exposure to financial risk. In practice, choosing an insurance plan is a complicated decision often made without full information. In this paper we combine new administrative data on health plan choices and claims with unique survey data on consumer information to identify risk preferences, information frictions, and hassle costs. Our additional friction measures are important predictors of choices and meaningfully impact risk preference estimates. We study the implications of counterfactual insurance allocations to illustrate the importance of distinguishing between these micro-foundations for welfare analysis. (JEL D81, D8 3, G22, I13) </jats:p>
research_question: How do information frictions, hassle costs, and limited consumer information affect health insurance plan choice and consumer welfare, beyond traditional models that assume fully informed and rational consumers?
answer: Information frictions and hassle costs are important predictors of insurance choices that meaningfully impact risk preference estimates, and distinguishing between these micro-foundations (rather than assuming full information and rationality) has significant implications for welfare analysis.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges traditional models of insurance choice that assume fully informed and rational consumers by incorporating real-world complexities of information frictions and hassle costs, using novel administrative and survey data to provide a more realistic framework for understanding consumer behavior in health insurance markets.

author: Benjamin Handel
title: The Socioeconomic Distribution of Choice Quality: Evidence from Health Insurance in the Netherlands
abstract: <jats:p> We study how choice quality relates to socioeconomic factors, using population-wide data on health insurance choices and utilization in the Netherlands. We document a striking choice quality gradient with respect to socioeconomic status, finding that those with higher income, higher education, and training in quantitative fields make meaningfully better choices. Household income for the top 5 percent of decision-makers, in terms of surplus captured, is almost three times higher than for the bottom 5 percent. When jointly including all factors, education degree and field of study are more important predictors of choice quality than income and other financial variables. (JEL D31, G22, G52, I13, L15) </jats:p>
research_question: How does choice quality in health insurance decisions relate to socioeconomic factors such as income, education, and field of study?
answer: There is a striking choice quality gradient with respect to socioeconomic status - those with higher income, higher education, and training in quantitative fields make meaningfully better health insurance choices, with education degree and field of study being more important predictors than income when all factors are considered jointly.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing population-wide empirical evidence on the relationship between socioeconomic characteristics and decision-making quality in health insurance markets, using comprehensive data from the Netherlands to quantify how choice quality varies across different demographic and economic groups.

author: Benjamin Handel
title: Messaging and the Mandate: The Impact of Consumer Experience on Health Insurance Enrollment Through Exchanges
abstract: <jats:p> The ability of web-based retailers to learn about and provide targeted consumer experiences is touted as an important distinction from traditional retailers. In principal, web-based insurance exchanges could benefit from these advantages. Using data from a large-scale experiment by a private sector health insurance exchange we estimate the returns to experimentation and targeted messaging. We find significant improvements in conversions in one treatment tested. Underlying the average impact were both intertemporal and demographic heterogeneity. We estimate that learning and targeted messaging could increase insurance applications by approximately 13 percent of the baseline conversion rate. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the returns to experimentation and targeted messaging on health insurance enrollment through web-based exchanges?
answer: Learning and targeted messaging could increase insurance applications by approximately 13 percent of the baseline conversion rate, with significant improvements in conversions found in one treatment tested, driven by both intertemporal and demographic heterogeneity.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as examining how web-based insurance exchanges could benefit from the advantages of targeted consumer experiences that distinguish web-based retailers from traditional retailers, specifically focusing on the potential for learning and personalization in the health insurance exchange context.

author: Benjamin Keys
title: The Cost of Consumer Collateral: Evidence From Bunching
abstract: <jats:p>How do collateral requirements impact consumer borrowing behavior? Using administrative loan application and performance data from the U.S. Federal Disaster Loan Program, we exploit a loan amount threshold above which households must post their residence as collateral. Our bunching estimates suggest that the median borrower is willing to give up 40% of their loan amount to avoid posting collateral. Exploiting time variation in the threshold, we estimate collateral causally reduces default rates by 36%. Finally, we structurally estimate households' attachment to their homes, net of any equity, and find a median value of $11,000. Attachment creates a wedge between lender and borrower valuation of collateral of 15%. Our results explain high perceived default costs in the mortgage market, and document the importance of collateral for reducing moral hazard in consumer credit markets.</jats:p>
research_question: How do collateral requirements impact consumer borrowing behavior?
answer: The median borrower is willing to give up 40% of their loan amount to avoid posting collateral, collateral causally reduces default rates by 36%, and households have a median attachment value to their homes of $11,000 net of equity, creating a 15% wedge between lender and borrower valuation of collateral.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding high perceived default costs in the mortgage market and documents the importance of collateral for reducing moral hazard in consumer credit markets, using novel bunching methodology and administrative data from the Federal Disaster Loan Program to provide causal evidence on collateral effects.

author: Benjamin Keys
title: Interest Rates and Equity Extraction During the Housing Boom
abstract: <jats:p> Credit record panel data from 1999–2010 indicates that the likelihood of home equity extraction (borrowing, on average, about $40,000 against one's home) peaked in 2003 when mortgage rates reached historic lows. We estimate a 27 percent rise in extraction in response to a 100 basis point rate decline, and that house price growth amplifies this relationship. Differential responses to interest rates and home price appreciation by borrower age and credit score provide new evidence of financial frictions. Finally, equity extractions are associated with higher default risk, consistent with the use of borrowed funds for consumption or illiquid investment. (JEL D14, E43, E52, G12, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How do interest rates affect home equity extraction behavior during the housing boom, and what are the implications for borrower risk?
answer: A 100 basis point decline in mortgage rates leads to a 27 percent increase in home equity extraction, with this effect amplified by house price growth. Equity extraction peaked in 2003 when rates hit historic lows, and such extractions are associated with higher default risk.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new evidence of financial frictions by examining differential responses to interest rates and home price appreciation across borrower demographics (age and credit score), and contributes to understanding the relationship between monetary policy, housing wealth extraction, and borrower risk during the housing boom period.

author: Benjamin Keys
title: Did Securitization Lead to Lax Screening? Evidence from Subprime Loans<sup>*</sup>

author: Benjamin Moll
title: Productivity Losses from Financial Frictions: Can Self-Financing Undo Capital Misallocation?
abstract: <jats:p> I develop a highly tractable general equilibrium model in which heterogeneous producers face collateral constraints, and study the effect of financial frictions on capital misallocation and aggregate productivity. My economy is isomorphic to a Solow model but with time-varying TFP. I argue that the persistence of idiosyncratic productivity shocks determines both the size of steady-state productivity losses and the speed of transitions: if shocks are persistent, steady-state losses are small but transitions are slow. Even if financial frictions are unimportant in the long run, they tend to matter in the short run and analyzing steady states only can be misleading. (JEL E21, E22, E23, G32, L26, O16) </jats:p>
research_question: How do financial frictions affect capital misallocation and aggregate productivity, and can self-financing mechanisms mitigate these effects over time?
answer: The persistence of idiosyncratic productivity shocks determines both the magnitude of steady-state productivity losses and transition speed - when shocks are persistent, steady-state losses are small but transitions are slow. Financial frictions may be unimportant in the long run but tend to matter significantly in the short run.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financial frictions and capital misallocation by developing a highly tractable general equilibrium model that is isomorphic to a Solow model with time-varying TFP, and argues that analyzing only steady states can be misleading since short-run effects of financial frictions are important even when long-run effects are minimal.

author: Benjamin Keys
title: Regional Redistribution through the US Mortgage Market
abstract: <jats:p> Regional shocks are an important feature of the US economy. Households' ability to self-insure against these shocks depends on how they affect local interest rates. In the United States, most borrowing occurs through the mortgage market and is influenced by the presence of government-sponsored enterprises (GSE). We establish that despite large regional variation in predictable default risk, GSE mortgage rates for otherwise identical loans do not vary spatially. In contrast, the private market does set interest rates which vary with local risk. We use a spatial model of collateralized borrowing to show that the national interest rate policy substantially affects welfare by redistributing resources across regions. (JEL E32, E43, G21, G28, L32, R11, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How do government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs) affect regional redistribution through mortgage interest rate policies, and what are the welfare implications of national versus spatially-varying interest rates?
answer: GSEs set uniform national mortgage rates despite large regional variation in predictable default risk, while private markets do vary rates with local risk. This national interest rate policy substantially affects welfare by redistributing resources across regions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on regional shocks and household self-insurance by examining the role of government-sponsored enterprises in the mortgage market, using a spatial model of collateralized borrowing to analyze welfare effects of uniform national interest rate policies versus market-based spatial variation.

author: Benjamin Moll
title: Optimal Development Policies With Financial Frictions
abstract: Is there a role for governments in emerging countries to accelerate economic development by intervening in product and factor markets? To address this question, we study optimal dynamic Ramsey policies in a standard growth model with financial frictions. The optimal policy intervention involves pro‐business policies like suppressed wages in early stages of the transition, resulting in higher entrepreneurial profits and faster wealth accumulation. This, in turn, relaxes borrowing constraints in the future, leading to higher labor productivity and wages. In the long run, optimal policy reverses sign and becomes pro‐worker. In a multi‐sector extension, optimal policy subsidizes sectors with a latent comparative advantage and, under certain circumstances, involves a depreciated real exchange rate. Our results provide an efficiency rationale, but also identify caveats, for many of the development policies actively pursued by dynamic emerging economies.

author: Benjamin Moll
title: Knowledge Growth and the Allocation of Time
abstract: We analyze a model economy with many agents, each with a different productivity level. Agents divide their time between two activities: producing goods with the production-related knowledge they already have and interacting with others in search of new, productivity-increasing ideas. These choices jointly determine the economy’s current production level and its rate of learning and real growth. We construct the balanced growth path for this economy. We also study the allocation chosen by an idealized planner who takes into account and internalizes the external benefits of search. Finally, we provide three examples of alternative learning technologies and show that the properties of equilibrium allocations are quite sensitive to two of these variations.

author: Benjamin Moll
title: Uneven Growth: Automation's Impact on Income and Wealth Inequality
abstract: <jats:p>The benefits of new technologies accrue not only to high‐skilled labor but also to owners of capital in the form of higher capital incomes. This increases inequality. To make this argument, we develop a tractable theory that links technology to the distribution of income and wealth—and not just that of wages—and use it to study the distributional effects of automation. We isolate a new theoretical mechanism: automation increases inequality by raising returns to wealth. The flip side of such return movements is that automation can lead to stagnant wages and, therefore, stagnant incomes at the bottom of the distribution. We use a multiasset model extension to confront differing empirical trends in returns to productive and safe assets and show that the relevant return measures have increased over time. Automation can account for part of the observed trends in income and wealth inequality.</jats:p>
research_question: How does automation affect income and wealth inequality through its impact on returns to capital and wages?
answer: Automation increases inequality by raising returns to wealth while leading to stagnant wages at the bottom of the distribution, with the benefits accruing to capital owners rather than just high-skilled labor.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theoretical mechanism linking technology to both income and wealth distribution (not just wages), extending beyond existing literature that primarily focuses on wage inequality to show how automation affects returns to capital and overall distributional outcomes.

author: Benjamin Moll
title: Present Bias Amplifies the Household Balance-Sheet Channels of Macroeconomic Policy
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
