               <jats:p>We study the effect of monetary and fiscal policy in a heterogeneous-agent model where households have present-biased time preferences and naive beliefs. The model features a liquid asset and illiquid home equity, which households can use as collateral for borrowing. Because present bias substantially increases households’ marginal propensity to consume (MPC), present bias increases the effect of fiscal policy. Present bias also amplifies the effect of monetary policy, but at the same time, slows down the speed of monetary transmission. Interest rate cuts incentivize households to conduct cash-out refinances, which become targeted liquidity injections to high-MPC households. Present bias also introduces a motive for households to procrastinate refinancing their mortgages, which slows down the speed with which this monetary channel operates.</jats:p>
research_question: How does present bias in household time preferences affect the transmission and effectiveness of monetary and fiscal policy through household balance-sheet channels?
answer: Present bias substantially increases households' marginal propensity to consume, which amplifies the effects of both fiscal and monetary policy. However, while present bias strengthens monetary policy transmission through cash-out refinances that provide targeted liquidity to high-MPC households, it simultaneously slows down the speed of monetary transmission due to household procrastination in mortgage refinancing.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the heterogeneous-agent macroeconomic literature by incorporating present-biased time preferences and naive beliefs into a model with liquid and illiquid assets, specifically examining how behavioral biases interact with household balance-sheet channels to affect macroeconomic policy transmission.

author: Benjamin Moll
title: Monetary Policy According to HANK
abstract: <jats:p> We revisit the transmission mechanism from monetary policy to household consumption in a Heterogeneous Agent New Keynesian (HANK) model. The model yields empirically realistic distributions of wealth and marginal propensities to consume because of two features: uninsurable income shocks and multiple assets with different degrees of liquidity and different returns. In this environment, the indirect effects of an unexpected cut in interest rates, which operate through a general equilibrium increase in labor demand, far outweigh direct effects such as intertemporal substitution. This finding is in stark contrast to small- and medium-scale Representative Agent New Keynesian (RANK) economies, where the substitution channel drives virtually all of the transmission from interest rates to consumption. Failure of Ricardian equivalence implies that, in HANK models, the fiscal reaction to the monetary expansion is a key determinant of the overall size of the macroeconomic response. (JEL D31, E12, E21, E24, E43, E52, E62) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the transmission mechanism from monetary policy to household consumption differ in a Heterogeneous Agent New Keynesian (HANK) model compared to Representative Agent New Keynesian (RANK) models?
answer: In HANK models, indirect effects of interest rate cuts through general equilibrium increases in labor demand far outweigh direct effects like intertemporal substitution, which is in stark contrast to RANK models where the substitution channel drives virtually all transmission from interest rates to consumption.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as revisiting and challenging the conventional understanding of monetary policy transmission by contrasting HANK models (which incorporate uninsurable income shocks and multiple assets with different liquidity and returns) against the established small- and medium-scale Representative Agent New Keynesian (RANK) framework that has dominated the literature.

author: Benjamin Moll
title: Life Cycle Wage Growth across Countries

author: Benjamin Moll
title: The Dynamics of Inequality
abstract: The past forty years have seen a rapid rise in top income inequality in the United States. While there is a large number of existing theories of the Pareto tail of the long‐run income distributions, almost none of these address the fast rise in top inequality observed in the data. We show that standard theories, which build on a random growth mechanism, generate transition dynamics that are too slow relative to those observed in the data. We then suggest two parsimonious deviations from the canonical model that can explain such changes: "scale dependence" that may arise from changes in skill prices, and "type dependence," that is, the presence of some "high‐growth types." These deviations are consistent with theories in which the increase in top income inequality is driven by the rise of "superstar" entrepreneurs or managers.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: Any Non‐welfarist Method of Policy Assessment Violates the Pareto Principle: A Comment

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: Second-Best Fairness: The Trade-Off between False Positives and False Negatives
abstract: <jats:p> A main focus in economics is how to design optimal policies in second-best situations, which often requires a trade-off between giving some individuals more than they deserve, false positives, and others less than they deserve, false negatives. This paper provides novel evidence on people’s second-best fairness preferences from large-scale experimental studies in the United States and Norway. The majority of people are more concerned with false negatives than with false positives, but we document substantial heterogeneity in second-best fairness preferences between the countries and across the political spectrum. The findings shed light on the political economy of social insurance and redistribution. (JEL D63, D72, D78, H23, I38) </jats:p>
research_question: What are people's preferences regarding the trade-off between false positives (giving individuals more than they deserve) and false negatives (giving individuals less than they deserve) in second-best policy situations?
answer: The majority of people are more concerned with false negatives than with false positives, but there is substantial heterogeneity in second-best fairness preferences between countries (United States and Norway) and across the political spectrum.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel evidence on people's second-best fairness preferences through large-scale experimental studies, contributing to the economics literature on optimal policy design in second-best situations and shedding light on the political economy of social insurance and redistribution.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: Cutthroat Capitalism versus Cuddly Socialism: Are Americans More Meritocratic and Efficiency-Seeking than Scandinavians?
abstract: There are striking differences in inequality and redistribution between the United States and Scandinavia. To study whether there are corresponding differences in social preferences, we conducted a large-scale international social preference experiment where Americans and Norwegians make distributive choices in identical environments. Combining the infrastructure of an international online labor market and that of a leading international data collection agency, we show that Americans and Norwegians differ significantly in fairness views, but not in the importance assigned to efficiency. We also provide causal evidence suggesting that fairness considerations are more fundamental for inequality acceptance than efficiency considerations.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: Just Luck: An Experimental Study of Risk-Taking and Fairness
abstract: <jats:p> Choices involving risk significantly affect the distribution of income and wealth in society. This paper reports the results of the first experiment, to our knowledge, to study fairness views about risk-taking, specifically whether such views are based chiefly on ex ante opportunities or on ex post outcomes. We find that, even though many participants focus exclusively on ex ante opportunities, most favor some redistribution ex post. Many participants also make a distinction between ex post inequalities that reflect differences in luck and ex post inequalities that reflect differences in choices. These findings apply to both stakeholders and impartial spectators. (JEL D63, D81, H23) </jats:p>
research_question: Whether fairness views about risk-taking are based chiefly on ex ante opportunities or on ex post outcomes, and how people view redistribution in contexts involving risk and luck.
answer: Most people favor some redistribution ex post even when ex ante opportunities were equal, and many participants distinguish between ex post inequalities due to luck versus those due to different choices. While some focus exclusively on ex ante opportunities, the majority support redistribution based on outcomes.
positioning_statement: This is the first experiment to study fairness views about risk-taking, specifically examining the distinction between ex ante opportunities and ex post outcomes in contexts involving risk and redistribution.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: The Effect of Early-Childhood Education on Social Preferences
abstract: We present results from the first study to examine the causal impact of early-childhood education on the social preferences of children. We compare children who, at 3–4 years old, were randomized into either a full-time preschool, a parenting program, or a control group. We returned to the children when they reached 6–8 years of age and conducted a series of incentivized experiments to elicit their social preferences. We find that early-childhood education has a strong causal impact on social preferences. Our findings highlight the importance of taking a broad perspective when designing and evaluating early-childhood educational programs.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: What Explains the Gender Gap in College Track Dropout? Experimental and Administrative Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> We exploit a unique data set, combining rich experimental data with high-quality administrative data, to study dropout from the college track in Norway, and why boys are more likely to drop out. The paper provides three main findings. First, we show that family background and personal characteristics contribute to explain dropout. Second, we show that the gender difference in dropout rates appears both when the adolescents select into the college track and after they have started. Third, we show that different processes guide the choices of the boys and the girls of whether to drop out from the college track. </jats:p>
research_question: What explains the gender gap in college track dropout, specifically why boys are more likely to drop out than girls?
answer: The gender difference in dropout rates appears both at the point of selection into the college track and after students have started, with different decision-making processes guiding boys' and girls' choices to drop out, while family background and personal characteristics also contribute to explaining dropout behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by exploiting a unique combination of rich experimental data with high-quality administrative data to provide comprehensive evidence on gender differences in college track dropout behavior in Norway.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: Just Luck: An Experimental Study of Risk-Taking and Fairness: Erratum

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: Universalism: Global Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> This paper leverages nationally representative surveys across 60 countries and 64,000 respondents to present novel stylized facts about the relationship-specific nature of altruism. Across individuals, universalist preferences systematically vary with demographics such as age and religiosity and are predictive of many left-wing political views, albeit in culturally highly heterogeneous ways. Across countries, universalism is strongly linked to a broader radius of trust. Looking at origins, universalism varies with the economic, political, and religious organization of societies in ways that are consistent with the idea that the scope of altruism is partly shaped by economic incentives and democracy. (JEL D12, D64, D72, Z12, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the patterns and determinants of universalist preferences (relationship-specific nature of altruism) across individuals and countries?
answer: Universalist preferences vary systematically with individual demographics (age, religiosity) and predict left-wing political views in culturally heterogeneous ways; across countries, universalism is strongly linked to broader trust and varies with economic, political, and religious organization in ways consistent with altruism being shaped by economic incentives and democracy.
positioning_statement: This paper presents novel stylized facts about the relationship-specific nature of altruism using nationally representative surveys across 60 countries and 64,000 respondents, providing new empirical evidence on how the scope of altruism varies across individuals and societies.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: Exercise Improves Academic Performance

author: Bingjing Li
title: Did US Politicians Expect the China Shock?
abstract: <jats:p> Information sets, expectations, and preferences of politicians are fundamental, but unobserved determinants of their policy choices. Employing repeated votes in the US House of Representatives on China’s normal trade relations (NTR) status during the two decades straddling China’s World Trade Organization (WTO) accession, we apply a moment inequality approach designed to deliver consistent estimates under weak informational assumptions on the information sets of members of Congress. This methodology offers a robust way to test hypotheses about what information politicians have at the time of their decision and to estimate the weight that constituents, ideology, and other factors have in policy making and voting. (JEL D72, D78, D83, D84, F14, P33) </jats:p>
research_question: What information did US politicians have about the economic impact of China's trade integration (the 'China Shock') when making policy decisions, and how did this information influence their voting behavior on China's normal trade relations status?
answer: The paper develops a methodology to estimate politicians' information sets and finds that the weight of constituents, ideology, and other factors in policy making can be robustly estimated even under weak assumptions about what information members of Congress possessed when voting on China's trade status.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by addressing a fundamental gap in understanding politicians' unobserved information sets, expectations, and preferences in policy making, offering a novel moment inequality approach that provides robust estimates under weaker informational assumptions than previous methods.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: When Parents Decide: Gender Differences in Competitiveness
abstract: Parents make important choices for their children in many areas of life, yet the empirical literature on this topic is scarce. We study parents’ competitiveness choices for their children by combining two large-scale artifactual field experiments with high-quality longitudinal administrative data. We document three main sets of findings. First, parents choose more competition for their sons than daughters. Second, this gender difference can largely be explained by parents’ beliefs about their children’s competitiveness preferences. Third, parents’ choices predict children’s later-in-life educational outcomes. Taken together, these findings provide novel evidence on the role of parents in shaping children’s long-term outcomes.

author: Bingjing Li
title: Rural Pensions, Labor Reallocation, and Aggregate Income: An Empirical and Quantitative Analysis of China
abstract: <jats:p>We exploit the implementation of a rural pension policy in China to estimate the average rural‐to‐urban migration cost for workers affected by the policy and the average underlying sectoral productivity difference. Our estimates, based on a large panel data set, reveal significant migration costs and substantial sectoral productivity differences, with sorting playing a minor role in accounting for sectoral labor income gaps. We construct and structurally estimate a general equilibrium household model with endogenous labor supply and migration. The results of this model align with the reduced‐form findings and illustrate how the rural pension policy influences migration, GDP, and welfare through improving within‐household labor allocation. Counterfactual analyses based on the model show that the positive effects of the policy remain even if migration costs were significantly lower, and that scaling up the rural pension policy would lead to even larger improvements in labor allocation, GDP, and welfare.</jats:p>
research_question: How does China's rural pension policy affect labor reallocation between rural and urban sectors, and what are the implications for migration costs, sectoral productivity differences, and aggregate economic outcomes?
answer: The rural pension policy reveals significant migration costs and substantial sectoral productivity differences, with sorting playing a minor role in sectoral labor income gaps. The policy improves labor allocation within households, leading to positive effects on migration, GDP, and welfare that would persist even with lower migration costs and could be amplified if scaled up.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by exploiting a specific policy implementation to empirically estimate migration costs and sectoral productivity differences, then using these estimates in a structural general equilibrium model to quantify the effects of rural pension policies on labor reallocation and aggregate outcomes.

author: Bertil Tungodden
title: The Pluralism of Fairness Ideals: An Experimental Approach
abstract: <jats:p> A core question in the contemporary debate on distributive justice is how to understand fairness in situations involving production. Important theories of distributive justice, such as strict egalitarianism, liberal egalitarianism, and libertarianism, provide different answers to this question. This paper presents the results from a dictator game where the distribution phase is preceded by a production phase. Each player's contribution is a result of a freely chosen investment level and an exogenously given rate of return. We estimate simultaneously the prevalence of three principles of distributive justice among the players and the distribution of the weight they attach to fairness. (JEL D63) </jats:p>
research_question: How do people understand and apply fairness in situations involving production, and what is the prevalence of different principles of distributive justice (strict egalitarianism, liberal egalitarianism, and libertarianism) among individuals?
answer: The paper finds that there is pluralism in fairness ideals - different principles of distributive justice coexist among individuals, with varying prevalence rates and different weights attached to fairness considerations in production-based distribution scenarios.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the contemporary debate on distributive justice by providing empirical evidence on how important theories of distributive justice (strict egalitarianism, liberal egalitarianism, and libertarianism) manifest in actual behavior, using an experimental approach that combines production and distribution phases to test these competing theoretical frameworks.

author: Brett Green
title: Breakthroughs, Deadlines, and Self-Reported Progress: Contracting for Multistage Projects
abstract: <jats:p> We study the optimal incentive scheme for a multistage project in which the agent privately observes intermediate progress. The optimal contract involves a soft deadline wherein the principal guarantees funding up to a certain date—if the agent reports progress at that date, then the principal gives him a relatively short hard deadline to complete the project—if progress is not reported at that date, then a probationary phase begins in which the project is randomly terminated at a constant rate until progress is reported. We explore several variants of the model with implications for optimal project design. In particular, we show that the principal benefits by imposing a small cost on the agent for submitting a progress report or by making the first stage of the project somewhat “harder” than the second. (JEL D82, D86, G32) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal incentive scheme for contracting multistage projects where the agent privately observes intermediate progress?
answer: The optimal contract involves a soft deadline with guaranteed funding up to a certain date, followed by either a short hard deadline if progress is reported or a probationary phase with random termination if no progress is reported. Additionally, imposing small costs for progress reports or making the first stage harder than the second benefits the principal.
positioning_statement: This paper studies optimal contracting for multistage projects with private information about intermediate progress, exploring variants with implications for optimal project design including progress reporting costs and asymmetric stage difficulty.

author: Brett Green
title: Bargaining and News
abstract: <jats:p> We study a bargaining model in which a buyer makes frequent offers to a privately informed seller, while gradually learning about the seller’s type from “news.” We show that the buyer’s ability to leverage this information to extract more surplus from the seller is remarkably limited. In fact, the buyer gains nothing from the ability to negotiate a better price despite the fact that a negotiation must take place in equilibrium. During the negotiation, the buyer engages in a form of costly “experimentation” by making offers that are sure to earn her negative payoffs if accepted, but speed up learning and improve her continuation payoff if rejected. We investigate the effects of market power by comparing our results to a setting with competitive buyers. Both efficiency and the seller’s payoff can decrease by introducing competition among buyers. (JEL C78, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How does a buyer's ability to gradually learn about a privately informed seller's type through 'news' affect surplus extraction and bargaining outcomes when the buyer makes frequent offers?
answer: The buyer's ability to leverage gradually acquired information to extract more surplus from the seller is remarkably limited - the buyer gains nothing from the ability to negotiate a better price despite negotiation taking place in equilibrium, and instead engages in costly 'experimentation' by making offers with negative expected payoffs to speed up learning.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the bargaining literature by examining a novel setting where buyers learn about seller types through external 'news' during frequent offer-making, and challenges conventional wisdom by showing that buyer competition can actually decrease both efficiency and seller payoffs, contrasting with standard competitive market results.

author: Brett Green
title: Liquidity Sentiments
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a rational theory of liquidity sentiments in which the market outcome in any given period depends on agents’ expectations about market conditions in future periods. Our theory is based on the interaction between adverse selection and resale considerations giving rise to an intertemporal coordination problem that yields multiple self-fulfilling equilibria. We construct “sentiment” equilibria in which sunspots generate fluctuations in prices, volume, and welfare, all of which are positively correlated. The intertemporal nature of the coordination problem disciplines the set of possible sentiment dynamics. In particular, sentiments must be sufficiently persistent and transitions must be stochastic. We consider an extension with production in which asset quality is endogenously determined and provide conditions under which sentiments are a necessary feature of any equilibrium. A testable implication is that assets produced in good times are of lower average quality than those produced in bad times. (JEL D84, D82, E32, E44, G12) </jats:p>
research_question: How do agents' expectations about future market conditions affect current market outcomes, particularly in the context of liquidity and market sentiment?
answer: The interaction between adverse selection and resale considerations creates an intertemporal coordination problem that yields multiple self-fulfilling equilibria, where sunspots can generate positively correlated fluctuations in prices, volume, and welfare through persistent sentiment dynamics.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a rational theory of liquidity sentiments that provides a theoretical foundation for understanding how market sentiment can create self-fulfilling prophecies in financial markets, extending beyond existing literature by incorporating the intertemporal coordination aspects of adverse selection and resale considerations.

author: Brett Green
title: Information Spillovers in Asset Markets with Correlated Values
abstract: <jats:p> We study information spillovers in a dynamic setting with correlated assets owned by privately informed sellers. In the model, a trade of one asset can provide information about the value of other assets. Importantly, the information content of trading behavior is endogenously determined. We show that this endogeneity leads to multiple equilibria when assets are sufficiently correlated. The equilibria are ranked in terms of both trade volume and efficiency. The model has implications for policies targeting post-trade transparency. We show that introducing post-trade transparency can increase or decrease welfare and trading volume depending on the asset correlation, equilibrium being played, and the composition of market participants. (JEL D82, D83, G14, G18) </jats:p>
research_question: How do information spillovers affect trading dynamics and market outcomes in asset markets where assets have correlated values and sellers possess private information?
answer: Information spillovers create endogenous information content in trading behavior, leading to multiple equilibria when assets are sufficiently correlated, with these equilibria being ranked by trade volume and efficiency. Post-trade transparency policies can either increase or decrease welfare and trading volume depending on asset correlation, the equilibrium being played, and market participant composition.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on information spillovers in asset markets by examining a dynamic setting with correlated assets and privately informed sellers, where the information content of trading behavior is endogenously determined rather than exogenously given, leading to novel insights about multiple equilibria and policy implications for post-trade transparency.

author: Brett Green
title: Digital Collateral
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A new form of secured lending using “digital collateral” has recently emerged, most prominently in low- and middle-income countries. Digital collateral relies on lockout technology, which allows the lender to temporarily disable the flow value of the collateral to the borrower without physically repossessing it. We explore this new form of credit in a model and a field experiment using school-fee loans digitally secured with a solar home system. Securing a loan with digital collateral drastically reduced default rates (by 19 percentage points) and increased the lender’s rate of return (by 49 percentage points). Using a variant of the Karlan and Zinman (2009) methodology, we decompose the total effect on repayment and find that roughly two-thirds is attributable to moral hazard, and one-third to adverse selection. In addition, access to digitally secured school-fee loans significantly increased school enrollment and school-related expenditures without detrimental effects on households’ balance sheets.</jats:p>
research_question: How does digital collateral - a new form of secured lending using lockout technology that allows lenders to temporarily disable collateral without physical repossession - affect loan default rates, lender returns, and borrower outcomes?
answer: Digital collateral drastically reduces default rates by 19 percentage points and increases lender rate of return by 49 percentage points, with roughly two-thirds of the repayment effect attributable to moral hazard and one-third to adverse selection. It also significantly increases school enrollment and expenditures without harming household balance sheets.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces and analyzes a new form of secured lending that has recently emerged, particularly in low- and middle-income countries, using methodology adapted from Karlan and Zinman (2009) to decompose the mechanisms behind improved repayment performance.

author: Bruce Sacerdote
title: How Much Would US Style Fiscal Integration Buffer European Unemployment and Income Shocks? (A Comparative Empirical Analysis)
abstract: <jats:p> We examine the degree to which federal fiscal integration smoothes income and unemployment shocks across US States. We find that roughly 25 cents of every dollar of income shock at the state level is offset by federal fiscal policy. This stabilization comes entirely through the Federal tax system, not through spending stabilizers, automatic or otherwise. If we apply a comparable amount of cross country stabilization to European Union countries (as exists across US States), Greece and Spain would be receiving additional transfers of 2.5 percent of GDP. </jats:p>
research_question: How much would US-style fiscal integration buffer European unemployment and income shocks compared to the current system?
answer: Federal fiscal integration smoothes approximately 25 cents of every dollar of income shock at the state level in the US, achieved entirely through the federal tax system rather than spending stabilizers. If applied to the EU, countries like Greece and Spain would receive additional transfers of 2.5 percent of GDP.
positioning_statement: This paper conducts a comparative empirical analysis between the US federal fiscal system and European fiscal integration, using the US model as a benchmark to quantify potential stabilization effects for European countries experiencing economic shocks.

author: Bruce Sacerdote
title: Geographic Dispersion of Economic Shocks: Evidence from the Fracking Revolution
abstract: <jats:p> We track the geographic and temporal propagation of local economic shocks from new oil and gas production generated by hydrofracturing. Each million dollars of new production produces $80,000 in wage income and $132,000 in royalty and business income within a county. Within 100 miles, one million dollars of new production generates $257,000 in wages and $286,000 in royalty and business income. Roughly two-thirds of the wage income increase persists for two years. Assuming no general equilibrium effects, new extraction increased aggregate US employment by as many as 640,000, and decreased the unemployment rate by 0.43 during the Great Recession. (JEL D86, L14, L81, L82) </jats:p>
research_question: How do local economic shocks from new oil and gas production generated by hydrofracturing propagate geographically and temporally?
answer: Each million dollars of new fracking production generates significant local economic impacts ($80,000 in wage income and $132,000 in royalty/business income within county, with effects extending up to 100 miles), with roughly two-thirds of wage income increases persisting for two years, and aggregate effects potentially creating 640,000 US jobs during the Great Recession.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on geographic dispersion of economic shocks by providing empirical evidence on the spatial and temporal spillover effects of the fracking revolution, quantifying both local and regional economic impacts of energy sector shocks.

author: Bruce Sacerdote
title: Geographic Dispersion of Economic Shocks: Evidence from the Fracking Revolution: Reply
abstract: <jats:p> Measuring the geographic spillovers from an economic shock remains a challenging econometric problem. In Feyrer, Mansur, and Sacerdote (2017) we study the propagation of positive shocks from the recent boom in oil and gas production in the United States. We regress changes in income per capita on new energy production per capita within increasingly larger geographic circles. James and Smith (2020) proposes instead a single regression of county income per capita on energy production from successively larger donuts around the county. This method controls for production outside of the circle of interest and is likely the appropriate estimation method for estimating the impact of within-county production. Their results suggest that FMS overestimates the impact of new production. We show that we can incorporate similar controls using our basic estimation method and that (unlike James and Smith) these controls do not significantly change our results. To explore these differences, we perform simulation exercises which show that the James-Smith estimation method is biased downward with the heterogeneous population distributions across counties that we observe in the data. (JEL E24, E32, J31, Q35, Q43, R11, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: How should geographic spillovers from economic shocks be measured, specifically in the context of the fracking boom's impact on local income?
answer: The original Feyrer, Mansur, and Sacerdote (2017) method of regressing income changes on energy production within increasingly larger geographic circles remains valid, as the alternative James-Smith method suffers from downward bias due to heterogeneous population distributions across counties.
positioning_statement: This paper defends the original FMS (2017) methodology against criticism from James and Smith (2020), showing that while the James-Smith approach may be theoretically appealing for controlling production outside circles of interest, it produces biased results in practice, whereas the FMS method remains robust even when incorporating similar controls.

author: Bruce Sacerdote
title: Estimating the Effect of Unearned Income on Labor Earnings, Savings, and Consumption: Evidence from a Survey of Lottery Players
abstract: <jats:p> This paper provides empirical evidence about the effect of unearned income on earnings, consumption, and savings. Using an original survey of people playing the lottery in Massachusetts in the mid-1980's, we analyze the effects of the magnitude of lottery prizes on economic behavior. The critical assumption is that among lottery winners the magnitude of the prize is randomly assigned. We find that unearned income reduces labor earnings, with a marginal propensity to consume leisure of approximately 11 percent, with larger effects for individuals between 55 and 65 years old. After receiving about half their prize, individuals saved about 16 percent. (JEL C81, D12, E21, J22, J26) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of unearned income on labor earnings, savings, and consumption?
answer: Unearned income reduces labor earnings with a marginal propensity to consume leisure of approximately 11 percent (with larger effects for individuals aged 55-65), and individuals saved about 16 percent of their prize after receiving about half of it.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence on the effects of unearned income using an original survey methodology of lottery players, leveraging the random assignment of prize magnitudes among lottery winners to identify causal effects.

author: Bruce Sacerdote
title: Katrina's Children: Evidence on the Structure of Peer Effects from Hurricane Evacuees
abstract: <jats:p> In 2005, Hurricanes Katrina and Rita forced many children to relocate across the Southeast. While schools quickly enrolled evacuees, families in receiving schools worried about the impacts on incumbent students. We find no effect, on average, of the inflow of evacuees on achievement in Houston. In Louisiana we find little impact on average and we reject linear-in-means models. Moreover, we find that student achievement improves with high achieving peers and worsens with low achieving peers. Finally, an increase in the inflow of evacuees raised incumbent absenteeism and disciplinary problems in Houston's secondary schools. (JEL I21, Q54) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the peer effects on incumbent students' academic achievement and behavior when Hurricane Katrina and Rita evacuees were enrolled in their schools?
answer: On average, there was no effect of evacuee inflow on incumbent student achievement in Houston and little impact in Louisiana. However, the study finds non-linear peer effects where student achievement improves with high-achieving peers and worsens with low-achieving peers. Additionally, evacuee inflow increased absenteeism and disciplinary problems in Houston's secondary schools.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the peer effects literature by rejecting linear-in-means models and providing evidence for non-linear peer effects, using the natural experiment created by Hurricane Katrina and Rita evacuations to identify causal effects that address typical endogeneity concerns in peer effects research.

author: Carola Frydman
title: Investment Banks as Corporate Monitors in the Early Twentieth Century United States
abstract: <jats:p> We study the effect of financial relationships on firms' investment decisions and access to external finance. In the early twentieth century, securities underwriters commonly held directorships with American corporations. Section 10 of the Clayton Antitrust Act prohibited bankers from serving on the boards of railroads for which they underwrote securities. We find that following the implementation of Section 10, railroads with strong preexisting relationships with underwriters saw declines in their investment rates, valuations, and leverage, and increases in their costs of external funds. Reassuringly, we do not observe similar effects among industrials and utilities, which were not subject to Section 10. Our results are consistent with underwriters on corporate boards acting as delegated monitors, and highlight the potential for regulations intended to address conflicts of interest to disrupt valuable information flows. (JEL G24, G31, G32, G34, K22, N21, N22) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of financial relationships, specifically investment bank board representation, on firms' investment decisions and access to external finance?
answer: Investment banks serving on corporate boards act as valuable delegated monitors - when this relationship was severed by regulation, affected railroads experienced declines in investment rates, valuations, and leverage, along with increases in their costs of external funds.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financial intermediation and corporate governance by using a natural experiment (Section 10 of the Clayton Antitrust Act) to identify the causal effects of banker-directors, highlighting that regulations designed to address conflicts of interest can disrupt valuable information flows and monitoring functions.
