author: Claudia Goldin
title: Can Online Learning Bend the Higher Education Cost Curve?
abstract: <jats:p> We examine whether online learning technologies have led to lower prices in higher education. Using data from the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, we show that online education is concentrated in large for-profit chains and less-selective public institutions. We find that colleges with a higher share of online students charge lower tuition prices. We present evidence of declining real and relative prices for full-time undergraduate online education from 2006 to 2013. Although the pattern of results suggests some hope that online technology can “bend the cost curve” in higher education, the impact of online learning on education quality remains uncertain. </jats:p>
research_question: Whether online learning technologies have led to lower prices in higher education
answer: Online education is associated with lower tuition prices - colleges with higher shares of online students charge lower tuition, and real and relative prices for full-time undergraduate online education declined from 2006 to 2013, suggesting online technology can 'bend the cost curve' in higher education
positioning_statement: The paper addresses the ongoing concern about rising higher education costs by examining online learning as a potential technological solution, though it acknowledges the uncertain impact on education quality remains an open question in the literature

author: Claudia Goldin
title: The Expanding Gender Earnings Gap: Evidence from the LEHD-2000 Census
abstract: <jats:p> The gender earnings gap is an expanding statistic over the lifecycle. We use the LEHD Census 2000 to understand the roles of industry, occupation, and establishment 14 years after leaving school. The gap for college graduates 26 to 39 years old expands by 34 log points, most occurring in the first 7 years. About 44 percent is due to disproportionate shifts by men into higher-earning positions, industries, and firms and about 56 percent to differential advances by gender within firms. Widening is greater for married individuals and for those in certain sectors. Non-college graduates experience less widening but with similar patterns. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the roles of industry, occupation, and establishment in explaining the expanding gender earnings gap over the lifecycle, particularly 14 years after leaving school?
answer: The gender earnings gap for college graduates aged 26-39 expands by 34 log points (mostly in the first 7 years), with about 44% due to men's disproportionate shifts into higher-earning positions, industries, and firms, and 56% due to differential gender-based advancement within firms. The widening is greater for married individuals and varies by sector.
positioning_statement: This paper uses LEHD Census 2000 data to provide new empirical evidence on the lifecycle expansion of the gender earnings gap, decomposing the sources of this expansion into between-firm mobility effects and within-firm advancement differences by gender.

author: Claudia Steinwender
title: Real Effects of Information Frictions: When the States and the Kingdom Became United
abstract: <jats:p> This paper exploits a unique historical experiment to estimate how information frictions distort international trade: the establishment of the transatlantic telegraph in 1866. I use newly collected data on cotton prices, trade, and information flows from historical newspapers and find that the average and volatility of the transatlantic price difference fell after the telegraph, while average trade flows increased and became more volatile. Using a trade model in which exporters use the latest news about a foreign market to forecast expected prices, I estimate the efficiency gains of the telegraph to be equivalent to 8 percent of export value. (JEL D83, F12, F14, L96, N71, N73) </jats:p>
research_question: How do information frictions distort international trade?
answer: The establishment of the transatlantic telegraph in 1866 reduced information frictions, leading to decreased average and volatility of transatlantic price differences, increased average trade flows with higher volatility, and efficiency gains equivalent to 8 percent of export value.
positioning_statement: This paper exploits a unique historical experiment (the 1866 transatlantic telegraph establishment) to provide empirical evidence on the real effects of information frictions in international trade, using newly collected historical data and a trade model where exporters forecast prices based on latest foreign market news.

author: Claudia Goldin
title: The Value of Postsecondary Credentials in the Labor Market: An Experimental Study
abstract: <jats:p> We study employers' perceptions of the value of postsecondary degrees using a field experiment. We randomly assign the sector and selectivity of institutions to fictitious resumes and apply to real vacancy postings for business and health jobs on a large online job board. We find that a business bachelor's degree from a for-profit online institution is 22 percent less likely to receive a callback than one from a nonselective public institution. In applications to health jobs, we find that for-profit credentials receive fewer callbacks unless the job requires an external quality indicator such as an occupational license. (JEL I23, I26, J24, J44, J63, M51) </jats:p>
research_question: How do employers perceive and value postsecondary degrees from different types of institutions (for-profit online vs. nonselective public) when making hiring decisions?
answer: Employers significantly discount credentials from for-profit online institutions - business bachelor's degrees from for-profit online institutions are 22% less likely to receive callbacks than those from nonselective public institutions, while for-profit health credentials only receive equal treatment when jobs require external quality indicators like occupational licenses.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on credential signaling and employer hiring behavior by using a field experimental approach to directly measure employer perceptions of different types of postsecondary institutions, providing causal evidence on how institutional sector and selectivity affect labor market outcomes.

author: Claudia Steinwender
title: Shocking Labor Supply: A Reassessment of the Role of World War II on Women's Labor Supply
abstract: <jats:p> The most prominent feature of the female labor force across the past hundred years is its enormous growth. But many believe that the increase was discontinuous. Our purpose is to identify the short- and long-run impacts of WWII on the labor supply of women who were currently married in 1950 and 1960. Using WWII mobilization rates by state, we find a wartime impact on weeks worked and the labor force participation of married white (non-farm) women in both 1950 and 1960. The impact, moreover, was experienced almost entirely by women in the top half of the education distribution. </jats:p>
research_question: What were the short- and long-run impacts of World War II on the labor supply of married women in 1950 and 1960?
answer: WWII had a significant wartime impact on weeks worked and labor force participation of married white (non-farm) women in both 1950 and 1960, with the impact concentrated almost entirely among women in the top half of the education distribution.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that female labor force growth was discontinuous by providing a reassessment of WWII's role, positioning itself as offering new evidence on the most prominent feature of female labor force development over the past hundred years.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: Tax Changes and Asset Pricing
abstract: <jats:p>The tax burden on equity securities has varied substantially over time and remains a source of continuing policy debate. This paper investigates whether investors were compensated for the tax burden of equity securities over the period between 1913 and 2006. Taxes on equity securities vary over time due to changes in dividend and capital gains tax rates and due to changes in corporate payout policies. Equity taxes also vary across firms due to persistent differences in propensities to pay dividends. The results indicate an economically plausible and statistically significant tax capitalization over time and cross-sectionally. (JEL G10, G12, H22, H24, N21, N22)</jats:p>
research_question: Were investors compensated for the tax burden of equity securities over the period between 1913 and 2006?
answer: Yes, the results indicate an economically plausible and statistically significant tax capitalization both over time and cross-sectionally, meaning investors were compensated for bearing the tax burden on equity securities.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the ongoing policy debate about tax burden on equity securities by providing empirical evidence of tax capitalization using a comprehensive historical dataset spanning nearly a century (1913-2006), examining both temporal variation in tax rates and cross-sectional variation in firm payout policies.

author: Clemens Sialm
title: Defined Contribution Pension Plans: Mutual Fund Asset Allocation Changes
abstract: <jats:p> In this paper we compare changes in asset allocations between mutual funds held in defined contribution pension plans and funds held by other investors. We investigate how flows into equity and fixed income mutual funds depend on macroeconomic conditions. We find that defined contribution plans react more sensitively to these conditions, suggesting effects on mutual fund managers and other investors. </jats:p>
research_question: How do asset allocation changes in mutual funds held in defined contribution pension plans compare to those held by other investors, and how do flows into equity and fixed income mutual funds depend on macroeconomic conditions?
answer: Defined contribution plans react more sensitively to macroeconomic conditions than other investors when making asset allocation changes, which has effects on mutual fund managers and other investors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by specifically comparing the investment behavior of defined contribution pension plans versus other investors in mutual funds, focusing on their differential sensitivity to macroeconomic conditions.

author: Clément de Chaisemartin
title: Estimating the Effect of Treatments Allocated by Randomized Waiting Lists
abstract: <jats:p>Oversubscribed treatments are often allocated using randomized waiting lists. Applicants are ranked randomly, and treatment offers are made following that ranking until all seats are filled. To estimate causal effects, researchers often compare applicants getting and not getting an offer. We show that those two groups are not statistically comparable. Therefore, the estimator arising from that comparison is inconsistent when the number of waitlists goes to infinity. We propose a new estimator, and show that it is consistent, provided the waitlists have at least two seats. Finally, we revisit an application, and we show that using our estimator can lead to a statistically significant difference with respect to the results obtained using the commonly used estimator.</jats:p>
research_question: How can researchers accurately estimate causal effects of treatments that are allocated using randomized waiting lists?
answer: The commonly used estimator that compares applicants getting and not getting treatment offers is inconsistent because the two groups are not statistically comparable. A new consistent estimator is proposed that works when waitlists have at least two seats.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a fundamental flaw in the standard approach used by researchers to estimate causal effects from randomized waiting lists, showing that the commonly used estimator is inconsistent, and proposes a corrected methodology that can produce statistically significant differences from existing results.

author: Conrad Miller
title: Would Eliminating Racial Disparities in Motor Vehicle Searches have Efficiency Costs?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>During traffic stops, police search black and Hispanic motorists more than twice as often as white motorists, yet those searches are no more likely to yield contraband. We ask whether equalizing search rates by motorist race would reduce contraband yield. We use unique administrative data from Texas to isolate variation in search behavior across and within highway patrol troopers and find that search rates are unrelated to the proportion of searches that yield contraband. We find that troopers can equalize search rates across racial groups, maintain the status quo search rate, and increase contraband yield. Troopers appear to be limited in their ability to discern between motorists who are more or less likely to carry contraband.</jats:p>
research_question: Would equalizing motor vehicle search rates across racial groups reduce the efficiency of contraband detection by police?
answer: No, eliminating racial disparities in search rates would not have efficiency costs. Troopers can equalize search rates across racial groups while maintaining overall search rates and actually increasing contraband yield, as search rates are unrelated to contraband detection success.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the existing literature documenting racial disparities in police searches by examining the efficiency implications of eliminating such disparities, using administrative data to isolate variation in trooper search behavior and challenge assumptions about trade-offs between equity and effectiveness in policing.

author: Clément de Chaisemartin
title: Fuzzy Differences-in-Differences
abstract: In many applications of the differences-in-differences (DID) method, the treatment increases more in the treatment group, but some units are also treated in the control group. In such fuzzy designs, a popular estimator of treatment effects is the DID of the outcome divided by the DID of the treatment, or OLS and 2SLS regressions with time and group fixed effects estimating weighted averages of this ratio across groups. We start by showing that when the treatment also increases in the control group, this ratio estimates a causal effect only if treatment effects are homogenous in the two groups. Even when the distribution of treatment is stable, it requires that the effect of time be the same on all counterfactual outcomes. As this assumption is not always applicable, we propose two alternative estimators. The first estimator relies on a generalization of common trends assumptions to fuzzy designs, while the second extends the changes-in-changes estimator of Athey & Imbens (2006). When the distribution of treatment changes in the control group, treatment effects are partially identified. Finally, we prove that our estimators are asymptotically normal and use them to revisit applied papers using fuzzy designs.

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: Debt Moratoria: Evidence from Student Loan Forbearance
abstract: <jats:p> We evaluate the effects of the 2020 student debt moratorium. Using administrative credit panel data, we compare borrowers whose loans were frozen to borrowers whose loans were not frozen based on whether the government owned the loans. We estimate that borrowers used the new liquidity to increase borrowing on mortgages, auto loans, and credit cards rather than avoid delinquencies. The effects are concentrated among borrowers without delinquencies, who saw no change in credit scores. The results highlight an important complementarity between liquidity and credit, as liquidity increases the demand for credit even as the supply of credit is fixed. (JEL E32, G21, G51, H81, I22, I23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of the 2020 student debt moratorium on borrower financial behavior?
answer: Borrowers used the new liquidity from the debt moratorium to increase borrowing on mortgages, auto loans, and credit cards rather than avoid delinquencies, with effects concentrated among borrowers without existing delinquencies who saw no change in credit scores.
positioning_statement: The paper highlights an important complementarity between liquidity and credit that has not been previously emphasized, showing that liquidity increases the demand for credit even when the supply of credit is fixed.

author: Conrad Miller
title: Institutions versus Policies: A Tale of Two Islands

author: Clément de Chaisemartin
title: Two-Way Fixed Effects Estimators with Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
abstract: <jats:p> Linear regressions with period and group fixed effects are widely used to estimate treatment effects. We show that they estimate weighted sums of the average treatment effects (ATE ) in each group and period, with weights that may be negative. Due to the negative weights, the linear regression coefficient may for instance be negative while all the ATEs are positive. We propose another estimator that solves this issue. In the two applications we revisit, it is significantly different from the linear regression estimator. (JEL C21, C23, D72, J31, J51, L82) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the properties of two-way fixed effects estimators when treatment effects are heterogeneous, and how can potential issues with these estimators be addressed?
answer: Two-way fixed effects estimators compute weighted sums of average treatment effects across groups and periods, but these weights can be negative, leading to misleading results where the regression coefficient may be negative even when all individual treatment effects are positive. The authors propose an alternative estimator that resolves this negative weighting problem.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a fundamental problem with widely used linear regression methods that include period and group fixed effects for estimating treatment effects, specifically highlighting the issue of negative weights in heterogeneous treatment effect settings, and contributes by proposing a solution that produces significantly different results from standard approaches in empirical applications.

author: Constantine Yannelis
title: Human Capital Depreciation and Returns to Experience
abstract: <jats:p> Human capital can depreciate if skills are unused. But estimating human capital depreciation is challenging, as worker skills are difficult to measure and less productive workers are more likely to spend time in nonemployment. We overcome these challenges with new administrative data on teachers’ assignments and their students’ outcomes, and quasi-random variation from the teacher assignment process in Greece. We find significant losses to output, as a one-year increase in time without formal employment lowers students’ test scores by 0.05 standard deviations. Using a simple production model, we estimate a skill depreciation rate of 4.3 percent and experience returns of 6.8 percent. (JEL I21, J24, J45, J64, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: How does time spent in nonemployment affect human capital through skill depreciation, and what are the rates of human capital depreciation and returns to experience?
answer: One year without formal employment significantly reduces productivity (lowering students' test scores by 0.05 standard deviations), with an estimated skill depreciation rate of 4.3 percent and experience returns of 6.8 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the challenging problem of estimating human capital depreciation by overcoming measurement difficulties and selection bias issues that have plagued previous research, using novel administrative data on teachers and quasi-random variation in teacher assignments to provide credible identification.

author: Cristina Gualdani
title: Partial Identification in Matching Models for the Marriage Market
abstract: We study partial identification of the preference parameters in the one-to-one matching model with perfectly transferable utilities. We do so without imposing parametric distributional assumptions on the unobserved heterogeneity and with data on one large market. We provide a tractable characterization of the identified set under various classes of nonparametric distributional assumptions on the unobserved heterogeneity. We reexamine some of the relevant questions in the empirical literature on the marriage market, which have been previously studied under the logit assumption. Our results reveal that many findings in the aforementioned literature are primarily driven by such parametric restrictions.

author: Daniel Garrett
title: Intertemporal Price Discrimination: Dynamic Arrivals and Changing Values
abstract: <jats:p> We study the profit-maximizing price path of a monopolist selling a durable good to buyers who arrive over time and whose values for the good evolve stochastically. The setting is completely stationary with an infinite horizon. Contrary to the case with constant values, optimal prices fluctuate with time. We argue that consumers’ randomly changing values offer an explanation for temporary price reductions that are often observed in practice. (JEL D82) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the profit-maximizing price path of a monopolist selling a durable good to buyers who arrive over time and whose values for the good evolve stochastically?
answer: Optimal prices fluctuate with time when consumers have randomly changing values, and these stochastically evolving values can explain temporary price reductions often observed in practice.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with existing literature on intertemporal price discrimination by introducing stochastically evolving consumer values, whereas previous work typically assumes constant values over time.

author: Daniel Garrett
title: Relational Contracts: Public versus Private Savings
abstract: <jats:p>Work on relational employment agreements often predicts low payments or termination for poor performance. The possibility of saving can, however, limit the effectiveness of monetary incentives in motivating an employee with diminishing marginal utility for consumption. We study the role of savings and their observability in optimal relational contracts. We focus on the case where players are not too patient, and hence the constant first‐best effort cannot be implemented. If savings are hidden, the relationship eventually deteriorates over time. In particular, both payments and effort decline. On the other hand, if savings are public, consumption is initially high, so the agent's savings fall over time, and effort and payments to the agent increase. The findings thus suggest how tacit agreements on consumption can forestall the deterioration of dynamic relationships in which the agent can save.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the observability of savings affect the design and performance of optimal relational employment contracts?
answer: When savings are hidden, relational contracts deteriorate over time with declining payments and effort, but when savings are publicly observable, contracts can be structured so that consumption starts high and savings fall over time while effort and payments increase, preventing relationship deterioration.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing work on relational employment agreements, which typically predicts low payments or termination for poor performance, by incorporating the role of employee savings and demonstrating how the observability of savings can limit or enhance the effectiveness of monetary incentives in motivating employees with diminishing marginal utility for consumption.

author: Daniel Garrett
title: Managerial Turnover in a Changing World

author: Daniel Garrett
title: A Dynamic Theory of Random Price Discounts
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A seller with commitment power sets prices over time. Risk-averse buyers arrive to the market and decide when to purchase. We show that it is optimal for the seller to choose a constant high price punctuated by occasional episodes of sequential discounts that occur at random times. This optimal price path has the property that the price a buyer ends up paying is independent of his arrival and purchase times, and only depends on his valuation. Our theory accommodates empirical findings on the timing of discounts.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal pricing strategy for a seller with commitment power when facing risk-averse buyers who arrive at different times and can choose when to purchase?
answer: It is optimal for the seller to set a constant high price punctuated by occasional episodes of sequential discounts that occur at random times, resulting in a price path where the final price paid by buyers depends only on their valuation, not their arrival or purchase timing.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a theoretical framework that accommodates and explains empirical findings on the timing of price discounts, contributing to the literature on dynamic pricing with strategic buyers.

author: Daniel Garrett
title: Competitive Screening Under Heterogeneous Information
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the interplay between informational frictions and second-degree price discrimination. Our theory recognizes that consumers differ in their tastes for quality as well as in the information they possess about available offers, which leads to dispersion over price–quality menus in equilibrium. While firms are ex ante identical, we show that their menus are ordered so that more generous menus leave more surplus to consumers of all valuations. We explore the cross-section of equilibrium menus and variations in market conditions to generate empirical predictions on prices, qualities, and markups across firms, and within a firm’s product line. For instance, more competition may raise prices for low-quality goods; yet, consumers are better off, as the qualities they receive also increase. The predictions of our model illuminate empirical findings in many markets, such as those for cell phone plans, yellow-pages advertising, cable TV, and air travel.</jats:p>
research_question: How do informational frictions interact with second-degree price discrimination when consumers differ in both their tastes for quality and their information about available offers?
answer: The interplay between informational frictions and second-degree price discrimination leads to dispersion over price-quality menus in equilibrium, where ex ante identical firms offer ordered menus such that more generous menus leave more surplus to consumers of all valuations, and more competition may raise prices for low-quality goods while making consumers better off through increased quality.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing price discrimination theory by incorporating heterogeneous consumer information alongside heterogeneous preferences for quality, generating new empirical predictions that illuminate findings in markets such as cell phone plans, yellow-pages advertising, cable TV, and air travel.

author: Daniel Gottlieb
title: Long‐Term Contracting With Time‐Inconsistent Agents
abstract: <jats:p>We study contracts between naive present‐biased consumers and risk‐neutral firms. We show that the welfare loss from present bias vanishes as the contracting horizon grows. This is true both when bargaining power is on the consumers' and on the firms' side, when consumers cannot commit to long‐term contracts, and when firms do not know the consumers' naiveté. However, the welfare loss from present bias does not vanish when firms do not know the consumers' present bias or when they cannot offer exclusive contracts.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the length of the contracting horizon affect welfare outcomes when naive present-biased consumers contract with risk-neutral firms?
answer: The welfare loss from present bias vanishes as the contracting horizon grows, except when firms do not know the consumers' present bias or when they cannot offer exclusive contracts.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on contracting with time-inconsistent agents by examining the role of contract duration and showing that long-term contracting can mitigate welfare losses from present bias under most conditions, identifying specific exceptions where this result does not hold.

author: Daniel Garrett
title: Spatial Influences in Upward Mobility
abstract: This paper extends a canonical model of intergenerational human capital investment to a geographic context to study the role of migration in influencing income mobility in the United States. The main result is that migration is considerably influential in shaping the high rates of economic mobility observed among children from low-wage areas, with human capital investment behavioral responses being important to consider. Equalizing school quality across locations does more to reduce interstate inequality in income mobility than equalizing skill prices, and policies that attempt to decrease human capital flight from low-wage areas via cash transfers are unlikely to be cost-effective.

author: Daniel Garrett
title: Tax Policy and Local Labor Market Behavior
abstract: <jats:p> Since 2002, the US government has encouraged business investment using accelerated depreciation policies that significantly reduce investment costs. We provide the first in-depth analysis of this stimulus on employment and earnings. Our local labor markets approach exploits cross-industry variation in policy generosity interacted with county-level industry location data. This strategy identifies the partial equilibrium effects of accelerated depreciation. Places that experience larger decreases in investment costs see an increase in employment and earnings. In contrast, the policy does not have positive effects on earnings-per-worker. Overall, our findings suggest federal corporate tax policy has large effects on local labor markets. (JEL D25, G31, H25, H32, J23, J31, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of accelerated depreciation tax policies on local labor market outcomes, specifically employment and earnings?
answer: Places that experience larger decreases in investment costs from accelerated depreciation policies see increases in employment and earnings, but the policy does not have positive effects on earnings-per-worker, demonstrating that federal corporate tax policy has large effects on local labor markets.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first in-depth analysis of accelerated depreciation stimulus effects on employment and earnings, using a novel local labor markets approach that exploits cross-industry variation in policy generosity interacted with county-level industry location data to identify partial equilibrium effects.

author: Daniel Gottlieb
title: Lapse-Based Insurance
abstract: <jats:p> Most individual life insurance policies lapse, with lapsers cross-subsidizing non-lapsers. We show that policies and lapse patterns predicted by standard rational expectations models are the opposite of those observed empirically. We propose two behavioral models consistent with the evidence: (i) consumers forget to pay premiums and (ii) consumers understate future liquidity needs. We conduct two surveys with a large insurer. New buyers believe that their own lapse probabilities are small compared to the insurer’s actual experience. For recent lapsers, forgetfulness accounts for 37.8 percent of lapses while unexpected liquidity accounts for 15.4 percent. (JEL D91, G22, G52) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do most individual life insurance policies lapse, and what behavioral factors explain the observed lapse patterns that contradict standard rational expectations models?
answer: Lapse patterns are driven by behavioral factors rather than rational expectations: forgetfulness accounts for 37.8% of lapses and unexpected liquidity needs account for 15.4% of lapses. Additionally, new buyers systematically underestimate their own lapse probabilities compared to actual insurer experience, creating cross-subsidization from lapsers to non-lapsers.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges standard rational expectations models in insurance by showing that predicted policies and lapse patterns are opposite to empirical observations, and instead proposes behavioral explanations (forgetfulness and understated liquidity needs) supported by novel survey evidence from a large insurer.

author: Daniel Gottlieb
title: Perfect Competition in Markets With Adverse Selection
abstract: This paper proposes a perfectly competitive model of a market with adverse selection. Prices are determined by zero‐profit conditions, and the set of traded contracts is determined by free entry. Crucially for applications, contract characteristics are endogenously determined, consumers may have multiple dimensions of private information, and an equilibrium always exists. Equilibrium corresponds to the limit of a differentiated products Bertrand game. We apply the model to establish theoretical results on the equilibrium effects of mandates. Mandates can increase efficiency but have unintended consequences. With adverse selection, an insurance mandate reduces the price of low‐coverage policies, which necessarily has indirect effects such as increasing adverse selection on the intensive margin and causing some consumers to purchase less coverage.

author: Daniel Gottlieb
title: A Theory of Fair CEO Pay
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies executive pay with fairness concerns: If the CEO's wage falls below a perceived fair share of output, he suffers disutility that is increasing in the discrepancy. Fairness concerns do not always lead to fair wages; instead, the firm threatens the CEO with unfair wages for low output to induce effort. The contract sometimes involves performance-vesting equity: The CEO is paid a constant share of output if it is sufficiently high and zero otherwise. Even without moral hazard, the contract features pay-for-performance to address fairness concerns and ensure participation. This rationalizes pay-for-performance even if effort incentives are unnecessary. (JEL D63, D82, D86, G34, M12, M52) </jats:p>
research_question: How do fairness concerns affect CEO compensation contracts and pay-for-performance structures?
answer: Fairness concerns lead to contracts where firms strategically threaten CEOs with unfair wages for low output to induce effort, often resulting in performance-vesting equity structures. Pay-for-performance emerges even without moral hazard issues as a mechanism to address fairness concerns and ensure CEO participation.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel theoretical framework that rationalizes pay-for-performance in executive compensation through fairness concerns rather than traditional moral hazard explanations, providing an alternative justification for performance-based pay even when effort incentives are unnecessary.

author: Daniel Gottlieb
title: Corrigendum: Long‐Term Contracting With Time‐Inconsistent Agents

author: Daniel Gottlieb
title: Moral Incentives in Credit Card Debt Repayment: Evidence from a Field Experiment
abstract: We study the role of morality in debt repayment, using an experiment with the credit card customers of a large Islamic bank in Indonesia. In our main treatment, clients receive a text message stating that “non-repayment of debts by someone who is able to repay is an injustice.” This moral appeal decreases delinquency by 4.4 percentage points from a baseline of 66 percent and reduces default among customers with the highest ex ante credit risk. Additional treatments help benchmark the effects against direct financial incentives and rule out competing explanations, such as reminder effects, priming religion, and provision of new information.

author: Daniel Gottlieb
title: Time Lotteries and Stochastic Impatience
abstract: <jats:p>We study preferences over lotteries in which both the prize and the payment date are uncertain. In particular, a<jats:italic>time lottery</jats:italic>is one in which the prize is fixed but the date is random. With Expected Discounted Utility, individuals must be risk<jats:italic>seeking</jats:italic>over time lotteries (RSTL). In an incentivized experiment, however, we find that almost all subjects violate this property. Our main contributions are theoretical. We first show that within a very broad class of models, which includes many forms of nonexpected utility and time discounting, it is impossible to accommodate even a single violation of RSTL without also violating a property we termed Stochastic Impatience, a risky counterpart of standard Impatience. We then present two positive results. If one wishes to maintain Stochastic Impatience, violations of RSTL can be accommodated by keeping Independence within periods while relaxing it across periods. If, instead, one is willing to forego Stochastic Impatience, violations of RSTL can be accommodated with a simple generalization of Expected Discounted Utility, obtained by imposing only the behavioral postulates of Discounted Utility and Expected Utility.</jats:p>
research_question: How do individuals make decisions over time lotteries where both the prize and payment date are uncertain, and can existing economic models accommodate observed violations of risk-seeking behavior over time lotteries?
answer: Almost all experimental subjects violate the Expected Discounted Utility prediction of being risk-seeking over time lotteries (RSTL). Within a broad class of models, accommodating even a single RSTL violation requires violating Stochastic Impatience. However, RSTL violations can be accommodated either by maintaining Stochastic Impatience while relaxing Independence across periods, or by foregoing Stochastic Impatience through a simple generalization of Expected Discounted Utility.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on decision-making under uncertainty by introducing the novel concept of time lotteries and demonstrating fundamental limitations of Expected Discounted Utility and other broad classes of models in explaining observed behavior, while proposing two theoretical solutions that relax different standard assumptions.

author: David Ahn
title: Ambiguity Without a State Space

author: David Ahn
title: Behavioural Characterizations of Naivete for Time-Inconsistent Preferences
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose non-parametric definitions of absolute and comparative naivete. These definitions leverage ex ante choice of menu to identify predictions of future behaviour and ex post (random) choices from menus to identify actual behaviour. The main advantage of our definitions is their independence from any assumed functional form for the utility function representing behaviour. An individual is sophisticated if she is indifferent ex ante between retaining the option to choose from a menu ex post or committing to her actual distribution of choices from that menu. She is naive if she prefers the flexibility in the menu, reflecting a mistaken belief that she will act more virtuously than she actually will. We propose two definitions of comparative naivete and explore the restrictions implied by our definitions for several prominent models of time inconsistency.</jats:p>
research_question: How can naivete in time-inconsistent preferences be characterized behaviorally without relying on specific functional forms for utility functions?
answer: The paper develops non-parametric definitions of absolute and comparative naivete by comparing ex ante menu choices (which reveal predictions of future behavior) with ex post actual choices from menus. An individual is sophisticated if indifferent between flexibility and commitment to their actual choice distribution, and naive if they prefer flexibility due to mistaken beliefs about acting more virtuously than they actually will.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the time-inconsistent preferences literature by providing behavioral characterizations of naivete that are independent of assumed functional forms for utility functions, offering a more general approach than existing parametric models of time inconsistency.

author: David Ahn
title: Trade Finance and the Great Trade Collapse
abstract: <jats:p> Economic models that do not incorporate financial frictions only explain about 70 to 80 percent of the decline in world trade that occurred in the 2008–2009 crisis. We review evidence that shows financial factors also contributed to the great trade collapse and uncover two new stylized facts in support of it. First, we show that the prices of manufactured exports rose relative to domestic prices during the crisis. Second, we show that US seaborne exports and imports, which are likely to be more sensitive to trade finance problems, saw their prices rise relative to goods shipped by air or land. </jats:p>
research_question: What role did financial factors, particularly trade finance problems, play in the great trade collapse during the 2008-2009 crisis beyond what can be explained by standard economic models without financial frictions?
answer: Financial factors contributed significantly to the great trade collapse, as evidenced by two key findings: (1) manufactured export prices rose relative to domestic prices during the crisis, and (2) US seaborne exports and imports, which are more sensitive to trade finance problems, experienced price increases relative to goods shipped by air or land.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the existing literature by showing that standard economic models without financial frictions can only explain 70-80% of the world trade decline during 2008-2009, and provides new empirical evidence for the role of financial factors that previous research had not fully captured.

author: David Atkin
title: The Caloric Costs of Culture: Evidence from Indian Migrants
abstract: <jats:p> Anthropologists have documented substantial and persistent differences in food preferences across social groups. My paper asks whether such food cultures can constrain caloric intake? I first document that interstate migrants within India consume fewer calories per rupee of food expenditure compared to their neighbors. Second, I show that migrants bring their origin-state food preferences with them. Third, I link these findings by showing that the gap in caloric intake between locals and migrants depends on the suitability and intensity of the migrants' origin-state preferences. The most affected migrants would consume seven percent more calories if they possessed their neighbors' preferences. (JEL D12, I12, O15, R23, Z12, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: Can food cultures constrain caloric intake, specifically examining whether cultural food preferences limit the caloric efficiency of food consumption among migrants?
answer: Yes, food cultures can constrain caloric intake. Interstate migrants in India consume fewer calories per rupee of food expenditure compared to locals because they maintain their origin-state food preferences, with the most affected migrants potentially consuming seven percent more calories if they adopted their neighbors' preferences.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on anthropological documentation of persistent differences in food preferences across social groups by providing economic evidence of how these cultural preferences create measurable constraints on caloric efficiency, using Indian interstate migration as a natural experiment to quantify the costs of maintaining cultural food practices.

author: David Atkin
title: Endogenous Skill Acquisition and Export Manufacturing in Mexico
abstract: <jats:p>This paper presents empirical evidence that the growth of export manufacturing in Mexico during a period of major trade reforms (the years 1986 to 2000) altered the distribution of education. I use variation in the timing of factory openings across commuting zones to show that school drop-out increased with local expansions in export-manufacturing industries. The magnitudes I find suggest that for every 25 jobs created, one student dropped out of school at grade 9 rather than continuing through to grade 12. These effects are driven by less-skilled export-manufacturing jobs which raised the opportunity cost of schooling for students at the margin. (JEL F14, F16, J24, L60, O14, O19)</jats:p>
research_question: How did the growth of export manufacturing in Mexico during major trade reforms (1986-2000) affect the distribution of education and school enrollment decisions?
answer: The expansion of export manufacturing increased school drop-out rates, with approximately one student dropping out of school at grade 9 (rather than continuing to grade 12) for every 25 jobs created in export manufacturing. This effect was driven by less-skilled export manufacturing jobs that raised the opportunity cost of schooling for marginal students.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes empirical evidence to the literature on trade liberalization and human capital formation by examining how export manufacturing growth specifically altered educational outcomes in Mexico, using variation in factory opening timing across commuting zones to identify causal effects of industrial expansion on schooling decisions.

author: David Atkin
title: Trade, Tastes, and Nutrition in India
abstract: <jats:p> This paper explores the causes and consequences of regional taste differences. I introduce habit formation into a standard general equilibrium model. Household tastes evolve over time to favor foods consumed as a child. Thus, locally abundant foods are preferred in every region, as they were relatively inexpensive in prior generations. These patterns alter the correspondence between price changes and nutrition. For example, neglecting this relationship between tastes and agro-climatic endowments overstates the short-run nutritional gains from agricultural trade liberalization, since preferred foods rise in price in every region. I examine the model's predictions using household survey data from many regions of India. (JEL D12, I12, O12, O18, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the causes and consequences of regional taste differences, particularly how do they affect the relationship between price changes and nutrition outcomes?
answer: Regional taste differences arise from habit formation where household tastes evolve to favor foods consumed as children, leading locally abundant foods to be preferred in every region since they were relatively inexpensive in prior generations. This relationship means that neglecting the connection between tastes and agro-climatic endowments overstates the short-run nutritional gains from agricultural trade liberalization, as preferred foods rise in price in every region.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces habit formation into a standard general equilibrium model to explain regional taste differences, contributing to the literature by showing how the relationship between tastes and agro-climatic endowments affects the correspondence between price changes and nutrition outcomes in ways that previous models have not captured.

author: David Atkin
title: Volatility and the Gains From Trade
abstract: <jats:p>Trade liberalization changes the volatility of returns by reducing the negative correlation between local prices and productivity shocks. In this paper, we explore these second‐moment effects of trade. Using forty years of agricultural micro‐data from India, we show that falling trade costs due to expansions of the Indian highway network reduced the responsiveness of local prices to local yields but increased the responsiveness of local prices to yields elsewhere. In response, farmers shifted their production toward crops with less volatile yields, especially so for those with poor access to risk mitigating technologies such as banks. We then characterize how volatility affects farmers' crop allocation using a portfolio choice framework where returns are determined in general equilibrium by a many‐location, many‐good Ricardian trade model with flexible trade costs. Finally, we structurally estimate the model—recovering farmers' risk‐return preferences from the gradient of the mean‐variance frontier at their observed crop choices—to quantify the second‐moment effects of trade. The simultaneous expansion of both the highway and rural bank networks increased the mean and the variance of farmer real income, with the first‐moment effect dominating such that expected welfare rose 4.4%. But had rural bank access remained unchanged, welfare gains would have been only half as great, as risk mitigating technologies allowed farmers to take advantage of higher‐risk higher‐return allocations.</jats:p>
research_question: How does trade liberalization affect the volatility of returns for farmers, and what are the welfare implications of these second-moment effects of trade?
answer: Trade liberalization reduces the negative correlation between local prices and productivity shocks, causing farmers to shift toward crops with less volatile yields. The simultaneous expansion of highway and rural bank networks increased both mean and variance of farmer real income, with expected welfare rising 4.4%, but welfare gains would have been only half as great without improved access to risk-mitigating technologies like banks.
positioning_statement: This paper explores the previously understudied second-moment effects of trade liberalization on volatility, using a novel approach that combines forty years of Indian agricultural micro-data with a portfolio choice framework integrated into a many-location, many-good Ricardian trade model to structurally estimate risk-return preferences and quantify welfare effects.

author: David Atkin
title: How Do We Choose Our Identity? A Revealed Preference Approach Using Food Consumption
abstract: Are identities fungible? How do people come to identify with specific groups? This paper proposes a revealed preference approach, using food consumption to uncover ethnic and religious identity choices in India. We first show that consumption \of identity goods responds to forces suggested by social identity research: group status and group salience. Moreover, identity choices respond to the cost of following the group’s prescribed behaviors. We propose and estimate a demand system to quantify the identity changes that followed India’s 1991 reforms. While social identity research has focused on status and salience, our results suggest that economic costs also play an important role.

author: David Atkin
title: Retail Globalization and Household Welfare: Evidence from Mexico

author: David Atkin
title: Exporting and Firm Performance: Evidence from a Randomized Experiment*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We conduct a randomized experiment that generates exogenous variation in the access to foreign markets for rug producers in Egypt. Combined with detailed survey data, we causally identify the impact of exporting on firm performance. Treatment firms report 16–26% higher profits and exhibit large improvements in quality alongside reductions in output per hour relative to control firms. These findings do not simply reflect firms being offered higher margins to manufacture high-quality products that take longer to produce. Instead, we find evidence of learning-by-exporting whereby exporting improves technical efficiency. First, treatment firms have higher productivity and quality after controlling for rug specifications. Second, when asked to produce an identical domestic rug using the same inputs and same capital equipment, treatment firms produce higher quality rugs despite no difference in production time. Third, treatment firms exhibit learning curves over time. Finally, we document knowledge transfers with quality increasing most along the specific dimensions that the knowledge pertained to.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal impact of exporting on firm performance, specifically examining whether exporting leads to learning effects that improve technical efficiency?
answer: Exporting causally improves firm performance through learning-by-exporting effects: treatment firms show 16-26% higher profits, improved quality, and higher technical efficiency. The learning effect is demonstrated by treatment firms producing higher quality products even when making identical domestic rugs with the same inputs, and quality improvements are strongest in dimensions where specific knowledge was transferred.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the causal identification challenge in the exporting literature by using a randomized experiment to generate exogenous variation in export market access, moving beyond correlational studies to definitively establish that performance improvements result from learning-by-exporting rather than simply reflecting selection of better firms into export markets or higher margins for export products.

author: David Atkin
title: Measuring Welfare and Inequality with Incomplete Price Information
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We propose and implement a new approach that allows us to estimate income-specific changes in household welfare in contexts where well-measured prices are not available for important subsets of consumption. Using rich but widely available expenditure survey microdata, we show that we can recover income-specific equivalent and compensating variations from horizontal shifts in what we call “relative Engel curves”—as long as preferences fall within the broad quasi-separable class (Gorman 1970, 1976). Our approach is flexible enough to allow for nonparametric estimation at each point of the income distribution. We apply the methodology to estimate inflation and welfare changes in rural India between 1987 and 2000. Our estimates reveal that lower rates of inflation for the rich erased the real income convergence found in the existing literature that uses the subset of consumption with well-measured prices to calculate inflation.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure income-specific changes in household welfare and inequality when well-measured prices are not available for important subsets of consumption?
answer: The authors develop a new approach using 'relative Engel curves' from expenditure survey microdata that can recover income-specific equivalent and compensating variations under quasi-separable preferences, revealing that lower inflation rates for the rich erased real income convergence in rural India between 1987-2000.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in existing literature by providing a methodology that works when well-measured prices are unavailable for important consumption categories, contrasting with existing studies that rely only on subsets of consumption with well-measured prices and may therefore miss important distributional effects.

author: David Baqaee
title: Cascading Failures in Production Networks
abstract: This paper analyzes a general equilibrium economy featuring input‐output connections, imperfect competition, and external economies of scale owing to entry and exit. The interaction of input‐output networks with industry‐level market structure affects the amplification of shocks and the pattern of diffusion in the model, generating cascades of firm entry and exit across the economy. In this model, sales provide a poor measure of the systemic importance of industries. Unlike the relevant notions of centrality in competitive constant‐returns‐to‐scale models, systemic importance depends on the industry's role as both a supplier and a consumer of inputs, as well as the market structure of industries. A basic calibration of the model suggests that aggregate output is three times more volatile in response to labor productivity shocks when compared to a perfectly competitive model.

author: David Baqaee
title: Networks, Barriers, and Trade
abstract: <jats:p>We study a flexible class of trade models with international production networks and arbitrary wedge‐like distortions like markups, tariffs, or nominal rigidities. We characterize the general equilibrium response of variables to shocks in terms of microeconomic statistics. Our results are useful for decomposing the sources of real GDP and welfare growth, and for computing counterfactuals. Using the same set of microeconomic sufficient statistics, we also characterize societal losses from increases in tariffs and iceberg trade costs and dissect the qualitative and quantitative importance of accounting for disaggregated details. Our results, which can be used to compute approximate and exact counterfactuals, provide an analytical toolbox for studying large‐scale trade models and help to bridge the gap between computation and theory.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we characterize the general equilibrium response of economic variables to shocks in trade models with international production networks and arbitrary wedge-like distortions using microeconomic statistics?
answer: The general equilibrium response can be characterized using a specific set of microeconomic sufficient statistics that allow for decomposing sources of real GDP and welfare growth, computing counterfactuals, and measuring societal losses from trade cost increases.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges the gap between computation and theory by providing an analytical toolbox that works across a flexible class of trade models, offering both approximate and exact counterfactual methods that can handle disaggregated details in large-scale trade models with production networks.

author: David Baqaee
title: Supply and Demand in Disaggregated Keynesian Economies with an Application to the COVID-19 Crisis
abstract: <jats:p> We study supply and demand shocks in a disaggregated model with multiple sectors, multiple factors, input-output linkages, downward nominal wage rigidities, credit-constraints, and a zero lower bound. We use the model to understand how the COVID-19 crisis, an omnibus supply and demand shock, affects output, unemployment, and inflation, and leads to the coexistence of tight and slack labor markets. We show that negative sectoral supply shocks are stagflationary, whereas negative demand shocks are deflationary, even though both can cause Keynesian unemployment. Furthermore, complementarities in production amplify Keynesian spillovers from supply shocks but mitigate them for demand shocks. This means that complementarities reduce the effectiveness of aggregate demand stimulus. In a stylized quantitative model of the United States, we find supply and demand shocks each explain about one-half of the reduction in real GDP from February to May 2020. Although there was as much as 6 percent Keynesian unemployment, this was concentrated in certain markets. Hence, aggregate demand stimulus is one quarter as effective as in a typical recession where all labor markets are slack. (JEL E12, E23, E24, E31, E32, E62, I12) </jats:p>
research_question: How do supply and demand shocks affect output, unemployment, and inflation in a disaggregated economy with multiple sectors and various frictions, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 crisis?
answer: Supply and demand shocks each explained about half of the GDP reduction during COVID-19 (February-May 2020). Negative supply shocks are stagflationary while negative demand shocks are deflationary, both causing Keynesian unemployment. Production complementarities amplify spillovers from supply shocks but mitigate them for demand shocks, making aggregate demand stimulus only one-quarter as effective as in typical recessions due to heterogeneous labor market conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper extends Keynesian macroeconomic analysis by incorporating disaggregation across multiple sectors and factors with input-output linkages, downward nominal wage rigidities, credit constraints, and zero lower bound constraints, providing a more nuanced framework for understanding how supply and demand shocks propagate differently through the economy compared to traditional aggregate models.

author: David Baqaee
title: Welfare and Output With Income Effects and Taste Shocks
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We present a unified treatment of how welfare responds to changes in budget sets or technologies with taste shocks and nonhomothetic preferences. We propose a welfare metric that ranks production possibility frontiers that differs from one that ranks budget sets and characterize it using a general equilibrium generalization of Hicksian demand. This extends Hulten’s theorem, the basis for constructing aggregate quantity indices, to environments with nonhomothetic and unstable preferences. We illustrate our results using both long- and short-run applications. In the long run, we show that if structural transformation is caused by income effects or changes in tastes, rather than substitution effects, then Baumol’s cost disease is twice as important for our preferred measure of welfare. In the short run, we show that standard chain-weighted deflators understate welfare-relevant inflation for current tastes. Finally, using the COVID-19 recession, we illustrate that chain-weighted real consumption and real GDP are unreliable metrics for measuring welfare or production when there are taste shocks.</jats:p>
research_question: How does welfare respond to changes in budget sets or technologies when there are taste shocks and nonhomothetic preferences?
answer: The paper proposes a new welfare metric that distinguishes between ranking production possibility frontiers versus budget sets, and shows that when structural transformation is driven by income effects or taste changes (rather than substitution effects), Baumol's cost disease has twice the impact on welfare, while standard chain-weighted measures understate welfare-relevant inflation and become unreliable during periods with taste shocks like COVID-19.
positioning_statement: This paper extends Hulten's theorem (the foundation for aggregate quantity indices) to environments with nonhomothetic and unstable preferences, providing a unified treatment that addresses limitations of existing welfare measurement approaches that assume homothetic preferences and stable tastes.

author: David Baqaee
title: Productivity and Misallocation in General Equilibrium
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper develops a general theory of aggregation in inefficient economies. We provide nonparametric formulas for aggregating microeconomic shocks in economies with distortions such as taxes, markups, frictions to resource reallocation, financial frictions, and nominal rigidities. We allow for arbitrary elasticities of substitution, returns to scale, factor mobility, and input-output network linkages. We show how to separately measure changes in technical and allocative efficiency. We also show how to compute the social cost of distortions. We pursue applications focusing on firm-level markups in the United States. We find that improvement in allocative efficiency, due to the reallocation over time of market share to high-markup firms, accounts for about half of aggregate TFP growth over the period 1997–2015. We also find that eliminating the misallocation resulting from the large and dispersed markups estimated in the data would raise aggregate TFP by about 15%, increasing the economy-wide cost of monopoly distortions by two orders of magnitude compared with the famous 0.1% estimate by Harberger (1954). These exact numbers should be interpreted with care because the data are imperfect and require substantial imputation.</jats:p>
research_question: How can microeconomic shocks be aggregated in economies with distortions, and what is the role of allocative efficiency versus technical efficiency in aggregate productivity growth?
answer: The paper finds that improvement in allocative efficiency (reallocation of market share to high-markup firms) accounts for about half of aggregate TFP growth in the US from 1997-2015, and eliminating misallocation from dispersed markups would raise aggregate TFP by about 15%, making the cost of monopoly distortions two orders of magnitude larger than Harberger's famous 0.1% estimate.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a general theory of aggregation in inefficient economies that extends beyond existing literature by providing nonparametric formulas that work with arbitrary elasticities of substitution, returns to scale, factor mobility, and input-output networks, while allowing separate measurement of technical and allocative efficiency changes, significantly revising upward the estimated costs of market distortions compared to classic estimates like Harberger (1954).

author: David Baqaee
title: The Darwinian Returns to Scale
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>How does an increase in market size, say due to globalization, affect welfare? We study this question using a model with monopolistic competition, heterogeneous markups, and fixed costs. We characterize changes in welfare and decompose changes in allocative efficiency into three different effects: (1) reallocations across firms with heterogeneous price elasticities due to intensifying competition, (2) reallocations due to the exit of marginally profitable firms, and (3) reallocations due to changes in firms’ markups. Whereas the second and third effects have ambiguous implications for welfare, the first effect, which we call the Darwinian effect, always increases welfare regardless of the shape of demand curves. We nonparametrically calibrate demand curves with data from Belgian manufacturing firms and quantify our results. We find that mild increasing returns at the microlevel can catalyze large increasing returns at the macrolevel. Between 70 and 90% of increasing returns to scale come from improvements in how a larger market allocates resources. The lion’s share of these gains are due to the Darwinian effect, which increases the aggregate markup and concentrates sales and employment in high-markup firms. This has implications for policy: an entry subsidy, which harnesses Darwinian reallocations, can improve welfare even when there is more entry than in the first best.</jats:p>
research_question: How does an increase in market size, say due to globalization, affect welfare?
answer: An increase in market size improves welfare primarily through the 'Darwinian effect' - reallocations across firms with heterogeneous price elasticities due to intensifying competition. This effect always increases welfare and accounts for the lion's share of gains, with 70-90% of increasing returns to scale coming from improvements in how a larger market allocates resources by concentrating sales and employment in high-markup firms.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the monopolistic competition literature by developing a model with heterogeneous markups and fixed costs that decomposes allocative efficiency changes into three distinct effects, introducing the novel concept of the 'Darwinian effect' and demonstrating how mild increasing returns at the microlevel can generate large increasing returns at the macrolevel through improved resource allocation.

author: David Baqaee
title: The Supply-Side Effects of Monetary Policy
abstract: We propose a supply-side channel for the transmission of monetary policy. We show that when high-markup firms have lower pass-throughs than low-markup firms, then positive demand shocks, such as monetary expansions, alleviate cross-sectional misallocation by reallocating resources to high-markup firms. Consequently, positive “demand shocks” are accompanied by endogenous positive “supply shocks” that raise productivity and lower inflation. We derive a tractable, four-equation model where monetary shocks generate hump-shaped productivity responses. In our calibration, the supply-side effect amplifies the total impact of monetary shocks on output by about 70%. We provide empirical evidence validating our model’s predictions using identified monetary shocks.

author: David Baqaee
title: The Macroeconomic Impact of Microeconomic Shocks: Beyond Hulten's Theorem
abstract: <jats:p>We provide a nonlinear characterization of the macroeconomic impact of microeconomic productivity shocks in terms of reduced‐form nonparametric elasticities for efficient economies. We also show how microeconomic parameters are mapped to these reduced‐form general equilibrium elasticities. In this sense, we extend the foundational theorem of Hulten (1978) beyond the first order to capture nonlinearities. Key features ignored by first‐order approximations that play a crucial role are: structural microeconomic elasticities of substitution, network linkages, structural microeconomic returns to scale, and the extent of factor reallocation. In a business‐cycle calibration with sectoral shocks, nonlinearities magnify negative shocks and attenuate positive shocks, resulting in an aggregate output distribution that is asymmetric (negative skewness), fat‐tailed (excess kurtosis), and has a negative mean, even when shocks are symmetric and thin‐tailed. Average output losses due to short‐run sectoral shocks are an order of magnitude larger than the welfare cost of business cycles calculated by Lucas (1987). Nonlinearities can also cause shocks to critical sectors to have disproportionate macroeconomic effects, almost tripling the estimated impact of the 1970s oil shocks on world aggregate output. Finally, in a long‐run growth context, nonlinearities, which underpin Baumol's cost disease via the increase over time in the sales shares of low‐growth bottleneck sectors, account for a 20 percentage point reduction in aggregate TFP growth over the period 1948–2014 in the United States.</jats:p>
research_question: How do microeconomic productivity shocks affect macroeconomic outcomes when accounting for nonlinear effects beyond first-order approximations?
answer: Nonlinearities significantly amplify the macroeconomic impact of microeconomic shocks, creating asymmetric effects (magnifying negative shocks while attenuating positive ones), resulting in fat-tailed output distributions with negative skewness and mean. These effects are driven by structural elasticities of substitution, network linkages, returns to scale, and factor reallocation, leading to welfare costs an order of magnitude larger than traditional business cycle estimates.
positioning_statement: This paper extends Hulten's (1978) foundational theorem beyond first-order approximations to capture nonlinear effects, addressing limitations of existing linear approaches that ignore crucial structural features like elasticities of substitution, network linkages, and factor reallocation in analyzing the transmission of microeconomic shocks to aggregate outcomes.

author: David Baqaee
title: Measuring Welfare by Matching Households across Time
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The money metric utility function is an essential tool for calculating welfare-relevant growth and inflation. We show how to recover it from repeated cross-sectional data without making parametric assumptions about preferences. We do this by solving the following recursive problem. Given compensated demand, we construct money metric utility by integration. Given money metric utility, we construct compensated demand by matching households over time whose money metric utility value is the same. We illustrate our method using household consumption survey data from the United Kingdom from 1974 to 2017 and find that real consumption calculated using official aggregate inflation statistics overstates money metric utility in 1974 pounds for the poorest households by around 0.5% a year and understates it by around a third of a percentage point per year for the richest households. We extend our method to allow for missing or mismeasured prices, assuming preferences are separable between goods with well-measured prices and the rest. We discuss how our results change if the prices of some service sectors are mismeasured.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we recover the money metric utility function from repeated cross-sectional data without making parametric assumptions about preferences to better measure welfare-relevant growth and inflation?
answer: The authors develop a recursive method that alternates between constructing money metric utility by integration from compensated demand and constructing compensated demand by matching households over time with the same money metric utility value. Applied to UK data (1974-2017), they find that official aggregate inflation statistics overstate money metric utility for the poorest households by around 0.5% annually and understate it for the richest households by around 0.33% annually.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the challenge of measuring welfare without parametric assumptions about preferences by developing a novel non-parametric approach to recover money metric utility from cross-sectional data, extending existing methods to handle missing or mismeasured prices under separability assumptions.

author: David Baqaee
title: How to Use Natural Experiments to Estimate Misallocation
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a method to estimate the effect of firm policies (e.g., bankruptcy laws) on allocative efficiency using (quasi-)experimental evidence. Our approach takes general equilibrium effects into account and requires neither a structural estimation nor a precise assumption on how the experiment affects firms. Our aggregation formula relies on treatment effects of the policy on the distribution of output-to-capital ratios, which are easily estimated. We show this method is valid for a large class of commonly used models in macrofinance. We apply it to the French banking deregulation episode of the mid- 1980s and find an increase in aggregate TFP of 5 percent. (JEL G21, G24, G28, G31, G32, H25) </jats:p>
research_question: How can natural experiments be used to estimate the effect of firm policies on allocative efficiency and misallocation?
answer: The authors develop a method that uses treatment effects on the distribution of output-to-capital ratios to estimate allocative efficiency effects, accounting for general equilibrium effects without requiring structural estimation or precise assumptions about how experiments affect firms. Applied to French banking deregulation in the mid-1980s, they find an increase in aggregate TFP of 5 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by proposing a novel methodological approach that overcomes limitations of existing methods - it accounts for general equilibrium effects while avoiding the need for structural estimation or precise assumptions about experimental effects on firms, and demonstrates validity across a large class of commonly used macrofinance models.

author: David Dillenberger
title: Allocation Mechanisms without Reduction
abstract: <jats:p> We study a simple variant of the house allocation problem (one-sided matching). We demonstrate that agents with recursive preferences may systematically prefer one allocation mechanism to the other, even among mechanisms that are considered to be the same in standard models, in the sense that they induce the same probability distribution over successful matchings. Using this, we propose a new priority groups mechanism and provide conditions under which it is preferred to two popular mechanisms, random top cycle and random serial dictatorship. (JEL C78, D44, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: How do agents with recursive preferences evaluate different allocation mechanisms in house allocation problems, and can a new mechanism be designed that they systematically prefer over existing popular mechanisms?
answer: Agents with recursive preferences systematically prefer certain allocation mechanisms over others, even when those mechanisms produce the same probability distribution over final matchings. A new priority groups mechanism can be designed that is preferred to both random top cycle and random serial dictatorship under specific conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the standard house allocation literature by introducing recursive preferences to distinguish between allocation mechanisms that are considered equivalent under standard models, thereby revealing preference differences that were previously undetectable and proposing an alternative mechanism design approach.

author: David Dillenberger
title: Caution and Reference Effects
abstract: <jats:p>We introduce Cautious Utility, a new model based on the idea that individuals are unsure of trade‐offs between goods and apply caution. The model yields an endowment effect, even when gains and losses are treated symmetrically. Moreover, it implies either loss aversion or loss neutrality for risk, but in a way unrelated to the endowment effect, and it captures the certainty effect, providing a novel unified explanation of all three phenomena. Cautious Utility can help organize empirical evidence, including some that directly contradicts leading alternatives.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a unified model explain the endowment effect, loss aversion/neutrality for risk, and the certainty effect based on individuals being unsure of trade-offs between goods?
answer: Yes, the Cautious Utility model successfully provides a unified explanation for all three phenomena by incorporating the idea that individuals apply caution when uncertain about trade-offs, yielding an endowment effect even with symmetric treatment of gains and losses, and capturing both risk preferences and certainty effects.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a novel unified explanation that can organize empirical evidence better than existing models, including evidence that directly contradicts leading alternative theories in behavioral economics.

title: Cautious Expected Utility and the Certainty Effect
