author: David Dillenberger
title: Deliberately Stochastic
abstract: <jats:p> We study stochastic choice as the outcome of deliberate randomization. We derive a general representation of a stochastic choice function where stochasticity allows the agent to achieve from any set the maximal element according to her underlying preferences over lotteries. We show that in this model stochasticity in choice captures complementarity between elements in the set, and thus necessarily implies violations of Regularity/Monotonicity, one of the most common properties of stochastic choice. This feature separates our approach from other models, e.g., Random Utility. (JEL D80, D81) </jats:p>
research_question: How can stochastic choice be understood as the outcome of deliberate randomization by agents?
answer: Stochastic choice can be represented as agents deliberately randomizing to achieve maximal elements according to their underlying preferences over lotteries, where stochasticity captures complementarity between elements in choice sets and necessarily violates Regularity/Monotonicity properties.
positioning_statement: This approach separates itself from existing models like Random Utility by showing that deliberate stochasticity necessarily implies violations of Regularity/Monotonicity, which is one of the most common properties assumed in other stochastic choice models.

author: David Lagakos
title: How Do Hours Worked Vary with Income? Cross-Country Evidence and Implications
abstract: <jats:p> This paper builds a new internationally comparable database of hours worked to measure how hours vary with income across and within countries. We document that average hours worked per adult are substantially higher in low-income countries than in high-income countries. The pattern of decreasing hours with aggregate income holds for both men and women, for adults of all ages and education levels, and along both the extensive and intensive margin. Within countries, hours worked per worker are also decreasing in the individual wage for most countries, though in the richest countries, hours worked are flat or increasing in the wage. One implication of our findings is that aggregate productivity and welfare differences across countries are larger than currently thought. (JEL E23, E24, J22, J31, O11, O15) </jats:p>
research_question: How do hours worked vary with income across and within countries?
answer: Average hours worked per adult are substantially higher in low-income countries than in high-income countries, with this pattern holding across demographics and margins. Within countries, hours per worker generally decrease with individual wages, except in the richest countries where hours are flat or increasing with wages.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes by building a new internationally comparable database of hours worked to provide comprehensive cross-country evidence on the relationship between hours and income, with implications that aggregate productivity and welfare differences across countries are larger than currently thought.

author: David Lagakos
title: Explaining Cross-Country Productivity Differences in Retail Trade

author: David Lagakos
title: Selection, Agriculture, and Cross-Country Productivity Differences
abstract: <jats:p> Cross-country labor productivity differences are larger in agriculture than in non-agriculture. We propose a new explanation for these patterns in which the self-selection of heterogeneous workers determines sector productivity. We formalize our theory in a general-equilibrium Roy model in which preferences feature a subsistence food requirement. In the model, subsistence requirements induce workers that are relatively unproductive at agricultural work to nonetheless select into the agriculture sector in poor countries. When parameterized, the model predicts that productivity differences are roughly twice as large in agriculture as non-agriculture even when countries differ by an economy-wide efficiency term that affects both sectors uniformly. (JEL J24, J31, J43, O11, O13, O40) </jats:p>
research_question: Why are cross-country labor productivity differences larger in agriculture than in non-agriculture?
answer: The self-selection of heterogeneous workers determines sector productivity - subsistence food requirements cause workers who are relatively unproductive at agricultural work to nonetheless select into the agriculture sector in poor countries, leading to productivity differences that are roughly twice as large in agriculture as non-agriculture.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new explanation for cross-country agricultural productivity patterns by developing a general-equilibrium Roy model with subsistence food requirements, offering an alternative mechanism to existing explanations for why agricultural productivity differences are systematically larger across countries.

author: David Dillenberger
title: Time Lotteries and Stochastic Impatience
abstract: <jats:p>We study preferences over lotteries in which both the prize and the payment date are uncertain. In particular, a<jats:italic>time lottery</jats:italic>is one in which the prize is fixed but the date is random. With Expected Discounted Utility, individuals must be risk<jats:italic>seeking</jats:italic>over time lotteries (RSTL). In an incentivized experiment, however, we find that almost all subjects violate this property. Our main contributions are theoretical. We first show that within a very broad class of models, which includes many forms of nonexpected utility and time discounting, it is impossible to accommodate even a single violation of RSTL without also violating a property we termed Stochastic Impatience, a risky counterpart of standard Impatience. We then present two positive results. If one wishes to maintain Stochastic Impatience, violations of RSTL can be accommodated by keeping Independence within periods while relaxing it across periods. If, instead, one is willing to forego Stochastic Impatience, violations of RSTL can be accommodated with a simple generalization of Expected Discounted Utility, obtained by imposing only the behavioral postulates of Discounted Utility and Expected Utility.</jats:p>
research_question: How do individuals make decisions over time lotteries where both the prize and payment date are uncertain, and can existing economic models accommodate observed violations of risk-seeking behavior over time lotteries?
answer: Almost all experimental subjects violate the Expected Discounted Utility prediction of being risk-seeking over time lotteries (RSTL). Within a broad class of models, accommodating even a single RSTL violation requires violating Stochastic Impatience. However, RSTL violations can be accommodated either by maintaining Stochastic Impatience while relaxing Independence across periods, or by foregoing Stochastic Impatience through a simple generalization of Expected Discounted Utility.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on decision-making under uncertainty by introducing the novel concept of time lotteries and demonstrating fundamental limitations of Expected Discounted Utility and other broad classes of models in explaining observed behavior, while proposing two theoretical solutions that relax different standard assumptions.

author: David Lagakos
title: The Welfare Effects of Encouraging Rural–Urban Migration
abstract: <jats:p>This paper studies the welfare effects of encouraging rural–urban migration in the developing world. To do so, we build and analyze a dynamic general‐equilibrium model of migration that features a rich set of migration motives. We estimate the model to replicate the results of a field experiment that subsidized seasonal migration in rural Bangladesh, leading to significant increases in migration and consumption. We show that the welfare gains from migration subsidies come from providing better insurance for vulnerable rural households rather than from correcting spatial misallocation by relaxing credit constraints for those with high productivity in urban areas that are stuck in rural areas.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the welfare effects of encouraging rural–urban migration in the developing world?
answer: The welfare gains from migration subsidies come from providing better insurance for vulnerable rural households rather than from correcting spatial misallocation by relaxing credit constraints for those with high productivity in urban areas that are stuck in rural areas.
positioning_statement: This paper builds and analyzes a dynamic general-equilibrium model of migration that features a rich set of migration motives, estimated to replicate results from a field experiment that subsidized seasonal migration in rural Bangladesh, distinguishing between insurance benefits versus spatial misallocation correction as sources of welfare gains.

author: David Lagakos
title: Labor Market Conflict and the Decline of the Rust Belt
abstract: No region of the United States fared worse over the postwar period than the Rust Belt. This paper analyzes how much of its decline can be accounted for by the persistent labor market conflict that characterized Rust Belt union-management relations. We develop a multisector, multiregion, dynamic general equilibrium model in which labor market conflict leads to strikes, wage premia, lower investment, and lower productivity growth. These lead to shrinking Rust Belt industries and to workers moving out of the Rust Belt. Labor conflict accounts for half of the decline in the region’s share of manufacturing employment. Foreign competition plays a smaller role, and its effects are concentrated after most of the region’s decline had already occurred.

author: David Lagakos
title: Agricultural Productivity Differences across Countries
abstract: <jats:p> Recent studies argue that cross-country labor productivity differences are much larger in agriculture than in the aggregate. We reexamine the agricultural productivity data underlying this conclusion using new evidence from disaggregate sources. We find that for the world's staple grains-maize, rice, and wheat-cross-country differences in the quantity of grain produced per worker are enormous according to both micro- and macrosources. Our findings validate the idea that understanding agricultural productivity is at the heart of understanding world income inequality. </jats:p>
research_question: Are cross-country labor productivity differences in agriculture actually much larger than in the aggregate economy, and what do disaggregate data sources reveal about agricultural productivity differences across countries?
answer: Cross-country differences in agricultural productivity are indeed enormous, with vast differences in the quantity of staple grains (maize, rice, and wheat) produced per worker across countries, as confirmed by both micro- and macro-level data sources.
positioning_statement: This paper reexamines and validates recent studies that argue agricultural productivity differences across countries are much larger than aggregate productivity differences, using new disaggregate evidence to confirm that understanding agricultural productivity is central to explaining world income inequality.

author: David Lagakos
title: The Agricultural Productivity Gap *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>According to national accounts data, value added per worker is much higher in the nonagricultural sector than in agriculture in the typical country, particularly in developing countries. Taken at face value, this “agricultural productivity gap” suggests that labor is greatly misallocated across sectors. In this article, we draw on new micro evidence to ask to what extent the gap is still present when better measures of sector labor inputs and value added are taken into consideration. We find that even after considering sector differences in hours worked and human capital per worker, as well as alternative measures of sector output constructed from household survey data, a puzzlingly large gap remains.</jats:p>
research_question: To what extent does the agricultural productivity gap persist when better measures of sector labor inputs and value added are taken into consideration?
answer: Even after accounting for sector differences in hours worked and human capital per worker, as well as using alternative measures of sector output from household survey data, a puzzlingly large agricultural productivity gap remains.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on existing literature that has identified the agricultural productivity gap in national accounts data by using new micro evidence to provide more accurate measurements of labor inputs and value added across sectors, thereby testing whether the gap is an artifact of measurement issues or a genuine economic phenomenon.

author: David Sraer
title: How to Use Natural Experiments to Estimate Misallocation
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a method to estimate the effect of firm policies (e.g., bankruptcy laws) on allocative efficiency using (quasi-)experimental evidence. Our approach takes general equilibrium effects into account and requires neither a structural estimation nor a precise assumption on how the experiment affects firms. Our aggregation formula relies on treatment effects of the policy on the distribution of output-to-capital ratios, which are easily estimated. We show this method is valid for a large class of commonly used models in macrofinance. We apply it to the French banking deregulation episode of the mid- 1980s and find an increase in aggregate TFP of 5 percent. (JEL G21, G24, G28, G31, G32, H25) </jats:p>
research_question: How can natural experiments be used to estimate the effect of firm policies on allocative efficiency and misallocation?
answer: The authors develop a method that uses treatment effects on the distribution of output-to-capital ratios to estimate allocative efficiency effects, accounting for general equilibrium effects without requiring structural estimation or precise assumptions about how experiments affect firms. Applied to French banking deregulation in the mid-1980s, they find an increase in aggregate TFP of 5 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by proposing a novel methodological approach that overcomes limitations of existing methods - it accounts for general equilibrium effects while avoiding the need for structural estimation or precise assumptions about experimental effects on firms, and demonstrates validity across a large class of commonly used macrofinance models.

author: David Sraer
title: The Collateral Channel: How Real Estate Shocks Affect Corporate Investment
abstract: <jats:p> What is the impact of real estate prices on corporate investment? In the presence of financing frictions, firms use pledgeable assets as collateral to finance new projects. Through this collateral channel, shocks to the value of real estate can have a large impact on aggregate investment. To compute the sensitivity of investment to collateral value, we use local variations in real estate prices as shocks to the collateral value of firms that own real estate. Over the 1993–2007 period, the representative US corporation invests $0.06 out of each $1 of collateral. (JEL D22, G31, R30) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of real estate prices on corporate investment?
answer: The representative US corporation invests $0.06 out of each $1 of collateral, demonstrating that real estate shocks have a significant impact on aggregate investment through the collateral channel where firms use pledgeable real estate assets as collateral to finance new projects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financing frictions by identifying and quantifying the collateral channel mechanism, using local variations in real estate prices as an empirical strategy to measure how shocks to collateral value affect corporate investment decisions.

author: David Thesmar
title: Overreaction in Expectations: Evidence and Theory
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We investigate biases in expectations across different settings through a large-scale randomized experiment where participants forecast stable stochastic processes. The experiment allows us to control forecasters’ information sets as well as the data-generating process, so we can cleanly measure biases in beliefs. We report three facts. First, forecasts display significant overreaction to the most recent observation. Second, overreaction is stronger for less persistent processes. Third, overreaction is also stronger for longer forecast horizons. We develop a tractable model of expectations formation with costly processing of past information, which closely fits the empirical facts. We also perform additional experiments to test the mechanism of the model.</jats:p>
research_question: What biases exist in expectations formation when people forecast stable stochastic processes, and what mechanisms can explain these biases?
answer: Forecasts display significant overreaction to the most recent observation, with stronger overreaction occurring for less persistent processes and longer forecast horizons. A model of expectations formation with costly processing of past information can explain these empirical patterns.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on biases in expectations by providing controlled experimental evidence of overreaction patterns and developing a tractable theoretical model based on costly information processing, which offers a mechanism-based explanation for observed forecasting biases across different settings.

author: David Yanagizawa-Drott
title: Propaganda and Conflict: Evidence from the Rwandan Genocide *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article investigates the role of mass media in times of conflict and state-sponsored mass violence against civilians. We use a unique village-level data set from the Rwandan genocide to estimate the impact of a popular radio station that encouraged violence against the Tutsi minority population. The results show that the broadcasts had a significant effect on participation in killings by both militia groups and ordinary civilians. An estimated 51,000 perpetrators, or approximately 10% of the overall violence, can be attributed to the station. The broadcasts increased militia violence not only directly by influencing behavior in villages with radio reception but also indirectly by increasing participation in neighboring villages. In fact, spillovers are estimated to have caused more militia violence than the direct effects. Thus, the article provides evidence that mass media can affect participation in violence directly due to exposure and indirectly due to social interactions.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of mass media in times of conflict and state-sponsored mass violence against civilians, specifically examining the impact of radio broadcasts that encouraged violence during the Rwandan genocide?
answer: Mass media broadcasts had a significant effect on participation in killings by both militia groups and ordinary civilians, with an estimated 51,000 perpetrators (approximately 10% of overall violence) attributable to the radio station. The broadcasts increased violence both directly in villages with radio reception and indirectly through spillovers to neighboring villages, with spillovers causing more militia violence than direct effects.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence using unique village-level data to quantify the causal impact of mass media on violent behavior during conflict, demonstrating that media affects participation in violence through both direct exposure effects and indirect social interaction effects.

author: David Thesmar
title: The Sovereign-Bank Diabolic Loop and ESBies
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a simple model of the sovereign-bank diabolic loop, and establish four results. First, the diabolic loop can be avoided by restricting banks' domestic sovereign exposures relative to their equity. Second, equity requirements can be lowered if banks only hold senior domestic sovereign debt. Third, such requirements shrink even further if banks only hold the senior tranche of an internationally diversified sovereign portfolio--known as ESBies in the euro-area context. Finally, ESBies generate more safe assets than domestic debt tranching alone; and, insofar as the diabolic loop is defused, the junior tranche generated by the securitization is itself risk-free. </jats:p>
research_question: How can the sovereign-bank diabolic loop be avoided or mitigated, and what role can ESBies (European Safe Bonds) play in this process?
answer: The diabolic loop can be avoided by restricting banks' domestic sovereign exposures relative to their equity, and this can be achieved more efficiently through ESBies - senior tranches of internationally diversified sovereign portfolios - which require lower equity requirements than domestic sovereign debt and generate more safe assets while making the junior tranche risk-free.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on sovereign-bank linkages by proposing a simple theoretical model that formalizes the diabolic loop problem and provides analytical solutions, specifically advancing the ESBies proposal in the euro-area context as a mechanism to break the vicious cycle between sovereign and banking crises.

author: David Yanagizawa-Drott
title: Long-Range Growth: Economic Development in the Global Network of Air Links*

author: David Yanagizawa-Drott
title: Does Religion Affect Economic Growth and Happiness? Evidence from Ramadan *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the economic effects of religious practices in the context of the observance of Ramadan fasting, one of the central tenets of Islam. To establish causality, we exploit variation in the length of daily fasting due to the interaction between the rotating Islamic calendar and a country’s latitude. We report two key, quantitatively meaningful results: (i) longer Ramadan fasting has a negative effect on output growth in Muslim countries, and (ii) it increases subjective well-being among Muslims. We find evidence that these patterns are consistent with a standard club good explanation for the emergence of costly religious practices: increased strictness of fasting screens out the less committed members, while the more committed respond with an increase in their relative levels of participation. Together, our results underscore that religious practices can affect individual behavior and beliefs in ways that have negative implications for economic performance, but that nevertheless increase subjective well-being among followers.</jats:p>
research_question: Does religious practice, specifically Ramadan fasting observance, affect economic growth and happiness?
answer: Longer Ramadan fasting has a negative effect on output growth in Muslim countries but increases subjective well-being among Muslims, consistent with a club good explanation where costly religious practices screen out less committed members while increasing participation among the more committed.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on religion and economics by providing causal evidence on how religious practices affect both economic performance and subjective well-being, using a novel identification strategy that exploits exogenous variation in fasting length due to the interaction between the Islamic calendar and geographic latitude.

author: David Yanagizawa-Drott
title: Misperceived Social Norms: Women Working Outside the Home in Saudi Arabia
abstract: <jats:p> We show that the vast majority of young married men in Saudi Arabia privately support women working outside the home (WWOH) and substantially underestimate support by other similar men. Correcting these beliefs increases men’s (costly) willingness to help their wives search for jobs. Months later, wives of men whose beliefs were corrected are more likely to have applied and interviewed for a job outside the home. In a recruitment experiment with a local company, randomly informing women about actual support for WWOH leads them to switch from an at-home temporary enumerator job to a higher-paying, outside-the-home version of the job. (JEL D83, J16, J22, O15, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: Do misperceived social norms about women working outside the home affect labor market participation decisions in Saudi Arabia?
answer: Yes, correcting men's underestimation of social support for women working outside the home increases their willingness to help wives search for jobs and leads to higher job application rates by women, demonstrating that misperceived social norms constrain female labor force participation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on social norms and labor market participation by providing experimental evidence that misperceptions of social support, rather than actual opposition, can constrain women's workforce participation in traditional societies.

author: David Yanagizawa-Drott
title: Opinions as Facts
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The rise of opinion programs has transformed television news. Because they present anchors’ subjective commentary and analysis, opinion programs often convey conflicting narratives about reality. We experimentally document that people across the ideological spectrum turn to opinion programs over “straight news”, even when provided large incentives to learn objective facts. We then examine the consequences of diverging narratives between opinion programs in a high-stakes setting: the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in the US. We find stark differences in the adoption of preventative behaviours among viewers of the two most popular opinion programs, both on the same network, which adopted opposing narratives about the threat posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. We then show that areas with greater relative viewership of the program downplaying the threat experienced a greater number of COVID-19 cases and deaths. Our evidence suggests that opinion programs may distort important beliefs and behaviours.</jats:p>
research_question: How do opinion programs on television news affect people's beliefs and behaviors, particularly in high-stakes situations like the COVID-19 pandemic?
answer: People prefer opinion programs over straight news even when incentivized to learn objective facts, and diverging narratives between opinion programs lead to stark differences in preventative behaviors and health outcomes - areas with greater viewership of programs downplaying COVID-19 threats experienced more cases and deaths.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the transformation of television news due to the rise of opinion programs and their role in conveying conflicting narratives about reality, contributing to understanding how media consumption affects real-world beliefs and behaviors in consequential settings.

author: David Yanagizawa-Drott
title: Do Political Protests Matter? Evidence from the Tea Party Movement*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Can protests cause political change, or are they merely symptoms of underlying shifts in policy preferences? We address this question by studying the Tea Party movement in the United States, which rose to prominence through coordinated rallies across the country on Tax Day, April 15, 2009. We exploit variation in rainfall on the day of these rallies as an exogenous source of variation in attendance. We show that good weather at this initial, coordinating event had significant consequences for the subsequent local strength of the movement, increased public support for Tea Party positions, and led to more Republican votes in the 2010 midterm elections. Policy making was also affected, as incumbents responded to large protests in their district by voting more conservatively in Congress. Our estimates suggest significant multiplier effects: an additional protester increased the number of Republican votes by a factor well above 1. Together our results show that protests can build political movements that ultimately affect policy making and that they do so by influencing political views rather than solely through the revelation of existing political preferences.</jats:p>
research_question: Can protests cause political change, or are they merely symptoms of underlying shifts in policy preferences?
answer: Protests can build political movements that ultimately affect policy making by influencing political views rather than solely through the revelation of existing political preferences. The study finds significant multiplier effects where an additional protester increased Republican votes by a factor well above 1, and good weather at initial Tea Party rallies led to stronger local movements, increased public support for Tea Party positions, more Republican votes in 2010 midterms, and more conservative voting by incumbents in Congress.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental question in political economy about whether protests are causal drivers of political change or merely reflective of underlying preference shifts. The authors position their work as providing causal evidence for the effectiveness of protests by exploiting exogenous variation in weather conditions, thereby contributing to the literature on political movements and their impact on electoral outcomes and policy making.

author: David Yanagizawa-Drott
title: Lemon Technologies and Adoption: Measurement, Theory and Evidence from Agricultural Markets in Uganda*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>To reduce poverty and food insecurity in Africa requires raising productivity in agriculture. Systematic use of fertilizer and hybrid seed is a pathway to increased productivity, but adoption of these technologies remains low. We investigate whether the quality of agricultural inputs can help explain low take-up. Testing modern products purchased in local markets, we find that 30% of nutrient is missing in fertilizer, and hybrid maize seed is estimated to contain less than 50% authentic seeds. We document that such low quality results in low average returns. If authentic technologies replaced these low-quality products, however, average returns are high. To rationalize the findings, we calibrate a learning model using data from our agricultural trials. Because agricultural yields are noisy, farmers’ ability to learn about quality is limited and this can help explain the low quality equilibrium we observe, but also why the market has not fully collapsed.</jats:p>
research_question: Can the quality of agricultural inputs help explain low adoption rates of fertilizer and hybrid seed technologies in African agriculture?
answer: Yes, poor input quality significantly explains low adoption - 30% of fertilizer nutrients are missing and hybrid maize seed contains less than 50% authentic seeds, resulting in low average returns that discourage adoption, while authentic technologies would yield high returns.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on agricultural technology adoption in Africa by identifying input quality as a key explanatory factor for low take-up rates, moving beyond traditional explanations to focus on the 'lemon' problem in agricultural input markets and using a learning model to explain why low-quality equilibrium persists without complete market collapse.

author: David Yanagizawa-Drott
title: Social capital vs institutions in the growth process

author: David Yang
title: Policy Experimentation in China: The Political Economy of Policy Learning
abstract: Many governments engage in policy experimentation in various forms to resolve uncertainty and facilitate learning. However, little is understood about the characteristics of policy experimentation, and how the structure of experimentation may affect policy learning and policy outcomes. We describe and explain China's policy experimentation since 1980, among the largest and most systematic in recent history. We collect comprehensive data on policy experiments conducted in China over the past four decades. We document three facts. First, about 90\% of the experiments exhibit positive sample selection in terms of a locality's economic development. Second, careerdriven local politicians allocate more resources to ensure the experiments' success, and such effort is not replicable when policies roll out to the entire country. Third, the central government is not fully sophisticated when interpreting experimentation outcomes. Under certain experimentation objectives, these facts imply that policy learning may be biased and national policies originating from the experimentation may be distorted. Taken together, while China's bureaucratic and institutional conditions make policy experimentation possible at an unparalleled scale, the complex political environments can also impose limitation on effective policy learning.

author: Davide Cantoni
title: Medieval Universities, Legal Institutions, and the Commercial Revolution *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We present new data documenting medieval Europe’s Commercial Revolution using information on the establishment of markets in Germany. We use these data to test whether medieval universities played a causal role in expanding economic activity, examining the foundation of Germany’s first universities after 1386 following the papal schism. We find that the trend rate of market establishment breaks upward in 1386 and this break is greatest where the distance to a university shrank most. There is no differential pre-1386 trend associated with the reduction in distance to a university, and there is no break in trend in 1386 where university proximity did not change. These results are robust to estimating a variety of specifications that address concerns about the endogeneity of university location. Universities provided training in newly rediscovered Roman and canon law; students with legal training served in positions that reduced the uncertainty of trade in the Middle Ages. We argue that training in the law, and the consequent development of legal and administrative institutions, was an important channel linking universities and greater economic activity in medieval Germany.</jats:p>
research_question: Did medieval universities play a causal role in expanding economic activity during Europe's Commercial Revolution?
answer: Yes, medieval universities causally expanded economic activity. The trend rate of market establishment broke upward in 1386 (when Germany's first universities were founded after the papal schism), with the greatest increase occurring where distance to a university shrank most.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new empirical evidence to the literature on medieval economic development by providing novel data on market establishment in Germany and demonstrating a causal link between universities and commercial expansion, specifically through the channel of legal training and institutional development that reduced trade uncertainty.

author: Davide Cantoni
title: The Rise of Fiscal Capacity: Administration and State Consolidation in the Holy Roman Empire
abstract: <jats:p>This paper studies the role of fiscal capacity in European state consolidation. Our analysis is organized around novel data on the territories and cities of the Holy Roman Empire in the early modern period. Territories implementing an early fiscal reform were more likely to survive, increased in size, and achieved a more compact extent. We provide evidence for the causal interpretation of these results and show key mechanisms: revenues, military investments, and marriage success. The imposition of Imperial taxes, quasi‐random in timing and size, increased the benefits of an efficient tax administration on the side of rulers, driving the implementation of fiscal centralization. Within territories, Chambers became the dominant administrative institution, tilting the consolidating states toward absolutism.</jats:p>
research_question: What role did fiscal capacity play in European state consolidation during the early modern period in the Holy Roman Empire?
answer: Territories that implemented early fiscal reforms were more likely to survive, increased in size, and achieved more compact territorial extent through improved revenues, military investments, and marriage success, with fiscal centralization driving state consolidation toward absolutism.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel empirical evidence on the relationship between fiscal capacity and state formation using new data from Holy Roman Empire territories and cities, providing causal identification through quasi-random Imperial tax impositions to demonstrate mechanisms linking fiscal administration to political consolidation.

author: David Yang
title: The Impact of Media Censorship: 1984 or Brave New World?
abstract: <jats:p> Media censorship is a hallmark of authoritarian regimes. We conduct a field experiment in China to measure the effects of providing citizens with access to an uncensored internet. We track subjects’ media consumption, beliefs regarding the media, economic beliefs, political attitudes, and behaviors over 18 months. We find four main results: (i) free access alone does not induce subjects to acquire politically sensitive information; (ii) temporary encouragement leads to a persistent increase in acquisition, indicating that demand is not permanently low; (iii) acquisition brings broad, substantial, and persistent changes to knowledge, beliefs, attitudes, and intended behaviors; and (iv) social transmission of information is statistically significant but small in magnitude. We calibrate a simple model to show that the combination of low demand for uncensored information and the moderate social transmission means China’s censorship apparatus may remain robust to a large number of citizens receiving access to an uncensored internet. (JEL C93, D72, D83, L82, L86, L88, P36) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of providing citizens with access to uncensored internet on their media consumption, beliefs, political attitudes, and behaviors in an authoritarian regime?
answer: Free access to uncensored internet alone does not lead citizens to seek politically sensitive information, but temporary encouragement creates persistent increases in information acquisition that substantially changes knowledge, beliefs, attitudes, and intended behaviors. However, social transmission of information is limited, suggesting censorship systems may remain robust even with widespread uncensored access.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on media censorship and authoritarian control by conducting the first field experiment measuring the causal effects of uncensored internet access on citizen behavior, providing empirical evidence to inform theoretical debates about whether censorship operates through limiting supply (1984-style) or manipulating demand (Brave New World-style).

author: Davide Cantoni
title: Religious Competition and Reallocation: the Political Economy of Secularization in the Protestant Reformation*

author: Davide Cantoni
title: The Consequences of Radical Reform: The French Revolution
abstract: <jats:p> The French Revolution had a momentous impact on neighboring countries. It removed the legal and economic barriers protecting oligarchies, established the principle of equality before the law, and prepared economies for the new industrial opportunities of the second half of the 19th century. We present within-Germany evidence on the long-run implications of these institutional reforms. Occupied areas appear to have experienced more rapid urbanization growth, especially after 1850. A two-stage least squares strategy provides evidence consistent with the hypothesis that the reforms instigated by the French had a positive impact on growth. JEL: N13, N43, O47 </jats:p>
research_question: What were the long-run economic implications of the institutional reforms instigated by the French Revolution, particularly in occupied German territories?
answer: The French Revolution's institutional reforms had a positive impact on long-run economic growth, with occupied areas experiencing more rapid urbanization growth, especially after 1850, as these reforms removed barriers protecting oligarchies, established equality before the law, and prepared economies for industrial opportunities.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing within-Germany empirical evidence on the long-run economic consequences of the French Revolution's institutional reforms, using a two-stage least squares identification strategy to establish causal effects on growth and urbanization in occupied versus non-occupied areas.

author: Davide Cantoni
title: Protests as Strategic Games: Experimental Evidence from Hong Kong's Antiauthoritarian Movement*
abstract: Social scientists have long viewed the decision to protest as strategic, with an individual's participation a function of their beliefs about others’ turnout. We conduct a framed field experiment that recalibrates individuals’ beliefs about others’ protest participation, in the context of Hong Kong's ongoing antiauthoritarian movement. We elicit subjects’ planned participation in an upcoming protest and their prior beliefs about others’ participation, in an incentivized manner. One day before the protest, we randomly provide a subset of subjects with truthful information about others’ protest plans and elicit posterior beliefs about protest turnout, again in an incentivized manner. After the protest, we elicit subjects’ actual participation. This allows us to identify the causal effects of positively and negatively updated beliefs about others’ protest participation on subjects’ own turnout. In contrast with the assumptions of many recent models of protest participation, we consistently find evidence of strategic substitutability. We provide guidance regarding plausible sources of strategic substitutability that can be incorporated into theoretical models of protests.

author: Davide Cantoni
title: Persistent Political Engagement: Social Interactions and the Dynamics of Protest Movements
abstract: <jats:p>We study the causes of sustained participation in political movements. To identify the persistent effect of protest participation, we randomly indirectly incentivize Hong Kong university students into participation in an antiauthoritarian protest. To identify the role of social networks, we randomize this treatment’s intensity across major-cohort cells. We find that incentives to attend one protest within a political movement increase subsequent protest attendance but only when a sufficient fraction of an individual’s social network is also incentivized to attend the initial protest. One-time mobilization shocks have dynamic consequences, with mobilization at the social network level important for sustained political engagement. (JEL D72, D74, I23, Z13)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the causes of sustained participation in political movements, specifically examining the persistent effects of protest participation and the role of social networks?
answer: Incentives to attend one protest increase subsequent protest attendance, but only when a sufficient fraction of an individual's social network is also incentivized to attend the initial protest. One-time mobilization shocks have dynamic consequences, with social network-level mobilization being crucial for sustained political engagement.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on political participation by using a randomized experimental approach to identify causal effects of both individual incentives and social network effects on sustained protest participation, addressing the challenge of identifying persistent effects in political movements through innovative methodology applied to Hong Kong university students.

author: Davide Cantoni
title: Curriculum and Ideology
abstract: We study the causal effect of school curricula on students’ political attitudes, exploiting a major textbook reform in China between 2004 and 2010. The sharp, staggered introduction of the new curriculum across provinces allows us to identify its causal effects. We examine government documents articulating desired consequences of the reform and identify changes in textbooks reflecting these aims. A survey we conducted reveals that the reform was often successful in shaping attitudes, while evidence on behavior is mixed. Studying the new curriculum led to more positive views of China’s governance, changed views on democracy, and increased skepticism toward free markets.

author: Davide Cantoni
title: Does Context Outweigh Individual Characteristics in Driving Voting Behavior? Evidence from Relocations within the United States
abstract: <jats:p> We measure the overall influence of contextual versus individual factors (e.g., voting rules and media as opposed to race and education) on voter behavior, and explore underlying mechanisms. Using a US-wide voter-level panel, 2008–2018, we examine voters who relocate across state and county lines, tracking changes in registration, turnout, and party affiliation to estimate location and individual fixed effects in a value-added model. Location explains 37 percent of the cross-state variation in turnout (to 63 percent for individual characteristics) and an only slightly smaller share of variation in party affiliation. Place effects are larger for young and White voters. (JEL D12, D72, I20, J15, L82, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relative influence of contextual factors (such as voting rules and media) versus individual characteristics (such as race and education) in driving voting behavior?
answer: Location/contextual factors explain 37 percent of cross-state variation in voter turnout (compared to 63 percent for individual characteristics) and a slightly smaller share of variation in party affiliation, with place effects being larger for young and White voters.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a comprehensive measurement of the overall influence of contextual versus individual factors on voter behavior using a novel approach that tracks individual voters who relocate across state and county lines, employing a value-added model with location and individual fixed effects to separate these influences.

author: Davide Cantoni
title: Strict Id Laws Don’t Stop Voters: Evidence from a U.S. Nationwide Panel, 2008–2018
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>U.S. states increasingly require identification to vote—an ostensible attempt to deter fraud that prompts complaints of selective disenfranchisement. Using a difference-in-differences design on a panel data set with 1.6 billion observations, 2008–2018, we find that the laws have no negative effect on registration or turnout, overall or for any group defined by race, gender, age, or party affiliation. These results hold through a large number of specifications. Our most demanding specification controls for state, year, and voter fixed effects, along with state and voter time-varying controls. Based on this specification, we obtain point estimates of −0.1 percentage points for effects both on overall registration and turnout (with 95% confidence intervals of [−2.3; 2.1 percentage points] and [−3.0; 2.8 percentage points], respectively), and +1.4 percentage points for the effect on the turnout of nonwhite voters relative to whites (with a 95% confidence interval of [−0.5; 3.2 percentage points]). The lack of negative impact on voter turnout cannot be attributed to voters’ reaction against the laws, measured by campaign contributions and self-reported political engagement. However, the likelihood that nonwhite voters were contacted by a campaign increases by 4.7 percentage points, suggesting that parties’ mobilization might have offset modest effects of the laws on the participation of ethnic minorities. Finally, strict ID requirements have no effect on fraud, actual or perceived. Overall, our findings suggest that efforts to improve elections may be better directed at other reforms.</jats:p>
research_question: Do strict voter ID laws affect voter registration and turnout, particularly among different demographic groups defined by race, gender, age, or party affiliation?
answer: Strict voter ID laws have no negative effect on registration or turnout, either overall or for any demographic group. The laws also have no effect on fraud, actual or perceived, suggesting that efforts to improve elections may be better directed at other reforms.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the ongoing debate about voter ID laws in the U.S., where states increasingly require identification to vote as an ostensible attempt to deter fraud, but which prompts complaints of selective disenfranchisement. The study contributes to this literature by using a comprehensive nationwide panel dataset with 1.6 billion observations from 2008-2018 and employing rigorous difference-in-differences methodology.

author: Devin Pope
title: Predicting Experimental Results: Who Knows What?
abstract: We analyze how academic experts and nonexperts forecast the results of 15 piece-rate and behavioral treatments in a real-effort task. The average forecast of experts closely predicts the experimental results, with a strong wisdom-of-crowds effect: the average forecast outperforms 96 percent of individual forecasts. Citations, academic rank, field, and contextual experience do not correlate with accuracy. Experts as a group do better than nonexperts, but not if accuracy is defined as rank-ordering treatments. Measures of effort, confidence, and revealed ability are predictive of forecast accuracy to some extent and allow us to identify “superforecasters” among the nonexperts.

author: Devin Pope
title: What Motivates Effort? Evidence and Expert Forecasts

author: Devin Pope
title: Is Tiger Woods Loss Averse? Persistent Bias in the Face of Experience, Competition, and High Stakes
abstract: <jats:p> Although experimental studies have documented systematic decision errors, many leading scholars believe that experience, competition, and large stakes will reliably extinguish biases. We test for the presence of a fundamental bias, loss aversion, in a high-stakes context: professional golfers' performance on the PGA Tour. Golf provides a natural setting to test for loss aversion because golfers are rewarded for the total number of strokes they take during a tournament, yet each individual hole has a salient reference point, par. We analyze over 2.5 million putts using precise laser measurements and find evidence that even the best golfers—including Tiger Woods—show evidence of loss aversion. (JEL D03, D81, L83). </jats:p>
research_question: Do experience, competition, and high stakes eliminate loss aversion bias in decision-making, as tested through professional golfers' performance on the PGA Tour?
answer: No, loss aversion persists even among the best professional golfers despite their extensive experience, competitive environment, and high financial stakes - even elite players like Tiger Woods demonstrate evidence of loss aversion in their putting performance.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the prevailing scholarly belief that experience, competition, and large stakes reliably eliminate cognitive biases by providing empirical evidence from a high-stakes professional setting that contradicts experimental findings suggesting biases can be extinguished under such conditions.

author: Devin Pope
title: Heuristic Thinking and Limited Attention in the Car Market
abstract: <jats:p> Can heuristic information processing affect important product markets? Analyzing over 22 million wholesale used-car transactions, we find evidence of left-digit bias in the processing of odometer values, whereby individuals focus on the number's leftmost digits. The bias leads to discontinuous drops in sale prices at 10,000-mile odometer thresholds, along with smaller drops at 1,000-mile thresholds. These findings reveal that information-processing heuristics matter even in markets with large stakes and easily observed information. We model left-digit bias in an inattention framework and structurally estimate the inattention parameter. Empirical patterns suggest the results are driven by final customers rather than professional agents. (JEL D12, D44, D83, L81) </jats:p>
research_question: Can heuristic information processing affect important product markets?
answer: Yes, heuristic information processing significantly affects product markets, as evidenced by left-digit bias in odometer values causing discontinuous drops in used car sale prices at 10,000-mile and 1,000-mile thresholds.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on information-processing heuristics by demonstrating that such biases matter even in markets with large financial stakes and easily observable information, contrary to assumptions that high stakes would eliminate such behavioral effects.

author: Devin Pope
title: Left-Digit Bias at Lyft
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Left-digit bias (or 99-cent pricing) has been discussed extensively in economics, psychology, and marketing. Despite this, we show that the rideshare company, Lyft, was not using a 99-cent pricing strategy prior to our study. Based on observational data from over 600 million Lyft sessions followed by a field experiment conducted with 21 million Lyft passengers, we provide evidence of large discontinuities in demand at dollar values. Approximately half of the downward slope of the demand curve occurs discontinuously as the price of a ride drops below a dollar value (e.g. $14.00 to $13.99). If our short-run estimates persist in the longer run, we calculate that Lyft could increase its profits by roughly $160M per year by employing a left-digit bias pricing strategy. Our results showcase the robustness of an important behavioral bias for a large, modern company and its persistence in a highly competitive market.</jats:p>
research_question: Does left-digit bias (99-cent pricing) affect demand in the rideshare market, and what are the potential profit implications for Lyft?
answer: There are large discontinuities in demand at dollar values, with approximately half of the downward slope of the demand curve occurring discontinuously as prices drop below dollar values (e.g. $14.00 to $13.99), suggesting Lyft could increase profits by roughly $160M per year by employing left-digit bias pricing strategy.
positioning_statement: While left-digit bias has been extensively discussed in economics, psychology, and marketing literature, this paper demonstrates that a major rideshare company (Lyft) was not utilizing this well-established pricing strategy, and provides empirical evidence of its robustness and persistence in a large, modern, highly competitive market setting.

author: Devin Pope
title:
The Psychological Effect of Weather on Car Purchases
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>When buying durable goods, consumers must forecast how much utility they will derive from future consumption, including consumption in different states of the world. This can be complicated for consumers because making intertemporal evaluations may expose them to a variety of psychological biases such as present bias, projection bias, and salience effects. We investigate whether consumers are affected by such intertemporal biases when they purchase automobiles. Using data for more than 40 million vehicle transactions, we explore the impact of weather on purchasing decisions. We find that the choice to purchase a convertible or a four-wheel-drive is highly dependent on the weather at the time of purchase in a way that is inconsistent with classical utility theory. We consider a range of rational explanations for the empirical effects we find, but none can explain fully the effects we estimate. We then discuss and explore projection bias and salience as two primary psychological mechanisms that are consistent with our results.</jats:p>
research_question: Are consumers affected by intertemporal psychological biases when purchasing automobiles, specifically whether weather at the time of purchase influences decisions to buy convertibles or four-wheel-drive vehicles?
answer: Yes, consumers exhibit significant psychological biases when purchasing cars - the choice to purchase a convertible or four-wheel-drive vehicle is highly dependent on the weather at the time of purchase in ways that are inconsistent with classical utility theory, with projection bias and salience effects being the primary psychological mechanisms explaining this behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on intertemporal consumer decision-making and psychological biases in durable goods purchases by providing large-scale empirical evidence (40+ million transactions) of weather-dependent car purchasing decisions that cannot be explained by rational economic theories, thereby advancing understanding of projection bias and salience effects in real-world consumer behavior.

author: Devin Pope
title: Attribution Bias in Consumer Choice
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>When judging the value of a good, people may be overly influenced by the state in which they previously consumed it. For example, someone who tries out a new restaurant while very hungry may subsequently rate it as high quality, even if the food is mediocre. We produce a simple framework for this form of attribution bias that embeds a standard model of decision making as a special case. We test for attribution bias across two consumer decisions. First, we conduct an experiment in which we randomly manipulate the thirst of participants prior to consuming a new drink. Second, using data from thousands of amusement park visitors, we explore how pleasant weather during their most recent trip affects their stated and actual likelihood of returning. In both of these domains, we find evidence that people misattribute the influence of a temporary state to a stable quality of the consumption good. We provide evidence against several alternative accounts for our findings and discuss the broader implications of attribution bias in economic decision making.</jats:p>
research_question: Do people exhibit attribution bias when judging the value of goods by being overly influenced by the temporary state they were in when they previously consumed those goods?
answer: Yes, people do exhibit attribution bias - they misattribute the influence of temporary states (like hunger or pleasant weather) to stable qualities of consumption goods, as demonstrated through experiments with drink consumption under different thirst conditions and analysis of amusement park visitor return likelihood based on weather during previous visits.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a simple framework for attribution bias that embeds standard decision-making models as a special case, extending existing literature by providing empirical evidence for this bias across multiple consumer domains and ruling out alternative explanations.

author: Devin Pope
title: Estimating the Effect of Salience in Wholesale and Retail Car Markets
abstract: <jats:p> We investigate whether the first digit of an odometer reading is more salient to consumers than subsequent digits. We find that retail transaction prices and volumes of used vehicles drop discontinuously at 10,000-mile odometer thresholds, echoing effects found in the wholesale market by Lacetera, Pope and Sydnor (2012). Our results reveal that retail consumers devote limited attention to evaluating vehicle mileage, and that this drives effects in the wholesale market. We estimate the inattention parameter implied by the price discontinuities. In addition, our results suggest that estimating consumer-level structural parameters using data from an intermediate market can give misleading results. </jats:p>
research_question: Whether the first digit of an odometer reading is more salient to consumers than subsequent digits in wholesale and retail car markets
answer: Retail transaction prices and volumes of used vehicles drop discontinuously at 10,000-mile odometer thresholds, revealing that retail consumers devote limited attention to evaluating vehicle mileage, and this drives effects in the wholesale market
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Lacetera, Pope and Sydnor (2012) who found effects in the wholesale market, by extending the analysis to retail markets and demonstrating that retail consumer inattention drives wholesale market effects, while also showing that estimating consumer-level structural parameters using intermediate market data can be misleading

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Investment Shocks and Asset Prices

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Growth Opportunities and Technology Shocks
abstract: We propose a theoretically motivated procedure for measuring heterogeneity in firms’ growth opportunities and document its empirical properties. The term “growth opportunities” refers to the component of a firm’s market value that cannot be attributed to its assets in place. This decomposition of firm value underpins many of the theoretical models describing cross-sectional differences in firms’ investment and stock return behavior. However, successful applications of such models depend on the quality of empirical measures of growth opportunities. Our procedure identifies economically significant differences in firms’ growth opportunities which are not captured by the commonly used empirical measures. We base our approach on a theoretical model incorporating investment specific productivity shocks and heterogenous firms. Productivity shocks in the capital goods sector account for a significant fraction of observed growth variability, according to the literature on the real determinants of economic growth (Jeremy Greenwood, Zvi Hercowitz and Per Krusell 1997, Jonas D. M. Fisher 2006). Greenwood, Hercowitz and Krusell (1997) show that, empirically, investment specific shocks are negatively correlated with aggregate investment, both at business cycle and lower frequencies. Our model predicts that the sensitivity of firm stock returns to investment specific productivity shocks (z-shocks) is greater for firms that derive Growth Opportunities and Technology Shocks

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: The Value and Ownership of Intangible Capital
abstract: <jats:p> Intangible capital which relies on essential human inputs, or 'organization capital,' presents a unique challenge for measurement. Organization capital cannot be fully owned by firms' financiers, because it is partly embodied in key labor inputs. Instead, cash flows must be shared with key talent and thus neither book nor market values will fully capture its value. Measurement of organization capital requires a model featuring these unique property rights. We use accounting data along with a simple example of such a model to measure the fraction of the US capital stock which is missing from book and market values. </jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure the fraction of the US capital stock that is missing from book and market values due to organization capital that cannot be fully owned by firms' financiers?
answer: Organization capital that relies on essential human inputs cannot be fully captured in book or market values because it is partly embodied in key labor inputs, requiring cash flows to be shared with key talent, and measurement requires a model that accounts for these unique property rights.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a unique challenge in measuring intangible capital by focusing specifically on 'organization capital' that presents property rights issues not fully addressed in existing literature, requiring a new modeling approach that accounts for the shared ownership between firms and key talent.

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Left Behind: Creative Destruction, Inequality, and the Stock Market
abstract: We develop a general equilibrium model of asset prices in which benefits of technological innovation are distributed asymmetrically. Financial market participants do not capture all economic gains from innovation even when they own shares in innovating firms. Such gains accrue partly to the innovators, who cannot sell claims on proceeds from their future ideas. We show how the resulting inequality among agents can give rise to a high risk premium on the aggregate stock market, return comovement and average return differences among firms, and the failure of traditional representative agent asset pricing models to account for cross-sectional differences in risk premia.

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Technological Innovation, Resource Allocation, and Growth*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a new measure of the economic importance of each innovation. Our measure uses newly collected data on patents issued to U.S. firms in the 1926 to 2010 period, combined with the stock market response to news about patents. Our patent-level estimates of private economic value are positively related to the scientific value of these patents, as measured by the number of citations the patent receives in the future. Our new measure is associated with substantial growth, reallocation, and creative destruction, consistent with the predictions of Schumpeterian growth models. Aggregating our measure suggests that technological innovation accounts for significant medium-run fluctuations in aggregate economic growth and TFP. Our measure contains additional information relative to citation-weighted patent counts; the relation between our measure and firm growth is considerably stronger. Importantly, the degree of creative destruction that is associated with our measure is higher than previous estimates, confirming that it is a useful proxy for the private valuation of patents.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we better measure the economic importance of technological innovations and what is their impact on economic growth, resource allocation, and creative destruction?
answer: The paper develops a new measure combining patent data with stock market responses that better captures private economic value of innovations. This measure shows that technological innovation accounts for significant medium-run fluctuations in aggregate economic growth and TFP, and is associated with higher levels of creative destruction than previously estimated.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as improving upon existing literature by proposing a superior measure of innovation's economic importance that contains additional information relative to citation-weighted patent counts, with a considerably stronger relation to firm growth and higher estimates of creative destruction than previous studies.

author: Dimitry Muravyev
title: Unsafe Sex in the City: Risk Pricing in the London Area
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This paper studies the incidence, determinants, and pricing of unprotected oral sex in the London sex services market. The analysis is based upon matched sex worker–client panel data, which were collected from ‘field reports’ on PunterNet.com website over the 1999–2009 time period. We find a steady increase in the incidence of unprotected oral sex during this period, rising from <20% to over 50% of all transactions. We show that the average premium for unprotected oral sex amounts to about 10–14% of the transaction price, and that this premium is higher if a sex worker has agency affiliation. Agency affiliated sex workers are also less likely to engage in unprotected oral sex compared to independent sex workers.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the incidence, determinants, and pricing of unprotected oral sex in the London sex services market?
answer: The incidence of unprotected oral sex increased steadily from less than 20% to over 50% of transactions between 1999-2009, with an average premium of 10-14% of the transaction price. Agency-affiliated sex workers charge higher premiums but are less likely to engage in unprotected oral sex compared to independent sex workers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical analysis of risk pricing in sex markets using unique matched sex worker-client panel data from online field reports, offering quantitative insights into unsafe sexual practices and their economic determinants in a specific geographic market.

author: Dimitris Papanikolaou
title: Measuring Technological Innovation over the Long Run
abstract: <jats:p> We use textual analysis of high-dimensional data from patent documents to create new indicators of technological innovation. We identify important patents based on textual similarity of a given patent to previous and subsequent work: these patents are distinct from previous work but related to subsequent innovations. Our importance indicators correlate with existing measures of patent quality but also provide complementary information. We identify breakthrough innovations as the most important patents—those in the right tail of our measure—and construct time series indices of technological change at the aggregate and sectoral levels. Our technology indices capture the evolution of technological waves over a long time span (1840 to the present) and cover innovation by private and public firms as well as nonprofit organizations and the US government. Advances in electricity and transportation drive the index in the 1880s, chemicals and electricity in the 1920s and 1930s, and computers and communication in the post-1980s. (JEL C43, N71, N72, O31, O33, O34) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure technological innovation over the long run using patent documents to identify breakthrough innovations and construct time series indices of technological change?
answer: The paper develops new indicators of technological innovation using textual analysis of patent documents, identifying important patents based on their textual similarity to previous and subsequent work. These indicators successfully capture technological waves from 1840 to present, showing electricity and transportation advances in the 1880s, chemicals and electricity in the 1920s-1930s, and computers and communication post-1980s.
positioning_statement: The paper's importance indicators correlate with existing measures of patent quality but also provide complementary information, offering a novel textual analysis approach that extends measurement capabilities across a longer time span and broader institutional coverage than previous work.

author: Dmitry Mukhin
title: An Equilibrium Model of the International Price System
abstract: <jats:p> What explains the central role of the dollar in world trade? Will the US currency retain its dominant status in the future? This paper develops a quantitative general equilibrium framework with endogenous currency choice that can address these questions. Complementarities in price setting and input-output linkages across firms generate complementarities in currency choice making exporters coordinate on the same currency of invoicing. The dollar is more likely to play this role because of the large size of the US economy, a widespread peg to the dollar, and the history dependence in currency choice. Calibrated using the world input-output tables and exchange rate moments, the model can successfully replicate the key empirical facts about the use of currencies at the global level, across countries, and over time. According to the counterfactual analysis, the peg to the dollar in other economies ensures that the US currency is unlikely to lose its global status because of the falling US share in the world economy, but can be replaced by the renminbi in case of a negative shock in the US economy. If the peg is abandoned, the world is likely to move to a new equilibrium with multiple regional currencies. (JEL D21, E31, E42, F14, F31, F33) </jats:p>
research_question: What explains the central role of the dollar in world trade and will the US currency retain its dominant status in the future?
answer: The dollar's dominance is explained by complementarities in currency choice driven by the large size of the US economy, widespread pegging to the dollar, and history dependence. The dollar is unlikely to lose its status due to falling US economic share alone, but could be replaced by the renminbi following a negative US shock, or the world could move to multiple regional currencies if dollar pegs are abandoned.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a quantitative general equilibrium framework with endogenous currency choice that incorporates complementarities in price setting and input-output linkages across firms, calibrated using world input-output tables and exchange rate moments to replicate empirical facts about global currency use across countries and over time.

author: Dmitry Mukhin
title: Optimal Policy under Dollar Pricing
abstract: <jats:p> Empirical evidence shows that most international prices are sticky in dollars. This paper studies the policy implications of this fact in the context of an open economy model with general preferences, technologies, asset markets, nominal rigidities, and a rich set of shocks. We show that although monetary policy is less efficient and cannot implement the flexible-price allocation, inflation targeting and a floating exchange rate remain robustly optimal in non-US economies. The capital controls cannot unilaterally improve the allocation and are useful only when coordinated across countries. International cooperation benefits other economies, but is not in the self-interest of the United States. (JEL E31, E52, F14, F31, F38, F41) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the optimal monetary policy and capital control implications when international prices are sticky in dollars rather than local currencies?
answer: Despite reduced monetary policy efficiency under dollar pricing, inflation targeting and floating exchange rates remain robustly optimal for non-US economies, while capital controls are only useful when coordinated internationally, and international cooperation benefits other countries but not the United States.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing open economy monetary policy literature by incorporating the empirically documented fact that most international prices are sticky in dollars, analyzing policy implications in a general framework with various preferences, technologies, asset markets, nominal rigidities, and shocks.

author: Dmitry Mukhin
title: Sanctions and the Exchange Rate
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Trade wars and financial sanctions are again becoming an increasingly common part of the international economic landscape, and the dynamics of the exchange rate are often used in real time to evaluate the effectiveness of sanctions and policy responses. We show that sanctions limiting a country’s exports or freezing its assets depreciate the exchange rate, while sanctions limiting imports appreciate it, even when both types of policies have exactly the same effect on real allocations, including household welfare and government fiscal revenues. Beyond the direct effect from sanctions, increased precautionary savings in foreign currency also depreciate the exchange rate when they are not offset by the sale of official reserves or financial repression of foreign-currency savings. We show that the dynamics of the ruble exchange rate following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 are quantitatively consistent with the combined effects of these forces calibrated to the observed sanctions and government policies. We evaluate the associated welfare, fiscal and inflationary consequences for both Russia and the coalition of Western countries.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different types of sanctions affect exchange rate dynamics, and can these effects explain the ruble's behavior following Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022?
answer: Sanctions limiting a country's exports or freezing its assets depreciate the exchange rate, while sanctions limiting imports appreciate it, even when both have identical effects on real allocations. The ruble's exchange rate dynamics following Russia's invasion of Ukraine are quantitatively consistent with the combined effects of these sanctions mechanisms plus increased precautionary foreign currency savings.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on sanctions and exchange rates by demonstrating that exchange rate movements can occur even when sanctions have identical real economic effects, and by providing a framework to evaluate sanctions effectiveness in real-time through exchange rate dynamics in the context of contemporary trade wars and financial sanctions.

author: Dmitry Mukhin
title: Exchange Rate Disconnect in General Equilibrium
abstract: We propose a dynamic general equilibrium model of exchange rate determination that accounts for all major exchange rate puzzles, including Meese-Rogoff, Backus-Smith, purchasing power parity, and uncovered interest rate parity puzzles. We build on a standard international real business cycle model with home bias in consumption, augmented with shocks in the financial market that result in a volatile near-martingale behavior of exchange rates and ensure their empirically relevant comovement with macroeconomic variables, both nominal and real. Combining financial shocks with conventional productivity and monetary shocks allows the model to reproduce the exchange rate disconnect properties without compromising the fit of the business cycle moments.

author: Dmitry Mukhin
title: Mussa Puzzle Redux
abstract:
<jats:p>The Mussa (1986) puzzle is the observation of a sharp and simultaneous increase in the volatility of both nominal and real exchange rates following the end of the Bretton Woods System of pegged exchange rates in 1973. It is commonly viewed as a central piece of evidence in favor of monetary non‐neutrality because it is an instance in which a change in the monetary regime caused a dramatic change in the equilibrium behavior of a 
            <jats:italic>real</jats:italic> variable—the real exchange rate—and is often further interpreted as direct evidence in favor of models with 
            <jats:italic>nominal rigidities</jats:italic> in price setting. This paper shows that the data do not support this latter conclusion because there was no simultaneous change in the properties of the other macro variables, nominal or real; an extended set of Mussa facts falsifies both 
            <jats:italic>conventional</jats:italic> flexible‐price RBC models and sticky‐price New Keynesian models. We present a resolution to the broader Mussa puzzle based on a model of segmented financial market, in which the bulk of the 
            <jats:italic>nominal</jats:italic> exchange rate risk is held by financial intermediaries and is not shared smoothly throughout the economy, emphasizing the importance of monetary transmission via the risk premium channel.
