          </jats:p>
research_question: Why did both nominal and real exchange rate volatility increase sharply and simultaneously after the end of the Bretton Woods System in 1973, and what does this tell us about monetary non-neutrality and the role of nominal rigidities?
answer: The Mussa puzzle cannot be explained by conventional sticky-price New Keynesian models or flexible-price RBC models because other macroeconomic variables did not show simultaneous changes in their properties. The puzzle is resolved through a segmented financial market model where nominal exchange rate risk is concentrated among financial intermediaries rather than shared throughout the economy, with monetary transmission occurring via the risk premium channel.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional interpretation of the Mussa puzzle as evidence for nominal rigidities in price setting by showing that existing sticky-price New Keynesian and flexible-price RBC models are both falsified by an extended set of empirical facts, and proposes an alternative explanation based on segmented financial markets rather than nominal rigidities.

author: Dong Lou
title: Superstar Firms and College Major Choice

author: Edouard Schaal
title: Uncertainty and Unemployment
abstract: This paper studies the impact of time‐varying idiosyncratic risk at the establishment level on unemployment fluctuations over 1972–2009. I build a tractable directed search model with firm dynamics and time‐varying idiosyncratic volatility. The model allows for endogenous separations, entry and exit, and job‐to‐job transitions. I show that the model can replicate salient features of the microeconomic behavior of firms and that the introduction of volatility improves the fit of the model for standard business cycle moments. In a series of counterfactual experiments, I show that time‐varying risk is important to account for the magnitude of fluctuations in aggregate unemployment for past U.S. recessions. Though the model can account for about 40% of the total increase in unemployment for the 2007–2009 recession, uncertainty alone is not sufficient to explain the magnitude and persistence of unemployment during that episode.

author: Edouard Schaal
title: Optimal Transport Networks in Spatial Equilibrium
abstract: <jats:p>We study optimal transport networks in spatial equilibrium. We develop a framework consisting of a neoclassical trade model with labor mobility in which locations are arranged on a graph. Goods must be shipped through linked locations, and transport costs depend on congestion and on the infrastructure in each link, giving rise to an optimal transport problem in general equilibrium. The optimal transport network is the solution to a social planner's problem of building infrastructure in each link. We provide conditions such that this problem is globally convex, guaranteeing its numerical tractability. We also study cases with increasing returns to transport technologies in which global convexity fails. We apply the framework to assess optimal investments and inefficiencies in the road networks of European countries.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we determine the optimal transport network infrastructure in spatial equilibrium when locations are connected through a graph and transport costs depend on congestion and infrastructure capacity?
answer: The optimal transport network can be found by solving a social planner's problem of building infrastructure in each link, with conditions identified that make this problem globally convex and numerically tractable, though global convexity fails under increasing returns to transport technologies.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new framework that combines a neoclassical trade model with labor mobility and optimal transport theory, extending existing literature by incorporating congestion effects and infrastructure decisions in a general equilibrium setting on network graphs.

author: Edouard Schaal
title: Uncertainty Traps*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a theory of endogenous uncertainty and business cycles in which short-lived shocks can generate long-lasting recessions. In the model, higher uncertainty about fundamentals discourages investment. Since agents learn from the actions of others, information flows slowly in times of low activity and uncertainty remains high, further discouraging investment. The economy displays uncertainty traps: self-reinforcing episodes of high uncertainty and low activity. Although the economy recovers quickly after small shocks, large temporary shocks may have long-lasting effects on the level of activity. The economy is subject to an information externality but uncertainty traps may remain in the efficient allocation. Embedding the mechanism in a standard business cycle framework, we find that endogenous uncertainty increases the persistence of large recessions and improves the performance of the model in accounting for the Great Recession.</jats:p>
research_question: How can short-lived shocks generate long-lasting recessions through endogenous uncertainty mechanisms?
answer: Short-lived shocks can create 'uncertainty traps' - self-reinforcing episodes where higher uncertainty discourages investment, which slows information flows and keeps uncertainty high, further discouraging investment and prolonging recessions.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theory of endogenous uncertainty and business cycles that explains persistent recessions through information externalities and social learning, extending standard business cycle frameworks to better account for phenomena like the Great Recession.

author: Eduardo Azevedo
title: Market Failure in Kidney Exchange
abstract: <jats:p> We show that kidney exchange markets suffer from market failures whose remedy could increase transplants by 30 to 63 percent. First, we document that the market is fragmented and inefficient; most transplants are arranged by hospitals instead of national platforms. Second, we propose a model to show two sources of inefficiency: hospitals only partly internalize their patients’ benefits from exchange, and current platforms suboptimally reward hospitals for submitting patients and donors. Third, we calibrate a production function and show that individual hospitals operate below efficient scale. Eliminating this inefficiency requires either a mandate or a combination of new mechanisms and reimbursement reforms. (JEL D24, D47, I11) </jats:p>
research_question: What market failures exist in kidney exchange markets and how much could transplants increase if these failures were remedied?
answer: Kidney exchange markets suffer from fragmentation and inefficiency due to hospitals only partly internalizing patient benefits and platforms suboptimally rewarding participation, with remedying these failures potentially increasing transplants by 30 to 63 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies and quantifies previously unrecognized market failures in kidney exchange, showing that most transplants are inefficiently arranged by individual hospitals rather than through national platforms, and demonstrates that hospitals operate below efficient scale.

author: Eduardo Azevedo
title: Strategy-proofness in the Large

author: Eduardo Azevedo
title: Perfect Competition in Markets With Adverse Selection
abstract: This paper proposes a perfectly competitive model of a market with adverse selection. Prices are determined by zero‐profit conditions, and the set of traded contracts is determined by free entry. Crucially for applications, contract characteristics are endogenously determined, consumers may have multiple dimensions of private information, and an equilibrium always exists. Equilibrium corresponds to the limit of a differentiated products Bertrand game. We apply the model to establish theoretical results on the equilibrium effects of mandates. Mandates can increase efficiency but have unintended consequences. With adverse selection, an insurance mandate reduces the price of low‐coverage policies, which necessarily has indirect effects such as increasing adverse selection on the intensive margin and causing some consumers to purchase less coverage.

author: Eduardo Azevedo
title: A Supply and Demand Framework for Two-Sided Matching Markets

author: Edouard Schaal
title: Optimal Lockdown in a Commuting Network
abstract: <jats:p> We study optimal dynamic lockdowns against COVID-19 within a commuting network. Our framework integrates canonical spatial epidemiology and trade models and is applied to cities with varying initial viral spread: Seoul, Daegu, and the New York City metropolitan area (NYM). Spatial lockdowns achieve substantially smaller income losses than uniform lockdowns. In the NYM and Daegu—with large initial shocks—the optimal lockdown restricts inflows to central districts before gradual relaxation, while in Seoul it imposes low temporal but large spatial variation. Actual commuting reductions were too weak in central locations in Daegu and the NYM and too strong across Seoul. (JEL H51, I12, I18, R23, R41) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the optimal dynamic lockdown policies against COVID-19 within a commuting network, and how do they vary across cities with different initial viral spread conditions?
answer: Spatial lockdowns achieve substantially smaller income losses than uniform lockdowns. For cities with large initial shocks (NYC metropolitan area and Daegu), optimal lockdowns should restrict inflows to central districts before gradual relaxation, while for cities with smaller initial spread (Seoul), optimal lockdowns should impose low temporal but large spatial variation.
positioning_statement: This paper integrates canonical spatial epidemiology and trade models to study optimal lockdown policies, positioning itself at the intersection of spatial economics, epidemiology, and trade theory to analyze COVID-19 policy responses across different urban contexts.

author: Eduardo Perez-Richet
title: Interim Bayesian Persuasion: First Steps
abstract: <jats:p> This paper makes a first attempt at building a theory of interim Bayesian persuasion. I work in a minimalist model where a low or high type sender seeks validation from a receiver who is willing to validate high types exclusively. After learning her type, the sender chooses a complete conditional information structure for the receiver from a possibly restricted feasible set. I suggest a solution to this game that takes into account the signaling potential of the sender's choice. </jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a theory of interim Bayesian persuasion where the sender learns her type before choosing an information structure to influence the receiver?
answer: The paper proposes a solution to the interim Bayesian persuasion game that accounts for the signaling potential of the sender's choice of information structure, working within a minimalist model where a sender seeks validation from a receiver who only validates high types.
positioning_statement: This paper makes a first attempt at building a theory of interim Bayesian persuasion, extending the existing Bayesian persuasion literature by considering the case where the sender learns her type before choosing the information structure, thus introducing signaling considerations into the persuasion framework.

author: Eduardo Azevedo
title: A/B Testing with Fat Tails
abstract: We propose a new framework for optimal experimentation, which we term the “A/B testing problem.” Our model departs from the existing literature by allowing for fat tails. Our key insight is that the optimal strategy depends on whether most gains accrue from typical innovations or from rare, unpredictable large successes. If the tails of the unobserved distribution of innovation quality are not too fat, the standard approach of using a few high-powered “big” experiments is optimal. However, if the distribution is very fat tailed, a “lean” strategy of trying more ideas, each with possibly smaller sample sizes, is preferred. Our theoretical results, along with an empirical analysis of Microsoft Bing’s EXP platform, suggest that simple changes to business practices could increase innovation productivity.

author: Eduardo Azevedo
title: Evolutionary Origins of the Endowment Effect: Evidence from Hunter-Gatherers
abstract: <jats:p> The endowment effect, the tendency to value possessions more than non-possessions, is a well-known departure from rational choice and has been replicated in numerous settings. We investigate the universality of the endowment effect, its evolutionary significance, and its dependence on environmental factors. We experimentally test for the endowment effect in an isolated and evolutionarily relevant population of hunter-gatherers, the Hadza Bushmen of Northern Tanzania. We find that Hadza living in isolated regions do not display the endowment effect, while Hadza living in a geographic region with increased exposure to modern society and markets do display the endowment effect. (JEL C93, D12, O15) </jats:p>
research_question: Is the endowment effect universal across human populations, what is its evolutionary significance, and how does it depend on environmental factors?
answer: The endowment effect is not universal - isolated Hadza hunter-gatherers do not display the endowment effect, while Hadza with greater exposure to modern society and markets do display it, suggesting the effect may be culturally acquired rather than evolutionarily hardwired.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the assumed universality of the endowment effect by testing it in an evolutionarily relevant hunter-gatherer population, providing novel evidence on whether this well-known departure from rational choice is innate or culturally dependent.

author: Eduardo Souza-Rodrigues
title: Deforestation in the Amazon: A Unified Framework for Estimation and Policy Analysis
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Deforestation is a matter of pressing global concern, yet surprisingly little is known about the relative efficacy of various policies designed to combat it. This article sets out a framework for measuring the cost effectiveness of alternative policies—both command-and-control and incentive-based—in the Brazilian Amazon. First, I estimate the demand for deforestation on private properties, exploiting regional variation in transportation costs as a means to recover farmers’ responses to permanent policies. Here, rescaling transportation costs using local yields allows me to express changes in farmers’ valuations in dollars per hectare. I then use the estimated demand to infer farmers’ willingness to deforest under different counterfactual policies, such as payments to avoid deforestation and taxes on land use, along with the corresponding potential farmers’ lost surpluses. The results indicate that payment programmes and land use taxes on agricultural land can be highly effective in preserving the rainforest and also be substantially less expensive than command-and-control policies (approximately 8 times less costly). A carbon tax equal to the social cost of carbon could virtually eliminate all agricultural land in the Amazon, given the low agricultural returns there.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relative cost effectiveness of alternative policies (command-and-control versus incentive-based) designed to combat deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon?
answer: Incentive-based policies such as payment programmes and land use taxes are highly effective in preserving the rainforest and are substantially less expensive than command-and-control policies (approximately 8 times less costly). A carbon tax equal to the social cost of carbon could virtually eliminate all agricultural land in the Amazon.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a significant gap in the literature by noting that despite deforestation being a matter of pressing global concern, surprisingly little is known about the relative efficacy of various anti-deforestation policies, and provides a unified framework for measuring and comparing policy cost effectiveness.

author: Eduardo Perez-Richet
title: Altruism in Networks
abstract: We provide the first analysis of altruism in networks. Agents are embedded in a fixed network and care about the well‐being of their network neighbors. Depending on incomes, they may provide financial support to their poorer friends. We study the Nash equilibria of the resulting game of transfers. We show that equilibria maximize a concave potential function. We establish existence, uniqueness of equilibrium consumption, and generic uniqueness of equilibrium transfers. We characterize the geometry of the network of transfers and highlight the key role played by transfer intermediaries. We then study comparative statics. A positive income shock to an individual benefits all. For small changes in incomes, agents in a component of the network of transfers act as if they were organized in an income‐pooling community. A decrease in income inequality or expansion of the altruism network may increase consumption inequality.

author: Eduardo Souza-Rodrigues
title: Optimal Environmental Targeting in the Amazon Rainforest
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article sets out a data-driven approach for targeting environmental policies optimally in order to combat deforestation. We focus on the Amazon, the world’s most extensive rainforest, where Brazil’s federal government issued a “Priority List” of municipalities in 2008—a blacklist to be targeted with more intense environmental monitoring and enforcement. First, we estimate the causal impact of the Priority List on deforestation (along with other relevant treatment effects) using “changes-in-changes” due to Athey and Imbens (2006), finding that it reduced deforestation by 43$\%$ and cut emissions by almost 50 million tons of carbon. Second, we develop a novel framework for computing targeted optimal blacklists that draws on our treatment effect estimates, assigning municipalities to a counterfactual list that minimizes total deforestation subject to realistic resource constraints. We show that the ex post optimal list would result in carbon emissions over 10$\%$ lower than the actual list, amounting to savings of more than $ \$ $1.2 billion (34$\%$ of the total value of the Priority List), with emissions over 23$\%$ lower on average than a randomly selected list. The approach we propose is relevant both for assessing targeted counterfactual policies to reduce deforestation and for quantifying the impacts of policy targeting more generally.</jats:p>
research_question: How can environmental policies be optimally targeted to combat deforestation in the Amazon rainforest, and what was the effectiveness of Brazil's Priority List policy?
answer: The Priority List reduced deforestation by 43% and cut emissions by almost 50 million tons of carbon. However, an ex post optimal targeting approach could have achieved carbon emissions over 10% lower than the actual list, resulting in savings of more than $1.2 billion (34% of the total value of the Priority List).
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a novel data-driven framework for computing targeted optimal blacklists that can be applied both for assessing targeted counterfactual policies to reduce deforestation specifically and for quantifying the impacts of policy targeting more generally, extending beyond existing environmental policy evaluation literature.

author: Eduardo Perez-Richet
title: Test Design Under Falsification
abstract: <jats:p>We study the optimal design of tests with manipulable inputs. Tests take a unidimensional state of the world as input and output, an informative signal to guide a receiver's approve or reject decision. The receiver wishes to only approve states that comply with her baseline standard. An agent with a preference for approval can covertly falsify the state of the world at a cost. We characterize receiver‐optimal tests and show they rely on productive falsification by compliant states. They work by setting a more stringent operational standard, and granting noncompliant states a positive approval probability to deter them from falsifying to the standard. We also study how falsification‐detection technologies improve optimal tests. They allow the designer to build an implicit cost of falsification into the test, in the form of signal devaluations. Exploiting this channel requires enriching the signal space.</jats:p>
research_question: How should tests be optimally designed when agents can manipulate or falsify the inputs to those tests?
answer: Receiver-optimal tests should rely on productive falsification by compliant states, work by setting more stringent operational standards than baseline standards, and grant noncompliant states positive approval probability to deter falsification. Falsification-detection technologies can improve tests by building implicit falsification costs through signal devaluations.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel framework for analyzing test design under manipulation, extending beyond existing literature by explicitly modeling the strategic interaction between test designers and agents who can falsify inputs, and showing how optimal tests can harness rather than simply prevent falsification.

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: Attack When the World Is Not Watching? US News and the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
abstract: Politicians may strategically time unpopular measures to coincide with newsworthy events that distract the media and the public. We test this hypothesis in the context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. We find that Israeli attacks are more likely to occur when US news on the following day is dominated by important predictable events. Strategic timing applies to attacks that bear risk of civilian casualties and are not too costly to postpone. Content analysis suggests that Israel’s strategy aims at minimizing next-day coverage, which is especially charged with negative emotional content. Palestinian attacks do not appear to be timed to US news.

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: Segregation and the Quality of Government in a Cross Section of Countries
abstract: <jats:p> We provide a new compilation of data on ethnic, linguistic, and religious composition at the subnational level for a large number of countries. Using these data, we measure segregation of groups within the country. To overcome the endogeneity problem that arises because of mobility and endogenous internal borders, we construct an instrument for segregation. We find that more ethnically and linguistically segregated countries, i.e., those where groups live more spatially separately, have a lower quality of government; there is no relationship between religious segregation and governance. Trust is an important channel of influence; it is lower in more segregated countries. (JEL H11, H77, J15, O17, Z12, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the spatial segregation of ethnic, linguistic, and religious groups within countries affect the quality of government?
answer: More ethnically and linguistically segregated countries (where groups live more spatially separated) have lower quality of government, with trust serving as an important channel of influence. However, there is no relationship between religious segregation and governance quality.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a new compilation of subnational data on ethnic, linguistic, and religious composition across countries and by addressing the endogeneity problem in measuring segregation's effects on governance through the construction of an instrumental variable approach to overcome issues related to mobility and endogenous internal borders.

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: Media and Political Persuasion: Evidence from Russia
abstract: <jats:p> This paper compares electoral outcomes of 1999 parliamentary elections in Russia among geographical areas with differential access to the only national TV channel independent from the government. It was available to three-quarters of Russia's population and its signal availability was idiosyncratic, conditional on observables. Independent TV decreased aggregate vote for the government party by 8.9 percentage points, increased the combined vote for major opposition parties by 6.3 percentage points, and decreased turnout by 3.8 percentage points. The probability of voting for opposition parties increased for individuals who watched independent TV even controlling for voting intentions measured one month before elections. (JEL D72, L82, P26) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of access to independent media on electoral outcomes and voting behavior?
answer: Access to independent TV significantly affected electoral outcomes: it decreased government party vote share by 8.9 percentage points, increased opposition party vote share by 6.3 percentage points, decreased turnout by 3.8 percentage points, and increased individual probability of voting for opposition parties even after controlling for prior voting intentions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on media and political persuasion by exploiting a natural experiment with idiosyncratic variation in access to Russia's only independent national TV channel during the 1999 parliamentary elections, providing causal evidence of media influence on voting behavior.

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: 3G Internet and Confidence in Government
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>How does mobile broadband internet affect approval of government? Using Gallup World Poll surveys of 840,537 individuals from 2,232 subnational regions in 116 countries from 2008 to 2017 and the global expansion of 3G mobile networks, we show that on average, an increase in mobile broadband internet access reduces government approval. This effect is present only when the internet is not censored, and it is stronger when the traditional media are censored. 3G helps expose actual corruption in government: revelations of the Panama Papers and other corruption incidents translate into higher perceptions of corruption in regions covered by 3G networks. Voter disillusionment had electoral implications. In Europe, 3G expansion led to lower vote shares for incumbent parties and higher vote shares for the antiestablishment populist opposition. Vote shares for nonpopulist opposition parties were unaffected by 3G expansion.</jats:p>
research_question: How does mobile broadband internet affect approval of government?
answer: Mobile broadband internet access reduces government approval on average, but only when the internet is not censored, with stronger effects when traditional media are censored. 3G helps expose corruption and leads to voter disillusionment, resulting in lower vote shares for incumbent parties and higher support for antiestablishment populist opposition.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on internet access and political outcomes by using the global expansion of 3G mobile networks to examine government approval across 116 countries, focusing on the conditional effects based on internet and media censorship, and extending analysis to electoral consequences including the rise of populist opposition parties.

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: Middleman Minorities and Ethnic Violence: Anti-Jewish Pogroms in the Russian Empire
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Using detailed panel data from the Pale of Settlement area between 1800 and 1927, we document that anti-Jewish pogroms—mob violence against the Jewish minority—broke out when economic shocks coincided with political turmoil. When this happened, pogroms primarily occurred in places where Jews dominated middleman occupations, i.e., moneylending and grain trading. This evidence is inconsistent with the scapegoating hypothesis, according to which Jews were blamed for all misfortunes of the majority. Instead, the evidence is consistent with the politico-economic mechanism, in which Jewish middlemen served as providers of insurance against economic shocks to peasants and urban grain buyers in a relationship based on repeated interactions. When economic shocks occurred in times of political stability, rolling over or forgiving debts was an equilibrium outcome because both sides valued their future relationship. In contrast, during political turmoil, debtors could not commit to paying in the future, and consequently, moneylenders and grain traders had to demand immediate (re)payment. This led to ethnic violence, in which the break in the relationship between the majority and Jewish middlemen was the igniting factor.</jats:p>
research_question: What economic and political conditions led to anti-Jewish pogroms in the Russian Empire, and what was the mechanism behind this ethnic violence?
answer: Anti-Jewish pogroms occurred when economic shocks coincided with political turmoil, primarily in places where Jews dominated middleman occupations like moneylending and grain trading. The mechanism was that during political instability, debtors could not commit to future payments, forcing Jewish middlemen to demand immediate repayment, which broke down their insurance-based relationships and ignited ethnic violence.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the scapegoating hypothesis (that Jews were blamed for all misfortunes) and instead supports a politico-economic mechanism that explains ethnic violence through the breakdown of economic relationships between middleman minorities and the majority population during times of combined economic and political stress.

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: Forced Migration and Human Capital: Evidence from Post-WWII Population Transfers
abstract: <jats:p> We study the long-run effects of forced migration on investment in education. After World War II, millions of Poles were forcibly uprooted from the Kresy territories of eastern Poland and resettled (primarily) in the newly acquired Western Territories, from which the Germans were expelled. We combine historical censuses with newly collected survey data to show that, while there were no pre-WWII differences in educational attainment, Poles with a family history of forced migration are significantly more educated today than other Poles. These results are driven by a shift in preferences away from material possessions toward investment in human capital. (JEL I25, I26, J24, N34, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-run effects of forced migration on investment in education?
answer: Poles with a family history of forced migration are significantly more educated today than other Poles, driven by a shift in preferences away from material possessions toward investment in human capital.
positioning_statement: The paper uses the unique historical context of post-WWII Polish population transfers to study forced migration effects, combining historical censuses with newly collected survey data to examine long-term educational outcomes across generations.

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: Who Are China's Entrepreneurs?

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: The Economic Effects of the Abolition of Serfdom: Evidence from the Russian Empire
abstract: <jats:p> We document substantial increases in agricultural productivity, industrial output, and peasants' nutrition in Imperial Russia as a result of the abolition of serfdom in 1861. Before the emancipation, provinces where serfs constituted the majority of agricultural laborers lagged behind provinces that primarily relied on free labor. The emancipation led to a significant but partial catch up. Better incentives of peasants resulting from the cessation of ratchet effect were a likely mechanism behind a relatively fast positive effect of reform on agricultural productivity. The land reform, which instituted communal land tenure after the emancipation, diminished growth in productivity in repartition communes. (JEL J47, N13, N33, N43, N53, Q11) </jats:p>
research_question: What were the economic effects of the abolition of serfdom in the Russian Empire in 1861?
answer: The abolition of serfdom led to substantial increases in agricultural productivity, industrial output, and peasants' nutrition, with provinces that previously relied heavily on serf labor experiencing significant catch-up growth relative to free labor provinces, primarily due to improved peasant incentives from the cessation of the ratchet effect.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence documenting the economic impacts of serf emancipation in Imperial Russia by comparing outcomes between provinces with different initial labor arrangements (serf vs. free labor) and examining the mechanisms behind productivity improvements, while also analyzing how subsequent land reform policies affected long-term growth.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: National Institutions and Subnational Development in Africa *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate the role of national institutions on subnational African development in a novel framework that accounts for both local geography and cultural-genetic traits. We exploit the fact that the political boundaries on the eve of African independence partitioned more than 200 ethnic groups across adjacent countries subjecting similar cultures, residing in homogeneous geographic areas, to different formal institutions. Using both a matching type and a spatial regression discontinuity approach we show that differences in countrywide institutional structures across the national border do not explain within-ethnicity differences in economic performance, as captured by satellite images of light density. The average noneffect of national institutions on ethnic development masks considerable heterogeneity partially driven by the diminishing role of national institutions in areas further from the capital cities.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of national institutions on subnational African development, controlling for local geography and cultural-genetic traits?
answer: Differences in countrywide institutional structures across national borders do not explain within-ethnicity differences in economic performance, though this average non-effect masks heterogeneity driven by the diminishing role of national institutions in areas further from capital cities.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a novel framework that accounts for both local geography and cultural-genetic traits by exploiting the natural experiment of political boundaries partitioning over 200 ethnic groups across adjacent countries, allowing for comparison of similar cultures in homogeneous geographic areas under different formal institutions.

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title: Opportunistic Political Cycles: Test in a Young Democracy Setting

author: Ekaterina Zhuravskaya
title:
Radio and the Rise of The Nazis in Prewar Germany
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>How do the media affect public support for democratic institutions in a fragile democracy? What role do they play in a dictatorial regime? We study these questions in the context of Germany of the 1920s and 1930s. During the democratic period, when the Weimar government introduced progovernment political news, the growth of Nazi popularity slowed down in areas with access to radio. This effect was reversed during the campaign for the last competitive election as a result of the pro-Nazi radio broadcast following Hitler’s appointment as chancellor. During the consolidation of dictatorship, radio propaganda helped the Nazis enroll new party members. After the Nazis established their rule, radio propaganda incited anti-Semitic acts and denunciations of Jews to authorities by ordinary citizens. The effect of anti-Semitic propaganda varied depending on the listeners’ predispositions toward the message. Nazi radio was most effective in places where anti-Semitism was historically high and had a negative effect in places with historically low anti-Semitism.</jats:p>
research_question: How do the media affect public support for democratic institutions in a fragile democracy? What role do they play in a dictatorial regime?
answer: Radio had different effects depending on the political regime and content: during the democratic Weimar period, pro-government radio slowed Nazi popularity growth; after Hitler's appointment, pro-Nazi radio broadcasts increased Nazi support and party enrollment; under Nazi rule, anti-Semitic radio propaganda incited anti-Semitic acts, with effectiveness varying based on listeners' historical predispositions toward anti-Semitism.
positioning_statement: This paper studies media effects on democratic support and dictatorial consolidation by examining the specific historical context of Germany in the 1920s and 1930s, analyzing how radio influenced political outcomes across different regime types and propaganda content.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: A Comment on: “State Capacity, Reciprocity, and the Social Contract”by Timothy Besley
abstract: <jats:p>In this note, I discuss avenues for future research stemming from Besley's [this issue] theoretical approach on the interconnections between civicness, institutions, and state‐fiscal capacity. First, I lay down some ideas on how one could extend the framework to model fragility traps that characterize many low‐income countries and study issues related to nation‐building, conflict, and heterogeneity across space and ethnic lines in the provision of public goods. Second, I discuss the relevance of the approach for the analysis of authoritarian populism that is spreading in developed countries and emerging markets.</jats:p>
research_question: How can Besley's theoretical framework on the interconnections between civicness, institutions, and state-fiscal capacity be extended to analyze fragility traps in low-income countries and authoritarian populism in developed countries?
answer: The framework can be extended in two main directions: (1) modeling fragility traps that characterize low-income countries to study nation-building, conflict, and heterogeneity in public goods provision across space and ethnic lines, and (2) analyzing the spread of authoritarian populism in developed countries and emerging markets.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as a commentary that builds upon and extends Besley's theoretical approach by proposing new research avenues that apply the civicness-institutions-state capacity framework to contemporary issues of state fragility and authoritarian populism that were not addressed in the original work.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: The Long-Run Effects of the Scramble for Africa
abstract: <jats:p> We explore the consequences of ethnic partitioning, a neglected aspect of the Scramble for Africa, and uncover the following. First, apart from the land mass and water bodies, split and non-split groups are similar across several dimensions. Second, the incidence, severity, and duration of political violence are all higher for partitioned homelands which also experience frequent military interventions from neighboring countries. Third, split groups are often entangled in a vicious circle of government-led discrimination and ethnic wars. Fourth, respondents from survey data identifying with split ethnicities are economically disadvantaged. The evidence highlights the detrimental repercussions of the colonial border design. (JEL D72, D74, F51, J15, O15, O17, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-run consequences of ethnic partitioning that resulted from the colonial border design during the Scramble for Africa?
answer: Ethnic partitioning has significant detrimental effects: partitioned ethnic groups experience higher incidence, severity, and duration of political violence; more frequent military interventions from neighboring countries; a vicious circle of government discrimination and ethnic wars; and economic disadvantage for individuals identifying with split ethnicities.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a neglected aspect of the Scramble for Africa literature by focusing specifically on the consequences of ethnic partitioning, filling a gap in understanding how colonial border design affected ethnic groups that were split across multiple countries.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: Regional Transfer Multipliers
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A series of discontinuities in the allocation mechanism of federal transfers to municipal governments in Brazil allow us to identify the causal effect of public spending on local labour markets, using a “fuzzy” Regression Discontinuity Design (RDD). Our estimates imply a cost per job of about 8,000 US dollars per year and a local income multiplier around two. The effect comes mostly from employment in services and is more pronounced among less financially developed municipalities.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal effect of public spending on local labour markets?
answer: Public spending has a significant positive effect on local labour markets, with a cost per job of about $8,000 US dollars per year and a local income multiplier around two, with effects primarily in services employment and stronger impacts in less financially developed municipalities.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using discontinuities in Brazil's federal transfer allocation mechanism to identify causal effects through a fuzzy Regression Discontinuity Design, providing clean identification of public spending multipliers in a developing country context.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: Ethnic Inequality

author: Elliot Lipnowski
title: Cheap Talk With Transparent Motives
abstract:
<jats:p>We study a model of cheap talk with one substantive assumption: The sender's preferences are state independent. Our main observation is that such a sender gains credibility by degrading self‐serving information. Using this observation, we examine the sender's benefits from communication, assess the value of commitment, and explicitly solve for sender‐optimal equilibria in three examples. A key result is a geometric characterization of the value of cheap talk, described by the 
            <jats:italic>quasi</jats:italic>concave envelope of the sender's value function.
          </jats:p>
research_question: How does state-independent preferences affect a sender's credibility and communication benefits in cheap talk games?
answer: A sender with state-independent preferences gains credibility by degrading self-serving information, and the value of cheap talk can be characterized geometrically by the quasi-concave envelope of the sender's value function.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the cheap talk literature by focusing on a specific but substantive assumption of state-independent sender preferences, providing new insights into credibility mechanisms and explicit solutions for sender-optimal equilibria.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: Landmines and Spatial Development
abstract: <jats:p>Landmines affect the lives of millions in many conflict‐ridden communities long after the end of hostilities. However, there is little research on the role of demining. We examine the economic consequences of landmine removal in Mozambique, the only country to transition from heavily contaminated in 1992 to mine‐free in 2015. First, we present the self‐assembled georeferenced catalog of areas suspected of contamination, along with a detailed record of demining operations. Second, the event‐study analysis reveals a robust association between demining activities and subsequent local economic performance, reflected in luminosity. Economic activity does not pick up in the years leading up to clearance, nor does it increase when operators investigate areas mistakenly marked as contaminated in prior surveys. Third, recognizing that landmine removal reshapes transportation access, we use a market‐access approach to explore direct and indirect effects. To advance on identification, we isolate changes in market access caused by removing landmines in previously considered safe areas, far from earlier nationwide surveys. Fourth, policy simulations reveal the substantial economywide dividends of clearance, but only when factoring in market‐access effects, which dwarf direct productivity links. Additionally, policy counterfactuals uncover significant aggregate costs when demining does not prioritize the unblocking of transportation routes. These results offer insights into the design of demining programs in Ukraine and elsewhere, highlighting the need for centralized coordination and prioritization of areas facilitating commerce.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the economic consequences of landmine removal, particularly examining both direct and indirect effects through transportation access and market connectivity?
answer: Demining activities have substantial positive effects on local economic performance, with market-access effects (indirect effects through improved transportation connectivity) being significantly larger than direct productivity effects. The economic benefits are maximized when demining prioritizes areas that facilitate commerce and transportation routes.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the literature on the role of demining by providing the first comprehensive analysis of landmine removal's economic effects using Mozambique as a unique case study - the only country to transition from heavily contaminated to mine-free status. While existing research focuses on the impacts of landmines themselves, there is little research on the economic consequences of their removal.

author: Elliot Lipnowski
title: Attention Management
abstract: <jats:p> Attention costs can cause some information to be ignored and decisions to be imperfect. Can we improve the material welfare of a rationally inattentive agent by restricting his information in the first place? In our model, a well-intentioned principal provides information to an agent for whom information is costly to process, but the principal does not internalize this cost. We show that full information is universally optimal if and only if the environment comprises one issue. With multiple issues, attention management becomes optimal: the principal restricts some information to induce the agent to pay attention to other aspects. (JEL D82, D83, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: Can we improve the material welfare of a rationally inattentive agent by restricting his information in the first place?
answer: Full information is universally optimal if and only if the environment comprises one issue. With multiple issues, attention management becomes optimal: the principal should restrict some information to induce the agent to pay attention to other aspects.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the problem of information provision when a well-intentioned principal provides information to an agent for whom information is costly to process, but the principal does not internalize this cost, contributing to the rational inattention literature by examining optimal information design under attention costs.

author: Elias Papaioannou
title: Intergenerational Mobility in Africa
abstract: <jats:p>We examine intergenerational mobility (IM) in educational attainment in Africa since independence using census data. First, we map IM across 27 countries and more than 2800 regions, documenting wide cross‐country and especially within‐country heterogeneity. Inertia looms large as differences in the literacy of the old generation explain about half of the observed spatial disparities in IM. The rural‐urban divide is substantial. Though conspicuous in some countries, there is no evidence of systematic gender gaps in IM. Second, we characterize the geography of IM, finding that colonial investments in railroads and Christian missions, as well as proximity to capitals and the coastline are the strongest correlates. Third, we ask whether the regional differences in mobility reflect spatial sorting or their independent role. To isolate the two, we focus on children whose families moved when they were young. Comparing siblings, looking at moves triggered by displacement shocks, and using historical migrations to predict moving‐families' destinations, we establish that, while selection is considerable, regional exposure effects are at play. An extra year spent in a high‐mobility region before the age of 12 (and after 5) significantly raises the likelihood for children of uneducated parents to complete primary school. Overall, the evidence suggests that geographic and historical factors laid the seeds for spatial disparities in IM that are cemented by sorting and the independent impact of regions.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the patterns and determinants of intergenerational mobility in educational attainment across African countries and regions since independence, and do regional differences reflect spatial sorting or independent regional effects?
answer: Intergenerational mobility in Africa shows wide cross-country and within-country heterogeneity, with about half of spatial disparities explained by differences in older generation literacy. Colonial investments (railroads, Christian missions) and proximity to capitals/coastline are strongest correlates. While spatial sorting is considerable, regional exposure effects are significant - an extra year in a high-mobility region before age 12 significantly increases the likelihood that children of uneducated parents complete primary school.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first comprehensive mapping of intergenerational mobility across 27 African countries and 2800+ regions using census data, filling a gap in understanding spatial patterns of educational mobility in Africa and establishing causal evidence for regional exposure effects through innovative identification strategies including sibling comparisons and displacement shocks.

author: Elliot Lipnowski
title: Buying from a Group
abstract: <jats:p> A buyer procures a good owned by a group of sellers whose heterogeneous cost of trade is private information. The buyer must either buy the whole good or nothing, and sellers share the transfer in proportion to their share of the good. We characterize the optimal mechanism: trade occurs if and only if the buyer’s benefit of trade exceeds a weighted average of sellers’ virtual costs. These weights are endogenous, with sellers who are ex ante less inclined to trade receiving higher weight. This mechanism always outperforms posted-price mechanisms. An extension characterizes the entire Pareto frontier. (JEL D44, D63, D82, Q15, Q24) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal mechanism for a buyer to procure a good from a group of sellers with private heterogeneous costs, where the buyer must purchase the entire good and sellers share the transfer proportionally?
answer: The optimal mechanism involves trade occurring if and only if the buyer's benefit exceeds a weighted average of sellers' virtual costs, where sellers who are ex ante less inclined to trade receive higher endogenous weights, and this mechanism always outperforms posted-price mechanisms.
positioning_statement: This paper extends mechanism design theory to the novel setting of group ownership with proportional sharing, characterizing both the optimal mechanism and the entire Pareto frontier for buyer-seller transactions involving multiple heterogeneous sellers.

author: Elliot Lipnowski
title: Peer‐Confirming Equilibrium
abstract: <jats:p>We can often predict the behavior of those closest to us more accurately than that of complete strangers, yet we routinely engage in strategic situations with both: our social network impacts our strategic knowledge. Peer‐confirming equilibrium describes the behavioral consequences of this intuition in a noncooperative game. We augment a game with a network to represent strategic information: if two players are linked in the network, they have correct conjectures about each others' strategies. In peer‐confirming equilibrium, there is common belief that players (i) behave rationally and (ii) correctly anticipate neighbors' play. In simultaneous‐move games, adding links to the network always restricts the set of outcomes. In dynamic games, the outcome set may vary non‐monotonically with the network because the actions of well‐connected players help poorly‐connected players coordinate. This solution concept provides a useful language for studying public good provision, highlights a new channel through which central individuals facilitate coordination, and delineates possible sources of miscoordination in protests and coups.</jats:p>
research_question: How does social network structure affect strategic behavior and equilibrium outcomes in noncooperative games when players have better information about the strategies of those they are connected to?
answer: The paper introduces 'peer-confirming equilibrium' which shows that in simultaneous-move games, adding network links always restricts the set of possible outcomes, while in dynamic games, network effects can vary non-monotonically because well-connected players help poorly-connected players coordinate.
positioning_statement: This paper augments traditional noncooperative game theory by incorporating network structure to represent strategic information, building on the intuition that people can predict the behavior of those closest to them more accurately than strangers, and provides a new solution concept that bridges game theory and network effects in strategic situations.

author: Elliot Lipnowski
title: Rank Uncertainty in Organizations
abstract: <jats:p> A principal incentivizes a team of agents to work by privately offering them bonuses contingent on team success. We study the principal’s optimal incentive scheme that implements work as a unique equilibrium. This scheme leverages rank uncertainty to address strategic uncertainty. Each agent is informed only of a ranking distribution and his own bonus, the latter making work dominant provided that higher-rank agents work. If agents are symmetric, their bonuses are identical. Thus, discrimination is strictly suboptimal, in sharp contrast with the case of public contracts (Winter 2004). We characterize how agents’ ranking and compensation vary with asymmetric effort costs. (JEL D23, D62, D81, D82, D86) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the principal's optimal incentive scheme for motivating a team of agents to work when contracts are private and there is strategic uncertainty?
answer: The optimal incentive scheme leverages rank uncertainty by informing each agent only of a ranking distribution and their own bonus, making work dominant if higher-rank agents work. For symmetric agents, identical bonuses are optimal, making discrimination strictly suboptimal.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with existing literature on public contracts (specifically Winter 2004) by showing that discrimination is strictly suboptimal under private contracts, whereas it may be optimal under public contracts.

author: Elliot Lipnowski
title: Persuasion via Weak Institutions
abstract: A sender commissions a study to persuade a receiver but influences the report with some probability. We show that increasing this probability can benefit the receiver and can lead to a discontinuous drop in the sender’s payoffs. To derive our results, we geometrically characterize the sender’s highest equilibrium payoff, which is based on the concavification of a capped value function.

author: Emanuel Vespa
title: Contingent Thinking and the Sure-Thing Principle: Revisiting Classic Anomalies in the Laboratory
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We present an experimental framework to study the extent to which failures of contingent thinking explain classic anomalies in a broad class of environments, including overbidding in auctions and the Ellsberg paradox. We study environments in which the subject’s choices affect payoffs only in some states but not in others. We find that anomalies are in large part driven by incongruences between choices in the standard presentation of each problem and a “contingent” presentation, which focuses the subject on the set of states where her actions matter. Additional evidence suggests that this phenomenon is in large part driven by people’s failure to put themselves in states that have not yet happened even though they are made aware that their actions only matter in those states.</jats:p>
research_question: To what extent do failures of contingent thinking explain classic anomalies in decision-making environments where subjects' choices affect payoffs only in some states but not others?
answer: Classic anomalies (including overbidding in auctions and the Ellsberg paradox) are largely driven by incongruences between choices in standard presentations versus 'contingent' presentations that focus subjects on states where their actions matter, with this phenomenon primarily caused by people's failure to mentally place themselves in states that have not yet occurred.
positioning_statement: This paper revisits classic anomalies in behavioral economics by proposing a novel experimental framework that tests whether these anomalies stem from failures in contingent thinking rather than fundamental violations of rational choice theory, offering a unified explanation for seemingly disparate behavioral phenomena.

author: Emanuel Vespa
title: Mental Models and Learning: The Case of Base-Rate Neglect
abstract: <jats:p> We experimentally document persistence of suboptimal behavior despite ample opportunities to learn from feedback in a canonical updating problem where people suffer from base-rate neglect. Our results provide insights on the mechanisms hindering learning from feedback. Importantly, our results suggest mistakes are more likely to be persistent when they are driven by incorrect mental models that miss or misrepresent important aspects of the environment. Such models induce confidence in initial answers, limiting engagement with and learning from feedback. We substantiate these insights in an alternative scenario where individuals involved in a voting problem overlook the importance of being pivotal. (JEL D83, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: Why does suboptimal behavior persist despite ample opportunities to learn from feedback in updating problems where people suffer from base-rate neglect?
answer: Mistakes are more likely to be persistent when they are driven by incorrect mental models that miss or misrepresent important aspects of the environment, as such models induce confidence in initial answers and limit engagement with and learning from feedback.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on learning from feedback by identifying the specific mechanisms that hinder learning, particularly focusing on how incorrect mental models create barriers to learning in canonical updating problems and voting scenarios.

author: Emily Breza
title: Measuring the Equilibrium Impacts of Credit: Evidence from the Indian Microfinance Crisis
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In October 2010, the state government of Andhra Pradesh, India, issued an emergency ordinance, bringing microfinance activities in the state to a complete halt and causing a nationwide shock to the liquidity of lenders, especially those with loans in the affected state. We use this massive dislocation in the microfinance market to identify the causal impacts of a reduction in credit supply on consumption, earnings, and employment in general equilibrium in rural labor markets. Using a proprietary district-level data set from 25 separate, for-profit microlenders matched with household data from the National Sample Survey, we find that district-level reductions in credit supply are associated with significant decreases in casual daily wages, household wage earnings, and consumption. We find a substantial consumption multiplier from credit that is likely driven by two channels—aggregate demand and business investment. We calibrate a simple two-period, two-sector model of the rural economy that incorporates both channels and show that the magnitude of our wage results is consistent with the model’s predictions.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the causal impacts of a reduction in credit supply on consumption, earnings, and employment in general equilibrium in rural labor markets?
answer: District-level reductions in credit supply cause significant decreases in casual daily wages, household wage earnings, and consumption, with a substantial consumption multiplier from credit driven by aggregate demand and business investment channels.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a unique natural experiment (the 2010 Andhra Pradesh microfinance crisis) to identify causal general equilibrium effects of credit supply changes, combining proprietary lender data with household survey data and validating findings through a calibrated two-sector model of the rural economy.

author: Emily Breza
title: Labor Rationing
abstract: <jats:p> This paper measures excess labor supply in equilibrium. We induce hiring shocks—which employ 24 percent of the labor force in external month-long jobs—in Indian local labor markets. In peak months, wages increase instantaneously and local aggregate employment declines. In lean months, consistent with severe labor rationing, wages and aggregate employment are unchanged, with positive employment spillovers on remaining workers, indicating that over a quarter of labor supply is rationed. At least 24 percent of lean self-employment among casual workers occurs because they cannot find jobs. Consequently, traditional survey approaches mismeasure labor market slack. Rationing has broad implications for labor market analysis. (JEL E24, J22, J23, J31, J64, O15, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: How much excess labor supply exists in equilibrium in local labor markets, and how does labor rationing affect employment and wages?
answer: Over a quarter of labor supply is rationed in lean months, with at least 24 percent of lean self-employment among casual workers occurring because they cannot find jobs, while traditional survey approaches mismeasure this labor market slack.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges traditional survey approaches to measuring labor market slack by providing experimental evidence of labor rationing, demonstrating that conventional methods mismeasure excess labor supply and revealing broad implications for labor market analysis.

author: Emily Breza
title: Social Networks, Reputation, and Commitment: Evidence From a Savings Monitors Experiment
abstract: We conduct an experiment to study whether individuals save more when information about the progress toward their self‐set savings goal is shared with another village member (a “monitor”). We develop a reputational framework to explore how a monitor's effectiveness depends on her network position. Savers who care about whether others perceive them as responsible should save more with central monitors, who more widely disseminate information, and proximate monitors, who pass information to individuals with whom the saver interacts frequently. We randomly assign monitors to savers and find that monitors on average increase savings by 36%. Consistent with the framework, more central and proximate monitors lead to larger increases in savings. Moreover, information flows through the network, with 63% of monitors telling others about the saver's progress. Fifteen months after the conclusion of the experiment, other villagers have updated their beliefs about the saver's responsibility in response to the intervention.

author: Emanuel Vespa
title: Failures in Contingent Reasoning: The Role of Uncertainty
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a new channel to account for the difficulties of individuals with contingent reasoning: the presence of uncertainty. When moving from an environment with one state of known value to one with multiple possible values, two changes occur. First, the number of values to consider increases. Second, the value of the state is uncertain. We show in an experiment that this lack of certainty, or the loss of the Power of Certainty, impedes payoff maximization and that it accounts for a substantial portion of the difficulties with contingent reasoning. (JEL D12, D81, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: What accounts for the difficulties individuals face with contingent reasoning, specifically examining the role of uncertainty?
answer: The lack of certainty, termed the 'loss of the Power of Certainty,' significantly impedes payoff maximization and accounts for a substantial portion of the difficulties people experience with contingent reasoning when moving from single-state known value environments to multi-state uncertain value environments.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new channel to explain contingent reasoning difficulties by isolating uncertainty as a key factor, distinguishing between the complexity of multiple values and the uncertainty of state values, thereby offering a novel explanation for existing behavioral phenomena in decision-making under uncertainty.

author: Emily Breza
title: The Morale Effects of Pay Inequality*

author: Emily Breza
title: When Less Is More: Experimental Evidence on Information Delivery During India’s Demonetisation
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>In disseminating information, policymakers face a choice between broadcasting to everyone and informing a small number of “seeds” who then spread the message. While broadcasting maximises the initial reach of messages, we offer theoretical and experimental evidence that it need not be the best strategy. In a field experiment during the 2016 Indian demonetisation, we delivered policy information, varying three dimensions of the delivery method at the village level: initial reach (broadcasting versus seeding); whether or not we induced common knowledge of who was initially informed; and number of facts delivered. We measured three outcomes: the volume of conversations about demonetisation, knowledge of demonetisation rules, and choice quality in a strongly incentivised policy-dependent decision. On all three outcomes, under common knowledge, seeding dominates broadcasting; moreover, adding common knowledge makes seeding more effective but broadcasting less so. We interpret our results via a model of image concerns deterring engagement in social learning, and we support this interpretation with evidence on differential behaviour across ability categories.</jats:p>
research_question: When disseminating policy information, is it more effective for policymakers to broadcast information to everyone or to inform a small number of 'seeds' who then spread the message?
answer: Seeding (informing a small number of people who then spread information) is more effective than broadcasting when there is common knowledge of who was initially informed, leading to better outcomes in conversation volume, knowledge of policy rules, and decision-making quality.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on information dissemination by providing both theoretical and experimental evidence that challenges the assumption that maximizing initial reach through broadcasting is optimal, instead showing that targeted seeding can be superior under certain conditions involving common knowledge and social learning dynamics.

author: Emily Breza
title: Using Aggregated Relational Data to Feasibly Identify Network Structure without Network Data
abstract: <jats:p> Social network data are often prohibitively expensive to collect, limiting empirical network research. We propose an inexpensive and feasible strategy for network elicitation using Aggregated Relational Data (ARD): responses to questions of the form “how many of your links have trait k ?” Our method uses ARD to recover parameters of a network formation model, which permits sampling from a distribution over node- or graph-level statistics. We replicate the results of two field experiments that used network data and draw similar conclusions with ARD alone. (JEL C81, C93, D85, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How can researchers feasibly identify network structure and recover network formation model parameters without collecting expensive social network data?
answer: Aggregated Relational Data (ARD) - responses to questions like 'how many of your links have trait k?' - can successfully recover parameters of network formation models and permit sampling from distributions over network statistics, as demonstrated by replicating results from two field experiments using ARD alone.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a key limitation in empirical network research by proposing an inexpensive alternative to costly social network data collection, positioning itself as a methodological contribution that makes network analysis more accessible and feasible for researchers.

author: Emily Breza
title: Naïve Learning with Uninformed Agents
abstract: <jats:p> The DeGroot model has emerged as a credible alternative to the standard Bayesian model for studying learning on networks, offering a natural way to model naïve learning in a complex setting. One unattractive aspect of this model is the assumption that the process starts with every node in the network having a signal. We study a natural extension of the DeGroot model that can deal with sparse initial signals. We show that an agent’s social influence in this generalized DeGroot model is essentially proportional to the degree-weighted share of uninformed nodes who will hear about an event for the first time via this agent. This characterization result then allows us to relate network geometry to information aggregation. We show information aggregation preserves “wisdom” in the sense that initial signals are weighed approximately equally in a model of network formation that captures the sparsity, clustering, and small-world properties of real-world networks. We also identify an example of a network structure where essentially only the signal of a single agent is aggregated, which helps us pinpoint a condition on the network structure necessary for almost full aggregation. Simulating the modeled learning process on a set of real-world networks, we find that there is on average 22.4 percent information loss in these networks. We also explore how correlation in the location of seeds can exacerbate aggregation failure. Simulations with real-world network data show that with clustered seeding, information loss climbs to 34.4 percent. (JEL D83, D85, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does social learning work in networks when only some agents initially have information signals, and what determines information aggregation quality in such sparse signal environments?
answer: An agent's social influence is proportional to the degree-weighted share of uninformed nodes who first hear about an event through that agent. Information aggregation can preserve 'wisdom' under certain network conditions, but real-world networks show 22.4% information loss on average, rising to 34.4% with clustered initial signals.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the DeGroot model of naïve learning by addressing a key limitation - the unrealistic assumption that all network nodes initially have signals - offering a more realistic alternative to standard Bayesian learning models for complex network settings.

author: Emily Breza
title: Changes in Social Network Structure in Response to Exposure to Formal Credit Markets
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that the entry of formal financial institutions can have far-reaching and long-lasting impacts on informal lending and social networks more generally. We first study the introduction of microfinance in 75 villages in Karnataka, India, 43 of which were exposed to microfinance. Using difference-in-differences, we show that networks shrank more in exposed villages. Moreover, links between households that were both unlikely to borrow from microfinance were at least as likely to disappear as links involving likely borrowers. We replicate these surprising findings in the context of a randomised controlled trial (RCT) in Hyderabad, where a microfinance institution randomly selected 52 of 104 neighbourhoods to enter first. Four years after all neighbourhoods were treated, households in early-entry neighbourhoods had credit access longer and had larger loans. We again find fewer social relationships between households in these neighbourhoods, even among those ex-ante unlikely to borrow. Because the results suggest global spillovers, atypical in usual models of network formation, we develop a new dynamic model of network formation that emphasizes chance meetings, where efforts to socialize generate a global network-level externality. Finally, we analyse informal borrowing and the sensitivity of consumption to income fluctuations. Households unlikely to take up microcredit suffer the greatest loss of informal borrowing and risk sharing, underscoring the global nature of the externality.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the introduction of formal financial institutions (microfinance) affect informal lending networks and social network structure?
answer: The entry of formal financial institutions causes social networks to shrink, with effects extending even to households unlikely to borrow from microfinance. This creates global spillovers where households unlikely to take up microcredit suffer the greatest loss of informal borrowing and risk sharing.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by documenting surprising global spillover effects of formal credit market entry on social networks that are atypical in usual models of network formation, leading the authors to develop a new dynamic model of network formation that emphasizes chance meetings and global network-level externalities.

author: Emily Oster
title: Hepatitis B and the Case of the Missing Women

author: Emily Oster
title: Optimal Expectations and Limited Medical Testing: Evidence from Huntington Disease
abstract: <jats:p> We use novel data to study genetic testing among individuals at risk for Huntington disease (HD), a hereditary disease with limited life expectancy. Although genetic testing is perfectly predictive and carries little economic cost, presymptomatic testing is rare. Testing rates increase with increases in ex ante risk of having HD. Untested individuals express optimistic beliefs about their health and make decisions (e.g., retirement) as if they do not have HD, even though individuals with confirmed HD behave differently. We suggest that these facts can be reconciled by an optimal expectations model (Brunnermeier and Parker 2005). (JEL D84, I12) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do individuals at risk for Huntington disease rarely undergo genetic testing despite the test being perfectly predictive and carrying little economic cost?
answer: Presymptomatic testing is rare because untested individuals maintain optimistic beliefs about their health and make decisions as if they do not have HD, which can be explained by an optimal expectations model where people choose beliefs that maximize their utility.
positioning_statement: This paper applies the optimal expectations framework of Brunnermeier and Parker (2005) to explain medical testing behavior, using novel data on Huntington disease to provide empirical evidence for how individuals strategically maintain optimistic beliefs when facing potentially devastating health information.

author: Emily Oster
title: Sexually Transmitted Infections, Sexual Behavior, and The HIV/AIDS Epidemic*

author: Emily Oster
title: The Power of TV: Cable Television and Women's Status in India<sup>*</sup>

author: Emily Oster
title: Limited Life Expectancy, Human Capital and Health Investments
abstract: <jats:p> Human capital theory predicts that life expectancy will impact human capital attainment. We estimate this relationship using variation in life expectancy driven by Huntington disease, an inherited neurological disorder. We compare investments for individuals who have ex-ante identical risks of HD but differ in disease realization. Individuals with the HD mutation complete less education and job training. The elasticity of demand for college attendance with respect to life expectancy is around 1.0. We relate this to cross-country and over-time differences in education. We use smoking and cancer screening data to test the corollary that health capital responds to life expectancy. (JEL I11, I12, I20, I31, J24) </jats:p>
research_question: How does life expectancy impact human capital attainment and health investments?
answer: Individuals with shorter life expectancy (due to Huntington disease mutation) complete less education and job training, with an elasticity of demand for college attendance with respect to life expectancy of around 1.0, and health capital also responds to life expectancy differences.
positioning_statement: This paper tests human capital theory's prediction about life expectancy's impact on human capital attainment using a novel identification strategy based on Huntington disease variation, and extends the analysis to health capital investments including smoking and cancer screening behaviors.

author: Emily Oster
title: Optimal Expectations and Limited Medical Testing: Evidence from Huntington Disease: Corrigendum

author: Emily Oster
title: Pandemic Schooling Mode and Student Test Scores: Evidence from US School Districts
abstract: <jats:p> We estimate the impact of district-level schooling mode (in-person versus hybrid or virtual learning) in the 2020–2021 school year on students’ pass rates on standardized tests in grades 3–8 across 11 states. Pass rates declined from 2019 to 2021: an average of 12.8 percentage points in math and 6.8 in English language arts (ELA). Focusing on within-state, within–commuting zone variation in schooling mode, we estimate that districts with full in-person learning had significantly smaller declines (13.4 pp in math, 8.3 in ELA). The value to in-person learning was larger for districts with larger populations of Black students. (JEL H75, I12, I18, I21, I28, J15) </jats:p>
research_question: What was the impact of different schooling modes (in-person versus hybrid or virtual learning) during the 2020-2021 school year on student standardized test performance?
answer: Districts with full in-person learning experienced significantly smaller declines in test pass rates compared to districts using hybrid or virtual learning, with the benefit being 13.4 percentage points smaller decline in math and 8.3 percentage points smaller decline in English language arts. The benefits of in-person learning were particularly pronounced for districts serving larger populations of Black students.
