positioning_statement: This paper contributes empirical evidence to the literature on pandemic-era educational impacts by providing the first large-scale analysis of how different schooling modalities affected student test performance across multiple states, using within-state and within-commuting zone variation to identify causal effects of schooling mode on academic outcomes.

author: Emily Oster
title: Health Recommendations and Selection in Health Behaviors
abstract: <jats:p>Consider a case in which a new research finding links a health behavior with good health outcomes. A possible consequence is take-up of this behavior among individuals who engage in other positive health behaviors. If this occurs, later analyses of observational data may be biased by the change in selection. This paper evaluates these dynamic biases in empirical settings. Using data from vitamin supplementation and diet, I show that selection responds endogenously to health recommendations. These results highlight how spurious findings on health behaviors can be self-reinforcing. (JEL I12)</jats:p>
research_question: How does the publication of new health research findings affect selection patterns in health behaviors, and what are the implications for subsequent empirical analyses of observational data?
answer: Selection in health behaviors responds endogenously to health recommendations, with individuals who already engage in positive health behaviors being more likely to adopt newly recommended behaviors, creating dynamic biases in later observational studies that can make spurious health findings appear self-reinforcing.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a previously underexplored source of bias in health behavior research by demonstrating how the publication of health recommendations itself changes the composition of who engages in certain behaviors, thereby affecting the validity of subsequent observational studies that rely on this changed selection pattern.

author: Emily Oster
title: Sexually Transmitted Infections, Sexual Behavior, and the HIV/AIDS Epidemic

author: Eran Shmaya
title: Regret‐Minimizing Project Choice
abstract: <jats:p>An agent observes the set of available projects and proposes some, but not necessarily all, of them. A principal chooses one or none from the proposed set. We solve for a mechanism that minimizes the principal's worst‐case regret. We compare the single‐project environment in which the agent can propose only one project with the multiproject environment in which he can propose many. In both environments, if the agent proposes one project, it is chosen for sure if the principal's payoff is sufficiently high; otherwise, the probability that it is chosen decreases in the agent's payoff. In the multiproject environment, the agent's payoff from proposing multiple projects equals his maximal payoff from proposing each project alone. The multiproject environment outperforms the single‐project one by providing better fallback options than rejection and by delivering this payoff to the agent more efficiently.</jats:p>
research_question: What mechanism minimizes a principal's worst-case regret when an agent selectively proposes projects from an available set for the principal to choose from?
answer: The optimal regret-minimizing mechanism involves probabilistic project selection where projects with sufficiently high principal payoffs are chosen with certainty, while projects with lower principal payoffs have decreasing selection probability based on the agent's payoff. The multiproject environment outperforms single-project environments by providing better fallback options and more efficient payoff delivery.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to mechanism design literature by introducing a regret-minimization framework for project selection problems, comparing single-project versus multiproject environments and demonstrating the efficiency gains from allowing agents to propose multiple projects rather than restricting them to single proposals.

author: Eran Shmaya
title: Experiments on Decisions under Uncertainty: A Theoretical Framework
abstract: <jats:p> The analysis of lab data entails a joint test of the underlying theory and of subjects' conjectures regarding the experimental design itself, how subjects frame the experiment. We provide a theoretical framework for analyzing such conjectures. We use experiments of decision making under uncertainty as a case study. Absent restrictions on subjects' framing of the experiment, we show that any behavior is consistent with standard updating (“anything goes”), including those suggestive of anomalies such as overconfidence, excess belief stickiness, etc. When the experimental protocol restricts subjects' conjectures (plausibly, by generating information during the experiment), standard updating has nontrivial testable implications. (JEL C91, D11, D81, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How do subjects' conjectures about experimental design affect the interpretation of laboratory data on decision making under uncertainty, and what are the testable implications of standard updating theory?
answer: Without restrictions on subjects' framing of experiments, any behavior is consistent with standard updating theory (including apparent anomalies like overconfidence), but when experimental protocols restrict subjects' conjectures by generating information during the experiment, standard updating has nontrivial testable implications.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a theoretical framework for analyzing how subjects' conjectures about experimental design affect the interpretation of lab data, addressing a fundamental methodological issue in experimental economics that recognizes laboratory data involves a joint test of underlying theory and subjects' understanding of the experimental context.

author: Eran Shmaya
title: The Interval Structure of Optimal Disclosure
abstract: <jats:p>A sender persuades a receiver to accept a project by disclosing information about a payoff‐relevant quality. The receiver has private information about the quality, referred to as his type. We show that the sender‐optimal mechanism takes the form of nested intervals: each type accepts on an interval of qualities and a more optimistic type's interval contains a less optimistic type's interval. This nested‐interval structure offers a simple algorithm to solve for the optimal disclosure and connects our problem to the monopoly screening problem. The mechanism is optimal even if the sender conditions the disclosure mechanism on the receiver's reported type.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal structure of information disclosure mechanisms when a sender tries to persuade a receiver with private information to accept a project?
answer: The sender-optimal mechanism takes the form of nested intervals, where each receiver type accepts on an interval of qualities and more optimistic types have intervals that contain less optimistic types' intervals.
positioning_statement: This paper connects the optimal disclosure problem to the monopoly screening problem through the nested-interval structure, providing a simple algorithmic solution that remains optimal even when conditioning on the receiver's reported type.

author: Eran Shmaya
title: Robust Monopoly Regulation
abstract: <jats:p> We study how to regulate a monopolistic firm using a robust-design, non-Bayesian approach. We derive a policy that minimizes the regulator’s worst-case regret, where regret is the difference between the regulator’s complete-information payoff and his realized payoff. When the regulator’s payoff is consumers’ surplus, he caps the firm’s average revenue. When his payoff is the total surplus of both consumers and the firm, he offers a piece rate subsidy to the firm while capping the total subsidy. For intermediate cases, the regulator combines these three policy instruments to balance three goals: protecting consumers’ surplus, mitigating underproduction, and limiting potential overproduction. (JEL D21, D42, D83, H25, L51) </jats:p>
research_question: How should a regulator design policy to regulate a monopolistic firm when using a robust-design, non-Bayesian approach that minimizes worst-case regret?
answer: The optimal regulatory policy depends on the regulator's objective: when maximizing consumers' surplus, cap the firm's average revenue; when maximizing total surplus, offer a piece rate subsidy with a total subsidy cap; for intermediate cases, combine revenue caps, piece rate subsidies, and subsidy caps to balance consumer protection, mitigating underproduction, and limiting overproduction.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to monopoly regulation literature by applying a robust-design, non-Bayesian approach that minimizes worst-case regret, departing from traditional Bayesian regulatory design methods.

author: Eran Shmaya
title: Uncertainty and Disagreement in Equilibrium Models

author: Eran Shmaya
title: The Axiomatic Structure of Empirical Content
abstract: <jats:p> We define the empirical content of an economic theory as the least restrictive observationally equivalent theory. We show that the empirical content of a theory is captured by a certain kind of axiomatization, with axioms that are universal negations of conjunctions of atomic formulae. (JEL B41, D01, D11) </jats:p>
research_question: How can the empirical content of an economic theory be formally defined and characterized?
answer: The empirical content of an economic theory can be defined as the least restrictive observationally equivalent theory and is captured by axiomatizations using universal negations of conjunctions of atomic formulae.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel axiomatic approach to defining empirical content in economic theory, contributing to the methodological foundations of economics by formalizing what constitutes the testable implications of economic theories.

author: Eric Gould
title: The Mystery of Monogamy
abstract: <jats:p> We examine why developed societies are monogamous while rich men throughout history have typically practiced polygyny. Wealth inequality naturally produces multiple wives for rich men in a standard model of the marriage market. However, we demonstrate that higher female inequality in the marriage market reduces polygyny. Moreover, we show that female inequality increases in the process of development as women are valued more for the quality of their children than for the quantity. Consequently, male inequality generates inequality in the number of wives per man in traditional societies, but manifests itself as inequality in the quality of wives in developed societies. (JEL J12, J16, J24, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: Why are developed societies monogamous while rich men throughout history have typically practiced polygyny?
answer: Female inequality increases during development as women are valued more for child quality than quantity, causing male inequality to manifest as inequality in wife quality rather than number of wives, leading to monogamy in developed societies.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the puzzle that standard marriage market models predict polygyny should increase with wealth inequality, but developed societies with high inequality are actually monogamous, requiring a new theoretical framework that incorporates female inequality and changing valuations of women during development.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Overconfidence in Political Behavior
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies, theoretically and empirically, the role of overconfidence in political behavior. Our model of overconfidence in beliefs predicts that overconfidence leads to ideological extremeness, increased voter turnout, and stronger partisan identification. The model also makes nuanced predictions about the patterns of ideology in society. These predictions are tested using unique data that measure the overconfidence and standard political characteristics of a nationwide sample of over 3,000 adults. Our numerous predictions find strong support in these data. In particular, we document that overconfidence is a substantively and statistically important predictor of ideological extremeness, voter turnout, and partisan identification. (JEL C83, D03, D72, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of overconfidence in political behavior, specifically how does overconfidence in beliefs affect ideological extremeness, voter turnout, and partisan identification?
answer: Overconfidence leads to ideological extremeness, increased voter turnout, and stronger partisan identification, with overconfidence being a substantively and statistically important predictor of these political behaviors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing both theoretical and empirical analysis of overconfidence in political behavior using unique nationwide data measuring overconfidence and political characteristics of over 3,000 adults, testing nuanced predictions about ideology patterns in society.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Explaining the Favorite–Long Shot Bias: Is it Risk-Love or Misperceptions?

author: Eric Weese
title: Insurgency and Small Wars: Estimation of Unobserved Coalition Structures
abstract: <jats:p>Insurgency and guerrilla warfare impose enormous socio‐economic costs and often persist for decades. The opacity of such forms of conflict is an obstacle to effective international humanitarian intervention and development programs. To shed light on the internal organization of otherwise unknown insurgent groups, this paper proposes two methodologies for the detection of unobserved coalitions of militants in conflict areas. These approaches are based on daily geocoded incident‐level data on insurgent attacks. We provide applications to the Afghan conflict during the 2004–2009 period and to Pakistan during the 2008–2011 period, identifying systematically different coalition structures. Applications to global terrorism data and identification of new groups or shifting coalitions are discussed.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we detect and identify unobserved coalition structures among insurgent groups in conflict areas?
answer: The paper proposes two methodologies based on daily geocoded incident-level data on insurgent attacks that can successfully identify systematically different coalition structures, as demonstrated through applications to Afghan conflict (2004-2009) and Pakistan (2008-2011).
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the opacity of insurgent conflicts that creates obstacles to effective international humanitarian intervention and development programs by providing novel methodological approaches to shed light on the internal organization of otherwise unknown insurgent groups.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Are conservatives overconfident?

author: Erik Snowberg
title: A Theory of Experimenters: Robustness, Randomization, and Balance
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies the problem of experiment design by an ambiguity-averse decision-maker who trades off subjective expected performance against robust performance guarantees. This framework accounts for real-world experimenters’ preference for randomization. It also clarifies the circumstances in which randomization is optimal: when the available sample size is large and robustness is an important concern. We apply our model to shed light on the practice of rerandomization, used to improve balance across treatment and control groups. We show that rerandomization creates a trade-off between subjective performance and robust performance guarantees. However, robust performance guarantees diminish very slowly with the number of rerandomizations. This suggests that moderate levels of rerandomization usefully expand the set of acceptable compromises between subjective performance and robustness. Targeting a fixed quantile of balance is safer than targeting an absolute balance objective. (JEL C90, D81) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do real-world experimenters prefer randomization in experiment design, and under what circumstances is randomization optimal?
answer: Randomization is preferred by ambiguity-averse experimenters who trade off subjective expected performance against robust performance guarantees. Randomization is optimal when the available sample size is large and robustness is an important concern.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a theoretical framework that accounts for real-world experimenters' preference for randomization by incorporating ambiguity aversion and the trade-off between subjective performance and robustness, which existing literature has not adequately explained.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Experimenting with Measurement Error: Techniques with Applications to the Caltech Cohort Study
abstract: Measurement error is ubiquitous in experimental work. It leads to imperfect statistical controls, attenuated estimated effects of elicited behaviors, and biased correlations between characteristics. We develop statistical techniques for handling experimental measurement error. These techniques are applied to data from the Caltech Cohort Study, which conducts repeated incentivized surveys of the Caltech student body. We replicate three classic experiments, demonstrating that results change substantially when measurement error is accounted for. Collectively, these results show that failing to properly account for measurement error may cause a field-wide bias leading scholars to identify “new” phenomena.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Testing the Waters: Behavior across Participant Pools
abstract: <jats:p>We leverage a large-scale incentivized survey eliciting behaviors from (almost) an entire undergraduate university student population, a representative sample of the US population, and Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) to address concerns about the external validity of experiments with student participants. Behavior in the student population offers bounds on behaviors in other populations, and correlations between behaviors are similar across samples. Furthermore, non-student samples exhibit higher levels of noise. Adding historical lab participation data, we find a small set of attributes over which lab participants differ from non-lab participants. An additional set of lab experiments shows no evidence of observer effects. (JEL C83, D90, D91)</jats:p>
research_question: Do experimental results obtained from student participants in laboratory settings have external validity when generalized to other populations?
answer: Student behavior provides useful bounds on behavior in other populations, with similar correlations between behaviors across samples, though non-student samples exhibit higher noise levels and lab participants differ from non-lab participants on only a small set of attributes.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses longstanding concerns in experimental economics about the external validity of using student participants by providing large-scale empirical evidence comparing behaviors across different participant pools (students, representative US population, and MTurk workers) to validate or challenge existing assumptions about generalizability.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Looming Large or Seeming Small? Attitudes Towards Losses in a Representative Sample
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We measure individual-level loss aversion using three incentivized, representative surveys of the U.S. population (combined N=3,000). We find that around 50% of the U.S. population is loss tolerant—they are willing to accept negative-expected-value gambles that contain a loss. This is counter to expert predictions and earlier findings—which mostly come from laboratory/student samples—that 70–90% of participants are loss averse. Consistent with the different findings in our study versus the prior literature, loss aversion is more prevalent in people with high cognitive ability. Further, our measure of gain–loss attitudes exhibits similar temporal stability and better predictive power outside our survey than measures of risk aversion. Loss-tolerant individuals are more likely to report recent gambling, investing a higher percentage of their assets in stocks, and experiencing financial shocks. These results support the general hypothesis that individuals value gains and losses differently, and that gain–loss attitudes are an important economic preference. However, the tendency in a large proportion of the population to emphasize gains over losses is an overlooked behavioural phenomenon.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the prevalence of loss aversion versus loss tolerance in the U.S. population, and how do gain-loss attitudes relate to real-world financial behaviors?
answer: Around 50% of the U.S. population is loss tolerant (willing to accept negative-expected-value gambles containing losses), contrary to prior laboratory studies showing 70-90% are loss averse. Loss-tolerant individuals are more likely to gamble, invest higher percentages in stocks, and experience financial shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing literature by using representative U.S. population surveys instead of laboratory/student samples, revealing that loss tolerance is much more prevalent than previously thought and identifying loss tolerance as an overlooked behavioral phenomenon, while confirming that gain-loss attitudes are important economic preferences with better predictive power than risk aversion measures.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Selective Trials: A Principal-Agent Approach to Randomized Controlled Experiments
abstract: <jats:p> We study the design of randomized controlled experiments when outcomes are significantly affected by experimental subjects' unobserved effort expenditure. While standard randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are internally consistent, the unobservability of effort compromises external validity. We approach trial design as a principal-agent problem and show that natural extensions of RCTs—which we call selective trials—can help improve external validity. In particular, selective trials can disentangle the effects of treatment, effort, and the interaction of treatment and effort. Moreover, they can help identify when treatment effects are affected by erroneous beliefs and inappropriate effort expenditure.(JEL C90, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: How can randomized controlled experiments be designed to improve external validity when outcomes are significantly affected by experimental subjects' unobserved effort expenditure?
answer: Natural extensions of RCTs called 'selective trials' that approach trial design as a principal-agent problem can help improve external validity by disentangling the effects of treatment, effort, and the interaction of treatment and effort, and can identify when treatment effects are affected by erroneous beliefs and inappropriate effort expenditure.
positioning_statement: While standard randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are internally consistent, this paper addresses the limitation that unobservability of effort compromises external validity, positioning selective trials as an improvement over standard RCTs for situations where subject effort significantly affects outcomes.

author: Ernesto Dal Bó
title: Cooperation under the Shadow of the Future: Experimental Evidence from Infinitely Repeated Games
abstract: <jats:p> While there is an extensive literature on the theory of infinitely repeated games, empirical evidence on how “the shadow of the future” affects behavior is scarce and inconclusive. I simulate infinitely repeated prisoner's dilemma games in the lab with a random continuation rule. The experimental design represents an improvement over the existing literature by including sessions with finite repeated games as controls and a large number of players per session (which allows for learning without contagion effects). I find that the shadow of the future matters not only by significantly reducing opportunistic behavior, but also because its impact closely follows theoretical predictions. </jats:p>
research_question: How does 'the shadow of the future' affect cooperative behavior in infinitely repeated games?
answer: The shadow of the future significantly reduces opportunistic behavior, and its impact closely follows theoretical predictions from infinitely repeated game theory.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the scarcity of empirical evidence on how the shadow of the future affects behavior in infinitely repeated games, improving upon existing literature by including finite repeated games as controls and using a large number of players per session to allow for learning without contagion effects.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Econographics
abstract: We study the pattern of correlations across a large number of behavioral regularities, with the goal of creating an empirical basis for more comprehensive theories of decision-making. We elicit 21 behaviors, using an incentivized survey on a representative sample (n=1,000) of the US population. Our data show a clear and relatively simple structure underlying the correlations between these measures. Using principal components analysis, we reduce the 21 variables to six components corresponding to clear clusters of high correlations. We examine the relationship between these components, cognitive ability, and demographics. Common extant theories are not compatible with all the patterns in our data.

author: Erik Snowberg
title: Valuing the Time of the Self-Employed
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>People’s value of their own time is a key input in public policy evaluations—these evaluations should account for time taken away from work or leisure as a result of policy. Measuring this value for the self-employed is challenging, as, by definition, it is not priced by the market. Using rich choice data collected from farming households in western Kenya, we show that households exhibit non-transitive preferences. As a result, neither market wages nor standard valuation techniques correctly measure participants’ value of time. Using a structural model, we identify the behavioural wedges in participants’ choices and find that distortions appear when households exchange cash either for time or for goods. Our model estimates suggest that valuing the time of the self-employed at 60% of the market wage is a reasonable rule of thumb.</jats:p>
research_question: How should we value the time of self-employed individuals for public policy evaluations, given that their time is not priced by the market?
answer: The time of self-employed individuals should be valued at approximately 60% of the market wage, as standard valuation techniques fail due to non-transitive preferences and behavioral distortions when households exchange cash for time or goods.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in existing literature by showing that standard valuation techniques and market wages incorrectly measure the value of time for self-employed individuals due to non-transitive preferences, requiring a structural model approach to identify behavioral wedges that previous methods have failed to account for.

author: Ernesto Dal Bó
title: Strengthening State Capabilities: The Role of Financial Incentives in the Call to Public Service*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study a recent recruitment drive for public sector positions in Mexico. Different salaries were announced randomly across recruitment sites, and job offers were subsequently randomized. Screening relied on exams designed to measure applicants’ intellectual ability, personality, and motivation. This allows the first experimental estimates of (1) the role of financial incentives in attracting a larger and more qualified pool of applicants, (2) the elasticity of the labor supply facing the employer, and (3) the role of job attributes (distance, attractiveness of the municipal environment) in helping fill vacancies, as well as the role of wages in helping fill positions in less attractive municipalities. A theoretical model of job applications and acceptance guides the empirical inquiry. We find that higher wages attract more able applicants as measured by their IQ, personality, and proclivity toward public sector work—that is, we find no evidence of adverse selection effects on motivation; higher wage offers also increased acceptance rates, implying a labor supply elasticity of around 2 and some degree of monopsony power. Distance and worse municipal characteristics strongly decrease acceptance rates, but higher wages help bridge the recruitment gap in worse municipalities.</jats:p>
research_question: How do financial incentives affect the recruitment of qualified candidates for public sector positions, specifically examining their impact on applicant pool quality, labor supply elasticity, and the ability to fill vacancies in less attractive locations?
answer: Higher wages attract more able applicants (measured by IQ, personality, and motivation for public service) without adverse selection effects, increase job acceptance rates with a labor supply elasticity of around 2, and help overcome recruitment challenges in less attractive municipalities, though distance and poor municipal characteristics still strongly decrease acceptance rates.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first experimental estimates of financial incentives' role in public sector recruitment by using a randomized controlled trial design with random salary announcements and job offers, filling a gap in the literature that has lacked rigorous experimental evidence on these relationships.

author: Ernesto Dal Bó
title: Information Technology and Government Decentralization: Experimental Evidence From Paraguay
abstract: <jats:p>Standard models of hierarchy assume that agents and middle managers are better informed than principals. We estimate the value of the informational advantage held by supervisors—middle managers—when ministerial leadership—the principal—introduced a new monitoring technology aimed at improving the performance of agricultural extension agents (AEAs) in rural Paraguay. Our approach employs a novel experimental design that elicited treatment‐priority rankings from supervisors before randomization of treatment. We find that supervisors have valuable information—they prioritize AEAs who would be more responsive to the monitoring treatment. We develop a model of monitoring under different scales of treatment roll‐out and different treatment allocation rules. We semiparametrically estimate marginal treatment effects (MTEs) to demonstrate that the value of information and the benefits to decentralizing treatment decisions depend crucially on the sophistication of the principal and on the scale of roll‐out.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the value of the informational advantage held by supervisors (middle managers) when principals introduce new monitoring technology, and how do the benefits of decentralizing treatment decisions depend on the principal's sophistication and scale of roll-out?
answer: Supervisors have valuable information as they can identify which agents would be more responsive to monitoring treatment. The value of this information and the benefits of decentralizing treatment decisions depend crucially on the sophistication of the principal and the scale of treatment roll-out.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to standard models of hierarchy that assume agents and middle managers are better informed than principals by providing experimental evidence that quantifies the value of supervisors' informational advantage and develops a model showing how decentralization benefits vary with principal sophistication and implementation scale.

author: Ernesto Dal Bó
title: The Evolution of Cooperation in Infinitely Repeated Games: Experimental Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> A usual criticism of the theory of infinitely repeated games is that it does not provide sharp predictions since there may be a multiplicity of equilibria. To address this issue, we present experimental evidence on the evolution of cooperation in infinitely repeated prisoner's dilemma games as subjects gain experience. We show that cooperation may prevail in infinitely repeated games, but the conditions under which this occurs are more stringent than the subgame perfect conditions usually considered or even a condition based on risk dominance. (JEL C71, C73) </jats:p>
research_question: How does cooperation evolve in infinitely repeated prisoner's dilemma games as subjects gain experience, and under what conditions does cooperation prevail?
answer: Cooperation may prevail in infinitely repeated games, but the conditions under which this occurs are more stringent than the subgame perfect conditions usually considered or even a condition based on risk dominance.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a usual criticism of the theory of infinitely repeated games - that it does not provide sharp predictions due to multiplicity of equilibria - by providing experimental evidence on cooperation evolution as subjects gain experience.

author: Ernesto Dal Bó
title: Who Becomes A Politician?*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Can a democracy attract competent leaders, while attaining broad representation? Economic models suggest that free-riding incentives and lower opportunity costs give the less competent a comparative advantage at entering political life. Moreover, if elites have more human capital, selecting on competence may lead to uneven representation. This article examines patterns of political selection among the universe of municipal politicians and national legislators in Sweden, using extraordinarily rich data on competence traits and social background for the entire population. We document four new facts that together characterize an “inclusive meritocracy.” First, politicians are on average significantly smarter and better leaders than the population they represent. Second, this positive selection is present even when conditioning on family (and hence social) background, suggesting that individual competence is key for selection. Third, the representation of social background, whether measured by parental earnings or occupational social class, is remarkably even. Fourth, there is at best a weak trade-off in selection between competence and social representation, mainly due to strong positive selection of politicians of low (parental) socioeconomic status. A broad implication of these facts is that it is possible for democracy to generate competent and socially representative leadership.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a democracy attract competent leaders while attaining broad representation?
answer: Yes, democracy can generate both competent and socially representative leadership - politicians are significantly smarter and better leaders than average, yet representation across social backgrounds is remarkably even, with only a weak trade-off between competence and social representation.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing economic models that suggest free-riding incentives and lower opportunity costs give the less competent a comparative advantage in politics, and that selecting on competence leads to uneven representation, by providing empirical evidence of an 'inclusive meritocracy' using comprehensive data on Swedish politicians.

author: Ernesto Dal Bó
title: Strategy Choice in the Infinitely Repeated Prisoner’s Dilemma
abstract: <jats:p> We use a novel experimental design to reliably elicit subjects’ strategies in an infinitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma experiment with perfect monitoring. We find that three simple strategies repre‑ sent the majority of the chosen strategies: Always Defect, Tit‑for‑Tat, and Grim. In addition, we identify how the strategies systematically vary with the parameters of the game. Finally, we use the elicited strategies to test the ability to recover strategies using statistical methods based on observed round‑by‑round cooperation choices and find that this can be done fairly well, but only under certain conditions. (JEL C72, C73, C92) </jats:p>
research_question: What strategies do subjects choose in an infinitely repeated prisoner's dilemma game with perfect monitoring, and how do these strategies vary with game parameters?
answer: Three simple strategies represent the majority of chosen strategies: Always Defect, Tit-for-Tat, and Grim. These strategies systematically vary with the parameters of the game, and can be recovered fairly well using statistical methods based on observed cooperation choices, but only under certain conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the experimental literature on repeated games by using a novel experimental design to directly elicit subjects' strategies, rather than inferring them from observed behavior, and tests the reliability of statistical methods for strategy recovery from behavioral data.

author: Ernesto Dal Bó
title: Institutions and Behavior: Experimental Evidence on the Effects of Democracy
abstract: <jats:p> A novel experiment is used to show that the effect of a policy on the level of cooperation is greater when it is chosen democratically by the subjects than when it is exogenously imposed. In contrast to the previous literature, our experimental design allows us to control for selection effects (e.g., those who choose the policy may be affected differently by it). Our finding implies that democratic institutions may affect behavior directly in addition to having effects through the choice of policies. Our findings have implications for the generalizability of the results of randomized policy interventions. (JEL C91, D02, D12, D72) </jats:p>
research_question: Does the method by which a policy is implemented (democratically chosen vs. exogenously imposed) affect its impact on cooperation behavior?
answer: The effect of a policy on the level of cooperation is greater when it is chosen democratically by the subjects than when it is exogenously imposed, indicating that democratic institutions may affect behavior directly in addition to having effects through policy choice.
positioning_statement: In contrast to the previous literature, this paper uses an experimental design that controls for selection effects (e.g., those who choose the policy may be affected differently by it), allowing for cleaner identification of the direct behavioral effects of democratic institutions beyond policy selection effects.

author: Erzo F.P. Luttmer
title: The Welfare Cost of Perceived Policy Uncertainty: Evidence from Social Security
abstract: <jats:p>Policy uncertainty reduces individual welfare when individuals have limited opportunities to mitigate or insure against the resulting consumption fluctuations. We field an original survey to measure the degree of perceived policy uncertainty in Social Security benefits and to estimate the impact of this uncertainty on individual welfare. Our central estimates show that on average individuals are willing to forgo 6 percent of the benefits they are supposed to get under current law to remove the policy uncertainty associated with their future Social Security benefits. This translates to a risk premium from policy uncertainty equal to 10 percent of expected benefits. (JEL D14, D81, H55)</jats:p>
research_question: What is the welfare cost of perceived policy uncertainty in Social Security benefits?
answer: Individuals are willing to forgo 6 percent of their expected Social Security benefits to eliminate policy uncertainty, which translates to a risk premium equal to 10 percent of expected benefits.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on policy uncertainty by providing direct empirical evidence of welfare costs through an original survey measuring perceived uncertainty in Social Security benefits, addressing the gap in quantifying how policy uncertainty affects individual welfare when people have limited opportunities to mitigate consumption fluctuations.

author: Erzo F.P. Luttmer
title: The Misallocation of Housing Under Rent Control
abstract: <jats:p> The standard analysis of price controls assumes that goods are efficiently allocated, even when there are shortages. But if shortages mean that goods are randomly allocated across the consumers that want them, the welfare costs from misallocation may be greater than the undersupply costs. We develop a framework to empirically test for misallocation. The methodology compares consumption patterns for demographic subgroups in rent-controlled and free-market places. We find that in New York City, which is rent-controlled, an economically and statistically significant fraction of apartments appears to be misallocated across demographic subgroups. </jats:p>
research_question: Are apartments efficiently allocated across consumers under rent control, or does rent control lead to misallocation of housing units?
answer: In New York City, an economically and statistically significant fraction of apartments appears to be misallocated across demographic subgroups under rent control.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard analysis of price controls which assumes that goods are efficiently allocated even when there are shortages, arguing instead that welfare costs from misallocation may be greater than undersupply costs when goods are randomly allocated.

author: Ernesto Dal Bó
title: Economic and Social Outsiders but Political Insiders: Sweden’s Populist Radical Right
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats, a major populist radical-right party. Based on detailed administrative data, we present the first comprehensive account of which politicians are selected into such a party. Surveys show that politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats share strong anti-establishment and anti-immigration attitudes that drastically set them apart from Sweden’s other parties. Searching for individual traits that link naturally to these attitudes, we classify the universe of Swedish politicians and voters by social and economic marginalization and exposure to immigration. Politicians from the Sweden Democrats over-represent marginalized groups without strong attachments to the labour market or to traditional nuclear families, which instead are under-represented among politicians in all other parties. Among voters, the Sweden Democrats have higher electoral support in precincts with higher shares of the same marginalized groups. We see the mobilization of the marginalized as an important driver of the party’s success. Finally, we uncover that Sweden-Democrat politicians score lower on a number of valence traits than other-party politicians. In sum, the rise of the Sweden Democrats raised political representation for marginalized groups, but this came at a valence cost.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the characteristics of politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats (a populist radical-right party), and how do these characteristics relate to the party's political success?
answer: Sweden Democrats politicians over-represent economically and socially marginalized groups without strong labor market attachments or traditional family ties, while their voters concentrate in precincts with higher shares of these same marginalized groups. The party's success is driven by mobilizing marginalized populations, though this comes at a cost as Sweden Democrat politicians score lower on valence traits compared to other parties.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first comprehensive account of politician selection in a populist radical-right party using detailed administrative data, filling a gap in understanding the individual-level characteristics that link politicians and voters in such parties beyond their shared anti-establishment and anti-immigration attitudes.

author: Erzo F.P. Luttmer
title: The Value of Medicaid: Interpreting Results from the Oregon Health Insurance Experiment
abstract: We develop frameworks for welfare analysis of Medicaid and apply them to the Oregon Health Insurance Experiment. Across different approaches, we estimate low-income uninsured adults’ willingness to pay for Medicaid between $0.5 and $1.2 per dollar of the resource cost of providing Medicaid; estimates of the expected transfer Medicaid provides to recipients are relatively stable across approaches, but estimates of its additional value from risk protection are more variable. We also estimate that the resource cost of providing Medicaid to an additional recipient is only 40 percent of Medicaid’s total cost; 60 percent of Medicaid spending is a transfer to providers of uncompensated care for the low-income uninsured.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: A Spatial Theory of Trade
abstract: <jats:p> The equilibrium relationship between trade and the spatial distribution of economic activity is fundamental to the analysis of national and regional trade patterns, as well as to the effect of trade frictions. We study this relationship using a trade model with a continuum of regions, transport costs, and agglomeration effects caused by production externalities. We analyze the equilibrium specialization and trade patterns for different levels of transport costs and externality parameters. Understanding trade via the distribution of economic activity in space naturally rationalizes the evidence on border effects and the “gravity equation.” </jats:p>
research_question: What is the equilibrium relationship between trade and the spatial distribution of economic activity?
answer: The equilibrium relationship between trade and spatial distribution of economic activity can be understood through a model with continuous regions, transport costs, and agglomeration effects from production externalities, which naturally explains observed border effects and gravity equation patterns in trade.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a fundamental framework for analyzing national and regional trade patterns by incorporating spatial distribution of economic activity, which helps rationalize existing empirical evidence on border effects and the gravity equation that previous literature has documented.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Organization and Inequality in a Knowledge Economy*

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: The Impact of Trade on Organization and Productivity*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A firm's productivity depends on how production is organized. To understand this relationship we develop a theory of an economy where firms with heterogeneous demands use labor and knowledge to produce. Entrepreneurs decide the number of layers of management and the knowledge and span of control of each agent. As a result, in the theory, heterogeneity in demand leads to heterogeneity in productivity and other firms' outcomes. We use the theory to analyze the impact of international trade on organization and calibrate the model to the U.S. economy. Our results indicate that, as a result of a bilateral trade liberalization, firms that export will increase the number of layers of management. The new organization of the average exporter results in higher productivity, although the responses of productivity are heterogeneous across these firms. Liberalizing trade from autarky to the level of openness in 2002 results in a 1% increase in productivity for the marginal exporter and a 1.8% increase in its revenue productivity. Endogenous organization increases the gains from trade by 41% relative to standard models.</jats:p>
research_question: How does international trade liberalization affect firm organization (management layers) and productivity?
answer: Trade liberalization causes exporting firms to increase their number of management layers, resulting in higher productivity - specifically a 1% increase in productivity and 1.8% increase in revenue productivity for the marginal exporter when moving from autarky to 2002 U.S. openness levels, with endogenous organization increasing gains from trade by 41% relative to standard models.
positioning_statement: This paper extends standard trade models by incorporating endogenous firm organization decisions, showing that allowing firms to optimally choose their management structure significantly amplifies the gains from trade by 41% compared to models that treat organization as fixed.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Spatial Development
abstract: <jats:p> We present a theory of spatial development. Manufacturing and services firms located in a continuous geographic area choose each period how much to innovate. Firms trade subject to transport costs and technology diffuses spatially. We apply the model to study the evolution of the US economy in the last half-century and find that it can generate the reduction in the manufacturing employment share, the increased spatial concentration of services, the growth in service productivity starting in the mid-1990s, the rise in the dispersion of land rents in the same period, as well as several other spatial and temporal patterns. (JEL J21, L16, L60, L80, O33, R11, R32) </jats:p>
research_question: How do innovation decisions by manufacturing and services firms in a continuous geographic area, combined with trade costs and spatial technology diffusion, explain the spatial and temporal patterns of economic development?
answer: The spatial development model can generate key observed patterns in the US economy over the last half-century, including the reduction in manufacturing employment share, increased spatial concentration of services, growth in service productivity starting in the mid-1990s, and the rise in dispersion of land rents in the same period.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a new theory of spatial development that integrates firm innovation decisions, trade costs, and spatial technology diffusion to explain multiple observed economic patterns simultaneously, rather than addressing these phenomena in isolation as previous literature has done.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Urban Accounting and Welfare
abstract: <jats:p> We use a simple theory of a system of cities to decompose the determinants of the city size distribution into three main components: efficiency, amenities, and frictions. Higher efficiency and better amenities lead to larger cities but also to greater frictions through congestion and other negative effects of agglomeration. Using data on MSAs in the United States, we estimate these city characteristics. Eliminating variation in any of them leads to large population reallocations, but modest welfare effects. We apply the same methodology to Chinese cities and find welfare effects that are many times larger than those in the US. (JEL H71, O18, P25, R11, R23, R41) </jats:p>
research_question: How do efficiency, amenities, and frictions determine city size distribution, and what are the welfare effects of eliminating variation in these components across cities?
answer: The three components (efficiency, amenities, frictions) lead to large population reallocations when their variation is eliminated, but produce modest welfare effects in the US, while Chinese cities show welfare effects many times larger than those in the US.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a simple theory of a system of cities to decompose city size distribution determinants into three main components, applying this methodology comparatively to both US MSAs and Chinese cities to quantify welfare effects.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Innovation in Space
abstract: <jats:p> This paper shows how competition for land may lead firms to optimally innovate in spite of the market being perfectly competitive. When bidding for a location, firms can enhance their bid by investing in innovations that make the land more valuable. Firms are willing to innovate because the non-replicability of land implies that they will not be undercut by some other producer leading to losses as in the standard theory. In the absence of spillovers over space and over time, firms will optimally innovate. Empirical evidence from U.S. metropolitan areas supports the predictions of the theory. </jats:p>
research_question: How can firms optimally innovate in perfectly competitive markets when competing for land locations?
answer: Competition for land leads firms to optimally innovate in perfectly competitive markets because when bidding for locations, firms can enhance their bids by investing in innovations that make the land more valuable, and the non-replicability of land protects them from being undercut by other producers.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard theory that firms in perfectly competitive markets cannot profitably innovate due to being undercut by competitors, by showing that the unique characteristics of land (non-replicability) create conditions where innovation becomes optimal even under perfect competition.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Inequality and the Organization of Knowledge

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Trading Tasks: A Simple Theory of Offshoring
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a theory of the global production process that focuses on tradeable tasks, and use it to study how falling costs of offshoring affect factor prices in the source country. We identify a productivity effect of task trade that benefits the factor whose tasks are more easily moved offshore. In the light of this effect, reductions in the cost of trading tasks can generate shared gains for all domestic factors, in contrast to the distributional conflict that typically results from reductions in the cost of trading goods. (JEL F11, F16)</jats:p>
research_question: How do falling costs of offshoring affect factor prices in the source country when production is organized around tradeable tasks rather than goods?
answer: Reductions in the cost of trading tasks can generate shared gains for all domestic factors due to a productivity effect that benefits the factor whose tasks are more easily moved offshore, unlike traditional trade in goods which typically creates distributional conflict.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new theoretical framework that focuses on tradeable tasks rather than tradeable goods in studying global production processes, contrasting with existing literature that emphasizes the distributional conflicts typically resulting from reductions in the cost of trading goods.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Location as an Asset
abstract: <jats:p>The location of individuals determines their job and schooling opportunities, amenities, and housing costs. We conceptualize the location choice of individuals as a decision to invest in a “location asset.” This asset has a current cost equal to the location's rent, and a future payoff through better job and schooling opportunities. As with any asset, savers in the location asset transfer resources into the future by going to expensive locations with high future returns. In contrast, borrowers transfer resources to the present by going to cheap locations that offer few other advantages. Holdings of the location asset depend on its comparison to other assets, with the distinction that the location asset is not subject to borrowing constraints. We propose a dynamic location model and derive an agent's mobility choices after experiencing income shocks. We document the investment dimension of location and confirm the core predictions of our theory using French individual panel data from tax returns.</jats:p>
research_question: How can individual location choices be understood as investment decisions in a 'location asset,' and how do income shocks affect mobility patterns when location is treated as an asset?
answer: Location functions as an asset where individuals make investment decisions by trading off current costs (rent) against future returns (better job and schooling opportunities). Savers invest in expensive locations with high future returns, while borrowers choose cheap locations to transfer resources to the present. Unlike other assets, the location asset is not subject to borrowing constraints, and mobility choices respond predictably to income shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel conceptual framework by treating location choice as an asset investment decision, extending traditional location choice models by incorporating dynamic investment theory and explicitly modeling how individuals use location decisions to transfer resources across time periods.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: The Industrial Revolution in Services
abstract: US firms in service industries increasingly operate in more local markets. Employment, sales, and spending on fixed costs have increased rapidly in these industries. These changes have favored top firms, leading to increasing national concentration. Top firms in service industries have grown by expanding into new local markets, predominantly small and mid-sized US cities. Market concentration at the local level has decreased in all US cities, particularly in cities that were initially small. These facts are consistent with the availability of new fixed-cost-intensive technologies that yield lower marginal costs in service sectors. The entry of top service firms into new local markets has led to substantial unmeasured productivity growth, particularly in small markets.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: External Economies and International Trade Redux<sup>*</sup>

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: The Economic Geography of Global Warming
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Global warming is a worldwide and protracted phenomenon with heterogeneous local economic effects. We propose a dynamic economic assessment model of the world economy with high spatial resolution to assess its consequences. Our model features several forms of adaptation to local temperature changes, including costly trade and migration, local technological innovations, and local natality rates. We quantify the model at a 1∘×1∘ resolution and estimate damage functions that determine the impact of temperature changes on a region’s fundamental productivity and amenities conditional on local temperatures. Welfare losses from global warming are very heterogeneous across locations, with 20% losses in parts of Africa and Latin America but also gains in some northern latitudes. Overall, spatial inequality increases. Uncertainty about average welfare effects is significant but much smaller for relative losses across space. Migration and innovation are shown to be important adaptation mechanisms. We use the model to study the impact of carbon taxes, abatement technologies, and clean energy subsidies. Carbon taxes delay consumption of fossil fuels and help flatten the temperature curve but are much more effective when an abatement technology is forthcoming.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the heterogeneous local economic effects of global warming across different geographic locations, and how do various adaptation mechanisms influence these outcomes?
answer: Global warming creates very heterogeneous welfare effects across locations, with severe losses of 20% in parts of Africa and Latin America while some northern latitudes experience gains, leading to increased spatial inequality. Migration and innovation serve as important adaptation mechanisms, and carbon taxes are most effective when combined with abatement technologies.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a dynamic economic assessment model with high spatial resolution (1°×1°) that incorporates multiple forms of adaptation to temperature changes, including trade, migration, technological innovation, and demographic responses, providing a more comprehensive framework for assessing the economic geography of climate change impacts.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: On the Internal Structure of Cities

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Establishment Size Dynamics in the Aggregate Economy
abstract: <jats:p> This paper presents a theory of establishment size dynamics based on the accumulation of industry-specific human capital that simultaneously rationalizes the economy-wide facts on establishment growth rates, exit rates, and size distributions. The theory predicts that establishment growth and net exit rates should decline faster with size, and that the establishment size distribution should have thinner tails, in sectors that use specific human capital less intensively. We establish that there is substantial cross-sector heterogeneity in US establishment size dynamics and distributions, which is well explained by relative factor intensities. (JEL L11, L16, L25). </jats:p>
research_question: What explains establishment size dynamics, including growth rates, exit rates, and size distributions across the aggregate economy?
answer: Establishment size dynamics are driven by the accumulation of industry-specific human capital, with establishments in sectors that use specific human capital less intensively showing faster declining growth and exit rates with size, and thinner-tailed size distributions.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified theory that simultaneously explains multiple economy-wide facts about establishment dynamics (growth rates, exit rates, and size distributions) through a single mechanism of industry-specific human capital accumulation, addressing the cross-sector heterogeneity in establishment size dynamics that existing literature has not comprehensively explained.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Learning From Coworkers
abstract: <jats:p>We investigate learning at the workplace. To do so, we use German administrative data that contain information on the entire workforce of a sample of establishments. We document that having more‐highly‐paid coworkers is strongly associated with future wage growth, particularly if those workers earn more. Motivated by this fact, we propose a dynamic theory of a competitive labor market where firms produce using teams of heterogeneous workers that learn from each other. We develop a methodology to structurally estimate knowledge flows using the full‐richness of the German employer‐employee matched data. The methodology builds on the observation that a competitive labor market prices coworker learning. Our quantitative approach imposes minimal restrictions on firms' production functions, can be implemented on a very short panel, and allows for potentially rich and flexible coworker learning functions. In line with our reduced‐form results, learning from coworkers is significant, particularly from more knowledgeable coworkers. We show that between 4 and 9% of total worker compensation is in the form of learning and that inequality in total compensation is significantly lower than inequality in wages.</jats:p>
research_question: How do workers learn from their coworkers in the workplace, and what is the magnitude and impact of this learning on wages and compensation?
answer: Workers learn significantly from coworkers, particularly from more highly-paid and knowledgeable colleagues, with learning representing 4-9% of total worker compensation and reducing overall compensation inequality compared to wage inequality alone.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the workplace learning literature by developing a novel structural methodology to estimate knowledge flows using German employer-employee matched data, proposing a dynamic competitive labor market theory where firms price coworker learning, and providing quantitative evidence with minimal restrictions on production functions that can be implemented on short panels.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Housing Externalities

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Commuting, Migration, and Local Employment Elasticities
abstract: <jats:p> We provide theory and evidence that the elasticity of local employment to a labor demand shock is heterogeneous depending on the commuting openness of the local labor market. We develop a quantitative general equilibrium model that incorporates spatial linkages in goods markets (trade) and factor markets (commuting and migration). We quantify this model to match the observed gravity equation relationships for trade and commuting. We find that empirically-observed reductions in commuting costs generate welfare gains of around 3.3 percent. We provide separate quasi-experimental evidence in support of the model’s predictions using the location decisions of million dollar plants. (JEL J23, J61, R23, R32, R41) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the commuting openness of local labor markets affect the elasticity of local employment to labor demand shocks?
answer: The elasticity of local employment to labor demand shocks is heterogeneous and depends on the commuting openness of the local labor market, with empirically-observed reductions in commuting costs generating welfare gains of around 3.3 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a quantitative general equilibrium model that incorporates both spatial linkages in goods markets (trade) and factor markets (commuting and migration), providing both theoretical framework and quasi-experimental evidence using million dollar plant location decisions to support the model's predictions.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Globalization and Pandemics
abstract: <jats:p> We provide theory and evidence on the relationship between globalization and pandemics. Business travel facilitates trade and travel leads to human interactions that transmit disease. Trade-motivated travel generates an epidemiological externality across countries. If infections lead to deaths, or reduce individual labor supply, we establish a general equilibrium social distancing effect, whereby increases in relative prices in unhealthy countries reduce travel to those countries. If agents internalize the threat of infection, we show that their behavioral responses lead to a reduction in travel that is larger for higher-trade-cost locations, which initially reduces the ratio of trade to output. (JEL D91, F14, F60, I12, N30, N70, Z31) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between globalization and pandemics, specifically how business travel that facilitates trade affects disease transmission across countries?
answer: Business travel creates an epidemiological externality across countries by facilitating disease transmission, but general equilibrium social distancing effects and behavioral responses lead to reduced travel (especially to higher-trade-cost locations) and a reduction in the ratio of trade to output during pandemics.
positioning_statement: This paper provides both theoretical framework and empirical evidence on the globalization-pandemic relationship, establishing novel concepts of epidemiological externalities from trade-motivated travel and general equilibrium social distancing effects that emerge when infections affect mortality or labor supply.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: The Geography of Development
abstract: We develop a dynamic spatial growth theory with realistic geography. We characterize the model and its balanced-growth path and propose a methodology to analyze equilibria with different levels of migration frictions. Different migration scenarios change local market size, innovation incentives, and the evolution of technology. We bring the model to the data for the whole world economy at a 1° × 1° geographic resolution. We then use the model to quantify the gains from relaxing migration restrictions. Our results indicate that fully liberalizing migration would increase welfare about threefold and would significantly affect the evolution of particular regions of the world.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: The Impact of Regional and Sectoral Productivity Changes on the U.S. Economy

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Productivity and Organization in Portuguese Firms
abstract: Using employer-employee matched and firm production quantity and input data for Portuguese firms, we study the endogenous response of productivity to firm reorganizations as measured by changes in the number of management layers. We show that, as a result of an exogenous demand or productivity shock that makes the firm reorganize and add a management layer, quantity-based productivity increases by about 6%, while revenue-based productivity drops by around 3%. Such a reorganization makes the firm more productive but also increases the quantity produced to an extent that lowers the price charged by the firm and, as a result, its revenue-based productivity as well.

author: Esteban Rossi-Hansberg
title: Plants in Space
abstract: To decide the number, size, and location of its plants, a firm balances the benefit of delivering goods from multiple plants with the cost of setting up and managing these plants and the potential for cannibalization among them. Modeling the decisions of heterogeneous firms in an economy with a vast number of distinct locations involves a large combinatorial problem. Using insights from discrete geometry, we study a tractable limit case of this problem in which these forces operate at a local level. Our analysis delivers predictions on sorting across space. Compared with less productive firms, productive firms place more plants in dense, high-rent locations and fewer plants in markets with low density and low rents. We present evidence consistent with these and several other predictions, using US establishment-level data.

author: Ezra Oberfield
title: A Theory of Input-Output Architecture
abstract: Individual producers exhibit enormous heterogeneity in many dimensions. This paper develops a theory in which the network structure of production—who buys inputs from whom—forms endogenously. Entrepreneurs produce using labor and exactly one intermediate input; the key decision is which other entrepreneur's good to use as an input. Their choices collectively determine the economy's equilibrium input–output structure, generating large differences in size and shaping both individual and aggregate productivity. When the elasticity of output to intermediate inputs in production is high, star suppliers emerge endogenously. This raises aggregate productivity as, in equilibrium, more supply chains are routed through higher‐productivity techniques.

author: Ezra Oberfield
title: Micro Data and Macro Technology
abstract: <jats:p>We develop a framework to estimate the aggregate capital‐labor elasticity of substitution by aggregating the actions of individual plants. The aggregate elasticity reflects substitution within plants and reallocation across plants; the extent of heterogeneity in capital intensities determines their relative importance. We use micro data on the cross‐section of plants to build up to the aggregate elasticity at a point in time. Interpreting our econometric estimates through the lens of several different models, we find that the aggregate elasticity for the U.S. manufacturing sector is in the range of 0.5–0.7, and has declined slightly since 1970. We use our estimates to measure the bias of technical change and assess the decline in labor's share of income in the U.S. manufacturing sector. Mechanisms that rely on changes in the relative supply of factors, such as an acceleration of capital accumulation, cannot account for the decline.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the aggregate capital-labor elasticity of substitution in the U.S. manufacturing sector, and how can it be estimated by aggregating individual plant-level data?
answer: The aggregate capital-labor elasticity of substitution for the U.S. manufacturing sector is in the range of 0.5-0.7 and has declined slightly since 1970. The aggregate elasticity reflects both substitution within plants and reallocation across plants, with the relative importance determined by heterogeneity in capital intensities.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel framework that estimates aggregate elasticity by building up from micro-level plant data, in contrast to existing approaches that may not adequately account for plant-level heterogeneity and reallocation effects in determining aggregate technology parameters.

author: Ezra Oberfield
title: The Global Diffusion of Ideas
abstract: <jats:p>We provide a tractable, quantitatively‐oriented theory of innovation and technology diffusion to explore the role of international trade in the process of development. We model innovation and diffusion as a process involving the combination of new ideas with insights from other industries or countries. We provide conditions under which each country's equilibrium frontier of knowledge converges to a Fréchet distribution, and derive a system of differential equations describing the evolution of the scale parameters of these distributions, that is, countries' stocks of knowledge. The model remains tractable with many asymmetric countries and generates a rich set of predictions about how the level and composition of trade affect countries' frontiers of knowledge. We use the framework to quantify the contribution of bilateral trade costs to long‐run changes in TFP and individual post‐war growth miracles. For our preferred calibration, we find that both gains from trade and the fraction of variation of TFP growth accounted for by changes in trade more than double relative to a model without diffusion.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of international trade in the process of development through innovation and technology diffusion?
answer: International trade significantly amplifies development through knowledge diffusion, with both gains from trade and the fraction of TFP growth variation explained by trade changes more than doubling compared to models without diffusion mechanisms.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a tractable, quantitatively-oriented theory that models innovation and diffusion as involving the combination of new ideas with insights from other industries or countries, extending beyond existing models by incorporating diffusion mechanisms that generate richer predictions about how trade affects countries' knowledge frontiers.

author: Ezra Oberfield
title: Misallocation in the Market for Inputs: Enforcement and the Organization of Production*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The strength of contract enforcement determines how firms source inputs and organize production. Using microdata on Indian manufacturing plants, we show that production and sourcing decisions appear systematically distorted in states with weaker enforcement. Specifically, we document that in industries that tend to rely more heavily on relationship-specific intermediate inputs, plants in states with more-congested courts shift their expenditures away from intermediate inputs and have a greater vertical span of production. To quantify the effect of these distortions on aggregate productivity, we construct a model in which plants have several ways of producing, each with different bundles of inputs. Weak enforcement exacerbates a holdup problem that arises when using inputs that require customization, distorting both the intensive and extensive margins of input use. The equilibrium organization of production and the network structure of input-output linkages arise endogenously from the producers’ simultaneous cost-minimization decisions. We identify the structural parameters that govern enforcement frictions from cross-state variation in the first moments of producers’ cost shares. A set of counterfactuals show that enforcement frictions lower aggregate productivity to an extent that is relevant on the macro scale.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the strength of contract enforcement affect how firms source inputs and organize production, and what are the aggregate productivity consequences of these distortions?
answer: Weak contract enforcement causes firms to systematically distort their production and sourcing decisions - specifically, in industries relying on relationship-specific inputs, firms in states with more congested courts shift expenditures away from intermediate inputs and increase vertical integration. These enforcement frictions lower aggregate productivity to a macroeconomically relevant extent through distortions in both intensive and extensive margins of input use.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on misallocation and productivity by focusing on how contract enforcement affects input sourcing decisions and production organization, using a structural model that endogenously determines the organization of production and input-output network structure from firms' cost-minimization decisions, and quantifying the aggregate productivity effects using microdata from Indian manufacturing plants.

author: Ezra Oberfield
title: Endogenous Education and Long-Run Factor Shares
abstract: <jats:p> We study the determinants of factor shares in a neoclassical environment with capital-skill complementarity and endogenous education. In this environment estimates of the elasticity of substitution between capital and labor that fail to account for human capital levels will be biased upward. We develop a model with overlapping generations, technology-driven neoclassical growth, and ongoing increases in educational attainment. For a class of production functions featuring capital-skill complementarity, a balanced growth path exists and is characterized by an inverse relationship between the rates of capital-and labor-augmenting technological progress and the capital share in national income. (JEL D33, E25, J24, O33) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the determinants of factor shares in an economy with capital-skill complementarity and endogenous education?
answer: There is an inverse relationship between the rates of capital- and labor-augmenting technological progress and the capital share in national income, and estimates of elasticity of substitution between capital and labor are biased upward when human capital levels are not properly accounted for.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the neoclassical growth literature by incorporating endogenous education and capital-skill complementarity to correct biases in existing estimates of factor substitution elasticity that fail to account for human capital accumulation.

author: Ezra Oberfield
title: Learning From Coworkers
abstract: <jats:p>We investigate learning at the workplace. To do so, we use German administrative data that contain information on the entire workforce of a sample of establishments. We document that having more‐highly‐paid coworkers is strongly associated with future wage growth, particularly if those workers earn more. Motivated by this fact, we propose a dynamic theory of a competitive labor market where firms produce using teams of heterogeneous workers that learn from each other. We develop a methodology to structurally estimate knowledge flows using the full‐richness of the German employer‐employee matched data. The methodology builds on the observation that a competitive labor market prices coworker learning.
