positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the workplace learning literature by developing a novel structural methodology to estimate knowledge flows using German employer-employee matched data, proposing a dynamic competitive labor market theory where firms price coworker learning, and providing quantitative evidence with minimal restrictions on production functions that can be implemented on short panels.

author: Federica Romei
title: The Paradox of Global Thrift
abstract: <jats:p> This paper describes a paradox of global thrift. Consider a world in which interest rates are low and monetary policy is constrained by the zero lower bound. Now imagine that governments implement prudential financial and fiscal policies to stabilize the economy. We show that these policies, while effective from the perspective of individual countries, might backfire if applied on a global scale. In fact, prudential policies generate a rise in the global supply of savings and a drop in global aggregate demand. Weaker global aggregate demand depresses output in countries at the zero lower bound. Due to this effect, noncooperative financial and fiscal policies might lead to a fall in global output and welfare. (JEL E21, E23, E43, E44, E52, E62, F32) </jats:p>
research_question: What happens when governments implement prudential financial and fiscal policies on a global scale in a low interest rate environment constrained by the zero lower bound?
answer: Prudential policies that are effective at the individual country level can backfire when applied globally, as they increase global savings supply and reduce aggregate demand, leading to depressed output and potentially lower global welfare due to noncooperative policy implementation.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a previously unrecognized paradox in macroeconomic policy coordination, showing that individually rational prudential policies can be collectively harmful in a zero lower bound environment, contributing to the literature on policy spillovers and international coordination.

author: Ezra Oberfield
title: Plants in Space
abstract: To decide the number, size, and location of its plants, a firm balances the benefit of delivering goods from multiple plants with the cost of setting up and managing these plants and the potential for cannibalization among them. Modeling the decisions of heterogeneous firms in an economy with a vast number of distinct locations involves a large combinatorial problem. Using insights from discrete geometry, we study a tractable limit case of this problem in which these forces operate at a local level. Our analysis delivers predictions on sorting across space. Compared with less productive firms, productive firms place more plants in dense, high-rent locations and fewer plants in markets with low density and low rents. We present evidence consistent with these and several other predictions, using US establishment-level data.

title: Mainstream Mathematical Economics in the 20th Century

author: Filip Matejka
title: Personalized Pricing and the Value of Time: Evidence From Auctioned Cab Rides
abstract: <jats:p>We recover valuations of time using detailed data from a large ride‐hail platform, where drivers bid on trips and consumers choose between a set of rides with different prices and wait times. Leveraging a consumer panel, we estimate demand as a function of both prices and wait times and use the resulting estimates to recover heterogeneity in the value of time across consumers. We study the welfare implications of personalized pricing and its effect on the platform, drivers, and consumers. Taking into account drivers' optimal reaction to the platform's pricing policy, personalized pricing lowers consumer surplus by 2.5% and increases overall surplus by 5.2%. Like the platform, drivers benefit from personalized pricing. By conditioning prices on drivers' wait times and not on consumers' data, the platform can capture a significant portion of the profits garnered from personalized pricing, and simultaneously benefit consumers.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the welfare implications of personalized pricing in ride-hail platforms, and how does it affect the platform, drivers, and consumers when accounting for heterogeneity in consumers' value of time?
answer: Personalized pricing decreases consumer surplus by 2.5% but increases overall surplus by 5.2%, benefiting both the platform and drivers. However, the platform can capture significant profits from personalized pricing while simultaneously benefiting consumers by conditioning prices on drivers' wait times rather than on consumers' personal data.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the personalized pricing literature by using detailed ride-hail platform data to recover heterogeneous valuations of time across consumers and studying welfare effects in a two-sided market context where drivers can optimally react to pricing policies, extending beyond previous work that typically focuses on single-sided markets or doesn't account for supply-side responses.

author: Federico Bandi
title: EXcess Idle Time
abstract: We introduce a novel economic indicator, named excess idle time (EXIT), measuring the extent of sluggishness in financial prices. Under a null and an alternative hypothesis grounded in no‐arbitrage (the null) and market microstructure (the alternative) theories of price determination, we derive a limit theory for EXIT leading to formal tests for staleness in the price adjustments. Empirical implementation of the theory indicates that financial prices are often more sluggish than implied by the (ubiquitous, in frictionless continuous‐time asset pricing) semimartingale assumption. EXIT is interpretable as an illiquidity proxy and is easily implementable, for each trading day, using transaction prices only. By using EXIT, we show how to estimate structurally market microstructure models with asymmetric information.

author: Florian Scheuer
title: The Taxation of Superstars*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>How are optimal taxes affected by superstar phenomena? To answer this question, we extend the Mirrlees model to incorporate an assignment problem in the labor market that generates superstar effects. Perhaps surprisingly, rather than providing a rationale for higher taxes, we show that superstar effects provide a force for lower marginal taxes conditional on the observed distribution of earnings. Superstar effects make the earnings schedule convex, which increases the responsiveness of individual earnings to tax changes. We show that various common elasticity measures must be adjusted upward in optimal tax formulas. Finally, we study a comparative static that does not keep the observed earnings distribution fixed: when superstar technologies are introduced, inequality increases but we obtain a neutrality result, finding optimal taxes unaltered.</jats:p>
research_question: How are optimal taxes affected by superstar phenomena?
answer: Superstar effects provide a force for lower marginal taxes conditional on the observed distribution of earnings, as they make the earnings schedule convex and increase the responsiveness of individual earnings to tax changes, requiring upward adjustments to elasticity measures in optimal tax formulas.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the Mirrlees model to incorporate an assignment problem in the labor market that generates superstar effects, addressing a gap in the optimal taxation literature by examining how superstar phenomena affect tax policy design.

author: Florian Scheuer
title: Redistributive Taxation in the Roy Model*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We consider optimal redistribution in a model where individuals can self-select into one of several possible sectors based on heterogeneity in a multidimensional skill vector. We first show that when the government does not observe the sectoral choice or underlying skills of its citizens, the constrained Pareto frontier can be implemented with a single nonlinear income tax. We then characterize this optimal tax schedule. If sectoral inputs are complements, a many-sector model with self-selection leads to optimal income taxes that are less progressive than the corresponding taxes in a standard single-sector model under natural conditions. However, they are more progressive than in canonical multisector economies with discrete types and without occupational choice or overlapping sectoral wage distributions.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal redistributive tax policy in an economy where individuals can self-select into different sectors based on their multidimensional skills, and how does this compare to taxation in single-sector models?
answer: When the government cannot observe sectoral choices or underlying skills, the optimal policy can be implemented with a single nonlinear income tax. When sectoral inputs are complements, this optimal tax is less progressive than in standard single-sector models under natural conditions, but more progressive than in canonical multisector economies with discrete types and no occupational choice.
positioning_statement: This paper extends optimal taxation theory by incorporating multidimensional skills and endogenous sectoral choice in a Roy model framework, bridging the gap between single-sector optimal taxation models and existing multisector models that assume discrete types without occupational choice or overlapping wage distributions.

author: Florian Scheuer
title: Signalling to Experts
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study competitive equilibria in a signalling economy with heterogeneously informed buyers. In terms of the classic Spence (1973, The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 87, 355—374) model of job market signalling, firms have access to direct but imperfect information about worker types, in addition to observing their education. Firms can be ranked according to the quality of their information, i.e., their expertise. In equilibrium, some high-type workers forgo signalling and are hired by better informed firms, which make positive profits. Workers’ education decisions and firms’ use of their expertise are strategic complements, allowing for multiple equilibria that can be Pareto ranked. We characterize wage dispersion and the extent of signalling as a function of the distribution of expertise among firms. Our model can also be applied to a variety of other signalling problems, including securitization, corporate financial structure, insurance markets, or dividend policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How do competitive equilibria in signalling markets change when buyers (firms) have heterogeneous levels of private information or expertise about the types of sellers (workers)?
answer: In equilibrium, some high-type workers choose not to signal and are hired by better-informed firms that make positive profits. Workers' education decisions and firms' use of expertise are strategic complements, leading to multiple Pareto-ranked equilibria with wage dispersion that depends on the distribution of expertise among firms.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the classic Spence (1973) job market signalling model by introducing heterogeneously informed buyers, where firms have access to direct but imperfect information about worker types in addition to observing education signals, and can be ranked by their information quality or expertise.

author: Florian Scheuer
title: Optimal Taxation with Rent-Seeking
abstract: We develop a framework for optimal taxation when agents can earn their income both in traditional activities, where private and social products coincide, and in rent-seeking activities, where private returns exceed social returns either because they involve the capture of pre-existing rents or because they reduce the returns to traditional work. We characterize Pareto optimal income taxes that do not condition on how much of an individual's income is earned in each of the two activities. These optimal taxes feature an externality-corrective term, the magnitude of which depends both on the Pigouvian correction that would obtain if rent-seeking incomes could be perfectly targeted and on the relative impact of rent-seeking externalities on the private returns to traditional and to rent-seeking activities. If rent-seeking externalities primarily affect other rent-seekers, for example, the optimal correction lies strictly below the Pigouvian correction. A calibrated model indicates that the gap between the Pigouvian and optimal correction can be quantitatively important. Our results thus point to a hefty informational requirement for correcting rent-seeking externalities through the income tax code.

author: Florian Scheuer
title: Competitive Markets without Commitment
abstract: In the presence of a time-inconsistency problem with agency contracts, we show that competitive markets can implement allocations that Pareto-dominate those achieved by a benevolent government, and they induce more effort. We analyze a model with moral hazard and a two-sided lack of commitment. After agents have chosen their work, firms can modify contracts and agents can switch firms. If the ex post market outcome satisfies a weak notion of competitiveness and sufficiently separates individuals, it is Pareto superior to a government’s allocation with a complete breakdown of incentives. Moreover, competitive markets without commitment implement more effort in equilibrium under general conditions.

author: Florian Scheuer
title: Capital Taxation under Political Constraints
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies optimal dynamic tax policy under the threat of political reform. A policy will be reformed ex post if a large enough coalition of citizens supports reform; thus, sustainable policies are those that will continue to attract enough political support in the future. We find that optimal marginal capital taxes are either progressive or U-shaped, so that savings are subsidized for the poor and/or the middle class but are taxed for the rich. U-shaped capital taxes always emerge when individuals' political behavior is purely determined by economic motives. (JEL D12, D14, D31, D72, H21, H25) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal dynamic tax policy design when policies face the threat of political reform and must maintain sufficient political support to remain sustainable?
answer: Optimal marginal capital taxes are either progressive or U-shaped, meaning savings should be subsidized for the poor and/or middle class while being taxed for the rich. U-shaped capital taxes always emerge when individuals' political behavior is driven purely by economic motives.
positioning_statement: This paper extends optimal taxation theory by incorporating political sustainability constraints, studying how the threat of political reform affects optimal tax policy design when policies must maintain sufficient coalition support to avoid being reformed ex post.

author: Ezra Oberfield
title: Balanced Growth Despite Uzawa
abstract: <jats:p>The evidence for the United States points to balanced growth despite falling investment-good prices and a less-than-unitary elasticity of substitution between capital and labor. This is inconsistent with the Uzawa Growth Theorem. We extend Uzawa's theorem to show that the introduction of human capital accumulation in the standard way does not resolve the puzzle. However, balanced growth is possible if education is endogenous and capital is more complementary with schooling than with raw labor. We present a class of aggregate production functions for which a neoclassical growth model with capital-augmenting technological progress and endogenous schooling converges to a balanced growth path. (JEL E22, E24, I26, J24, O33, O41, O47)</jats:p>
research_question: How can the U.S. economy exhibit balanced growth despite falling investment-good prices and a less-than-unitary elasticity of substitution between capital and labor, which contradicts the Uzawa Growth Theorem?
answer: Balanced growth is possible when education is endogenous and capital is more complementary with schooling than with raw labor, achieved through a neoclassical growth model with capital-augmenting technological progress and endogenous schooling that converges to a balanced growth path.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the existing Uzawa Growth Theorem by demonstrating that while the standard introduction of human capital accumulation does not resolve the theoretical puzzle of observed balanced growth, a new approach incorporating endogenous education and differential complementarity between capital and schooling versus raw labor can reconcile theory with empirical evidence.

author: Florian Zimmermann
title: The Dynamics of Motivated Beliefs
abstract: <jats:p>A key question in the literature on motivated reasoning and self-deception is how motivated beliefs are sustained in the presence of feedback. In this paper, we explore dynamic motivated belief patterns after feedback. We establish that positive feedback has a persistent effect on beliefs. Negative feedback, instead, influences beliefs in the short run, but this effect fades over time. We investigate the mechanisms of this dynamic pattern, and provide evidence for an asymmetry in the recall of feedback. Finally, we establish that, in line with theoretical accounts, incentives for belief accuracy mitigate the role of motivated reasoning. (JEL C91, D83, D91)</jats:p>
research_question: How are motivated beliefs sustained and how do they change over time in the presence of feedback?
answer: Positive feedback has a persistent effect on beliefs, while negative feedback influences beliefs only in the short run before fading over time, with this asymmetry driven by differential recall of feedback types.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a key question in the existing literature on motivated reasoning and self-deception by exploring the previously understudied dynamic patterns of motivated beliefs after feedback, and confirms theoretical accounts regarding the mitigating role of accuracy incentives.

author: Florian Zimmermann
title: Correlation Neglect in Belief Formation
abstract: Many information structures generate correlated rather than mutually independent signals, the news media being a prime example. This paper shows experimentally that in such contexts many people neglect these correlations in the updating process and treat correlated information as independent. In consequence, people's beliefs are excessively sensitive to well-connected information sources, implying a pattern of "overshooting" beliefs. Additionally, in an experimental asset market, correlation neglect not only drives overoptimism and overpessimism at the individual level, but also affects aggregate outcomes in a systematic manner. In particular, the excessive confidence swings caused by correlated signals give rise to predictable price bubbles and crashes. These findings are reminiscent of popular narratives according to which aggregate booms and busts might be driven by the spread of "stories". Our results also lend direct support to recent models of boundedly rational social learning.

author: Francesc Dilmé
title: Robust Information Transmission
abstract: <jats:p> This paper investigates robust information transmission between a sender and a receiver in the Crawford and Sobel (1982) model. We characterize behavior that remains equilibrium behavior independently of the form of a small communication cost. Under standard conditions, we find that an equilibrium outcome is robust if and only if it features a maximal number of on-path actions and each is induced by a single message. The result extends regardless of the direction of the bias, the number of available messages, or whether the objectives of the sender and the receiver are aligned. (JEL D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: What constitutes robust information transmission behavior that remains equilibrium behavior independently of the form of small communication costs in the Crawford and Sobel (1982) model?
answer: An equilibrium outcome is robust if and only if it features a maximal number of on-path actions and each action is induced by a single message, regardless of bias direction, number of available messages, or alignment of sender and receiver objectives.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the Crawford and Sobel (1982) model by investigating robustness to small communication costs, providing a characterization that holds under general conditions including different bias directions, message availability, and objective alignment between parties.

author: Florian Zimmermann
title: Stories, Statistics, and Memory
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>For many decisions, we encounter relevant information over the course of days, months, or years. We consume such information in various forms, including stories (qualitative content about individual instances) and statistics (quantitative data about collections of observations). This article proposes that information type—story versus statistic—shapes selective memory. In controlled experiments, we document a pronounced story-statistic gap in memory: the average impact of statistics on beliefs fades by 73% over the course of a day, but the impact of a story fades by only 32%. Guided by a model of selective memory, we disentangle different mechanisms and document that similarity relationships drive this gap. Recall of a story increases when its qualitative content is more similar to a memory prompt. Irrelevant information in memory that is similar to the prompt, on the other hand, competes for retrieval with relevant information, impeding successful recall.</jats:p>
research_question: How does information type (stories versus statistics) affect selective memory and the persistence of their impact on beliefs over time?
answer: There is a pronounced story-statistic gap in memory: statistics' impact on beliefs fades by 73% over a day while stories' impact fades by only 32%. This gap is driven by similarity relationships, where stories are better recalled when their qualitative content is similar to memory prompts, though irrelevant similar information can compete for retrieval.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a novel framework examining how information format affects memory retention in decision-making contexts where relevant information is encountered over extended periods, contributing to understanding of selective memory mechanisms through controlled experimental evidence.

author: Florian Zimmermann
title: Moral Universalism and the Structure of Ideology
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Throughout the Western world, people’s policy views are correlated across domains in a strikingly similar fashion. This article proposes that what partly explains the structure of ideology is moral universalism: the extent to which people exhibit the same level of altruism and trust towards strangers as towards in-group members. In new large-scale multinational surveys, heterogeneity in universalism descriptively explains why some people support redistribution, health care, environmental protection, affirmative action, and foreign aid, while others advocate for spending on the military, law enforcement, and border protection. Universalism is a substantially stronger predictor of policy views and ideological constraints than variables such as income, wealth, education, religiosity, or beliefs about government efficiency. Consistent with the idea that universalism shapes policy views, we further document that the left–right divide on redistribution, environmental protection, or foreign aid strongly attenuates or even reverses when people evaluate less universalist implementations of these policies.</jats:p>
research_question: What explains the strikingly similar structure of ideology and correlation of policy views across domains throughout the Western world?
answer: Moral universalism - the extent to which people exhibit the same level of altruism and trust towards strangers as towards in-group members - partly explains the structure of ideology and is a substantially stronger predictor of policy views than traditional variables like income, wealth, education, religiosity, or beliefs about government efficiency.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a novel explanation for ideological structure by introducing moral universalism as a key factor, positioning it as a stronger predictor than commonly studied variables in existing literature such as socioeconomic factors, education, religiosity, or government efficiency beliefs.

author: Francesc Dilmé
title: Sequentially Stable Outcomes
abstract:
<jats:p>This paper introduces and analyzes 
            <jats:italic>sequentially stable outcomes</jats:italic> in extensive‐form games. An outcome 
            <jats:italic>ω</jats:italic> is sequentially stable if, for any 
            <jats:italic>ε</jats:italic> > 0 and any small enough perturbation of the players' behavior, there is an 
            <jats:italic>ε</jats:italic>‐perturbation of the players' payoffs and a corresponding equilibrium with outcome close to 
            <jats:italic>ω</jats:italic>. Sequentially stable outcomes exist for all finite games and are outcomes of sequential equilibria. They are closely related to stable sets of equilibria and satisfy versions of forward induction, iterated strict equilibrium dominance, and invariance to simultaneous moves. In signaling games, sequentially stable outcomes pass the standard selection criteria, and when payoffs are generic, they coincide with outcomes of stable sets of equilibria.
          </jats:p>
research_question: What constitutes a sequentially stable outcome in extensive-form games and what are its properties?
answer: Sequentially stable outcomes exist for all finite games, are outcomes of sequential equilibria, and satisfy key game-theoretic properties including forward induction, iterated strict equilibrium dominance, and invariance to simultaneous moves. In signaling games with generic payoffs, they coincide with outcomes of stable sets of equilibria.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new solution concept that builds upon existing sequential equilibrium theory and stable sets of equilibria, providing a refinement that satisfies standard selection criteria in signaling games while maintaining desirable theoretical properties.

author: Francesc Dilmé
title: A Dynamic Theory of Random Price Discounts
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A seller with commitment power sets prices over time. Risk-averse buyers arrive to the market and decide when to purchase. We show that it is optimal for the seller to choose a constant high price punctuated by occasional episodes of sequential discounts that occur at random times. This optimal price path has the property that the price a buyer ends up paying is independent of his arrival and purchase times, and only depends on his valuation. Our theory accommodates empirical findings on the timing of discounts.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal pricing strategy for a seller with commitment power when facing risk-averse buyers who arrive at different times and can choose when to purchase?
answer: It is optimal for the seller to set a constant high price punctuated by occasional episodes of sequential discounts that occur at random times, resulting in a price path where the final price paid by buyers depends only on their valuation, not their arrival or purchase timing.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a theoretical framework that accommodates and explains empirical findings on the timing of price discounts, contributing to the literature on dynamic pricing with strategic buyers.

author: Francesc Dilmé
title: Relational Contracts: Public versus Private Savings
abstract: <jats:p>Work on relational employment agreements often predicts low payments or termination for poor performance. The possibility of saving can, however, limit the effectiveness of monetary incentives in motivating an employee with diminishing marginal utility for consumption. We study the role of savings and their observability in optimal relational contracts. We focus on the case where players are not too patient, and hence the constant first‐best effort cannot be implemented. If savings are hidden, the relationship eventually deteriorates over time. In particular, both payments and effort decline. On the other hand, if savings are public, consumption is initially high, so the agent's savings fall over time, and effort and payments to the agent increase. The findings thus suggest how tacit agreements on consumption can forestall the deterioration of dynamic relationships in which the agent can save.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the observability of savings affect the design and performance of optimal relational employment contracts?
answer: When savings are hidden, relational contracts deteriorate over time with declining payments and effort, but when savings are publicly observable, contracts can be structured so that consumption starts high and savings fall over time while effort and payments increase, preventing relationship deterioration.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing work on relational employment agreements, which typically predicts low payments or termination for poor performance, by incorporating the role of employee savings and demonstrating how the observability of savings can limit or enhance the effectiveness of monetary incentives in motivating employees with diminishing marginal utility for consumption.

author: Francesca Molinari
title: Discrete Choice under Risk with Limited Consideration
abstract: <jats:p>This paper is concerned with learning decision-makers’ preferences using data on observed choices from a finite set of risky alternatives. We propose a discrete choice model with unobserved heterogeneity in consideration sets and in standard risk aversion. We obtain sufficient conditions for the model’s semi-nonparametric point identification, including in cases where consideration depends on preferences and on some of the exogenous variables. Our method yields an estimator that is easy to compute and is applicable in markets with large choice sets. We illustrate its properties using a dataset on property insurance purchases. (JEL D81, D83, D91, G22, G52)</jats:p>
research_question: How can we learn decision-makers' preferences from observed choices among risky alternatives when individuals have limited consideration sets and heterogeneous risk preferences?
answer: The paper develops a discrete choice model with unobserved heterogeneity in both consideration sets and risk aversion, provides sufficient conditions for semi-nonparametric point identification, and creates an easy-to-compute estimator that works with large choice sets.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing discrete choice literature by simultaneously incorporating unobserved heterogeneity in both consideration sets and risk preferences, addressing a gap where previous models typically consider these factors separately, and provides a tractable solution for markets with large choice sets.

author: Francesca Molinari
title: Asymptotic Properties for a Class of Partially Identified Models

author: Francesc Dilmé
title: Revenue Management without Commitment: Dynamic Pricing and Periodic Flash Sales
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A seller has a fixed number of goods to sell by a deadline. At each time, he posts a regular price and decides whether to hold a flash sale. Over time, buyers privately enter the market and strategically time their purchases. If a buyer does not purchase when she arrives, she can pay an attention cost to recheck the regular price afterwards, or she can wait for future flash sales where she may obtain a good at a discounted price. In the unique Markov perfect equilibrium, the seller sporadically holds flash sales to lower the stock of goods. A flash sale increases the willingness to pay of future buyers, but decreases the willingness to pay of buyers who arrive early in the game. When it is very likely that a buyer will obtain a good in a flash sale, the seller holds a “big” initial flash sale for all but one unit of the good.</jats:p>
research_question: How does a seller optimally use dynamic pricing and periodic flash sales to sell a fixed inventory by a deadline when buyers can strategically time their purchases and the seller cannot commit to future pricing strategies?
answer: In the unique Markov perfect equilibrium, the seller sporadically holds flash sales to manage inventory levels, with flash sales increasing future buyers' willingness to pay but decreasing early buyers' willingness to pay. When buyers have a high probability of obtaining goods during flash sales, the seller optimally conducts one large initial flash sale for nearly all inventory.
positioning_statement: This paper extends revenue management literature by analyzing dynamic pricing without commitment in a setting where buyers can strategically time purchases and pay attention costs to monitor prices, contributing to the intersection of dynamic pricing, strategic consumer behavior, and inventory management.

author: Francesca Molinari
title: Heterogeneous Choice Sets and Preferences
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a robust method of discrete choice analysis when agents' choice sets are unobserved. Our core model assumes nothing about agents' choice sets apart from their minimum size. Importantly, it leaves unrestricted the dependence, conditional on observables, between choice sets and preferences. We first characterize the sharp identification region of the model's parameters by a finite set of conditional moment inequalities. We then apply our theoretical findings to learn about households' risk preferences and choice sets from data on their deductible choices in auto collision insurance. We find that the data can be explained by expected utility theory with low levels of risk aversion and heterogeneous non‐singleton choice sets, and that more than three in four households require limited choice sets to explain their deductible choices. We also provide simulation evidence on the computational tractability of our method in applications with larger feasible sets or higher‐dimensional unobserved heterogeneity.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we analyze discrete choice behavior when agents' choice sets are unobserved and may vary heterogeneously across individuals?
answer: The data can be explained by expected utility theory with low levels of risk aversion and heterogeneous non-singleton choice sets, with more than three in four households requiring limited choice sets to explain their deductible choices in auto collision insurance.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a robust method that assumes nothing about agents' choice sets apart from their minimum size and leaves unrestricted the dependence between choice sets and preferences conditional on observables, addressing a gap in discrete choice analysis where choice sets are typically assumed to be known or follow restrictive patterns.

author: Francesca Molinari
title: The Nature of Risk Preferences: Evidence from Insurance Choices
abstract: <jats:p> We use data on insurance deductible choices to estimate a structural model of risky choice that incorporates “standard” risk aversion (diminishing marginal utility for wealth) and probability distortions. We find that probability distortions—characterized by substantial overweighting of small probabilities and only mild insensitivity to probability changes—play an important role in explaining the aversion to risk manifested in deductible choices. This finding is robust to allowing for observed and unobserved heterogeneity in preferences. We demonstrate that neither Kőszegi-Rabin loss aversion alone nor Gul disappointment aversion alone can explain our estimated probability distortions, signifying a key role for probability weighting. (JEL D14, D81, G22) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the nature of risk preferences, specifically the relative roles of standard risk aversion versus probability distortions in explaining risky choice behavior?
answer: Probability distortions—characterized by substantial overweighting of small probabilities and mild insensitivity to probability changes—play an important role in explaining risk aversion manifested in insurance deductible choices, beyond standard diminishing marginal utility for wealth.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on risk preferences by using structural estimation on insurance choices to demonstrate that probability weighting plays a key role that cannot be explained by existing alternative theories like Kőszegi-Rabin loss aversion or Gul disappointment aversion alone.

author: Francesca Molinari
title: Confidence Intervals for Projections of Partially Identified Parameters
abstract:
<jats:p>We propose a bootstrap‐based 
            <jats:italic>calibrated projection</jats:italic> procedure to build confidence intervals for single components and for smooth functions of a partially identified parameter vector in moment (in)equality models. The method controls asymptotic coverage uniformly over a large class of data generating processes. The extreme points of the calibrated projection confidence interval are obtained by extremizing the value of the function of interest subject to a proper relaxation of studentized sample analogs of the moment (in)equality conditions. The degree of relaxation, or critical level, is calibrated so that the function of 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic>, not 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic> itself, is uniformly asymptotically covered with prespecified probability. This calibration is based on repeatedly checking feasibility of linear programming problems, rendering it computationally attractive.
          </jats:p>
          <jats:p>Nonetheless, the program defining an extreme point of the confidence interval is generally nonlinear and potentially intricate. We provide an algorithm, based on the response surface method for global optimization, that approximates the solution rapidly and accurately, and we establish its rate of convergence. The algorithm is of independent interest for optimization problems with simple objectives and complicated constraints. An empirical application estimating an entry game illustrates the usefulness of the method. Monte Carlo simulations confirm the accuracy of the solution algorithm, the good statistical as well as computational performance of calibrated projection (including in comparison to other methods), and the algorithm's potential to greatly accelerate computation of other confidence intervals.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we construct confidence intervals for single components and smooth functions of partially identified parameter vectors in moment inequality models that control asymptotic coverage uniformly over a large class of data generating processes?
answer: The paper develops a bootstrap-based calibrated projection procedure that builds confidence intervals by extremizing the function of interest subject to relaxed studentized sample analogs of moment inequality conditions, with the critical level calibrated to ensure uniform asymptotic coverage, combined with a response surface method algorithm for efficient computation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on inference for partially identified parameters by proposing a computationally attractive method that uses linear programming for calibration and provides an optimization algorithm of independent interest, with demonstrated improvements in statistical and computational performance compared to other existing methods.

author: Francesca Molinari
title: Distinguishing Probability Weighting from Risk Misperceptions in Field Data
abstract: <jats:p> We outline a strategy for distinguishing rank-dependent probability weighting from systematic risk misperceptions in field data. Our strategy relies on singling out a field environment with two key properties: (i) the objects of choice are money lotteries with more than two outcomes; and (ii) the ranking of outcomes differs across lotteries. We first present an abstract model of risky choice that elucidates the identification problem and our strategy. The model has numerous applications, including insurance choices and gambling. We then consider the application of insurance deductible choices and illustrate our strategy using simulated data. </jats:p>
research_question: How can we distinguish between rank-dependent probability weighting and systematic risk misperceptions when analyzing field data on risky choices?
answer: The key finding is a strategy that relies on identifying field environments with two properties: (i) choices involve money lotteries with more than two outcomes, and (ii) the ranking of outcomes differs across lotteries. This strategy enables separation of probability weighting effects from risk misperceptions.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental identification problem in behavioral economics by providing a novel methodological approach to separate two competing explanations for deviations from expected utility theory - probability weighting versus risk misperceptions - which has been difficult to distinguish in existing field data analysis.

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: Escaping the Great Recession
abstract: <jats:p> We show that policy uncertainty about how the rising public debt will be stabilized accounts for the lack of deflation in the US economy at the zero lower bound. We first estimate a Markov-switching VAR to highlight that a zero-lower-bound regime captures most of the comovements during the Great Recession: a deep recession, no deflation, and large fiscal imbalances. We then show that a microfounded model that features policy uncertainty accounts for these stylized facts. Finally, we highlight that policy uncertainty arises at the zero lower bound because of a trade-off between mitigating the recession and preserving long-run macroeconomic stability. (JEL E31, E32, E52, E62, G01, H63) </jats:p>
research_question: Why was there a lack of deflation in the US economy during the Great Recession when interest rates were at the zero lower bound?
answer: Policy uncertainty about how rising public debt will be stabilized accounts for the absence of deflation during the zero lower bound period of the Great Recession.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a novel explanation for the stylized facts of the Great Recession (deep recession, no deflation, large fiscal imbalances) through a microfounded model that incorporates policy uncertainty, specifically highlighting the trade-off between recession mitigation and long-run macroeconomic stability at the zero lower bound.

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: Regime Switches, Agents' Beliefs, and Post-World War II U.S. Macroeconomic Dynamics

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: Evolving Monetary/Fiscal Policy Mix in the United States
abstract: <jats:p> A micro-founded model that allows for changes in the monetary/fiscal policy mix and in the volatility of structural shocks is fit to US post-WWII data. Agents are aware of the possibility of regime changes and their beliefs have an impact on the law of motion of the macroeconomy. The results show that the '60s and the '70s were characterized by a prolonged period of active fiscal policy and passive monetary policy. The appointment of Volcker marked a change in the conduct of monetary policy, but it took almost ten years for the fiscal authority to start accommodating this regime change. </jats:p>
research_question: How has the monetary/fiscal policy mix evolved in the United States during the post-WWII period, and how do regime changes in policy coordination affect macroeconomic dynamics?
answer: The 1960s and 1970s were characterized by active fiscal policy and passive monetary policy, with a regime change beginning when Volcker was appointed (marking a shift to active monetary policy), but fiscal policy took nearly ten years to accommodate this change by becoming more passive.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a micro-founded model that explicitly accounts for regime changes in the monetary/fiscal policy mix and incorporates agents' awareness of potential regime shifts, allowing for the analysis of how changing policy coordination affects macroeconomic outcomes over time.

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: Diagnostic Business Cycles
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A large psychology literature argues that, due to selective memory recall, decision-makers’ forecasts of the future are overly influenced by the perceived news. We adopt the diagnostic expectations (DE) paradigm [Bordalo et al. (2018), Journal of Finance, 73, 199–227] to capture this feature of belief formation, develop a method to incorporate DE in business cycle models, and study the implications for aggregate dynamics. First, we address (1) the theoretical challenges associated with modelling the feedback between optimal actions and agents’ DE beliefs and (2) the time-inconsistencies that arise under distant memory (i.e. when news is perceived with respect to a more distant past than just the immediate one). Second, we show that under distant memory the interaction between actions and DE beliefs naturally generates repeated boom–bust cycles in response to a single initial shock. We also propose a portable solution method to study DE in dynamic stochastic general equilibrium models and use it to estimate a quantitative DE New Keynesian model. Both endogenous states and distant memory play a critical role in successfully replicating the boom–bust cycle observed in response to a monetary policy shock.</jats:p>
research_question: How do diagnostic expectations (where decision-makers' forecasts are overly influenced by perceived news due to selective memory recall) affect aggregate business cycle dynamics?
answer: Under distant memory, the interaction between optimal actions and diagnostic expectations beliefs naturally generates repeated boom-bust cycles in response to a single initial shock, with both endogenous states and distant memory playing critical roles in replicating observed business cycle patterns.
positioning_statement: This paper adopts the diagnostic expectations paradigm from Bordalo et al. (2018) and extends it to business cycle models by developing new methods to incorporate DE in DSGE models, addressing theoretical challenges around feedback between actions and beliefs, and proposing portable solution methods for studying DE in dynamic macroeconomic models.

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: A Fiscal Theory of Persistent Inflation
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a new class of general-equilibrium models with partially unfunded debt to propose a fiscal theory of persistent inflation. In response to business cycle shocks, the monetary authority controls inflation and the fiscal authority stabilizes debt. However, the central bank accommodates unfunded fiscal shocks, causing persistent movements in inflation, output, and real interest rates. In an estimated quantitative model, fiscal inflation accounts for the bulk of inflation dynamics. In the aftermath of the pandemic, unfunded fiscal shocks sustain the recovery but also cause a persistent increase in inflation. The model is able to predict the inflationary effects of the American Rescue Plan Act fiscal stimulus out of sample and with real-time data.</jats:p>
research_question: How do unfunded fiscal shocks interact with monetary policy to generate persistent inflation dynamics in general equilibrium?
answer: Unfunded fiscal shocks cause persistent movements in inflation, output, and real interest rates when the central bank accommodates these shocks, with fiscal inflation accounting for the bulk of inflation dynamics in their estimated model.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new class of general-equilibrium models with partially unfunded debt to propose a fiscal theory of persistent inflation, distinguishing itself by showing how fiscal and monetary authorities interact differently in response to business cycle shocks versus unfunded fiscal shocks.

author: Francesco Decarolis
title: Medicare Part D: Are Insurers Gaming the Low Income Subsidy Design?
abstract: <jats:p> This paper shows how in Medicare Part D insurers' gaming of the subsidy paid to low-income enrollees distorts premiums and raises the program cost. Using plan-level data from the first five years of the program, I find multiple instances of pricing strategy distortions for the largest insurers. Instrumental variable estimates indicate that the changes in a concentration index measuring the manipulability of the subsidy can explain a large share of the premium growth observed between 2006 and 2011. Removing this distortion could reduce the cost of the program without worsening consumer welfare.(JEL G22, H51, I13, I18) </jats:p>
research_question: Are insurers in Medicare Part D gaming the low income subsidy design, and if so, how does this affect premiums and program costs?
answer: Yes, insurers are gaming the low income subsidy system, which distorts premiums and raises program costs. The manipulation of subsidy design can explain a large share of premium growth between 2006 and 2011, and removing this distortion could reduce program costs without harming consumer welfare.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies and quantifies a previously unexamined form of insurer strategic behavior in Medicare Part D, specifically focusing on how insurers manipulate the low income subsidy design to distort pricing strategies and increase program costs.

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: Uncertainty Shocks, Asset Supply and Pricing over the Business Cycle

author: Francesco Decarolis
title: From Mad Men to Maths Men: Concentration and Buyer Power in Online Advertising
abstract: <jats:p> This paper analyzes the impact of intermediary concentration on the allocation of revenue in online platforms. We study sponsored search documenting how advertisers increasingly bid through a handful of specialized intermediaries. This enhances automated bidding and data pooling, but lessens competition whenever the intermediary represents competing advertisers. Using data on nearly 40 million Google keyword auctions, we first apply machine learning algorithms to cluster keywords into thematic groups serving as relevant markets. Using an instrumental variable strategy, we estimate a decline in the platform’s revenue of approximately 11 percent due to the average rise in concentration associated with intermediary merger and acquisition activity. (JEL C45, D44, G34, L13, L81, M37) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of intermediary concentration on the allocation of revenue in online advertising platforms?
answer: The rise in intermediary concentration leads to approximately 11 percent decline in platform revenue due to reduced competition when intermediaries represent competing advertisers, despite benefits from automated bidding and data pooling.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by documenting and quantifying how the shift toward specialized intermediaries in online advertising affects market outcomes, using machine learning to define relevant markets and instrumental variables to establish causal effects of intermediary merger and acquisition activity on platform revenues.

author: Francesco Bianchi
title: Belief Distortions and Macroeconomic Fluctuations
abstract: <jats:p> This paper combines a data-rich environment with a machine learning algorithm to provide new estimates of time-varying systematic expectational errors (“belief distortions”) embedded in survey responses. We find sizable distortions even for professional forecasters, with all respondent-types overweighting the implicit judgmental component of their forecasts relative to what can be learned from publicly available information. Forecasts of inflation and GDP growth oscillate between optimism and pessimism by large margins, with belief distortions evolving dynamically in response to cyclical shocks. The results suggest that artificial intelligence algorithms can be productively deployed to correct errors in human judgment and improve predictive accuracy. (JEL C45, D83, E23, E27, E31, E32, E37) </jats:p>
research_question: How can machine learning algorithms be used to identify and measure time-varying systematic expectational errors (belief distortions) in economic forecasts, and what patterns do these distortions exhibit?
answer: The study finds sizable belief distortions even among professional forecasters, with all respondent types overweighting judgmental components relative to publicly available information. Forecasts of inflation and GDP growth oscillate between optimism and pessimism by large margins, with belief distortions evolving dynamically in response to cyclical shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by combining a data-rich environment with machine learning algorithms to provide new estimates of time-varying systematic expectational errors, suggesting that artificial intelligence can be productively deployed to correct human judgment errors and improve predictive accuracy in macroeconomic forecasting.

author: Francesco Decarolis
title: Subsidy Design in Privately Provided Social Insurance: Lessons from Medicare Part D
abstract: The efficiency of publicly subsidized, privately provisioned social insurance programs depends on the interaction between strategic insurers and the subsidy mechanism. We study this interaction in the context of Medicare’s prescription drug coverage program. We find that the observed mechanism is successful in keeping “raise-the-subsidy” incentives relatively low, acts much like a flat voucher, and obtains a level of welfare close to that for the optimal voucher. Across a range of counterfactuals, we find that more efficient subsidy mechanisms share three features: they retain the marginal elasticity of demand, limit the exercise of market power, and preserve the link between prices and marginal costs.

author: Francesco Decarolis
title: Rules, Discretion, and Corruption in Procurement: Evidence from Italian Government Contracting

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Insurgency and Small Wars: Estimation of Unobserved Coalition Structures
abstract: <jats:p>Insurgency and guerrilla warfare impose enormous socio‐economic costs and often persist for decades. The opacity of such forms of conflict is an obstacle to effective international humanitarian intervention and development programs. To shed light on the internal organization of otherwise unknown insurgent groups, this paper proposes two methodologies for the detection of unobserved coalitions of militants in conflict areas. These approaches are based on daily geocoded incident‐level data on insurgent attacks. We provide applications to the Afghan conflict during the 2004–2009 period and to Pakistan during the 2008–2011 period, identifying systematically different coalition structures. Applications to global terrorism data and identification of new groups or shifting coalitions are discussed.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we detect and identify unobserved coalition structures among insurgent groups in conflict areas?
answer: The paper proposes two methodologies based on daily geocoded incident-level data on insurgent attacks that can successfully identify systematically different coalition structures, as demonstrated through applications to Afghan conflict (2004-2009) and Pakistan (2008-2011).
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the opacity of insurgent conflicts that creates obstacles to effective international humanitarian intervention and development programs by providing novel methodological approaches to shed light on the internal organization of otherwise unknown insurgent groups.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: How Is Power Shared in Africa?

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Factions in Nondemocracies: Theory and Evidence From the Chinese Communist Party
abstract: <jats:p>This paper theoretically and empirically investigates factional arrangements within the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), the governing political party of the People's Republic of China. Using detailed biographical information of political elites in the Central Committee and provincial governments, we present a set of new empirical regularities within the CCP, including systematic patterns of cross‐factional balancing at different levels of the political hierarchy and substantial faction premia in promotions. We propose and estimate an organizational economic model to characterize factional politics within single‐party nondemocratic regimes and its economic implications.</jats:p>
research_question: How do factional arrangements operate within the Chinese Communist Party and what are their economic implications for single-party nondemocratic regimes?
answer: The study finds systematic patterns of cross-factional balancing at different levels of the CCP's political hierarchy and substantial faction premia in promotions, revealing organized factional politics with measurable economic effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing the first comprehensive theoretical and empirical investigation of factional arrangements within the Chinese Communist Party using detailed biographical data, and by developing an organizational economic model to characterize factional politics in single-party nondemocratic regimes.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: How Do Voters Respond to Information? Evidence from a Randomized Campaign
abstract: <jats:p> In a large-scale controlled trial in collaboration with the reelection campaign of an Italian incumbent mayor, we administered (randomized) messages about the candidate's valence or ideology. Informational treatments affected both actual votes in the precincts and individual vote declarations. Campaigning on valence brought more votes to the incumbent, but both messages affected voters' beliefs. Cross-learning occurred, as voters who received information about the incumbent also updated their beliefs on the opponent. With a novel protocol of beliefs elicitation and structural estimation, we assess the weights voters place upon politicians' valence and ideology, and simulate counterfactual campaigns. (JEL D12, D72, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How do voters respond to different types of campaign information, specifically messages about a candidate's valence (competence/quality) versus ideology?
answer: Informational treatments affected both actual votes and individual vote declarations, with valence-focused campaigning bringing more votes to the incumbent than ideology-focused messaging. Both types of messages affected voters' beliefs, and cross-learning occurred where voters receiving information about one candidate also updated their beliefs about the opponent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by conducting a large-scale controlled trial in collaboration with an actual political campaign, using a novel protocol of beliefs elicitation and structural estimation to assess the weights voters place on politicians' valence versus ideology, and simulating counterfactual campaigns.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Unbundling Polarization
abstract: <jats:p>This paper investigates the determinants of political polarization, a phenomenon of increasing relevance in Western democracies. How much of polarization is driven by divergence in the ideologies of politicians? How much is instead the result of changes in the capacity of parties to control their members? We use detailed internal information on party discipline in the context of the U.S. Congress—whip count data for 1977–1986—to identify and structurally estimate an economic model of legislative activity in which agenda selection, party discipline, and member votes are endogenous. The model delivers estimates of the ideological preferences of politicians, the extent of party control, and allows us to assess the effects of polarization through agenda setting (i.e., which alternatives to a status quo are strategically pursued). We find that parties account for approximately 40% of the political polarization in legislative voting over this time period, a critical inflection point in U.S. polarization. We also show that, absent party control, historically significant economic policies would have not passed or lost substantial support. Counterfactual exercises establish that party control is highly relevant for the probability of success of a given bill and that polarization in ideological preferences is more consequential for policy selection, resulting in different bills being pursued.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the determinants of political polarization, specifically how much is driven by divergence in politicians' ideologies versus changes in parties' capacity to control their members?
answer: Parties account for approximately 40% of political polarization in legislative voting during 1977-1986, with party control being highly relevant for bill success probability, while ideological preference polarization is more consequential for policy selection and determines which bills are pursued.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the polarization literature by using unique whip count data and a structural economic model to separately identify and quantify the roles of ideological divergence versus party discipline mechanisms in driving political polarization, addressing a gap in understanding the relative importance of these two factors.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Electoral Rules and Minority Representation in U.S. Cities<sup>*</sup>
abstract: This paper studies the choice of electoral rules and in particular the question of minority representation. Majorities tend to disenfranchise minorities through strategic manipulation of electoral rules. With the aim of explaining changes in electoral rules adopted by U.S. cities, particularly in the South, we show why majorities tend to adopt "winner-take-all" city-wide rules (at-large elections) in response to an increase in the size of the minority when the minority they are facing is relatively small. In this case, for the majority it is more effective to leverage on its sheer size instead of risking conceding representation to voters from minority-elected districts. However, as the minority becomes larger (closer to a fifty-fifty split), the possibility of losing the whole city induces the majority to prefer minority votes to be confined in minority-packed districts. Single-member district rules serve this purpose. We show empirical results consistent with these implications of the model in a novel data set covering U.S. cities and towns from 1930 to 2000.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: The Political Economy of the US Mortgage Default Crisis
abstract: <jats:p> We examine the effects of constituents, special interests, and ideology on congressional voting on two of the most significant pieces of legislation in US economic history. Representatives whose constituents experience a sharp increase in mortgage defaults are more likely to support the Foreclosure Prevention Act, especially in competitive districts. Interestingly, representatives are more sensitive to defaults of their own-party constituents. Special interests in the form of higher campaign contributions from the financial industry increase the likelihood of supporting the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act. However, ideologically conservative representatives are less responsive to both constituent and special interests. (JEL D72, G21, G28) </jats:p>
research_question: How do constituents, special interests, and ideology affect congressional voting on major mortgage crisis legislation?
answer: Representatives are more likely to support foreclosure prevention when their constituents experience higher mortgage defaults (especially own-party constituents in competitive districts), financial industry contributions increase support for bailout legislation, but ideologically conservative representatives are less responsive to both constituent needs and special interests.
positioning_statement: This paper examines congressional voting on two of the most significant pieces of legislation in US economic history, contributing to the political economy literature by analyzing how multiple factors (constituents, special interests, ideology) simultaneously influence legislative behavior during a major financial crisis.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Did US Politicians Expect the China Shock?
abstract: <jats:p> Information sets, expectations, and preferences of politicians are fundamental, but unobserved determinants of their policy choices. Employing repeated votes in the US House of Representatives on China’s normal trade relations (NTR) status during the two decades straddling China’s World Trade Organization (WTO) accession, we apply a moment inequality approach designed to deliver consistent estimates under weak informational assumptions on the information sets of members of Congress. This methodology offers a robust way to test hypotheses about what information politicians have at the time of their decision and to estimate the weight that constituents, ideology, and other factors have in policy making and voting. (JEL D72, D78, D83, D84, F14, P33) </jats:p>
research_question: What information did US politicians have about the economic impact of China's trade integration (the 'China Shock') when making policy decisions, and how did this information influence their voting behavior on China's normal trade relations status?
answer: The paper develops a methodology to estimate politicians' information sets and finds that the weight of constituents, ideology, and other factors in policy making can be robustly estimated even under weak assumptions about what information members of Congress possessed when voting on China's trade status.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by addressing a fundamental gap in understanding politicians' unobserved information sets, expectations, and preferences in policy making, offering a novel moment inequality approach that provides robust estimates under weaker informational assumptions than previous methods.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Is It Whom You Know or What You Know? An Empirical Assessment of the Lobbying Process
abstract: <jats:p> Do lobbyists provide issue-specific information to members of Congress? Or do they provide special interests access to politicians? We present evidence to assess the role of issue expertise versus connections in the US Federal lobbying process and illustrate how both are at work. In support of the connections view, we show that lobbyists follow politicians they were initially connected to when those politicians switch to new committee assignments. In support of the expertise view, we show that there is a group of experts that even politicians of opposite political affiliation listen to. However, we find a more consistent monetary premium for connections than expertise. (JEL D72, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: Do lobbyists provide issue-specific information to members of Congress, or do they provide special interests access to politicians through connections?
answer: Both connections and expertise play roles in the lobbying process, but connections provide a more consistent monetary premium than expertise. Lobbyists follow connected politicians to new committee assignments, and some expert lobbyists are consulted across party lines, demonstrating that both mechanisms are at work.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes empirical evidence to assess the relative importance of two competing theories in lobbying literature: the information/expertise view versus the access/connections view, showing that both mechanisms operate simultaneously rather than being mutually exclusive.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Tax-Exempt Lobbying: Corporate Philanthropy as a Tool for Political Influence
abstract: <jats:p> We explore the role of charitable giving as a means of political influence. For philanthropic foundations associated with large US corporations, we present three different identification strategies that consistently point to the use of corporate social responsibility in ways that parallel the strategic use of political action committee (PAC) spending. Our estimates imply that 6.3 percent of corporate charitable giving may be politically motivated, an amount 2.5 times larger than annual PAC contributions and 35 percent of federal lobbying. Absent of disclosure requirements, charitable giving may be a form of corporate political influence undetected by voters and subsidized by taxpayers. (JEL D22, D64, D72, L31) </jats:p>
research_question: Does corporate charitable giving serve as a tool for political influence, functioning similarly to political action committee (PAC) spending?
answer: Yes, corporate charitable giving is used strategically for political influence, with 6.3 percent of corporate charitable giving being politically motivated - an amount 2.5 times larger than annual PAC contributions and equivalent to 35 percent of federal lobbying expenditures.
positioning_statement: This paper explores a previously understudied form of corporate political influence by examining charitable giving as a parallel to the established literature on strategic PAC spending, revealing a significant channel of political influence that operates without disclosure requirements and receives taxpayer subsidies.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title:
Inconsistent Regulators: Evidence from Banking
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We find that regulators can implement identical rules inconsistently due to differences in their institutional design and incentives, and this behavior may adversely impact the effectiveness with which regulation is implemented. We study supervisory decisions of U.S. banking regulators and exploit a legally determined rotation policy that assigns federal and state supervisors to the same bank at exogenously set time intervals. Comparing federal and state regulator supervisory ratings within the same bank, we find that federal regulators are systematically tougher, downgrading supervisory ratings almost twice as frequently as do state supervisors. State regulators counteract these downgrades to some degree by upgrading more frequently. Under federal regulators, banks report worse asset quality, higher regulatory capital ratios, and lower return on assets. Leniency of state regulators relative to their federal counterparts is related to costly outcomes, such as higher failure rates and lower repayment rates of government assistance funds. The discrepancy in regulator behavior is related to different weights given by regulators to local economic conditions and, to some extent, differences in regulatory resources. We find no support for regulator self-interest, which includes “revolving doors” as a reason for leniency of state regulators.</jats:p>
research_question: Do regulators implement identical rules consistently, and what are the consequences of any inconsistencies in regulatory implementation?
answer: Regulators implement identical rules inconsistently due to differences in their institutional design and incentives, with federal regulators being systematically tougher than state regulators (downgrading supervisory ratings almost twice as frequently), and this inconsistency leads to adverse outcomes including higher bank failure rates and lower repayment rates of government assistance funds under more lenient state regulation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on regulatory effectiveness by providing novel evidence of systematic inconsistencies between different types of regulators operating under the same legal framework, exploiting a unique legally determined rotation policy to identify causal effects of regulator type on supervisory outcomes within the same banks.

author: Francesco Trebbi
title: Hall of Mirrors: Corporate Philanthropy and Strategic Advocacy
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Information is central to designing effective policy, and policy makers often rely on competing interests to separate useful from biased information. We show how this logic of virtuous competition can break down, using a new and comprehensive data set on U.S. federal regulatory rulemaking for 2003–2016. For-profit corporations and nonprofit entities are active in the rulemaking process and are arguably expected to provide independent viewpoints. Policy makers, however, may not be fully aware of the financial ties between some firms and nonprofits—grants that are legal and tax-exempt but hard to trace. We document three patterns that suggest that these grants may distort policy. First, we show that shortly after a firm donates to a nonprofit, the nonprofit is more likely to comment on rules on which the firm has also commented. Second, when a firm comments on a rule, the comments by nonprofits that recently received grants from the firm’s foundation are systematically closer in content to the firm’s own comments, relative to comments submitted by other nonprofits. Third, the final rule’s discussion by a regulator is more similar to the firm’s comments on that rule when the firm’s recent grantees also commented on it.</jats:p>
research_question: How do financial ties between for-profit corporations and nonprofit entities through corporate philanthropy affect the independence of viewpoints provided to policy makers in the U.S. federal regulatory rulemaking process?
answer: Corporate grants to nonprofits distort policy by reducing the independence of nonprofit comments in regulatory rulemaking - nonprofits that receive corporate grants are more likely to comment on the same rules as their donors, their comments are more similar in content to the donor firm's comments, and regulators' final rules more closely reflect the firm's position when the firm's grantees also comment.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the existing assumption that for-profit corporations and nonprofit entities provide independent viewpoints in policy making by revealing how corporate philanthropy creates hidden financial ties that undermine the 'virtuous competition' logic that policy makers rely on to separate useful from biased information.

title: Endogenous Political Institutions
