author: Frank Verboven
title: Subsidies and Time Discounting in New Technology Adoption: Evidence from Solar Photovoltaic Systems
abstract: <jats:p> We study a generous program to promote the adoption of solar photovoltaic (PV) systems through subsidies on future electricity production, rather than through upfront investment subsidies. We develop a tractable dynamic model of new technology adoption, also accounting for local market heterogeneity. We identify the discount factor from demand responses to variation that shifts expected future but not current utilities. Despite the massive adoption, we find that households significantly discounted the future benefits from the new technology. This implies that an upfront investment subsidy program would have promoted the technology at a much lower budgetary cost. (JEL C51, D15, Q48, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: How do households discount future benefits when adopting new technology (solar PV systems), and what are the implications for subsidy design comparing future production subsidies versus upfront investment subsidies?
answer: Households significantly discount future benefits from new technology adoption despite massive adoption under the subsidy program, which implies that upfront investment subsidies would have promoted solar PV technology at a much lower budgetary cost than subsidies on future electricity production.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on new technology adoption by developing a tractable dynamic model that accounts for local market heterogeneity and uses a novel identification strategy to estimate discount factors from demand responses to variation in expected future (but not current) utilities, providing empirical evidence on household time discounting in the context of renewable energy adoption.

author: Frederico Finan
title: Electoral Accountability and Corruption: Evidence from the Audits of Local Governments
abstract: <jats:p> We show that political institutions affect corruption levels. We use audit reports in Brazil to construct new measures of political corruption in local governments and test whether electoral accountability affects the corruption practices of incumbent politicians. We find significantly less corruption in municipalities where mayors can get reelected. Mayors with reelection incentives misappropriate 27 percent fewer resources than mayors without reelection incentives. These effects are more pronounced among municipalities with less access to information and where the likelihood of judicial punishment is lower. Overall our findings suggest that electoral rules that enhance political accountability play a crucial role in constraining politician's corrupt behavior. (JEL D72, K42, O17) </jats:p>
research_question: Does electoral accountability affect the corruption practices of incumbent politicians in local governments?
answer: Electoral accountability significantly reduces corruption - mayors who can get reelected misappropriate 27 percent fewer resources than mayors without reelection incentives, with effects being more pronounced in municipalities with less access to information and lower likelihood of judicial punishment.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on political institutions and corruption by providing new empirical evidence using audit reports from Brazilian local governments to construct novel measures of political corruption and test the relationship between electoral incentives and corrupt behavior.

author: Frank Verboven
title: Investment and Usage of New Technologies: Evidence from a Shared ATM Network
abstract: <jats:p> The success of new technologies depends on both the firms' investment and consumers' usage decisions. We study this problem in a shared ATM network. Inefficiencies may arise because banks coordinate investment, and consumers may not make proper use of the network. Based on an empirical model of ATM investment and demand, we find that banks substantially underinvested in ATMs, in contrast with earlier findings of strategic overinvestment in the United States. Furthermore, ATM usage was too low, because regulation prohibited fees for cash withdrawals. A direct promotion of investment improves welfare, but fees for branch cash withdrawals would be more effective. (JEL G21, G31, O33) </jats:p>
research_question: How do firms' investment decisions and consumers' usage decisions interact to determine the success of new technologies in a shared ATM network, and what inefficiencies arise from this interaction?
answer: Banks substantially underinvested in ATMs and consumers underused the network due to regulatory prohibition of cash withdrawal fees, with fees for branch cash withdrawals being more effective than direct investment promotion for improving welfare.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with earlier findings of strategic overinvestment in ATMs in the United States by demonstrating substantial underinvestment in a shared ATM network context, while also examining the dual problem of both investment and usage decisions in technology adoption.

title: The Evolution of Price Dispersion in the European Car Market

author: Frank Verboven
title: Market Entry, Fighting Brands, and Tacit Collusion: Evidence from the French Mobile Telecommunications Market
abstract: <jats:p>We study a major new entry in the French mobile telecommunications market, followed by the introduction of fighting brands by the three incumbents. Using an empirical oligopoly model, we find that the incumbents’ fighting brand strategies are difficult to rationalize as unilateral best responses. Instead, their strategies are consistent with a breakdown of tacit semi-collusion: before entry, the incumbents could successfully coordinate on restricting product variety to avoid cannibalization; after entry, this outcome became harder to sustain because of increased business stealing incentives. Consumers gained considerably from the added variety and, to a lesser extent, from the incumbents’ price responses. (JEL L13, L21, L96, M31)</jats:p>
research_question: How can the introduction of fighting brands by incumbent firms following new market entry be explained - as unilateral best responses or as evidence of breakdown in tacit collusion?
answer: The incumbents' fighting brand strategies are not rational unilateral best responses, but rather evidence of a breakdown of tacit semi-collusion that existed before entry, where incumbents previously coordinated on restricting product variety to avoid cannibalization but could no longer sustain this coordination due to increased business stealing incentives after entry.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical evidence that fighting brand strategies in oligopolistic markets can be better understood through the lens of tacit collusion breakdown rather than traditional unilateral competitive responses, using an empirical oligopoly model to analyze a major market entry event.

author: Frederico Finan
title: Combating Political Corruption with Policy Bundles

author: Frederico Finan
title: Do Government Audits Reduce Corruption? Estimating the Impacts of Exposing Corrupt Politicians
abstract: This paper examines the extent to which government audits of public resources can reduce corruption by enhancing political and judiciary accountability. We do so in the context of Brazil’s anticorruption program, which randomly audits municipalities for their use of federal funds. We find that being audited in the past reduces future corruption by 8 percent, while also increasing the likelihood of experiencing a subsequent legal action by 20 percent. We interpret these reduced-form findings through a political agency model, which we structurally estimate. Our results suggest that the reduction in corruption comes mostly from the audits increasing the perceived nonelectoral costs of engaging in corruption.

author: Frederico Finan
title: Brokering Votes With Information Spread Via Social Networks
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Politicians rely on political brokers to buy votes throughout much of the developing world. We investigate how social networks facilitate these vote-buying exchanges. Our conceptual framework suggests brokers should be particularly well-placed within the network to learn about non-copartisans’ reciprocity in order to target transfers effectively. As a result, parties should recruit brokers who are central among non-copartisans. We combine village network data from brokers and citizens with broker reports of vote buying, allowing us to use broker and citizen fixed effects. We show that networks diffuse information about citizens to brokers who leverage it to target transfers. In particular, among those citizens who are not registered to their party, brokers target reciprocal citizens about whom they can learn more through their network, and these citizens are more likely to support the brokers’ party. Moreover, recruited brokers are significantly more central than other citizens among non-copartisans, but not among copartisans. These results highlight the importance of information diffusion through social networks for vote buying, broker recruitment, and ultimately for political outcomes.</jats:p>
research_question: How do social networks facilitate vote-buying exchanges between politicians and brokers in developing countries?
answer: Social networks enable information diffusion about citizens' reciprocity to brokers, who leverage this information to effectively target vote-buying transfers. Parties strategically recruit brokers who are central among non-copartisans to maximize their ability to learn about and influence voters outside their party base.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on vote buying and political brokerage by providing the first empirical analysis that combines village network data from both brokers and citizens with broker reports of vote buying, using broker and citizen fixed effects to demonstrate the specific role of information diffusion through social networks in facilitating these political exchanges.

author: Frederico Finan
title: Strengthening State Capabilities: The Role of Financial Incentives in the Call to Public Service*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study a recent recruitment drive for public sector positions in Mexico. Different salaries were announced randomly across recruitment sites, and job offers were subsequently randomized. Screening relied on exams designed to measure applicants’ intellectual ability, personality, and motivation. This allows the first experimental estimates of (1) the role of financial incentives in attracting a larger and more qualified pool of applicants, (2) the elasticity of the labor supply facing the employer, and (3) the role of job attributes (distance, attractiveness of the municipal environment) in helping fill vacancies, as well as the role of wages in helping fill positions in less attractive municipalities. A theoretical model of job applications and acceptance guides the empirical inquiry. We find that higher wages attract more able applicants as measured by their IQ, personality, and proclivity toward public sector work—that is, we find no evidence of adverse selection effects on motivation; higher wage offers also increased acceptance rates, implying a labor supply elasticity of around 2 and some degree of monopsony power. Distance and worse municipal characteristics strongly decrease acceptance rates, but higher wages help bridge the recruitment gap in worse municipalities.</jats:p>
research_question: How do financial incentives affect the recruitment of qualified candidates for public sector positions, specifically examining their impact on applicant pool quality, labor supply elasticity, and the ability to fill vacancies in less attractive locations?
answer: Higher wages attract more able applicants (measured by IQ, personality, and motivation for public service) without adverse selection effects, increase job acceptance rates with a labor supply elasticity of around 2, and help overcome recruitment challenges in less attractive municipalities, though distance and poor municipal characteristics still strongly decrease acceptance rates.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first experimental estimates of financial incentives' role in public sector recruitment by using a randomized controlled trial design with random salary announcements and job offers, filling a gap in the literature that has lacked rigorous experimental evidence on these relationships.

author: Frederico Finan
title: Information Technology and Government Decentralization: Experimental Evidence From Paraguay
abstract: <jats:p>Standard models of hierarchy assume that agents and middle managers are better informed than principals. We estimate the value of the informational advantage held by supervisors—middle managers—when ministerial leadership—the principal—introduced a new monitoring technology aimed at improving the performance of agricultural extension agents (AEAs) in rural Paraguay. Our approach employs a novel experimental design that elicited treatment‐priority rankings from supervisors before randomization of treatment. We find that supervisors have valuable information—they prioritize AEAs who would be more responsive to the monitoring treatment. We develop a model of monitoring under different scales of treatment roll‐out and different treatment allocation rules. We semiparametrically estimate marginal treatment effects (MTEs) to demonstrate that the value of information and the benefits to decentralizing treatment decisions depend crucially on the sophistication of the principal and on the scale of roll‐out.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the value of the informational advantage held by supervisors (middle managers) when principals introduce new monitoring technology, and how do the benefits of decentralizing treatment decisions depend on the principal's sophistication and scale of roll-out?
answer: Supervisors have valuable information as they can identify which agents would be more responsive to monitoring treatment. The value of this information and the benefits of decentralizing treatment decisions depend crucially on the sophistication of the principal and the scale of treatment roll-out.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to standard models of hierarchy that assume agents and middle managers are better informed than principals by providing experimental evidence that quantifies the value of supervisors' informational advantage and develops a model showing how decentralization benefits vary with principal sophistication and implementation scale.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Bureaucrats or Politicians? Comment
abstract: <jats:p> Alesina and Tabellini (2007) investigate the normative criteria for allocating policy tasks to bureaucrats versus politicians. While they establish criteria with respect to a number of parameters, they do not give a criterion with respect to the degree of imperfect monitoring. We establish an unambiguous criterion about imperfect monitoring. (JEL D72, D73) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the criterion for allocating policy tasks to bureaucrats versus politicians with respect to the degree of imperfect monitoring?
answer: An unambiguous criterion about imperfect monitoring for the allocation of policy tasks between bureaucrats and politicians is established.
positioning_statement: This paper extends Alesina and Tabellini (2007) by filling a gap in their normative criteria framework - while they established criteria with respect to various parameters, they did not provide a criterion regarding the degree of imperfect monitoring, which this paper addresses.

author: Frederico Finan
title: Who Becomes A Politician?*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Can a democracy attract competent leaders, while attaining broad representation? Economic models suggest that free-riding incentives and lower opportunity costs give the less competent a comparative advantage at entering political life. Moreover, if elites have more human capital, selecting on competence may lead to uneven representation. This article examines patterns of political selection among the universe of municipal politicians and national legislators in Sweden, using extraordinarily rich data on competence traits and social background for the entire population. We document four new facts that together characterize an “inclusive meritocracy.” First, politicians are on average significantly smarter and better leaders than the population they represent. Second, this positive selection is present even when conditioning on family (and hence social) background, suggesting that individual competence is key for selection. Third, the representation of social background, whether measured by parental earnings or occupational social class, is remarkably even. Fourth, there is at best a weak trade-off in selection between competence and social representation, mainly due to strong positive selection of politicians of low (parental) socioeconomic status. A broad implication of these facts is that it is possible for democracy to generate competent and socially representative leadership.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a democracy attract competent leaders while attaining broad representation?
answer: Yes, democracy can generate both competent and socially representative leadership - politicians are significantly smarter and better leaders than average, yet representation across social backgrounds is remarkably even, with only a weak trade-off between competence and social representation.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing economic models that suggest free-riding incentives and lower opportunity costs give the less competent a comparative advantage in politics, and that selecting on competence leads to uneven representation, by providing empirical evidence of an 'inclusive meritocracy' using comprehensive data on Swedish politicians.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Matching and Price Competition: Comment

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Recent Developments in Matching with Constraints
abstract: <jats:p> In an earlier work (Kamada and Kojima 2015), we introduced “matching with constraints,” a two-sided matching problem in which the market is subject to feasibility constraints. That paper proposed and analyzed a possible solution to this problem and discussed various real-market applications of our results. The present paper reorganizes some of the findings from our more recent effort, based on Kamada and Kojima (2016a, b). </jats:p>
research_question: How can two-sided matching problems be solved when the market is subject to feasibility constraints?
answer: The paper presents reorganized findings from recent research that builds upon their earlier proposed solution to matching with constraints problems, though specific key findings are not detailed in the abstract.
positioning_statement: This paper builds directly on the authors' earlier work (Kamada and Kojima 2015) that introduced the concept of 'matching with constraints' and extends it by reorganizing findings from their more recent research efforts (Kamada and Kojima 2016a, b).

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Fair Matching under Constraints: Theory and Applications
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper studies a general model of matching with constraints. Observing that a stable matching typically does not exist, we focus on feasible, individually rational, and fair matchings. We characterize such matchings by fixed points of a certain function. Building on this result, we characterize the class of constraints on individual schools under which there exists a student-optimal fair matching, the matching that is the most preferred by every student among those satisfying the three desirable properties. We study the numerical relevance of our theory using data on government-organized daycare allocation.</jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions do fair matchings exist in matching markets with constraints, and when does a student-optimal fair matching exist?
answer: Fair matchings can be characterized by fixed points of a certain function, and there exists a student-optimal fair matching under a specific class of constraints on individual schools.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the problem that stable matchings typically do not exist in constrained matching markets by focusing on an alternative solution concept of feasible, individually rational, and fair matchings.

author: Frederico Finan
title: Economic and Social Outsiders but Political Insiders: Sweden’s Populist Radical Right
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats, a major populist radical-right party. Based on detailed administrative data, we present the first comprehensive account of which politicians are selected into such a party. Surveys show that politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats share strong anti-establishment and anti-immigration attitudes that drastically set them apart from Sweden’s other parties. Searching for individual traits that link naturally to these attitudes, we classify the universe of Swedish politicians and voters by social and economic marginalization and exposure to immigration. Politicians from the Sweden Democrats over-represent marginalized groups without strong attachments to the labour market or to traditional nuclear families, which instead are under-represented among politicians in all other parties. Among voters, the Sweden Democrats have higher electoral support in precincts with higher shares of the same marginalized groups. We see the mobilization of the marginalized as an important driver of the party’s success. Finally, we uncover that Sweden-Democrat politicians score lower on a number of valence traits than other-party politicians. In sum, the rise of the Sweden Democrats raised political representation for marginalized groups, but this came at a valence cost.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the characteristics of politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats (a populist radical-right party), and how do these characteristics relate to the party's political success?
answer: Sweden Democrats politicians over-represent economically and socially marginalized groups without strong labor market attachments or traditional family ties, while their voters concentrate in precincts with higher shares of these same marginalized groups. The party's success is driven by mobilizing marginalized populations, though this comes at a cost as Sweden Democrat politicians score lower on valence traits compared to other parties.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first comprehensive account of politician selection in a populist radical-right party using detailed administrative data, filling a gap in understanding the individual-level characteristics that link politicians and voters in such parties beyond their shared anti-establishment and anti-immigration attitudes.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Stability and Strategy-Proofness for Matching with Constraints: A Problem in the Japanese Medical Match and Its Solution
abstract: <jats:p> Real matching markets are subject to constraints. For example, the Japanese government introduced a new medical matching system in 2009 that imposes a “regional cap” in each of its 47 prefectures, which regulates the total number of medical residents who can be employed in each region. Based on Kamada and Kojima (2011), this paper studies matching markets with such constraints by examining in great detail the Japanese medical matching market. Specifically, we show that the new system introduced in 2009 has problems in terms of stability and strategy-proofness, and provide an alternative mechanism that does better. </jats:p>
research_question: How can matching markets with constraints (specifically regional caps in the Japanese medical matching system) be designed to achieve both stability and strategy-proofness?
answer: The Japanese medical matching system introduced in 2009 with regional caps has problems in terms of stability and strategy-proofness, but an alternative mechanism can be provided that performs better on these criteria.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Kamada and Kojima (2011) to study matching markets with constraints, using the Japanese medical matching market as a detailed case study to examine real-world implementation challenges and solutions.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Efficient Matching under Distributional Constraints: Theory and Applications
abstract: <jats:p> Many real matching markets are subject to distributional constraints. These constraints often take the form of restrictions on the numbers of agents on one side of the market matched to certain subsets on the other side. Real-life examples include restrictions on regions in medical matching, academic master's programs in graduate admission, and state-financed seats for college admission. Motivated by these markets, we study design of matching mechanisms under distributional constraints. We show that existing matching mechanisms suffer from inefficiency and instability, and propose a mechanism that is better in terms of efficiency, stability, and incentives while respecting the distributional constraints. (JEL C70, D61, D63) </jats:p>
research_question: How can matching mechanisms be designed to achieve efficiency, stability, and proper incentives while respecting distributional constraints that restrict the numbers of agents on one side of the market matched to certain subsets on the other side?
answer: The authors propose a new matching mechanism that is superior to existing mechanisms in terms of efficiency, stability, and incentives while respecting distributional constraints, addressing the inefficiency and instability problems found in current matching mechanisms.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies deficiencies in existing matching mechanisms under distributional constraints, showing that current mechanisms suffer from inefficiency and instability, and positions itself as providing a superior alternative mechanism that addresses these shortcomings.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Incentives and Stability in Large Two-Sided Matching Markets
abstract: <jats:p> A number of labor markets and student placement systems can be modeled as many-to-one matching markets. We analyze the scope for manipulation in many-to-one matching markets under the student-optimal stable mechanism when the number of participants is large. Under some regularity conditions, we show that the fraction of participants with incentives to misrepresent their preferences when others are truthful approaches zero as the market becomes large. With an additional condition, truthful reporting by every participant is an approximate equilibrium under the student-optimal stable mechanism in large markets. (JEL C78) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the scope for manipulation in many-to-one matching markets under the student-optimal stable mechanism when the number of participants is large?
answer: Under regularity conditions, the fraction of participants with incentives to misrepresent their preferences approaches zero as the market becomes large, and truthful reporting by every participant becomes an approximate equilibrium in large markets.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes manipulation incentives in large two-sided matching markets, specifically focusing on many-to-one matching markets (such as labor markets and student placement systems) and examining how market size affects strategic behavior under the student-optimal stable mechanism.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Job Matching with Subsidy and Taxation
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>In markets for indivisible resources such as workers and objects, subsidy and taxation for an agent may depend on the set of acquired resources and prices. This paper investigates how such transfer policies interfere with the substitutes condition, which is critical for market equilibrium existence and auction mechanism performance among other important issues. For environments where the condition holds in the absence of policy intervention, we investigate which transfer policies preserve the substitutes condition in various economically meaningful settings, establishing a series of characterisation theorems. For environments where the condition may fail without policy intervention, we examine how to use transfer policies to re-establish it, finding exactly when transfer policies based on scales are effective for that purpose. These results serve to inform policymakers, market designers, and market participants of how transfer policies may impact markets, so more informed decisions can be made.</jats:p>
research_question: How do subsidy and taxation transfer policies interfere with the substitutes condition in markets for indivisible resources, and which transfer policies preserve or re-establish this condition?
answer: The paper establishes characterization theorems showing which transfer policies preserve the substitutes condition in various economically meaningful settings, and finds that transfer policies based on scales can effectively re-establish the substitutes condition when it fails without policy intervention.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in understanding how transfer policies impact the substitutes condition in markets for indivisible resources, building on existing literature about market equilibrium existence and auction mechanism performance by specifically examining the interaction between policy interventions and this critical market condition.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Matching with Contracts: Comment
abstract: <jats:p> Hatfield and Milgrom (2005) present a unified model of matching with contracts phrased in terms of hospitals and doctors, which subsumes the standard two-sided matching and some package auction models. They show that a stable allocation exists if contracts are substitutes for each hospital. They further claim that if a hospital's preferences violate the substitutes condition, there exist singleton preferences for the other hospitals and doctors such that no stable allocation exists. We show this last claim does not hold in general. We further present a weaker condition that is necessary to guarantee the existence of stable allocations. (JEL C78, D86, J41) </jats:p>
research_question: Does the claim by Hatfield and Milgrom (2005) that violating the substitutes condition necessarily leads to non-existence of stable allocations hold in general?
answer: No, the claim by Hatfield and Milgrom (2005) does not hold in general - violating the substitutes condition does not necessarily imply that no stable allocation exists.
positioning_statement: This paper directly challenges a specific claim made by Hatfield and Milgrom (2005) in their unified model of matching with contracts, showing that their necessity result regarding the substitutes condition is incorrect, and contributes by identifying a weaker necessary condition for the existence of stable allocations.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Investment Incentives in Labor Market Matching
abstract: <jats:p> We provide an illustration of how the design of labor market clearing mechanisms can affect incentives for human capital acquisition. Specifically, we extend the labor market matching model (with discrete transfers) of Kelso and Crawford (1982) to incorporate the possibility that agents may invest in human capital before matching. We show that in this setting, the worker-optimal stable matching mechanism incentivizes workers to make (nearly) efficient human capital investments. En route to our main result, we show that so long as the space of salaries is sufficiently rich, every stable outcome in the Kelso and Crawford (1982) setting is approximately efficient. </jats:p>
research_question: How does the design of labor market clearing mechanisms affect incentives for human capital acquisition?
answer: The worker-optimal stable matching mechanism incentivizes workers to make nearly efficient human capital investments, and every stable outcome is approximately efficient when the space of salaries is sufficiently rich.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the labor market matching model of Kelso and Crawford (1982) by incorporating the possibility that agents may invest in human capital before matching, thereby analyzing investment incentives within the established matching framework.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Stable Matching in Large Economies
abstract: We study stability of two‐sided many‐to‐one matching in which firms' preferences for workers may exhibit complementarities. Although such preferences are known to jeopardize stability in a finite market, we show that a stable matching exists in a large market with a continuum of workers, provided that each firm's choice is convex and changes continuously as the set of available workers changes. We also study the existence and structure of stable matchings under preferences exhibiting substitutability and indifferences in a large market. Building on these results, we show that an approximately stable matching exists in large finite economies. We extend our framework to ensure a stable matching with desirable incentive and fairness properties in the presence of indifferences in firms' preferences.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Job Matching under Constraints
abstract: <jats:p> Studying job matching in a Kelso-Crawford framework, we consider arbitrary constraints imposed on sets of doctors that a hospital can hire. We characterize all constraints that preserve the substitutes condition (for all revenue functions that satisfy the substitutes condition), a critical condition on hospitals’ revenue functions for well-behaved competitive equilibria. A constraint preserves the substitutes condition if and only if it is a “generalized interval constraint,” which specifies the minimum and maximum numbers of hired doctors, forces some hires, and forbids others. Additionally, “generalized polyhedral constraints” are precisely those that preserve the substitutes condition for all “group separable” revenue functions. (JEL C78, D47, I11, J23, J41, J44) </jats:p>
research_question: What types of constraints on hospital hiring preserve the substitutes condition in job matching models?
answer: A constraint preserves the substitutes condition if and only if it is a 'generalized interval constraint' (specifying minimum/maximum numbers of hired doctors, forcing some hires, and forbidding others), while 'generalized polyhedral constraints' preserve the substitutes condition specifically for group separable revenue functions.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the Kelso-Crawford framework for job matching by introducing and analyzing arbitrary constraints on hospital hiring, characterizing which constraints maintain the critical substitutes condition necessary for well-behaved competitive equilibria.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Matching with Couples: Stability and Incentives in Large Markets*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Accommodating couples has been a long-standing issue in the design of centralized labor market clearinghouses for doctors and psychologists, because couples view pairs of jobs as complements. A stable matching may not exist when couples are present. This article’s main result is that a stable matching exists when there are relatively few couples and preference lists are sufficiently short relative to market size. We also discuss incentives in markets with couples. We relate these theoretical results to the job market for psychologists, in which stable matchings exist for all years of the data, despite the presence of couples.</jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions do stable matchings exist in centralized labor market clearinghouses when couples are present, given that couples view pairs of jobs as complements?
answer: A stable matching exists when there are relatively few couples and preference lists are sufficiently short relative to market size.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a long-standing issue in the design of centralized labor market clearinghouses for doctors and psychologists by providing theoretical conditions for stability when couples are present, and validates these findings with empirical evidence from the psychology job market where stable matchings exist despite couple participation.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: Designing Random Allocation Mechanisms: Theory and Applications
abstract: <jats:p> Randomization is commonplace in everyday resource allocation. We generalize the theory of randomized assignment to accommodate multi-unit allocations and various real-world constraints, such as group-specific quotas (“controlled choice”) in school choice and house allocation, and scheduling and curriculum constraints in course allocation. We develop new mechanisms that are ex ante efficient and fair in these environments, and that incorporate certain non-additive substitutable preferences. We also develop a “utility guarantee” technique that limits ex post unfairness in random allocations, supplementing the ex ante fairness promoted by randomization. This can be applied to multi-unit assignment problems and certain two-sided matching problems. (JEL C78, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: How can random allocation mechanisms be designed to handle multi-unit allocations and real-world constraints while achieving efficiency and fairness?
answer: The paper develops new mechanisms that achieve ex ante efficiency and fairness in constrained multi-unit allocation environments, and introduces a 'utility guarantee' technique that limits ex post unfairness to supplement the ex ante fairness provided by randomization.
positioning_statement: This paper generalizes the existing theory of randomized assignment beyond single-unit allocations to accommodate multi-unit allocations and various real-world constraints that have not been adequately addressed in prior literature, extending the theoretical framework to practical applications like school choice, house allocation, and course allocation.

author: Gabriel Carroll
title: Robustness and Linear Contracts
abstract: <jats:p> We consider a moral hazard problem where the principal is uncertain as to what the agent can and cannot do: she knows some actions available to the agent, but other, unknown actions may also exist. The principal demands robustness, evaluating possible contracts by their worst-case performance, over unknown actions the agent might potentially take. The model assumes risk-neutrality and limited liability, and no other functional form assumptions. Very generally, the optimal contract is linear. The model thus offers a new explanation for linear contracts in practice. It also introduces a flexible modeling approach for moral hazard under nonquantifiable uncertainty. (JEL D81, D82, D86) </jats:p>
research_question: Why are linear contracts optimal in moral hazard problems when the principal faces uncertainty about what actions are available to the agent?
answer: When the principal demands robustness by evaluating contracts based on their worst-case performance over unknown actions the agent might take, the optimal contract is linear, providing a new theoretical explanation for the prevalence of linear contracts in practice.
positioning_statement: This paper offers a new explanation for linear contracts in practice and introduces a flexible modeling approach for moral hazard under nonquantifiable uncertainty, distinguishing itself from existing literature by focusing on principal uncertainty about agent capabilities rather than traditional moral hazard assumptions.

author: Gabriel Carroll
title: Robustness and Separation in Multidimensional Screening
abstract: A principal wishes to screen an agent along several dimensions of private information simultaneously. The agent has quasilinear preferences that are additively separable across the various components. We consider a robust version of the principal's problem, in which she knows the marginal distribution of each component of the agent's type, but does not know the joint distribution. Any mechanism is evaluated by its worst‐case expected profit, over all joint distributions consistent with the known marginals. We show that the optimum for the principal is simply to screen along each component separately. This result does not require any assumptions (such as single crossing) on the structure of preferences within each component. The proof technique involves a generalization of the concept of virtual values to arbitrary screening problems. Sample applications include monopoly pricing and a stylized dynamic taxation model.

author: Fuhito Kojima
title: “Near” Weighted Utilitarian Characterizations of Pareto Optima
abstract: <jats:p>We give two characterizations of Pareto optimality via “near” weighted utilitarian welfare maximization. One characterization sequentially maximizes utilitarian welfare functions using a finite sequence of nonnegative and eventually positive welfare weights. The other maximizes a utilitarian welfare function with a certain class of positive hyperreal weights. The social welfare ordering represented by these “near” weighted utilitarian welfare criteria is characterized by the standard axioms for weighted utilitarianism under a suitable weakening of the continuity axiom.</jats:p>
research_question: How can Pareto optimality be characterized through weighted utilitarian welfare maximization approaches that avoid the limitations of standard weighted utilitarian methods?
answer: Pareto optimality can be characterized through two 'near' weighted utilitarian approaches: (1) sequential maximization using finite sequences of nonnegative and eventually positive welfare weights, and (2) maximization using positive hyperreal weights, both of which represent social welfare orderings that satisfy standard weighted utilitarian axioms under weakened continuity conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the existing weighted utilitarian literature by developing alternative characterizations that overcome limitations of standard approaches, specifically by weakening the continuity axiom while maintaining the core axioms of weighted utilitarianism to achieve Pareto optimal outcomes.

author: Gabriel Carroll
title: Robustly Optimal Auctions with Unknown Resale Opportunities
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The standard revenue-maximizing auction discriminates against a priori stronger bidders so as to reduce their information rents. We show that such discrimination is no longer optimal when the auction’s winner may resell to another bidder, and the auctioneer has non-Bayesian uncertainty about such resale opportunities. We identify a “worst-case” resale scenario, in which bidders’ values become publicly known after the auction and losing bidders compete Bertrand-style to buy the object from the winner. With this form of resale, misallocation no longer reduces the information rents of the high-value bidder, as he could still secure the same rents by buying the object in resale. Under regularity assumptions, we show that revenue is maximized by a version of the Vickrey auction with bidder-specific reserve prices, first proposed by Ausubel and Cramton (2004). The proof of optimality involves constructing Lagrange multipliers on a double continuum of binding non-local incentive constraints.</jats:p>
research_question: How should auction design change when the auctioneer faces non-Bayesian uncertainty about potential resale opportunities between bidders after the auction?
answer: When facing worst-case resale scenarios where bidders' values become public and losing bidders can compete to buy from the winner, the optimal auction design shifts from the standard discriminatory revenue-maximizing auction to a Vickrey auction with bidder-specific reserve prices, because traditional discrimination no longer effectively reduces high-value bidders' information rents.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard auction theory result that revenue-maximizing auctions should discriminate against stronger bidders by introducing non-Bayesian uncertainty about resale opportunities, building on Ausubel and Cramton (2004)'s proposed auction format and extending auction theory to account for post-auction resale markets.

author: Gabriel Carroll
title: A General Framework for Robust Contracting Models
abstract:
<jats:p>We study a class of models of moral hazard in which a principal contracts with a counterparty, which may have its own internal organizational structure. The principal has non‐Bayesian uncertainty as to what actions might be taken in response to the contract, and wishes to maximize her worst‐case payoff. We identify conditions on the counterparty's possible responses to any given contract that imply that a linear contract solves this maxmin problem. In conjunction with a 
            <jats:italic>Richness</jats:italic> property motivated by much previous literature, we identify a 
            <jats:italic>Responsiveness</jats:italic> property that is sufficient—and, in an appropriate sense, also necessary—to ensure that linear contracts are optimal. We illustrate by contrasting several possible models of contracting in hierarchies. The analysis demonstrates how one can distill key features of contracting models that allow their findings to be carried beyond the bilateral setting.
          </jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions are linear contracts optimal when a principal faces non-Bayesian uncertainty about a counterparty's actions in moral hazard problems?
answer: Linear contracts are optimal when the counterparty's possible responses satisfy a Responsiveness property (in conjunction with a Richness property), which is both sufficient and necessary for optimality in the principal's maxmin problem.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing bilateral contracting literature by developing a general framework that can handle counterparties with internal organizational structures, moving beyond traditional bilateral settings and identifying key properties that allow contracting model findings to be generalized.

author: Gabriel Carroll
title: Strategic Communication With Minimal Verification
abstract: <jats:p>A receiver wants to learn multidimensional information from a sender, and she has the capacity to verify just one dimension. The sender's payoff depends on the belief he induces, via an exogenously given monotone function. We show that by using a randomized verification strategy, the receiver can learn the sender's information fully in many cases. We characterize exactly when it is possible to do so. In particular, when the exogenous payoff function is submodular, we can explicitly describe a full‐learning mechanism; when it is (strictly) supermodular, full learning is not possible. In leading cases where full learning is possible, it can be attained using an indirect mechanism in which the sender chooses the probability of verifying each dimension.</jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions can a receiver learn multidimensional information from a sender when she can only verify one dimension, and how can this be achieved through strategic verification mechanisms?
answer: A receiver can achieve full learning of the sender's multidimensional information through randomized verification strategies when the sender's exogenous payoff function is submodular, but full learning is impossible when the payoff function is strictly supermodular. When full learning is possible, it can be implemented using an indirect mechanism where the sender chooses verification probabilities for each dimension.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the strategic communication literature by analyzing the novel problem of multidimensional information transmission with limited verification capacity, extending beyond traditional cheap talk models to examine how verification constraints affect information revelation in sender-receiver games.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title:
The Employment Effects of Credit Market Disruptions: Firm-level Evidence from the 2008–9 Financial Crisis
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article investigates the effect of bank lending frictions on employment outcomes. I construct a new data set that combines information on banking relationships and employment at 2,000 nonfinancial firms during the 2008–9 crisis. The article first verifies empirically the importance of banking relationships, which imply a cost to borrowers who switch lenders. I then use the dispersion in lender health following the Lehman crisis as a source of exogenous variation in the availability of credit to borrowers. I find that credit matters. Firms that had precrisis relationships with less healthy lenders had a lower likelihood of obtaining a loan following the Lehman bankruptcy, paid a higher interest rate if they did borrow, and reduced employment by more compared to precrisis clients of healthier lenders. Consistent with frictions deriving from asymmetric information, the effects vary by firm type. Lender health has an economically and statistically significant effect on employment at small and medium firms, but the data cannot reject the hypothesis of no effect at the largest or most transparent firms. Abstracting from general equilibrium effects, I find that the withdrawal of credit accounts for between one-third and one-half of the employment decline at small and medium firms in the sample in the year following the Lehman bankruptcy.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of bank lending frictions on employment outcomes during financial crises?
answer: Credit market disruptions significantly affect employment, with firms connected to less healthy lenders experiencing lower loan approval rates, higher interest rates, and greater employment reductions. The effects are concentrated among small and medium firms rather than large or transparent firms, with credit withdrawal accounting for one-third to one-half of employment decline at smaller firms following the Lehman bankruptcy.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by constructing a new dataset combining banking relationships and employment data for 2,000 nonfinancial firms, using the dispersion in lender health following the Lehman crisis as exogenous variation to identify causal effects of credit availability on employment, and demonstrating that these effects vary by firm type consistent with asymmetric information frictions.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: The Cyclicality of the Opportunity Cost of Employment

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: Secular Labor Reallocation and Business Cycles
abstract: We revisit an old question: does industry labor reallocation affect the business cycle? Our empirical methodology exploits variation in a local labor market’s exposure to industry reallocation on the basis of the area’s initial industry composition and national industry employment trends for identification. Applied to confidential employment data over 1980–2014, we find sharp evidence of reallocation contributing to higher local area unemployment if it occurs during a national recession but little difference in outcomes during an expansion. A multiarea, multisector search-and-matching model with imperfect mobility across industries and downward nominal wage rigidity can reproduce these cross-sectional patterns.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: The Macro Effects of Unemployment Benefit Extensions: a Measurement Error Approach*
abstract: By how much does an extension of unemployment benefits affect macroeconomic outcomes such as unemployment? Answering this question is challenging because U.S. law extends benefits for states experiencing high unemployment. We use data revisions to decompose the variation in the duration of benefits into the part coming from actual differences in economic conditions and the part coming from measurement error in the real-time data used to determine benefit extensions. Using only the variation coming from measurement error, we find that benefit extensions have a limited influence on state-level macroeconomic outcomes. We apply our estimates to the increase in the duration of benefits during the Great Recession and find that they increased the unemployment rate by at most 0.3 percentage point.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: The Macroeconomics of the Greek Depression
abstract: <jats:p> Greece experienced a boom until 2007, followed by a collapse of unprecedented magnitude and persistence. We assess the sources of the boom and the bust, using a rich estimated dynamic general equilibrium model. External demand and government consumption fueled the boom in production, whereas transfers fueled the boom in consumption. Different from the standard narrative, wages and prices declined substantially during the bust. Tax policy accounts for the largest fraction of the bust in production, whereas uninsurable risk accounts for the bust in consumption and wages. We assess how the composition of fiscal adjustment and bailouts affected the crisis. (JEL E21, E23, E24, E32, E62, F41, H20) </jats:p>
research_question: What were the sources of Greece's economic boom until 2007 and the subsequent collapse, and how did fiscal adjustment and bailouts affect the crisis?
answer: External demand and government consumption fueled the production boom while transfers fueled the consumption boom. During the bust, tax policy was the largest contributor to the production collapse, while uninsurable risk drove the decline in consumption and wages. Contrary to standard narratives, wages and prices declined substantially during the crisis.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard narrative about the Greek crisis by using a rich estimated dynamic general equilibrium model to show that wages and prices actually declined substantially during the bust, and provides a comprehensive assessment of how fiscal adjustment composition and bailouts affected the crisis.

author: Giovanni Gallipoli
title: Skill Dispersion and Trade Flows
abstract: <jats:p> Is skill dispersion a source of comparative advantage? In this paper we use microdata from the International Adult Literacy Survey to show that the effect of skill dispersion on trade flows is quantitatively similar to that of the aggregate endowment of human capital. In particular we investigate, and find support for, the hypothesis that countries with a more dispersed skill distribution specialize in industries characterized by lower complementarity of workers' skills. The result is robust to the introduction of controls for alternative sources of comparative advantage, as well as to alternative measures of industry-level skill complementarity. (JEL F14, F16, J24, J31) </jats:p>
research_question: Is skill dispersion a source of comparative advantage in international trade?
answer: Yes, skill dispersion has a quantitatively similar effect on trade flows as aggregate human capital endowment, with countries having more dispersed skill distributions specializing in industries with lower skill complementarity among workers.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces skill dispersion as a novel determinant of comparative advantage alongside traditional factors, using microdata from the International Adult Literacy Survey to empirically test this relationship while controlling for alternative sources of comparative advantage.

author: Gharad Bryan
title: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy among Ghana's Rural Poor Is Effective Regardless of Baseline Mental Distress
abstract: <jats:p> We study the impact of group-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT ) for individuals selected from the general population of poor households in rural Ghana (N = 7,227). Results from one to three months after the program show strong impacts on mental and perceived physical health, cognitive and socioemotional skills, and economic self-perceptions. These effects hold regardless of baseline mental distress. We argue that this is because CBT can improve well-being for a general population of poor individuals through two pathways: reducing vulnerability to deteriorating mental health and directly increasing cognitive capacity and socioemotional skills. (JEL D12, I12, I15, I31, I32, O12, O18) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of group-based cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) on individuals selected from the general population of poor households in rural Ghana, and does this impact vary by baseline mental distress levels?
answer: Group-based CBT has strong positive impacts on mental and perceived physical health, cognitive and socioemotional skills, and economic self-perceptions among Ghana's rural poor, and these effects are effective regardless of baseline mental distress levels.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that CBT can improve well-being for a general population of poor individuals (not just those with clinical mental health conditions) through two distinct pathways: reducing vulnerability to deteriorating mental health and directly increasing cognitive capacity and socioemotional skills.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: Stock Market Wealth and the Real Economy: A Local Labor Market Approach
abstract: <jats:p>We provide evidence of the stock market consumption wealth effect by using a local labor market analysis. An increase in local stock wealth driven by aggregate stock prices increases local employment and payroll in nontradable industries and in total, with no effect on employment in tradable industries. In a model of geographic heterogeneity in stock wealth, these responses imply an MPC of 3.2 cents per year and that a 20 percent increase in stock valuations, unless countered by monetary policy, increases the aggregate labor bill by at least 1.7 percent and aggregate hours by at least 0.7 percent two years after the shock. (JEL E21, E24, E52, G12, G51, R22, R23 )</jats:p>
research_question: What is the magnitude and mechanism of the stock market wealth effect on real economic activity, particularly employment and consumption?
answer: The stock market wealth effect operates through local consumption demand, with an MPC of 3.2 cents per year. A 20% increase in stock valuations increases the aggregate labor bill by at least 1.7% and aggregate hours by at least 0.7% two years after the shock, with effects concentrated in nontradable industries that serve local demand.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the wealth effect literature by using a novel local labor market approach to identify causal effects, exploiting geographic heterogeneity in stock wealth exposure to overcome identification challenges that have limited previous aggregate-level studies.

author: Garance Genicot
title: Tolerance and Compromise in Social Networks
abstract: Individuals typically differ in their identities—the behaviors they deem ideal for themselves and for the members of their network—and in their tolerance for behaviors that deviate from their ideals. This paper studies compromise—that is, departures from one’s ideal point, to be accepted by others. I show that an individual’s compromise in equilibrium is bounded by the difference between her tolerance level and the lowest tolerance level in society. Relatively intolerant individuals, who serve as “bridges,” are critical for reciprocated compromise. When individuals with extreme identities are systematically less tolerant, societies polarize. In contrast, intolerance among moderates encourages cohesion.

author: Garance Genicot
title: Group Formation in Risk-Sharing Arrangements

author: Garance Genicot
title: Aspirations and Inequality
abstract: This paper develops a theory of socially determined , and the interaction of those aspirations with growth and inequality. The interaction is bidirectional: economy‐wide outcomes determine individual aspirations, which in turn determine investment incentives and social outcomes. Thus aspirations, income, and the  of income evolve jointly. When capital stocks lie in some compact set, steady state distributions must exhibit inequality and are typically clustered around local poles. When sustained growth is possible, initial histories matter. Either there is convergence to an equal distribution (with growth) or there is perennial relative divergence across clusters, with within‐cluster convergence. A central feature that drives these results is that aspirations that are moderately above an individual's current standard of living tend to encourage investment, while still higher aspirations may lead to frustration.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: Cash and the Economy: Evidence from India’s Demonetization*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We analyze a unique episode in the history of monetary economics, the 2016 Indian “demonetization.” This policy made 86% of cash in circulation illegal tender overnight, with new notes gradually introduced over the next several months. We present a model of demonetization where agents hold cash both to satisfy a cash-in-advance constraint and for tax evasion purposes. We test the predictions of the model in the cross-section of Indian districts using several novel data sets including: the geographic distribution of demonetized and new notes for causal inference; night light activity and employment surveys to measure economic activity including in the informal sector; debit/credit cards and e-wallet transactions data; and banking data on deposit and credit growth. Districts experiencing more severe demonetization had relative reductions in economic activity, faster adoption of alternative payment technologies, and lower bank credit growth. The cross-sectional responses cumulate to a contraction in aggregate employment and night lights–based output due to the the cash shortage of at least 2 percentage points and of bank credit of 2 percentage points in 2016Q4 relative to their counterfactual paths, effects that dissipate over the next few months. Our analysis rejects monetary neutrality using a large-scale natural experiment, something that is still rare in the vast literature on the effects of monetary policy.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the economic effects of India's 2016 demonetization policy, which made 86% of cash in circulation illegal tender overnight?
answer: Demonetization caused significant economic contractions, with districts experiencing more severe cash shortages showing relative reductions in economic activity, faster adoption of alternative payment technologies, and lower bank credit growth. The aggregate effects included at least 2 percentage point contractions in employment, night lights-based output, and bank credit in 2016Q4, though these effects dissipated over subsequent months.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the monetary policy literature by providing rare large-scale natural experimental evidence that rejects monetary neutrality, analyzing a unique episode in monetary economics history using novel datasets and cross-sectional variation in demonetization severity across Indian districts.

author: Garance Genicot
title: Reciprocity in Groups and the Limits to Social Capital

author: Gharad Bryan
title: The Aggregate Productivity Effects of Internal Migration: Evidence from Indonesia
abstract: We estimate the aggregate productivity gains from reducing barriers to internal labor migration in Indonesia, accounting for worker selection and spatial differences in human capital. We distinguish between movement costs, which mean workers will move only if they expect higher wages, and amenity differences, which mean some locations must pay more to attract workers. We find modest but important aggregate impacts. We estimate a 22 percent increase in labor productivity from removing all barriers. Reducing migration costs to the US level, a high-mobility benchmark, leads to a 7.1 percent productivity boost. These figures hide substantial heterogeneity. The origin population that benefits most sees a 104 percent increase in average earnings from a complete barrier removal, or a 25 percent gain from moving to the US benchmark.

author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich
title: The 2000s Housing Cycle with 2020 Hindsight: A Neo-Kindlebergerian View
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>With “2020 hindsight,” the 2000s housing cycle is not a boom–bust but a boom–bust–rebound. Using a spatial equilibrium regression in which house prices are determined by income, amenities, urbanization, and supply, we show that long-run city-level fundamentals predict not only 1997–2019 price and rent growth but also the amplitude of the boom–bust–rebound. This evidence motivates our model of a cycle rooted in fundamentals. Households learn about fundamentals by observing “dividends” but become over-optimistic in the boom due to diagnostic expectations. A bust ensues when beliefs start to correct, exacerbated by a price–foreclosure spiral that drives prices below their long-run level. The rebound follows as prices converge to a path commensurate with higher fundamental growth. The estimated model explains the boom–bust–rebound with a single shock and accounts quantitatively for the dynamics of prices, rents, and foreclosures in cities with the largest cycles. We draw implications for asset cycles more generally.</jats:p>
research_question: How can the 2000s housing cycle, viewed as a boom-bust-rebound pattern rather than just boom-bust, be explained by fundamental economic factors and behavioral mechanisms?
answer: Long-run city-level fundamentals predict both 1997-2019 price and rent growth and the amplitude of the boom-bust-rebound cycle. The cycle can be explained by a single shock in a model where households learn about fundamentals through observing 'dividends' but become over-optimistic during the boom due to diagnostic expectations, leading to a bust when beliefs correct (exacerbated by price-foreclosure spirals), followed by a rebound as prices converge to fundamentals.
positioning_statement: This paper takes a 'Neo-Kindlebergerian view' and positions itself as providing a fundamentals-based explanation for the complete 2000s housing cycle (including the rebound phase that previous literature may have missed), using a behavioral model with diagnostic expectations to explain how markets can deviate from and return to fundamental values, with broader implications for understanding asset cycles generally.

author: Garance Genicot
title: Measuring Upward Mobility
abstract: <jats:p>We conceptualize and measure upward mobility over income or wealth. At the core of our exercise is the Growth Progressivity Axiom: transfers of instantaneous growth rates from relatively rich to poor individuals increases upward mobility. This axiom, along with mild auxiliary restrictions, identifies an “upward mobility kernel” with a single free parameter, in which mobility is linear in individual growth rates, with geometrically declining weights on baseline incomes. We extend this kernel to trajectories over intervals. The analysis delivers an upward mobility index that does not rely on panel data. That significantly expands our analytical scope to data-poor settings. (JEL D31, D63, I32, O15, O40)</jats:p>
research_question: How can upward mobility over income or wealth be conceptualized and measured, particularly in settings where panel data is not available?
answer: The paper develops an upward mobility index based on the Growth Progressivity Axiom that is linear in individual growth rates with geometrically declining weights on baseline incomes, and crucially does not require panel data, making it applicable to data-poor settings.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the existing literature by creating a measurement framework for upward mobility that significantly expands analytical scope to data-poor settings by not relying on panel data, unlike previous approaches.

author: Gharad Bryan
title: Big Loans to Small Businesses: Predicting Winners and Losers in an Entrepreneurial Lending Experiment
abstract: <jats:p> We experimentally study the impact of relatively large enterprise loans in Egypt. Larger loans generate small average impacts, but machine learning using psychometric data reveals “ top performers” (those with the highest predicted treatment effects) substantially increase profits, while profits drop for poor performers. The large differences imply that lender credit allocation decisions matter for aggregate income, yet we find existing practice leads to substantial misallocation. We argue that some entrepreneurs are overoptimistic and squander the opportunities presented by larger loans by taking on too much risk, and show the promise of allocations based on entrepreneurial type relative to firm characteristics. (JEL C45, D22, G21, G32, L25, L26, O16) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of relatively large enterprise loans on small businesses, and can machine learning predict which entrepreneurs will succeed or fail with larger loans?
answer: Larger loans generate small average impacts overall, but machine learning using psychometric data can identify 'top performers' who substantially increase profits with larger loans, while poor performers see profit drops. This reveals substantial misallocation in current lending practices, with some entrepreneurs being overoptimistic and squandering opportunities by taking excessive risks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the entrepreneurial lending literature by demonstrating that lender credit allocation decisions matter significantly for aggregate income, and argues for a shift from traditional firm characteristic-based lending to allocations based on entrepreneurial type using psychometric data and machine learning predictions.

author: Gharad Bryan
title: Randomizing Religion: the Impact of Protestant Evangelism on Economic Outcomes*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the causal impact of religiosity through a randomized evaluation of an evangelical Protestant Christian values and theology education program delivered to thousands of ultrapoor Filipino households. Six months after the program ended, treated households have higher religiosity and income; no statistically significant differences in total labor supply, consumption, food security, or life satisfaction; and lower perceived relative economic status. Exploratory analysis suggests that the income treatment effect may operate through increasing grit. Thirty months after the program ended, significant differences in the intensity of religiosity disappear, but those in the treatment group are less likely to be Catholic and more likely to be Protestant, and there is some mixed evidence that their consumption and perceived relative economic status are higher.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal impact of religiosity on economic outcomes?
answer: Protestant evangelical education increases religiosity and income in the short term (6 months), with income effects potentially operating through increased grit, while long-term effects (30 months) show religious conversion from Catholic to Protestant and mixed evidence of higher consumption and perceived economic status.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the causal impact of religiosity on economic outcomes through a randomized evaluation, contributing to the literature by providing experimental evidence rather than relying on observational studies that may suffer from endogeneity concerns.

author: Giovanni Gallipoli
title: Education Policy and Intergenerational Transfers in Equilibrium
abstract: We examine the equilibrium effects of college financial aid policies building an overlapping-generations life cycle model with education, labor supply, and saving decisions. Cognitive and noncognitive skills of children depend on parental education and skills and affect education and labor market outcomes. Education is funded by parental transfers that supplement grants, loans, and student labor supply. Crowding out of parental transfers by government programs is sizable and cannot be ignored. The current system of federal aid improves long-run welfare by 6 percent. More generous ability-tested grants would increase welfare and dominate both an expansion of student loans and a labor tax cut.
