author: Glenn Ellison
title: Evolving Standards for Academic Publishing: A q‐r Theory
abstract: This paper develops models of quality standards to examine two trends: academic journals increasingly require extensive revisions of submissions, and articles are becoming longer and changing in other ways. Papers are modeled as varying along two quality dimensions: q reflects the importance of the main ideas and r other aspects of quality. Observed trends are regarded as increases in r‐quality. A static equilibrium model illustrates comparative statics explanations. A dynamic model in which referees (with a biased view of their own work) learn social norms for weighting q and r is shown to produce a long, gradual evolution of social norms.

author: Glenn Ellison
title: What Causes Industry Agglomeration? Evidence from Coagglomeration Patterns
abstract: <jats:p> Why do firms cluster near one another? We test Marshall's theories of industrial agglomeration by examining which industries locate near one another, or coagglomerate. We construct pairwise coagglomeration indices for US manufacturing industries from the Economic Census. We then relate coagglomeration levels to the degree to which industry pairs share goods, labor, or ideas. To reduce reverse causality, where collocation drives input-output linkages or hiring patterns, we use data from UK industries and from US areas where the two industries are not collocated. All three of Marshall's theories of agglomeration are supported, with input-output linkages particularly important. (JEL L14, L60, O33, R23, R32) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do firms cluster near one another, and which of Marshall's theories of industrial agglomeration (sharing of goods, labor, or ideas) best explain coagglomeration patterns?
answer: All three of Marshall's theories of agglomeration are supported as explanations for why firms cluster together, with input-output linkages being particularly important in driving coagglomeration patterns.
positioning_statement: This paper tests Marshall's foundational theories of industrial agglomeration by examining coagglomeration patterns between industry pairs, using innovative methodological approaches to address reverse causality concerns that have limited previous empirical tests of these theories.

author: Glenn Ellison
title: Economic Research Evolves: Fields and Styles
abstract: <jats:p> We examine the evolution of economics research using a machine-learning-based classification of publications into fields and styles. The changing field distribution of publications would not seem to favor empirical papers. But economics' empirical shift is a within-field phenomenon; even fields that traditionally emphasize theory have gotten more empirical. Empirical work has also come to be more cited than theoretical work. The citation shift is sharpened when citations are weighted by journal importance. Regression analyses of citations per paper show empirical publications reaching citation parity with theoretical publications around 2000. Within fields and journals, however, empirical work is now cited more. </jats:p>
research_question: How has economics research evolved in terms of fields and styles, particularly regarding the shift between theoretical and empirical work?
answer: Economics has undergone a significant empirical shift that is primarily a within-field phenomenon rather than a between-field phenomenon - even traditionally theory-focused fields have become more empirical. Empirical work achieved citation parity with theoretical work around 2000 and now receives more citations than theoretical work, especially when weighted by journal importance.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a novel machine-learning-based classification approach to systematically analyze the evolution of economics research fields and styles, providing empirical evidence for the discipline's shift toward empirical work that goes beyond anecdotal observations to quantify changes in publication patterns and citation impacts over time.

author: Gregor Matvos
title: Searching for Approval
abstract: <jats:p>This paper theoretically and empirically studies the interaction of search and application approval in credit markets. Risky borrowers internalize the probability that their application is rejected and behave as if they had high search costs. Thus, “overpayment” may be a poor proxy for consumer sophistication since it partly represents rational search in response to rejections. Contrary to standard search models, our model implies (1) endogenous adverse selection through the search and application approval process, (2) a possibly non‐monotone or non‐decreasing relationship between search and realized interest, default, and application approval rates, and (3) search costs estimated from transaction prices alone are biased. We find support for the model's predictions using a unique data set detailing search behavior of mortgage borrowers. Estimating the model, we find that screening is informative and search is costly. Counterfactual analyses reveal that tightening lending standards and discrimination through application rejection both increase equilibrium interest rates. This increase in realized interest rates is in part due to strategic complementarity in bank rate setting.</jats:p>
research_question: How do search behavior and application approval processes interact in credit markets, and what are the implications for borrower behavior and market outcomes?
answer: Risky borrowers who anticipate rejection behave as if they have high search costs, leading to endogenous adverse selection through the search process. This creates non-standard relationships between search intensity and market outcomes (interest rates, default rates, approval rates), and means that 'overpayment' may reflect rational search behavior rather than consumer naivety.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges standard search models in credit markets by incorporating application approval processes, showing that contrary to existing models, the interaction creates endogenous adverse selection and non-monotone relationships between search and outcomes, while demonstrating that search costs estimated from prices alone are biased.

author: Glenn Ellison
title: The Econometric Society Annual Reports Report of the Editors 2002-2003

author: Gregor Matvos
title: Deposit Competition and Financial Fragility: Evidence from the US Banking Sector
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a structural empirical model of the US banking sector. Insured depositors and run-prone uninsured depositors choose between differentiated banks. Banks compete for deposits and endogenously default. The estimated demand for uninsured deposits declines with banks' financial distress, which is not the case for insured deposits. We calibrate the supply side of the model. The calibrated model possesses multiple equilibria with bank-run features, suggesting that banks can be very fragile. We use our model to analyze proposed bank regulations. For example, our results suggest that a capital requirement below 18 percent can lead to significant instability in the banking system. (JEL E44, G01, G21, G28, G32) </jats:p>
research_question: How does deposit competition affect financial fragility in the US banking sector, particularly regarding the differential behavior of insured versus uninsured depositors and the resulting implications for bank stability?
answer: The key finding is that uninsured depositors are sensitive to banks' financial distress and withdraw deposits when banks are in trouble (while insured depositors are not), creating multiple equilibria with bank-run features that make banks very fragile. The model suggests that capital requirements below 18 percent can lead to significant banking system instability.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a structural empirical model that explicitly incorporates both insured and uninsured depositor behavior in a competitive banking environment, allowing for endogenous bank defaults and multiple equilibria, which enables analysis of how deposit competition mechanisms create financial fragility and evaluation of proposed banking regulations.

author: Gregor Matvos
title: Is an Automaker's Road to Bankruptcy Paved with Customers' Beliefs?
abstract: <jats:p> We explore the role the feedback loop between firms' financial health and consumers' demand for their products plays in the auto market. We construct a simple model of an automaker making pricing and debt service (continuation) decisions while recognizing that consumers are sensitive to whether it stays in business. We show that multiple equilibria can exist in such a model, and calibrate it to match stylized facts surrounding GM's recent bankruptcy. The results suggest that while the impact of financial distress on demand substantially reduced GM's profit, bank-run-like multiple equilibria do not appear likely in this market. </jats:p>
research_question: What role does the feedback loop between firms' financial health and consumers' demand for their products play in the auto market, particularly regarding whether customer beliefs about a firm's survival can create bank-run-like scenarios leading to bankruptcy?
answer: While financial distress significantly reduces automaker profits through decreased consumer demand, bank-run-like multiple equilibria scenarios where customer beliefs alone drive firms to bankruptcy do not appear likely in the auto market, as demonstrated through analysis of GM's bankruptcy case.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a theoretical model that incorporates the feedback mechanism between firm financial health and consumer demand in the automotive industry, extending beyond traditional financial distress models to examine how consumer behavior regarding firm survival prospects affects market outcomes and equilibrium conditions.

author: Glenn Ellison
title: The Efficiency of Race-Neutral Alternatives to Race-Based Affirmative Action: Evidence from Chicago’s Exam Schools
abstract: <jats:p> Several K-12 and university systems have adopted race-neutral affirmative action in place of race-based alternatives. This paper explores whether these plans are effective substitutes for racial quotas in Chicago Public Schools (CPS), which now employs a race-neutral, place-based affirmative action system at its selective exam high schools. The CPS plan is ineffective compared to plans that explicitly consider race: about three-quarters of the reduction in average entrance scores at the top schools could have been avoided with the same level of racial diversity. Moreover, the CPS plan is less effective at adding low-income students than was the previous system of racial quotas. We develop a theoretical framework that motivates quantifying the inefficiency of race-neutral policies based on the distortion in student preparedness they create for a given level of diversity and use it to evaluate several alternatives. The CPS plan can be improved in several ways, but no race-neutral policy restores minority representation to prior levels without substantially greater distortions, implying significant efficiency costs from prohibitions on the explicit use of race. (JEL H75, I21, I28, J15) </jats:p>
research_question: Are race-neutral affirmative action plans effective substitutes for race-based alternatives in achieving diversity goals at selective schools?
answer: Race-neutral affirmative action plans are ineffective substitutes for race-based policies - they create significant efficiency costs and distortions in student preparedness while failing to restore minority representation to prior levels or effectively add low-income students.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on affirmative action policy alternatives by providing empirical evidence from Chicago Public Schools and developing a theoretical framework to quantify the inefficiency of race-neutral policies, specifically measuring the distortion in student preparedness they create for a given level of diversity.

title: Monetary Tightening, Commercial Real Estate Distress, and US Bank Fragility
