title: Beyond the Balance Sheet Model of Banking: Implications for Bank Regulation and Monetary Policy

author: Glenn Ellison
title: Do Schools Matter for High Math Achievement? Evidence from the American Mathematics Competitions
abstract: <jats:p>This paper uses data from the American Mathematics Competitions to examine the rates at which different high schools produce high-achieving math students. There are large differences in the frequency with which students from seemingly similar schools reach high achievement levels. The distribution of unexplained school effects includes a thick tail of schools that produce many more high-achieving students than is typical. Several additional analyses suggest that the differences are not primarily due to unobserved differences in student characteristics. The differences are persistent across time, suggesting that differences in the effectiveness of educational programs are not primarily due to direct peer effects. (JEL H75, I21, I24, I28, R23)</jats:p>
research_question: Do schools matter for high math achievement, specifically examining whether different high schools vary in their rates of producing high-achieving math students?
answer: Yes, schools do matter for high math achievement. There are large differences in the frequency with which students from seemingly similar schools reach high achievement levels, with some schools producing many more high-achieving students than typical. These differences are persistent across time and are not primarily due to unobserved student characteristics or direct peer effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on school effectiveness by using data from the American Mathematics Competitions to examine high math achievement specifically, providing evidence that school differences in producing high-achieving students are not primarily explained by student characteristics or peer effects, but rather by differences in educational program effectiveness.

author: Gregor Matvos
title: Arbitration with Uninformed Consumers
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>This article studies the impact of the arbitrator selection process on consumer outcomes. Using data from consumer arbitration cases in the securities industry over the past two decades, where we observe detailed information on case characteristics, the randomly generated list of potential arbitrators presented to both parties, the selected arbitrator, and case outcomes, we establish several motivating facts. These facts suggest that firms hold an informational advantage over consumers in selecting arbitrators, resulting in industry-friendly arbitration outcomes. We then develop and calibrate a quantitative model of arbitrator selection in which firms hold an informational advantage in selecting arbitrators. Arbitrators, who are compensated only if chosen, compete with each other to be selected. The model allows us to decompose the firms’ advantage into two components: the advantage of choosing pro-industry arbitrators from a given pool and the equilibrium pro-industry tilt in the arbitration pool that arises because of arbitrator competition. Selecting arbitrators without the input of firms and consumers would increase consumer awards by $60,000 on average relative to the current system. Forty percent of this effect arises because the pool of arbitrators skews pro-industry due to competition. Even an informed consumer cannot avoid this pro-industry equilibrium effect. Counterfactuals suggest that redesigning the arbitrator selection mechanism for the benefit of consumers hinges on whether consumers are informed. Policies intended to benefit consumers, such as increasing arbitrator compensation or giving parties more choice, would benefit informed consumers but hurt the uninformed.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the arbitrator selection process impact consumer outcomes in arbitration, particularly when firms have informational advantages over consumers?
answer: Firms' informational advantage in selecting arbitrators results in industry-friendly outcomes that reduce consumer awards by $60,000 on average compared to random selection, with 40% of this disadvantage arising from arbitrators competing to be selected by tilting pro-industry, and 60% from firms directly choosing favorable arbitrators from the available pool.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the arbitration literature by providing the first quantitative decomposition of how informational asymmetries between firms and consumers affect arbitrator selection and outcomes, using unique detailed data on the complete arbitration process including randomly generated arbitrator lists, selections, and outcomes to develop a novel theoretical model of arbitrator competition.

author: Gregory Duffee
title: Fair Accumulation under Risky Lifetime
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Individuals save for their old days, but not all of them enjoy the old age. This paper characterizes the optimal capital accumulation in a two‐period OLG model where lifetime is risky and varies across individuals. We compare two long‐run social optima: (1) the average utilitarian optimum, where steady‐state average welfare is maximized; (2) the egalitarian optimum, where the welfare of the worst‐off at the steady‐state is maximized. It is shown that, under plausible conditions, the egalitarian optimum involves a higher capital and a lower fertility than the utilitarian optimum. Those inequalities hold also in a second‐best framework where survival conditions are exogenously linked to the capital level.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal capital accumulation in a two-period overlapping generations model where lifetime is risky and varies across individuals, and how do different social welfare criteria (utilitarian vs. egalitarian) affect these optimal accumulation paths?
answer: Under plausible conditions, the egalitarian optimum (maximizing welfare of the worst-off) involves higher capital accumulation and lower fertility compared to the average utilitarian optimum (maximizing average welfare). These results hold both in first-best conditions and in second-best frameworks where survival conditions are linked to capital levels.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the standard overlapping generations model by incorporating risky and heterogeneous lifetimes, and contributes to the literature by comparing two distinct social welfare criteria (utilitarian versus egalitarian) in determining optimal capital accumulation and fertility decisions under mortality risk.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: A Minimalist Model for the Ruble during the Russian Invasion of Ukraine
abstract: <jats:p> This note isolates an overlooked economic force for the ruble to appreciate in response to international sanctions limiting exports to Russia. The intuition is that when Russians are unable to buy the mix of foreign goods they wish, foreign goods become less attractive, increasing demand for domestic goods. To reestablish an equilibrium, a real appreciation is needed to raise the relative price of domestic goods and incentivize imports from nonsanctioning countries. We also review well-known forces for depreciation. Our analysis emphasizes that the exchange rate is an inadequate signal of the welfare impact and of the effectiveness of sanctions. (JEL D74, E31, F14, F31, F51, P24, P33) </jats:p>
research_question: What economic forces explain the ruble's appreciation in response to international sanctions during the Russian invasion of Ukraine?
answer: When sanctions limit Russians' ability to buy their desired mix of foreign goods, foreign goods become less attractive, increasing demand for domestic goods. This requires a real appreciation to raise the relative price of domestic goods and incentivize imports from non-sanctioning countries.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies an overlooked economic force for ruble appreciation that has been missed in existing literature, while also acknowledging well-known depreciation forces, and emphasizes that exchange rates are inadequate signals of welfare impact and sanctions effectiveness.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: Optimal Monetary Policy with Uncertain Fundamentals and Dispersed Information*

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: Inefficient Credit Booms

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: A Theory of Demand Shocks
abstract: <jats:p> This paper presents a model of business cycles driven by shocks to consumer expectations regarding aggregate productivity. Agents are hit by heterogeneous productivity shocks, they observe their own productivity and a noisy public signal regarding aggregate productivity. The public signal gives rise to “noise shocks,” which have the features of aggregate demand shocks: they increase output, employment, and inflation in the short run and have no effects in the long run. Numerical examples suggest that the model can generate sizable amounts of noise-driven volatility. (JEL D83, D84, E21, E23, E32) </jats:p>
research_question: How can shocks to consumer expectations regarding aggregate productivity drive business cycles and generate aggregate demand-like effects?
answer: The model shows that noisy public signals about aggregate productivity create 'noise shocks' that have the characteristics of aggregate demand shocks - they increase output, employment, and inflation in the short run but have no long-run effects, and can generate substantial noise-driven economic volatility.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to business cycle theory by providing a new mechanism for generating aggregate demand shocks through expectation-driven noise in productivity signals, offering an alternative explanation for short-run economic fluctuations that differs from traditional demand shock models.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: Risk-Sharing Externalities
abstract: Financial crises typically occur because firms and financial institutions are highly exposed to aggregate shocks. We propose a theory to explain these exposures. We study a model where entrepreneurs can issue state-contingent claims to consumers. Even though entrepreneurs can use these instruments to hedge negative shocks, they do not necessarily do so because insuring against these shocks is expensive, as consumers are also harmed by them. This effect is self-reinforcing because riskier balance sheets for entrepreneurs imply higher income volatility for the consumers, making insurance more costly in equilibrium. We show that this feedback is quantitatively important and leads to inefficiently high risk exposure for entrepreneurs.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: Credit Crises, Precautionary Savings, and the Liquidity Trap*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the effects of a credit crunch on consumer spending in a heterogeneous-agent incomplete-market model. After an unexpected permanent tightening in consumers’ borrowing capacity, constrained consumers are forced to repay their debt, and unconstrained consumers increase their precautionary savings. This depresses interest rates, especially in the short run, and generates an output drop, even with flexible prices. The output drop is larger with sticky prices, if the zero lower bound prevents the interest rate from adjusting downward. Adding durable goods to the model, households take larger debt positions and the output response can be larger.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of a credit crunch on consumer spending in an economy with heterogeneous agents and incomplete markets?
answer: A credit crunch forces constrained consumers to repay debt while unconstrained consumers increase precautionary savings, which depresses interest rates and generates output drops even with flexible prices. The output drop is amplified with sticky prices when the zero lower bound prevents interest rate adjustment, and the effects are magnified when durable goods are included in the model.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using a heterogeneous-agent incomplete-market model to analyze credit crunches, demonstrating that output drops can occur even with flexible prices, and showing how the zero lower bound and durable goods amplify these effects.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: Wall Street and Silicon Valley: A Delicate Interaction
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Entrepreneurs and venture capitalists are concerned about investors’ beliefs in asset markets because these beliefs shape the value of a potential IPO and the possibility to expand. Investors’ beliefs, on the other hand, can be influenced by start-up activity insofar as the latter contains valuable information about eventual profitability. This two-way feedback is shown to generate excessive, non-fundamental, waves in start-up activity, IPOs, and asset prices. Policies that “lean against the wind” can improve welfare, without requiring an informational advantage by the government.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the two-way feedback between entrepreneurs/venture capitalists and asset market investors' beliefs affect start-up activity, IPOs, and asset prices?
answer: The two-way feedback between Wall Street and Silicon Valley generates excessive, non-fundamental waves in start-up activity, IPOs, and asset prices, and policies that 'lean against the wind' can improve welfare without requiring government informational advantages.
positioning_statement: This paper examines the previously understudied bidirectional relationship between entrepreneurial activity and asset market beliefs, showing how information flows between start-up activity and investor beliefs create market inefficiencies that can be addressed through policy intervention.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: Financial Crises, Dollarization, and Lending of Last Resort in Open Economies
abstract: <jats:p> Foreign currency debt is considered a source of financial instability in emerging markets. We propose a theory in which liability dollarization arises from an insurance motive of domestic savers. Since financial crises are associated to depreciations, savers ask for a risk premium when saving in local currency. This force makes domestic currency debt expensive, and incentivizes borrowers to issue foreign currency debt. Providing ex post support to borrowers can alleviate the effect of the crisis on savers’ income, lowering their demand for insurance, and, surprisingly, it can reduce ex ante incentives to borrow in foreign currency. (JEL E21, E42, E44, F34, G01) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do emerging market economies engage in liability dollarization (borrowing in foreign currency) and how does lending of last resort policy affect this behavior?
answer: Liability dollarization arises from an insurance motive of domestic savers who demand risk premiums for local currency savings due to expected depreciations during financial crises, making foreign currency debt cheaper for borrowers. Ex post lending of last resort support can reduce ex ante incentives to borrow in foreign currency by alleviating crisis effects on savers' income and lowering their demand for insurance.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new theoretical explanation for liability dollarization that focuses on the insurance motive of domestic savers, contrasting with existing literature that typically views foreign currency debt primarily as a source of financial instability in emerging markets.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: A Theory of Capital Controls as Dynamic Terms-of-Trade Manipulation

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: News, Noise, and Fluctuations: An Empirical Exploration
abstract: <jats:p> We explore empirically models of aggregate fluctuations in which consumers form anticipations about the future based on noisy sources of information and these anticipations affect output in the short run. Our objective is to separate fluctuations due to changes in fundamentals (news) from those due to temporary errors in agents' estimates (noise). We show that structural VARs cannot be used to identify news and noise shocks, but identification is possible via a method of moments or maximum likelihood. Next, we estimate our model on US data. Our results suggest that noise shocks explain a sizable fraction of short-run consumption fluctuations. (JEL D84, E13, E21, E32) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we empirically separate aggregate economic fluctuations caused by changes in fundamentals (news) from those caused by temporary errors in agents' estimates due to noisy information (noise)?
answer: Noise shocks explain a sizable fraction of short-run consumption fluctuations, and while structural VARs cannot identify news and noise shocks, identification is possible through method of moments or maximum likelihood estimation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on aggregate fluctuations by providing an empirical framework to distinguish between fundamental-driven fluctuations and those caused by information processing errors, addressing a key identification challenge that existing structural VAR methods cannot solve.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: House Prices and Consumer Spending

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: Slow Moving Debt Crises
abstract: <jats:p> We study slow moving debt crises: self-fulfilling equilibria in which high interest rates, due to the fear of a future default, lead to a gradual but faster accumulation of debt, ultimately validating investors’ fear. We show that slow moving crises arise in a variety of settings, both when fiscal policy follows a given rule and when it is chosen by an optimizing government. A key assumption, in all these settings, is that the borrowing government cannot commit to issue a fixed amount of bonds in a given period. We discuss how multiplicity is avoided for low debt levels, for sufficiently responsive fiscal policy rules, and for long enough debt maturities. When the equilibrium is unique, debt dynamics are characterized by a tipping point, below which debt falls and stabilizes and above which debt and default rates grow. (JEL E43, E62, H50, H63) </jats:p>
research_question: How do slow moving debt crises arise as self-fulfilling equilibria where high interest rates due to default fears lead to gradual debt accumulation that ultimately validates investors' concerns?
answer: Slow moving debt crises can occur in various settings when governments cannot commit to fixed bond issuance amounts, leading to self-fulfilling equilibria where fear-driven high interest rates cause faster debt accumulation that validates the initial fears. However, multiplicity can be avoided through low initial debt levels, sufficiently responsive fiscal policies, or longer debt maturities, with unique equilibria characterized by a tipping point below which debt stabilizes and above which debt and default rates grow.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the debt crisis literature by identifying and analyzing a specific type of crisis mechanism - slow moving crises - that differs from traditional sudden-stop or immediate default scenarios, focusing on the gradual nature of debt accumulation driven by self-fulfilling expectations in environments where governments lack commitment power over bond issuance.

author: Guido Lorenzoni
title: Macroeconomic Implications of COVID-19: Can Negative Supply Shocks Cause Demand Shortages?
abstract: <jats:p> Motivated by the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, we present a theory of Keynesian supply shocks: shocks that reduce potential output in a sector of the economy, but that, by reducing demand in other sectors, ultimately push aggregate activity below potential. A Keynesian supply shock is more likely when the elasticity of substitution between sectors is relatively low, the intertemporal elasticity of substitution is relatively high, and markets are incomplete. Fiscal policy can display a smaller multiplier, but the insurance benefit of fiscal transfers can be enhanced. Firm exits and job destruction can amplify and propagate the shock. (JEL D52, E23, E24, E32, E62, I12, I18) </jats:p>
research_question: Can negative supply shocks cause demand shortages, and what are the macroeconomic implications of such shocks as observed during the COVID-19 pandemic?
answer: Yes, negative supply shocks can cause demand shortages through what the authors term 'Keynesian supply shocks' - shocks that reduce potential output in one sector but ultimately push aggregate activity below potential by reducing demand in other sectors. This is more likely when substitution between sectors is low, intertemporal substitution is high, and markets are incomplete.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new theoretical framework of 'Keynesian supply shocks' motivated by COVID-19 effects, extending traditional macroeconomic theory by showing how supply shocks can generate demand-side effects that push aggregate activity below potential, with implications for fiscal policy effectiveness and the role of firm exits and job destruction in amplifying shocks.

author: Guo Xu
title: The Costs of Employment Segregation: Evidence from the Federal Government Under Woodrow Wilson
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We link newly digitized personnel records of the U.S. government for 1907–1921 to census data to study the segregation of the civil service by race under President Woodrow Wilson. Using a difference-in-differences design around Wilson’s inauguration, we find that the introduction of employment segregation increased the black-white earnings gap by 3.4–6.9 percentage points. This increasing gap is driven by a reallocation of existing black civil servants to lower-paid positions, lowering their returns to education. Importantly, the negative effects extend beyond Wilson’s presidency. Using census data for 1900–1940, we show that segregation caused a relative decline in the home ownership rate of black civil servants. Moreover, by comparing children of black and white civil servants in adulthood, we provide suggestive evidence that descendants of black civil servants who were exposed to Wilson’s presidency exhibit lower levels of education, earnings, and social mobility. Our combined results thus document significant short- and long-run costs borne by minorities during a unique episode of state-sanctioned discrimination.</jats:p>
research_question: What were the economic costs of employment segregation in the U.S. federal civil service under President Woodrow Wilson?
answer: Employment segregation increased the black-white earnings gap by 3.4-6.9 percentage points through reallocation of black civil servants to lower-paid positions, reduced their returns to education, caused relative decline in home ownership rates, and had negative intergenerational effects on descendants' education, earnings, and social mobility.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on state-sanctioned discrimination by providing quantitative evidence of both short- and long-run economic costs of employment segregation using newly digitized personnel records and a difference-in-differences design around a unique historical episode of federal government segregation.

author: Guo Xu
title: Who gives aid to whom and when? Aid accelerations, shocks and policies

author: Guo Xu
title: The Costs of Patronage: Evidence from the British Empire
abstract: <jats:p> I combine newly digitized personnel and public finance data from the British colonial administration for the period 1854–1966 to study how patronage affects the promotion and incentives of governors. Governors are more likely to be promoted to higher salaried colonies when connected to their superior during the period of patronage. Once allocated, they provide more tax exemptions, raise less revenue, and invest less. The promotion and performance gaps disappear after the abolition of patronage appointments. Patronage therefore distorts the allocation of public sector positions and reduces the incentives of favored bureaucrats to perform. (JEL D73, F54, H83, J45, M51, N43, N44) </jats:p>
research_question: How does patronage affect the promotion and incentives of governors in the British colonial administration?
answer: Patronage distorts the allocation of public sector positions by making connected governors more likely to be promoted to higher salaried colonies, and reduces the incentives of favored bureaucrats to perform by leading them to provide more tax exemptions, raise less revenue, and invest less. These effects disappear after the abolition of patronage appointments.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on patronage and public sector performance by providing novel empirical evidence using newly digitized personnel and public finance data from the British Empire (1854-1966), examining both the allocation effects and performance consequences of patronage systems in a historical colonial administrative context.

author: Guo Xu
title: Strengthening State Capacity: Civil Service Reform and Public Sector Performance during the Gilded Age
abstract: <jats:p> We use newly digitized records from the post office to study the effects of strengthened state capacity between 1875 and 1901. Exploiting the implementation of the Pendleton Act—a landmark statute that shielded bureaucrats from political interference—across US cities over two waves, we find that civil service reform reduced postal delivery errors and increased productivity. These improvements were most pronounced during election years when the reform dampened bureaucratic turnover. We provide suggestive evidence that reformed cities witnessed declining local partisan newspapers. Separating politics from administration, therefore, not only improved state effectiveness but also weakened the role of local politics. (JEL D24, D73, H83, J45, L82, L87, N41) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of strengthened state capacity through civil service reform on public sector performance, specifically examining how the Pendleton Act's protection of bureaucrats from political interference affected postal service efficiency?
answer: Civil service reform reduced postal delivery errors and increased productivity, with the most pronounced improvements occurring during election years when the reform dampened bureaucratic turnover. Additionally, reformed cities experienced declining local partisan newspapers, indicating that separating politics from administration improved state effectiveness while weakening local political influence.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on state capacity and civil service reform by providing empirical evidence from newly digitized historical records of the post office during the Gilded Age (1875-1901), using the implementation of the Pendleton Act as a natural experiment to measure the causal effects of reducing political interference in bureaucratic operations.

author: Hanming Fang
title: Social Culture and Economic Performance
abstract: <jats:p> The connection between obtaining higher paying jobs and undertaking some seemingly irrelevant activity is interpreted as “social culture.” In the context of a society trying to adopt a new technology, I show that by allowing the firms to give preferential treatment to workers based on some “cultural activity,” the society can partially overcome an informational free-riding problem. Therefore, social culture may affect the economic performance by altering the effective production technology of the economy. (JEL P17, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does social culture affect economic performance in the context of technology adoption?
answer: Social culture can improve economic performance by allowing firms to give preferential treatment to workers based on cultural activities, which helps overcome informational free-riding problems and alters the effective production technology of the economy.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel interpretation of social culture as a mechanism connecting seemingly irrelevant activities to higher-paying jobs, offering a new perspective on how cultural factors can address informational problems in technology adoption contexts.

author: Hanming Fang
title: Detecting Potential Overbilling in Medicare Reimbursement via Hours Worked
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a novel and easy-to-implement approach to detect potential overbilling based on the hours worked implied by the service codes which physicians submit to Medicare. Using the Medicare Part B Fee-for-Service (FFS) Physician Utilization and Payment Data in 2012 and 2013 released by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, we construct estimates for physicians' hours spent on Medicare beneficiaries. We find that about 2,300 physicians, representing about 3 percent of those with 20 or more hours of Medicare Part B FFS services, have billed Medicare over 100 hours per week. We consider these implausibly long hours. (JEL H51, I13, I18, J22) </jats:p>
research_question: How can potential overbilling in Medicare reimbursement be detected using physicians' implied hours worked based on submitted service codes?
answer: About 2,300 physicians (approximately 3% of those with 20+ hours of Medicare Part B FFS services) billed Medicare for over 100 hours per week in 2012-2013, representing implausibly long hours that suggest potential overbilling.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a novel and easy-to-implement approach to detect potential Medicare overbilling by analyzing implied hours worked from service codes, offering a new methodology not previously used in the literature for fraud detection in healthcare reimbursement.

author: Hanming Fang
title: Dynamic Inefficiencies in an Employment-Based Health Insurance System: Theory and Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> We investigate the effects of the institutional settings of the US health care system on individuals' life-cycle medical expenditures. Health is a form of general human capital; labor turnover and labor-market frictions prevent an employer-employee pair from capturing the entire surplus from investment in an employee's health. Thus, the pair underinvests in health during working years, thereby increasing medical expenditures during retirement. We provide empirical evidence consistent with the comparative statics predictions of our model using the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS) and the Health and Retirement Study (HRS). Our estimates suggest significant inefficiencies in health investment in the United States. (JEL D14, D91, G22, I11, J32) </jats:p>
research_question: How do the institutional settings of the US employment-based health insurance system affect individuals' life-cycle medical expenditures and health investment decisions?
answer: The employment-based health insurance system creates dynamic inefficiencies where employer-employee pairs underinvest in health during working years due to labor turnover and market frictions preventing them from capturing the full surplus from health investments, leading to increased medical expenditures during retirement.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by theoretically modeling health as a form of general human capital and demonstrating how labor market frictions in the US employment-based health insurance system create investment inefficiencies, providing both theoretical framework and empirical evidence for these dynamic effects across the life cycle.

author: Hanming Fang
title: Equilibrium Labor Market Search and Health Insurance Reform
abstract: We present and empirically implement an equilibrium labor market search model where risk-averse workers facing medical expenditure shocks are matched with firms making health insurance coverage decisions. We use our estimated model to evaluate the equilibrium impact of many health care reform proposals, including the 2010 Affordable Care Act (ACA). We use the estimates of the early impact of the ACA as a model validation. We find that income-based subsidies for health insurance premiums are crucial for the sustainability of the ACA, while the ACA can still substantially reduce the uninsured rate without the individual or the employer mandate.

author: Hanming Fang
title: “Golden Ages”: A Tale of the Labor Markets in China and the United States
abstract: The peak age of the earnings profile in China declined from 55 in the 1990s to 35 in the 2010s, while in the United States it remained steady at around 50. Motivated by this and other facts, we propose and empirically implement a decomposition framework to infer from repeated cross-sectional earnings data the experience, cohort, and time effects. We find that China experienced a considerably larger intercohort human capital growth and increase in human capital rental price, but lower life-cycle human capital accumulation, compared to the United States. We use the inferred components to revisit several applications in macroeconomics and labor economics.

author: Hanming Fang
title: Observational Learning: Evidence from a Randomized Natural Field Experiment
abstract: <jats:p> We report results from a randomized natural field experiment conducted in a restaurant dining setting to distinguish the observational learning effect from the saliency effect. We find that, when customers are given ranking information of the five most popular dishes, the demand for those dishes increases by 13 to 20 percent. We do not find a significant saliency effect. We also find modest evidence that the observational learning effects are stronger among infrequent customers, and that dining satisfaction is increased when customers are presented with the information of the top five dishes, but not when presented with only names of some sample dishes. (JEL C93, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How can observational learning effects be distinguished from saliency effects in consumer decision-making?
answer: Observational learning has a significant positive effect on demand - providing ranking information of the five most popular dishes increases demand for those dishes by 13-20 percent, while saliency effects are not significant. The observational learning effects are stronger among infrequent customers and increase dining satisfaction.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using a randomized natural field experiment in a restaurant setting to empirically separate observational learning effects from saliency effects, addressing a key identification challenge in the observational learning literature.

author: Hanming Fang
title: “Dysfunctional Identities” Can Be Rational

author: Hanming Fang
title: Detecting Potential Overbilling in Medicare Reimbursement via Hours Worked: Reply
abstract: <jats:p> Matsumoto (2020) pointed out data and coding errors in Fang and Gong (2017). We show that these errors have limited impacts: all qualitative findings remain after correcting them. Matsumoto also discussed potential service overcounting in the aggregated utilization data we used to illustrate our method, and then quantified the extent of overcounting with a sample of Medicare claims. We acknowledge the issue but discuss the noise and the bias in his quantification. Overall, our proposed method remains useful, as regulators who are interested in applying the method are unlikely to be subject to the data limitations. (JEL H51, I13, I18, J22, J44) </jats:p>
research_question: How to address criticisms and data concerns regarding a method for detecting potential overbilling in Medicare reimbursement via hours worked analysis?
answer: The data and coding errors identified by Matsumoto (2020) have limited impacts on the original findings - all qualitative results remain valid after corrections, and despite acknowledged issues with service overcounting in aggregated data, the proposed method remains useful for regulators.
positioning_statement: This paper responds to Matsumoto (2020)'s critique of Fang and Gong (2017) by acknowledging some valid concerns about data limitations while defending the robustness of their original method and findings, arguing that regulators would not face the same data constraints that limit academic researchers.

author: Hanming Fang
title: Sources of Advantageous Selection: Evidence from the Medigap                     Insurance Market

author: Hanming Fang
title: German Long-Term Health Insurance: Theory Meets Evidence
abstract: To insure policyholders against contemporaneous health expenditure shocks and future reclassiﬁcation risk, long-term health insurance constitutes an alternative to community-rated short-term contracts with an individual mandate. We study the German long-term health insurance (GLTHI) from a life-cycle perspective. We ﬁrst present and discuss insurer regulation, premium setting, and the main market principles of the GLTHI. We then empirically estimate the ingredients of a life-cycle model to assess the welfare effects of the GLTHI. We ﬁnd that the GLTHI achieves a high level of welfare against several benchmarks. Finally, we discuss the implications for the health care reform debate in the U.S.

author: Hanming Fang
title: Testing the Mechanisms of Structural Models: The Case of the Mickey Mantle Effect

author: Holger Mueller
title: Wage Inequality and Firm Growth
abstract: <jats:p> We discuss firm-level evidence based on UK data showing that within-firm pay inequality--wage differentials between top- and bottom-level jobs--increases with firm size. Moreover, within-firm pay inequality rises as firms grow larger over time. Lastly, using wage data from 15 developed countries, we document a positive association between aggregate wage inequality at the country level and growth by the largest firms in the country. We conclude that part of what may be perceived as a global trend toward more wage inequality may be driven by an increase in the size of the largest firms in the economy. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between firm growth/size and wage inequality, both within firms and at the aggregate country level?
answer: Within-firm pay inequality increases with firm size and rises as firms grow over time, and there is a positive association between aggregate wage inequality at the country level and growth by the largest firms in the country.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a firm-level explanation for what may be perceived as a global trend toward more wage inequality, arguing that it may be driven by an increase in the size of the largest firms in the economy rather than other commonly cited factors.

author: Holger Mueller
title: Firm Leverage, Consumer Demand, and Employment Losses During the Great Recession*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article argues that firms’ balance sheets were instrumental in the transmission of consumer demand shocks during the Great Recession. Using micro-level data from the U.S. Census Bureau, we find that establishments of more highly levered firms experienced significantly larger employment losses in response to declines in local consumer demand. These results are not driven by firms being less productive, having expanded too much prior to the Great Recession, or being generally more sensitive to fluctuations in either aggregate employment or house prices. Likewise, at the county level, we find that counties with more highly levered firms experienced significantly larger declines in employment in response to local consumer demand shocks. Accordingly, firms’ balance sheets also matter for aggregate employment. Our results suggest a possible role for employment policies that target firms directly besides conventional stimulus.</jats:p>
research_question: How did firms' balance sheets (specifically leverage) affect the transmission of consumer demand shocks to employment losses during the Great Recession?
answer: Establishments of more highly levered firms experienced significantly larger employment losses in response to declines in local consumer demand during the Great Recession, and this effect holds at both the firm and county levels, indicating that firms' balance sheets were instrumental in amplifying the impact of consumer demand shocks on employment.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that firm leverage played a crucial role in transmitting consumer demand shocks to employment during the Great Recession, going beyond existing explanations based on firm productivity, pre-recession expansion patterns, or general sensitivity to aggregate fluctuations, and suggests that employment policies should consider targeting firms directly rather than relying solely on conventional stimulus measures.

author: Holger Mueller
title: Firms’ Internal Networks and Local Economic Shocks
abstract: <jats:p> Using confidential establishment-level data from the US Census Bureau’s Longitudinal Business Database, this paper documents how local shocks propagate across US regions through firms’ internal networks of establishments. Consistent with a model of optimal within-firm resource allocation, we find that establishment-level employment is sensitive to shocks in distant regions in which the establishment’s parent firm is operating, and that the elasticity with respect to such shocks increases with the firm’s financial constraint. At the aggregate regional level, we find that aggregate county-level employment is sensitive to shocks in distant counties linked through firms’ internal networks. (JEL D22, G32, L14, L22, R23, R32) </jats:p>
research_question: How do local economic shocks propagate across US regions through firms' internal networks of establishments?
answer: Local shocks propagate through firms' internal networks, with establishment-level employment being sensitive to shocks in distant regions where the parent firm operates, and this sensitivity increases with the firm's financial constraints. At the aggregate level, county employment is affected by shocks in distant counties linked through firms' internal networks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using confidential establishment-level data from the US Census Bureau's Longitudinal Business Database to empirically document shock propagation through firms' internal networks, providing evidence consistent with models of optimal within-firm resource allocation.

author: Holger Mueller
title: Growth Dynamics: The Myth of Economic Recovery: Comment
abstract: <jats:p> This comment highlights different ways of coding crisis episodes in Cerra and Saxena (2008) (CS). The comment shows that the coding used for civil war implies a misrepresentation of its impact. A correct coding of civil war reveals that the average civil war leads to a loss in output of 18 percent. This makes civil wars more devastating than all other crisis studied by CS. </jats:p>
research_question: How does the correct coding of civil war episodes affect the measurement of their economic impact compared to other types of crises?
answer: When civil war episodes are correctly coded, they lead to an average output loss of 18 percent, making civil wars more economically devastating than all other types of crises studied.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as a methodological correction to Cerra and Saxena (2008), identifying coding errors in their crisis episode classification that led to misrepresentation of civil war's economic impact relative to other crises.

author: Hülya Eraslan
title: Mandatory versus Discretionary Spending: The Status Quo Effect
abstract: <jats:p> Do mandatory spending programs such as Medicare improve efficiency? We analyze a model with two parties allocating a fixed budget to a public good and private transfers each period over an infinite horizon. We compare two institutions that differ in whether public good spending is discretionary or mandatory. We model mandatory spending as an endogenous status quo since it is enacted by law and remains in effect until changed. Mandatory programs result in higher public good spending; furthermore, they ex ante Pareto dominate discretionary programs when parties are patient, persistence of power is low, and polarization is low. (JEL C78, E62, H41, H61) </jats:p>
research_question: Do mandatory spending programs such as Medicare improve efficiency compared to discretionary spending programs?
answer: Mandatory programs result in higher public good spending and ex ante Pareto dominate discretionary programs when parties are patient, persistence of power is low, and polarization is low.
positioning_statement: The paper analyzes a model with two parties allocating a fixed budget to compare two institutions that differ in whether public good spending is discretionary or mandatory, modeling mandatory spending as an endogenous status quo that is enacted by law and remains in effect until changed.

author: Hülya Eraslan
title: Strategic Voting over Strategic Proposals

author: Holger Mueller
title: Propagation and Amplification of Local Productivity Spillovers
abstract: <jats:p>The gains from agglomeration economies are believed to be highly localized. Using confidential Census plant‐level data, we show that large industrial plant openings raise the productivity not only of local plants but also of distant plants hundreds of miles away, which belong to large multi‐plant, multi‐region firms that are exposed to the local productivity spillover through one of their plants. This “global” productivity spillover does not decay with distance and is stronger if plants are in industries that share knowledge with each other. To quantify the significance of firms' plant‐level networks for the propagation and amplification of local productivity shocks, we estimate a quantitative spatial model in which plants of multi‐region firms are linked through shared knowledge. Counterfactual exercises show that while large industrial plant openings have a greater local impact in less developed regions, the aggregate gains are greatest when the plants locate in well‐developed regions, which are connected to other regions through firms' plant‐level (knowledge‐sharing) networks.</jats:p>
research_question: How do local productivity spillovers from agglomeration economies propagate beyond their immediate geographic area through firms' multi-plant networks?
answer: Large industrial plant openings create productivity spillovers that extend hundreds of miles away through multi-plant, multi-region firms' knowledge-sharing networks, with these global spillovers not decaying with distance and being stronger between knowledge-sharing industries. While local impacts are greater in less developed regions, aggregate gains are maximized when plants locate in well-developed regions that are better connected through firms' plant-level networks.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom that agglomeration economies are highly localized by demonstrating that productivity spillovers can propagate globally through firms' multi-plant networks, extending the literature on agglomeration effects beyond geographic proximity to include organizational connectivity.

author: Ilse Lindenlaub
title: Sorting Multidimensional Types: Theory and Application

author: Ilse Lindenlaub
title: Risky Matching
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a model where risk-averse workers can costly invest in their skills before matching with heterogenous firms. At the investment stage, workers face multiple sources of risk. They are uncertain about how skilled they will turn out and also about their income shock realizations at the time of employment. We analyse the equilibria of two versions of the model that depend on when uncertainty resolves, which determines the available risk-sharing possibilities between workers and firms. We provide a thorough analysis of equilibrium comparative statics regarding changes in risk, worker and firm heterogeneity, and technology. We derive conditions on the match output function and risk attitudes under which these shifts lead to more investment and show how this affects matching and wages. To illustrate the applied relevance of our theory, we provide a stylized quantitative assessment of the model and analyse the sources (risk, heterogeneity, or technology) of rising U.S. wage inequality. We find that changes in risk were the most important driver behind the surge in inequality, followed by technological change. We show that these conclusions are significantly altered if one neglects the key feature of our model, which is that educational investment is endogenous.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different sources of risk affect workers' skill investment decisions, matching with firms, and wage inequality when workers are risk-averse and can endogenously invest in skills before matching with heterogeneous firms?
answer: Changes in risk were the most important driver behind rising U.S. wage inequality, followed by technological change, and these conclusions are significantly altered when educational investment is treated as endogenous rather than exogenous.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a model that incorporates endogenous skill investment by risk-averse workers facing multiple sources of uncertainty before matching with heterogeneous firms, emphasizing that neglecting the endogenous nature of educational investment significantly alters conclusions about the sources of wage inequality.

author: Ilse Lindenlaub
title: Multidimensional Sorting under Random Search
abstract: We analyze sorting in a frictional labor market when workers and jobs have multidimensional characteristics. We say that matching is positive assortative in dimension (j, k) if workers with higher endowment in skill k are matched to a job distribution with higher values of attribute j in the first-order stochastic dominance sense. Crucial for sorting is a single-crossing property of technology. Sorting is positive between worker-job attributes with strong complementarities but negative in other dimensions. Finally, sorting is based on comparative advantage: workers sort into jobs that suit their skill mix rather than their overall skill level.

author: Isaac Sorkin
title: Granular Search, Market Structure, and Wages
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a model of size-based market power in a frictional labour market. In the canonical search environment, competition for workers is encoded in outside options. In our granular setting, large employers remove their own job postings from their workers’ outside option. Thus, size gives market power and a more concentrated market structure depresses wages because it reduces competition for workers. We calibrate the model to Austrian data and find that such size-based market power depresses wages by about 2.6% or 1,500 euros annually per worker.</jats:p>
research_question: How does firm size and market concentration affect wages in frictional labor markets through size-based market power?
answer: Large employers gain market power by removing their own job postings from their workers' outside options, and this size-based market power depresses wages by approximately 2.6% or 1,500 euros annually per worker in more concentrated markets.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the canonical search environment by introducing a granular setting where competition for workers through outside options is modified by firm size, providing a new mechanism through which market structure affects wages in frictional labor markets.

author: Isaac Sorkin
title: The Role of Firms in Gender Earnings Inequality: Evidence from the United States
abstract: <jats:p> This paper documents that in the US, men are more likely than women to work in both high-wage firms and high-wage industries. I then ask why this sorting occurs. I consider two main explanations: men and women have different preferences, and men and women have different opportunities. Through the lens of a simple random search model, I find that the dominant explanation for sorting is differences in opportunities. One implication of this result is that women are at firms that offer better nonpay characteristics, and this plays an important role in explaining the gender earnings gap. </jats:p>
research_question: Why do men and women sort into different firms and industries, with men being more likely to work in high-wage firms and high-wage industries?
answer: The dominant explanation for gender-based sorting into different firms and industries is differences in opportunities rather than differences in preferences, with women ending up at firms that offer better nonpay characteristics, which plays an important role in explaining the gender earnings gap.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the gender earnings inequality literature by focusing specifically on the role of firms in creating earnings differences, examining both preference-based and opportunity-based explanations for why men and women sort into different firms and industries.

author: Isaac Sorkin
title: Ranking Firms Using Revealed Preference*

author: Ilse Lindenlaub
title: Marriage Market and Labour Market Sorting
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a new equilibrium model in which households’ labour supply choices form the link between sorting on the marriage market and sorting on the labour market. We first show that in theory, the nature of home production—whether partners’ hours are complements or substitutes—shapes equilibrium labour supply as well as marriage and labour market sorting. We then estimate our model using German data to empirically assess the nature of home production, and find that spouses’ home hours are complements. We investigate to what extent complementarity in home hours drives sorting and inequality. We find that home production complementarity strengthens positive marriage sorting and reduces the gender gap in hours and in labour sorting. This puts significant downward pressure on the gender wage gap and on within-household income inequality, but fuels between-household inequality. Our estimated model sheds new light on the sources of inequality in today’s Germany, and—by identifying important shifts in home production technology toward more complementarity—on the evolution of inequality over time.</jats:p>
research_question: How do households' labour supply choices link sorting on the marriage market and sorting on the labour market, and what role does the nature of home production (whether partners' hours are complements or substitutes) play in shaping equilibrium labour supply and market sorting?
answer: Spouses' home hours are complements, and this complementarity in home production strengthens positive marriage sorting, reduces the gender gap in hours and labour sorting, puts downward pressure on the gender wage gap and within-household income inequality, but increases between-household inequality.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new equilibrium model that explicitly connects marriage market sorting and labour market sorting through households' labour supply choices, with a focus on how home production technology affects these relationships - providing new insights into the sources of inequality in Germany and its evolution over time through shifts in home production technology toward more complementarity.

author: Isaac Sorkin
title: Employers and Unemployment Insurance Take-Up
abstract: <jats:p> We quantify the employer's role in unemployment insurance (UI) take-up. Employer effects on claiming and appeals are substantial, and those effects are negatively correlated, consistent with appeals deterring claims. Low-wage workers are less likely to claim and more likely to have their claims appealed than median-wage workers. Employer effects help explain these income gradients, so equalizing employer effects on claiming would increase the progressivity of UI. Finally, the main source of targeting error in UI is that eligible workers do not claim. (JEL J22, J31, J63, J64, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of employers in determining unemployment insurance take-up rates among eligible workers?
answer: Employer effects on UI claiming and appeals are substantial and negatively correlated, meaning appeals deter claims. Low-wage workers are less likely to claim UI and more likely to have their claims appealed than median-wage workers, with employer effects helping to explain these income gradients.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a previously underexplored factor in UI take-up by quantifying employer effects, addressing the main source of targeting error in UI systems where eligible workers do not claim benefits, and providing new insights into the income gradients in UI claiming behavior.

author: Isaac Sorkin
title: Bartik Instruments: What, When, Why, and How
abstract: <jats:p> The Bartik instrument is formed by interacting local industry shares and national industry growth rates. We show that the typical use of a Bartik instrument assumes a pooled exposure research design, where the shares measure differential exposure to common shocks, and identification is based on exogeneity of the shares. Next, we show how the Bartik instrument weights each of the exposure designs. Finally, we discuss how to assess the plausibility of the research design. We illustrate our results through two applications: estimating the elasticity of labor supply, and estimating the elasticity of substitution between immigrants and natives. (JEL C51, F14, J15, J22, L60, R23, R32) </jats:p>
research_question: How should researchers understand, construct, and validate Bartik instruments in empirical economics research?
answer: The typical use of a Bartik instrument assumes a pooled exposure research design where local industry shares measure differential exposure to common shocks, and identification relies on exogeneity of the shares; the paper provides a framework for understanding how Bartik instruments weight different exposure designs and methods for assessing research design plausibility.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a comprehensive methodological framework for understanding Bartik instruments, filling a gap in the literature by clarifying the underlying assumptions, weighting mechanisms, and validation approaches for this widely-used instrumental variable technique in applied economics.

author: Isabelle Mejean
title: Large Firms and International Business Cycle Comovement
abstract: <jats:p> This paper investigates the role of the top 100 firms in France in aggregate business cycle comovement. We establish that the top 100 firms (i) are important in aggregate; (ii) exhibit stronger international linkages than the rest of the economy; and (iii) contribute substantially to aggregate comovement. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of the top 100 firms in France in aggregate business cycle comovement?
answer: The top 100 firms in France are important in aggregate, exhibit stronger international linkages than the rest of the economy, and contribute substantially to aggregate comovement.
positioning_statement: This paper investigates the specific role of large firms in international business cycle comovement, focusing on how the largest firms contribute to aggregate economic synchronization across countries.

author: Isabela Manelici
title: The Effects of Joining Multinational Supply Chains: New Evidence from Firm-to-Firm Linkages
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the effects of becoming a supplier to multinational corporations (MNCs) using tax data tracking firm-to-firm transactions in Costa Rica. Event study estimates reveal that domestic firms experience strong and persistent gains in performance after supplying to a first MNC buyer. Four years after, domestic firms employ 26% more workers and have a 4% to 9% higher total factor productivity (TFP). These effects are unlikely to be explained by demand effects or changes in tax compliance. Moreover, suppliers experience a large drop in their sales to all other buyers except the first MNC buyer in the year of the event, followed by a gradual recovery. The dynamics of adjustment in sales to others suggests that firms face short-run capacity constraints that relax over time. Four years later, the sales to others grow by 20%. Most of this growth comes from the acquisition of new buyers, which tend to be “better buyers” (e.g., larger and with more stable supplier relationships). Finally, we collected survey data from domestic firms and MNCs to provide further insights into the wide-ranging benefits of supplying to MNCs. According to our surveys, these benefits range from better managerial practices to a better reputation.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects on domestic firms of becoming suppliers to multinational corporations (MNCs)?
answer: Domestic firms experience strong and persistent performance gains after supplying to their first MNC buyer, including 26% more workers and 4-9% higher total factor productivity after four years, along with 20% growth in sales to other buyers through acquisition of new, better buyers, despite initial short-run capacity constraints.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new evidence on MNC supplier relationships using unique firm-to-firm transaction tax data from Costa Rica, complemented by survey data, to examine both direct performance effects and spillover effects to other buyer relationships that have not been comprehensively studied in existing literature.

author: Isaac Sorkin
title: Teacher Labor Market Policy and the Theory of the Second Best
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We estimate a matching model of teachers and elementary schools with rich data on teachers' applications and principals' ratings from a large, urban district in North Carolina. Both teachers’ and principals’ preferences deviate from those that would maximize the achievement of economically disadvantaged students: teachers prefer schools with fewer disadvantaged students, and principals' ratings are weakly related to teacher effectiveness. In equilibrium, these two deviations combine to produce a surprisingly equitable current allocation, where teacher quality is balanced across advantaged and disadvantaged students. To close achievement gaps, policies that address deviations on one side alone are ineffective or harmful, while policies that address both could substantially increase the achievement of disadvantaged students.</jats:p>
research_question: How do teacher and principal preferences in the teacher-school matching process affect the allocation of teacher quality across advantaged and disadvantaged students, and what policy interventions could improve outcomes for disadvantaged students?
answer: Teachers prefer schools with fewer disadvantaged students and principals' ratings are weakly related to teacher effectiveness, but these two deviations surprisingly combine to produce an equitable allocation of teacher quality across student types. Policies addressing only one side of the market are ineffective or harmful, while policies addressing both teacher and principal preferences could substantially increase achievement of disadvantaged students.
positioning_statement: This paper applies the theory of the second best to teacher labor markets, showing that when both sides of the matching market have preferences that deviate from maximizing disadvantaged student achievement, the interaction of these deviations can produce unexpectedly equitable outcomes, requiring coordinated policy interventions rather than single-sided reforms.

author: Jakub Steiner
title: Growth and Redistribution: The Hedging Perspective
abstract: <jats:p> We investigate the impact of wealth redistribution on economic growth, building on Kelly’s (1956) optimal investment portfolio theory. A growth-optimal policy redistributes wealth from “lucky” overperforming individuals to underperforming ones, minimizing the systematic component of this redistribution in a myopic fashion. That is, the optimal policy minimizes the discrepancy between endowments and outcomes, counterfactually taking outcomes as independent of endowments. The myopia in this result follows from a decoupling argument that allows us to model the planner as independently choosing a growth-maximizing policy and a pattern of wealth circulation. (JEL D31, E23, G41, G51, H23, O41) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of wealth redistribution on economic growth?
answer: A growth-optimal policy redistributes wealth from 'lucky' overperforming individuals to underperforming ones, minimizing the systematic component of this redistribution in a myopic fashion by minimizing the discrepancy between endowments and outcomes.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Kelly's (1956) optimal investment portfolio theory to investigate wealth redistribution and economic growth, using a decoupling argument that allows modeling the planner as independently choosing a growth-maximizing policy and a pattern of wealth circulation.

author: Isabelle Mejean
title: Foreign Shocks as Granular Fluctuations
abstract: This paper uses a dataset covering the universe of French firm-level value-added, imports, and exports and a quantitative multicountry heterogeneous firm model to study the propagation of foreign shocks to the domestic economy. Foreign shocks are transmitted primarily through large firms as they are the most likely to trade internationally. At the micro level, the majority of the GDP impact of foreign shocks is accounted for by the “foreign granular residual,” a statistic capturing larger firms’ greater responsiveness to foreign shocks. At the macro level, firm heterogeneity attenuates the GDP impact of foreign shocks relative to a homogeneous firm counterfactual.

author: Isabelle Mejean
title: Regulation under Asymmetric Information in Water Utilities

author: Isabelle Mejean
title: The Micro Origins of International Business-Cycle Comovement
abstract: <jats:p> This paper investigates the role of individual firms in international business-cycle comovement using data covering the universe of French firm-level value added and international linkages over the period 1993–2007. At the micro level, trade and multinational linkages with a particular foreign country are associated with a significantly higher correlation between a firm and that foreign country. The impact of direct linkages on comovement at the micro level has significant macro implications. Without those linkages the correlation between France and foreign countries would fall by about 0.098, or one-third of the observed average correlation of 0.291 in our sample of partner countries. (JEL F14, F23, F44, F62, L14) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of individual firms in international business-cycle comovement, specifically how do firm-level trade and multinational linkages affect correlations between domestic and foreign business cycles?
answer: Individual firms with trade and multinational linkages to foreign countries exhibit significantly higher correlations with those countries' business cycles, and these micro-level linkages have substantial macro implications - without direct firm linkages, the correlation between France and foreign countries would fall by about 0.098, representing one-third of the observed average correlation of 0.291.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the international business-cycle comovement literature by providing micro-level evidence using comprehensive firm-level data, investigating how individual firm linkages aggregate to explain macro-level international correlations, rather than focusing solely on aggregate-level relationships.

author: Ivana Komunjer
title: Estimation and Testing of Forecast Rationality under Flexible Loss

author: Ivana Komunjer
title: What Goods Do Countries Trade? A Quantitative Exploration of Ricardo's Ideas
abstract: The Ricardian model predicts that countries should produce and export relatively more in industries in which they are relatively more productive. Though one of the most celebrated insights in the theory of international trade, this prediction has received little attention in the empirical literature since the mid-1960s. The main reason behind this lack of popularity is the absence of clear theoretical foundations to guide the empirical analysis. Building on the seminal work of Eaton and Kortum ("Technology, Geography, and Trade", Econometrica, 70, 1741--1779 2002), we offer such foundations and use them to quantify the importance of Ricardian comparative advantage. In the process, we also provide a theoretically consistent alternative to Balassa's (1965, "An Empirical Demonstration of Classical Comparative Cost Theory", Review of Economics and Statistics, 45, 231--238) well-known index of "revealed comparative advantage". Copyright 2012, Oxford University Press.

author: Ivana Komunjer
title: Learning from a Piece of Pie
