title: Event Exchangeability: Probabilistic Sophistication Without Continuity or Monotonicity

author: Itamar Drechsler
title: The Deposits Channel of Monetary Policy*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We present a new channel for the transmission of monetary policy, the deposits channel. We show that when the Fed funds rate rises, banks widen the spreads they charge on deposits, and deposits flow out of the banking system. We present a model where this is due to market power in deposit markets. Consistent with the market power mechanism, deposit spreads increase more and deposits flow out more in concentrated markets. This is true even when we control for lending opportunities by only comparing different branches of the same bank. Since deposits are the main source of liquid assets for households, the deposits channel can explain the observed strong relationship between the liquidity premium and the Fed funds rate. Since deposits are also a uniquely stable funding source for banks, the deposits channel impacts bank lending. When the Fed funds rate rises, banks that raise deposits in concentrated markets contract their lending by more than other banks. Our estimates imply that the deposits channel can account for the entire transmission of monetary policy through bank balance sheets.</jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy transmit through the banking system via deposit markets, and what role does bank market power play in this transmission mechanism?
answer: When the Fed funds rate rises, banks with market power widen deposit spreads and experience deposit outflows, which constrains their lending. Banks in concentrated deposit markets contract lending more than others, and this 'deposits channel' can account for the entire transmission of monetary policy through bank balance sheets.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a new channel for monetary policy transmission - the deposits channel - that complements existing literature by focusing on how bank market power in deposit markets affects both household liquidity and bank lending, providing a comprehensive explanation for monetary policy transmission through bank balance sheets.

author: Jakub Steiner
title: Perceiving Prospects Properly
abstract: <jats:p> When an agent chooses between prospects, noise in information processing generates an effect akin to the winner's curse. Statistically unbiased perception systematically overvalues the chosen action because it fails to account for the possibility that noise is responsible for making the preferred action appear to be optimal. The optimal perception pattern exhibits a key feature of prospect theory, namely, overweighting of small probability events (and corresponding underweighting of high probability events). This bias arises to correct for the winner's curse effect. (JEL D11, D81, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How should agents optimally perceive probabilities when making choices between prospects in the presence of noisy information processing?
answer: Optimal perception exhibits overweighting of small probability events and underweighting of high probability events (similar to prospect theory) in order to correct for a winner's curse effect that arises when noise in information processing causes agents to systematically overvalue their chosen actions.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a rational foundation for a key feature of prospect theory (probability weighting) by showing it emerges as an optimal response to noisy information processing, rather than being an irrational behavioral bias as traditionally viewed in the literature.

author: Jakub Steiner
title: Who Matters in Coordination Problems?
abstract: <jats:p> Agents face a coordination problem akin to the adoption of a network technology. A principal announces investment subsidies that, at minimal cost, attain a given likelihood of successful coordination. Optimal subsidies target agents who impose high externalities on others and on whom others impose low externalities. Based on the analysis of the role of strategic uncertainty in coordination processes, we provide a methodology that can be used to find the optimal targets for a variety of interventions in a large class of coordination problems with heterogeneous agents. (JEL D81, D82, D83, O33) </jats:p>
research_question: How should a principal optimally design investment subsidies to achieve successful coordination in network technology adoption problems with heterogeneous agents?
answer: Optimal subsidies should target agents who impose high externalities on others and on whom others impose low externalities, which minimizes the cost of achieving a given likelihood of successful coordination.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the coordination problems literature by providing a methodology based on strategic uncertainty analysis that can identify optimal intervention targets across a large class of coordination problems with heterogeneous agents, extending beyond the specific context of network technology adoption.

author: Jakub Steiner
title: Attention Please!
abstract: <jats:p>We study the impact of manipulating the attention of a decision‐maker who learns sequentially about a number of items before making a choice. Under natural assumptions on the decision‐maker's strategy, directing attention toward one item increases its likelihood of being chosen regardless of its value. This result applies when the decision‐maker can reject all items in favor of an outside option with known value; if no outside option is available, the direction of the effect of manipulation depends on the value of the item. A similar result applies to manipulation of choices in bandit problems.</jats:p>
research_question: How does manipulating the attention of a decision-maker who learns sequentially about multiple items before making a choice affect the likelihood of selecting specific items?
answer: Directing attention toward one item increases its likelihood of being chosen regardless of its value when an outside option with known value is available; without an outside option, the effect depends on the item's value.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on sequential decision-making and attention manipulation by providing a theoretical framework that applies to both choice problems with outside options and bandit problems, offering general results under natural assumptions about decision-maker strategies.

author: Jakub Steiner
title: Rational Inattention Dynamics: Inertia and Delay in Decision-Making
abstract: We solve a general class of dynamic rational inattention problems in which an agent repeatedly acquires costly information about an evolving state and selects actions. The solution resembles the choice rule in a dynamic logit model, but it is biased toward an optimal default rule that is independent of the realized state. The model provides the same fit to choice data as dynamic logit, but, because of the bias, yields different counterfactual predictions. We apply the general solution to the study of (i) the status quo bias; (ii) inertia in actions leading to lagged adjustments to shocks; and (iii) the tradeoff between accuracy and delay in decision‐making.

author: James Choi
title: Randomizing Religion: the Impact of Protestant Evangelism on Economic Outcomes*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the causal impact of religiosity through a randomized evaluation of an evangelical Protestant Christian values and theology education program delivered to thousands of ultrapoor Filipino households. Six months after the program ended, treated households have higher religiosity and income; no statistically significant differences in total labor supply, consumption, food security, or life satisfaction; and lower perceived relative economic status. Exploratory analysis suggests that the income treatment effect may operate through increasing grit. Thirty months after the program ended, significant differences in the intensity of religiosity disappear, but those in the treatment group are less likely to be Catholic and more likely to be Protestant, and there is some mixed evidence that their consumption and perceived relative economic status are higher.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal impact of religiosity on economic outcomes?
answer: Protestant evangelical education increases religiosity and income in the short term (6 months), with income effects potentially operating through increased grit, while long-term effects (30 months) show religious conversion from Catholic to Protestant and mixed evidence of higher consumption and perceived economic status.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the causal impact of religiosity on economic outcomes through a randomized evaluation, contributing to the literature by providing experimental evidence rather than relying on observational studies that may suffer from endogeneity concerns.

author: Jakub Steiner
title: Decision Theory and Stochastic Growth
abstract: <jats:p> This paper examines connections between stochastic growth and decision problems. We use tools from the theory of large deviations to show that wishful thinking decision problems are equivalent to utility maximization problems, both of which are equivalent to growth maximization under idiosyncratic risk. Rational inattention problems are equivalent to growth-optimal portfolio problems, both of which are equivalent to growth maximization under aggregate risk. Stochastic growth generates extreme inequality, with nearly all wealth eventually held by those who happen to have faced empirical distributions that match the solution to the wishful thinking or rational inattention problem. (JEL D31, D81, D82, D83, G51, O41) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the connections between stochastic growth and decision problems, specifically how do wishful thinking and rational inattention problems relate to growth maximization?
answer: Wishful thinking decision problems are equivalent to utility maximization problems and growth maximization under idiosyncratic risk, while rational inattention problems are equivalent to growth-optimal portfolio problems and growth maximization under aggregate risk. Stochastic growth generates extreme inequality where wealth concentrates among those whose empirical distributions match the solutions to these decision problems.
positioning_statement: This paper uses tools from the theory of large deviations to establish novel equivalences between different types of decision problems (wishful thinking, rational inattention, utility maximization, growth-optimal portfolios) and stochastic growth models, providing a unifying framework that connects decision theory with growth theory and wealth inequality.

author: James Choi
title: Social Identity and Preferences
abstract: <jats:p> Social identities prescribe behaviors for people. We identify the marginal behavioral effect of these norms on discount rates and risk aversion by measuring how laboratory subjects' choices change when an aspect of social identity is made salient. When we make ethnic identity salient to Asian-American subjects, they make more patient choices. When we make racial identity salient to black subjects, non-immigrant blacks (but not immigrant blacks) make more patient choices. Making gender identity salient has no effect on intertemporal or risk choices. (JEL D81, J15, J16, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the marginal behavioral effect of social identity norms on discount rates and risk aversion when different aspects of social identity are made salient?
answer: Making ethnic identity salient to Asian-American subjects increases patience; making racial identity salient to non-immigrant black subjects (but not immigrant blacks) increases patience; making gender identity salient has no effect on intertemporal or risk choices.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies the causal behavioral effects of social identity norms by experimentally manipulating identity salience in laboratory settings, providing direct measurement of how social identities prescribe and influence economic preferences.

author: James Choi
title: Optimal Defaults

author: James Cloyne
title: Discretionary Tax Changes and the Macroeconomy: New Narrative Evidence from the United Kingdom
abstract: <jats:p> This paper provides new estimates of the macroeconomic effects of tax changes using a new narrative dataset for the United Kingdom. Identification is achieved by isolating “exogenous” tax policy changes using the Romer and Romer narrative strategy. I find that a 1 percent cut in taxes increases GDP by 0.6 percent on impact and 2.5 percent over three years. The findings are remarkably similar to Romer and Romer narrative estimates for the United States, reinforcing the view that tax changes have powerful and persistent effects. “Exogenous” tax changes are also shown to have contributed to important episodes in the UK business cycle. (JEL E23, E32, E62, H20, H61) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the macroeconomic effects of discretionary tax changes in the United Kingdom?
answer: A 1 percent cut in taxes increases GDP by 0.6 percent on impact and 2.5 percent over three years, demonstrating that tax changes have powerful and persistent effects on the macroeconomy.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the Romer and Romer narrative strategy to the United Kingdom context, providing new evidence that reinforces and validates the US findings that tax changes have significant macroeconomic effects, while also contributing new narrative evidence from a different country setting.

author: James Cloyne
title: Household Debt and the Dynamic Effects of Income Tax Changes

author: James Cloyne
title: The Effect of House Prices on Household Borrowing: A New Approach
abstract: <jats:p>We investigate the effect of house prices on household borrowing using administrative mortgage data from the United Kingdom and a new empirical approach. The data contain household-level information on house prices and borrowing in a panel of homeowners, who refinance at regular and quasi-exogenous intervals. The data and setting allow us to develop an empirical approach that exploits house price variation coming from the idiosyncratic and exogenous timing of refinance events around the Great Recession. We present two main results. First, there is a clear and robust effect of house prices on borrowing. Second, the effect of house prices on borrowing can be explained largely by collateral effects. We study the collateral channel through a multivariate and nonparametric heterogeneity analysis of proxies for collateral and wealth effects. (JEL D14, E32, R31)</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of house prices on household borrowing?
answer: There is a clear and robust effect of house prices on borrowing, and this effect can be explained largely by collateral effects rather than wealth effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a new empirical approach using administrative mortgage data from the UK and exploiting quasi-exogenous variation in refinancing timing around the Great Recession to identify causal effects of house prices on borrowing, distinguishing between collateral and wealth channels.

author: James Cloyne
title: Monetary Policy when Households have Debt: New Evidence on the Transmission Mechanism
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Using household survey data for the U.S. and the U.K., we show that the aggregate response of consumption to interest rate changes is driven by households with a mortgage. Outright home-owners do not adjust expenditure at all while renters change their spending but by less than mortgagors. Income rises for all households as interest rate cuts directly affect firm investment and household consumption, boosting aggregate demand. A crucial difference between the housing tenure groups is the composition of their balance sheets: mortgagors hold sizable illiquid assets but little liquid wealth. Our results reveal that general equilibrium effects on household income coupled with balance-sheet-driven heterogeneity in the marginal propensity to consume play a key role in the transmission of monetary policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How does household debt, particularly mortgage debt, affect the transmission mechanism of monetary policy to consumption?
answer: The aggregate consumption response to interest rate changes is driven primarily by households with mortgages, while outright homeowners do not adjust expenditure and renters respond less than mortgagors. This differential response is explained by balance sheet composition differences - mortgagors hold large illiquid assets but little liquid wealth - combined with general equilibrium income effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new empirical evidence on monetary policy transmission by using household survey data to reveal that balance-sheet-driven heterogeneity in marginal propensity to consume, coupled with general equilibrium effects on household income, plays a key role in how monetary policy affects the economy through household debt channels.

author: James Cloyne
title: Are Tax Cuts Contractionary at the Zero Lower Bound? Evidence from a Century of Data

author: James Cloyne
title: Taxes and Growth: New Narrative Evidence from Interwar Britain
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The impact of fiscal policy on economic activity is still a matter of great debate. And, ever since Keynes first commented on it, interwar Britain, 1918–39, has remained a particularly interesting and contentious case—not least because of its high-debt environment and turbulent business cycle. This debate has often focused on the effects of government spending, but little is known about the effects of tax changes. In fact, a number of tax reforms in the period focused on long-term and social objectives, often reflecting the personality of British Chancellors. Based on extensive historiographical research, we apply a narrative approach to the interwar period in Britain and isolate a new series of exogenous tax changes. We find that tax changes have a sizable effect on GDP, with multipliers exceeding 2 within two years. Our estimates provide new evidence on the effects of tax changes, contribute to the historical debate about fiscal policy in the interwar period and are also consistent with the sizable tax multipliers found after World War II.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of tax changes on economic activity in interwar Britain (1918-39), particularly in a high-debt environment with turbulent business cycles?
answer: Tax changes have a sizable effect on GDP, with multipliers exceeding 2 within two years, based on a new series of exogenous tax changes identified through narrative approach.
positioning_statement: This paper fills a gap in the literature on interwar Britain fiscal policy, which has focused primarily on government spending effects rather than tax changes, and contributes new evidence to the historical debate about fiscal policy while being consistent with post-WWII findings on tax multipliers.

author: James Cloyne
title: Estimating the Elasticity of Intertemporal Substitution Using Mortgage Notches

author: James Roberts
title: When Should Sellers Use Auctions?
abstract: <jats:p> A bidding process can be organized so that offers are submitted simultaneously or sequentially. In the latter case, potential buyers can condition their behavior on previous entrants' decisions. The relative performance of these mechanisms is investigated when entry is costly and selective, meaning that potential buyers with higher values are more likely to participate. A simple sequential mechanism can give both buyers and sellers significantly higher payoffs than the commonly used simultaneous bid auction. The findings are illustrated with parameters estimated from simultaneous entry USFS timber auctions where our estimates predict that the sequential mechanism would increase revenue and efficiency. (JEL D44, L73, Q23) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relative performance of simultaneous versus sequential bidding mechanisms when entry is costly and selective?
answer: A simple sequential mechanism can give both buyers and sellers significantly higher payoffs than the commonly used simultaneous bid auction, with estimates from USFS timber auctions predicting that sequential mechanisms would increase revenue and efficiency.
positioning_statement: This paper investigates the choice between simultaneous and sequential bidding processes in the context of costly and selective entry, extending existing auction theory by examining how the timing of bid submission affects mechanism performance when potential buyers with higher values are more likely to participate.

author: James Vickery
title: Credit Ratings and Security Prices in the Subprime MBS Market
abstract: <jats:p> We present and discuss preliminary evidence suggesting that credit ratings significantly influenced prices for subprime mortgage-backed securities issued in the period leading up to the recent financial crisis. Ratings are closely correlated with prices even controlling for a rich set of security- and loan-level controls. This incremental variation in ratings has much less predictive power for security defaults, however, based on findings to date from our ongoing research, suggesting prices were excessively sensitive to ratings relative to their informational content. </jats:p>
research_question: Did credit ratings significantly influence prices for subprime mortgage-backed securities issued in the period leading up to the recent financial crisis?
answer: Credit ratings significantly influenced prices for subprime mortgage-backed securities and were closely correlated with prices even when controlling for security- and loan-level factors, but prices were excessively sensitive to ratings relative to their actual informational content about security defaults.
positioning_statement: This paper provides preliminary evidence on the relationship between credit ratings and security prices in the subprime MBS market, contributing to understanding of pricing dynamics during the pre-financial crisis period by examining whether market prices appropriately reflected the informational content of credit ratings.

author: Jan De Loecker
title: Markups and Firm-Level Export Status
abstract: <jats:p> In this paper, we develop a method to estimate markups using plant-level production data. Our approach relies on cost-minimizing producers and the existence of at least one variable input of production. The suggested empirical framework relies on the estimation of a production function and provides estimates of plant-level mark-ups without specifying how firms compete in the product market. We rely on our method to explore the relationship between markups and export behavior. We find that markups are estimated significantly higher when controlling for unobserved productivity; that exporters charge, on average, higher markups and that markups increase upon export entry. (JEL D22, D24, F14, L11, L60) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between firm-level markups and export behavior?
answer: Exporters charge higher markups on average compared to non-exporters, and markups increase when firms begin exporting.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new method to estimate plant-level markups using production data that relies on cost-minimizing behavior and variable inputs, without requiring specification of product market competition structure, and applies this method to examine the previously understudied relationship between markups and export status.

author: Jan De Loecker
title: Job reallocation and productivity growth in a post-socialist economy: Evidence from Slovenian manufacturing

author: Jan De Loecker
title: Reallocation and Technology: Evidence from the US Steel Industry
abstract: <jats:p> We measure the impact of a drastic new technology for producing steel—the minimill—on industry-wide productivity in the US steel industry, using unique plant-level data between 1963 and 2002. The sharp increase in the industry's productivity is linked to this new technology through two distinct mechanisms: (i ) the mere displacement of the older technology (vertically integrated producers) was responsible for a third of the increase in the industry's productivity, and (ii ) increased competition, due the minimill expansion, drove a productivity resurgence at the surviving vertical integrated producers and, consequently, the productivity of the industry as a whole. (JEL D24, L13, L23, L61, M11, O31, O33) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of minimill technology on industry-wide productivity in the US steel industry?
answer: The minimill technology caused a sharp increase in industry productivity through two mechanisms: (1) displacement of older vertically integrated producers accounted for one-third of the productivity increase, and (2) increased competition from minimill expansion drove productivity improvements at surviving vertically integrated producers, boosting overall industry productivity.
positioning_statement: This paper uses unique plant-level data from 1963-2002 to measure the productivity impact of a drastic new steel production technology, providing empirical evidence on how technological change affects industry-wide performance through both direct displacement and competitive effects.

author: Jan De Loecker
title: (Mis)Allocation, Market Power, and Global Oil Extraction
abstract: <jats:p> We propose an approach to measuring the misallocation of production in a market that compares actual industry cost curves to undistorted (counterfactual ) supply curves. As compared to traditional, TFPR-based, misallocation measures, this approach leverages cost data, such that results are readily mapped to welfare metrics. As an application, we analyze global crude oil extraction and quantify the extent of misallocation therein, together with the proportion attributable to market power. From 1970 to 2014, we find substantial misallocation, in the order of US$744 billion, 14.1 percent to 21.9 percent of which is attributable to market power. (JEL D24, F23, L13, L71, Q35) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure the misallocation of production in markets and what is the extent of misallocation in global crude oil extraction, including the proportion attributable to market power?
answer: The paper finds substantial misallocation in global crude oil extraction from 1970 to 2014, totaling approximately US$744 billion, with 14.1 percent to 21.9 percent of this misallocation attributable to market power.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new approach to measuring misallocation that compares actual industry cost curves to undistorted counterfactual supply curves, which differs from traditional TFPR-based misallocation measures by leveraging cost data that can be readily mapped to welfare metrics.

author: Jan De Loecker
title: The Rise of Market Power and the Macroeconomic Implications*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We document the evolution of market power based on firm-level data for the U.S. economy since 1955. We measure both markups and profitability. In 1980, aggregate markups start to rise from 21% above marginal cost to 61% now. The increase is driven mainly by the upper tail of the markup distribution: the upper percentiles have increased sharply. Quite strikingly, the median is unchanged. In addition to the fattening upper tail of the markup distribution, there is reallocation of market share from low- to high-markup firms. This rise occurs mostly within industry. We also find an increase in the average profit rate from 1% to 8%. Although there is also an increase in overhead costs, the markup increase is in excess of overhead. We discuss the macroeconomic implications of an increase in average market power, which can account for a number of secular trends in the past four decades, most notably the declining labor and capital shares as well as the decrease in labor market dynamism.</jats:p>
research_question: How has market power evolved in the U.S. economy since 1955, and what are the macroeconomic implications of changes in firm-level markups and profitability?
answer: Aggregate markups have risen dramatically from 21% above marginal cost in 1980 to 61% currently, driven primarily by increases in the upper tail of the markup distribution while the median remains unchanged. This rise is accompanied by market share reallocation from low- to high-markup firms and an increase in average profit rates from 1% to 8%. The increase in market power can explain several secular macroeconomic trends including declining labor and capital shares and decreased labor market dynamism.
positioning_statement: This paper provides comprehensive firm-level documentation of the evolution of market power in the U.S. economy over six decades, offering empirical evidence that connects microeconomic changes in firm markups and profitability to macroeconomic secular trends, thereby bridging industrial organization and macroeconomic literature on market concentration and its economy-wide effects.

author: Jan De Loecker
title: Dynamic Inputs and Resource (Mis)Allocation

author: Jan De Loecker
title: Prices, Markups, and Trade Reform
abstract: This paper examines how prices, markups, and marginal costs respond to trade liberalization. We develop a framework to estimate markups from production data with multi‐product firms. This approach does not require assumptions on the market structure or demand curves faced by firms, nor assumptions on how firms allocate their inputs across products. We exploit quantity and price information to disentangle markups from quantity‐based productivity, and then compute marginal costs by dividing observed prices by the estimated markups. We use India's trade liberalization episode to examine how firms adjust these performance measures. Not surprisingly, we find that trade liberalization lowers factory‐gate prices and that output tariff declines have the expected pro‐competitive effects. However, the price declines are small relative to the declines in marginal costs, which fall predominantly because of the input tariff liberalization. The reason for this incomplete cost pass‐through to prices is that firms offset their reductions in marginal costs by raising markups. Our results demonstrate substantial heterogeneity and variability in markups across firms and time and suggest that producers benefited relative to consumers, at least immediately after the reforms.

author: Jean-François Houde
title: Spatial Differentiation and Vertical Mergers in Retail Markets for Gasoline
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies an empirical model of spatial competition applied to gasoline markets. The main feature is to specify commuting paths as the “locations'' of consumers in a Hotelling-style model. As a result, spatial differentiation depends in an intuitive way on the structure of the road network and the direction of traffic flows. The model is estimated using panel data on the Quebec City gasoline market and used to evaluate the consequences of a recent vertical merger. Difference-in-difference and counterfactual simulation methods are compared, and the results, to a large extent, validate the assumptions of the demand model. (JEL G34, L13, L42, L81, Q41, R41) </jats:p>
research_question: How does spatial competition in gasoline markets work when consumer locations are defined by commuting paths, and what are the consequences of vertical mergers in such spatially differentiated markets?
answer: Spatial differentiation in gasoline markets depends intuitively on road network structure and traffic flow directions when commuting paths define consumer locations, and the empirical results from difference-in-difference and counterfactual simulation methods largely validate the demand model assumptions when evaluating vertical merger consequences.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the spatial competition literature by innovatively specifying commuting paths as consumer 'locations' in a Hotelling-style model, providing a more realistic framework for analyzing gasoline markets compared to traditional spatial models, and offers empirical validation through comparison of difference-in-difference and counterfactual simulation methods.

author: Jean-François Houde
title: When Does Regulation Distort Costs? Lessons from Fuel Procurement in US Electricity Generation: Comment
abstract: <jats:p> We revisit one of the results in Cicala (2015) and show that the previously estimated large and significant effects of US electricity restructuring on fuel procurement are not robust to the presence of outliers. Using methodologies from the robust statistics literature, we estimate the effect to be less than one-half of the previous estimate and not statistically different from zero. The robust methodology also identifies as outliers the plants owned by a single company whose coal contracts were renegotiated before discussions about restructuring even started. (JEL D83, O13, O33, Q16) </jats:p>
research_question: Are the previously estimated large effects of US electricity restructuring on fuel procurement costs robust to statistical outliers?
answer: The previously estimated large and significant effects of US electricity restructuring on fuel procurement are not robust to outliers; when using robust statistical methodologies, the effect is less than half the previous estimate and not statistically significant.
positioning_statement: This paper directly challenges the findings of Cicala (2015) by applying robust statistical methods to show that the original results were driven by outliers, specifically plants owned by a single company whose coal contracts were renegotiated before restructuring discussions began.

author: Jean-François Houde
title: Hub-and-Spoke Cartels: Theory and Evidence from the Grocery Industry
abstract: <jats:p> Numerous recently uncovered cartels operated along the supply chain, with firms at one end facilitating collusion at the other—hub-and-spoke arrangements. These cartels are hard to rationalize because they induce double marginalization and higher costs. We examine Canada’s alleged bread cartel and provide the first comprehensive analysis of hub-and-spoke collusion. Using court documents and pricing data, we make three contributions: (i) we show that collusion was effective, increasing inflation by about 50 percent; (ii) we provide evidence that collusion existed at both ends of the supply chain; and (iii) we develop a model explaining why this form of collusion arose. (JEL E31, K21, L12, L14, L22, L42, L81) </jats:p>
research_question: How do hub-and-spoke cartels operate along supply chains, and why do firms choose this form of collusion despite it inducing double marginalization and higher costs?
answer: Hub-and-spoke cartels can be effective despite their apparent inefficiencies - the Canadian bread cartel increased inflation by about 50 percent, with collusion occurring at both ends of the supply chain, and there are rational economic explanations for why firms choose this arrangement.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first comprehensive analysis of hub-and-spoke collusion, addressing a gap in understanding these recently uncovered cartels that are difficult to rationalize under existing theory due to their apparent cost-increasing effects.

author: Jean-François Houde
title: Nexus Tax Laws and Economies of Density in E‐Commerce: A Study of Amazon's Fulfillment Center Network
abstract: <jats:p>We quantify the distortionary effects of nexus tax laws on Amazon's distribution network investments between 1999 and 2018. We highlight the role of two features of the expansion of Amazon's network: densification of the network of distribution facilities and vertical integration into package sortation. Densification results in a reduction in the cost of shipping orders, but comes at the expense of higher facility operating costs in more expensive areas and lower scale economies of processing shipments. Nexus laws furthermore generate additional sales tax liabilities as the network grows. Combining data on household spending across online and offline retailers with detailed data on Amazon's distribution network, we quantify these trade‐offs through a static model of demand and a dynamic model of investment. Our results suggest that Amazon's expansion led to significant shipping cost savings and facilitated the realization of aggregate economies of scale. We find that abolishing nexus tax laws in favor of a non‐discriminatory tax policy would induce the company to decentralize its network, lowering its shipping costs. Non‐discriminatory taxation would also entail lower revenue, however, as tax‐inclusive prices would rise, resulting in a fall in profit overall. This drop and the decline in consumer welfare from higher taxes together fall short of the increases in tax revenue and rival profit, suggesting that the abolishment of nexus laws would lead to an increase in total welfare.</jats:p>
research_question: How do nexus tax laws distort Amazon's distribution network investment decisions and what are the welfare implications of these distortions?
answer: Nexus tax laws cause Amazon to maintain a more centralized distribution network than would be optimal, leading to higher shipping costs but lower tax liabilities. Abolishing nexus laws in favor of non-discriminatory taxation would induce network decentralization, reduce shipping costs, but ultimately decrease Amazon's profits due to higher tax-inclusive prices, while increasing total welfare through higher tax revenue and rival profits.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by quantifying the distortionary effects of nexus tax laws on e-commerce distribution networks, specifically examining the trade-offs between network densification benefits (reduced shipping costs) and costs (higher facility operating costs, lower scale economies, and increased tax liabilities), using Amazon's network expansion from 1999-2018 as a case study.

author: Jean-François Houde
title: Search Frictions and Market Power in Negotiated-Price Markets
abstract: We provide a framework for empirical analysis of negotiated-price markets. Using mortgage market data and a search and negotiation model, we characterize the welfare impact of search frictions and quantify the role of search costs and brand loyalty for market power. Search frictions reduce consumer surplus by $12/month/consumer, 28 percent of which can be associated with discrimination, 22 percent with inefficient matching, and 50 percent with search costs. Banks with large consumer bases have margins 70 percent higher than those with small consumer bases. The main source of this incumbency advantage is brand loyalty; however, price discrimination based on search frictions accounts for almost a third.

author: Jean-François Houde
title: The Effect of Mergers in Search Markets: Evidence from the Canadian Mortgage Industry
abstract: <jats:p> We examine the relationship between concentration and price dispersion using variation induced by a merger in the Canadian mortgage market. Since interest rates are determined through a search and negotiation process, consolidation weakens consumers' bargaining positions. We use reduced-form techniques to estimate the mergers' distributional impact, and show that competition benefits only consumers at the bottom and middle of the transaction price distribution, and that mergers reduce the dispersion of prices. We illustrate that these effects can be explained by the presence of search frictions, and that the average effect of mergers on rates underestimates the increase in market power. (JEL G21, G34, K21, L13, L41) </jats:p>
research_question: How does market concentration affect price dispersion in search markets, specifically examining the impact of mergers on the distribution of mortgage interest rates?
answer: Mergers in search markets reduce price dispersion and weaken consumers' bargaining positions, with competition benefiting only consumers at the bottom and middle of the transaction price distribution, while the average effect of mergers underestimates the true increase in market power.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on search markets and merger effects by providing empirical evidence from the Canadian mortgage industry, demonstrating that traditional average-effect analyses of mergers underestimate market power increases and that distributional effects reveal important insights about how search frictions interact with market concentration.

author: Jeanne Hagenbach
title: Capital Flow Management
abstract: <jats:p>There is a wide variety in the capital account policies of emerging markets and developing economies. Some countries, such as Brazil, have recently experimented with prudential controls on capital inflows, whereas others, such as China, have continued to maintain tight controls. This paper reviews the recent theoretical literature explaining the motivations behind capital account policies, and whether there is a case for international coordination in this area.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the theoretical motivations behind capital account policies in emerging markets and developing economies, and is there a case for international coordination in capital flow management?
answer: There is wide variety in capital account policies across emerging markets and developing economies, with different countries adopting different approaches ranging from prudential controls on inflows to tight comprehensive controls, and the theoretical literature provides explanations for these varied motivations.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as a review of the recent theoretical literature on capital flow management, examining the diverse policy approaches taken by emerging markets and developing economies and synthesizing existing theoretical explanations for these policy choices.

author: Jeanne Hagenbach
title: Strategic Communication Networks

author: Jeanne Hagenbach
title: Motivated Skepticism
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We experimentally study how individuals read strategically transmitted information when they have preferences over what they will learn. Subjects play disclosure games in which Receivers should interpret messages skeptically. We vary whether the state that Senders communicate about is ego-relevant or neutral for Receivers, and whether skeptical beliefs are aligned or not with what Receivers prefer believing. Compared to neutral settings, skepticism is significantly lower when it is self-threatening, and not enhanced when it is self-serving. These results shed light on a new channel that individuals can use to protect their beliefs in communication situations: they exercise skepticism in a motivated way, that is, in a way that depends on the desirability of the conclusions that skeptical inferences lead to. We propose two behavioural models that can generate motivated skepticism. In one model, the Receiver freely manipulates his beliefs after having made skeptical inferences. In the other, the Receiver reasons about evidence in steps and the depth of his reasoning is motivated.</jats:p>
research_question: How do individuals' preferences over what they will learn affect their skeptical interpretation of strategically transmitted information in disclosure games?
answer: Individuals exercise 'motivated skepticism' - they are significantly less skeptical when skeptical beliefs would be self-threatening, but do not increase skepticism when it would be self-serving, compared to neutral settings where they have no preferences over the information.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a new channel through which individuals protect their beliefs in communication situations - motivated skepticism - extending beyond existing literature on strategic communication by showing how receivers' preferences over learning outcomes systematically bias their interpretation of messages, even when they should rationally apply uniform skepticism.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: A Comment on: “Presidential Address: Economics and Measurement: New Measures to Model Decision Making” by Ingvild Almås, Orazio Attanasio, and Pamela Jervis

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: A Model of Scientific Communication
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a positive model of empirical science in which an analyst makes a report to an audience after observing some data. Agents in the audience may differ in their beliefs or objectives, and may therefore update or act differently following a given report. We contrast the proposed model with a classical model of statistics in which the report directly determines the payoff. We identify settings in which the predictions of the proposed model differ from those of the classical model, and seem to better match practice.</jats:p>
research_question: How does scientific communication work when an analyst reports findings to an audience with heterogeneous beliefs and objectives, and how does this differ from classical statistical models?
answer: The proposed model of scientific communication, where audience members with different beliefs and objectives update and act differently following reports, makes predictions that differ from classical statistical models and better matches actual scientific practice.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts its proposed positive model of empirical science with the classical model of statistics where reports directly determine payoffs, positioning itself as offering a more realistic alternative to traditional statistical communication models.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Measuring the Sensitivity of Parameter Estimates to Estimation Moments*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a local measure of the relationship between parameter estimates and the moments of the data they depend on. Our measure can be computed at negligible cost even for complex structural models. We argue that reporting this measure can increase the transparency of structural estimates, making it easier for readers to predict the way violations of identifying assumptions would affect the results. When the key assumptions are orthogonality between error terms and excluded instruments, we show that our measure provides a natural extension of the omitted variables bias formula for nonlinear models. We illustrate with applications to published articles in several fields of economics.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure the sensitivity of parameter estimates to the estimation moments they depend on in structural economic models?
answer: The authors propose a local measure that can be computed at negligible cost even for complex structural models, and when key assumptions involve orthogonality between error terms and excluded instruments, this measure provides a natural extension of the omitted variables bias formula for nonlinear models.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the need for increased transparency in structural estimation by providing a practical tool that extends existing omitted variables bias analysis to nonlinear models, filling a gap in methods for assessing the robustness of structural parameter estimates to violations of identifying assumptions.
