author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Pre-Event Trends in the Panel Event-Study Design
abstract: <jats:p> We consider a linear panel event-study design in which unobserved confounds may be related both to the outcome and to the policy variable of interest. We provide sufficient conditions to identify the causal effect of the policy by exploiting covariates related to the policy only through the confounds. Our model implies a set of moment equations that are linear in parameters. The effect of the policy can be estimated by 2SLS, and causal inference is valid even when endogeneity leads to pre-event trends (“pre-trends”) in the outcome. Alternative approaches perform poorly in our simulations. (JEL C23, C26) </jats:p>
research_question: How can researchers identify causal effects in panel event-study designs when unobserved confounds create endogeneity and lead to pre-event trends in the outcome variable?
answer: The causal effect of a policy can be identified using 2SLS estimation by exploiting covariates that are related to the policy only through the confounds, allowing for valid causal inference even in the presence of pre-trends caused by endogeneity.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a key limitation of existing panel event-study methods by providing a solution that works when endogeneity creates pre-event trends, whereas alternative approaches perform poorly in such situations according to the authors' simulations.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Measuring Group Differences in High‐Dimensional Choices: Method and Application to Congressional Speech
abstract: <jats:p>We study the problem of measuring group differences in choices when the dimensionality of the choice set is large. We show that standard approaches suffer from a severe finite‐sample bias, and we propose an estimator that applies recent advances in machine learning to address this bias. We apply this method to measure trends in the partisanship of congressional speech from 1873 to 2016, defining partisanship to be the ease with which an observer could infer a congressperson's party from a single utterance. Our estimates imply that partisanship is far greater in recent years than in the past, and that it increased sharply in the early 1990s after remaining low and relatively constant over the preceding century.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we accurately measure group differences in choices when the dimensionality of the choice set is large, and how has partisanship in congressional speech evolved from 1873 to 2016?
answer: Standard approaches suffer from severe finite-sample bias in high-dimensional settings, but machine learning advances can address this bias. Applied to congressional speech, partisanship is far greater in recent years than in the past, with a sharp increase in the early 1990s after remaining low and relatively constant over the preceding century.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses limitations of standard approaches for measuring group differences in high-dimensional choice settings by proposing a new estimator that incorporates recent advances in machine learning to correct for finite-sample bias.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: How Are SNAP Benefits Spent? Evidence from a Retail Panel
abstract: <jats:p> We use a novel retail panel with detailed transaction records to study the effect of the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) on household spending. We use administrative data to motivate three approaches to causal inference. The marginal propensity to consume SNAP-eligible food (MPCF) out of SNAP benefits is 0.5 to 0.6. The MPCF out of cash is much smaller. These patterns obtain even for households for whom SNAP benefits are economically equivalent to cash because their benefits are below their food spending. Using a semiparametric framework, we reject the hypothesis that households respect the fungibility of money. A model with mental accounting can match the facts. (JEL D12, H75, I12, I18, I38) </jats:p>
research_question: How do SNAP benefits affect household spending patterns, and do households treat SNAP benefits as equivalent to cash when making purchasing decisions?
answer: The marginal propensity to consume SNAP-eligible food out of SNAP benefits is 0.5 to 0.6, which is much higher than the marginal propensity to consume food out of cash. Households do not respect the fungibility of money - they do not treat SNAP benefits as equivalent to cash even when benefits are below their total food spending, and this behavior can be explained by mental accounting models.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a novel retail panel with detailed transaction records and administrative data to provide new empirical evidence on SNAP benefit spending patterns, employing three approaches to causal inference and a semiparametric framework to test economic theories about money fungibility that previous literature has not been able to definitively resolve.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: The Effect of Newspaper Entry and Exit on Electoral Politics
abstract: <jats:p> We use new data on entries and exits of US daily newspapers from 1869 to 2004 to estimate effects on political participation, party vote shares, and electoral competitiveness. Our identification strategy exploits the precise timing of these events and allows for the possibility of confounding trends. We focus our analysis on the years 1869– 1928, and we use the remaining years of data to look at changes over time. We find that newspapers have a robust positive effect on political participation, with one additional newspaper increasing both presidential and congressional turnout by approximately 0.3 percentage points. Newspaper competition is not a key driver of turnout: our effect is driven mainly by the first newspaper in a market, and the effect of a second or third paper is significantly smaller. The effect on presidential turnout diminishes after the introduction of radio and television, while the estimated effect on congressional turnout remains similar up to recent years. We find no evidence that partisan newspapers affect party vote shares, with confidence intervals that rule out even moderate-sized effects. We find no clear evidence that newspapers systematically help or hurt incumbents. (JEL D72, L11, L82, N41, N42, N81, N82) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of newspaper entry and exit on political participation, party vote shares, and electoral competitiveness?
answer: Newspapers have a robust positive effect on political participation, with one additional newspaper increasing both presidential and congressional turnout by approximately 0.3 percentage points. The effect is driven mainly by the first newspaper in a market, with diminishing returns from additional papers. There is no evidence that partisan newspapers affect party vote shares or systematically help or hurt incumbents.
positioning_statement: This paper uses new data on US daily newspaper entries and exits from 1869 to 2004 with an identification strategy that exploits precise timing of these events and allows for confounding trends, focusing analysis on 1869-1928 and examining changes over time through recent years to provide empirical evidence on media effects in electoral politics.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Can Higher Prices Stimulate Product Use? Evidence from a Field Experiment in Zambia
abstract: <jats:p> The controversy over how much to charge for health products in the developing world rests, in part, on whether higher prices can increase use, either by targeting distribution to high-use households (a screening effect), or by stimulating use psychologically through a sunk-cost effect. We develop a methodology for separating these two effects. We implement the methodology in a field experiment in Zambia using door-to-door marketing of a home water purification solution. We find evidence of economically important screening effects. By contrast, we find no consistent evidence of sunk-cost effects. (JEL C93, D12, I11, M31, O12) </jats:p>
research_question: Can higher prices increase product use through screening effects (targeting high-use households) or sunk-cost effects (psychological stimulation of use), and how can these two effects be separated and measured?
answer: Higher prices can increase product use through economically important screening effects that target distribution to high-use households, but there is no consistent evidence of sunk-cost effects that psychologically stimulate use.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the controversy over pricing health products in developing countries by developing a novel methodology to separate screening effects from sunk-cost effects, addressing a key gap in understanding the mechanisms through which higher prices might influence product use.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Competition and Ideological Diversity: Historical Evidence from US Newspapers
abstract: <jats:p> We study the competitive forces which shaped ideological diversity in the US press in the early twentieth century. We find that households preferred like-minded news and that newspapers used their political orientation to differentiate from competitors. We formulate a model of newspaper demand, entry, and political affiliation choice in which newspapers compete for both readers and advertisers. We use a combination of estimation and calibration to identify the model's parameters from novel data on newspaper circulation, costs, and revenues. The estimated model implies that competition enhances ideological diversity, that the market undersupplies diversity, and that optimal competition policy requires accounting for the two-sidedness of the news market. (JEL D72, K21, L13, L41, L82, N42, N72) </jats:p>
research_question: What competitive forces shaped ideological diversity in the US press in the early twentieth century, and how did competition affect the supply of ideological diversity in newspaper markets?
answer: Competition enhances ideological diversity in newspaper markets, but the market undersupplies diversity relative to the social optimum, and newspapers use political orientation as a differentiation strategy to compete for both readers and advertisers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing historical evidence and a formal model of how competition affects ideological diversity in media markets, specifically accounting for the two-sided nature of newspaper markets where firms compete for both readers and advertisers, and demonstrating that optimal competition policy must consider this dual market structure.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: On the Informativeness of Descriptive Statistics for Structural Estimates
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a way to formalize the relationship between descriptive analysis and structural estimation. A researcher reports an estimate<jats:italic>ĉ</jats:italic>of a structural quantity of interest<jats:italic>c</jats:italic>that is exactly or asymptotically unbiased under some base model. The researcher also reports descriptive statistics<a:math xmlns:a="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><a:mover accent="true"><a:mi>γ</a:mi><a:mo>ˆ</a:mo></a:mover></a:math>that estimate features<jats:italic>γ</jats:italic>of the distribution of the data that are related to<jats:italic>c</jats:italic>under the base model. A reader entertains a less restrictive model that is local to the base model, under which the estimate<jats:italic>ĉ</jats:italic>may be biased. We study the reduction in worst‐case bias from a restriction that requires the reader's model to respect the relationship between<jats:italic>c</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>γ</jats:italic>specified by the base model. Our main result shows that the proportional reduction in worst‐case bias depends only on a quantity we call the<jats:italic>informativeness</jats:italic>of<d:math xmlns:d="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="inline"><d:mover accent="true"><d:mi>γ</d:mi><d:mo>ˆ</d:mo></d:mover></d:math>for<jats:italic>ĉ</jats:italic>. Informativeness can be easily estimated even for complex models. We recommend that researchers report estimated informativeness alongside their descriptive analyses, and we illustrate with applications to three recent papers.</jats:p>
research_question: How can the relationship between descriptive analysis and structural estimation be formalized, and how much do descriptive statistics reduce the potential bias in structural estimates when readers consider alternative models?
answer: The proportional reduction in worst-case bias of structural estimates depends only on a quantity called 'informativeness' of descriptive statistics for the structural estimate, which can be easily estimated even for complex models and provides a measurable way to assess how much descriptive statistics constrain potential bias.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a novel framework to formalize the connection between descriptive analysis and structural estimation, addressing a gap in the literature by providing a systematic way to quantify how descriptive statistics can reduce bias concerns when readers consider models that deviate from the researcher's base assumptions.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Pricing Power in Advertising Markets: Theory and Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> Existing theories of media competition imply that advertisers will pay a lower price in equilibrium to reach consumers who multi-home across competing outlets. We generalize and extend this theoretical result and test it using data from television and social media advertising. We find that the model is a good match, qualitatively and quantitatively, to variation in advertising prices across demographic groups, outlets, platforms, and over time. We use the model to quantify the effects of competition within and across platforms. (JEL G34, K21, L13, L82, M37) </jats:p>
research_question: How does consumer multi-homing behavior across competing media outlets affect the pricing power of advertising platforms and the prices advertisers pay to reach those consumers?
answer: Advertisers pay lower prices in equilibrium to reach consumers who multi-home across competing outlets, and this theoretical prediction matches well with empirical variation in advertising prices across demographic groups, outlets, platforms, and over time in both television and social media markets.
positioning_statement: This paper generalizes and extends existing theories of media competition that predict lower advertising prices for multi-homing consumers, providing both theoretical advancement and empirical validation using comprehensive data from television and social media advertising markets.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Structural Estimation Under Misspecification: Theory and Implications for Practice
abstract:
<jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A researcher can use a tightly parameterized structural model to obtain internally consistent estimates of a wide range of economically interesting targets. We ask how reliable these estimates are when the researcher’s model may be misspecified. We focus on the case of multivariate, potentially nonlinear models where the causal variable of interest is endogenous. Reliable estimates require that the researcher’s model is flexible enough to describe the effects of the endogenous variable approximately correctly. Reliable estimates do not require that the researcher has correctly specified the role of the exogenous controls in the model. However, if the role of the controls is misspecified, reliable estimates require a property we call strong exclusion. Strong exclusion depends on having sufficiently many instruments that are unrelated to the controls. We discuss how practitioners can achieve strong exclusion, and illustrate our findings with an application to a differentiated goods model of demand for beer.</jats:p>
research_question: How reliable are structural model estimates of economically interesting targets when the researcher's model may be misspecified?
answer: Reliable estimates require that the model is flexible enough to describe the effects of the endogenous variable approximately correctly, but do not require correct specification of exogenous controls' role. However, if controls are misspecified, reliable estimates require 'strong exclusion' - having sufficiently many instruments that are unrelated to the controls.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the gap in understanding how model misspecification affects the reliability of structural estimation in multivariate, potentially nonlinear models with endogenous variables, introducing the concept of 'strong exclusion' as a key requirement for reliable estimates under misspecification.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Labor Market Returns and the Evolution of Cognitive Skills: Theory and Evidence
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A large literature in cognitive science studies the puzzling “Flynn effect” of rising fluid intelligence (reasoning skill) in rich countries. We develop an economic model in which a cohort’s mix of skills is determined by different skills’ relative returns in the labor market and by the technology for producing skills. We estimate the model using administrative data from Sweden. Combining data from exams taken at military enlistment with earnings records from the tax register, we document an increase in the relative labor market return to logical reasoning skill as compared to vocabulary knowledge. The estimated model implies that changes in labor market returns explain 37% of the measured increase in reasoning skill, and can also explain the decline in knowledge. An original survey of parents, an analysis of trends in school curricula, and an analysis of occupational characteristics show evidence of increasing emphasis on reasoning as compared to knowledge.</jats:p>
research_question: What explains the Flynn effect of rising fluid intelligence (reasoning skill) in rich countries, and specifically how do changes in labor market returns influence the evolution of cognitive skills?
answer: Changes in labor market returns explain 37% of the measured increase in reasoning skill. The study finds an increase in the relative labor market return to logical reasoning skill compared to vocabulary knowledge, which drives individuals to invest more in developing reasoning skills rather than knowledge acquisition.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the large literature in cognitive science studying the Flynn effect by providing an economic framework that explains rising fluid intelligence through labor market incentives, offering a novel economic perspective on a phenomenon traditionally studied from psychological and cognitive science viewpoints.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: A Taste of Their Own Medicine: Guideline Adherence and Access to Expertise
abstract: <jats:p> We use administrative data from Sweden to study adherence to 63 medication-related guidelines. We compare the adherence of patients without personal access to medical expertise to that of patients with access, namely doctors and their close relatives. We estimate that observably similar patients with access to expertise have 3.8 percentage points lower adherence, relative to a baseline adherence rate of 54.4 percent among those without access. Our findings suggest an important role in nonadherence for factors other than those, such as ignorance, poor communication, and complexity, that would be expected to diminish with access to expertise.(JEL D82, D83, I11, I12, I18) </jats:p>
research_question: How does personal access to medical expertise affect adherence to medication-related guidelines?
answer: Patients with access to medical expertise (doctors and their close relatives) have 3.8 percentage points lower adherence to medication guidelines compared to patients without such access, relative to a baseline adherence rate of 54.4 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on medication adherence by demonstrating that factors beyond ignorance, poor communication, and complexity play an important role in nonadherence, as evidenced by lower adherence rates among those with better access to medical knowledge.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Patent Remedies
abstract: <jats:p> Since the Supreme Court's eBay decision in 2006, the U.S. has employed a hybrid patent remedy system that mixes property and liability rules. When the patent owner and the infringer are competitors, the courts typically issue a permanent injunction requiring the infringer to cease its infringing activities. In contrast, when the patent owner and the infringer are not competitors, the courts often allow the infringer to continue its infringing activities so long as it pays specified ongoing royalties to the patent holder. This article studies the incentives for invention and for new product development in such a hybrid system. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the incentives for invention and for new product development in the U.S. hybrid patent remedy system that mixes property and liability rules following the Supreme Court's eBay decision in 2006?
answer: The hybrid system creates different incentive structures depending on the competitive relationship between patent owners and infringers - with permanent injunctions (property rules) applied when parties are competitors and ongoing royalty payments (liability rules) applied when they are not competitors.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes the post-eBay hybrid patent remedy system as a distinct institutional framework that combines property and liability rules, studying its unique incentive effects on innovation that differ from traditional single-rule patent systems.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Do Pharmacists Buy Bayer? Informed Shoppers and the Brand Premium *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We estimate the effect of information and expertise on consumers’ willingness to pay for national brands in physically homogeneous product categories. In a detailed case study of headache remedies, we find that more informed or expert consumers are less likely to pay extra to buy national brands, with pharmacists choosing them over store brands only 9 percent of the time, compared to 26 percent of the time for the average consumer. In a similar case study of pantry staples such as salt and sugar, we show that chefs devote 12 percentage points less of their purchases to national brands than demographically similar nonchefs. We extend our analysis to cover 50 retail health categories and 241 food and drink categories. The results suggest that misinformation and related consumer mistakes explain a sizable share of the brand premium for health products, and a much smaller share for most food and drink products. We tie our estimates together using a stylized model of demand and pricing.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of information and expertise on consumers' willingness to pay for national brands in physically homogeneous product categories?
answer: More informed or expert consumers are significantly less likely to pay premiums for national brands - pharmacists choose national brands only 9% of the time versus 26% for average consumers, and chefs devote 12 percentage points less of their purchases to national brands than similar non-chefs. Misinformation explains a sizable share of brand premiums for health products but much smaller shares for food and drink products.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on consumer behavior and brand premiums by providing empirical evidence that consumer mistakes and misinformation, rather than rational preferences, explain significant portions of brand premiums in certain product categories, particularly health products, using expert consumers as a benchmark for informed decision-making.

author: Jessica Wachter
title: A Retrieved-Context Theory of Financial Decisions
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Studies of human memory indicate that features of an event evoke memories of prior associated contextual states, which in turn become associated with the current event’s features. This retrieved-context mechanism allows the remote past to influence the present, even as agents gradually update their beliefs about their environment. We apply a version of retrieved-context theory, drawn from the literature on human memory, to explain three types of evidence in the financial economics literature: the role of early life experience in shaping investment choices, occurrence of financial crises, and the effect of fear on asset allocation. These applications suggest a recasting of neoclassical rational expectations in terms of beliefs as governed by principles of human memory.</jats:p>
research_question: How can retrieved-context theory from human memory literature explain financial decision-making patterns that deviate from neoclassical rational expectations?
answer: A retrieved-context mechanism, where features of current events evoke memories of prior associated contextual states that become associated with current features, can explain three key financial phenomena: how early life experiences shape investment choices, the occurrence of financial crises, and the effect of fear on asset allocation.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as offering an alternative to neoclassical rational expectations by recasting beliefs in financial decision-making through principles of human memory, specifically applying retrieved-context theory from the memory literature to financial economics.

author: Jesse M. Shapiro
title: Patent Remedies
abstract: <jats:p> Since the Supreme Court's eBay decision in 2006, the U.S. has employed a hybrid patent remedy system that mixes property and liability rules. When the patent owner and the infringer are competitors, the courts typically issue a permanent injunction requiring the infringer to cease its infringing activities. In contrast, when the patent owner and the infringer are not competitors, the courts often allow the infringer to continue its infringing activities so long as it pays specified ongoing royalties to the patent holder. This article studies the incentives for invention and for new product development in such a hybrid system. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the incentives for invention and for new product development in the U.S. hybrid patent remedy system that mixes property and liability rules following the Supreme Court's eBay decision in 2006?
answer: The hybrid system creates different incentive structures depending on the competitive relationship between patent owners and infringers - with permanent injunctions (property rules) applied when parties are competitors and ongoing royalty payments (liability rules) applied when they are not competitors.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes the post-eBay hybrid patent remedy system as a distinct institutional framework that combines property and liability rules, studying its unique incentive effects on innovation that differ from traditional single-rule patent systems.

author: Jia Li
title: Generalized Method of Integrated Moments for High-Frequency Data
abstract: We propose a semiparametric two‐step inference procedure for a finite‐dimensional parameter based on moment conditions constructed from high‐frequency data. The population moment conditions take the form of temporally integrated functionals of state‐variable processes that include the latent stochastic volatility process of an asset. In the first step, we nonparametrically recover the volatility path from high‐frequency asset returns. The nonparametric volatility estimator is then used to form sample moment functions in the second‐step GMM estimation, which requires the correction of a high‐order nonlinearity bias from the first step. We show that the proposed estimator is consistent and asymptotically mixed Gaussian and propose a consistent estimator for the conditional asymptotic variance. We also construct a Bierens‐type consistent specification test. These infill asymptotic results are based on a novel empirical‐process‐type theory for general integrated functionals of noisy semimartingale processes.

author: Jianfeng Yu
title: Financial Entanglement: A Theory of Incomplete Integration, Leverage, Crashes, and Contagion
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a unified model of limited market integration, asset-price determination, leveraging, and contagion. Investors and firms are located on a circle, and access to markets involves participation costs that increase with distance. Due to a complementarity between participation and leverage decisions, the equilibrium may exhibit diverse leverage and participation choices across investors, although investors are ex ante identical. Small changes in market-access costs can cause a change in the type of equilibrium, leading to discontinuous price changes, deleveraging, and portfolio-flow reversals. Moreover, the market is subject to contagion—an adverse shock to investors in some locations affects prices everywhere. (JEL D83, G11, G12, G32, G35) </jats:p>
research_question: How do market participation costs, leverage decisions, and limited market integration interact to create financial instability, crashes, and contagion effects?
answer: Due to complementarity between participation and leverage decisions, small changes in market-access costs can cause discontinuous equilibrium shifts leading to price crashes, deleveraging, and portfolio reversals, while adverse shocks in some market locations spread everywhere through contagion effects.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified theoretical framework that integrates previously separate concepts of limited market integration, asset pricing, leverage decisions, and contagion into a single model, offering a comprehensive explanation for financial instability phenomena.

author: Joachim Freyberger
title: On Completeness and Consistency in Nonparametric Instrumental Variable Models
abstract: This paper provides positive testability results for the identification condition in a nonparametric instrumental variable model, known as completeness, and it links the outcome of the test to properties of an estimator of the structural function. In particular, I show that the data can provide empirical evidence in favor of both an arbitrarily small identified set as well as an arbitrarily small asymptotic bias of the estimator. This is the case for a large class of complete distributions as well as certain incomplete distributions. As a byproduct, the results can be used to estimate an upper bound of the diameter of the identified set and to obtain an easy to report estimator of the identified set itself.

author: Joachim Freyberger
title: Non-parametric Panel Data Models with Interactive Fixed Effects

author: Johanna Rickne
title: Sexual Harassment and Gender Inequality in the Labor Market
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We describe how sexual harassment contributes to sex segregation and pay inequality in the labor market. Combining nationally representative survey data and administrative data, we show that both harassment and wages vary strongly and systematically across workplaces. Women self-report more harassment from colleagues and managers in male-dominated workplaces where wages are relatively high, and men self-report more harassment in female-dominated workplaces where wages are low. These patterns imply two ways that harassment may contribute to gender inequality. First, harassment deters women and men from applying for jobs in workplaces where they are the gender minority. A survey experiment with hypothetical job choices supports this mechanism. Respondents are highly averse to accepting jobs in workplaces with a higher harassment risk for their own gender, but less averse when people of the opposite sex are at higher risk. A second way that harassment contributes to inequality is by making workplace gender minorities leave their workplaces for new jobs. An analysis of workplace transitions supports this mechanism. Women who self-report harassment are more likely to switch to new workplaces with more female colleagues and lower pay.</jats:p>
research_question: How does sexual harassment contribute to sex segregation and pay inequality in the labor market?
answer: Sexual harassment contributes to gender inequality through two main mechanisms: (1) it deters women and men from applying for jobs in workplaces where they are the gender minority, and (2) it causes workplace gender minorities to leave for new jobs, with harassed women switching to workplaces with more female colleagues but lower pay.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing new empirical evidence on the role of sexual harassment in labor market outcomes by combining nationally representative survey data with administrative data to systematically document how harassment varies across workplaces and directly contributes to occupational segregation and wage gaps.

author: Joachim Freyberger
title: How Well Does Bargaining Work in Consumer Markets? A Robust Bounds Approach
abstract: <jats:p>This study provides a structural analysis of detailed, alternating‐offer bargaining data from eBay, deriving bounds on buyers and sellers private value distributions and the gains from trade using a range of assumptions on behavior and the informational environment. These assumptions range from weak (assuming only that acceptance and rejection decisions are rational) to less weak (e.g., assuming that bargaining offers are weakly increasing in players' private values). We estimate the bounds and show what they imply for consumer negotiation behavior and inefficient breakdown. For the median product, bargaining ends in impasse in 37% of negotiations even when the buyer values the good more than the seller.</jats:p>
research_question: How well does bargaining work in consumer markets, specifically examining the efficiency of alternating-offer bargaining and the extent of inefficient breakdown in negotiations?
answer: Bargaining in consumer markets works poorly, with negotiations ending in impasse 37% of the time for the median product even when the buyer values the good more than the seller, indicating substantial inefficiency from bargaining breakdown.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing the first structural analysis of detailed alternating-offer bargaining data from a real consumer market (eBay), using a robust bounds approach that accommodates a range of behavioral and informational assumptions rather than relying on restrictive parametric models.

author: Joan Llull
title: Immigration, Wages, and Education: A Labour Market Equilibrium Structural Model

author: Joachim Freyberger
title: Normalizations and Misspecification in Skill Formation Models
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>An important class of structural models studies the determinants of skill formation and the optimal timing of interventions. In this article, I provide new identification results for these models and investigate the effects of seemingly innocuous scale and location restrictions on parameters of interest. To do so, I first characterize the identified set of all parameters without these additional restrictions and show that important policy-relevant parameters are point identified under weaker assumptions than commonly used in the literature. The implications of imposing standard scale and location restrictions depend on how the model is specified, but they generally impact the interpretation of parameters and may affect counterfactuals. Importantly, with the popular constant elasticity of substitution (CES) production function, commonly used scale restrictions fix identified parameters and lead to misspecification. Consequently, simply changing the units of measurements of observed variables might yield ineffective investment strategies and misleading policy recommendations. I show how existing estimators can easily be adapted to solve these issues. As a byproduct, this article also presents a general and formal definition of when restrictions are truly normalizations.</jats:p>
research_question: How do scale and location restrictions (normalizations) affect the identification and interpretation of parameters in structural models of skill formation, and what are the implications for policy recommendations?
answer: Scale and location restrictions commonly used in skill formation models can lead to misspecification and affect policy-relevant parameters, particularly with CES production functions where standard scale restrictions fix identified parameters. This can result in ineffective investment strategies and misleading policy recommendations, but existing estimators can be adapted to solve these issues.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new identification results for skill formation models under weaker assumptions than commonly used in the literature, and demonstrates that important policy-relevant parameters are point identified without the standard restrictions that previous work has relied upon.

author: Johanna Rickne
title: Gender Quotas and the Crisis of the Mediocre Man: Theory and Evidence from Sweden
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a model where party leaders choose the competence of politicians on the ballot to trade off electoral success against their own survival. The predicted correlation between the competence of party leaders and followers is strongly supported in Swedish data. We use a novel approach, based on register data for the earnings of the whole population, to measure the competence of all politicians in 7 parties, 290 municipalities, and 10 elections (for the period 1982–2014). We ask how competence was affected by a zipper quota, requiring local parties to alternate men and women on the ballot, implemented by the Social Democratic Party in 1993. Far from being at odds with meritocracy, this quota raised the competence of male politicians where it raised female representation the most. We argue that resignation of mediocre male leaders was a key driver of this effect. (JEL D72, J16) </jats:p>
research_question: How did the zipper quota requiring alternating men and women on ballots affect the competence of politicians, particularly male politicians, in Swedish local parties?
answer: The zipper quota raised the competence of male politicians where it raised female representation the most, primarily through the resignation of mediocre male leaders, demonstrating that the quota enhanced rather than undermined meritocracy.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that gender quotas are at odds with meritocracy by developing a theoretical model of party leader selection and providing empirical evidence that quotas can actually improve overall politician competence, using a novel approach based on population-wide earnings data to measure competence.

author: Johanna Rickne
title: Who Becomes A Politician?*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Can a democracy attract competent leaders, while attaining broad representation? Economic models suggest that free-riding incentives and lower opportunity costs give the less competent a comparative advantage at entering political life. Moreover, if elites have more human capital, selecting on competence may lead to uneven representation. This article examines patterns of political selection among the universe of municipal politicians and national legislators in Sweden, using extraordinarily rich data on competence traits and social background for the entire population. We document four new facts that together characterize an “inclusive meritocracy.” First, politicians are on average significantly smarter and better leaders than the population they represent. Second, this positive selection is present even when conditioning on family (and hence social) background, suggesting that individual competence is key for selection. Third, the representation of social background, whether measured by parental earnings or occupational social class, is remarkably even. Fourth, there is at best a weak trade-off in selection between competence and social representation, mainly due to strong positive selection of politicians of low (parental) socioeconomic status. A broad implication of these facts is that it is possible for democracy to generate competent and socially representative leadership.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a democracy attract competent leaders while attaining broad representation?
answer: Yes, democracy can generate both competent and socially representative leadership - politicians are significantly smarter and better leaders than average, yet representation across social backgrounds is remarkably even, with only a weak trade-off between competence and social representation.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing economic models that suggest free-riding incentives and lower opportunity costs give the less competent a comparative advantage in politics, and that selecting on competence leads to uneven representation, by providing empirical evidence of an 'inclusive meritocracy' using comprehensive data on Swedish politicians.

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: The Value of Unemployment Insurance
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Due to the absence of unemployment insurance (UI) choices, the traditional approach to estimating the value of UI is to infer it from the observed consumption response to job loss under some assumption on risk preferences. Exploiting the rich data and unique policy context in Sweden, we propose two alternative approaches that relax this assumption and we implement all three methods on the same sample of workers. The first approach considers the difference in marginal propensity to consume (MPC) when unemployed versus employed, which allows to identify the difference in prices to smooth consumption in the respective states. The second approach exploits UI choices embedded in the Swedish UI system in a Revealed Preference approach. While the drop in consumption expenditures is relatively small ($\sim$13%), we find that the MPC is around 25% higher when unemployed than employed, translating into a marginal value of transfers that is at least $60$% higher when unemployed than employed. This high value of UI is confirmed by our RP estimates and indicates substantial risk aversion given the relatively small drop in consumption expenditures.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the value of unemployment insurance to workers, and how can this value be estimated without relying on assumptions about risk preferences?
answer: The marginal value of transfers is at least 60% higher when unemployed than employed, indicating substantial risk aversion despite a relatively small (13%) drop in consumption expenditures. The marginal propensity to consume is around 25% higher when unemployed versus employed.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as an alternative to the traditional approach of estimating UI value by inferring it from consumption responses to job loss under risk preference assumptions. Instead, it proposes two new approaches that relax these assumptions: comparing marginal propensity to consume between unemployed and employed states, and exploiting UI choices in Sweden's system using a Revealed Preference approach.

author: Johanna Rickne
title: Economic and Social Outsiders but Political Insiders: Sweden’s Populist Radical Right
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats, a major populist radical-right party. Based on detailed administrative data, we present the first comprehensive account of which politicians are selected into such a party. Surveys show that politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats share strong anti-establishment and anti-immigration attitudes that drastically set them apart from Sweden’s other parties. Searching for individual traits that link naturally to these attitudes, we classify the universe of Swedish politicians and voters by social and economic marginalization and exposure to immigration. Politicians from the Sweden Democrats over-represent marginalized groups without strong attachments to the labour market or to traditional nuclear families, which instead are under-represented among politicians in all other parties. Among voters, the Sweden Democrats have higher electoral support in precincts with higher shares of the same marginalized groups. We see the mobilization of the marginalized as an important driver of the party’s success. Finally, we uncover that Sweden-Democrat politicians score lower on a number of valence traits than other-party politicians. In sum, the rise of the Sweden Democrats raised political representation for marginalized groups, but this came at a valence cost.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the characteristics of politicians and voters of the Sweden Democrats (a populist radical-right party), and how do these characteristics relate to the party's political success?
answer: Sweden Democrats politicians over-represent economically and socially marginalized groups without strong labor market attachments or traditional family ties, while their voters concentrate in precincts with higher shares of these same marginalized groups. The party's success is driven by mobilizing the marginalized, though this comes at a cost as Sweden Democrat politicians score lower on valence traits compared to other parties.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first comprehensive account of politician selection in a populist radical-right party using detailed administrative data, filling a gap in understanding the individual-level characteristics that link to anti-establishment and anti-immigration attitudes in such parties.

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: The Nature of Long-Term Unemployment: Predictability, Heterogeneity, and Selection

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: The Socioeconomic Distribution of Choice Quality: Evidence from Health Insurance in the Netherlands
abstract: <jats:p> We study how choice quality relates to socioeconomic factors, using population-wide data on health insurance choices and utilization in the Netherlands. We document a striking choice quality gradient with respect to socioeconomic status, finding that those with higher income, higher education, and training in quantitative fields make meaningfully better choices. Household income for the top 5 percent of decision-makers, in terms of surplus captured, is almost three times higher than for the bottom 5 percent. When jointly including all factors, education degree and field of study are more important predictors of choice quality than income and other financial variables. (JEL D31, G22, G52, I13, L15) </jats:p>
research_question: How does choice quality in health insurance decisions relate to socioeconomic factors such as income, education, and field of study?
answer: There is a striking choice quality gradient with respect to socioeconomic status - those with higher income, higher education, and training in quantitative fields make meaningfully better health insurance choices, with education degree and field of study being more important predictors than income when all factors are considered jointly.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing population-wide empirical evidence on the relationship between socioeconomic characteristics and decision-making quality in health insurance markets, using comprehensive data from the Netherlands to quantify how choice quality varies across different demographic and economic groups.

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: Job Seekers’ Perceptions and Employment Prospects: Heterogeneity, Duration Dependence, and Bias
abstract: <jats:p> This paper uses job seekers’ elicited beliefs about job finding to disentangle the sources of the decline in job-finding rates by duration of unemployment. We document that beliefs have strong predictive power for job finding, but are not revised downward when remaining unemployed and are subject to optimistic bias, especially for the long-term unemployed. Leveraging the predictive power of beliefs, we find substantial heterogeneity in job finding with the resulting dynamic selection explaining most of the observed negative duration dependence in job finding. Moreover, job seekers’ beliefs underreact to heterogeneity in job finding, distorting search behavior and increasing long-term unemployment. (JEL D83, E24, J22, J64, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the sources of the decline in job-finding rates by duration of unemployment, and how do job seekers' beliefs about job finding contribute to this phenomenon?
answer: The decline in job-finding rates is primarily explained by substantial heterogeneity in job finding and resulting dynamic selection rather than true duration dependence. Job seekers' beliefs have strong predictive power but are subject to optimistic bias and underreact to heterogeneity, which distorts search behavior and increases long-term unemployment.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on unemployment duration dependence by using a novel approach of analyzing job seekers' elicited beliefs to disentangle the sources of declining job-finding rates, providing new evidence on the role of heterogeneity versus true duration dependence and identifying belief biases that affect search behavior.

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: The Optimal Timing of Unemployment Benefits: Theory and Evidence from Sweden
abstract: <jats:p> This paper provides a simple, yet robust framework to evaluate the time profile of benefits paid during an unemployment spell. We derive sufficient-statistics formulae capturing the marginal insurance value and incentive costs of unemployment benefits paid at different times during a spell. Our approach allows us to revisit separate arguments for inclining or declining profiles put forward in the theoretical literature and to identify welfare-improving changes in the benefit profile that account for all relevant arguments jointly. For the empirical implementation, we use administrative data on unemployment, linked to data on consumption, income, and wealth in Sweden. First, we exploit duration-dependent kinks in the replacement rate and find that, if anything, the moral hazard cost of benefits is larger when paid earlier in the spell. Second, we find that the drop in consumption affecting the insurance value of benefits is large from the start of the spell, but further increases throughout the spell. In trading off insurance and incentives, our analysis suggests that the flat benefit profile in Sweden has been too generous overall. However, both from the insurance and the incentives side, we find no evidence to support the introduction of a declining tilt in the profile. (JEL D82, E21, E24, J64, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal time profile of unemployment benefits during an unemployment spell, considering both insurance value and incentive costs?
answer: The flat benefit profile in Sweden has been too generous overall, but there is no evidence to support introducing a declining benefit profile - both insurance and incentive considerations argue against a declining tilt in benefits over the unemployment spell duration.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified framework that revisits and reconciles separate theoretical arguments for inclining or declining benefit profiles in the existing literature, using sufficient-statistics formulae to jointly account for all relevant insurance and incentive arguments rather than considering them in isolation.

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: Retirement Consumption and Pension Design
abstract: <jats:p> This paper analyzes consumption to evaluate the distributional effects of pension reforms. Using Swedish administrative data, we show that on average, workers who retire earlier consume less while retired and experience larger drops in consumption around retirement. Interpreted via a theoretical model, these findings imply that reforms incentivizing later retirement incur a substantial consumption smoothing cost. Turning to other features of pension policy, we find that reforms that redistribute based on early-career labor supply would have opposite-signed redistributive effects, while differentiating on wealth may help to target pension benefits toward those who are vulnerable to larger drops in consumption around retirement. (JEL E21, G51, H23, H55, J22, J26) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the distributional effects of pension reforms on consumption patterns, particularly examining how retirement timing affects consumption levels and consumption drops around retirement?
answer: Workers who retire earlier consume less while retired and experience larger drops in consumption around retirement, implying that reforms incentivizing later retirement incur substantial consumption smoothing costs. Additionally, reforms redistributing based on early-career labor supply would have opposite-signed redistributive effects, while wealth-based differentiation could better target benefits to those vulnerable to larger consumption drops.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the pension reform literature by using Swedish administrative data to analyze consumption patterns and evaluate distributional effects through a theoretical model framework, providing new insights on the consumption smoothing costs of retirement timing incentives and alternative redistribution mechanisms in pension design.

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: Risk-Based Selection in Unemployment Insurance: Evidence and Implications
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies whether adverse selection can rationalize a universal mandate for unemployment insurance (UI). Building on a unique feature of the unemployment policy in Sweden, where workers can opt for supplemental UI coverage above a minimum mandate, we provide the first direct evidence for adverse selection in UI and derive its implications for UI design. We find that the unemployment risk is more than twice as high for workers who buy supplemental coverage. Exploiting variation in risk and prices, we show how 25–30 percent of this correlation is driven by risk-based selection, with the remainder driven by moral hazard. Due to the moral hazard and despite the adverse selection we find that mandating the supplemental coverage to individuals with low willingness-to-pay would be suboptimal. We show under which conditions a design leaving choice to workers would dominate a UI system with a single mandate. In this design, using a subsidy for supplemental coverage is optimal and complementary to the use of a minimum mandate. (JEL D82, G22, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: Can adverse selection rationalize a universal mandate for unemployment insurance?
answer: Despite finding evidence of adverse selection in unemployment insurance (with unemployment risk more than twice as high for workers who buy supplemental coverage), mandating supplemental coverage to individuals with low willingness-to-pay would be suboptimal due to moral hazard effects. A design that leaves choice to workers, combined with subsidies for supplemental coverage and a minimum mandate, can dominate a single universal mandate system.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first direct evidence for adverse selection in unemployment insurance by exploiting a unique feature of Sweden's unemployment policy where workers can opt for supplemental coverage above a minimum mandate, filling a gap in the literature that previously lacked direct empirical evidence of risk-based selection in UI markets.

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: Erratum: Production versus Revenue Efficiency with Limited Tax Capacity: Theory and Evidence from Pakistan

author: Johannes Spinnewijn
title: How to Improve Tax Compliance? Evidence from Population-Wide Experiments in Belgium
abstract: We study the impact of simplification, deterrence, and tax morale on tax compliance. We ran four natural field experiments varying the communication of the tax administration with the universe of income taxpayers in Belgium throughout the tax process. A consistent picture emerges across experiments: (i) simplifying communication substantially increases compliance, (ii) deterrence messages have an additional positive effect, (iii) invoking tax morale is not effective and often backfires. A discontinuity in enforcement intensity, combined with the experimental variation, allows us to compare simplification with standard enforcement measures. We find that simplification is far more cost-effective, allowing for substantial savings on enforcement costs.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Very Long-Run Discount Rates *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We estimate how households trade off immediate costs and uncertain future benefits that occur in the very long run, 100 or more years away. We exploit a unique feature of housing markets in the United Kingdom and Singapore, where residential property ownership takes the form of either leaseholds or freeholds. Leaseholds are temporary, prepaid, and tradable ownership contracts with maturities between 99 and 999 years, while freeholds are perpetual ownership contracts. The price difference between leaseholds and freeholds reflects the present value of perpetual rental income starting at leasehold expiration, and is thus informative about very long-run discount rates. We estimate the price discounts for varying leasehold maturities compared to freeholds and extremely long-run leaseholds via hedonic regressions using proprietary data sets of the universe of transactions in each country. Households discount very long-run cash flows at low rates, assigning high present value to cash flows hundreds of years in the future. For example, 100-year leaseholds are valued at more than 10% less than otherwise identical freeholds, implying discount rates below 2.6% for 100-year claims.</jats:p>
research_question: How do households trade off immediate costs and uncertain future benefits that occur in the very long run, 100 or more years away?
answer: Households discount very long-run cash flows at low rates, assigning high present value to cash flows hundreds of years in the future. For example, 100-year leaseholds are valued at more than 10% less than otherwise identical freeholds, implying discount rates below 2.6% for 100-year claims.
positioning_statement: This paper exploits a unique feature of housing markets in the United Kingdom and Singapore, where residential property ownership takes the form of either leaseholds or freeholds, to estimate very long-run discount rates - an approach that provides novel empirical evidence on household valuation of extremely distant future cash flows.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Segmented Housing Search
abstract: <jats:p> We study housing markets with multiple segments searched by heterogeneous clienteles. In the San Francisco Bay Area, search activity and inventory covary negatively across cities, but positively across market segments within cities. A quantitative search model shows how the endogenous flow of broad searchers to high-inventory segments within their search ranges induces a positive relationship between inventory and search activity across segments with a large common clientele. The prevalence of broad searchers shapes the response of housing markets to localized supply and demand shocks. Broad searchers help spread shocks across many segments and reduce their effect on local market activity. (JEL D83, R21, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How do heterogeneous searchers behave across different housing market segments, and what explains the varying relationships between search activity and inventory across versus within geographic markets?
answer: Broad searchers endogenously flow to high-inventory segments within their search ranges, creating a positive relationship between inventory and search activity across segments with large common clienteles, while their prevalence helps spread localized shocks across many segments and reduces effects on local market activity.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to housing search literature by introducing the concept of segmented markets with heterogeneous clienteles, explaining previously unexplained empirical patterns where search activity and inventory covary negatively across cities but positively within cities across market segments.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Reply to “Rational Bubbles in UK Housing Markets”
abstract: <jats:p>In Giglio, Maggiori, and Stroebel (2016), we propose and implement a new test for classic rational bubbles. Such bubbles derive their value from each agent's rational expectation of being able to resell the bubble claims to the next agent. Backward induction ensures that classic rational bubbles can only exist on infinite‐maturity assets. Our empirical exercise shows that infinite‐maturity claims and 999‐year claims for otherwise identical housing assets trade at the same price, and thus rules out the presence of classic rational bubbles. Domeij and Ellingsen (DE) informally propose an alternative equilibrium of a bubble that they claim is consistent with our empirical findings. DE's bubble relies on information frictions such that market participants are unaware of the bubble. Our paper clearly excluded this type of bubble from the scope of our test, and DE's note thus has no implications for the validity of our test. Instead, DE's bubble simply represents one of many possible examples of bubbles on which our test was explicitly silent.</jats:p>
research_question: How to respond to Domeij and Ellingsen's critique of the test for classic rational bubbles in housing markets?
answer: Domeij and Ellingsen's proposed alternative bubble equilibrium based on information frictions is outside the scope of the original test for classic rational bubbles, and therefore does not invalidate the test's validity or findings.
positioning_statement: This paper defends the original methodology by clarifying that it was designed specifically to test for classic rational bubbles (which require rational expectations of resale and can only exist on infinite-maturity assets), while explicitly excluding bubbles based on information frictions that DE proposes, thus maintaining that DE's critique does not affect the validity of their test.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: No-Bubble Condition: Model-Free Tests in Housing Markets
abstract: We test for the existence of housing bubbles associated with a failure of the transversality condition that requires the present value of payments occurring infinitely far in the future to be zero. The most prominent such bubble is the classic rational bubble. We study housing markets in the United Kingdom and Singapore, where residential property ownership takes the form of either leaseholds or freeholds. Leaseholds are finite‐maturity, pre‐paid, and tradeable ownership contracts with maturities often exceeding 700 years. Freeholds are infinite‐maturity ownership contracts. The price difference between leaseholds with extremely‐long maturities and freeholds reflects the present value of a claim to the freehold after leasehold expiry, and is thus a direct empirical measure of the transversality condition. We estimate this price difference, and find no evidence of failures of the transversality condition in housing markets in the U.K. and Singapore, even during periods when a sizable bubble was regularly thought to be present.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: House Price Beliefs And Mortgage Leverage Choice
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the relationship between homebuyers’ beliefs about future house price changes and their mortgage leverage choices. Whether more pessimistic homebuyers choose higher or lower leverage depends on their willingness and ability to reduce the size of their housing market investments. When households primarily maximize the levered return of their property investments, more pessimistic homebuyers reduce their leverage to purchase smaller houses. On the other hand, when considerations such as family size pin down the desired property size, pessimistic homebuyers reduce their financial exposure to the housing market by making smaller downpayments to buy similarly-sized homes. To determine which scenario better describes the data, we investigate the cross-sectional relationship between house price beliefs and mortgage leverage choices in the U.S. housing market. We use plausibly exogenous variation in house price beliefs to show that more pessimistic homebuyers make smaller downpayments and choose higher leverage, in particular in states where default costs are relatively low, as well as during periods when house prices are expected to fall on average. Our results highlight the important role of heterogeneous beliefs in explaining households’ financial decisions.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between homebuyers' beliefs about future house price changes and their mortgage leverage choices?
answer: More pessimistic homebuyers make smaller downpayments and choose higher leverage, particularly in states where default costs are relatively low and during periods when house prices are expected to fall on average. This occurs because when property size considerations are fixed, pessimistic homebuyers reduce their financial exposure to the housing market through smaller downpayments rather than purchasing smaller houses.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by highlighting the important role of heterogeneous beliefs in explaining households' financial decisions, specifically examining how house price expectations influence mortgage leverage choices - a relationship that depends on whether households can adjust their housing market investment size or are constrained by factors like desired property size.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Five Facts about Beliefs and Portfolios
abstract: <jats:p> We study a newly designed survey administered to a large panel of wealthy retail investors. The survey elicits beliefs that are important for macroeconomics and finance, and matches respondents with administrative data on their portfolio composition, their trading activity, and their login behavior. We establish five facts inthese data. (i) Beliefs are reflected in portfolio allocations. The sensitivity of portfolios to beliefs is small on average, but varies significantly with investor wealth, attention, trading frequency, and confidence. (ii) Belief changes do not predict when investors trade, but conditional on trading, they affect both the direction and the magnitude of trades. (iii) Beliefs are mostly characterized by large and persistent individual heterogeneity. Demographic characteristics explain only asmall part of why some individuals are optimistic and some are pessimistic. (iv) Expected cash flow growth and expected returns are positively related, both within and across investors. (v) Expected returns and the subjective probability of rare disasters are negatively related, both within and across investors. These five facts provide useful guidance for the design of macro-finance models. (JEL D83, E23, G11, G12, G41, G51) </jats:p>
research_question: How do investor beliefs relate to portfolio allocations, trading behavior, and what are the key characteristics of these beliefs among wealthy retail investors?
answer: Five key findings: (1) beliefs are reflected in portfolio allocations with sensitivity varying by investor characteristics, (2) belief changes don't predict when investors trade but affect trading direction and magnitude, (3) beliefs show large persistent individual heterogeneity poorly explained by demographics, (4) expected cash flow growth and returns are positively related, and (5) expected returns and subjective disaster probabilities are negatively related.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel empirical evidence by matching survey data on investor beliefs with administrative portfolio data from wealthy retail investors, establishing stylized facts that can guide the design of macro-finance models.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: The Economic Effects of Social Networks: Evidence from the Housing Market
abstract: We show how data from online social networking services can help researchers better understand the effects of social interactions on economic decision making. We combine anonymized data from Facebook, the largest online social network, with housing transaction data and explore both the structure and the effects of social networks. Individuals whose geographically distant friends experienced larger recent house price increases are more likely to transition from renting to owning. They also buy larger houses and pay more for a given house. Survey data show that these relationships are driven by the effects of social interactions on individuals’ housing market expectations.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Do Banks Pass through Credit Expansions to Consumers Who want to Borrow?*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a new approach to studying the pass-through of credit expansion policies that focuses on frictions, such as asymmetric information, that arise in the interaction between banks and borrowers. We decompose the effect of changes in banks’ cost of funds on aggregate borrowing into the product of banks’ marginal propensity to lend (MPL) to borrowers and those borrowers’ marginal propensity to borrow (MPB), aggregated over all borrowers in the economy. We apply our framework by estimating heterogeneous MPBs and MPLs in the U.S. credit card market. Using panel data on 8.5 million credit cards and 743 credit limit regression discontinuities, we find that the MPB is declining in credit score, falling from 59% for consumers with FICO scores below 660 to essentially zero for consumers with FICO scores above 740. We use a simple model of optimal credit limits to show that a bank’s MPL depends on a small number of parameters that can be estimated using our credit limit discontinuities. For the lowest FICO score consumers, higher credit limits sharply reduce profits from lending, limiting banks’ optimal MPL to these consumers. The negative correlation between MPB and MPL reduces the impact of changes in banks’ cost of funds on aggregate household borrowing, and highlights the importance of frictions in bank-borrower interactions for understanding the pass-through of credit expansions.</jats:p>
research_question: How effectively do banks pass through credit expansion policies to consumers who want to borrow, and what frictions in bank-borrower interactions affect this pass-through?
answer: Banks' pass-through of credit expansions is limited by a negative correlation between borrowers' marginal propensity to borrow (MPB) and banks' marginal propensity to lend (MPL). Consumers with low credit scores have high MPB (59% for FICO <660) but banks have low MPL to them due to reduced profitability, while high credit score consumers have essentially zero MPB despite banks' willingness to lend to them.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new approach to studying credit expansion pass-through that focuses on frictions such as asymmetric information in bank-borrower interactions, decomposing aggregate effects into the product of banks' marginal propensity to lend and borrowers' marginal propensity to borrow - a framework that highlights previously understudied frictions affecting credit policy transmission.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title:
Regulating Consumer Financial Products: Evidence from Credit Cards
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We analyze the effectiveness of consumer financial regulation by considering the 2009 Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure (CARD) Act. We use a panel data set covering 160 million credit card accounts and a difference-in-differences research design that compares changes in outcomes over time for consumer credit cards, which were subject to the regulations, to changes for small business credit cards, which the law did not cover. We estimate that regulatory limits on credit card fees reduced overall borrowing costs by an annualized 1.6% of average daily balances, with a decline of more than 5.3% for consumers with FICO scores below 660. We find no evidence of an offsetting increase in interest charges or a reduction in the volume of credit. Taken together, we estimate that the CARD Act saved consumers $11.9 billion a year. We also analyze a nudge that disclosed the interest savings from paying off balances in 36 months rather than making minimum payments. We detect a small increase in the share of accounts making the 36-month payment value but no evidence of a change in overall payments.</jats:p>
research_question: How effective was the 2009 Credit Card Accountability Responsibility and Disclosure (CARD) Act in regulating consumer financial products, specifically in terms of its impact on borrowing costs, credit availability, and consumer behavior?
answer: The CARD Act was highly effective, reducing overall borrowing costs by 1.6% of average daily balances annually (5.3% for consumers with FICO scores below 660) and saving consumers $11.9 billion per year, with no evidence of offsetting increases in interest charges or reductions in credit volume. However, the disclosure nudge requiring minimum payment information had minimal impact on consumer payment behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on consumer financial regulation effectiveness by providing comprehensive empirical evidence on the CARD Act's impact using a large-scale panel dataset and difference-in-differences methodology, comparing regulated consumer credit cards to unregulated small business credit cards as a control group.

author: Johannes Stroebel
title: Social Networks Shape Beliefs and Behavior: Evidence from Social Distancing during the COVID-19 Pandemic
