author: John Asker
title: Raising Retailers’ Profits: On Vertical Practices and the Exclusion of Rivals
abstract: <jats:p> Resale price maintenance (RPM), slotting fees, loyalty rebates, and other related vertical practices can allow an incumbent manufacturer to transfer profits to retailers. If these retailers were to accommodate entry, upstream competition could lead to lower industry profits and the breakdown of these profit transfers. Thus, in equilibrium, retailers can internalize the effect of accommodating entry on the incumbent’s profits. Consequently, if entry requires downstream accommodation, entry can be deterred. We discuss policy implications of this aspect of vertical contracting practices. (JEL L14, L22, L25, L42, L81) </jats:p>
research_question: How do vertical practices like resale price maintenance, slotting fees, and loyalty rebates affect entry deterrence when incumbent manufacturers can transfer profits to retailers?
answer: Vertical practices that allow incumbent manufacturers to transfer profits to retailers can deter entry because retailers internalize the effect that accommodating new entrants would have on the incumbent's profits - specifically that upstream competition would reduce industry profits and eliminate these profitable transfers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on vertical contracting practices by identifying a novel mechanism through which these practices can exclude rivals - not just through direct effects, but by aligning retailer incentives with incumbent manufacturer interests through profit transfers that would be threatened by entry.

author: John Asker
title: Competition and the Structure of Vertical Relationships in Capital Markets

author: John Friedman
title: Optimal Gerrymandering: Sometimes Pack, But Never Crack
abstract: <jats:p> Standard intuitions for optimal gerrymandering involve concentrating one's extreme opponents in “unwinnable” districts (“packing”) and spreading one's supporters evenly over “winnable” districts (“cracking”). These intuitions come from models with either no uncertainty about voter preferences or only two voter types. In contrast, we characterize the solution to a problem in which a gerrymanderer observes a noisy signal of voter preferences from a continuous distribution and creates N districts of equal size to maximize the expected number of districts she wins. Under mild regularity conditions, we show that cracking is never optimal—one's most ardent supporters should be grouped together. Moreover, for sufficiently precise signals, the optimal solution involves creating a district that matches extreme “Republicans” with extreme “Democrats,” and then continuing to match toward the center of the signal distribution. (JEL D72) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal gerrymandering strategy when a gerrymanderer observes noisy signals of voter preferences from a continuous distribution and seeks to maximize the expected number of districts won?
answer: Cracking (spreading supporters evenly) is never optimal - the most ardent supporters should be grouped together. For sufficiently precise signals, the optimal strategy involves creating districts that match extreme Republicans with extreme Democrats, then continuing to match toward the center of the signal distribution.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges standard gerrymandering intuitions that come from models with either no uncertainty about voter preferences or only two voter types, by instead analyzing a more realistic scenario with continuous voter preference distributions and noisy signals.

author: John Asker
title: (Mis)Allocation, Market Power, and Global Oil Extraction
abstract: <jats:p> We propose an approach to measuring the misallocation of production in a market that compares actual industry cost curves to undistorted (counterfactual ) supply curves. As compared to traditional, TFPR-based, misallocation measures, this approach leverages cost data, such that results are readily mapped to welfare metrics. As an application, we analyze global crude oil extraction and quantify the extent of misallocation therein, together with the proportion attributable to market power. From 1970 to 2014, we find substantial misallocation, in the order of US$744 billion, 14.1 percent to 21.9 percent of which is attributable to market power. (JEL D24, F23, L13, L71, Q35) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure the misallocation of production in markets and what is the extent of misallocation in global crude oil extraction, including the proportion attributable to market power?
answer: The paper finds substantial misallocation in global crude oil extraction from 1970 to 2014, totaling approximately US$744 billion, with 14.1 percent to 21.9 percent of this misallocation attributable to market power.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new approach to measuring misallocation that compares actual industry cost curves to undistorted counterfactual supply curves, which differs from traditional TFPR-based misallocation measures by leveraging cost data that can be readily mapped to welfare metrics.

author: John Asker
title: Dynamic Inputs and Resource (Mis)Allocation

author: John Asker
title: A Study of the Internal Organization of a Bidding Cartel
abstract: <jats:p> This paper examines bidding in over 1,700 knockout auctions used by a bidding cartel (or ring) of stamp dealers in the 1990s. The knockout was conducted using a variant of the model studied by Daniel Graham, Robert Marshall, and Jean-Francois Richard (1990). Following a reduced form examination of these data, damages, induced inefficiency, and the ring's benefit from colluding are estimated using a structural model in the spirit of Emmanuel Guerre, Isabelle Perrigne, and Quang Vuong (2000). A notable finding is that nonring bidders suffered damages that were of the same order of magnitude as those of the sellers. (JEL D43, D44, L12) </jats:p>
research_question: How does a bidding cartel organize its internal operations and what are the economic effects on different market participants?
answer: The study finds that nonring bidders suffered damages of the same order of magnitude as sellers, and provides estimates of damages, induced inefficiency, and the ring's benefits from collusion based on analysis of over 1,700 knockout auctions.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the theoretical model of Graham, Marshall, and Richard (1990) by examining real-world knockout auction data, and employs a structural estimation approach following Guerre, Perrigne, and Vuong (2000) to quantify the economic impacts of cartel behavior.

author: John Friedman
title: Measuring the Impacts of Teachers I: Evaluating Bias in Teacher Value-Added Estimates
abstract: <jats:p> Are teachers' impacts on students' test scores (value-added) a good measure of their quality? One reason this question has sparked debate is disagreement about whether value-added (VA) measures provide unbiased estimates of teachers' causal impacts on student achievement. We test for bias in VA using previously unobserved parent characteristics and a quasi-experimental design based on changes in teaching staff. Using school district and tax records for more than one million children, we find that VA models which control for a student's prior test scores provide unbiased forecasts of teachers' impacts on student achievement. (JEL H75, I21, J24, J45) </jats:p>
research_question: Are teachers' impacts on students' test scores (value-added) a good measure of their quality, specifically whether value-added measures provide unbiased estimates of teachers' causal impacts on student achievement?
answer: Value-added models which control for a student's prior test scores provide unbiased forecasts of teachers' impacts on student achievement.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a key debate in the literature about whether value-added measures provide unbiased estimates of teachers' causal impacts, contributing novel evidence using previously unobserved parent characteristics and quasi-experimental design with large-scale administrative data.

author: John Friedman
title: Using Differences in Knowledge Across Neighborhoods to Uncover the Impacts of the EITC on Earnings
abstract: <jats:p> We estimate the impacts of the Earned Income Tax Credit on labor supply using local variation in knowledge about the EITC schedule. We proxy for EITC knowledge in a Zip code with the fraction of individuals who manipulate reported self-employment income to maximize their EITC refund. This measure varies significantly across areas. We exploit changes in EITC eligibility at the birth of a child to estimate labor supply effects. Individuals in high-knowledge areas change wage earnings sharply to obtain larger EITC refunds relative to those in low-knowledge areas. These responses come primarily from intensive-margin earnings increases in the phase-in region. (JEL H23, H24, H31, J22, J23, J31) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the impacts of the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) on labor supply, and how do these impacts vary based on local knowledge about the EITC schedule?
answer: The EITC has significant positive effects on labor supply, but only in areas where people have high knowledge about the EITC schedule. Individuals in high-knowledge areas change their wage earnings sharply to maximize EITC refunds, primarily through intensive-margin earnings increases in the phase-in region, while those in low-knowledge areas show little response.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a novel methodological approach to estimating EITC effects by using local variation in EITC knowledge (proxied by self-employment income manipulation rates) rather than relying solely on policy changes or eligibility thresholds, allowing for identification of how information and understanding mediate the effectiveness of tax credit policies.

author: John Friedman
title: Measuring the Impacts of Teachers: Reply
abstract: <jats:p> Rothstein (2017) successfully replicates Chetty, Friedman, and Rockoff's (2014a, b)—henceforth, CFR's—results using data from North Carolina, but raises concerns about CFR's methods. We show that Rothstein's methodological critiques are invalid by presenting simulations and supplementary empirical evidence which show that (i) his preferred imputation of missing data generates bias; (ii) his “placebo test” rejects valid research designs; and (iii) his method of controlling for covariates yields inconsistent estimates of teachers' long-term effects. Consistent with the conclusions of Bacher-Hicks, Kane, and Staiger (2016) using data from Los Angeles, we conclude that Rothstein's replication study ultimately reinforces CFR's methods and results. (JEL H75, I21, J45) </jats:p>
research_question: Are the methodological critiques raised by Rothstein (2017) against Chetty, Friedman, and Rockoff's (2014) methods for measuring teacher impacts valid?
answer: Rothstein's methodological critiques are invalid - his preferred imputation method generates bias, his placebo test incorrectly rejects valid research designs, and his covariate control method yields inconsistent estimates of teachers' long-term effects.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as a defense of CFR's original methods against Rothstein's critiques, aligning with Bacher-Hicks, Kane, and Staiger (2016) findings from Los Angeles data, and arguing that Rothstein's replication study actually reinforces rather than undermines CFR's methods and results.

author: John List
title: Does Market Experience Eliminate Market Anomalies? The Case of Exogenous Market Experience
abstract: <jats:p> A vibrant literature has emerged that suggests willingness to pay and willingness to accept measures of value are quite different for inexperienced consumers but that value differences erode with market experience. One potential shortcoming of this literature is that market experience is endogenous. This study presents a framed field experiment that exogenously induces market experience. Empirical findings support the premise that market experience, alone, can eliminate an important market anomaly. </jats:p>
research_question: Does market experience eliminate market anomalies, specifically the difference between willingness to pay and willingness to accept measures of value?
answer: Yes, market experience alone can eliminate an important market anomaly - the empirical findings support that exogenously induced market experience eliminates the difference between willingness to pay and willingness to accept measures.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a potential shortcoming in the existing literature by using exogenous (rather than endogenous) market experience through a framed field experiment, building on the vibrant literature showing that value differences between willingness to pay and willingness to accept erode with market experience among inexperienced consumers.

author: John Friedman
title: Measuring the Impacts of Teachers II: Teacher Value-Added and Student Outcomes in Adulthood
abstract: <jats:p> Are teachers' impacts on students' test scores (value-added) a good measure of their quality? This question has sparked debate partly because of a lack of evidence on whether high value-added (VA) teachers improve students' long-term outcomes. Using school district and tax records for more than one million children, we find that students assigned to high-VA teachers are more likely to attend college, earn higher salaries, and are less likely to have children as teenagers. Replacing a teacher whose VA is in the bottom 5 percent with an average teacher would increase the present value of students' lifetime income by approximately $250,000 per classroom. (JEL H75, I21, J24, J45) </jats:p>
research_question: Are teachers' impacts on students' test scores (value-added) a good measure of their quality?
answer: Yes, high value-added teachers significantly improve students' long-term outcomes - students assigned to high-VA teachers are more likely to attend college, earn higher salaries, and are less likely to have children as teenagers, with replacing a bottom 5% teacher with an average teacher increasing lifetime income by approximately $250,000 per classroom.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in existing literature by providing empirical evidence on the relationship between teacher value-added and long-term student outcomes, responding to ongoing debate that has been limited by lack of evidence on whether high value-added teachers improve students' outcomes beyond test scores.

author: John List
title: Does Price Matter in Charitable Giving? Evidence from a Large-Scale Natural Field Experiment
abstract: <jats:p> We conducted a natural field experiment to further our understanding of the economics of charity. Using direct mail solicitations to over 50,000 prior donors of a nonprofit organization, we tested the effectiveness of a matching grant on charitable giving. We find that the match offer increases both the revenue per solicitation and the response rate. Larger match ratios (i.e., $3:$1 and $2:$1) relative to a smaller match ratio ($1:$1) had no additional impact, however. The results provide avenues for future empirical and theoretical work on charitable giving, cost-benefit analysis, and the private provision of public goods. (JEL D64, L31) </jats:p>
research_question: Does the price of giving (through matching grants) matter in charitable giving, and how do different matching ratios affect donation behavior?
answer: Matching grants increase both revenue per solicitation and response rates, but larger match ratios ($3:1 and $2:1) have no additional impact compared to smaller match ratios ($1:1).
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the economics of charity literature by providing large-scale natural field experiment evidence on matching grants' effectiveness, offering new empirical insights for future theoretical work on charitable giving, cost-benefit analysis, and private provision of public goods.

author: John List
title: Editor’s Introduction to JPE Micro
abstract: I am pleased to present the inaugural issue of the Journal of Political Economy Microeconomics ( JPE Micro). JPE Micro, which is published by the University of Chicago Press and is closely tied to the Journal of Political Economy ( JPE), is intended to serve as a forum for high-quality theoretical and empirical research in microeconomics. More specifically, the journal strives to publish high-quality theoretical, empirical, and econometric research papers and replication studies that address issues of relevance to microeconomics. JPE Micro interprets microeconomics in the broadest possible sense, which means including issues related to how individuals, households, firms, and governments make choices and how those choices affect prices, the allocation of resources, and the well-being of people. JPE Micro welcomes submissions in all areas of microeconomics including, but not limited to, industrial organization and labor, behavioral, experimental, environmental, international, public, health care, education, and development economics. The journal is served by a truly outstanding board of editors, which includes Eduardo Azevedo, Lint Barrage, Anna Dreber Almenberg, Matthew Grennan, Christian Hansen, and Juanna Schrøter Joensen. Each is an exceptional scholar, and as a collective, they provide the breadth and depth of economic wisdom and knowledge that a top scholarly journal demands. In addition to these editors, several exceptional associate editors also have agreed to advise in the handling of manuscripts.

author: John List
title: Supply and Demand for Discrimination: Strategic Revelation of Own Characteristics in a Trust Game
abstract: <jats:p> In strategic settings a player may be able to influence the behavior of an opponent by revealing information about their own characteristics. They may for example aim to exploit stereotypes held by others. We provide an experimental test of this. A substantial fraction of players in a trust game exhibit a positive willingness to pay to reveal a photograph of themselves to their randomly-assigned partner. This suggests that they perceive that they can use their own characteristics to influence the behavior of others. The demand for such self-revelation depends negatively on price. </jats:p>
research_question: Can players strategically influence their opponent's behavior by revealing information about their own characteristics (specifically their photograph) in a trust game, and what is their willingness to pay for such revelation?
answer: A substantial fraction of players exhibit a positive willingness to pay to reveal their photograph to randomly-assigned partners, suggesting they believe they can strategically use their own characteristics to influence others' behavior, with demand for self-revelation decreasing as price increases.
positioning_statement: This paper provides an experimental test of strategic self-revelation in games, specifically examining how players may exploit stereotypes held by others by revealing their own characteristics, contributing to the literature on information revelation and strategic behavior in trust games.

author: John List
title: Principles of (Behavioral) Economics
abstract: <jats:p> Behavioral economics has become an important and integrated component of modern economics. Behavioral economists embrace the core principles of economics—optimization and equilibrium—and seek to develop and extend those ideas to make them more empirically accurate. Behavioral models assume that economic actors try to pick the best feasible option and those actors sometimes make mistakes. Behavioral ideas should be incorporated throughout the first-year undergraduate course. Instructors should also considering allocating a lecture (or more) to a focused discussion of behavioral concepts. We describe our approach to such a lecture, highlighting six modular principles and empirical examples that support them. </jats:p>
research_question: How should behavioral economics concepts be integrated into undergraduate economics education?
answer: Behavioral economics should be incorporated throughout the first-year undergraduate course, with instructors also considering dedicating focused lectures to behavioral concepts using six modular principles supported by empirical examples.
positioning_statement: This paper positions behavioral economics as an important and integrated component of modern economics that embraces core economic principles (optimization and equilibrium) while extending them to be more empirically accurate, rather than as a separate or competing field.

author: John List
title: Putting Behavioral Economics to Work: Testing for Gift Exchange in Labor Markets Using Field Experiments

author: John Friedman
title: Diversifying Society’s Leaders? The Determinants and Causal Effects of Admission to Highly Selective Private Colleges
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We use anonymized admissions data from several colleges linked to income tax records and SAT and ACT test scores to study the determinants and causal effects of attending Ivy-Plus colleges (Ivy League, Stanford, MIT, Duke, and Chicago). Children from families in the top 1% are more than twice as likely to attend an Ivy-Plus college as those from middle-class families with comparable SAT/ACT scores. Two-thirds of this gap is due to higher admissions rates for students with comparable test scores from high-income families; the remaining third is due to differences in rates of application and matriculation. In contrast, children from high-income families have no admissions advantage at flagship public colleges. The high-income admissions advantage at Ivy-Plus colleges is driven by three factors: (1) preferences for children of alumni, (2) weight placed on non-academic credentials, and (3) athletic recruitment. Using a new research design that isolates idiosyncratic variation in admissions decisions for waitlisted applicants, we show that attending an Ivy-Plus college instead of the average flagship public college increases students- chances of reaching the top 1% of the earnings distribution by 50%, nearly doubles their chances of attending an elite graduate school, and almost triples their chances of working at a prestigious firm. The three factors that give children from high-income families an admissions advantage are uncorrelated or negatively correlated with post-college outcomes, whereas academic credentials such as SAT/ACT scores are highly predictive of post-college success.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the determinants of admission to highly selective private colleges (Ivy-Plus) and what are the causal effects of attending these institutions on post-college outcomes?
answer: Children from top 1% income families are more than twice as likely to attend Ivy-Plus colleges as middle-class children with comparable test scores, with two-thirds of this gap due to higher admissions rates. Attending Ivy-Plus colleges increases chances of reaching top 1% earnings by 50%, nearly doubles elite graduate school attendance, and almost triples working at prestigious firms. The admissions advantages for high-income students (legacy preferences, non-academic credentials, athletic recruitment) are uncorrelated or negatively correlated with post-college success.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel evidence by using anonymized admissions data linked to tax records and test scores to identify causal effects of elite college attendance through a new research design focusing on waitlisted applicants, while documenting specific mechanisms behind socioeconomic admissions advantages that previous literature had not systematically analyzed.

author: John List
title: Do Natural Field Experiments Afford Researchers More or Less Control than Laboratory Experiments?
abstract: <jats:p> A commonly held view is that laboratory experiments provide researchers with more “control” than natural field experiments. This paper explores how natural field experiments can provide researchers with more control than laboratory experiments. While laboratory experiments provide researchers with a high degree of control in the environment which participants agree to be experimental subjects, when participants systematically opt out of laboratory experiments, the researcher's ability to manipulate certain variables is limited. In contrast, natural field experiments bypass the participation decision altogether due to their covertness, and they allow for a potentially more diverse participant pool within the market of interest. </jats:p>
research_question: Do natural field experiments afford researchers more or less control than laboratory experiments?
answer: Natural field experiments can provide researchers with more control than laboratory experiments because they bypass the participation decision through their covertness and allow for a potentially more diverse participant pool within the market of interest, whereas laboratory experiments face limitations when participants systematically opt out.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the commonly held view that laboratory experiments provide researchers with more 'control' than natural field experiments by arguing that systematic opt-out behavior in laboratory settings actually limits researchers' ability to manipulate certain variables compared to the covert nature of natural field experiments.

author: John List
title: One Swallow Doesn't Make a Summer: New Evidence on Anchoring Effects
abstract: <jats:p> Some researchers have argued that anchoring in economic valuations casts doubt on the assumption of consistent and stable preferences. We present new evidence that explores the strength of certain anchoring results. We then present a theoretical framework that provides insights into why we should be cautious of initial empirical findings in general. The model importantly highlights that the rate of false positives depends not only on the observed significance level, but also on statistical power, research priors, and the number of scholars exploring the question. Importantly, a few independent replications dramatically increase the chances that the original finding is true. (JEL D12, C91) </jats:p>
research_question: How strong and reliable are anchoring effects in economic valuations, and what does this tell us about the stability of economic preferences?
answer: The strength of certain anchoring results is questionable, and while anchoring effects may exist, a few independent replications are needed to dramatically increase confidence that original findings are true rather than false positives.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing literature that uses anchoring effects to question the assumption of consistent and stable preferences, by providing new evidence on the strength of anchoring results and developing a theoretical framework that explains why initial empirical findings in general should be viewed with caution.

author: John List
title: Equalizing Superstars: The Internet and the Democratization of Education
abstract: <jats:p> Internet-based educational resources are proliferating rapidly. One concern associated with these (potentially transformative) technological changes is that they will be disequalizing—as many technologies of the last several decades have been—creating superstar teachers and a winner-take-all education system. These important concerns notwithstanding, we contend that a major impact of web-based educational technologies will be the democratization of education: educational resources will be more equally distributed, and lower-skilled teachers will benefit. At the root of our results is the observation that skilled lecturers can only exploit their comparative advantage if other teachers complement those lectures with face-to-face instruction. This complementarity will increase the quantity and quality of face-to-face teaching services, potentially increasing the marginal product and wages of lower-skill teachers. </jats:p>
research_question: Will internet-based educational technologies create a disequalizing winner-take-all education system with superstar teachers, or will they lead to democratization of education?
answer: Internet-based educational technologies will lead to democratization of education, making educational resources more equally distributed and benefiting lower-skilled teachers by increasing their marginal product and wages through complementarity with skilled online lecturers.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the prevailing concern that internet-based educational technologies will be disequalizing like many technologies of recent decades, instead arguing for a contrarian view that these technologies will democratize rather than concentrate educational advantages.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: Pretest with Caution: Event-Study Estimates after Testing for Parallel Trends
abstract: <jats:p>This paper discusses two important limitations of the common practice of testing for preexisting differences in trends (“ pre-trends”) when using difference-in-differences and related methods. First, conventional pre-trends tests may have low power. Second, conditioning the analysis on the result of a pretest can distort estimation and inference, potentially exacerbating the bias of point estimates and under-coverage of confidence intervals. I analyze these issues both in theory and in simulations calibrated to a survey of recent papers in leading economics journals, which suggest that these limitations are important in practice. I conclude with practical recommendations for mitigating these issues. (JEL A14, C23, C51)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the limitations of testing for preexisting differences in trends (pre-trends) when using difference-in-differences and related methods?
answer: There are two key limitations: (1) conventional pre-trends tests may have low power, and (2) conditioning the analysis on pretest results can distort estimation and inference, potentially exacerbating bias in point estimates and causing under-coverage of confidence intervals.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies and analyzes previously underexplored problems with the common practice of pre-trends testing in difference-in-differences methodology, using both theoretical analysis and simulations calibrated to recent papers in leading economics journals to demonstrate the practical importance of these issues.

author: John List
title: The Effect of Early-Childhood Education on Social Preferences
abstract: We present results from the first study to examine the causal impact of early-childhood education on the social preferences of children. We compare children who, at 3–4 years old, were randomized into either a full-time preschool, a parenting program, or a control group. We returned to the children when they reached 6–8 years of age and conducted a series of incentivized experiments to elicit their social preferences. We find that early-childhood education has a strong causal impact on social preferences. Our findings highlight the importance of taking a broad perspective when designing and evaluating early-childhood educational programs.

author: John List
title: Predicting and Preventing Shootings among At-Risk Youth
abstract: <jats:p> Each year, more than 250 students in the Chicago Public Schools (CPS) are shot. The authors of this paper worked with the leadership of CPS to build a predictive model of shootings that helped determine which students would be included in a highly targeted and resource intensive mentorship program. This paper describes our predictive model and offers a preliminary evaluation of the mentoring intervention performed by Youth Advocate Programs, Inc. (YAP). We find little evidence that the intervention reduces school misconducts or improves educational outcomes. The scale of intervention was too small to generate meaningful findings on shootings. </jats:p>
research_question: Can a predictive model identify at-risk youth for shootings and can a targeted mentorship intervention prevent shootings and improve educational outcomes among these students?
answer: The predictive model successfully identified at-risk students, but the mentorship intervention showed little evidence of reducing school misconducts or improving educational outcomes, and the intervention scale was too small to generate meaningful findings on shooting prevention.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by applying predictive modeling to identify at-risk youth for gun violence in an educational setting and providing empirical evaluation of a targeted intervention program, addressing a gap in evidence-based approaches to preventing youth shootings in urban school districts.

author: Jonathan Lewellen
title: The Safe-Asset Share
abstract: <jats:p> We document that the percentage of all U.S. assets that are “safe” has remained stable at about 33 percent since 1952. This stable ratio is a rare example of calm in a rapidly changing financial world. Over the same time period, the ratio of U.S. assets to GDP has increased by a factor of 2.5, and the main supplier of safe financial debt has shifted from commercial banks to the “shadow banking system.” We analyze this pattern of stylized facts and offer some tentative conclusions about the composition of the safe-asset share and its role within the overall economy. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the percentage of all U.S. assets that are 'safe' and how has this share evolved over time since 1952?
answer: The safe-asset share has remained remarkably stable at approximately 33 percent of all U.S. assets since 1952, despite significant changes in the financial system including a 2.5x increase in the assets-to-GDP ratio and a shift in safe debt provision from commercial banks to shadow banking.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies the stable safe-asset share as 'a rare example of calm in a rapidly changing financial world,' positioning this finding as a notable exception to the typical pattern of financial system transformation and offering new empirical documentation of this previously unrecognized stability.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: A More Credible Approach to Parallel Trends
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper proposes tools for robust inference in difference-in-differences and event-study designs where the parallel trends assumption may be violated. Instead of requiring that parallel trends holds exactly, we impose restrictions on how different the post-treatment violations of parallel trends can be from the pre-treatment differences in trends (“pre-trends”). The causal parameter of interest is partially identified under these restrictions. We introduce two approaches that guarantee uniformly valid inference under the imposed restrictions, and we derive novel results showing that they have desirable power properties in our context. We illustrate how economic knowledge can inform the restrictions on the possible violations of parallel trends in two economic applications. We also highlight how our approach can be used to conduct sensitivity analyses showing what causal conclusions can be drawn under various restrictions on the possible violations of the parallel trends assumption.</jats:p>
research_question: How can researchers conduct robust inference in difference-in-differences and event-study designs when the parallel trends assumption may be violated?
answer: The paper develops tools that impose restrictions on how post-treatment violations of parallel trends can differ from pre-treatment trend differences, leading to partial identification of causal parameters and two approaches that guarantee uniformly valid inference with desirable power properties.
positioning_statement: Instead of requiring that parallel trends holds exactly as in existing literature, this paper relaxes this assumption by allowing for violations while imposing plausible restrictions based on pre-treatment trend differences, and provides methods for sensitivity analyses under various violation scenarios.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: Logs with Zeros? Some Problems and Solutions
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>When studying an outcome Y that is weakly positive but can equal zero (e.g., earnings), researchers frequently estimate an average treatment effect (ATE) for a “log-like” transformation that behaves like log (Y) for large Y but is defined at zero (e.g., log (1 + Y), $\operatorname{arcsinh}(Y)$). We argue that ATEs for log-like transformations should not be interpreted as approximating percentage effects, since unlike a percentage, they depend on the units of the outcome. In fact, we show that if the treatment affects the extensive margin, one can obtain a treatment effect of any magnitude simply by rescaling the units of Y before taking the log-like transformation. This arbitrary unit dependence arises because an individual-level percentage effect is not well-defined for individuals whose outcome changes from zero to nonzero when receiving treatment, and the units of the outcome implicitly determine how much weight the ATE for a log-like transformation places on the extensive margin. We further establish a trilemma: when the outcome can equal zero, there is no treatment effect parameter that is an average of individual-level treatment effects, unit invariant, and point identified. We discuss several alternative approaches that may be sensible in settings with an intensive and extensive margin, including (i) expressing the ATE in levels as a percentage (e.g., using Poisson regression), (ii) explicitly calibrating the value placed on the intensive and extensive margins, and (iii) estimating separate effects for the two margins (e.g., using Lee bounds). We illustrate these approaches in three empirical applications.</jats:p>
research_question: How should researchers interpret and estimate average treatment effects when using log-like transformations (e.g., log(1+Y), arcsinh(Y)) for outcomes that can equal zero?
answer: Average treatment effects for log-like transformations should not be interpreted as approximating percentage effects because they depend on the units of the outcome and can yield arbitrary magnitudes simply by rescaling units. The authors establish a trilemma showing that no treatment effect parameter can simultaneously be an average of individual-level effects, unit invariant, and point identified when outcomes can equal zero.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the common practice in empirical economics of using log-like transformations as approximations for percentage effects when outcomes include zeros, revealing fundamental problems that existing literature has overlooked and proposing alternative approaches including Poisson regression, explicit calibration of intensive/extensive margin weights, and separate estimation using methods like Lee bounds.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: When Is Parallel Trends Sensitive to Functional Form?
abstract: <jats:p>This paper assesses when the validity of difference‐in‐differences depends on functional form. We provide a novel characterization: the parallel trends assumption holds under all strictly monotonic transformations of the outcome if and only if a stronger “parallel trends”‐type condition holds for the cumulative distribution function of untreated potential outcomes. This condition for parallel trends to be insensitive to functional form is satisfied if and essentially only if the population can be partitioned into a subgroup for which treatment is effectively randomly assigned and a remaining subgroup for which the distribution of untreated potential outcomes is stable over time. These conditions have testable implications, and we introduce falsification tests for the null that parallel trends is insensitive to functional form.</jats:p>
research_question: When does the validity of difference-in-differences estimation depend on the functional form of the outcome variable?
answer: Parallel trends is insensitive to functional form if and only if a stronger condition holds for the cumulative distribution function of untreated potential outcomes, which is satisfied when the population can be partitioned into a subgroup with effectively random treatment assignment and a remaining subgroup with stable untreated outcome distributions over time.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel theoretical characterization of when difference-in-differences is robust to functional form transformations and introduces new falsification tests, addressing a gap in the existing literature on the sensitivity of parallel trends assumptions to outcome transformations.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: The Effects of Poor Neonatal Health on Children's Cognitive Development
abstract: <jats:p> We make use of a new data resource—merged birth and school records for all children born in Florida from 1992 to 2002—to study the relationship between birth weight and cognitive development. Using singletons as well as twin and sibling fixed effects models, we find that the effects of early health on cognitive development are essentially constant through the school career; that these effects are similar across a wide range of family backgrounds; and that they are invariant to measures of school quality. We conclude that the effects of early health on adult outcomes are therefore set very early. (JEL I12, J13, J24) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between birth weight (neonatal health) and children's cognitive development throughout their school career?
answer: The effects of early health on cognitive development are essentially constant through the school career, are similar across a wide range of family backgrounds, are invariant to measures of school quality, and therefore the effects of early health on adult outcomes are set very early in life.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by utilizing a new comprehensive data resource of merged birth and school records for all children born in Florida from 1992 to 2002, and employs both singleton and twin/sibling fixed effects models to establish causal relationships between neonatal health and cognitive development.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: Efficient Estimation for Staggered Rollout Designs
abstract: We study estimation of causal effects in staggered-rollout designs—that is, settings where there is staggered treatment adoption and the timing of treatment is as good as randomly assigned. We derive the most efficient estimator in a class of estimators that nests several popular generalized difference-in-differences methods. A feasible plug-in version of the efficient estimator is asymptotically unbiased, with efficiency (weakly) dominating that of existing approaches. We provide both t-based and permutation-test-based methods for inference. In an application to a training program for police officers, confidence intervals for the proposed estimator are as much as eight times shorter than those for existing approaches.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: Inference for Linear Conditional Moment Inequalities
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that moment inequalities in a wide variety of economic applications have a particular linear conditional structure. We use this structure to construct uniformly valid confidence sets that remain computationally tractable even in settings with nuisance parameters. We first introduce least-favorable critical values which deliver non-conservative tests if all moments are binding. Next, we introduce a novel conditional inference approach which ensures a strong form of insensitivity to slack moments. Our recommended approach is a hybrid technique which combines desirable aspects of the least favorable and conditional methods. The hybrid approach performs well in simulations calibrated to Wollmann (2018, American Economic Review, 108, 1364–1406), with favorable power and computational time comparisons relative to existing alternatives.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we construct uniformly valid and computationally tractable confidence sets for linear conditional moment inequalities in economic applications, particularly in settings with nuisance parameters?
answer: The paper develops a hybrid inference approach that combines least-favorable critical values (which are non-conservative when all moments are binding) with a novel conditional inference method (which ensures insensitivity to slack moments), resulting in a technique that performs well in terms of both statistical power and computational efficiency.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies that moment inequalities across a wide variety of economic applications share a particular linear conditional structure that has not been fully exploited, and develops new inference methods that improve upon existing alternatives in terms of computational tractability while maintaining uniform validity, as demonstrated through comparisons with existing methods using simulations calibrated to Wollmann (2018).

author: Joseph Vavra
title:
Inflation Dynamics and Time-Varying Volatility: New Evidence and an Ss Interpretation
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Is monetary policy less effective at increasing real output during periods of high volatility than during normal times? In this article, I argue that greater volatility leads to an increase in aggregate price flexibility so that nominal stimulus mostly generates inflation rather than output growth. To do this, I construct price-setting models with “volatility shocks” and show these models match new facts in CPI micro data that standard price-setting models miss. I then show that these models imply that output responds less to nominal stimulus during times of high volatility. Furthermore, because volatility is countercyclical, this implies that nominal stimulus has smaller real effects during downturns. For example, the estimated output response to additional nominal stimulus in September 1995, a time of low volatility, is 55% larger than the response in October 2001, a time of high volatility.</jats:p>
research_question: Is monetary policy less effective at increasing real output during periods of high volatility than during normal times?
answer: Yes, monetary policy is less effective during high volatility periods because greater volatility increases aggregate price flexibility, causing nominal stimulus to generate mostly inflation rather than output growth. The estimated output response to nominal stimulus in low volatility periods is 55% larger than in high volatility periods.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by constructing price-setting models with 'volatility shocks' that match new facts in CPI micro data that standard price-setting models miss, providing a novel theoretical framework to explain the relationship between volatility and monetary policy effectiveness.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: Measuring and Bounding Experimenter Demand
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a technique for assessing robustness to demand effects of findings from experiments and surveys. The core idea is that by deliberately inducing demand in a structured way we can bound its influence. We present a model in which participants respond to their beliefs about the researcher’s objectives. Bounds are obtained by manipulating those beliefs with “demand treatments.” We apply the method to 11 classic tasks, and estimate bounds averaging 0.13 standard deviations, suggesting that typical demand effects are probably modest. We also show how to compute demand-robust treatment effects and how to structurally estimate the model. (JEL C83, C90, D83, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure and bound the influence of experimenter demand effects on findings from experiments and surveys?
answer: The paper develops a technique using 'demand treatments' that deliberately manipulate participant beliefs about researcher objectives to bound demand effects, finding that typical demand effects average 0.13 standard deviations and are probably modest in magnitude.
positioning_statement: The paper addresses a fundamental methodological concern in experimental economics and psychology by providing the first systematic approach to quantify and bound experimenter demand effects, filling a gap in the literature where demand effects were recognized as a potential threat to validity but lacked rigorous measurement techniques.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: Mechanism Design in Large Games: Incentives and Privacy
abstract: <jats:p> We study the design of mechanisms satisfying a novel desideratum: privacy. This requires the mechanism not reveal 'much' about any agent's type to other agents. We propose the notion of joint differential privacy: a variant of differential privacy used in the privacy literature. We show by construction that mechanisms satisfying our desiderata exist when there are a large number of players, and any player's action affects any other's payoff by at most a small amount. Our results imply that in large economies, privacy concerns of agents can be accommodated at no additional 'cost' to standard incentive concerns. </jats:p>
research_question: Can mechanisms be designed in large games that satisfy both standard incentive compatibility requirements and privacy constraints that prevent revealing much information about any agent's type to other agents?
answer: Yes, mechanisms satisfying both incentive compatibility and joint differential privacy exist when there are a large number of players and any player's action affects others' payoffs by only a small amount, with privacy accommodated at no additional cost to standard incentive concerns.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel desideratum of privacy to mechanism design by adapting joint differential privacy from the privacy literature, extending traditional mechanism design beyond standard incentive concerns to address privacy protection in large economies.

author: Jonathan Roth
title: Mechanism Design in Large Games: Incentives and Privacy
abstract: <jats:p> We study the design of mechanisms satisfying a novel desideratum: privacy. This requires the mechanism not reveal 'much' about any agent's type to other agents. We propose the notion of joint differential privacy: a variant of differential privacy used in the privacy literature. We show by construction that mechanisms satisfying our desiderata exist when there are a large number of players, and any player's action affects any other's payoff by at most a small amount. Our results imply that in large economies, privacy concerns of agents can be accommodated at no additional 'cost' to standard incentive concerns. </jats:p>
research_question: Can mechanisms be designed in large games that satisfy both standard incentive compatibility requirements and privacy constraints that prevent revealing much information about any agent's type to other agents?
answer: Yes, mechanisms satisfying both incentive compatibility and joint differential privacy exist when there are a large number of players and any player's action affects others' payoffs by only a small amount, with privacy accommodated at no additional cost to standard incentive concerns.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel desideratum of privacy to mechanism design by adapting joint differential privacy from the privacy literature, extending traditional mechanism design beyond standard incentive concerns to address privacy protection in large economies.

author: Joseph Vavra
title: Measuring How Fiscal Shocks Affect Durable Spending in Recessions and Expansions
abstract: <jats:p> We estimate how durable expenditures respond to government spending shocks at different points in the business cycle using a nonlinear VAR approach that allows for the durable multiplier to vary smoothly with the state of the economy. We find strong evidence that the aggregate durable spending response to fiscal shocks is substantially larger during expansions than during recessions, in contrast to what has been has been observed for the aggregate multiplier. We argue that these results are consistent with the theoretical predictions of the fixed cost model of durable demand in Berger and Vavra (2012). </jats:p>
research_question: How do durable expenditures respond to government spending shocks at different points in the business cycle?
answer: The aggregate durable spending response to fiscal shocks is substantially larger during expansions than during recessions, which contrasts with what has been observed for the aggregate multiplier.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts its findings with existing literature on aggregate multipliers by showing that durable spending responds differently across business cycles than previously observed, and argues these results align with theoretical predictions from Berger and Vavra's (2012) fixed cost model of durable demand.

author: Joseph Vavra
title: Shocks versus Responsiveness: What Drives Time-Varying Dispersion?
abstract: The dispersion of many economic variables is countercyclical. What drives this fact? Greater dispersion could arise from greater volatility of shocks or from agents responding more to shocks of constant size. Without data separately measuring exogenous shocks and endogenous responses, a theoretical debate between these explanations has emerged. In this paper, we provide novel identification using price data in the open-economy environment: using confidential BLS microdata, we document a robust positive relationship between exchange rate pass-through and the dispersion of item-level price changes. We then show that this relationship supports models with time-varying responsiveness.

title: Consumption Dynamics During Recessions

author: Joseph Vavra
title: Mortgage Prepayment and Path-Dependent Effects of Monetary Policy
abstract: <jats:p> How much ability does the Fed have to stimulate the economy by cutting interest rates? We argue that the presence of substantial debt in fixed-rate, prepayable mortgages means that the ability to stimulate the economy by cutting interest rates depends not just on their current level but also on their previous path. Using a household model of mortgage prepayment matched to detailed loan-level evidence on the relationship between prepayment and rate incentives, we argue that recent interest rate paths will generate substantial headwinds for future monetary stimuli. (JEL E32, E43, E52, E58, G21, G51) </jats:p>
research_question: How much ability does the Fed have to stimulate the economy by cutting interest rates, particularly given the presence of substantial debt in fixed-rate, prepayable mortgages?
answer: The Fed's ability to stimulate the economy by cutting interest rates depends not just on their current level but also on their previous path, and recent interest rate paths will generate substantial headwinds for future monetary stimuli.
positioning_statement: This paper argues that existing literature has not adequately considered how the path-dependent effects of mortgage prepayment behavior affect monetary policy transmission, using a household model of mortgage prepayment matched to detailed loan-level evidence to demonstrate this previously underexplored mechanism.

author: Joseph Vavra
title: House Prices and Consumer Spending

author: Joseph Vavra
title: Regional Heterogeneity and the Refinancing Channel of Monetary Policy*
abstract: We argue that the time-varying regional distribution of housing equity influences the aggregate consequences of monetary policy through its effects on mortgage refinancing. Using detailed loan-level data, we show that regional differences in housing equity affect refinancing and spending responses to interest rate cuts, but these effects vary over time with changes in the regional distribution of house price growth. We build a heterogeneous household model of refinancing with mortgage borrowers and lenders and use it to explore the monetary policy implications arising from our regional evidence. We find that the 2008 equity distribution made spending in depressed regions less responsive to interest rate cuts, thus dampening aggregate stimulus and increasing regional consumption inequality, whereas the opposite occurred in some earlier recessions. Taken together, our results strongly suggest that monetary policy makers should track the regional distribution of equity over time.

author: Joseph Vavra
title: Spending and Job-Finding Impacts of Expanded Unemployment Benefits: Evidence from Administrative Micro Data
abstract: <jats:p> We show that the largest increase in unemployment benefits in US history had large spending impacts and small job-finding impacts. This finding has three implications. First, increased benefits were important for explaining aggregate spending dynamics—but not employment dynamics—during the pandemic. Second, benefit expansions allow us to study the MPC of normally low-liquidity households in a high-liquidity state. These households still have high MPCs. This suggests a role for permanent behavioral characteristics, rather than just current liquidity, in driving spending behavior. Third, the mechanisms driving our results imply that temporary benefit supplements are a promising countercyclical tool. (JEL E21, E24, E32, E62, E71, G51, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the spending and job-finding impacts of the largest increase in unemployment benefits in US history during the pandemic?
answer: The expanded unemployment benefits had large spending impacts but small job-finding impacts, suggesting benefits significantly affected aggregate spending dynamics but not employment dynamics during the pandemic.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using administrative micro data to study unemployment benefit effects during an unprecedented expansion, providing new insights into the marginal propensity to consume of low-liquidity households in high-liquidity states and demonstrating that permanent behavioral characteristics, rather than just current liquidity, drive spending behavior.

author: Joshua Hausman
title: Fiscal Policy and Economic Recovery: The Case of the 1936 Veterans' Bonus
abstract: <jats:p> Conventional wisdom has it that in the 1930s fiscal policy did not work because it was not tried. This paper shows that fiscal policy was tried in 1936. The veterans' bonus of 1936 paid 2 percent of GDP to 3.2 million veterans; the typical veteran received a payment equal to per capita income. Multiple sources, including a household consumption survey, show that veterans spent the majority of their bonus. Point estimates of the MPC are between 0.6 and 0.75. Spending was concentrated on cars and housing in particular. (JEL E21, E32, E62, N32, N42) </jats:p>
research_question: Did fiscal policy work as an economic stimulus during the 1930s, specifically examining the effectiveness of the 1936 veterans' bonus payment?
answer: Fiscal policy was effective in 1936 - veterans spent the majority of their bonus payments (60-75% marginal propensity to consume), particularly on cars and housing, demonstrating that fiscal stimulus did work when actually implemented during the Great Depression era.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom that fiscal policy didn't work in the 1930s because it wasn't tried, by providing evidence that fiscal policy was actually implemented in 1936 through the veterans' bonus and demonstrating its effectiveness.

author: Joshua Hausman
title: Power Flows: Transmission Lines, Allocative Efficiency, and Corporate Profits
abstract: <jats:p> Accelerated investment in electricity transmission could reduce total costs and enhance renewable integration. I document static allocative inefficiencies induced by incomplete market integration in 2 major US markets; these have risen over time and totaled $2 billion in 2022. I also argue that estimating firm-level impacts is important, as incumbents may have the power to block new lines and other reforms. I show that 4 firms would have experienced a collective $1.3 billion drop in net revenues in 2022 had the market been integrated, and there are reports of some of these firms blocking transmission projects. (JEL D22, D24, L13, L94, Q42, Q48) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the static allocative inefficiencies caused by incomplete electricity market integration in major US markets, and how do firm-level impacts affect transmission investment decisions?
answer: Incomplete market integration in 2 major US electricity markets has created static allocative inefficiencies totaling $2 billion in 2022 that have risen over time, while 4 incumbent firms would have lost a collective $1.3 billion in net revenues under market integration, creating incentives for these firms to block transmission projects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on electricity transmission investment by documenting quantified allocative inefficiencies from incomplete market integration and arguing for the importance of analyzing firm-level impacts, as incumbent firms with potential losses may have the power to block efficiency-enhancing transmission lines and market reforms.

author: Joseph Vavra
title: Regional Redistribution through the US Mortgage Market
abstract: <jats:p> Regional shocks are an important feature of the US economy. Households' ability to self-insure against these shocks depends on how they affect local interest rates. In the United States, most borrowing occurs through the mortgage market and is influenced by the presence of government-sponsored enterprises (GSE). We establish that despite large regional variation in predictable default risk, GSE mortgage rates for otherwise identical loans do not vary spatially. In contrast, the private market does set interest rates which vary with local risk. We use a spatial model of collateralized borrowing to show that the national interest rate policy substantially affects welfare by redistributing resources across regions. (JEL E32, E43, G21, G28, L32, R11, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How do government-sponsored enterprises (GSEs) affect regional redistribution through mortgage interest rate policies, and what are the welfare implications of national versus spatially-varying interest rates?
answer: GSEs set uniform national mortgage rates despite large regional variation in predictable default risk, while private markets do vary rates with local risk. This national interest rate policy substantially affects welfare by redistributing resources across regions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on regional shocks and household self-insurance by examining the role of government-sponsored enterprises in the mortgage market, using a spatial model of collateralized borrowing to analyze welfare effects of uniform national interest rate policies versus market-based spatial variation.

author: Joshua Hausman
title: Recovery from the Great Depression: The Farm Channel in Spring 1933
abstract: <jats:p> From March to July 1933, US industrial production rose 57 percent. We show that an important source of recovery was the effect of dollar devaluation on farm prices, incomes, and consumption. Devaluation immediately raised traded crop prices, and auto sales grew more rapidly in states and counties most exposed to these price increases. The response was amplified in counties with more severe farm debt burdens. For plausible assumptions about farmers’ relative MPC, the incidence of higher farm prices, and the aggregate multiplier, this redistribution to farmers accounted for a substantial portion of spring 1933 growth. This farm channel thus provides an example of how the distributional consequences of macroeconomic policies can have large aggregate effects. That recovery in 1933 benefited from redistribution to farmers suggests an important limitation to the use of 1933 as a guide to the effects of monetary regime changes in other circumstances. (JEL E32, E65, N12, N52, Q11, Q12) </jats:p>
research_question: What were the sources of the dramatic 57 percent rise in US industrial production from March to July 1933 during recovery from the Great Depression?
answer: An important source of the spring 1933 recovery was the effect of dollar devaluation on farm prices, incomes, and consumption, with devaluation immediately raising traded crop prices and stimulating auto sales more rapidly in areas most exposed to these price increases, particularly in counties with severe farm debt burdens.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a new explanation for the 1933 recovery by identifying a previously underexplored 'farm channel' mechanism, demonstrating how the distributional consequences of macroeconomic policies can have large aggregate effects, and suggesting that the unique role of redistribution to farmers limits the generalizability of 1933 as a guide for monetary regime changes in other circumstances.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title: Using Models to Persuade
abstract: <jats:p> We present a framework where “model persuaders” influence receivers’ beliefs by proposing models that organize past data to make predictions. Receivers are assumed to find models more compelling when they better explain the data, fixing receivers’ prior beliefs. Model persuaders face a trade-off: better-fitting models induce less movement in receivers’ beliefs. Consequently, a receiver exposed to the true model can be most misled by persuasion when that model fits poorly, competition between persuaders tends to neutralize the data by pushing toward better-fitting models, and a persuader facing multiple receivers is more effective when he can send tailored, private messages. (JEL C50, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How do model persuaders influence receivers' beliefs by proposing models that organize past data to make predictions, and what trade-offs do they face in this process?
answer: Model persuaders face a fundamental trade-off where better-fitting models induce less movement in receivers' beliefs. Key findings include: receivers can be most misled when the true model fits data poorly, competition between persuaders neutralizes persuasion by pushing toward better-fitting models, and persuaders are more effective with tailored private messages to multiple receivers.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a novel framework for understanding persuasion through model selection, contributing to the literature on information economics and strategic communication by examining how the quality of model fit affects persuasive power and belief formation.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title:
Learning Through Noticing: Theory and Evidence from a Field Experiment
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We consider a model of technological learning under which people “learn through noticing”: they choose which input dimensions to attend to and subsequently learn about from available data. Using this model, we show how people with a great deal of experience may persistently be off the production frontier because they fail to notice important features of the data they possess. We also develop predictions on when these learning failures are likely to occur, as well as on the types of interventions that can help people learn. We test the model’s predictions in a field experiment with seaweed farmers. The survey data reveal that these farmers do not attend to pod size, a particular input dimension. Experimental trials suggest that farmers are particularly far from optimizing this dimension. Furthermore, consistent with the model, we find that simply having access to the experimental data does not induce learning. Instead, behavioral changes occur only after the farmers are presented with summaries that highlight previously unattended-to relationships in the data.</jats:p>
research_question: How do people learn about technology and production processes, particularly why experienced individuals may persistently operate below the production frontier despite having access to data?
answer: People 'learn through noticing' - they selectively choose which input dimensions to attend to and only learn from data about those dimensions. Experienced people can persistently underperform because they fail to notice important features in available data. Simply providing access to data is insufficient for learning; interventions must highlight previously unattended relationships through summaries or other attention-directing mechanisms.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new model of technological learning that explains persistent suboptimal performance among experienced individuals, contrasting with existing literature that assumes people learn from all available data by proposing that learning is constrained by selective attention to input dimensions.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title:
Behavioral Hazard in Health Insurance
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A fundamental implication of standard moral hazard models is overuse of low-value medical care because copays are lower than costs. In these models, the demand curve alone can be used to make welfare statements, a fact relied on by much empirical work. There is ample evidence, though, that people misuse care for a different reason: mistakes, or “behavioral hazard.” Much high-value care is underused even when patient costs are low, and some useless care is bought even when patients face the full cost. In the presence of behavioral hazard, welfare calculations using only the demand curve can be off by orders of magnitude or even be the wrong sign. We derive optimal copay formulas that incorporate both moral and behavioral hazard, providing a theoretical foundation for value-based insurance design and a way to interpret behavioral “nudges.” Once behavioral hazard is taken into account, health insurance can do more than just provide financial protection—it can also improve health care efficiency.</jats:p>
research_question: How does behavioral hazard (mistakes in healthcare decision-making) affect welfare calculations and optimal insurance design in health insurance, beyond the traditional moral hazard framework?
answer: Behavioral hazard can cause welfare calculations using only demand curves to be off by orders of magnitude or even have the wrong sign. The paper derives optimal copay formulas incorporating both moral and behavioral hazard, showing that health insurance can improve healthcare efficiency beyond just providing financial protection.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard moral hazard models that rely solely on demand curves for welfare analysis by introducing the concept of behavioral hazard, providing theoretical foundation for value-based insurance design and behavioral nudges that existing literature has not adequately addressed.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title: Beyond Beta-Delta: The Emerging Economics of Personal Plans
abstract: <jats:p> People make personal plans regarding whether, when, where, and how to undertake certain actions. We discuss three questions related to personal plans. First, what are the effects of plans on behavior? Second, when are plans formed? Third, how do plans deviate from optimality? For each of these questions, we (a) offer a brief overview of research that sheds light on the issue and (b) identify gaps in current knowledge. We emphasize connections to the growing theoretical literature that gives personal plans a substantive role, but we conclude that more research is needed, especially on the latter two questions we cover. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of plans on behavior, when are plans formed, and how do plans deviate from optimality?
answer: The paper identifies that while there is some research on the effects of plans on behavior, there are significant gaps in current knowledge, particularly regarding when plans are formed and how they deviate from optimality, requiring more research especially on the latter two questions.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as connecting to and reviewing the growing theoretical literature that gives personal plans a substantive role, moving beyond traditional beta-delta models to establish an emerging field of economics focused on personal plans.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title: A Model of Relative Thinking
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Fixed differences loom smaller when compared to large differences. We propose a model of relative thinking where a person weighs a given change along a consumption dimension by less when it is compared to bigger changes along that dimension. In deterministic settings, the model predicts context effects such as the attraction effect but predicts meaningful bounds on such effects driven by the intrinsic utility for the choices. In risky environments, a person is less likely to sacrifice utility on one dimension to gain utility on another that is made riskier. For example, a person is less likely to exert effort for a fixed monetary return if there is greater overall income uncertainty. We design and run experiments to test basic model predictions and find support for these predictions.</jats:p>
research_question: How do people make decisions when evaluating changes or differences in consumption dimensions, and how does the context of comparison affect their decision-making?
answer: People engage in relative thinking where they weigh a given change along a consumption dimension by less when it is compared to bigger changes along that dimension. This leads to context effects like the attraction effect in deterministic settings (with bounds driven by intrinsic utility) and reduced willingness to make trade-offs when one dimension becomes riskier in uncertain environments.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new model of relative thinking that explains context effects in decision-making, extending beyond existing literature by providing a unified framework that works in both deterministic and risky environments, with meaningful bounds on context effects driven by intrinsic utility considerations.

author: Joshua Rauh
title: Family, Education, and Sources of Wealth among the Richest Americans, 1982–2012
abstract: <jats:p> We examine characteristics of the 400 wealthiest individuals in the United States over the past three decades as tabulated by Forbes Magazine, and analyze which theories of increasing inequality are most consistent with these data. The people of the Forbes 400 in recent years did not grow up as advantaged as in decades past. They are more likely to have started their businesses and to have grown up upper-middle class, not wealthy. Today's Forbes 400 were able to access education while young, and apply their skills to the most scalable industries: technology, finance, and mass retail. Most of the change occurred by 2001. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the characteristics of the 400 wealthiest Americans over the past three decades and which theories of increasing inequality are most consistent with these data?
answer: The Forbes 400 in recent years are less advantaged in their upbringing compared to decades past, more likely to be self-made business founders from upper-middle class (rather than wealthy) backgrounds, who accessed education and applied skills to scalable industries like technology, finance, and mass retail, with most changes occurring by 2001.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on increasing inequality by empirically examining the changing characteristics of America's wealthiest individuals to test which theoretical explanations of inequality are most supported by the data.

author: Joshua Rauh
title: State Taxation and the Reallocation of Business Activity: Evidence from Establishment-Level Data
abstract: Using census microdata on multistate firms and their organizational forms, we estimate the impact of state taxes on business activity. For C corporations, employment and the number of establishments have short-run corporate tax elasticities of −0.4 to −0.5 and do not vary with changes in personal tax rates. Pass-through entity activities show tax elasticities of −0.2 to −0.4 with respect to personal tax rates and are invariant with respect to corporate tax rates. Capital shows similar patterns. Reallocation of productive resources to other states drives around half the effect. The responses are strongest for firms in tradable and footloose industries.

author: Joshua R. Schwartzstein
title: Representation and Extrapolation: Evidence from Clinical Trials
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article examines the consequences and causes of low enrollment of Black patients in clinical trials. We develop a simple model of similarity-based extrapolation that predicts that evidence is more relevant for decision-making by physicians and patients when it is more representative of the group being treated. This generates the key result that the perceived benefit of a medicine for a group depends not only on the average benefit from a trial but also on the share of patients from that group who were enrolled in the trial. In survey experiments, we find that physicians who care for Black patients are more willing to prescribe drugs tested in representative samples, an effect substantial enough to close observed gaps in the prescribing rates of new medicines. Black patients update more on drug efficacy when the sample that the drug is tested on is more representative, reducing Black-white patient gaps in beliefs about whether the drug will work as described. Despite these benefits of representative data, our framework and evidence suggest that those who have benefited more from past medical breakthroughs are less costly to enroll in the present, leading to persistence in who is represented in the evidence base.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the consequences and causes of low enrollment of Black patients in clinical trials, and how does the representativeness of trial samples affect physician prescribing behavior and patient beliefs about drug efficacy?
answer: The perceived benefit of a medicine for a group depends not only on the average benefit from a trial but also on the share of patients from that group enrolled in the trial. Physicians caring for Black patients are more willing to prescribe drugs tested in representative samples (enough to close observed prescribing gaps), and Black patients update more on drug efficacy when samples are more representative, reducing Black-white gaps in beliefs about drug effectiveness.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel similarity-based extrapolation model to explain how evidence representativeness affects medical decision-making, providing both theoretical framework and empirical evidence for why representative clinical trial enrollment matters for reducing healthcare disparities - an issue that has been observed but not systematically modeled in existing literature.
