author: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato
title: Who Benefits from State Corporate Tax Cuts? A Local Labor Markets Approach with Heterogeneous Firms
abstract: <jats:p>This paper estimates the incidence of state corporate taxes on the welfare of workers, landowners, and firm owners using variation in state corporate tax rates and apportionment rules. We develop a spatial equilibrium model with imperfectly mobile firms and workers. Firm owners may earn profits and be inframarginal in their location choices due to differences in location-specific productivities. We use the reduced-form effects of tax changes to identify and estimate incidence as well as the structural parameters governing these impacts. In contrast to standard open economy models, firm owners bear roughly 40 percent of the incidence, while workers and landowners bear 30–35 percent and 25–30 percent, respectively. (JEL H22, H25, H32, H71, R23, R51)</jats:p>
research_question: Who bears the incidence of state corporate tax cuts among workers, landowners, and firm owners?
answer: Firm owners bear roughly 40 percent of the incidence of state corporate taxes, while workers bear 30-35 percent and landowners bear 25-30 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with standard open economy models by developing a spatial equilibrium model with imperfectly mobile firms and workers, where firm owners can earn profits and be inframarginal in location choices due to location-specific productivity differences.

author: Joshua Schwartzstein
title:
Behavioral Hazard in Health Insurance
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A fundamental implication of standard moral hazard models is overuse of low-value medical care because copays are lower than costs. In these models, the demand curve alone can be used to make welfare statements, a fact relied on by much empirical work. There is ample evidence, though, that people misuse care for a different reason: mistakes, or “behavioral hazard.” Much high-value care is underused even when patient costs are low, and some useless care is bought even when patients face the full cost. In the presence of behavioral hazard, welfare calculations using only the demand curve can be off by orders of magnitude or even be the wrong sign. We derive optimal copay formulas that incorporate both moral and behavioral hazard, providing a theoretical foundation for value-based insurance design and a way to interpret behavioral “nudges.” Once behavioral hazard is taken into account, health insurance can do more than just provide financial protection—it can also improve health care efficiency.</jats:p>
research_question: How does behavioral hazard (mistakes in healthcare decision-making) affect welfare calculations and optimal insurance design in health insurance, beyond the traditional moral hazard framework?
answer: Behavioral hazard can cause welfare calculations using only demand curves to be off by orders of magnitude or even have the wrong sign. The paper derives optimal copay formulas incorporating both moral and behavioral hazard, showing that health insurance can improve healthcare efficiency beyond just providing financial protection.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard moral hazard models that rely solely on demand curves for welfare analysis by introducing the concept of behavioral hazard, providing theoretical foundation for value-based insurance design and behavioral nudges that existing literature has not adequately addressed.

author: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato
title: Who Benefits from State Corporate Tax Cuts? A Local Labor Market Approach with Heterogeneous Firms: Reply
abstract: <jats:p> In Suárez Serrato and Zidar (2016), we estimate the incidence of state corporate taxes. Malgouyres, Mayer, and Mazet-Sonilhac (2023) highlight two errors, ignoring effects on firm composition and characterizing capital costs inconsistently. This reply corrects the structural model and corresponding incidence estimates. The incidence results are similar to the originally reported estimates and the confidence intervals widen for some estimates. In the corrected structural model, the firm owner incidence share estimate changes by 1.6 percentage points relative to the original version (i.e., 38.1 percent versus 36.5 percent). The worker share estimate is 35.0 percent. Landowners bear the remaining 26.8 percent. (JEL H22, H25, H32, H71, R23, R51) </jats:p>
research_question: Who bears the incidence of state corporate tax cuts across different economic actors (firm owners, workers, and landowners)?
answer: After correcting structural model errors, firm owners bear 38.1% of corporate tax incidence, workers bear 35.0%, and landowners bear 26.8%. These results are similar to the original estimates despite the corrections.
positioning_statement: This paper is a reply that corrects methodological errors identified by Malgouyres, Mayer, and Mazet-Sonilhac (2023) in the original Suárez Serrato and Zidar (2016) study, specifically addressing issues with firm composition effects and capital cost characterization while validating the robustness of the original incidence findings.

author: Joshua Schwartzstein
title: Representation and Extrapolation: Evidence from Clinical Trials
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article examines the consequences and causes of low enrollment of Black patients in clinical trials. We develop a simple model of similarity-based extrapolation that predicts that evidence is more relevant for decision-making by physicians and patients when it is more representative of the group being treated. This generates the key result that the perceived benefit of a medicine for a group depends not only on the average benefit from a trial but also on the share of patients from that group who were enrolled in the trial. In survey experiments, we find that physicians who care for Black patients are more willing to prescribe drugs tested in representative samples, an effect substantial enough to close observed gaps in the prescribing rates of new medicines. Black patients update more on drug efficacy when the sample that the drug is tested on is more representative, reducing Black-white patient gaps in beliefs about whether the drug will work as described. Despite these benefits of representative data, our framework and evidence suggest that those who have benefited more from past medical breakthroughs are less costly to enroll in the present, leading to persistence in who is represented in the evidence base.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the consequences and causes of low enrollment of Black patients in clinical trials, and how does the representativeness of trial samples affect physician prescribing behavior and patient beliefs about drug efficacy?
answer: The perceived benefit of a medicine for a group depends not only on the average benefit from a trial but also on the share of patients from that group enrolled in the trial. Physicians caring for Black patients are more willing to prescribe drugs tested in representative samples (enough to close observed prescribing gaps), and Black patients update more on drug efficacy when samples are more representative, reducing Black-white gaps in beliefs about drug effectiveness.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel similarity-based extrapolation model to explain how evidence representativeness affects medical decision-making, providing both theoretical framework and empirical evidence for why representative clinical trial enrollment matters for reducing healthcare disparities - an issue that has been observed but not systematically modeled in existing literature.

author: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato
title: Tax Policy and Local Labor Market Behavior
abstract: <jats:p> Since 2002, the US government has encouraged business investment using accelerated depreciation policies that significantly reduce investment costs. We provide the first in-depth analysis of this stimulus on employment and earnings. Our local labor markets approach exploits cross-industry variation in policy generosity interacted with county-level industry location data. This strategy identifies the partial equilibrium effects of accelerated depreciation. Places that experience larger decreases in investment costs see an increase in employment and earnings. In contrast, the policy does not have positive effects on earnings-per-worker. Overall, our findings suggest federal corporate tax policy has large effects on local labor markets. (JEL D25, G31, H25, H32, J23, J31, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of accelerated depreciation tax policies on local labor market outcomes, specifically employment and earnings?
answer: Places that experience larger decreases in investment costs from accelerated depreciation policies see increases in employment and earnings, but the policy does not have positive effects on earnings-per-worker, demonstrating that federal corporate tax policy has large effects on local labor markets.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first in-depth analysis of accelerated depreciation stimulus effects on employment and earnings, using a novel local labor markets approach that exploits cross-industry variation in policy generosity interacted with county-level industry location data to identify partial equilibrium effects.

author: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato
title: Tax Advantages and Imperfect Competition in Auctions for Municipal Bonds
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the interaction between tax advantages for municipal bonds and the market structure of auctions for these bonds. We show that this interaction can limit a bidder’s ability to extract information rents and is a crucial determinant of state and local governments’ borrowing costs. Reduced-form estimates show that increasing the tax advantage by 3 pp lowers mean borrowing costs by 9–10$\%$. We estimate a structural auction model to measure markups and to illustrate and quantify how the interaction between tax policy and bidder strategic behaviour determines the impact of tax advantages on municipal borrowing costs. We use the estimated model to evaluate the efficiency of Obama and Trump administration policies that limit the tax advantage for municipal bonds. Because reductions in the tax advantage inflate bidder markups and depress competition, the resulting increase in municipal borrowing costs more than offsets the tax savings to the government. Finally, we use the model to analyse a recent non-tax regulation that affects entry into municipal bond auctions.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the interaction between tax advantages for municipal bonds and the market structure of auctions for these bonds affect state and local governments' borrowing costs?
answer: The interaction between tax advantages and auction market structure is a crucial determinant of municipal borrowing costs, with a 3 percentage point increase in tax advantage lowering mean borrowing costs by 9-10%. Reductions in tax advantages inflate bidder markups, depress competition, and increase municipal borrowing costs more than they save in tax revenue for the government.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by studying the previously unexplored interaction between tax policy and bidder strategic behavior in municipal bond auctions, using both reduced-form estimates and a structural auction model to measure markups and quantify how this interaction determines the impact of tax advantages on borrowing costs.

author: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato
title: State Taxes and Spatial Misallocation
abstract: We study state taxes as a potential source of spatial misallocation in the United States. We build a spatial general-equilibrium framework that incorporates salient features of the U.S. state tax system, and use changes in state tax rates between 1980 and 2010 to estimate the model parameters that determine how worker and rm location responds to changes in state taxes. We nd that tax dispersion leads to aggregate losses and the potential losses from even greater tax dispersion can be large. A government-spending-constant elimination of spatial dispersion in state taxes (which account for 4% of GDP) would increase worker welfare by 0.2%, while doubling spatial tax dispersion would reduce worker welfare by 0.4%.

author: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato
title: Tax Policy and Lumpy Investment Behaviour: Evidence from China’s VAT Reform
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We incorporate the lumpy nature of firm-level investment into the study of how tax policy affects investment behaviour. We show that tax policies can directly impact the lumpiness of investment. Extensive-margin responses to tax policy are key to understanding the effects of different tax reforms and to designing effective stimulus policies. We illustrate these results by studying China’s 2009 VAT reform, which lowered the tax cost of investment and reduced partial irreversibility—the price gap between new and used capital. Using comprehensive tax survey data and a difference-in-differences design, we estimate a 36$\%$ relative investment increase that is driven by investment spikes. Using a dynamic investment model that fits the reduced-form effects of the reform, we show that policies that directly reduce the likelihood of firm inaction are more effective at stimulating investment.</jats:p>
research_question: How does tax policy affect lumpy investment behavior at the firm level, specifically examining both the intensive and extensive margins of investment responses?
answer: Tax policies can directly impact the lumpiness of investment, with extensive-margin responses being key to understanding tax reform effects. China's 2009 VAT reform generated a 36% relative investment increase driven by investment spikes, and policies that directly reduce firm inaction likelihood are more effective at stimulating investment than those operating through other channels.
positioning_statement: This paper incorporates the lumpy nature of firm-level investment into tax policy analysis, extending beyond traditional studies by emphasizing extensive-margin responses and showing that policies reducing partial irreversibility and firm inaction are more effective stimulus tools than conventional approaches.

author: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato
title: Notching R&D Investment with Corporate Income Tax Cuts in China
abstract: <jats:p> We study a Chinese policy that awards substantial tax cuts to firms with R&D investment over a threshold or “notch.” Quasi-experimental variation and administrative tax data show a significant increase in reported R&D that is partly driven by firms relabeling expenses as R&D. Structural estimates show relabeling accounts for 24.2 percent of reported R&D and that doubling R&D would increase productivity by 9 percent. Policy simulations show that firm selection and relabeling determine the cost-effectiveness of stimulating R&D, that notch-based policies are more effective than tax credits when relabeling is prevalent, and that modest spillovers justify the program from a welfare perspective. (JEL D22, D24, H25, O14, O32, P31, P35) </jats:p>
research_question: How effective are notch-based corporate income tax cuts in stimulating genuine R&D investment in China, and what role does expense relabeling play in firms' responses to this policy?
answer: The policy significantly increases reported R&D investment, but 24.2% of this increase comes from firms relabeling existing expenses as R&D rather than genuine new investment. Despite this relabeling, doubling R&D would increase productivity by 9%, and the notch-based policy is more cost-effective than tax credits when relabeling is prevalent, with modest spillovers justifying the program from a welfare perspective.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on R&D tax incentives by using quasi-experimental variation and administrative tax data to quantify the extent of expense relabeling in response to tax policy, providing structural estimates that separate genuine R&D investment from relabeling behavior, and comparing the effectiveness of notch-based policies versus traditional tax credits in the presence of relabeling.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: On the Timing and Pricing of Dividends
abstract: <jats:p> We present evidence on the term structure of the equity premium. We recover prices of dividend strips, which are short-term assets that pay dividends on the stock index every period up to period T and nothing thereafter. It is short-term relative to the index because the index pays dividends in perpetuity. We find that expected returns, Sharpe ratios, and volatilities on short-term assets are higher than on the index, while their CAPM betas are below one. Short-term assets are more volatile than their realizations, leading to excess volatility and return predictability. Our findings are inconsistent with many leading theories. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the characteristics of the term structure of the equity premium, specifically how do short-term dividend strips compare to the overall stock index in terms of returns, volatility, and predictability?
answer: Short-term dividend strips have higher expected returns, Sharpe ratios, and volatilities compared to the stock index, while having CAPM betas below one. These short-term assets also exhibit excess volatility relative to their realizations, leading to return predictability.
positioning_statement: The findings are inconsistent with many leading theories in finance, suggesting that existing theoretical frameworks may not adequately explain the observed patterns in dividend strip pricing and the term structure of equity premiums.

author: Juan Carlos Suárez Serrato
title: Regulating Conglomerates: Evidence from an Energy Conservation Program in China
abstract: <jats:p> We study a prominent energy regulation affecting large Chinese manufacturers that are part of broader conglomerates. Using detailed firm-level data and difference-in-differences research designs, we show that regulated firms cut output and shifted some production to unregulated firms within their conglomerate instead of improving their energy efficiency. To account for conglomerate and market spillovers, we interpret these results through the lens of an industry equilibrium model featuring conglomerate production. The policy raises welfare if the per ton benefits of carbon reduction exceed $161. Alternative policies that exploit public information on business networks can increase aggregate energy savings by 10 percent. (JEL D22, L22, L51, L60, P28, P31, Q48) </jats:p>
research_question: How do large Chinese manufacturing firms that are part of conglomerates respond to energy conservation regulations, and what are the welfare implications of such policies?
answer: Regulated firms cut output and shifted production to unregulated firms within their conglomerate rather than improving energy efficiency. The policy raises welfare only if carbon reduction benefits exceed $161 per ton, and alternative policies using business network information could increase energy savings by 10 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining energy regulation effects on conglomerates using an industry equilibrium model that accounts for both conglomerate and market spillovers, providing a framework to evaluate alternative policies that exploit public information on business networks.

author: Julia Cagé
title: The Production of Information in an Online World
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>News production requires investment, and competitors’ ability to appropriate a story may reduce a media’s incentives to provide original content. Yet, there is little legal protection of intellectual property rights in online news production, which raises the issue of the extent of copying online and the incentives to provide original content. In this article, we build a unique dataset combining all the online content produced by French news media during the year 2013 with new micro audience data. We develop a topic detection algorithm that identifies each news event, trace the timeline of each story, and study news propagation. We provide new evidence on online news production. First, we document high reactivity of online media: one quarter of the news stories are reproduced online in under 4 min. We show that this is accompanied by substantial copying, both at the extensive and at the intensive margins, which may constitute a severe threat to the commercial viability of the news media. Next, we estimate the returns to originality in online news production. Using article-level variations and media-level daily audience combined with article-level social media statistics, we find that original content producers tend to receive more viewers, thereby mitigating the newsgathering incentive problem raised by copying.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the extent of copying in online news production and what are the incentives for media outlets to provide original content given the lack of intellectual property protection?
answer: There is substantial copying in online news (one quarter of stories are reproduced within 4 minutes), but original content producers receive more viewers, which mitigates the disincentive effects of copying on news production.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in understanding online news production dynamics by providing new empirical evidence on copying behavior and originality returns, using a unique comprehensive dataset of French news media combined with novel topic detection algorithms to trace news propagation timelines.

author: Jules van Binsbergen
title: On the Timing and Pricing of Dividends: Reply
abstract: <jats:p> Schulz (2016) replicates the findings of van Binsbergen, Brandt, and Koijen (2012)—henceforth, BBK—and agrees that the average pretax returns on short-term dividend strips are higher than those of the index, but argues that the after-tax returns are not. He thus provides a possible economic interpretation of the results in BBK: taxes. Schulz (2016) estimates the differential tax rates of dividends versus capital gains from ex-dividend day returns. We show that these estimated tax rates are suspect and imprecisely measured, peaking at over 100 percent in some periods. The results in BBK are robust to using tax rates from the literature (Sialm 2009). The arguments in Schulz (2016) thus crucially depend on implausibly large tax esti mates. We further discuss two other financial market imperfections discussed in the literature and show that they are also unlikely to explain the results in BBK. (JEL G11, G12, G35) </jats:p>
research_question: Can taxes or other financial market imperfections explain the finding that short-term dividend strips have higher average pretax returns than the index?
answer: Taxes and other financial market imperfections are unlikely to explain the dividend strip return anomaly, as the tax rate estimates used to support the tax explanation are implausibly large (over 100% in some periods) and imprecisely measured, and the original results remain robust when using established tax rates from the literature.
positioning_statement: This paper defends the original findings of van Binsbergen, Brandt, and Koijen (2012) against the tax-based critique by Schulz (2016), demonstrating that the proposed tax explanation relies on suspect methodology and implausibly high tax rate estimates, while also addressing other potential market imperfection explanations discussed in the broader literature.

author: Julia Cagé
title: Heroes and Villains: The Effects of Heroism on Autocratic Values and Nazi Collaboration in France
abstract: <jats:p>We measure how a network of heroes can legitimize and diffuse extreme political behaviors. We exploit newly declassified intelligence files, novel voting data, and regimental histories to show that home municipalities of French line regiments arbitrarily rotated under Philippe Pétain’s generalship through the heroic World War I battlefield of Verdun diverge politically thereafter, particularly following Pétain’s own overt espousal of authoritarian views. Further, under Pétain’s collaborationist Vichy regime (1940–1944), they raise 7 percent more active Nazi collaborators per capita. These effects extend across all forms of Nazi collaboration and diffuse beyond the veterans themselves. (JEL D72, D74, N34, N44, Z13)</jats:p>
research_question: How does a network of heroes legitimize and diffuse extreme political behaviors, specifically examining the effects of heroism on autocratic values and Nazi collaboration in France?
answer: Home municipalities of French line regiments that served under Philippe Pétain's generalship at the heroic World War I battlefield of Verdun subsequently diverged politically and raised 7 percent more active Nazi collaborators per capita under Pétain's collaborationist Vichy regime, with these effects extending across all forms of Nazi collaboration and diffusing beyond the veterans themselves.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by exploiting newly declassified intelligence files, novel voting data, and regimental histories to provide empirical evidence of how heroic networks can legitimize and spread extreme political behaviors, using the specific historical context of French regiments' arbitrary rotation through Verdun under Pétain's command.

author: Juliane Begenau
title: A Q-Theory of Banks
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Bank capital requirements are based on book values, which are slow to reflect losses. In this article, we develop a dynamic model of banks to study the interaction of regulation and delayed accounting. Our model explains four stylized facts: book and market values diverge during crises, the market-to-book ratio predicts future profitability, book leverage constraints rarely bind strictly even as market leverage fans out during crises, and banks delever gradually after net-worth shocks. We show how delayed accounting can allow the regulator to achieve better outcomes than immediate (mark-to-market) accounting. In an estimated version of the model, the optimal regulation couples faster loan-loss recognition with a modest relaxation of the book leverage constraint.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the interaction between bank capital regulation based on book values and delayed accounting recognition affect bank behavior and regulatory outcomes?
answer: Delayed accounting can allow regulators to achieve better outcomes than immediate mark-to-market accounting, and optimal regulation should combine faster loan-loss recognition with a modest relaxation of book leverage constraints.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a dynamic model that explains four previously unexplained stylized facts about bank behavior during crises, filling a gap in understanding how book-value-based regulation interacts with accounting delays to influence bank decision-making and market outcomes.

author: Juliane Begenau
title: Financial Regulation in a Quantitative Model of the Modern Banking System
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>How does the shadow banking system respond to changes in capital regulation of commercial banks? We propose a quantitative general equilibrium model with regulated and unregulated banks to study the unintended consequences of regulation. Tighter capital requirements for regulated banks cause higher convenience yield on debt of all banks, leading to higher shadow bank leverage and a larger shadow banking sector. At the same time, tighter regulation eliminates the subsidies to commercial banks from deposit insurance, reducing the competitive pressures on shadow banks to take risks. The net effect is a safer financial system with more shadow banking. Calibrating the model to data on financial institutions in the US, the optimal capital requirement is around 16$\%$.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the shadow banking system respond to changes in capital regulation of commercial banks?
answer: Tighter capital requirements for regulated banks lead to a safer overall financial system with more shadow banking - higher convenience yield on debt increases shadow bank leverage and sector size, but elimination of deposit insurance subsidies reduces competitive pressures for risk-taking, with the optimal capital requirement being around 16%.
positioning_statement: The paper proposes a quantitative general equilibrium model with both regulated and unregulated banks to study the unintended consequences of regulation, addressing the gap in understanding how banking regulation affects the broader financial system including shadow banking.

author: Jun Pan
title: Transform Analysis and Asset Pricing for Affine Jump-diffusions

author: Juuso Toikka
title: Value of Persistent Information
abstract: We develop a theory of how the value of an agent's information advantage depends on the persistence of information. We focus on strategic situations with strict conflict of interest, formalized as stochastic zero-sum games where only one of the players observes the state that evolves according to a Markov operator. Operator Q is said to be better for the informed player than operator P if the value of the game under Q is higher than under P regardless of the stage game. We show that this defines a convex partial order on the space of ergodic Markov operators. Our main result is a full characterization of this partial order, intepretable as an ordinal notion of persistence relevant for games. The analysis relies on a novel characterization of the value of a stochastic game with incomplete information.

author: Juuso Toikka
title: Robust Incentives for Teams
abstract: <jats:p>We show that demanding team incentives to be robust to nonquantifiable uncertainty about the game played by the agents leads to contracts that align the agents' interests. Such contracts have a natural interpretation as team‐based compensation. Under budget balance they reduce to linear contracts, thus identifying profit‐sharing, or equity, as an optimal contract absent a sink or a source of funds. A linear contract also gives the best profit guarantee to an outside residual claimant. These contracts still suffer from the free‐rider problem, but a positive guarantee obtains if and only if the technology known to the contract designer is sufficiently productive.</jats:p>
research_question: How can team incentive contracts be designed to be robust to nonquantifiable uncertainty about the strategic interactions between agents?
answer: Demanding robustness to nonquantifiable uncertainty leads to contracts that align agents' interests, specifically linear contracts (profit-sharing or equity arrangements) under budget balance, which provide optimal guarantees despite free-rider problems when technology is sufficiently productive.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the team incentives literature by introducing a robustness criterion for contract design under uncertainty about agent interactions, providing theoretical justification for commonly observed linear compensation schemes like profit-sharing and equity arrangements.

author: Juuso Toikka
title: Simultaneous Model of Innovation, Secrecy, and Patent Policy

author: Juuso Toikka
title: Dynamic Oligopoly with Incomplete Information
abstract: We consider learning and signalling in a dynamic Cournot oligopoly where firms have private information about their production costs and only observe the market price, which is subject to unobservable demand shocks. An equilibrium is Markov if play depends on the history only through the firms’ beliefs about costs and calendar time. We characterize symmetric linear Markov equilibria as solutions to a boundary value problem. In every such equilibrium, given a long enough horizon, play converges to the static complete information outcome for the realized costs, but each firm only learns its competitors’ average cost. The weights assigned to costs and beliefs under the equilibrium strategies are non-monotone over time. We explain this by decomposing incentives into signalling and learning, and discuss implications for prices, quantities, and welfare.
