author: Juuso Toikka
title: Affiliated Common Value Auctions with Costly Entry
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Many auctions and procurement contests entail non-trivial bidding costs, which makes the bidders’ participation decisions endogenous to the auction design. We analyse the effect of different auction rules on potential bidders’ incentives to participate. We focus on first-price auctions with affiliated common values and a large pool of potential bidders. Our main interest is on auctions where the realized number of bidders is unknown at the bidding stage. In contrast to the standard case, both participation and bidding decisions are often non-monotonic in the symmetric equilibrium of our model. The expected revenue to the seller is often higher in the auction where the realized number of participating bidders is not disclosed.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different auction rules affect potential bidders' incentives to participate in first-price auctions with affiliated common values and costly entry, particularly when the realized number of bidders is unknown at the bidding stage?
answer: Both participation and bidding decisions are often non-monotonic in symmetric equilibrium when the number of bidders is unknown, and expected revenue to the seller is often higher when the realized number of participating bidders is not disclosed to bidders.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the standard auction theory literature by analyzing the case where bidders face costly entry and the realized number of bidders is unknown at the bidding stage, contrasting with standard models where these factors are typically known or costless.

author: Jörg Stoye
title: Nonparametric Analysis of Random Utility Models
abstract: This paper develops and implements a nonparametric test of Random Utility Models. The motivating application is to test the null hypothesis that a sample of cross-sectional demand distributions was generated by a population of rational consumers. We test a necessary and sufficient condition for this that does not rely on any restriction on unobserved heterogeneity or the number of goods. We also propose and implement a control function approach to account for endogenous expenditure. An econometric result of independent interest is a test for linear inequality constraints when these are represented as the vertices of a polyhedron rather than its faces. An empirical application to the U.K. Household Expenditure Survey illustrates computational feasibility of the method in demand problems with 5 goods.

author: Jörg Stoye
title: Confidence Intervals for Projections of Partially Identified Parameters
abstract:
<jats:p>We propose a bootstrap‐based 
            <jats:italic>calibrated projection</jats:italic> procedure to build confidence intervals for single components and for smooth functions of a partially identified parameter vector in moment (in)equality models. The method controls asymptotic coverage uniformly over a large class of data generating processes. The extreme points of the calibrated projection confidence interval are obtained by extremizing the value of the function of interest subject to a proper relaxation of studentized sample analogs of the moment (in)equality conditions. The degree of relaxation, or critical level, is calibrated so that the function of 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic>, not 
            <jats:italic>θ</jats:italic> itself, is uniformly asymptotically covered with prespecified probability. This calibration is based on repeatedly checking feasibility of linear programming problems, rendering it computationally attractive.
          </jats:p>
          <jats:p>Nonetheless, the program defining an extreme point of the confidence interval is generally nonlinear and potentially intricate. We provide an algorithm, based on the response surface method for global optimization, that approximates the solution rapidly and accurately, and we establish its rate of convergence. The algorithm is of independent interest for optimization problems with simple objectives and complicated constraints. An empirical application estimating an entry game illustrates the usefulness of the method. Monte Carlo simulations confirm the accuracy of the solution algorithm, the good statistical as well as computational performance of calibrated projection (including in comparison to other methods), and the algorithm's potential to greatly accelerate computation of other confidence intervals.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we construct confidence intervals for single components and smooth functions of partially identified parameter vectors in moment inequality models that control asymptotic coverage uniformly over a large class of data generating processes?
answer: The paper develops a bootstrap-based calibrated projection procedure that builds confidence intervals by extremizing the function of interest subject to relaxed studentized sample analogs of moment inequality conditions, with the critical level calibrated to ensure uniform asymptotic coverage, combined with a response surface method algorithm for efficient computation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on inference for partially identified parameters by proposing a computationally attractive method that uses linear programming for calibration and provides an optimization algorithm of independent interest, with demonstrated improvements in statistical and computational performance compared to other existing methods.

author: Karel Mertens
title: The Dynamic Effects of Personal and Corporate Income Tax Changes in the United States: Reply
abstract: <jats:p> In this reply to a comment by Jentsch and Lunsford, we show that the evidence for economic and statistically significant macroeconomic effects of tax changes in Mertens and Ravn (2013) remains present for a range of asymptotically valid inference methods. (JEL E23, E62, H24, H25, H31, H32) </jats:p>
research_question: Do personal and corporate income tax changes have statistically significant macroeconomic effects when using asymptotically valid inference methods?
answer: Yes, the evidence for economic and statistically significant macroeconomic effects of tax changes remains present across a range of asymptotically valid inference methods.
positioning_statement: This paper defends the original findings of Mertens and Ravn (2013) against methodological criticisms raised by Jentsch and Lunsford, demonstrating that the conclusions are robust to alternative statistical inference approaches.

author: Jörg Stoye
title: The Distribution of Doctor Quality: Evidence from Cardiologists in England

author: Jörg Stoye
title: Revealed Price Preference: Theory and Empirical Analysis
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>To determine the welfare implications of price changes in demand data, we introduce a revealed preference relation over prices. We show that the absence of cycles in this relation characterizes a consumer who trades off the utility of consumption against the disutility of expenditure. Our model can be applied whenever a consumer’s demand over a strict subset of all available goods is being analysed; it can also be extended to settings with discrete goods and non-linear prices. To illustrate its use, we apply our model to a single-agent data set and to a data set with repeated cross-sections. We develop a novel test of linear hypotheses on partially identified parameters to estimate the proportion of the population who are revealed better off due to a price change in the latter application. This new technique can be used for non-parametric counterfactual analysis more broadly.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we determine the welfare implications of price changes in demand data using revealed preference theory?
answer: The paper introduces a revealed preference relation over prices and shows that the absence of cycles in this relation characterizes a consumer who trades off utility of consumption against disutility of expenditure, providing a method to assess welfare effects of price changes.
positioning_statement: This paper extends traditional revealed preference theory by developing a framework that can be applied when analyzing consumer demand over a strict subset of available goods, and extends to settings with discrete goods and non-linear prices, offering a novel approach for non-parametric counterfactual analysis.

author: Kaspar Wüthrich
title: Detecting p‐Hacking
abstract:
<jats:p>We theoretically analyze the problem of testing for 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hacking based on distributions of 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐values across multiple studies. We provide general results for when such distributions have testable restrictions (are non‐increasing) under the null of no 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hacking. We find novel additional testable restrictions for 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐values based on 
            <jats:italic>t</jats:italic>‐tests. Specifically, the shape of the power functions results in both complete monotonicity as well as bounds on the distribution of 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐values. These testable restrictions result in more powerful tests for the null hypothesis of no 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hacking. When there is also publication bias, our tests are joint tests for 
            <jats:italic>p</jats:italic>‐hacking and publication bias. A reanalysis of two prominent data sets shows the usefulness of our new tests.
          </jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop better statistical tests to detect p-hacking based on distributions of p-values across multiple studies?
answer: The paper develops novel testable restrictions for p-values based on t-tests, finding that the shape of power functions results in complete monotonicity and bounds on p-value distributions, which enables more powerful tests for detecting p-hacking compared to existing methods.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on p-hacking detection by providing general theoretical results for when p-value distributions have testable restrictions under the null of no p-hacking, and introduces novel additional testable restrictions that result in more powerful tests than current approaches.

author: Karel Mertens
title: Leverage and the Financial Accelerator in a Liquidity Trap
abstract: <jats:p> We show that the financial accelerator may be very large in a liquidity trap. We study a sticky price model with real estate and a financial friction specified as a collateral constraint. Expectations can lead the economy to a self-fulfilling liquidity trap equilibrium where the lower bound on the nominal interest rate binds. We model these equilibria as stochastic sunspots. As in the Great Depression, a liquidity trap entails house price depreciation and potentially large output losses. Higher leverage implies much larger output losses but at the same time rules out the existence of short-lived liquidity traps. </jats:p>
research_question: How does the financial accelerator mechanism operate in a liquidity trap, particularly in relation to leverage and its effects on output losses?
answer: The financial accelerator may be very large in a liquidity trap, where higher leverage leads to much larger output losses but simultaneously prevents the existence of short-lived liquidity traps. Liquidity trap equilibria can be self-fulfilling and result in house price depreciation and potentially large output losses.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing financial accelerator literature by examining its operation specifically within liquidity trap conditions using a sticky price model with real estate and collateral constraints, drawing parallels to the Great Depression experience and modeling liquidity trap equilibria as stochastic sunspots.

author: Karel Mertens
title: Marginal Tax Rates and Income: New Time Series Evidence*

author: Karel Mertens
title: The Macroeconomic Effects of Government Asset Purchases: Evidence from Postwar U.S. Housing Credit Policy*
abstract: We document the portfolio activity of federal housing agencies and provide evidence on its impact on mortgage markets and the economy. Through a narrative analysis, we identify historical policy changes leading to expansions or contractions in agency mortgage holdings. Based on those regulatory events that we classify as unrelated to short-run cyclical or credit market shocks, we find that an increase in mortgage purchases by the agencies boosts mortgage lending and lowers mortgage rates. Agency purchases influence prices in other asset markets and stimulate residential investment. Using information in GSE stock prices to construct an alternative instrument for agency purchasing activity yields very similar results as our benchmark narrative identification approach.

author: Katherine Casey
title: Crossing Party Lines: The Effects of Information on Redistributive Politics
abstract: <jats:p> Many lament that weak accountability and poor governance impede economic development in Africa. Politicians rely on ethnic allegiances that deliver the vote irrespective of performance, dampening electoral incentives. Giving voters information about candidate competence counters ethnic loyalty and strengthens accountability. I extend a canonical electoral model to show how information provision flows through voter behavior and ultimately impacts the distribution of political spending. I test the theory on data from Sierra Leone using decentralization and differential radio coverage to identify information's effects. Estimates suggest that information increases voting across ethnic-party lines and induces a more equitable allocation of campaign spending. (JEL D72, D83, J15, O17, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does providing voters with information about candidate competence affect electoral behavior and the distribution of political spending in contexts where ethnic allegiances traditionally determine voting patterns?
answer: Information provision increases cross-ethnic voting (voters choosing candidates outside their ethnic group) and leads to a more equitable allocation of campaign spending across different groups.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the widely recognized problem of weak accountability and poor governance in Africa by extending canonical electoral models to examine how information can counter ethnic-based voting patterns and strengthen democratic accountability through altered voter behavior and political spending distributions.

author: Karel Mertens
title: The Dynamic Effects of Personal and Corporate Income Tax Changes in the United States
abstract: <jats:p> This paper estimates the dynamic effects of changes in taxes in the United States. We distinguish between changes in personal and corporate income taxes and develop a new narrative account of federal tax liability changes in these two tax components. We develop an estimator which uses narratively identified tax changes as proxies for structural tax shocks and apply it to quarterly post-WWII data. We find that short run output effects of tax shocks are large and that it is important to distinguish between different types of taxes when considering their impact on the labor market and on expenditure components. (JEL E23, E62, H24, H25, H31, H32) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the dynamic effects of changes in personal and corporate income taxes on the U.S. economy?
answer: Short run output effects of tax shocks are large, and different types of taxes (personal vs. corporate income taxes) have distinct impacts on labor markets and expenditure components.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a new narrative account that distinguishes between personal and corporate income tax changes and creates an estimator that uses narratively identified tax changes as proxies for structural tax shocks, applied to quarterly post-WWII U.S. data.

author: Katherine Casey
title: An Experiment in Candidate Selection
abstract: <jats:p> Are ordinary citizens or political party leaders better positioned to select candidates? While the American primary system lets citizens choose, most democracies rely instead on party officials to appoint or nominate candidates. The consequences of these distinct design choices are unclear: while officials are often better informed about candidate qualifications, they may value traits, like party loyalty or willingness to pay for the nomination, at odds with identifying the best performer. We partnered with both major political parties in Sierra Leone to experimentally vary how much say voters have in selecting Parliamentary candidates. Estimates suggest that more democratic procedures increase the likelihood that parties select voters’ most preferred candidates and favor candidates with stronger records of public goods provision. (JEL D72, H41, O17) </jats:p>
research_question: Are ordinary citizens or political party leaders better positioned to select candidates for political office?
answer: More democratic candidate selection procedures (giving voters more say) increase the likelihood that parties select voters' most preferred candidates and favor candidates with stronger records of public goods provision.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses an unclear area in the literature regarding the consequences of different candidate selection systems - contrasting the American primary system where citizens choose versus most democracies where party officials appoint candidates, and examining the trade-off between officials' better information about qualifications versus their potential preference for traits like party loyalty over performance.

author: Katherine Casey
title: Debates: Voting and Expenditure Responses to Political Communication
abstract: Candidate debates have a rich history and remain integral to contemporary campaign strategy. There is, however, little evidence that they affect the behavior of voters or politicians. The scarcity of political information in the developing world offers an attractive testing ground. Using experimental variation in Sierra Leone, we find that public debate screenings build political knowledge that changes the way people vote, which induces a campaign expenditure response by candidates and fosters accountability pressure over the spending of elected officials. Results show how political communication can trigger a chain of events that begins with voters and ultimately influences policy.

author: Katherine Casey
title: Reshaping Institutions: Evidence on Aid Impacts Using a Preanalysis Plan*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Despite their importance, there is limited evidence on how institutions can be strengthened. Evaluating the effects of specific reforms is complicated by the lack of exogenous variation in institutions, the difficulty of measuring institutional performance, and the temptation to “cherry pick” estimates from among the large number of indicators required to capture this multifaceted subject. We evaluate one attempt to make local institutions more democratic and egalitarian by imposing participation requirements for marginalized groups (including women) and test for learning-by-doing effects. We exploit the random assignment of a governance program in Sierra Leone, develop innovative real-world outcome measures, and use a preanalysis plan (PAP) to bind our hands against data mining. The intervention studied is a “community-driven development” program, which has become a popular strategy for foreign aid donors. We find positive short-run effects on local public goods and economic outcomes, but no evidence for sustained impacts on collective action, decision making, or the involvement of marginalized groups, suggesting that the intervention did not durably reshape local institutions. We discuss the practical trade-offs faced in implementing a PAP and show how in its absence we could have generated two divergent, equally erroneous interpretations of program impacts on institutions.</jats:p>
research_question: Can institutions be strengthened through aid interventions that impose participation requirements for marginalized groups, and do such interventions have sustained impacts on local democratic and egalitarian governance?
answer: The community-driven development program produced positive short-run effects on local public goods and economic outcomes, but failed to create sustained impacts on collective action, decision making, or involvement of marginalized groups, indicating that the intervention did not durably reshape local institutions.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the limited evidence on institutional strengthening by tackling three key methodological challenges that have plagued prior research: the lack of exogenous variation in institutions, difficulty measuring institutional performance, and the temptation to cherry-pick results from multiple indicators. The study contributes methodologically by using random assignment, innovative real-world outcome measures, and a preanalysis plan to prevent data mining.

author: Keisuke Hirano
title: A Comment on: “Invidious Comparisons: Ranking and Selection as Compound Decisions” by Jiaying Gu and Roger Koenker

author: Keisuke Hirano
title: Semiparametric Bayesian Inference in Autoregressive Panel Data Models

author: Keisuke Hirano
title: Asymptotic Efficiency in Parametric Structural Models with Parameter-Dependent Support

author: Keisuke Hirano
title: Forecasting With Model Uncertainty: Representations and Risk Reduction
abstract: We consider forecasting with uncertainty about the choice of predictor variables. The researcher wants to select a model, estimate the parameters, and use the parameter estimates for forecasting. We investigate the distributional properties of a number of different schemes for model choice and parameter estimation, including: in‐sample model selection using the Akaike information criterion; out‐of‐sample model selection; and splitting the data into subsamples for model selection and parameter estimation. Using a weak‐predictor local asymptotic scheme, we provide a representation result that facilitates comparison of the distributional properties of the procedures and their associated forecast risks. This representation isolates the source of inefficiency in some of these procedures. We develop a simulation procedure that improves the accuracy of the out‐of‐sample and split‐sample methods uniformly over the local parameter space. We also examine how bootstrap aggregation (bagging) affects the local asymptotic risk of the estimators and their associated forecasts. Numerically, we find that for many values of the local parameter, the out‐of‐sample and split‐sample schemes perform poorly if implemented in the conventional way. But they perform well, if implemented in conjunction with our risk‐reduction method or bagging.

author: Kelly Shue
title: Promotions and the Peter Principle*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The best worker is not always the best candidate for manager. In these cases, do firms promote the best potential manager or the best worker in their current job? Using microdata on the performance of sales workers at 131 firms, we find evidence consistent with the Peter Principle, which proposes that firms prioritize current job performance in promotion decisions at the expense of other observable characteristics that better predict managerial performance. We estimate that the costs of promoting workers with lower managerial potential are high, suggesting either that firms are making inefficient promotion decisions or that the benefits of promotion-based incentives are great enough to justify the costs of managerial mismatch. We find that firms manage the costs of the Peter Principle by placing less weight on sales performance in promotion decisions when managerial roles entail greater responsibility and when frontline workers are incentivized by strong pay for performance.</jats:p>
research_question: When the best worker is not the best candidate for manager, do firms promote the best potential manager or the best worker in their current job?
answer: Firms exhibit behavior consistent with the Peter Principle, prioritizing current job performance in promotion decisions at the expense of other observable characteristics that better predict managerial performance, though they mitigate costs by placing less weight on sales performance when managerial roles have greater responsibility and when frontline workers have strong pay-for-performance incentives.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence for the Peter Principle using microdata on sales worker performance across 131 firms, contributing to the literature on promotion decisions by quantifying the costs of promoting workers with lower managerial potential and identifying conditions under which firms adjust their promotion criteria to manage these costs.

author: Keisuke Hirano
title: Efficient Estimation of Average Treatment Effects Using the Estimated Propensity Score

author: Keisuke Hirano
title: Combining Panel Data Sets with Attrition and Refreshment Samples

author: Keisuke Hirano
title: Robustness to Parametric Assumptions in Missing Data Models
abstract: <jats:p> We consider estimation of population averages when data are missing at random. If some cells contain few observations, there can be substantial gains from imposing parametric restrictions on the cell means, but there is also a danger of misspecification. We develop a simple empirical Bayes estimator, which combines parametric and unadjusted estimates of cell means in a data-driven way. We also consider ways to use knowledge of the form of the propensity score to increase robustness. We develop an empirical Bayes extension of a double robust estimator. In a small simulation study, the empirical Bayes estimators perform well. They are similar to fully nonparametric methods and robust to misspecification when cells are moderate to large in size, and when cells are small they maintain the benefits of parametric methods and can have lower sampling variance. </jats:p>
research_question: How can we robustly estimate population averages when data are missing at random, particularly when some cells contain few observations and there is uncertainty about parametric model specifications?
answer: A simple empirical Bayes estimator that combines parametric and unadjusted estimates of cell means in a data-driven way performs well across different scenarios - it maintains robustness to misspecification when cells are moderate to large in size (similar to nonparametric methods) while preserving the benefits of parametric methods with lower sampling variance when cells are small.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the trade-off between the substantial gains from imposing parametric restrictions on cell means versus the danger of misspecification in missing data models, developing empirical Bayes methods that bridge parametric and nonparametric approaches, including an extension of double robust estimators.

author: Kelsey Jack
title: Seasonal Liquidity, Rural Labor Markets, and Agricultural Production
abstract: <jats:p> Rural economies in many developing countries are characterized by a lean season in the months preceding harvest, when farmers have depleted their cash and grain savings from the previous year. To identify the impacts of liquidity during the lean season, we offered subsidized loans in randomly selected villages in rural Zambia. Ninety-eight percent of households took up the loan. Loan eligibility led to increases in on-farm labor and agricultural output, driving up wages in local labor markets. Larger effects for poorer households suggest that liquidity constraints contribute to inequality in rural economies. (JEL O13, O15, O18, Q11, Q12, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the impacts of liquidity constraints during the lean season on agricultural production and rural labor markets in developing countries?
answer: Providing subsidized loans during the lean season increases on-farm labor and agricultural output, drives up local wages, and has larger effects for poorer households, demonstrating that liquidity constraints contribute to inequality in rural economies.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the understudied issue of seasonal liquidity constraints in rural developing economies by using a randomized controlled trial to identify causal impacts on agricultural production and labor markets, contributing to literature on rural finance, agricultural productivity, and inequality in developing countries.

author: Koichiro Ito
title: Do Consumers Respond to Marginal or Average Price? Evidence from Nonlinear Electricity Pricing
abstract: <jats:p> Nonlinear pricing and taxation complicate economic decisions by creating multiple marginal prices for the same good. This paper provides a framework to uncover consumers’ perceived price of nonlinear price schedules. I exploit price variation at spatial discontinuities in electricity service areas, where households in the same city experience substantially different nonlinear pricing. Using household-level panel data from administrative records, I find strong evidence that consumers respond to average price rather than marginal or expected marginal price. This suboptimizing behavior makes nonlinear pricing unsuccessful in achieving its policy goal of energy conservation and critically changes the welfare implications of nonlinear pricing. (JEL D12, L11, L94, L98, Q41) </jats:p>
research_question: Do consumers respond to marginal price or average price when facing nonlinear electricity pricing schedules?
answer: Consumers respond to average price rather than marginal or expected marginal price, demonstrating suboptimizing behavior that makes nonlinear pricing unsuccessful in achieving energy conservation goals.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a framework to uncover consumers' perceived price of nonlinear price schedules by exploiting spatial discontinuities in electricity service areas, contributing to the literature on how nonlinear pricing and taxation complicate economic decisions and critically changing the understanding of welfare implications of nonlinear pricing.

author: Kelsey Jack
title: Money (Not) to Burn: Payments for Ecosystem Services to Reduce Crop Residue Burning
abstract: <jats:p> We test whether payments for ecosystem services (PES) can curb the highly polluting practice of crop residue burning in India. Standard PES contracts pay participants after verification that they met a proenvironment condition (clearing fields without burning). We randomize paying a portion of the money up front and unconditionally to address liquidity constraints and farmer distrust, which may undermine the standard contract’s effectiveness. Incorporating partial up-front payment into the contract increases compliance by 10 percentage points, which is corroborated by satellite-based burning measurements. The cost per life saved is $3,600–$5,400. The standard PES contract has no effect on burning. (JEL D86, O13, Q12, Q15, Q18, Q53, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: Can payments for ecosystem services (PES) effectively reduce crop residue burning in India, and does incorporating partial up-front payment improve contract effectiveness compared to standard PES contracts?
answer: Standard PES contracts have no effect on crop residue burning, but incorporating partial up-front payment into PES contracts increases compliance by 10 percentage points, with a cost per life saved of $3,600–$5,400.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the payments for ecosystem services literature by testing a novel contract design modification (partial up-front payment) to address liquidity constraints and farmer distrust that may undermine standard PES contract effectiveness, specifically in the context of reducing crop residue burning pollution in India.

author: Kelsey Jack
title: Poor and Rational: Decision-Making under Scarcity
abstract: We investigate the link between poverty and decision-making in a sample of farmers in Zambia, who were given the opportunity to exchange randomly assigned household items for alternative items of similar value. Analyzing a total of 5,842 trading decisions and leveraging multiple sources of variation in financial constraints, we show that exchange asymmetries decrease in magnitude when participants are more constrained. This result is robust to experimental procedures and is not mediated by changes in cognitive performance. Consistent with the interpretation that scarcity leads to more rational decisions by increasing the utility loss from forgone trading, we show that trading probabilities go up when the market value of the items is exogenously increased.

author: Kelsey Jack
title: Pay as You Go: Prepaid Metering and Electricity Expenditures in South Africa
abstract: <jats:p> High rates of customer default on utility bills present a barrier to the expansion of electricity access in the developing world. Pre-paid electricity metering offers a technological solution to ensuring timely payment. Using an eleven-year panel of pre-paid electricity customers in Cape Town, South Africa, we describe patterns of purchase behavior across property values, our measure of socioeconomic status. Poorer households buy electricity more often, in smaller increments, and are most likely to buy on payday. These patterns suggest difficulties smoothing income, and reveal a preference for small, frequent purchases that is incompatible with a standard monthly electricity billing cycle. </jats:p>
research_question: How do prepaid electricity metering systems affect electricity purchase behavior patterns across different socioeconomic groups, and what do these patterns reveal about income smoothing difficulties and payment preferences?
answer: Poorer households buy electricity more frequently in smaller increments and are most likely to purchase on payday, indicating difficulties with income smoothing and a preference for small, frequent purchases that is incompatible with standard monthly billing cycles.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the barrier of high customer default rates on utility bills that impede electricity access expansion in developing countries by examining prepaid metering as a technological solution, using detailed behavioral data to reveal previously undocumented patterns in electricity purchasing behavior across socioeconomic groups.

author: Kenneth Ahern
title: The Changing of the Boards: The Impact on Firm Valuation of Mandated Female Board Representation *

author: Kerry Back
title: Information in Securities Markets: Kyle Meets Glosten and Milgrom

author: Kerry Back
title: Activism, Strategic Trading, and Liquidity
abstract: We analyze dynamic trading by an activist investor who can expend costly effort to affect firm value. We obtain the equilibrium in closed form for a general activism technology, including both binary and continuous outcomes. Variation in parameters can produce either positive or negative relations between market liquidity and economic efficiency, depending on the activism technology and model parameters. Two results that contrast with the previous literature are that (a) the relationship between market liquidity and economic efficiency is independent of the activist's initial stake for a broad set of activism technologies, and (b) an increase in noise trading can reduce market liquidity because it increases uncertainty about the activist's trades (the activist trades in the opposite direction of noise traders) and thereby increases information asymmetry about the activist's intentions.

author: Kelly Shue
title:
Decision Making Under the Gambler’s Fallacy: Evidence from Asylum Judges, Loan Officers, and Baseball Umpires
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We find consistent evidence of negative autocorrelation in decision making that is unrelated to the merits of the cases considered in three separate high-stakes field settings: refugee asylum court decisions, loan application reviews, and Major League Baseball umpire pitch calls. The evidence is most consistent with the law of small numbers and the gambler’s fallacy—people underestimating the likelihood of sequential streaks occurring by chance—leading to negatively autocorrelated decisions that result in errors. The negative autocorrelation is stronger among more moderate and less experienced decision makers, following longer streaks of decisions in one direction, when the current and previous cases share similar characteristics or occur close in time, and when decision makers face weaker incentives for accuracy. Other explanations for negatively autocorrelated decisions such as quotas, learning, or preferences to treat all parties fairly are less consistent with the evidence, though we cannot completely rule out sequential contrast effects as an alternative explanation.</jats:p>
research_question: Do decision makers in high-stakes field settings exhibit systematic biases in sequential decision making, specifically negative autocorrelation patterns that are inconsistent with the merits of cases?
answer: Yes, there is consistent evidence of negative autocorrelation in decision making across three high-stakes settings (asylum courts, loan applications, and baseball umpiring) that is unrelated to case merits and most consistent with the gambler's fallacy and law of small numbers, where decision makers underestimate the likelihood of sequential streaks occurring by chance, leading to negatively autocorrelated decisions that result in errors.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on behavioral biases in decision making by providing field evidence of the gambler's fallacy in high-stakes professional settings, distinguishing this bias from alternative explanations such as quotas, learning, preferences for fairness, and sequential contrast effects through systematic analysis across multiple domains.

author: Koichiro Ito
title: The Investment Effects of Market Integration: Evidence From Renewable Energy Expansion in Chile
abstract: <jats:p>We study the investment effects of market integration on renewable energy expansion. Our theory highlights that market integration not only improves allocative efficiency by gains from trade but also incentivizes new investment in renewable power plants. To test our theoretical predictions, we examine how recent grid expansions in the Chilean electricity market changed electricity production, wholesale prices, generation costs, and renewable investments. We then build a structural model of power plant entry to quantify the impact of market integration with and without the investment effects. We find that the market integration in Chile increased solar generation by around 180%, saved generation costs by 8%, and reduced carbon emissions by 5%. A substantial amount of renewable entry would not have occurred in the absence of market integration. Our findings suggest that ignoring these investment effects would substantially understate the benefits of market integration and its important role in expanding renewable energy.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the investment effects of market integration on renewable energy expansion?
answer: Market integration in Chile increased solar generation by around 180%, saved generation costs by 8%, and reduced carbon emissions by 5%, with substantial renewable entry that would not have occurred without market integration.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on market integration by highlighting that it not only improves allocative efficiency through gains from trade but also incentivizes new investment in renewable power plants, arguing that ignoring these investment effects substantially understates the benefits of market integration.

author: Koichiro Ito
title: Willingness to Pay for Clean Air: Evidence from Air Purifier Markets in China
abstract: We develop a framework to estimate willingness to pay for clean air from defensive investments on differentiated products. Applying this framework to scanner data on air purifier sales in China, we find that a household is willing to pay $1.34 annually to remove 1 μg/m3 of air pollution (PM10) and $32.7 annually to eliminate the pollution induced by the Huai River heating policy. Substantial heterogeneity is explained by income and exposure to information on air pollution. Using these estimates, we evaluate various environmental policies and quantify the value of recent air quality improvements since China declared a war on pollution in 2014.

author: Koichiro Ito
title: Sequential Markets, Market Power, and Arbitrage
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a framework to characterize strategic behavior in sequential markets under imperfect competition and restricted entry in arbitrage. Our theory predicts that these two elements can generate a systematic price premium. We test the model predictions using microdata from the Iberian electricity market. We show that the observed price differences and firm behavior are consistent with the model. Finally, we quantify the welfare effects of arbitrage using a structural model. In the presence of market power, we show that full arbitrage is not necessarily welfare-enhancing, reducing consumer costs but increasing deadweight loss. (JEL D42, D43, L12, L13, L94, Q41) </jats:p>
research_question: How do imperfect competition and restricted entry in arbitrage affect strategic behavior and pricing in sequential markets?
answer: These two elements can generate systematic price premiums, and full arbitrage is not necessarily welfare-enhancing as it reduces consumer costs but increases deadweight loss when market power is present.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new framework to characterize strategic behavior in sequential markets by incorporating both imperfect competition and restricted arbitrage entry, extending beyond existing literature that may not fully account for these combined market imperfections.

author: Konrad Burchardi
title: The Economic Impact of Social Ties: Evidence from German Reunification*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We use the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 to show that personal relationships which individuals maintain for noneconomic reasons can be an important determinant of regional economic growth. We show that West German households who had social ties to East Germany in 1989 experienced a persistent rise in their personal incomes after the fall of the Berlin Wall. Moreover, the presence of these households significantly affects economic performance at the regional level: it increases the returns to entrepreneurial activity, the share of households who become entrepreneurs, and the likelihood that firms based within a given West German region invest in East Germany. As a result, West German regions that (for idiosyncratic reasons) have a high concentration of households with social ties to the East exhibit substantially higher growth in income per capita in the early 1990s. A one standard deviation rise in the share of households with social ties to East Germany in 1989 is associated with a 4.7 percentage point rise in income per capita over six years. We interpret our findings as evidence of a causal link between social ties and regional economic development.</jats:p>
research_question: Can personal relationships that individuals maintain for noneconomic reasons be an important determinant of regional economic growth?
answer: Yes, social ties significantly impact regional economic development. West German regions with higher concentrations of households having social ties to East Germany experienced substantially higher income growth after reunification, with a one standard deviation increase in social ties associated with a 4.7 percentage point rise in income per capita over six years.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing causal evidence of the link between social ties and regional economic development, using the natural experiment of German reunification to identify how personal relationships maintained for noneconomic reasons can drive economic outcomes at both individual and regional levels.

author: Konrad Burchardi
title: Migrants, Ancestors, and Foreign Investments
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use 130 years of data on historical migrations to the U.S. to show a causal effect of the ancestry composition of U.S. counties on foreign direct investment (FDI) sent and received by local firms. To isolate the causal effect of ancestry on FDI, we build a simple reduced-form model of migrations: Migrations from a foreign country to a U.S. county at a given time depend on (1) a push factor, causing emigration from that foreign country to the entire U.S., and (2) a pull factor, causing immigration from all origins into that U.S. county. The interaction between time-series variation in origin-specific push factors and destination-specific pull factors generates quasi-random variation in the allocation of migrants across U.S. counties. We find that doubling the number of residents with ancestry from a given foreign country relative to the mean increases the probability that at least one local firm engages in FDI with that country by 4 percentage points. We present evidence that this effect is primarily driven by a reduction in information frictions, and not by better contract enforcement, taste similarities, or a convergence in factor endowments.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the ancestry composition of U.S. counties causally affect foreign direct investment (FDI) flows between local firms and the ancestral countries of origin?
answer: There is a causal effect of ancestry composition on FDI - doubling the number of residents with ancestry from a given foreign country increases the probability that at least one local firm engages in FDI with that country by 4 percentage points, primarily through reducing information frictions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by establishing a causal relationship between historical migration patterns and FDI flows using 130 years of migration data and a novel identification strategy that exploits quasi-random variation from the interaction of origin-specific push factors and destination-specific pull factors in migration patterns.

author: Konrad Burchardi
title: Moral Hazard: Experimental Evidence from Tenancy Contracts*
abstract: We report results from a field experiment designed to estimate the effects of tenancy contracts on agricultural input choices, risk-taking, and output. The experiment induced variation in the terms of sharecropping contracts: some tenants paid 50% of output in compensation for land usage; others paid 25%; again others paid 50% of output and received cash, either fixed or stochastic. We find that tenants with higher output share utilized more inputs, cultivated riskier crops, and generated 60% more output relative to control. Cash transfers did not effect farm output. We interpret the increase in output as the incentive effect of sharecropping.

author: Konrad Burchardi
title: Incentives and the De Soto Effect

author: Kurt Mitman
title: Macroeconomic Effects of Bankruptcy and Foreclosure Policies
abstract: <jats:p>I study the implications of two major debt-relief policies in the United States: the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act (BAPCPA) and the Home Affordable Refinance Program (HARP). To do so, I develop a model of housing and default that includes relevant dimensions of credit-market policy and captures rich heterogeneity in household balance sheets. The model also explains the observed cross-state variation in consumer default rates. I find that BAPCPA significantly reduced bankruptcy rates, but increased foreclosure rates when house prices fell. HARP reduced foreclosures by 1 percentage point and provided substantial welfare gains to households with high loan-to-value mortgages. (JEL D14, K35, R31)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the macroeconomic implications and effects of two major U.S. debt-relief policies: the Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act (BAPCPA) and the Home Affordable Refinance Program (HARP)?
answer: BAPCPA significantly reduced bankruptcy rates but increased foreclosure rates when house prices fell, while HARP reduced foreclosures by 1 percentage point and provided substantial welfare gains to households with high loan-to-value mortgages.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a comprehensive model of housing and default that incorporates relevant dimensions of credit-market policy and captures rich heterogeneity in household balance sheets, while also explaining observed cross-state variation in consumer default rates.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Media Frenzies in Markets for Financial Information
abstract: <jats:p> Emerging equity markets witness occasional surges in prices (frenzies) and cross-market price dispersion (herds), accompanied by abundant media coverage. An information market complementarity can explain these anomalies. Because information has high fixed costs, high volume makes it inexpensive. Low prices induce investors to buy information that others buy. Given two identical assets, investors learn about one; abundant information reduces its payoff risk and raises its price. Transitions between low-information/low-asset-price and high-information/high-asset-price equilibria resemble frenzies. Equity data and new panel data on news coverage support the model's predictions: Asset market movements generate news and news raises prices and price dispersion. </jats:p>
research_question: How can information market complementarity explain the occasional surges in prices (frenzies) and cross-market price dispersion (herds) accompanied by abundant media coverage in emerging equity markets?
answer: Information market complementarity creates a mechanism where high trading volume makes information inexpensive due to high fixed costs, leading investors to buy the same information others buy. This creates transitions between low-information/low-asset-price and high-information/high-asset-price equilibria that resemble market frenzies, with abundant information reducing payoff risk and raising prices.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel explanation for market anomalies in emerging equity markets by focusing on information market complementarity, offering an alternative theoretical framework to existing literature on market frenzies and herding behavior, supported by both equity data and new panel data on news coverage.

author: Kurt Mitman
title: Micro and Macro Effects of Unemployment Insurance Policies: Evidence from Missouri
abstract: We develop a method to jointly measure the response of worker search effort (micro effect) and vacancy creation (macro effect) to changes in the duration of unemployment insurance (UI) benefits. To implement this approach, we exploit an unexpected cut in UI durations in Missouri and provide quasi-experimental evidence on the effect of UI on the labor market. The data indicate that the cut in Missouri significantly increased job finding rates by both raising the search effort of unemployed workers and the availability of jobs. The latter accounts for at least one half of the total effect.

author: Kurt Mitman
title: The Housing Boom and Bust: Model Meets Evidence
abstract: We build a model of the US economy with multiple aggregate shocks that generate fluctuations in equilibrium house prices. Through counterfactual experiments, we study the housing boom-bust around the Great Recession, with three main results. First, the main driver of movements in house prices and rents was a shift in beliefs, not a change in credit conditions. Second, the boom-bust in house prices explains half of the corresponding swings in nondurable expenditures through a wealth effect. Third, a large-scale debt forgiveness program would have done little to temper the collapse of house prices and expenditures but would have dramatically reduced foreclosures and induced a small, but persistent, increase in consumption during the recovery.

author: Kristoph Kleiner
title: Battling over Jobs: Occupational Licensing in Health Care
abstract: <jats:p> The goal of this paper is to outline the major tensions between the monopoly face of licensing versus potential consumer protection goals of occupational regulation in the health care industry. Historically, health care occupations limited supply as a method of raising earnings, but with the growth in the number of newly regulated occupations, many professions have come in conflict over who gets to do the work. Rather than having consumers decide, state legislatures and licensing boards determine the allocation of tasks. The paper outlines policies that may allow consumers rather than service providers determine the direct allocation of these jobs. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the major tensions between the monopoly aspects of occupational licensing versus consumer protection goals in the health care industry, and how do conflicts over task allocation between professions affect this dynamic?
answer: Health care occupations have historically used licensing to limit supply and raise earnings, but the growth in newly regulated occupations has created conflicts between professions over task allocation, with state legislatures and licensing boards rather than consumers determining who performs specific work.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as examining the dual nature of occupational licensing in health care - acknowledging both the traditional monopoly/supply restriction function and the stated consumer protection rationale - while focusing on the emerging issue of inter-professional conflicts over work allocation that has arisen with the proliferation of licensed health care occupations.

author: Lars-Alexander Kuehn
title: Long Run Risks, Credit Markets, and Financial Structure

author: Lars-Alexander Kuehn
title: Endogenous Disasters
abstract: <jats:p> Market economies are intrinsically unstable. The standard search model of equilibrium unemployment, once solved accurately with a globally nonlinear algorithm, gives rise endogenously to rare disasters. Intuitively, in the presence of cumulatively large negative shocks, inertial wages remain relatively high, and reduce profits. The marginal costs of hiring run into downward rigidity, which stems from the trading externality of the matching process, and fail to decline relative to profits. Inertial wages and rigid hiring costs combine to stifle job creation flows, depressing the economy into disasters. The disaster dynamics are robust to extensions to home production, capital accumulation, and recursive utility. (JEL E22, E23, E24, E32, J41, J63, N12) </jats:p>
research_question: Are market economies intrinsically unstable, and can standard equilibrium unemployment models endogenously generate rare economic disasters?
answer: Yes, market economies are intrinsically unstable. When the standard search model of equilibrium unemployment is solved with a globally nonlinear algorithm, it endogenously generates rare disasters through a mechanism where inertial wages remain high during negative shocks, hiring costs become rigid due to matching externalities, and job creation flows are stifled, leading to economic disasters.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard view by demonstrating that existing equilibrium unemployment models, when solved more accurately with nonlinear methods, can endogenously produce rare disasters without requiring exogenous shocks, suggesting that market instability is an inherent feature rather than an external phenomenon.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Information Markets and the Comovement of Asset Prices

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Knowing What Others Know: Coordination Motives in Information Acquisition

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Long-Run Growth of Financial Data Technology
abstract: <jats:p> “Big data” financial technology raises concerns about market inefficiency. A common concern is that the technology might induce traders to extract others’ information, rather than to produce information themselves. We allow agents to choose how much they learn about future asset values or about others’ demands, and we explore how improvements in data processing shape these information choices, trading strategies and market outcomes. Our main insight is that unbiased technological change can explain a market-wide shift in data collection and trading strategies. However, in the long run, as data processing technology becomes increasingly advanced, both types of data continue to be processed. Two competing forces keep the data economy in balance: data resolve investment risk, but future data create risk. The efficiency results that follow from these competing forces upend two pieces of common wisdom: our results offer a new take on what makes prices informative and whether trades typically deemed liquidity-providing actually make markets more resilient. (JEL C55, D83, G12, G14, O33) </jats:p>
research_question: How do improvements in big data financial technology and data processing capabilities affect agents' information choices, trading strategies, and market outcomes in terms of efficiency?
answer: Unbiased technological change can explain market-wide shifts in data collection and trading strategies, but in the long run, both fundamental information (about asset values) and market information (about others' demands) continue to be processed due to competing forces where data resolve investment risk but future data create risk, keeping the data economy in balance.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing common wisdom by offering a new perspective on what makes prices informative and questioning whether trades typically considered liquidity-providing actually enhance market resilience, addressing concerns about big data technology potentially causing market inefficiency through information extraction rather than production.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Information Choice Technologies
abstract: <jats:p> Theories based on information costs or frictions have become increasing popular in macroeconomics and macro-finance. The literature has used various types of information choices, such as rational inattention, inattentiveness, information markets and costly precision. Using a unified framework, we compare these different information choice technologies and explain why some generate increasing returns and others, particularly those where agents choose how much public information to observe, generate multiple equilibria. The results can help applied theorists to choose the appropriate information choice technology for their application and to understand the consequences of that modeling choice. </jats:p>
research_question: How do different information choice technologies (rational inattention, inattentiveness, information markets, costly precision) compare in their properties and equilibrium outcomes?
answer: Some information choice technologies generate increasing returns while others, particularly those where agents choose how much public information to observe, generate multiple equilibria.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified framework to compare various information choice technologies that have become increasingly popular in macroeconomics and macro-finance literature, helping applied theorists understand the consequences of different modeling choices.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Information Acquisition and Under-Diversification

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Germs, Social Networks, and Growth
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Does the pattern of social connections between individuals matter for macroeconomic outcomes? If so, where do differences in these patterns come from and how large are their effects? Using network analysis tools, we explore how different social network structures affect technology diffusion and thereby a country’s rate of growth. The correlation between high-diffusion networks and income is strongly positive. But when we use a model to isolate the effect of a change in social networks on growth, the effect can be positive, negative, or zero. The reason is that networks diffuse both ideas and disease. Low-diffusion networks have evolved in countries where disease is prevalent because limited connectivity protects residents from epidemics. But a low-diffusion network in a low-disease environment compromises the diffusion of good ideas. In general, social networks have evolved to fit their economic and epidemiological environment. Trying to change networks in one country to mimic those in a higher-income country may well be counterproductive.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the pattern of social connections between individuals matter for macroeconomic outcomes, and if so, where do differences in these patterns come from and how large are their effects?
answer: Social network structures affect growth through technology diffusion, but the effect can be positive, negative, or zero because networks diffuse both beneficial ideas and harmful diseases. Low-diffusion networks evolved in high-disease environments as protection from epidemics, while high-diffusion networks correlate with higher income but may be inappropriate for disease-prevalent areas.
positioning_statement: This paper uses network analysis tools to explore the relationship between social network structures and macroeconomic growth, specifically examining how networks affect technology diffusion and considering the dual role of networks in spreading both ideas and disease - a perspective that appears to be novel in connecting epidemiological factors to network evolution and economic outcomes.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: The Tail That Wags the Economy: Beliefs and Persistent Stagnation
abstract: The Great Recession was a deep downturn with long-lasting effects on credit, employment, and output. While narratives about its causes abound, the persistence of gross domestic product below precrisis trends remains puzzling. We propose a simple persistence mechanism that can be quantified and combined with existing models. Our key premise is that agents do not know the true distribution of shocks but use data to estimate it nonparametrically. Then, transitory events, especially extreme ones, generate persistent changes in beliefs and macro outcomes. Embedding this mechanism in a neoclassical model, we find that it endogenously generates persistent drops in economic activity after tail events.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: A Rational Theory of Mutual Funds' Attention Allocation
abstract: The question of whether and how mutual fund managers provide valuable services for their clients motivates one of the largest literatures in finance. One candidate explanation is that funds process information about future asset values and use that information to invest in high‐valued assets. But formal theories are scarce because information choice models with many assets are difficult to solve as well as difficult to test. This paper tackles both problems by developing a new attention allocation model that uses the state of the business cycle to predict information choices, which in turn, predict observable patterns of portfolio investments and returns. The predictions about fund portfolios' covariance with payoff shocks, cross‐fund portfolio and return dispersion, and their excess returns are all supported by the data. These findings offer new evidence that some investment managers have skill and that attention is allocated rationally.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Taking Orders and Taking Notes: Dealer Information Sharing in Treasury Auctions
abstract: The use of order-flow information by financial firms has come to the forefront of the regulatory debate. Should a dealer who acquires information by taking client orders be allowed to use or share that information? We explore how information sharing affects dealers, clients, and issuer revenues in US Treasury auctions, in a model calibrated to auction results data, which we use to quantify counterfactuals. Sharing information reduces uncertainty about future value. With less uncertainty, risk-averse bidders bid more. For investors, the welfare effects of information sharing depend on how information is shared and how it affects asymmetry. The model shows that investors can benefit when dealers share information with each other, not when they share more with clients.

author: Laura Veldkamp
title: Leadership, Coordination, and Corporate Culture

author: Lawrence F. Katz
title: The Legacy of U.S. Educational Leadership: Notes on Distribution and Economic Growth in the 20th Century
abstract: The United States led all rich and industrialized countries in the establishment of mass secondary and higher education, and it led all in Europe by at least several decades for much of the 20th century. The U.S. advantage in the schooling of its young produced, by midcentury, large differences between the educational stock of its labor force and that of other rich countries, a result that would hardly be surprising except for the fact that the United States had absorbed millions of less-educated immigrants. Only in recent decades have many rich countries caught up to, and even exceeded, the United States in years of education for young persons. At the same time that the United States led the world in mass education in the 20th century, it rapidly expanded its economic lead. No single factor can account for the economic dominance of the United States in the 20th century, and most of the favored explanations, be they rooted in technological, institutional, or natural resource factors, are complementary ones. Despite that admonition, it would appear logical that part, possibly a major part, of the economic

author: Lawrence F. Katz
title: Career and Marriage in the Age of the Pill

author: Lawrence F. Katz
title: The Power of the Pill: Oral Contraceptives and Women’s Career and Marriage Decisions
abstract: The fraction of U.S. college graduate women entering professional programs increased substantially just after 1970, and the age at first marriage among all U.S. college graduate women began to soar around the same year. We explore the relationship between these two changes and the diffusion of the birth control pill (“the pill”) among young, unmarried college graduate women. Although the pill was approved in 1960 by the Food and Drug Administration and spread rapidly among married women, it did not diffuse among young, single women until the late 1960s after state law changes reduced the age of majority and extended “mature minor” decisions. We present both descriptive time series and formal econometric evidence that exploit cross‐state and cross‐cohort variation in pill availability to young, unmarried women, establishing the “power of the pill” in lowering the costs of long‐duration professional education for women and raising the age at first marriage.

author: Lawrence F. Katz
title: Transitions: Career and Family Life Cycles of the Educational Elite

author: Lawrence F. Katz
title: The Role of Unemployment in the Rise in Alternative Work Arrangements
abstract: <jats:p> The share of U.S. workers in alternative work arrangements has increased substantially in recent decades. Micro longitudinal analyses show that unemployed workers are much more likely to transition into alternative work arrangements than other workers. Macro time-series evidence shows that weak labor market conditions lead to an increase in non-traditional work. But the estimated magnitudes imply that the Great Recession and high unemployment in the 2000s can account for only a modest part of the rise in alternative work. Secular factors associated with rising inequality and technological changes making it easier to contract out work appear to be the driving forces. </jats:p>
research_question: What role does unemployment play in explaining the rise in alternative work arrangements among U.S. workers?
answer: While unemployed workers are much more likely to transition into alternative work arrangements and weak labor market conditions do increase non-traditional work, unemployment and the Great Recession can only account for a modest part of the overall rise in alternative work. The primary driving forces are secular factors including rising inequality and technological changes that make contracting out work easier.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on alternative work arrangements by providing both micro longitudinal and macro time-series evidence to quantify the specific contribution of unemployment versus other factors, distinguishing cyclical labor market effects from longer-term secular trends in work arrangements.

author: Lawrence F. Katz
title: Achieving Escape Velocity: Neighborhood and School Interventions to Reduce Persistent Inequality
abstract: <jats:p> This paper reviews the evidence on the efficacy of neighborhood and school interventions in improving the long-run outcomes of children growing up in poor families. We focus on studies exploiting exogenous sources of variation in neighborhoods and schools and which examine at least medium-term outcomes. Higher-quality neighborhoods improve family safety, adult subjective well-being and health, and girls' mental health. But they have no detectable impact on youth human capital, labor market outcomes, or risky behaviors. In contrast, higher-quality schools can improve children's academic achievement and can have longer-term positive impacts of increasing educational attainment and earnings and reducing incarceration and teen pregnancy. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the efficacy of neighborhood and school interventions in improving the long-run outcomes of children growing up in poor families?
answer: Higher-quality neighborhoods improve family safety, adult subjective well-being and health, and girls' mental health, but have no detectable impact on youth human capital, labor market outcomes, or risky behaviors. In contrast, higher-quality schools can improve children's academic achievement and have longer-term positive impacts including increased educational attainment and earnings and reduced incarceration and teen pregnancy.
positioning_statement: This paper reviews evidence from studies exploiting exogenous sources of variation in neighborhoods and schools that examine at least medium-term outcomes, focusing specifically on interventions aimed at reducing persistent inequality for children from poor families.

author: Lawrence F. Katz
title: The Effects of Exposure to Better Neighborhoods on Children: New Evidence from the Moving to Opportunity Experiment
abstract: <jats:p>The Moving to Opportunity (MTO) experiment offered randomly selected families housing vouchers to move from high-poverty housing projects to lower-poverty neighborhoods. We analyze MTO's impacts on children's long-term outcomes using tax data. We find that moving to a lower-poverty neighborhood when young (before age 13) increases college attendance and earnings and reduces single parenthood rates. Moving as an adolescent has slightly negative impacts, perhaps because of disruption effects. The decline in the gains from moving with the age when children move suggests that the duration of exposure to better environments during childhood is an important determinant of children's long-term outcomes. (JEL I31, I38, J13, R23, R38)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of exposure to better neighborhoods on children's long-term outcomes?
answer: Moving to lower-poverty neighborhoods when young (before age 13) increases college attendance and earnings and reduces single parenthood rates, while moving as an adolescent has slightly negative impacts, suggesting that duration of exposure to better environments during childhood is crucial for positive long-term outcomes.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new evidence on neighborhood effects using the Moving to Opportunity experiment and tax data to analyze long-term outcomes, contributing to the literature on how residential mobility and neighborhood quality affect children's development.
