author: Lawrence F. Katz
title: Creating Moves to Opportunity: Experimental Evidence on Barriers to Neighborhood Choice
abstract: <jats:p> Low-income families often live in low-upward-mobility neighborhoods. We study why by using a randomized trial with housing voucher recipients that provided information, financial support, and customized search assistance to move to high-opportunity neighborhoods. The treatment increased the fraction moving to high-upward-mobility areas from 15 to 53 percent. A second trial reveals this treatment effect is driven primarily by customized search assistance. Qualitative interviews show that the intervention relaxed bandwidth constraints and addressed family-specific needs. Our findings imply many low-income families do not have strong preferences to stay in low-opportunity areas and that barriers in housing search significantly increase residential segregation by income. (JEL D83, G51, R21, R23, R31, R38) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do low-income families often live in low-upward-mobility neighborhoods?
answer: Many low-income families do not have strong preferences to stay in low-opportunity areas, but face significant barriers in housing search that increase residential segregation by income. Providing customized search assistance, information, and financial support can dramatically increase moves to high-opportunity neighborhoods (from 15% to 53%).
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the question of residential choice barriers through experimental evidence, contributing to the literature on residential segregation by income and neighborhood mobility by demonstrating that search barriers, rather than preferences, are the primary constraint preventing low-income families from moving to high-opportunity areas.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Costly Expertise

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Testing the Waters: Behavior across Participant Pools
abstract: <jats:p>We leverage a large-scale incentivized survey eliciting behaviors from (almost) an entire undergraduate university student population, a representative sample of the US population, and Amazon Mechanical Turk (MTurk) to address concerns about the external validity of experiments with student participants. Behavior in the student population offers bounds on behaviors in other populations, and correlations between behaviors are similar across samples. Furthermore, non-student samples exhibit higher levels of noise. Adding historical lab participation data, we find a small set of attributes over which lab participants differ from non-lab participants. An additional set of lab experiments shows no evidence of observer effects. (JEL C83, D90, D91)</jats:p>
research_question: Do experimental results obtained from student participants in laboratory settings have external validity when generalized to other populations?
answer: Student behavior provides useful bounds on behavior in other populations, with similar correlations between behaviors across samples, though non-student samples exhibit higher noise levels and lab participants differ from non-lab participants on only a small set of attributes.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses longstanding concerns in experimental economics about the external validity of using student participants by providing large-scale empirical evidence comparing behaviors across different participant pools (students, representative US population, and MTurk workers) to validate or challenge existing assumptions about generalizability.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Contiguous Search: Exploration and Ambition on Uncharted Terrain
abstract: . We provide a framework for analyzing search across correlated observations. The agent—an online customer, a drug company, a politician—tracks innovations over a Brownian path. The agent chooses the speed and length of search and retrospectively picks the best innovation when search is completed. We show that the optimal search speed is U-shaped: it is highest when approaching a breakthrough or when nearing search termination. Unlike search across independent samples, search optimally stops when observations are su ffi ciently discouraging , following a drawdown stopping boundary. We also show the tractability and features of optimal search contracts in our setting.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Experiments on Decisions under Uncertainty: A Theoretical Framework
abstract: <jats:p> The analysis of lab data entails a joint test of the underlying theory and of subjects' conjectures regarding the experimental design itself, how subjects frame the experiment. We provide a theoretical framework for analyzing such conjectures. We use experiments of decision making under uncertainty as a case study. Absent restrictions on subjects' framing of the experiment, we show that any behavior is consistent with standard updating (“anything goes”), including those suggestive of anomalies such as overconfidence, excess belief stickiness, etc. When the experimental protocol restricts subjects' conjectures (plausibly, by generating information during the experiment), standard updating has nontrivial testable implications. (JEL C91, D11, D81, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How do subjects' conjectures about experimental design affect the interpretation of laboratory data on decision making under uncertainty, and what are the testable implications of standard updating theory?
answer: Without restrictions on subjects' framing of experiments, any behavior is consistent with standard updating theory (including apparent anomalies like overconfidence), but when experimental protocols restrict subjects' conjectures by generating information during the experiment, standard updating has nontrivial testable implications.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a theoretical framework for analyzing how subjects' conjectures about experimental design affect the interpretation of lab data, addressing a fundamental methodological issue in experimental economics that recognizes laboratory data involves a joint test of underlying theory and subjects' understanding of the experimental context.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Present Bias and Collective Dynamic Choice in the Lab
abstract: <jats:p> We study collective decisions by time-discounting individuals choosing a common consumption stream. We show that with any heterogeneity in time preferences, utilitarian aggregation necessitates a present bias. In lab experiments three quarters of “social planners” exhibited present biases, and less than two percent were time consistent. Roughly a third of subjects acted as if they were pure utilitarians, and the rest chose as if they also had varying degrees of distributional concerns. (JEL C91, D12, D71, D72) </jats:p>
research_question: How do collective decisions by time-discounting individuals affect intertemporal choice and present bias when choosing a common consumption stream?
answer: With any heterogeneity in time preferences, utilitarian aggregation necessitates a present bias. In experiments, three quarters of social planners exhibited present biases, less than two percent were time consistent, roughly a third acted as pure utilitarians, and the rest had varying degrees of distributional concerns.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on present bias and time inconsistency from individual decision-making to collective choice settings, demonstrating that present bias emerges endogenously from utilitarian aggregation of heterogeneous time preferences rather than being solely an individual behavioral phenomenon.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Diffusion of Behavior and Equilibrium Properties in Network Games

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Centralized Matching with Incomplete Information
abstract: <jats:p> We study the impacts of incomplete information on centralized one-to-one matching markets. We focus on the commonly used Deferred Acceptance mechanism (Gale and Shapley 1962). We show that many complete-information results are fragile to a small infusion of uncertainty about others’ preferences. (JEL C78, D11, D21, D47) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the impacts of incomplete information on centralized one-to-one matching markets, specifically when using the Deferred Acceptance mechanism?
answer: Many complete-information results are fragile to a small infusion of uncertainty about others' preferences in centralized matching markets using the Deferred Acceptance mechanism.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the foundational work of Gale and Shapley (1962) on the Deferred Acceptance mechanism by examining how the introduction of incomplete information affects the robustness of established complete-information results in centralized matching markets.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Collective Progress: Dynamics of Exit Waves
abstract: We introduce a framework for studying collective search by teams. Discoveries are correlated over time and governed by a Brownian path, where search speed is jointly controlled. Agents individually choose when to cease search and implement their best discovery. We characterize equilibrium and optimal policies. Search speeds are constant within active alliances and depend on complementarities between members. A drawdown stopping boundary governs each agent’s search termination. The consequent exit waves, whereby possibly heterogeneous agents cease search simultaneously, exhibit deterministic sequencing but stochastic timing. We highlight environments with lower than optimal equilibrium speeds and search durations, and different exit waves.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Experimenting with Measurement Error: Techniques with Applications to the Caltech Cohort Study
abstract: Measurement error is ubiquitous in experimental work. It leads to imperfect statistical controls, attenuated estimated effects of elicited behaviors, and biased correlations between characteristics. We develop statistical techniques for handling experimental measurement error. These techniques are applied to data from the Caltech Cohort Study, which conducts repeated incentivized surveys of the Caltech student body. We replicate three classic experiments, demonstrating that results change substantially when measurement error is accounted for. Collectively, these results show that failing to properly account for measurement error may cause a field-wide bias leading scholars to identify “new” phenomena.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Government Policy with Time Inconsistent Voters
abstract: <jats:p> Behavioral economics presents a “paternalistic” rationale for benevolent government intervention. This paper presents a model of public debt where voters have self-control problems and attempt to commit using illiquid assets. In equilibrium, government accumulates debt to respond to individuals' desire to undo their commitments, which leads individuals to rebalance their portfolio, in turn feeding into a demand for further debt accumulation. As a consequence, (i) large (and distortionary) government debt accumulation occurs, and (ii) banning illiquid assets could improve individuals' welfare. These results offer a new rationale for balanced budget rules in constitutions to restrain governments' responses to voters' self-control problems.(JEL D2, D72, D78, H62, H63) </jats:p>
research_question: How do voters' self-control problems and attempts to commit using illiquid assets affect government debt accumulation and welfare outcomes?
answer: Government accumulates large and distortionary debt in response to voters' desire to undo their commitments through illiquid assets, creating a feedback loop where individuals rebalance portfolios leading to further debt demand. This can result in welfare losses that could be improved by banning illiquid assets.
positioning_statement: This paper extends behavioral economics' paternalistic rationale for government intervention by presenting a new model that explains government debt accumulation as a response to voters' self-control problems, offering a novel justification for constitutional balanced budget rules that differs from traditional fiscal policy rationales.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Coordination with Differential Time Preferences: Experimental Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> The experimental literature on repeated games has largely focused on settings where players discount the future identically. In applications, however, interactions often occur between players whose time preferences differ. We study experimentally the effects of discounting differentials in infinitely repeated coordination games. In our data, differential discount factors play two roles. First, they provide a coordination anchor: more impatient players get higher payoffs first. Introducing even small discounting differentials reduces coordination failures significantly. Second, with pronounced discounting differentials, intertemporal trades are prevalent: impatient players get higher payoffs for an initial phase and patient players get higher payoffs in perpetuity afterward. (JEL C72, C92, D15, D25) </jats:p>
research_question: How do differential time preferences (discount factors) between players affect coordination outcomes in infinitely repeated coordination games?
answer: Differential discount factors play two key roles: (1) they serve as coordination anchors where more impatient players receive higher payoffs first, with even small discounting differentials significantly reducing coordination failures, and (2) with large discounting differentials, intertemporal trades emerge where impatient players get higher initial payoffs while patient players receive higher payoffs in perpetuity afterward.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the experimental literature on repeated games, which has largely focused on settings where players have identical discount factors, by studying the more realistic scenario where players have different time preferences in coordination games.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Deliberating Collective Decisions

author: Leeat Yariv
title: A Field Study on Matching with Network Externalities
abstract: <jats:p> We study the effects of network externalities within a protocol for matching faculty to offices in a new building. Using web and survey data on faculty's attributes and choices, we identify the different layers of the social network: institutional affiliation, coauthorships, and friendships. We quantify the effects of network externalities on choices and outcomes, disentangle the layers of the networks, and quantify their relative influence. Finally, we assess the protocol used from a welfare perspective. Our study suggests the importance and feasibility of accounting for network externalities in assignment problems and evaluates techniques that can be employed to this end. (JEL C78, C93, D62, D85, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How do network externalities affect choices and outcomes in matching protocols, specifically in the context of faculty office assignments?
answer: Network externalities significantly influence matching choices and outcomes, with different layers of social networks (institutional affiliation, coauthorships, and friendships) having varying degrees of influence on faculty office selection decisions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the matching literature by demonstrating the importance and feasibility of accounting for network externalities in assignment problems, providing empirical evidence and evaluation techniques that can be applied to improve matching protocols from a welfare perspective.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Top of the Batch: Interviews and the Match
abstract: <jats:p> Most doctors in the National Resident Matching Program (NRMP) match with one of their most preferred internship programs. However, surveys indicate doctors’ preferences are similar, suggesting a puzzle: how can so many doctors match with their top choices when positions are scarce? We provide one possible explanation. We show that the patterns in the NRMP data may be an artifact of the interview process that precedes the match. Our study highlights the importance of understanding market interactions occurring before and after a matching clearinghouse. It casts doubts on analyses of clearinghouses that take reported preferences at face value. (JEL C78, I11, I18, J44) </jats:p>
research_question: How can so many doctors match with their top choices in the National Resident Matching Program when positions are scarce and doctors' preferences appear to be similar?
answer: The high rate of doctors matching with their most preferred programs may be an artifact of the interview process that precedes the match, rather than reflecting true preference satisfaction in a scarce market.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing analyses of matching clearinghouses by highlighting the importance of understanding market interactions that occur before the formal matching process, and questions studies that take reported preferences at face value without considering how pre-match processes shape those preferences.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: From Extreme to Mainstream: The Erosion of Social Norms
abstract: <jats:p> Social norms, usually persistent, can change quickly when new public information arrives, such as a surprising election outcome. People may become more inclined to express views or take actions previously perceived as stigmatized and may judge others less negatively for doing so. We examine this possibility using two experiments. We first show via revealed preference experiments that Donald Trump’s rise in popularity and eventual victory increased individuals’ willingness to publicly express xenophobic views. We then show that individuals are sanctioned less negatively if they publicly expressed a xenophobic view in an environment where that view is more popular. (JEL D72, D85, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How do surprising political events, such as unexpected election outcomes, affect the persistence of social norms and people's willingness to express previously stigmatized views?
answer: Donald Trump's rise in popularity and electoral victory increased individuals' willingness to publicly express xenophobic views through revealed preference, and individuals face less negative sanctions for expressing such views when they are more popular in the environment.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that social norms are persistent by demonstrating that they can change quickly when new public information arrives, contributing to the literature on social norm dynamics and political influence on social behavior.

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Network Games

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: How Does Peer Pressure Affect Educational Investments?

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: The Schooling Decision: Family Preferences, Intergenerational Conflict, and Moral Hazard in the Brazilian Favelas

author: Leeat Yariv
title: Equitable Voting Rules
abstract: <jats:p>May's theorem (1952), a celebrated result in social choice, provides the foundation for majority rule. May's crucial assumption of symmetry, often thought of as a procedural equity requirement, is violated by many choice procedures that grant voters identical roles. We show that a weakening of May's symmetry assumption allows for a far richer set of rules that still treat voters equally. We show that such rules can have minimal winning coalitions comprising a vanishing fraction of the population, but not less than the square root of the population size. Methodologically, we introduce techniques from group theory and illustrate their usefulness for the analysis of social choice questions.</jats:p>
research_question: What voting rules can treat voters equally while relaxing May's symmetry assumption that underlies majority rule?
answer: A weakening of May's symmetry assumption allows for a far richer set of equitable voting rules that can have minimal winning coalitions comprising a vanishing fraction of the population, but not less than the square root of the population size.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on May's theorem (1952) by challenging its crucial symmetry assumption, showing that many choice procedures that grant voters identical roles actually violate this assumption, and demonstrating that relaxing it opens up new possibilities for equitable voting rules while introducing group theory techniques to social choice analysis.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: Cool to be Smart or Smart to be Cool? Understanding Peer Pressure in Education
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We model and test two school-based peer cultures: one that stigmatizes effort and one that rewards ability. The model shows that either may reduce participation in educational activities when peers can observe participation and performance. We design a field experiment that allows us to test for, and differentiate between, these two concerns. We find that peer pressure reduces takeup of an SAT prep package virtually identically across two very different high school settings. However, the effects arise from very distinct mechanisms: a desire to hide effort in one setting and a desire to hide low ability in the other.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different types of peer pressure mechanisms (stigmatization of effort versus rewards for ability) affect student participation in educational activities?
answer: Peer pressure reduces takeup of educational activities (SAT prep) equally across different school settings, but through distinct mechanisms: students hide effort in one setting and hide low ability in the other setting.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on peer effects in education by modeling and empirically distinguishing between two specific peer culture mechanisms - effort stigmatization versus ability rewards - that previous research has not systematically differentiated.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: Misperceived Social Norms: Women Working Outside the Home in Saudi Arabia
abstract: <jats:p> We show that the vast majority of young married men in Saudi Arabia privately support women working outside the home (WWOH) and substantially underestimate support by other similar men. Correcting these beliefs increases men’s (costly) willingness to help their wives search for jobs. Months later, wives of men whose beliefs were corrected are more likely to have applied and interviewed for a job outside the home. In a recruitment experiment with a local company, randomly informing women about actual support for WWOH leads them to switch from an at-home temporary enumerator job to a higher-paying, outside-the-home version of the job. (JEL D83, J16, J22, O15, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: Do misperceived social norms about women working outside the home affect labor market participation decisions in Saudi Arabia?
answer: Yes, correcting men's underestimation of social support for women working outside the home increases their willingness to help wives search for jobs and leads to higher job application rates by women, demonstrating that misperceived social norms constrain female labor force participation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on social norms and labor market participation by providing experimental evidence that misperceptions of social support, rather than actual opposition, can constrain women's workforce participation in traditional societies.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: Moral Incentives in Credit Card Debt Repayment: Evidence from a Field Experiment
abstract: We study the role of morality in debt repayment, using an experiment with the credit card customers of a large Islamic bank in Indonesia. In our main treatment, clients receive a text message stating that “non-repayment of debts by someone who is able to repay is an injustice.” This moral appeal decreases delinquency by 4.4 percentage points from a baseline of 66 percent and reduces default among customers with the highest ex ante credit risk. Additional treatments help benchmark the effects against direct financial incentives and rule out competing explanations, such as reminder effects, priming religion, and provision of new information.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: ‘Acting Wife’: Marriage Market Incentives and Labor Market Investments
abstract: <jats:p> Do single women avoid career-enhancing actions because these actions signal undesirable traits, like ambition, to the marriage market? While married and unmarried female MBA students perform similarly when their performance is unobserved by classmates (on exams and problem sets), unmarried women have lower participation grades. In a field experiment, single female students reported lower desired salaries and willingness to travel and work long hours on a real-stakes placement questionnaire when they expected their classmates to see their preferences. Other groups' responses were unaffected by peer observability. A second experiment indicates the effects are driven by observability by single male peers. (JEL C93, D82, J12, J16, J31) </jats:p>
research_question: Do single women avoid career-enhancing actions because these actions signal undesirable traits, like ambition, to the marriage market?
answer: Yes, single women do avoid career-enhancing actions when observed by potential marriage market partners. Single female MBA students have lower participation grades when performance is observable, report lower desired salaries and reduced willingness to travel/work long hours when they expect classmates to see their preferences, with effects specifically driven by observability by single male peers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel empirical evidence to the literature on marriage market effects on labor market behavior by using field experiments and observational data from MBA students to demonstrate that single women strategically underinvest in career-enhancing activities when these investments are observable to potential romantic partners, thereby providing direct evidence for the 'acting wife' phenomenon.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: The Environment and Directed Technical Change
abstract: <jats:p> This paper introduces endogenous and directed technical change in a growth model with environmental constraints. The final good is produced from “dirty” and “clean” inputs. We show that: (i) when inputs are sufficiently substitutable, sustainable growth can be achieved with temporary taxes/subsidies that redirect innovation toward clean inputs; (ii) optimal policy involves both “carbon taxes” and research subsidies, avoiding excessive use of carbon taxes; (iii) delay in intervention is costly, as it later necessitates a longer transition phase with slow growth; and (iv) use of an exhaustible resource in dirty input production helps the switch to clean innovation under laissez-faire. (JEL O33, O44, Q30, Q54, Q56, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: How can directed technical change be used to achieve sustainable economic growth under environmental constraints, and what are the optimal policy interventions to redirect innovation toward clean technologies?
answer: Sustainable growth can be achieved through temporary taxes and subsidies that redirect innovation toward clean inputs when inputs are sufficiently substitutable. Optimal policy requires both carbon taxes and research subsidies rather than relying excessively on carbon taxes alone. Delayed intervention increases costs by requiring longer transition periods with slower growth.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces endogenous and directed technical change into environmental growth models, extending the literature by analyzing how innovation can be strategically directed toward clean technologies and examining the policy mix needed to achieve sustainable growth with environmental constraints.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: Opinions as Facts
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The rise of opinion programs has transformed television news. Because they present anchors’ subjective commentary and analysis, opinion programs often convey conflicting narratives about reality. We experimentally document that people across the ideological spectrum turn to opinion programs over “straight news”, even when provided large incentives to learn objective facts. We then examine the consequences of diverging narratives between opinion programs in a high-stakes setting: the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in the US. We find stark differences in the adoption of preventative behaviours among viewers of the two most popular opinion programs, both on the same network, which adopted opposing narratives about the threat posed by the COVID-19 pandemic. We then show that areas with greater relative viewership of the program downplaying the threat experienced a greater number of COVID-19 cases and deaths. Our evidence suggests that opinion programs may distort important beliefs and behaviours.</jats:p>
research_question: How do opinion programs on television news affect people's beliefs and behaviors, particularly in high-stakes situations like the COVID-19 pandemic?
answer: People prefer opinion programs over straight news even when incentivized to learn objective facts, and diverging narratives between opinion programs lead to stark differences in preventative behaviors and health outcomes - areas with greater viewership of programs downplaying COVID-19 threats experienced more cases and deaths.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the transformation of television news due to the rise of opinion programs and their role in conveying conflicting narratives about reality, contributing to understanding how media consumption affects real-world beliefs and behaviors in consequential settings.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: The Immigrant Next Door
abstract: <jats:p> We study how decades-long exposure to individuals of a given foreign descent shapes natives’ attitudes and behavior toward that group. Using individualized donations data, we show that long-term exposure to a given foreign ancestry leads to more generous behavior specifically toward that group’s ancestral country. Focusing on exposure to Arab Muslims to examine mechanisms, we show that long-term exposure (i) decreases explicit and implicit prejudice against Arab Muslims, (ii) reduces support for policies and political candidates hostile toward Arab Muslims, (iii) increases charitable donations to Arab countries, (iv) leads to more personal contact with Arab Muslims, and (v) increases knowledge of Arab Muslims and Islam. (JEL D64, D83, D91, J15) </jats:p>
research_question: How does decades-long exposure to individuals of a given foreign descent shape natives' attitudes and behavior toward that group?
answer: Long-term exposure to foreign ancestry groups leads to more generous behavior toward those groups' ancestral countries, decreases prejudice, reduces support for hostile policies, increases charitable donations, promotes personal contact, and increases knowledge about the groups.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on intergroup contact and prejudice by examining long-term exposure effects using individualized donations data and focusing specifically on mechanisms through the case of Arab Muslims, providing empirical evidence for how sustained contact shapes attitudes and behaviors toward foreign ancestry groups.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: Killer Incentives: Rivalry, Performance and Risk-Taking among German Fighter Pilots, 1939–45
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Using newly collected data on death rates and aerial victories of more than 5,000 German fighter pilots during World War II, we examine the effects of public recognition on performance and risk-taking. When a particular pilot is honoured publicly, both the victory rate and the death rate of his former peers increase. Fellow pilots react more if they come from the same region of Germany, or if they worked closely with him. Our results suggest that personal rivalry can be a prime motivating force, and that non-financial rewards can lead to a crowd-in of both effort and risk-taking via social connections.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of public recognition on performance and risk-taking behavior, specifically examining how public honors given to individuals affect the performance and risk-taking of their peers?
answer: When a pilot receives public recognition, both the victory rate and death rate of his former peers increase, with stronger effects among pilots from the same region or those who worked closely together, demonstrating that non-financial rewards can motivate increased effort and risk-taking through social connections and personal rivalry.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on non-financial incentives and peer effects by using a unique historical dataset to demonstrate that personal rivalry can be a prime motivating force, showing how public recognition can crowd-in both effort and risk-taking via social connections rather than traditional financial mechanisms.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: Persistent Political Engagement: Social Interactions and the Dynamics of Protest Movements
abstract: <jats:p>We study the causes of sustained participation in political movements. To identify the persistent effect of protest participation, we randomly indirectly incentivize Hong Kong university students into participation in an antiauthoritarian protest. To identify the role of social networks, we randomize this treatment’s intensity across major-cohort cells. We find that incentives to attend one protest within a political movement increase subsequent protest attendance but only when a sufficient fraction of an individual’s social network is also incentivized to attend the initial protest. One-time mobilization shocks have dynamic consequences, with mobilization at the social network level important for sustained political engagement. (JEL D72, D74, I23, Z13)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the causes of sustained participation in political movements, specifically examining the persistent effects of protest participation and the role of social networks?
answer: Incentives to attend one protest increase subsequent protest attendance, but only when a sufficient fraction of an individual's social network is also incentivized to attend the initial protest. One-time mobilization shocks have dynamic consequences, with social network-level mobilization being crucial for sustained political engagement.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on political participation by using a randomized experimental approach to identify causal effects of both individual incentives and social network effects on sustained protest participation, addressing the challenge of identifying persistent effects in political movements through innovative methodology applied to Hong Kong university students.

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: Status Goods: Experimental Evidence from Platinum Credit Cards*

author: Leonardo Bursztyn
title: Justifying Dissent
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Dissent plays an important role in any society, but dissenters are often silenced through social sanctions. Beyond their persuasive effects, rationales providing arguments supporting dissenters’ causes can increase the public expression of dissent by providing a “social cover” for voicing otherwise stigmatized positions. Motivated by a simple theoretical framework, we experimentally show that liberals are more willing to post a tweet opposing the movement to defund the police, are seen as less prejudiced, and face lower social sanctions when their tweet implies they had first read credible scientific evidence supporting their position. Analogous experiments with conservatives demonstrate that the same mechanisms facilitate anti-immigrant expression. Our findings highlight both the power of rationales and their limitations in enabling dissent and shed light on phenomena such as social movements, political correctness, propaganda, and antiminority behavior.</jats:p>
research_question: How do rationales providing arguments affect people's willingness to publicly express dissenting views that may face social sanctions?
answer: Rationales providing credible supporting evidence increase public expression of dissent by offering 'social cover' - people are more willing to voice stigmatized positions, are perceived as less prejudiced, and face lower social sanctions when their dissenting views are backed by credible arguments or scientific evidence.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding the mechanisms behind dissent expression by experimentally demonstrating how rationales function as social cover, providing insights into broader phenomena including social movements, political correctness, propaganda, and antiminority behavior that existing literature has not fully explained through this lens.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Growth Opportunities and Technology Shocks
abstract: We propose a theoretically motivated procedure for measuring heterogeneity in firms’ growth opportunities and document its empirical properties. The term “growth opportunities” refers to the component of a firm’s market value that cannot be attributed to its assets in place. This decomposition of firm value underpins many of the theoretical models describing cross-sectional differences in firms’ investment and stock return behavior. However, successful applications of such models depend on the quality of empirical measures of growth opportunities. Our procedure identifies economically significant differences in firms’ growth opportunities which are not captured by the commonly used empirical measures. We base our approach on a theoretical model incorporating investment specific productivity shocks and heterogenous firms. Productivity shocks in the capital goods sector account for a significant fraction of observed growth variability, according to the literature on the real determinants of economic growth (Jeremy Greenwood, Zvi Hercowitz and Per Krusell 1997, Jonas D. M. Fisher 2006). Greenwood, Hercowitz and Krusell (1997) show that, empirically, investment specific shocks are negatively correlated with aggregate investment, both at business cycle and lower frequencies. Our model predicts that the sensitivity of firm stock returns to investment specific productivity shocks (z-shocks) is greater for firms that derive Growth Opportunities and Technology Shocks

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Catching Up with the Joneses: Heterogeneous Preferences and the Dynamics of Asset Prices

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Left Behind: Creative Destruction, Inequality, and the Stock Market
abstract: We develop a general equilibrium model of asset prices in which benefits of technological innovation are distributed asymmetrically. Financial market participants do not capture all economic gains from innovation even when they own shares in innovating firms. Such gains accrue partly to the innovators, who cannot sell claims on proceeds from their future ideas. We show how the resulting inequality among agents can give rise to a high risk premium on the aggregate stock market, return comovement and average return differences among firms, and the failure of traditional representative agent asset pricing models to account for cross-sectional differences in risk premia.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Erratum: “Equilibrium Cross Section of Returns”

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Equilibrium Cross Section of Returns

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Durability of Output and Expected Stock Returns
abstract: The demand for durable goods is more cyclical than that for nondurable goods and services. Consequently, the cash flows and stock returns of durable‐good producers are exposed to higher systematic risk. Using the benchmark input‐output accounts of the National Income and Product Accounts, we construct portfolios of durable‐good, nondurable‐good, and service producers. In the cross section, an investment strategy that is long on the durable‐good portfolio and short on the service portfolio earns a risk premium exceeding 4 percent annually. In the time series, an investment strategy that is long on the durable‐good portfolio and short on the market portfolio earns a countercyclical risk premium. We explain these findings in a general equilibrium asset‐pricing model with endogenous production.

author: Lorenzo Casaburi
title: Demand and Supply of Infrequent Payments as a Commitment Device: Evidence from Kenya
abstract: <jats:p> Despite extensive evidence that preferences are often time-inconsistent, there is only scarce evidence of willingness to pay for commitment. Infrequent payments for frequently provided goods and services are a common feature of many markets and they may naturally provide commitment to save for lumpy expenses. Multiple experiments in the Kenyan dairy sector show that: (i) farmers are willing to incur sizable costs to receive infrequent payments as a commitment device, (ii) poor contract enforcement, however, limits competition among buyers in the supply of infrequent payments. We then present a model of demand and supply of infrequent payments and test its additional predictions. (JEL K12, L66, O13, O17, Q12, Q13) </jats:p>
research_question: Are people willing to pay for commitment devices in the form of infrequent payments for frequently provided goods and services, and what factors affect the supply of such commitment mechanisms?
answer: Farmers are willing to incur sizable costs to receive infrequent payments as a commitment device to save for lumpy expenses, but poor contract enforcement limits competition among buyers in supplying these infrequent payment arrangements.
positioning_statement: While there is extensive evidence that preferences are often time-inconsistent, there is only scarce evidence of willingness to pay for commitment devices, which this paper addresses by examining infrequent payments as a naturally occurring commitment mechanism in markets.

author: Lorenzo Casaburi
title: Ghost-House Busters: The Electoral Response to a Large Anti–Tax Evasion Program *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The incentives of political agents to enforce tax collection are key determinants of the levels of compliance. We study the electoral response to the Ghost Buildings program, a nationwide anti tax evasion policy in Italy that used innovative monitoring technologies to target buildings hidden from tax authorities. The program induced monetary and non-monetary benefits for non-evaders and an increase in local government expenditures. A one standard deviation increase in town-level program intensity leads to a 4.8% increase in local incumbent reelection rates. In addition, these political returns are higher in areas with lower tax evasion tolerance and with higher efficiency of public good provision, implying complementarity among enforcement policies, the underlying tax culture, and the quality of the government.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the electoral response to anti-tax evasion enforcement policies, specifically Italy's Ghost Buildings program that used innovative monitoring technologies to target buildings hidden from tax authorities?
answer: Anti-tax evasion enforcement generates positive electoral returns for incumbents - a one standard deviation increase in program intensity leads to a 4.8% increase in local incumbent reelection rates, with higher returns in areas with lower tax evasion tolerance and more efficient public good provision.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on political incentives for tax enforcement by providing empirical evidence of how anti-tax evasion policies affect electoral outcomes, demonstrating complementarity among enforcement policies, tax culture, and government quality - areas that have been key determinants of compliance levels but lacked direct electoral impact analysis.

author: Leonid Kogan
title: Technological Innovation, Resource Allocation, and Growth*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a new measure of the economic importance of each innovation. Our measure uses newly collected data on patents issued to U.S. firms in the 1926 to 2010 period, combined with the stock market response to news about patents. Our patent-level estimates of private economic value are positively related to the scientific value of these patents, as measured by the number of citations the patent receives in the future. Our new measure is associated with substantial growth, reallocation, and creative destruction, consistent with the predictions of Schumpeterian growth models. Aggregating our measure suggests that technological innovation accounts for significant medium-run fluctuations in aggregate economic growth and TFP. Our measure contains additional information relative to citation-weighted patent counts; the relation between our measure and firm growth is considerably stronger. Importantly, the degree of creative destruction that is associated with our measure is higher than previous estimates, confirming that it is a useful proxy for the private valuation of patents.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we better measure the economic importance of technological innovations and what is their impact on economic growth, resource allocation, and creative destruction?
answer: The paper develops a new measure combining patent data with stock market responses that better captures private economic value of innovations. This measure shows that technological innovation accounts for significant medium-run fluctuations in aggregate economic growth and TFP, and is associated with higher levels of creative destruction than previously estimated.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as improving upon existing literature by proposing a superior measure of innovation's economic importance that contains additional information relative to citation-weighted patent counts, with a considerably stronger relation to firm growth and higher estimates of creative destruction than previous studies.

author: Lorenzo Casaburi
title: Land Rental Markets: Experimental Evidence from Kenya
abstract: <jats:p> Do land market frictions cause misallocation in agriculture? In a field experiment in western Kenya, we randomly subsidize owners to rent out land. Induced rentals mostly persist after the subsidy ends and increase output and value added, consistent with misallocation. Gains from trade arise from renters choosing higher-value crops, having higher productivity, and adopting more nonlabor inputs, while renters use similar quantities of labor as owners. Induced rentals are not those with the largest predicted gains, underlining the importance of the joint distribution of gains and frictions, with frictions arising from search, risk, and learning.(JEL C93, O13, O18, Q12, Q15, Q24, R52) </jats:p>
research_question: Do land market frictions cause misallocation in agriculture?
answer: Yes, land market frictions cause agricultural misallocation. Subsidizing land rentals increases output and value added through better crop choices, higher productivity, and increased non-labor inputs, with gains persisting after subsidies end.
positioning_statement: This paper provides experimental evidence on land market frictions and agricultural misallocation, emphasizing the importance of understanding the joint distribution of gains from trade and market frictions (search, risk, and learning costs) rather than focusing solely on potential efficiency gains.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: Inferring Inequality With Home Production
abstract: <jats:p>We revisit the causes, welfare consequences, and policy implications of the dispersion in households' labor market outcomes using a model with uninsurable risk, incomplete asset markets, and home production. Allowing households to be heterogeneous in both their disutility of home work and their home production efficiency, we find that home production amplifies welfare‐based differences, meaning that inequality in standards of living is larger than we thought. We infer significant home production efficiency differences across households because hours working at home do not covary with consumption and wages in the cross section of households. Heterogeneity in home production efficiency is essential for inequality, as home production would not amplify inequality if differences at home only reflected heterogeneity in disutility of work.</jats:p>
research_question: How does incorporating home production with heterogeneous household efficiency and disutility affect our understanding of inequality in welfare and standards of living?
answer: Home production amplifies welfare-based differences, making inequality in standards of living larger than previously estimated, due to significant heterogeneity in home production efficiency across households.
positioning_statement: This paper revisits existing understanding of inequality causes, welfare consequences, and policy implications by extending models with uninsurable risk and incomplete asset markets to include home production with household heterogeneity in both disutility and efficiency.

author: Lorenzo Casaburi
title: Loyalty, Exit, and Enforcement: Evidence from a Kenya Dairy Cooperative
abstract: <jats:p> Organizations depend on members' “loyalty” for their success. Studying a cooperative's attempt to increase deliveries by members, we show that the threat of sanctions leads to highly heterogeneous response among members. Despite the cooperative not actually enforcing the threatened sanctions, positive effects for some members persist for several months. Other members “exit,” stopping delivering altogether. Among non-compliant members we document substantial heterogeneity in beliefs about the legitimacy of the sanctions. This lack of common understanding highlights the role played by managers in organizations and provides a candidate explanation for lack of sanctions enforcement documented by Ostrom (1990) and other studies. </jats:p>
research_question: How do members of a cooperative respond to threatened sanctions aimed at increasing their deliveries, and what factors explain the heterogeneous responses observed?
answer: The threat of sanctions leads to highly heterogeneous responses among cooperative members - some members increase compliance and maintain positive effects for months even without enforcement, while others 'exit' by stopping deliveries altogether. This heterogeneity is explained by substantial differences in members' beliefs about the legitimacy of the sanctions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on organizational enforcement and member behavior by providing empirical evidence that explains the lack of sanctions enforcement documented by Ostrom (1990) and other studies, specifically highlighting how heterogeneous beliefs about legitimacy among members creates challenges for managers in organizations.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: The Global Decline of the Labor Share*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The stability of the labor share of income is a key foundation in macroeconomic models. We document, however, that the global labor share has significantly declined since the early 1980s, with the decline occurring within the large majority of countries and industries. We show that the decrease in the relative price of investment goods, often attributed to advances in information technology and the computer age, induced firms to shift away from labor and toward capital. The lower price of investment goods explains roughly half of the observed decline in the labor share, even when we allow for other mechanisms influencing factor shares, such as increasing profits, capital-augmenting technology growth, and the changing skill composition of the labor force. We highlight the implications of this explanation for welfare and macroeconomic dynamics.</jats:p>
research_question: What explains the global decline in the labor share of income since the early 1980s?
answer: The decrease in the relative price of investment goods, often attributed to advances in information technology and the computer age, induced firms to shift away from labor and toward capital, explaining roughly half of the observed decline in the labor share.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the key macroeconomic assumption of labor share stability by documenting a significant global decline since the early 1980s, and provides a novel explanation through investment goods pricing while accounting for alternative mechanisms like increasing profits, capital-augmenting technology growth, and changing skill composition.

author: Lorenzo Casaburi
title: Time versus State in Insurance: Experimental Evidence from Contract Farming in Kenya
abstract: <jats:p> The gains from insurance arise from the transfer of income across states. Yet, by requiring that the premium be paid up front, standard insurance products also transfer income across time. We show that this intertemporal transfer can help explain low insurance demand, especially among the poor, and in a randomized control trial in Kenya we test a crop insurance product which removes it. The product is interlinked with a contract farming scheme: as with other inputs, the buyer of the crop offers the insurance and deducts the premium from farmer revenues at harvest time. The take-up rate for pay-at-harvest insurance is 72 percent, compared to 5 percent for the standard pay-up-front contract, and the difference is largest among poorer farmers. Additional experiments and outcomes provide evidence on the role of liquidity constraints, present bias, and counterparty risk, and find that enabling farmers to commit to pay the premium just 1 month later increases demand by 21 percentage points. (JEL G22, I32, O13, O16, Q12, Q14) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the timing of premium payments affect insurance demand, particularly among poor farmers, and can removing the intertemporal transfer component of insurance increase take-up rates?
answer: Removing the intertemporal transfer by allowing farmers to pay premiums at harvest time dramatically increases insurance take-up from 5% to 72%, with the largest effects among poorer farmers, and even allowing farmers to delay payment by just 1 month increases demand by 21 percentage points.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on low insurance demand by identifying and testing a new mechanism - that standard insurance products problematically combine both cross-state risk transfer (the desired insurance function) and intertemporal income transfer (the undesired liquidity constraint), particularly affecting the poor who face greater liquidity constraints and behavioral biases.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: The Cyclicality of the Opportunity Cost of Employment

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: The Life-Cycle Profile of Time Spent on Job Search
abstract: <jats:p> Using time use survey data we document a hump-shaped profile of job search time in the United States across the life-cycle. The middle-aged unemployed spend roughly three times as much time in job search as the youngest group of unemployed. The hump-shaped profile of job search time is relatively stable across demographic groups. However, the profile of job search time appears to be declining in non-US countries. We discuss how standard life-cycle models with incomplete markets have difficulty in accounting for the hump-shaped profile found in the US data. </jats:p>
research_question: How does time spent on job search vary across the life-cycle?
answer: Job search time follows a hump-shaped profile across the life-cycle in the United States, with middle-aged unemployed individuals spending roughly three times as much time searching for jobs as the youngest unemployed group.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies an empirical pattern that standard life-cycle models with incomplete markets have difficulty explaining, suggesting a gap in existing theoretical frameworks for understanding job search behavior across age groups.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: Time Use During the Great Recession
abstract: <jats:p> Using data from the American Time Use Survey between 2003 and 2010, we document that home production absorbs roughly 30 percent of foregone market work hours at business cycle frequencies. Leisure absorbs roughly 50 percent of foregone market work hours, with sleeping and television watching accounting for most of this increase. We document significant increases in time spent on shopping, child care, education, and health. Job search absorbs between 2 and 6 percent of foregone market work hours. We discuss the implications of our results for business cycle models with home production and non-separable preferences. (JEL D31, E32, J22) </jats:p>
research_question: How do individuals allocate their time across different activities (home production, leisure, job search, etc.) when market work hours decrease during economic downturns?
answer: During the Great Recession, individuals allocated foregone market work hours as follows: approximately 30% to home production, 50% to leisure activities (primarily sleeping and television watching), 2-6% to job search, and significant increases to shopping, child care, education, and health activities.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes empirical evidence on time allocation during business cycles that has implications for business cycle models with home production and non-separable preferences, filling a gap in understanding how people substitute between market work and other activities during economic downturns.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: The Macroeconomics of the Greek Depression
abstract: <jats:p> Greece experienced a boom until 2007, followed by a collapse of unprecedented magnitude and persistence. We assess the sources of the boom and the bust, using a rich estimated dynamic general equilibrium model. External demand and government consumption fueled the boom in production, whereas transfers fueled the boom in consumption. Different from the standard narrative, wages and prices declined substantially during the bust. Tax policy accounts for the largest fraction of the bust in production, whereas uninsurable risk accounts for the bust in consumption and wages. We assess how the composition of fiscal adjustment and bailouts affected the crisis. (JEL E21, E23, E24, E32, E62, F41, H20) </jats:p>
research_question: What were the sources of Greece's economic boom until 2007 and the subsequent collapse, and how did fiscal adjustment and bailouts affect the crisis?
answer: External demand and government consumption fueled the production boom while transfers fueled the consumption boom. During the bust, tax policy was the largest contributor to the production collapse, while uninsurable risk drove the decline in consumption and wages. Contrary to standard narratives, wages and prices declined substantially during the crisis.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard narrative about the Greek crisis by using a rich estimated dynamic general equilibrium model to show that wages and prices actually declined substantially during the bust, and provides a comprehensive assessment of how fiscal adjustment composition and bailouts affected the crisis.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: The Macro Effects of Unemployment Benefit Extensions: a Measurement Error Approach*
abstract: By how much does an extension of unemployment benefits affect macroeconomic outcomes such as unemployment? Answering this question is challenging because U.S. law extends benefits for states experiencing high unemployment. We use data revisions to decompose the variation in the duration of benefits into the part coming from actual differences in economic conditions and the part coming from measurement error in the real-time data used to determine benefit extensions. Using only the variation coming from measurement error, we find that benefit extensions have a limited influence on state-level macroeconomic outcomes. We apply our estimates to the increase in the duration of benefits during the Great Recession and find that they increased the unemployment rate by at most 0.3 percentage point.

author: Luca Braghieri
title: Social Media and Mental Health
abstract: <jats:p> We provide quasi-experimental estimates of the impact of social media on mental health by leveraging a unique natural experiment: the staggered introduction of Facebook across US colleges. Our analysis couples data on student mental health around the years of Facebook’s expansion with a generalized difference-in-differences empirical strategy. We find that the rollout of Facebook at a college had a negative impact on student mental health. It also increased the likelihood with which students reported experiencing impairments to academic performance due to poor mental health. Additional evidence on mechanisms suggests the results are due to Facebook fostering unfavorable social comparisons. (JEL D91, I12, I23, L82) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal impact of social media on mental health?
answer: The rollout of Facebook at colleges had a negative impact on student mental health and increased the likelihood of students reporting academic performance impairments due to poor mental health, with the mechanism being unfavorable social comparisons fostered by Facebook.
positioning_statement: This paper provides quasi-experimental causal estimates of social media's impact on mental health by leveraging the unique natural experiment of Facebook's staggered introduction across US colleges, coupled with a generalized difference-in-differences empirical strategy.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: Capital Allocation and Productivity in South Europe*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Starting in the early 1990s, countries in southern Europe experienced low productivity growth alongside declining real interest rates. We use data for manufacturing firms in Spain between 1999 and 2012 to document a significant increase in the dispersion of the return to capital across firms, a stable dispersion of the return to labor, and a significant increase in productivity losses from capital misallocation over time. We develop a model with size-dependent financial frictions that is consistent with important aspects of firms’ behavior in production and balance sheet data. We illustrate how the decline in the real interest rate, often attributed to the euro convergence process, leads to a significant decline in sectoral total factor productivity as capital inflows are misallocated toward firms that have higher net worth but are not necessarily more productive. We show that similar trends in dispersion and productivity losses are observed in Italy and Portugal but not in Germany, France, and Norway.</jats:p>
research_question: Why did countries in southern Europe experience low productivity growth alongside declining real interest rates starting in the early 1990s, and what role did capital misallocation play in this phenomenon?
answer: The decline in real interest rates (attributed to euro convergence) led to significant productivity losses through capital misallocation, where capital inflows were directed toward firms with higher net worth rather than more productive firms, resulting in increased dispersion of returns to capital and declining sectoral total factor productivity.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a model with size-dependent financial frictions that explains firm behavior in both production and balance sheet data, and provides empirical evidence of capital misallocation patterns that are specific to southern European countries (Spain, Italy, Portugal) but not observed in northern European countries (Germany, France, Norway).

author: Lu Han
title: The Microgeography of Housing Supply
abstract: We perform a comprehensive neighborhood-level analysis of housing supply. Predictions of floor space and housing unit supply elasticities using our estimates average 0.5 and 0.3 across all urban neighborhoods in the United States, exhibiting greater variation within than between metro regions. New construction accounts for about 50% of unit supply responses, with important additional roles for teardowns and renovations. Supply responses grow with central business district distance mostly from the increasing availability of undeveloped land, flatter land, and less regulation. Identification comes from variation in labor demand shocks to commuting destinations, as aggregated using insights from a quantitative spatial equilibrium model.

author: Loukas Karabarbounis
title: Regional Consumption Responses and the Aggregate Fiscal Multiplier
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use regional variation in the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009–12) to analyse the effect of government spending on consumer spending. Our consumption data come from household-level retail purchases in the Nielsen scanner data and auto purchases from Equifax credit balances. We estimate that a $1 increase in county-level government spending increases local non-durable consumer spending by $0.29 and local auto spending by $0.09. We translate the regional consumption responses to an aggregate fiscal multiplier using a multi-region, new Keynesian model with heterogeneous agents, incomplete markets, and trade linkages. Our model is consistent with the estimated positive local multiplier, a result that distinguishes our incomplete markets model from models with complete markets. At the zero lower bound, the aggregate consumption multiplier is twice as large as the local multiplier because trade linkages propagate the effect of government spending across regions.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of government spending on consumer spending, and how do regional consumption responses translate to aggregate fiscal multipliers?
answer: A $1 increase in county-level government spending increases local non-durable consumer spending by $0.29 and local auto spending by $0.09. At the zero lower bound, the aggregate consumption multiplier is twice as large as the local multiplier due to trade linkages that propagate government spending effects across regions.
positioning_statement: This paper distinguishes itself from existing literature by using a multi-region, new Keynesian model with heterogeneous agents and incomplete markets, which is consistent with the estimated positive local multiplier - a result that differentiates it from models with complete markets.

author: Luca Braghieri
title: The Welfare Effects of Social Media
abstract: <jats:p>The rise of social media has provoked both optimism about potential societal benefits and concern about harms such as addiction, depression, and political polarization. In a randomized experiment, we find that deactivating Facebook for the four weeks before the 2018 US midterm election (i) reduced online activity, while increasing offline activities such as watching TV alone and socializing with family and friends; (ii) reduced both factual news knowledge and political polarization; (iii) increased subjective well-being; and post-experiment Facebook use. Deactivation reduced post-experiment valuations of Facebook, suggesting that traditional metrics may overstate consumer surplus. (JEL D12, D72, D90, I31, L82, L86, Z13)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the welfare effects of social media, specifically Facebook, on users' online/offline activities, political knowledge and polarization, and subjective well-being?
answer: Deactivating Facebook for four weeks led to reduced online activity and increased offline socializing, reduced both factual news knowledge and political polarization, increased subjective well-being, and decreased post-experiment valuations of Facebook, suggesting traditional metrics may overstate consumer surplus from social media.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the ongoing debate between optimistic views of social media's societal benefits and concerns about potential harms such as addiction, depression, and political polarization by providing experimental evidence on Facebook's actual welfare effects.

author: Luca Braghieri
title: Political Correctness, Social Image, and Information Transmission
abstract: <jats:p> A prominent argument in the political correctness debate is that people feel pressure to publicly espouse sociopolitical views they do not privately hold, and that such misrepresentations might render public discourse less vibrant and informative. This paper formalizes the argument in terms of social image and evaluates it experimentally in the context of college campuses. The results show that (i) social image concerns drive a wedge between the sensitive sociopolitical attitudes that college students report in private and in public; (ii) public utterances are indeed less informative than private utterances; and (iii) information loss is exacerbated by (partial) audience naïveté. (JEL D72, D83, D91, I23, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: Do social image concerns cause people to publicly espouse sociopolitical views they do not privately hold, and does this misrepresentation make public discourse less informative?
answer: Yes, social image concerns create a gap between private and public expression of sensitive sociopolitical attitudes among college students, making public utterances less informative than private ones, with information loss worsened by audience naïveté.
positioning_statement: This paper formalizes a prominent argument in the political correctness debate by providing experimental evidence for the theoretical claim that social image pressures lead to misrepresentation of private views in public discourse, thereby reducing the informativeness of public communication.

author: Luca Braghieri
title: A Theory of Chosen Preferences
abstract: <jats:p> We propose and develop a dynamic theory of endogenous preference formation in which people adopt worldviews that shape their judgments about their experiences. The framework highlights the role of mindset flexibility, a trait that determines the relative weights the decision-maker places on her current and anticipated worldviews when evaluating future outcomes. The theory generates rich behavioral dynamics, thereby illuminating a wide range of applications and providing potential explanations for a variety of observed phenomena. (JEL D11, D81, D91, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How do people endogenously form preferences over time, and what role does mindset flexibility play in shaping how individuals evaluate future outcomes based on their worldviews?
answer: People adopt worldviews that shape their judgments about experiences, with mindset flexibility serving as a key trait that determines how individuals weight their current versus anticipated future worldviews when evaluating outcomes, leading to rich behavioral dynamics.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new dynamic theory of endogenous preference formation that provides potential explanations for a variety of observed phenomena, positioning itself as offering a novel framework that illuminates a wide range of applications in understanding how preferences are chosen rather than fixed.

author: Luca Braghieri
title: Italy: Immigration and the evolution of populism

author: Luca Fornaro
title: The Paradox of Global Thrift
abstract: <jats:p> This paper describes a paradox of global thrift. Consider a world in which interest rates are low and monetary policy is constrained by the zero lower bound. Now imagine that governments implement prudential financial and fiscal policies to stabilize the economy. We show that these policies, while effective from the perspective of individual countries, might backfire if applied on a global scale. In fact, prudential policies generate a rise in the global supply of savings and a drop in global aggregate demand. Weaker global aggregate demand depresses output in countries at the zero lower bound. Due to this effect, noncooperative financial and fiscal policies might lead to a fall in global output and welfare. (JEL E21, E23, E43, E44, E52, E62, F32) </jats:p>
research_question: What happens when governments implement prudential financial and fiscal policies on a global scale in a low interest rate environment constrained by the zero lower bound?
answer: Prudential policies that are effective at the individual country level can backfire when applied globally, as they increase global savings supply and reduce aggregate demand, leading to depressed output and potentially lower global welfare due to noncooperative policy implementation.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a previously unrecognized paradox in macroeconomic policy coordination, showing that individually rational prudential policies can be collectively harmful in a zero lower bound environment, contributing to the literature on global policy spillovers and the limitations of uncoordinated policy responses.

author: Luca Fornaro
title: Stagnation Traps

author: Luca Fornaro
title: A Theory of Monetary Union and Financial Integration
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Since the creation of the euro, capital flows among member countries have been large and volatile. Motivated by this fact, I provide a theory connecting the exchange rate regime to financial integration. The key feature of the model is that monetary policy affects the value of collateral that creditors seize upon default. Under flexible exchange rates, national governments can expropriate foreign creditors by depreciating the exchange rate, which induces investors to impose tight constraints on international borrowing. Creating a monetary union, by eliminating this source of currency risk, increases financial integration among member countries. This process, however, does not necessarily lead to higher welfare. The reason is that a high degree of capital mobility can generate multiple equilibria, with bad equilibria characterized by inefficient capital flights. Capital controls or fiscal transfers can eliminate bad equilibria, but their implementation requires international cooperation.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the exchange rate regime affect financial integration, particularly in the context of monetary unions like the eurozone?
answer: Creating a monetary union increases financial integration among member countries by eliminating currency risk that allows national governments to expropriate foreign creditors through exchange rate depreciation, but this increased capital mobility can generate multiple equilibria including bad equilibria with inefficient capital flights that may reduce welfare.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel theoretical connection between exchange rate regimes and financial integration by focusing on how monetary policy affects collateral values in default situations, offering an explanation for the large and volatile capital flows observed among eurozone countries since the euro's creation.

author: Luca Fornaro
title: The Global Financial Resource Curse
abstract: <jats:p> We provide a model connecting the global saving glut to productivity growth. The key feature is that the tradable sector is the engine of growth of the economy. Capital flows from developing countries to the United States boost demand for US nontradable goods, inducing a reallocation of US economic activity from the tradable sector to the nontradable one. In turn, lower profits in the tradable sector lead firms to cut back investment in innovation. Since innovation in the United States determines the evolution of the world technological frontier, the result is a drop in global productivity growth. (JEL E21, E22, E23, E44, F32, F43, O31) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the global saving glut affect productivity growth through its impact on sectoral reallocation and innovation?
answer: Capital flows from developing countries to the US cause a reallocation from the tradable to nontradable sector, reducing innovation investment and leading to a drop in global productivity growth since US innovation determines the world technological frontier.
positioning_statement: This paper connects the global saving glut literature to productivity growth by modeling the tradable sector as the engine of economic growth and showing how capital flows affect sectoral reallocation and innovation decisions.
