author: Luca Fornaro
title: Microdynamics, granularity and populism: The Finnish case

author: Luca Fornaro
title: Monetary Policy for a Bubbly World
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>What is the role of monetary policy in a bubbly world? To address this question, we study an economy in which financial frictions limit the supply of assets. The ensuing scarcity generates a demand for “unbacked” assets, i.e., assets that are backed only by the expectation of their future value. We consider two types of unbacked assets: bubbles, which are created by the private sector, and money, which is created by the central bank. Bubbles and money share many features, but they also differ in two crucial respects. First, while the rents from the creation of bubbles accrue to entrepreneurs and foster investment, the rents from money creation accrue to the central bank. Second, while bubbles are driven by market psychology, and can rise and fall according to the whims of the market, money is under the control of the central bank. We characterize the optimal monetary policy and show that, through its ability to supply assets, monetary policy plays a key role in the bubbly world. The model sheds light on the recent expansion of central bank liabilities in response to the bursting of bubbles.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of monetary policy in a bubbly world?
answer: Monetary policy plays a key role in a bubbly world through the central bank's ability to supply assets. The optimal monetary policy involves the central bank creating money as an 'unbacked' asset that can substitute for private sector bubbles, with the key advantage that money creation rents accrue to the central bank rather than entrepreneurs, and money supply is under central bank control rather than subject to market psychology.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by modeling bubbles and money as similar 'unbacked' assets in an economy with financial frictions and asset scarcity, while highlighting their crucial differences in terms of rent distribution and controllability. The model provides theoretical insight into recent central bank balance sheet expansions following bubble bursts.

author: Luciano Pomatto
title: The Cost of Information: The Case of Constant Marginal Costs
abstract: <jats:p>We develop an axiomatic theory of information acquisition that captures the idea of constant marginal costs in information production: the cost of generating two independent signals is the sum of their costs, and generating a signal with probability half costs half its original cost. Together with Blackwell monotonicity and a continuity condition, these axioms determine the cost of a signal up to a vector of parameters. These parameters have a clear economic interpretation and determine the difficulty of distinguishing states. (JEL D82, D83)</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop an axiomatic theory that characterizes information acquisition costs when marginal costs are constant?
answer: The cost of a signal can be uniquely determined (up to a vector of parameters) by three axioms: constant marginal costs (cost of two independent signals equals sum of their individual costs, and generating a signal with probability half costs half the original cost), Blackwell monotonicity, and continuity. The parameters have clear economic interpretation and determine the difficulty of distinguishing between different states.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new axiomatic foundation for information acquisition costs by focusing specifically on the case of constant marginal costs, providing a theoretical framework that complements existing literature on information economics by offering a precise characterization of cost structures in information production.

author: Luciano Pomatto
title: Stochastic Dominance under Independent Noise
abstract: Stochastic dominance is a crucial tool for the analysis of choice under risk. It is typically analyzed as a property of two gambles that are taken in isolation. We study how additional independent sources of risk (e.g., uninsurable labor risk, house price risk) can affect the ordering of gambles. We show that, perhaps surprisingly, background risk can be strong enough to render lotteries that are ranked by their expectation ranked in terms of first-order stochastic dominance. We extend our results to second-order stochastic dominance and show how they lead to a novel and elementary axiomatization of mean-variance preferences.

author: Luciano Pomatto
title: Claim Validation
abstract: <jats:p> Hume (1748) challenged the idea that a general claim (e.g., “all swans are white”) can be validated by empirical evidence, no matter how compelling. We examine this issue from the perspective of a tester who must accept or reject the forecasts of a potential expert. If experts can be skeptical about the validity of claims then they can evade rejection strategically. In contrast, if experts are required to conclude that claims backed by sufficient evidence are likely to be true, then they can be tested and rejected. These results provide an economic rationale for claim validation based on incentive problems. (JEL D82) </jats:p>
research_question: How can general claims be validated by empirical evidence when experts can strategically evade rejection by being skeptical about the validity of claims?
answer: If experts are required to conclude that claims backed by sufficient evidence are likely to be true, then they can be tested and rejected, providing an economic rationale for claim validation based on incentive problems.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses Hume's (1748) philosophical challenge about validating general claims with empirical evidence by examining it from an economic perspective focused on the incentive problems between testers and experts in forecasting scenarios.

author: Luciano Pomatto
title: From Blackwell Dominance in Large Samples to Rényi Divergences and Back Again
abstract: <jats:p>We study repeated independent Blackwell experiments; standard examples include drawing multiple samples from a population, or performing a measurement in different locations. In the baseline setting of a binary state of nature, we compare experiments in terms of their informativeness in large samples. Addressing a question due to Blackwell (1951), we show that generically an experiment is more informative than another in large samples if and only if it has higher Rényi divergences.</jats:p><jats:p>We apply our analysis to the problem of measuring the degree of dissimilarity between distributions by means of divergences. A useful property of Rényi divergences is their additivity with respect to product distributions. Our characterization of Blackwell dominance in large samples implies that every additive divergence that satisfies the data processing inequality is an integral of Rényi divergences.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between Blackwell dominance in large samples and Rényi divergences for repeated independent experiments?
answer: An experiment is more informative than another in large samples if and only if it has higher Rényi divergences, and every additive divergence satisfying the data processing inequality is an integral of Rényi divergences.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a question originally posed by Blackwell (1951) and provides a characterization that connects information theory (Blackwell dominance) with statistical divergence measures (Rényi divergences), offering new insights into measuring dissimilarity between distributions.

author: Luciano Pomatto
title: Background Risk and Small-Stakes Risk Aversion
abstract: <jats:p> Building on Pomatto, Strack, and Tamuz (2020), we identify a tight condition for when background risk can induce first-order stochastic dominance. Using this condition, we show that under plausible levels of background risk, no theory of choice under risk can simultaneously satisfy the following three economic postulates: (i) decision-makers are risk averse over small gambles, (ii) their preferences respect stochastic dominance, and (iii) they account for background risk. This impossibility result applies to expected utility theory, prospect theory, rank-dependent utility, and many other models. (JEL D81, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: Can any theory of choice under risk simultaneously satisfy risk aversion over small gambles, respect for stochastic dominance, and accounting for background risk under plausible levels of background risk?
answer: No theory of choice under risk can simultaneously satisfy all three economic postulates (small-stakes risk aversion, stochastic dominance, and accounting for background risk) under plausible levels of background risk - this impossibility result applies to expected utility theory, prospect theory, rank-dependent utility, and many other models.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Pomatto, Strack, and Tamuz (2020) by identifying a tight condition for when background risk can induce first-order stochastic dominance, and uses this condition to establish a fundamental impossibility result that applies broadly across multiple existing theories of choice under risk including expected utility theory, prospect theory, and rank-dependent utility.

author: Luciano Pomatto
title: Monotone Additive Statistics
abstract: <jats:p>The expectation is an example of a descriptive statistic that is monotone with respect to stochastic dominance, and additive for sums of independent random variables. We provide a complete characterization of such statistics, and explore a number of applications to models of individual and group decision‐making. These include a representation of stationary monotone time preferences, extending the work of Fishburn and Rubinstein (1982) to time lotteries. This extension offers a new perspective on risk attitudes toward time, as well as on the aggregation of multiple discount factors. We also offer a novel class of non‐expected utility preferences over gambles which satisfy invariance to background risk as well as betweenness, but are versatile enough to capture mixed risk attitudes.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the complete characterization of descriptive statistics that are both monotone with respect to stochastic dominance and additive for sums of independent random variables?
answer: The paper provides a complete characterization of monotone additive statistics (beyond just the expectation) and demonstrates their applications in modeling individual and group decision-making, including stationary monotone time preferences and non-expected utility preferences that satisfy invariance to background risk and betweenness while capturing mixed risk attitudes.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the work of Fishburn and Rubinstein (1982) on time preferences to time lotteries, offers a new perspective on risk attitudes toward time and aggregation of multiple discount factors, and introduces a novel class of non-expected utility preferences that can handle mixed risk attitudes while satisfying key invariance properties.

author: Lucie Gadenne
title: Informality, Consumption Taxes, and Redistribution
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Can taxes on consumption redistribute in developing countries? Contrary to consensus, we show that taxing consumption is progressive once we account for informal consumption. Using household expenditure surveys in 32 countries, we proxy for informal consumption using the type of store where purchases occur. We establish that the budget share spent in informal stores steeply declines with income, so that richer households pay a substantially larger share of their income in taxes. Our findings imply that the widespread policy of exempting food from taxation is hard to justify on equity grounds in low-income countries.</jats:p>
research_question: Can taxes on consumption redistribute in developing countries?
answer: Yes, taxing consumption is progressive once we account for informal consumption, as richer households pay a substantially larger share of their income in taxes because they spend less in informal (untaxed) stores.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the existing consensus that consumption taxes are not redistributive in developing countries by incorporating the role of informal consumption patterns that previous literature has overlooked.

author: Lucie Gadenne
title: In-Kind Transfers as Insurance
abstract: <jats:p> Households in developing countries often face variation in the prices of consumption goods. We develop a model demonstrating that in-kind transfers will provide insurance benefits against price risk if the covariance between the marginal utility of income and price is positive. Using calorie shortfalls as a proxy for marginal utility, we find that this condition holds for low-income Indian households. Expansions in India’s flagship in-kind food transfer program not only increase caloric intake but also reduce caloric sensitivity to prices. Our results contribute to ongoing debates about the optimal form of social protection programs. (JEL D12, H53, I18, I38, O12, O15) </jats:p>
research_question: Do in-kind transfers provide insurance benefits against price risk for households in developing countries, and how do they affect caloric sensitivity to price variations?
answer: In-kind transfers provide insurance benefits when the covariance between marginal utility of income and price is positive (which holds for low-income Indian households), and expansions of India's in-kind food transfer program both increase caloric intake and reduce caloric sensitivity to prices.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to ongoing debates about the optimal form of social protection programs by providing theoretical and empirical evidence for the insurance value of in-kind transfers against price risk, specifically in the context of developing countries facing consumption goods price variation.

author: Ludvig Sinander
title: The Converse Envelope Theorem
abstract: <jats:p>I prove an envelope theorem with a converse: the envelope formula is<jats:italic>equivalent</jats:italic>to a first‐order condition. Like Milgrom and Segal's (2002) envelope theorem, my result requires no structure on the choice set. I use the converse envelope theorem to extend to general outcomes and preferences the canonical result in mechanism design that any increasing allocation is implementable, and apply this to selling information.</jats:p>
research_question: Can the envelope formula be shown to be equivalent to a first-order condition, and what are the implications of this equivalence for mechanism design?
answer: The envelope formula is equivalent to a first-order condition, and this equivalence extends the canonical mechanism design result that any increasing allocation is implementable to general outcomes and preferences.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Milgrom and Segal's (2002) envelope theorem by proving a converse relationship, requiring no structure on the choice set like the original theorem, and extends canonical mechanism design results beyond their traditional scope to general outcomes and preferences.

author: Ludvig Sinander
title: Optimism, Overconfidence, and Moral Hazard

author: Ludvig Sinander
title: Agenda-Manipulation in Ranking
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the susceptibility of committee governance (e.g. by boards of directors), modelled as the collective determination of a ranking of a set of alternatives, to manipulation of the order in which pairs of alternatives are voted on—agenda-manipulation. We exhibit an agenda strategy called insertion sort that allows a self-interested committee chair with no knowledge of how votes will be cast to do as well as if she had complete knowledge. Strategies with this “regret-freeness” property are characterized by their efficiency, and by their avoidance of two intuitive errors. What distinguishes regret-free strategies from each other is how they prioritize among alternatives; insertion sort prioritizes lexicographically.</jats:p>
research_question: How susceptible is committee governance to manipulation of the voting agenda order when collectively determining rankings of alternatives, and what strategies can a committee chair use to maximize outcomes without prior knowledge of voting patterns?
answer: A committee chair can use an 'insertion sort' agenda strategy to achieve optimal outcomes without any knowledge of how votes will be cast, performing as well as if she had complete information. This and other 'regret-free' strategies are characterized by their efficiency and avoidance of two intuitive errors, with insertion sort distinguished by its lexicographic prioritization among alternatives.
positioning_statement: This paper studies agenda-manipulation in the context of committee governance and collective ranking determination, focusing on characterizing optimal agenda strategies for chairs with incomplete information and identifying the properties that distinguish effective 'regret-free' strategies from one another.

author: Ludvig Sinander
title: Comparative Statics With Adjustment Costs and the Le Chatelier Principle
abstract: <jats:p>We develop a theory of monotone comparative statics for models with adjustment costs. We show that comparative‐statics conclusions may be drawn under the usual ordinal complementarity assumptions on the objective function, assuming very little about costs: only a mild monotonicity condition is required. We use this insight to prove a general Le Chatelier principle: under the ordinal complementarity assumptions, if short‐run adjustment is subject to a monotone cost, then the long‐run response to a shock is greater than the short‐run response. We extend these results to a fully dynamic model of adjustment over time: the Le Chatelier principle remains valid, and under slightly stronger assumptions, optimal adjustment follows a monotone path. We apply our results to models of saving, production, pricing, labor supply, and investment.</jats:p>
research_question: How do adjustment costs affect comparative statics results, and what is the relationship between short-run and long-run responses to economic shocks when adjustment is costly?
answer: Comparative statics conclusions can be drawn under standard ordinal complementarity assumptions with minimal requirements on adjustment costs (only mild monotonicity), and a general Le Chatelier principle holds: long-run responses to shocks are greater than short-run responses when adjustment is subject to monotone costs.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a general theory of monotone comparative statics for adjustment cost models that requires weaker assumptions than existing literature, extending the Le Chatelier principle to a broader class of economic models and providing a unified framework applicable across multiple domains including saving, production, pricing, labor supply, and investment.

author: Ludvig Sinander
title: The Missing Profits of Nations
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>By exploiting new macroeconomic data known as foreign affiliates statistics, we show that affiliates of foreign multinational firms are an order of magnitude more profitable than local firms in a number of low-tax countries. Leveraging this differential profitability, we estimate that 36$\%$ of multinational profits are shifted to tax havens globally. US multinationals shift twice as much profit as other multinationals relative to the size of their foreign earnings. We analyse how the location of corporate profits would change if shifted profits were reallocated to their source countries. Domestic profits would increase by about 20$\%$ in high-tax European Union countries, 10$\%$ in the US, and 5$\%$ in developing countries, while they would fall by 55$\%$ in tax havens. We provide a new international database of GDP, trade balances, and factor shares corrected for profit shifting. In contrast to the picture painted by official statistics, our results suggest that the corporate capital share has increased not only in North America but also in high-tax European countries. Capital is making a comeback globally, but its rise is obscured by the tax avoidance strategies of multinational companies.</jats:p>
research_question: How much multinational profit is shifted to tax havens globally, and what would be the impact on different countries if these profits were reallocated to their source countries?
answer: 36% of multinational profits are shifted to tax havens globally, with US multinationals shifting twice as much as others. If reallocated, domestic profits would increase by 20% in high-tax EU countries, 10% in the US, and 5% in developing countries, while falling 55% in tax havens. The corporate capital share has actually increased globally, including in high-tax European countries, contrary to official statistics.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing new empirical evidence using previously unexploited macroeconomic data (foreign affiliates statistics) to correct the misleading picture painted by official statistics regarding profit shifting and the global rise of capital, revealing that tax avoidance strategies have obscured the true comeback of capital globally.

author: Ludwig Straub
title: Endogenous Uncertainty and Credit Crunches
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a theory of endogenous uncertainty in which the ability of investors to learn about firm-level fundamentals is impaired during financial crises. At the same time, higher uncertainty reinforces financial distress. Through this two-way feedback loop, a temporary financial shock can cause a persistent reduction in risky lending, output, and employment that coincides with increased uncertainty, default rates, credit spreads, and disagreement among forecasters. We embed our mechanism into standard real business cycle and New-Keynesian models and show how it generates endogenous and internally persistent processes for the efficiency and labour wedges.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the interaction between uncertainty and financial distress create persistent economic downturns following temporary financial shocks?
answer: A two-way feedback loop exists where financial crises impair investors' ability to learn about firm fundamentals (increasing uncertainty), while higher uncertainty reinforces financial distress, causing temporary financial shocks to generate persistent reductions in risky lending, output, and employment alongside increased uncertainty, default rates, credit spreads, and forecaster disagreement.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a theory of endogenous uncertainty that can be embedded into standard real business cycle and New-Keynesian models, providing a mechanism that generates endogenous and internally persistent processes for efficiency and labour wedges during financial crises.

author: Ludwig Straub
title: Positive Long-Run Capital Taxation: Chamley-Judd Revisited
abstract: <jats:p> According to the Chamley-Judd result, capital should not be taxed in the long run. In this paper, we overturn this conclusion, showing that it does not follow from the very models used to derive it. For the main model in Judd (1985), we prove that the long-run tax on capital is positive and significant, whenever the intertemporal elasticity of substitution is below one. For higher elasticities, the tax converges to zero but may do so at a slow rate, after centuries of high tax rates. The main model in Chamley (1986) imposes an upper bound on capital taxes. We provide conditions under which these constraints bind forever, implying positive long-run taxes. When this is not the case, the long-run tax may be zero. However, if preferences are recursive and discounting is locally nonconstant (e.g., not additively separable over time), a zero long-run capital tax limit must be accompanied by zero private wealth (zero tax base) or by zero labor taxes (first-best). Finally, we explain why the equivalence of a positive capital tax with ever-increasing consumption taxes does not provide a firm rationale against capital taxation. (JEL H21, H25) </jats:p>
research_question: Should capital be taxed in the long run, contrary to the Chamley-Judd result that concludes capital should not be taxed in the long run?
answer: Capital should be taxed in the long run - the long-run tax on capital is positive and significant when the intertemporal elasticity of substitution is below one, and even when elasticity is higher, taxes may remain high for centuries before converging to zero.
positioning_statement: This paper directly challenges and overturns the influential Chamley-Judd result by demonstrating that positive long-run capital taxation actually follows from the very same models (Judd 1985 and Chamley 1986) that were originally used to argue against capital taxation, while also addressing the theoretical equivalence argument between capital taxes and consumption taxes.

author: Ludwig Straub
title: A Theory of Foreign Exchange Interventions
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study a real small open economy with two key ingredients (1) partial segmentation of home and foreign bond markets and (2) a pecuniary externality that makes the real exchange rate excessively volatile in response to capital flows. Partial segmentation implies that, by intervening in the bond markets, the central bank can affect the exchange rate and the spread between home- and foreign-bond yields. Such interventions allow the central bank to address the pecuniary externality, but they are also costly, as foreigners make carry trade profits. We analytically characterize the optimal intervention policy that solves this trade-off: (1) the optimal policy leans against the wind, stabilizing the exchange rate; (2) it involves smooth spreads but allows exchange rates to jump; (3) it partly relies on “forward guidance,” with non-zero interventions even after the shock has subsided; (4) it requires credibility, in that central banks do not intervene without commitment. Finally, we shed light on the global consequences of widespread interventions, using a multi-country extension of our model. We find that, left to themselves, countries over-accumulate reserves, reducing welfare and leading to inefficiently low world interest rates.</jats:p>
research_question: How should central banks optimally intervene in foreign exchange markets when bond markets are partially segmented and the real exchange rate exhibits excessive volatility due to pecuniary externalities?
answer: The optimal intervention policy should: (1) lean against the wind to stabilize exchange rates, (2) maintain smooth interest rate spreads while allowing exchange rate jumps, (3) use forward guidance with interventions continuing after shocks subside, and (4) require credible commitment from central banks. However, when countries act independently, they over-accumulate reserves, reducing global welfare and leading to inefficiently low world interest rates.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the foreign exchange intervention literature by developing a theoretical framework that incorporates partial bond market segmentation and pecuniary externalities, providing analytical characterization of optimal intervention policies and extending analysis to global consequences of widespread interventions across multiple countries.

author: Ludwig Straub
title: Indebted Demand
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a theory of indebted demand, capturing the idea that large debt burdens lower aggregate demand, and thus the natural rate of interest. At the core of the theory is the simple yet underappreciated observation that borrowers and savers differ in their marginal propensities to save out of permanent income. Embedding this insight in a two-agent perpetual-youth model, we find that recent trends in income inequality and financial deregulation lead to indebted household demand, pushing down the natural rate of interest. Moreover, popular expansionary policies—such as accommodative monetary policy—generate a debt-financed short-run boom at the expense of indebted demand in the future. When demand is sufficiently indebted, the economy gets stuck in a debt-driven liquidity trap, or debt trap. Escaping a debt trap requires consideration of less conventional macroeconomic policies, such as those focused on redistribution or those reducing the structural sources of high inequality.</jats:p>
research_question: How do large debt burdens affect aggregate demand and the natural rate of interest, and what are the implications for macroeconomic policy?
answer: Large debt burdens lower aggregate demand and push down the natural rate of interest due to differences in marginal propensities to save between borrowers and savers. Income inequality and financial deregulation lead to indebted household demand, and when demand becomes sufficiently indebted, the economy can get stuck in a debt-driven liquidity trap that requires unconventional policies focused on redistribution to escape.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new theory of 'indebted demand' built on the underappreciated observation that borrowers and savers have different marginal propensities to save out of permanent income, embedded in a two-agent perpetual-youth model to analyze the relationship between debt, demand, and interest rates.

author: Ludwig Straub
title: The Intertemporal Keynesian Cross

author: Ludwig Straub
title: New Pricing Models, Same Old Phillips Curves?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that in a broad class of menu cost models, the first-order dynamics of aggregate inflation in response to arbitrary shocks to aggregate costs are nearly the same as in Calvo models with suitably chosen Calvo adjustment frequencies. We first prove that the canonical menu cost model is first-order equivalent to a mixture of two time-dependent models, which reflect the extensive and intensive margins of price adjustment. We then show numerically that in any plausible parameterization, this mixture is well approximated by a single Calvo model. This close numerical fit carries over to other standard specifications of menu cost models. Thus, for shocks that are not too large, the Phillips curve for a menu cost model looks like the New Keynesian Phillips curve, but with a higher slope.</jats:p>
research_question: Do menu cost models generate fundamentally different aggregate inflation dynamics compared to Calvo models, or do they produce similar Phillips curve relationships?
answer: Menu cost models produce nearly identical first-order inflation dynamics to Calvo models with appropriately chosen adjustment frequencies, resulting in Phillips curves that look like the New Keynesian Phillips curve but with a higher slope.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges the gap between two major pricing model frameworks in macroeconomics by demonstrating that despite their different microeconomic foundations, menu cost models and Calvo models yield remarkably similar aggregate outcomes, suggesting that the choice between these modeling approaches may be less consequential for aggregate analysis than previously thought.

author: Ludwig Straub
title: Using the Sequence‐Space Jacobian to Solve and Estimate Heterogeneous‐Agent Models
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a general and highly efficient method for solving and estimating general equilibrium heterogeneous‐agent models with aggregate shocks in discrete time. Our approach relies on the rapid computation of<jats:italic>sequence‐space Jacobians</jats:italic>—the derivatives of perfect‐foresight equilibrium mappings between aggregate sequences around the steady state. Our main contribution is a fast algorithm for calculating Jacobians for a large class of heterogeneous‐agent problems. We combine this algorithm with a systematic approach to composing and inverting Jacobians to solve for general equilibrium impulse responses. We obtain a rapid procedure for likelihood‐based estimation and computation of nonlinear perfect‐foresight transitions. We apply our methods to three canonical heterogeneous‐agent models: a neoclassical model, a New Keynesian model with one asset, and a New Keynesian model with two assets.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a general and highly efficient computational method for solving and estimating general equilibrium heterogeneous-agent models with aggregate shocks in discrete time?
answer: The paper develops a fast algorithm based on sequence-space Jacobians that enables rapid computation of derivatives of perfect-foresight equilibrium mappings, which can be systematically composed and inverted to solve for general equilibrium impulse responses and perform likelihood-based estimation.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses computational challenges in heterogeneous-agent modeling by proposing a novel methodological approach that significantly improves efficiency compared to existing methods, demonstrated through application to three canonical models in the literature.

author: Ludwig Straub
title: Macroeconomic Implications of COVID-19: Can Negative Supply Shocks Cause Demand Shortages?
abstract: <jats:p> Motivated by the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, we present a theory of Keynesian supply shocks: shocks that reduce potential output in a sector of the economy, but that, by reducing demand in other sectors, ultimately push aggregate activity below potential. A Keynesian supply shock is more likely when the elasticity of substitution between sectors is relatively low, the intertemporal elasticity of substitution is relatively high, and markets are incomplete. Fiscal policy can display a smaller multiplier, but the insurance benefit of fiscal transfers can be enhanced. Firm exits and job destruction can amplify and propagate the shock. (JEL D52, E23, E24, E32, E62, I12, I18) </jats:p>
research_question: Can negative supply shocks cause demand shortages, and what are the macroeconomic implications of such shocks as observed during the COVID-19 pandemic?
answer: Yes, negative supply shocks can cause demand shortages through what the authors term 'Keynesian supply shocks' - shocks that reduce potential output in one sector but ultimately push aggregate activity below potential by reducing demand in other sectors. This is more likely when substitution between sectors is low, intertemporal substitution is high, and markets are incomplete.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new theoretical framework of 'Keynesian supply shocks' motivated by COVID-19 effects, extending traditional macroeconomic theory by showing how supply shocks can generate demand-side effects that push aggregate activity below potential, with implications for fiscal policy effectiveness and the role of firm exits and job destruction in amplifying shocks.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Disability Insurance: Error Rates and Gender Differences
abstract: We provide a life-cycle framework for comparing insurance and disincentive effects of disability benefits. The risks that individuals face and the parameters of the Disability Insurance (DI ) program are estimated from consumption, health, disability insurance, and wage data. We characterize the effects of disability insurance and study how policy reforms impact behavior and welfare. DI features high rejection rates of disabled applicants and some acceptance of healthy applicants. Despite worse incentives, welfare increases as programs become less strict or generosity increases. Disability insurance interacts with welfare programs: making unconditional means-tested programs more generous improves disability insurance targeting and increases welfare.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Consumption Inequality over the Last Half Century: Some Evidence Using the New PSID Consumption Measure
abstract: <jats:p> This paper contributes to the debate regarding trends in consumption inequality in the United States. We present a new measure of consumption inequality based on the redesigned 1999-2011 PSID. We impute consumption to the families observed before 1999 using the more comprehensive consumption data available from 1999 onward. One advantage of this procedure is in sample verification of the quality of the imputation procedure; another is that it yields a long time series (1967-2010). Consumption inequality was stable in the 1970s, as was income inequality. It increased significantly after 1980. The Great Recession was associated with a decline in consumption inequality. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the trends in consumption inequality in the United States over the last half century?
answer: Consumption inequality was stable in the 1970s, increased significantly after 1980, and declined during the Great Recession, with these patterns generally following income inequality trends.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the existing debate regarding trends in consumption inequality by providing a new measure based on the redesigned PSID data with an imputation procedure that creates a long time series from 1967-2010, offering advantages in sample verification and comprehensive coverage.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Asset Pricing Implications of Pareto Optimality with Private Information
abstract: We compare the empirical performance of a standard incomplete markets asset pricing model with that of a novel model with constrained Pareto‐optimal allocations. We represent the models’ stochastic discount factors in terms of the cross‐sectional distribution of consumption and use these representations to evaluate the models’ empirical implications. The first model is inconsistent with the equity premium in the United States, United Kingdom, and Italy. The second model is consistent with the equity premium and the risk‐free rate in all three countries if the coefficient of relative risk aversion is roughly 5 and the quarterly discount factor is less than 0.5.
