author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Disability Insurance and the Dynamics of the Incentive Insurance Trade-Off
abstract: <jats:p>We provide a life-cycle framework for comparing insurance and disincentive effects of disability benefits. The risks that individuals face and the parameters of the Disability Insurance (DI) program are estimated from consumption, health, disability insurance, and wage data. We characterize the effects of disability insurance and study how policy reforms impact behavior and welfare. DI features high rejection rates of disabled applicants and some acceptance of healthy applicants. Despite worse incentives, welfare increases as programs become less strict or generosity increases. Disability insurance interacts with welfare programs: making unconditional means-tested programs more generous improves disability insurance targeting and increases welfare. (JEL D14, J24, J65)</jats:p>
research_question: How do insurance benefits and work disincentive effects of disability insurance programs interact over the life cycle, and what are the welfare implications of different policy reforms?
answer: Despite creating worse work incentives, welfare increases when disability insurance programs become less strict or more generous. Additionally, making unconditional means-tested programs more generous improves disability insurance targeting and increases overall welfare.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a comprehensive life-cycle framework that jointly analyzes the insurance-disincentive trade-off in disability insurance by estimating program parameters from multiple data sources (consumption, health, disability insurance, and wage data) and examining interactions between disability insurance and other welfare programs.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Portfolio choices, firm shocks and uninsurable wage risk

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Firm-Related Risk and Precautionary Saving Response
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a new approach to identify the strength of the precautionary motive and the extent of self-insurance in response to earnings risk based on Euler equation estimates. To address endogeneity problems, we use Norwegian administrative data and instrument consumption and earnings volatility with the variance of firm-specific shocks. The instrument is valid because firms pass some of their productivity shocks onto wages; moreover, for most workers, firm shocks are hard to avoid. Our estimates suggest a coefficient of relative prudence of 2, in a very plausible range. </jats:p>
research_question: How strong is the precautionary saving motive and what is the extent of self-insurance in response to earnings risk?
answer: The coefficient of relative prudence is approximately 2, indicating a moderate and plausible strength of precautionary saving behavior in response to earnings volatility.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new approach to identify precautionary saving strength using Euler equation estimates with firm-specific shocks as instruments, addressing endogeneity problems that have challenged previous research in this area.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Heterogeneity in Returns to Wealth and the Measurement of Wealth Inequality
abstract: <jats:p> Lacking a long time series on the assets of the very wealthy, Saez and Zucman (2015) use US tax records to obtain estimates of wealth holdings by capitalizing asset income from tax returns. They document marked upward trends in wealth concentration. We use data on tax returns and actual wealth holdings from tax records for the whole Norwegian population to test the robustness of the methodology. We document that measures of wealth based on the capitalization approach can lead to misleading conclusions about the level and the dynamics of wealth inequality if returns are heterogeneous and even moderately correlated with wealth. </jats:p>
research_question: How robust is the capitalization methodology used by Saez and Zucman (2015) for measuring wealth inequality when applied to actual wealth data?
answer: The capitalization approach can lead to misleading conclusions about both the level and dynamics of wealth inequality when returns are heterogeneous and even moderately correlated with wealth.
positioning_statement: This paper tests and challenges the robustness of the influential capitalization methodology developed by Saez and Zucman (2015) by using comprehensive Norwegian tax data that includes both tax returns and actual wealth holdings, providing empirical validation that was previously unavailable due to data limitations.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Heterogeneity and Persistence in Returns to Wealth
abstract: <jats:p>We provide a systematic analysis of the properties of individual returns to wealth using 12 years of population data from Norway's administrative tax records. We document a number of novel results. First, individuals earn markedly different average returns on their net worth (a standard deviation of 22.1%) and on its components. Second, heterogeneity in returns does not arise merely from differences in the allocation of wealth between safe and risky assets: returns are heterogeneous even within narrow asset classes. Third, returns are positively correlated with wealth: moving from the 10th to the 90th percentile of the net worth distribution increases the return by 18 percentage points (and 10 percentage points if looking at net‐of‐tax returns). Fourth, individual wealth returns exhibit substantial persistence over time. We argue that while this persistence partly arises from stable differences in risk exposure and assets scale, it also reflects heterogeneity in sophistication and financial information, as well as entrepreneurial talent. Finally, wealth returns are correlated across generations. We discuss the implications of these findings for several strands of the wealth inequality debate.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the properties of individual returns to wealth, particularly regarding heterogeneity and persistence across individuals?
answer: Individual returns to wealth exhibit substantial heterogeneity (standard deviation of 22.1%), are positively correlated with wealth levels (18 percentage point difference between 10th and 90th percentiles), show significant persistence over time, and are correlated across generations. This heterogeneity exists even within narrow asset classes and reflects differences in sophistication, financial information, and entrepreneurial talent beyond just risk exposure.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first systematic analysis of individual wealth returns using comprehensive population-level administrative data, documenting novel empirical facts that have important implications for multiple strands of the wealth inequality literature.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Wage Risk and Employment Risk over the Life Cycle
abstract: <jats:p> We specify a life-cycle model of consumption, labor supply and job mobility in an economy with search frictions. We distinguish different sources of risk, including shocks to productivity, job arrival, and job destruction. Allowing for job mobility has a large effect on the estimate of productivity risk. Increases in the latter impose a considerable welfare loss. Increases in employment risk have large effects on output and, primarily through this channel, affect welfare. The welfare value of programs such as Food Stamps, partially insuring productivity risk, is greater than the value of unemployment insurance which provides (partial) insurance against employment risk. (JEL D91, J22, J31, J61, J64, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: How do different sources of risk (productivity shocks, job arrival, and job destruction) affect welfare over the life cycle in an economy with search frictions and job mobility?
answer: Productivity risk imposes considerable welfare losses when accounting for job mobility, employment risk affects welfare primarily through its large effects on output, and programs like Food Stamps that partially insure productivity risk provide greater welfare value than unemployment insurance that insures against employment risk.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing life-cycle models by incorporating job mobility and search frictions to distinguish between different sources of risk, showing that allowing for job mobility has a large effect on estimates of productivity risk compared to previous literature.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Consumption Inequality and Partial Insurance
abstract: <jats:p> This paper examines the link between income and consumption inequality. We create panel data on consumption for the Panel Study of Income Dynamics using an imputation procedure based on food demand estimates from the Consumer Expenditure Survey. We document a disjuncture between income and consumption inequality over the 1980s and show that it can be explained by changes in the persistence of income shocks. We find some partial insurance of permanent shocks, especially for the college educated and those near retirement. We find full insurance of transitory shocks except among poor households. Taxes, transfers, and family labor supply play an important role in insuring permanent shocks. (JEL D12, D31, D91, E21) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the link between income and consumption inequality, and how do households insure against different types of income shocks?
answer: There is a disjuncture between income and consumption inequality over the 1980s that can be explained by changes in the persistence of income shocks. Households have partial insurance against permanent shocks (especially college-educated and near-retirement individuals) and full insurance against transitory shocks (except among poor households), with taxes, transfers, and family labor supply serving as important insurance mechanisms for permanent shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by creating new panel data on consumption for the PSID using an imputation procedure based on food demand estimates from the Consumer Expenditure Survey, allowing for a novel examination of the consumption-income inequality relationship and the degree of insurance against different types of income shocks.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Erratum: Children, Time Allocation, and Consumption Insurance
abstract: As a result of a small programmingmistake, some of the results contained in the paper “Children, Time Allocation, and Consumption Insurance,” published in the October 2018 issue (vol. 126[S1]) of the Journal of Political Economy, are incorrect. In keeping with the journal’s editorial policy, this erratum includes the revised tables andfigures; as the interested reader can verify, the changes are negligible and do not affect in any meaningful way the qualitative interpretation of the findings. For this reason, the text has not beenmodified. Researchers interested in replicating the results below should access the updated replication package available on the journal’s website.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Consumption Network Effects
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In this article we study consumption network effects. Does the consumption of our peers affect our own consumption? How large is such effect? What are the economic mechanisms behind it? We use administrative panel data on Danish households to construct a measure of consumption based on tax records on income and assets. We combine tax record data with matched employer–employee data to identify peer groups based on workplace, which gives us a much tighter and credible definition of networks than used in previous literature. We use the non-overlapping network structure of one’s peers group, as well as firm-level shocks, to build valid instruments for peer consumption. We estimate non-negligible and statistically significant network effects, capable of generating sizable multiplier effect at the macro-level. We also investigate what mechanisms generate such effects, distinguishing between intertemporal and intratemporal consumption effects as well as a more traditional risk sharing view.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the consumption of our peers affect our own consumption, how large is such effect, and what are the economic mechanisms behind it?
answer: The study finds non-negligible and statistically significant network effects in consumption that are capable of generating sizable multiplier effects at the macro-level, with mechanisms including both intertemporal and intratemporal consumption effects as well as risk sharing.
positioning_statement: This paper improves upon previous literature by using administrative panel data on Danish households combined with matched employer-employee data to identify peer groups based on workplace, which provides a much tighter and credible definition of networks than used in previous literature, and employs non-overlapping network structure and firm-level shocks to build valid instruments for peer consumption.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Children, Time Allocation, and Consumption Insurance
abstract: We study choices of households deciding on consumption and allocation of spouses’ time to work, leisure, and child care. With uncertainty, the allocation of goods and time over the life cycle also serves the purpose of smoothing marginal utility in response to shocks. Combining data on consumption, wages, hours of work, and time spent with children, we compute the sensitivity of consumption and time allocation to transitory and permanent wage shocks. We find that family labor supply responses depend on three counteracting forces: complementarity of leisure time, substitutability of time in the production of child services, and added worker effects.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Consumption Inequality and Family Labor Supply
abstract: <jats:p> We examine the link between wage and consumption inequality using a life-cycle model incorporating consumption and family labor supply decisions. We derive analytical expressions for the dynamics of consumption, hours, and earnings of two earners in the presence of correlated wage shocks, nonseparability, progressive taxation, and asset accumulation. The model is estimated using panel data for hours, earnings, assets, and consumption. We focus on family labor supply as an insurance mechanism and find strong evidence of smoothing of permanent wage shocks. Once family labor supply, assets, and taxes are properly accounted for there is little evidence of additional insurance. (JEL D12, D14, D91, J22, J31) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the link between wage and consumption inequality, and how do family labor supply decisions serve as an insurance mechanism against wage shocks?
answer: Family labor supply provides strong evidence of smoothing permanent wage shocks, and once family labor supply, assets, and taxes are properly accounted for, there is little evidence of additional insurance mechanisms needed to explain the relationship between wage and consumption inequality.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by incorporating family labor supply decisions into a life-cycle model that examines consumption inequality, using analytical expressions that account for correlated wage shocks, nonseparability, progressive taxation, and asset accumulation, and estimating the model with comprehensive panel data on hours, earnings, assets, and consumption.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Credit within the Firm

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Adjustment Costs, Firm Responses, and Micro vs. Macro Labor Supply Elasticities: Evidence from Danish Tax Records
abstract: We show that the effects of taxes on labor supply are shaped by interactions between adjustment costs for workers and hours constraints set by firms. We develop a model in which firms post job offers characterized by an hours requirement and workers pay search costs to find jobs. We present evidence supporting three predictions of this model by analyzing bunching at kinks using Danish tax records. First, larger kinks generate larger taxable income elasticities. Second, kinks that apply to a larger group of workers generate larger elasticities. Third, the distribution of job offers is tailored to match workers' aggregate tax preferences in equilibrium. Our results suggest that macro elasticities may be substantially larger than the estimates obtained using standard microeconometric methods.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: The Role of Social Capital in Financial Development
abstract: <jats:p> To identify the effect of social capital on financial development, we exploit social capital differences within Italy. In high-social-capital areas, households are more likely to use checks, invest less in cash and more in stock, have higher access to institutional credit, and make less use of informal credit. The effect of social capital is stronger where legal enforcement is weaker and among less educated people. These results are not driven by omitted environmental variables, since we show that the behavior of movers is still affected by the level of social capital of the province where they were born. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of social capital on financial development?
answer: Social capital positively affects financial development - in high-social-capital areas, households are more likely to use formal financial instruments (checks, stocks, institutional credit) rather than informal alternatives (cash, informal credit), with stronger effects where legal enforcement is weaker and among less educated people.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing causal identification of social capital's effect on financial development through exploiting within-country variation in Italy and demonstrating that results are not driven by omitted environmental variables using evidence from geographic movers.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Cultural Biases in Economic Exchange?<sup>*</sup>

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: Corporate Culture, Societal Culture, and Institutions
abstract: <jats:p> While both cultural and legal norms (institutions) help foster cooperation, culture is the more primitive of the two and itself sustains formal institutions. Cultural changes are rarer and slower than changes in legal institutions, which makes it difficult to identify the role played by culture. Cultural changes and their effects are easier to identify in simpler, more controlled, environments, such as corporations. Corporate culture, thus, is not only interesting per se, but also as a laboratory to study the role of societal culture and the way it can be changed. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of culture in fostering cooperation and sustaining formal institutions, and how can corporate culture serve as a laboratory to study societal culture and cultural change?
answer: Culture is more primitive than legal institutions and itself sustains formal institutions, with corporate culture providing a simpler, more controlled environment where cultural changes and their effects can be more easily identified and studied.
positioning_statement: This paper positions corporate culture not only as an important subject of study in its own right, but as a methodological laboratory for understanding broader societal culture and cultural change, given that cultural changes are typically rarer and slower than institutional changes, making them difficult to study in broader societal contexts.

author: Lukas Schmid
title: The Impact of Host Language Proficiency on Migrants’ Employment Outcomes
abstract: <jats:p> This paper estimates the economic gains from proficiency in the host country’s language on migrants’ employment outcomes by exploiting the exogenous placement of refugees to Swiss cantons and a sharp language border dividing German- and French-speaking regions. Using administrative data on African refugees who applied for Swiss asylum between 2008 and 2017, I compare French-speaking refugees assigned to the French-speaking region to French-speaking refugees assigned to the German-speaking region and adjust for common regional differences with outcomes from English-speaking African refugees. The results suggest that language proficiency more than doubles the employment level in the first five years after arrival. (JEL J15, J24, J31, J82, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the economic impact of host country language proficiency on migrants' employment outcomes?
answer: Language proficiency more than doubles the employment level in the first five years after arrival for migrants.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by exploiting a unique natural experiment using the exogenous placement of refugees across Swiss language regions and a sharp language border, combined with administrative data, to identify causal effects of language proficiency on employment outcomes.

author: Luigi Pistaferri
title: The Wind of Change: Maritime Technology, Trade, and Economic Development
abstract: <jats:p>The 1870–1913 period marked the birth of the first era of trade globalization. How did this tremendous increase in trade affect economic development? This work isolates a causality channel by exploiting the fact that the introduction of the steamship in the shipping industry produced an asymmetric change in trade distances among countries. Before this invention, trade routes depended on wind patterns. The steamship reduced shipping costs and time in a disproportionate manner across countries and trade routes. Using this source of variation and novel data on shipping, trade, and development, I find that (i) the adoption of the steamship had a major impact on patterns of trade worldwide; (ii) only a small number of countries, characterized by more inclusive institutions, benefited from trade integration; and (iii) globalization was the major driver of the economic divergence between the rich and the poor portions of the world in the years 1850–1900. (JEL F14, F43, F63, L92, N70, O33)</jats:p>
research_question: How did the tremendous increase in trade during the first era of trade globalization (1870-1913) affect economic development?
answer: The adoption of the steamship had a major impact on global trade patterns, but only countries with more inclusive institutions benefited from trade integration, and globalization was the major driver of economic divergence between rich and poor countries during 1850-1900.
positioning_statement: This work isolates a causality channel by exploiting the asymmetric change in trade distances produced by steamship introduction, using the fact that pre-steamship trade routes depended on wind patterns while steamships reduced shipping costs and time disproportionately across countries and trade routes.

author: Lukas Schmid
title: Sticky Leverage
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a tractable general equilibrium model that captures the interplay between nominal long-term corporate debt, inflation, and real aggregates. We show that unanticipated inflation changes the real burden of debt and, more significantly, leads to a debt overhang that distorts future investment and production decisions. For these effects to be both large and very persistent, it is essential that debt maturity exceeds one period. We also show that interest rate rules can help stabilize our economy. (JEL E12, E31, E44, E52, G01, G32, G35) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the interplay between nominal long-term corporate debt, inflation, and real aggregates affect investment and production decisions in a general equilibrium framework?
answer: Unanticipated inflation changes the real burden of debt and creates a debt overhang that distorts future investment and production decisions, with these effects being both large and very persistent when debt maturity exceeds one period, while interest rate rules can help stabilize the economy.
positioning_statement: The paper develops a tractable general equilibrium model to capture the previously underexplored dynamics between nominal long-term corporate debt, inflation, and real economic aggregates, emphasizing the critical role of debt maturity in generating persistent economic effects.

author: Manasi Deshpande
title: Does Welfare Inhibit Success? The Long-Term Effects of Removing Low-Income Youth from the Disability Rolls
abstract: <jats:p> I estimate the effects of removing low-income youth with disabilities from Supplemental Security Income (SSI) on their earnings and income in adulthood. Using a regression discontinuity design based on a 1996 policy change in age 18 medical reviews, I find that youth who are removed from SSI at age 18 recover one-third of the lost SSI cash income in earnings. SSI youth who are removed and stay off SSI earn on average $4,400 annually, and they lose $76,000 in present discounted observed income over the 16 years following removal relative to those who do not receive a review. (JEL I30, I38, J14) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-term effects on earnings and income when low-income youth with disabilities are removed from Supplemental Security Income (SSI) at age 18?
answer: Youth removed from SSI at age 18 recover only one-third of their lost SSI cash income through earnings, earning on average $4,400 annually, and lose $76,000 in present discounted observed income over 16 years compared to those who remain on SSI.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on welfare effects by using a regression discontinuity design based on a 1996 policy change in age 18 medical reviews to provide causal estimates of SSI removal effects on youth with disabilities, addressing the question of whether welfare inhibits success.

author: Manasi Deshpande
title: Does Welfare Prevent Crime? the Criminal Justice Outcomes of Youth Removed from Ssi
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We estimate the effect of losing Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits at age 18 on criminal justice and employment outcomes over the next two decades. To estimate this effect, we use a regression discontinuity design in the likelihood of being reviewed for SSI eligibility at age 18 created by the 1996 welfare reform law. We evaluate this natural experiment with Social Security Administration data linked to records from the Criminal Justice Administrative Records System. We find that SSI removal increases the number of criminal charges by a statistically significant 20% over the next two decades. The increase in charges is concentrated in offenses for which income generation is a primary motivation (60% increase), especially theft, burglary, fraud/forgery, and prostitution. The effect of SSI removal on criminal justice involvement persists more than two decades later, even as the effect of removal on contemporaneous SSI receipt diminishes. In response to SSI removal, youth are twice as likely to be charged with an illicit income-generating offense than they are to maintain steady employment at ${\$}$15,000/year in the labor market. As a result of these charges, the annual likelihood of incarceration increases by a statistically significant 60% in the two decades following SSI removal. The costs to taxpayers of enforcement and incarceration from SSI removal are so high that they nearly eliminate the savings to taxpayers from reduced SSI benefits.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of losing Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits at age 18 on criminal justice and employment outcomes over the next two decades?
answer: SSI removal increases criminal charges by 20% over two decades, with a 60% increase in income-generating offenses (theft, burglary, fraud/forgery, prostitution) and a 60% increase in incarceration likelihood. Youth are twice as likely to engage in illicit income-generating activities than maintain steady employment, and the costs of enforcement and incarceration nearly eliminate taxpayer savings from reduced SSI benefits.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a regression discontinuity design created by the 1996 welfare reform law to provide causal evidence on the relationship between welfare benefits and crime, utilizing linked Social Security Administration and Criminal Justice Administrative Records System data to examine long-term effects over two decades.

author: Manasi Deshpande
title: Beyond Health: Nonhealth Risk and the Value of Disability Insurance
abstract: <jats:p>The public debate over disability insurance has centered on concerns about individuals without severe health conditions receiving benefits. We go beyond health risk alone to quantify the overall insurance value of U.S. disability programs, including value from insuring nonhealth risk. We find that disability recipients, especially those with less‐severe health conditions, are much more likely to have experienced a wide variety of nonhealth shocks than nonrecipients. Selection into disability receipt on the basis of nonhealth shocks is so strong among individuals with less‐severe health conditions that by many measures less‐severe recipients are worse off than more‐severe recipients. As a result, under baseline assumptions, benefits to less‐severe recipients have an annual surplus value (insurance benefit less efficiency cost) over cost‐equivalent tax cuts of $7700 per recipient, about three‐fourths that of benefits to more‐severe recipients ($9900). Insurance against nonhealth risk accounts for about one‐half of the value of U.S. disability programs.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the overall insurance value of U.S. disability programs when considering both health and nonhealth risks, particularly for recipients with less-severe health conditions?
answer: Disability insurance provides substantial value beyond health risk protection, with nonhealth risk accounting for about half of the total program value. Benefits to less-severe recipients have an annual surplus value of $7,700 per recipient (about three-fourths that of more-severe recipients at $9,900), and these recipients are actually worse off than more-severe recipients by many measures due to strong selection based on nonhealth shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper goes beyond the existing literature's focus on health risk alone and challenges the public debate's concern about individuals without severe health conditions receiving benefits by quantifying the broader insurance value that includes protection against nonhealth shocks.

author: Manasi Deshpande
title: The (Lack of) Anticipatory Effects of the Social Safety Net on Human Capital Investment
abstract: <jats:p>How does the expectation that a child will receive government benefits in adulthood affect parental investments in the child’s human capital? Most parents whose children receive Supplemental Security Income (SSI) benefits overestimate the likelihood that their child will receive SSI benefits in adulthood. We present randomly selected families with the predicted likelihood that their child will receive SSI benefits in adulthood. Reducing parents’ expectations that children will receive benefits in adulthood does not increase investments in children’s human capital. This zero effect is precisely estimated. Likely explanations include parents working more themselves, nonfinancial goals influencing investment, and families facing investment constraints. (JEL G52, I26, I38, J13, J24, J31)</jats:p>
research_question: How does the expectation that a child will receive government benefits in adulthood affect parental investments in the child's human capital?
answer: Reducing parents' expectations that children will receive SSI benefits in adulthood does not increase investments in children's human capital - the effect is precisely estimated to be zero.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in understanding anticipatory effects of social safety net programs on human capital investment decisions, specifically examining whether correcting parental overestimation of future SSI benefit likelihood affects current investment behavior.

author: Manisha Shah
title: Do Sex Workers Respond to Disease? Evidence from the Male Market for Sex
abstract: <jats:p> Sex markets play a key role in the transmission of sexually transmitted infections (STI) and HIV/AIDS in developing countries. While individuals should substitute away from risky sex as STI prevalence rises, female sex workers draw a premium for engaging in unprotected sex, mitigating their propensity to use condoms. We provide the first evidence of a positive premium for non-condom sex in developing country male sex markets. Testing whether this is a compensating differential for disease risk, we find that a one percentage point increase in the STI rate increases the premium 28 percent. Market forces may curb the self-limiting effect of STI epidemics. </jats:p>
research_question: Do sex workers respond to disease risk, and specifically, is there a compensating differential for disease risk in male sex markets in developing countries?
answer: Yes, sex workers respond to disease risk through pricing. A one percentage point increase in the STI rate increases the premium for unprotected sex by 28 percent, and there is a positive premium for non-condom sex in developing country male sex markets.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first evidence of a positive premium for non-condom sex in developing country male sex markets, extending beyond existing literature that has focused on female sex workers who draw premiums for unprotected sex, and contributes to understanding how market forces may limit the self-limiting effects of STI epidemics.

author: Manisha Shah
title: Decriminalizing Indoor Prostitution: Implications for Sexual Violence and Public Health

author: Manisha Shah
title: Prostitutes and Brides?

author: Manisha Shah
title: Drought of Opportunities: Contemporaneous and Long-Term Impacts of Rainfall Shocks on Human Capital
abstract: Higher wages are generally thought to increase human capital production, particularly in the developing world. We introduce a simple model of human capital production in which investments and time allocation differ by age. Using data on test scores and schooling from rural India, we show that higher wages increase human capital investment in early life (in utero to age 2) but decrease human capital from age 5 to 16. Children switch out of school into productive work when rainfall is higher. The opportunity cost of schooling, even for fairly young children, is an important factor in determining overall human capital investment.

author: Manudeep Bhuller
title: Feedback and Learning: The Causal Effects of Reversals on Judicial Decision-Making
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Do judges respond to reversals of their decisions? Using random assignment of cases across two stages of the criminal justice system in Norway and a novel dataset linking trial court decisions to reversals in appeals courts, we provide causal evidence on feedback effects in judicial decision-making. By exploiting differences in the tendencies of randomly assigned appeal panels to reverse trial court decisions, we show that trial court judges who receive a reversal of a sentence respond by updating the likelihood of imposing a prison sentence in the direction of the reversal in future cases. Consistent with a Bayesian learning model, we find that the responses are stronger for judges with weaker priors and for reversals corresponding to stronger signals. Our estimates, however, also indicate that judges overreact to reversals compared to Bayes’ rule.</jats:p>
research_question: Do judges respond to reversals of their decisions, and if so, how do they update their future decision-making based on this feedback?
answer: Trial court judges do respond to reversals by updating their future sentencing decisions in the direction of the reversal, with stronger responses from judges with weaker priors and for reversals that provide stronger signals, though judges overreact compared to optimal Bayesian updating.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first causal evidence on feedback effects in judicial decision-making by exploiting random assignment of cases in Norway's criminal justice system, addressing a gap in the literature on how judges learn from appellate court feedback.

author: Manisha Shah
title: Risky Business: The Market for Unprotected Commercial Sex

author: Manisha Shah
title: Crimes Against Morality: Unintended Consequences of Criminalizing Sex Work*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We examine the impact of criminalizing sex work, exploiting an event in which local officials unexpectedly criminalized sex work in one district in East Java, Indonesia, but not in neighboring districts. We collect data from female sex workers and their clients before and after the change. We find that criminalization increases sexually transmitted infections among female sex workers by 58 percent, measured by biological tests. This is driven by decreased condom access and use. We also find evidence that criminalization decreases earnings among women who left sex work due to criminalization and decreases their ability to meet their children’s school expenses while increasing the likelihood that children begin working to supplement household income. Although criminalization has the potential to improve population STI outcomes if the market shrinks permanently, we show that five years postcriminalization the market has rebounded and the probability of STI transmission in the general population is likely to have increased.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of criminalizing sex work on health outcomes for sex workers, their economic circumstances, and broader population effects?
answer: Criminalizing sex work increases sexually transmitted infections among female sex workers by 58 percent due to decreased condom access and use, reduces earnings for women who exit sex work, negatively affects their children's education and increases child labor, and likely increases STI transmission risk in the general population as the market rebounds within five years.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on unintended consequences of criminalization policies by providing causal evidence through a natural experiment in Indonesia, examining both immediate health and economic effects on sex workers and longer-term population-level outcomes that previous studies may have overlooked.

author: Mar Reguant
title: Pass-Through of Emissions Costs in Electricity Markets
abstract: <jats:p> We measure the pass-through of emissions costs to electricity prices. We perform both reduced-form and structural estimations based on optimal bidding in this market. Using rich micro-level data, we estimate the channels affecting pass-through in a flexible manner, with minimal functional form assumptions. Contrary to many studies in the general pass-through literature, we find that emissions costs are almost fully passed through to electricity prices. Since electricity is traded through high-frequency auctions for highly inelastic demand, firms have weak incentives to adjust markups after the cost shock. Furthermore, the costs of price adjustment are small. (JEL D44, L11, L94, L98, Q52, Q54) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the pass-through rate of emissions costs to electricity prices?
answer: Emissions costs are almost fully passed through to electricity prices, contrary to findings in many general pass-through studies.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with the general pass-through literature by finding nearly complete pass-through, which the authors attribute to the unique characteristics of electricity markets including high-frequency auctions, highly inelastic demand, weak incentives for markup adjustment after cost shocks, and small costs of price adjustment.

author: Manudeep Bhuller
title: Incarceration, Recidivism, and Employment
abstract: Using a random judge design and panel data from Norway, we estimate that imprisonment discourages further criminal behavior, with reoffense probabilities falling by 29 percentage points and criminal charges dropping by 11 over a 5-year period. Ordinary least squares mistakenly reaches the opposite conclusion. The decline is driven by individuals not working prior to incarceration; these individuals increase participation in employment programs and raise their future employment and earnings. Previously employed individuals experience lasting negative employment effects. These findings demonstrate that time spent in prison with a focus on rehabilitation can be preventive for a large segment of the criminal population.

author: Manudeep Bhuller
title: Broadband Internet: An Information Superhighway to Sex Crime?

author: Mar Reguant
title: Complementary Bidding Mechanisms and Startup Costs in Electricity Markets
abstract: I extend multi-unit auction estimation techniques to a setting in which firms can express cost complementarities over time. In the context of electricity markets, I show how the auction structure and bidding data can be used to estimate these complementarities, which in these markets arise due to startup costs. I find that startup costs are substantial and that taking them into account helps better explain firm bidding strategies and production patterns. As in other dynamic settings, I find that startup costs limit the ability of firms to change production over time, exacerbating fluctuations in market prices. These fluctuations can induce estimates of market power that ignore dynamic costs to overstate markup volatility, with predicted markups that can be even negative in periods of low demand. I show how accounting for startup costs can provide a natural correction for these markup biases.

author: Manudeep Bhuller
title: Signaling and Employer Learning with Instruments
abstract: <jats:p> This paper considers the use of instruments to identify and estimate private and social returns to education within a model of employer learning. What an instrument identifies depends on whether it is hidden from, or transparent (i.e., observed ) to, the employers. A hidden instrument identifies private returns to education, and a transparent instrument identifies social returns to education. We use variation in compulsory schooling laws across noncentral and central municipalities in Norway to, respectively, construct hidden and transparent instruments. We estimate a private return of 7.9 percent, of which 70 percent is due to increased productivity and the remaining 30 percent is due to signaling. (JEL D82, H75, I26, I28, J24, J31) </jats:p>
research_question: How can instruments be used to identify and estimate the private and social returns to education within a model of employer learning, and what portion of education returns is due to productivity increases versus signaling?
answer: The private return to education is 7.9 percent, with 70 percent attributable to increased productivity and 30 percent due to signaling effects. Hidden instruments identify private returns while transparent instruments identify social returns to education.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the employer learning literature by developing a novel instrumental variable approach that distinguishes between hidden and transparent instruments to separately identify private and social returns to education, providing a new method to decompose education returns into productivity and signaling components.

author: Mar Reguant
title: The Investment Effects of Market Integration: Evidence From Renewable Energy Expansion in Chile
abstract: <jats:p>We study the investment effects of market integration on renewable energy expansion. Our theory highlights that market integration not only improves allocative efficiency by gains from trade but also incentivizes new investment in renewable power plants. To test our theoretical predictions, we examine how recent grid expansions in the Chilean electricity market changed electricity production, wholesale prices, generation costs, and renewable investments. We then build a structural model of power plant entry to quantify the impact of market integration with and without the investment effects. We find that the market integration in Chile increased solar generation by around 180%, saved generation costs by 8%, and reduced carbon emissions by 5%. A substantial amount of renewable entry would not have occurred in the absence of market integration. Our findings suggest that ignoring these investment effects would substantially understate the benefits of market integration and its important role in expanding renewable energy.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the investment effects of market integration on renewable energy expansion?
answer: Market integration in Chile increased solar generation by around 180%, saved generation costs by 8%, and reduced carbon emissions by 5%, with substantial renewable entry that would not have occurred without market integration.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on market integration by highlighting that it not only improves allocative efficiency through gains from trade but also incentivizes new investment in renewable power plants, arguing that ignoring these investment effects substantially understates the benefits of market integration.

author: Mar Reguant
title: Sequential Markets, Market Power, and Arbitrage
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a framework to characterize strategic behavior in sequential markets under imperfect competition and restricted entry in arbitrage. Our theory predicts that these two elements can generate a systematic price premium. We test the model predictions using microdata from the Iberian electricity market. We show that the observed price differences and firm behavior are consistent with the model. Finally, we quantify the welfare effects of arbitrage using a structural model. In the presence of market power, we show that full arbitrage is not necessarily welfare-enhancing, reducing consumer costs but increasing deadweight loss. (JEL D42, D43, L12, L13, L94, Q41) </jats:p>
research_question: How do imperfect competition and restricted entry in arbitrage affect strategic behavior and pricing in sequential markets?
answer: These two elements can generate systematic price premiums, and full arbitrage is not necessarily welfare-enhancing as it reduces consumer costs but increases deadweight loss when market power is present.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new framework to characterize strategic behavior in sequential markets by incorporating both imperfect competition and restricted arbitrage entry, extending beyond existing literature that may not fully account for these combined market imperfections.

author: Mar Reguant
title: Market-Based Emissions Regulation and Industry Dynamics
abstract: We assess the static and dynamic implications of alternative market-based policies limiting greenhouse gas emissions in the US cement industry. Our results highlight two countervailing market distortions. First, emissions regulation exacerbates distortions associated with the exercise of market power in the domestic cement market. Second, emissions “leakage” in trade-exposed markets offsets domestic emissions reductions. Taken together, these forces can result in social welfare losses under policy regimes that fully internalize the emissions externality. Market-based policies that incorporate design features to mitigate the exercise of market power and emissions leakage deliver welfare gains when damages from carbon emissions are high.

author: Marcella Alsan
title: Tuskegee and the Health of Black Men*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>For 40 years, the Tuskegee Study of Untreated Syphilis in the Negro Male passively monitored hundreds of adult black men with syphilis despite the availability of effective treatment. The study’s methods have become synonymous with exploitation and mistreatment by the medical profession. To identify the study’s effects on the behavior and health of older black men, we use an interacted difference-in-difference-in-differences model, comparing older black men to other demographic groups, before and after the Tuskegee revelation, in varying proximity to the study’s victims. We find that the disclosure of the study in 1972 is correlated with increases in medical mistrust and mortality and decreases in both outpatient and inpatient physician interactions for older black men. Our estimates imply life expectancy at age 45 for black men fell by up to 1.5 years in response to the disclosure, accounting for approximately 35% of the 1980 life expectancy gap between black and white men and 25% of the gap between black men and women.</jats:p>
research_question: What were the effects of the Tuskegee Study disclosure on the behavior and health of older black men?
answer: The disclosure of the Tuskegee Study in 1972 led to increased medical mistrust and mortality, and decreased physician interactions among older black men, with life expectancy at age 45 falling by up to 1.5 years, accounting for approximately 35% of the 1980 life expectancy gap between black and white men and 25% of the gap between black men and women.
positioning_statement: This paper examines the long-term behavioral and health consequences of medical exploitation by analyzing how the revelation of the Tuskegee Study's unethical methods affected trust in healthcare and health outcomes among the demographic group most directly impacted by the study.

author: Mara P. Squicciarini
title: Human Capital and Industrialization: Evidence from the Age of Enlightenment *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>While human capital is a strong predictor of economic development today, its importance for the Industrial Revolution has typically been assessed as minor. To resolve this puzzling contrast, we differentiate average human capital (literacy) from upper-tail knowledge. As a proxy for the historical presence of knowledge elites, we use city-level subscriptions to the famous Encyclopédie in mid-18th century France. We show that subscriber density is a strong predictor of city growth after the onset of French industrialization. Alternative measures of development such as soldier height, disposable income, and industrial activity confirm this pattern. Initial literacy levels, on the other hand, are associated with development in the cross-section, but they do not predict growth. Finally, by joining data on British patents with a large French firm survey from the 1840s, we shed light on the mechanism: upper-tail knowledge raised productivity in innovative industrial technology.</jats:p>
research_question: Why is human capital a strong predictor of economic development today, but its importance for the Industrial Revolution has typically been assessed as minor?
answer: The resolution lies in differentiating between average human capital (literacy) and upper-tail knowledge - while average literacy levels do not predict growth during industrialization, the presence of knowledge elites (measured by Encyclopédie subscriptions) is a strong predictor of city growth and development after the onset of French industrialization, with upper-tail knowledge raising productivity in innovative industrial technology.
positioning_statement: This paper resolves a puzzling contrast in the existing literature by proposing that previous assessments underestimated human capital's role in the Industrial Revolution because they focused on average human capital rather than distinguishing between general literacy and upper-tail knowledge held by intellectual elites.

author: Mara P. Squicciarini
title: Technology Adoption and Productivity Growth: Evidence from Industrialization in France

author: Mara P. Squicciarini
title: Devotion and Development: Religiosity, Education, and Economic Progress in Nineteenth-Century France
abstract: <jats:p>This paper studies when religion can hamper diffusion of knowledge and economic development, and through which mechanism. I examine Catholicism in France during the Second Industrial Revolution (1870–1914). In this period, technology became skill-intensive, leading to the introduction of technical education in primary schools. I find that more religious locations had lower economic development after 1870. Schooling appears to be the key mechanism: more religious areas saw a slower adoption of the technical curriculum and a push for religious education. In turn, religious education was negatively associated with industrial development 10 to 15 years later, when schoolchildren entered the labor market. (JEL D83, I21, I26, N33, Z12)</jats:p>
research_question: When can religion hamper diffusion of knowledge and economic development, and through which mechanism?
answer: Religion can hamper economic development when technological progress becomes skill-intensive, with the key mechanism being that more religious areas resist adoption of technical education curricula in favor of religious education, leading to lower industrial development 10-15 years later when those students enter the labor market.
positioning_statement: This paper examines the specific case of Catholicism in France during the Second Industrial Revolution (1870-1914) to provide empirical evidence on the conditions and mechanisms through which religion can impede knowledge diffusion and economic progress, focusing on the educational channel during a period when technology became increasingly skill-intensive.

author: Marcella Alsan
title: The Effect of the TseTse Fly on African Development
abstract: <jats:p>The TseTse fly is unique to Africa and transmits a parasite harmful to humans and lethal to livestock. This paper tests the hypothesis that the TseTse reduced the ability of Africans to generate an agricultural surplus historically. Ethnic groups inhabiting TseTse-suitable areas were less likely to use domesticated animals and the plow, less likely to be politically centralized, and had a lower population density. These correlations are not found in the tropics outside of Africa, where the fly does not exist. The evidence suggests current economic performance is affected by the TseTse through the channel of pre colonial political centralization. (JEL I12, N57, O13, O17, Q12, Q16, Q18)</jats:p>
research_question: Does the TseTse fly reduce the ability of Africans to generate an agricultural surplus historically, and how does this affect current economic performance?
answer: The TseTse fly reduced African agricultural surplus generation by making ethnic groups in TseTse-suitable areas less likely to use domesticated animals and plows, less likely to be politically centralized, and resulting in lower population density. Current economic performance is negatively affected through the channel of reduced pre-colonial political centralization.
positioning_statement: This paper provides unique evidence by comparing correlations within Africa (where TseTse flies exist) to the tropics outside of Africa (where the fly does not exist), demonstrating that the observed effects are specific to the presence of the TseTse fly rather than general tropical conditions.

author: Marcella Alsan
title: Watersheds in Child Mortality: The Role of Effective Water and Sewerage Infrastructure, 1880–1920
abstract: We explore the first period of sustained decline in child mortality in the United States and provide estimates of the independent and combined effects of clean water and effective sewerage systems on under-5 mortality. Our case is Massachusetts, 1880–1920, when authorities developed a sewerage and water district in the Boston area. We find the two interventions were complementary and together account for approximately one-third of the decline in log child mortality during the 41 years. Our findings are relevant to the developing world and suggest that a piecemeal approach to infrastructure investments is unlikely to significantly improve child health.

author: Marcella Alsan
title: “Something Works” in U.S. Jails: Misconduct and Recidivism Effects of the IGNITE Program
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A long-standing and influential view in U.S. correctional policy is that “nothing works” when it comes to rehabilitating incarcerated individuals. We revisit this hypothesis by studying an innovative law-enforcement-led program launched in the county jail of Flint, MI: Inmate Growth Naturally and Intentionally through Education (IGNITE). We develop an instrumental variables approach to estimate the effects of IGNITE exposure, leveraging quasi-random court delays that cause individuals to spend more time in jail before and after the program’s launch. Holding time in jail fixed, we find that one additional month of IGNITE exposure reduces weekly misconduct in jail by 25% and three-month recidivism by 24%, with the recidivism effects growing over time. Surveys of staff and community members, along with administrative test-score records and within-jail text messages, suggest that cultural change and improved literacy and numeracy scores are contributing mechanisms.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the IGNITE (Inmate Growth Naturally and Intentionally through Education) program in U.S. jails effectively reduce misconduct and recidivism among incarcerated individuals?
answer: Yes, the IGNITE program is effective - one additional month of exposure reduces weekly misconduct in jail by 25% and three-month recidivism by 24%, with recidivism effects growing over time, achieved through cultural change and improved literacy and numeracy.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the long-standing and influential 'nothing works' hypothesis in U.S. correctional policy by demonstrating that rehabilitation programs can be effective in reducing misconduct and recidivism.

author: Marcella Alsan
title: Does Diversity Matter for Health? Experimental Evidence from Oakland
abstract: <jats:p> We study the effect of physician workforce diversity on the demand for preventive care among African American men. In an experiment in Oakland, California, we randomize black men to black or non-black male medical doctors. We use a two-stage design, measuring decisions before (pre-consultation) and after (post-consultation) meeting their assigned doctor. Subjects select a similar number of preventives in the pre-consultation stage, but are much more likely to select every preventive service, particularly invasive services, once meeting with a racially concordant doctor. Our findings suggest black doctors could reduce the black-white male gap in cardiovascular mortality by 19 percent. (JEL I12, I14, C93) </jats:p>
research_question: Does physician workforce diversity, specifically racial concordance between doctors and patients, affect the demand for preventive care among African American men?
answer: African American men are much more likely to select preventive services, particularly invasive ones, when meeting with racially concordant (black) doctors compared to non-black doctors, with findings suggesting this could reduce the black-white male gap in cardiovascular mortality by 19 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes experimental evidence to the literature on physician workforce diversity and healthcare disparities by using a randomized controlled trial design with a two-stage measurement approach to isolate the causal effect of racial concordance on preventive care demand among African American men.

author: Marcelo Moreira
title: Valid t-ratio Inference for IV
abstract: <jats:p> In the single-IV model, researchers commonly rely on t-ratio-based inference, even though the literature has quantified its potentially severe large-sample distortions. Building on Stock and Yogo (2005), we introduce the tF critical value function, leading to a standard error adjustment that is a smooth function of the first-stage F-statistic. For one-quarter of specifications in 61 AER papers, corrected standard errors are at least 49 and 136 percent larger than conventional 2SLS standard errors at the 5 percent and 1 percent significance levels, respectively. tF confidence intervals have shorter expected length than those of Anderson and Rubin (1949), whenever both are bounded. (JEL C13, C26) </jats:p>
research_question: How can t-ratio-based inference be made valid in single-IV models given the potentially severe large-sample distortions that have been documented in the literature?
answer: The paper introduces the tF critical value function that provides a standard error adjustment as a smooth function of the first-stage F-statistic, which corrects for the distortions in t-ratio inference and produces confidence intervals with shorter expected length than Anderson-Rubin intervals when both are bounded.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Stock and Yogo (2005) and addresses the well-documented problem that researchers commonly rely on potentially severely distorted t-ratio-based inference in single-IV models, offering a practical solution that improves upon existing methods like Anderson and Rubin (1949) confidence intervals.

author: Marcella Alsan
title: Representation and Extrapolation: Evidence from Clinical Trials
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article examines the consequences and causes of low enrollment of Black patients in clinical trials. We develop a simple model of similarity-based extrapolation that predicts that evidence is more relevant for decision-making by physicians and patients when it is more representative of the group being treated. This generates the key result that the perceived benefit of a medicine for a group depends not only on the average benefit from a trial but also on the share of patients from that group who were enrolled in the trial. In survey experiments, we find that physicians who care for Black patients are more willing to prescribe drugs tested in representative samples, an effect substantial enough to close observed gaps in the prescribing rates of new medicines. Black patients update more on drug efficacy when the sample that the drug is tested on is more representative, reducing Black-white patient gaps in beliefs about whether the drug will work as described. Despite these benefits of representative data, our framework and evidence suggest that those who have benefited more from past medical breakthroughs are less costly to enroll in the present, leading to persistence in who is represented in the evidence base.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the consequences and causes of low enrollment of Black patients in clinical trials, and how does the representativeness of trial samples affect physician prescribing behavior and patient beliefs about drug efficacy?
answer: The perceived benefit of a medicine for a group depends not only on the average benefit from a trial but also on the share of patients from that group enrolled in the trial. Physicians caring for Black patients are more willing to prescribe drugs tested in representative samples (enough to close observed prescribing gaps), and Black patients update more on drug efficacy when samples are more representative, reducing Black-white gaps in beliefs about drug effectiveness.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel similarity-based extrapolation model to explain how evidence representativeness affects medical decision-making, providing both theoretical framework and empirical evidence for why representative clinical trial enrollment matters for reducing healthcare disparities - an issue that has been observed but not systematically modeled in existing literature.

author: Mariano Massimiliano Croce
title: International Robust Disagreement
abstract: <jats:p> We characterize the equilibrium of a two-country, two-good economy in which agents have opposite preference bias toward one of the two consumption goods and fear model misspecification. We document that disagreement about endowments' growth prospects is a persistent endogenous outcome of this class of economies. </jats:p>
research_question: How does model misspecification and preference bias affect equilibrium outcomes in a two-country, two-good international economy?
answer: Disagreement about endowments' growth prospects emerges as a persistent endogenous outcome when agents have opposite preference biases toward consumption goods and fear model misspecification.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing international trade and finance literature by incorporating robust control theory (fear of model misspecification) into a multi-country framework with heterogeneous preferences, showing how disagreement can arise endogenously rather than being assumed exogenously.

author: Margarita Tsoutsoura
title: TRAINING, JOB SECURITY AND INCENTIVE WAGES
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>This paper considers the optimal level of firm‐specific training by taking into account the positive effect of training on the expected duration of workers' current employment. In the framework of an efficiency wage model, a short expected job tenure represents a disamenity that reduces the penalty from shirking. As this disamenity increases, workers have an incentive to continue providing a positive level of effort only if they are compensated by a higher wage. We endogenize the employment separation rate by introducing firm‐specific training. Firm‐specific training creates a rent that is lost if the worker is separated from the firm. As a result, the firm will be more reluctant to fire its trained workforce in a recession. This implies that firm‐specific training can decrease current wages because it represents a commitment to lower future labour turnover.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal level of firm-specific training when considering its positive effect on expected duration of workers' employment and its interaction with incentive wages?
answer: Firm-specific training can decrease current wages because it represents a commitment to lower future labor turnover - the training creates a rent that makes firms more reluctant to fire trained workers, thereby reducing the disamenity of job insecurity and allowing for lower compensating wages.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the efficiency wage model literature by endogenizing the employment separation rate through firm-specific training, whereas previous models treated job tenure and turnover as exogenous factors in wage determination.

author: Margarita Tsoutsoura
title: Measuring Income Tax Evasion Using Bank Credit: Evidence from Greece *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We document that in semiformal economies, banks lend to tax-evading individuals based on the bank’s assessment of the individual’s true income. This observation leads to a novel approach to estimate tax evasion. We use microdata on household credit from a Greek bank and replicate the bank underwriting model to infer the banks estimate of individuals’ true income. We estimate that 43–45% of self-employed income goes unreported and thus untaxed. For 2009, this implies €28.2 billion of unreported income, implying forgone tax revenues of over €11 billion or 30% of the deficit. Our method innovation allows for estimating the industry distribution of tax evasion in settings where uncovering the incidence of hidden cash transactions is difficult using other methods. Primary tax-evading industries are professional services—medicine, law, engineering, education, and media. We conclude with evidence that contemplates the importance of institutions, paper trail, and political willpower for the persistence of tax evasion.</jats:p>
research_question: How can bank credit data be used to measure income tax evasion in semiformal economies, and what is the extent of tax evasion among self-employed individuals?
answer: 43-45% of self-employed income goes unreported and untaxed, representing €28.2 billion of unreported income in Greece for 2009, resulting in forgone tax revenues of over €11 billion (30% of the deficit), with primary tax-evading industries being professional services including medicine, law, engineering, education, and media.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel methodological approach to estimate tax evasion by leveraging the fact that banks in semiformal economies lend based on their assessment of borrowers' true income rather than reported income, offering a new way to uncover hidden cash transactions where other methods are difficult to apply.

author: Mariassunta Giannetti
title: Flight Home, Flight Abroad, and International Credit Cycles
abstract: <jats:p> This paper shows that banks exhibit a weaker (stronger) home bias in the extension of new loans when funding conditions in their home country improve (deteriorate). We refer to these changes in home bias as flight abroad and flight home effects, respectively, and show that they are unrelated to the better known flight to quality effect that arises during periods of market turmoil. Our results also indicate that global banks amplify the effect of homegrown shocks on foreign countries while they are a stabilizing factor for the supply of credit in their home countries. </jats:p>
research_question: How do changes in home country funding conditions affect banks' home bias in loan extension, and what are the implications for international credit cycles?
answer: Banks exhibit weaker home bias (flight abroad) when home country funding conditions improve and stronger home bias (flight home) when conditions deteriorate. Global banks amplify homegrown shocks on foreign countries while stabilizing credit supply domestically.
positioning_statement: This paper distinguishes flight abroad and flight home effects from the well-established flight to quality effect, showing these phenomena are unrelated to market turmoil periods and represent a separate mechanism in international banking.

author: Marciano Siniscalchi
title: Structural Rationality in Dynamic Games
abstract:
<jats:p>The analysis of dynamic games hinges on assumptions about players' actions and beliefs at information sets that are not expected to be reached during game play. Under the standard notion of sequential rationality, these assumptions cannot be tested on the basis of observed, on‐path behavior. This paper introduces a novel optimality criterion, 
            <jats:italic>structural rationality</jats:italic>, which addresses this concern. In any dynamic game, structural rationality implies weak sequential rationality (Reny (1992)). If players are structurally rational, assumptions about on‐path and off‐path beliefs concerning off‐path actions can be tested via suitable “side bets.” Structural rationality also provides a theoretical rationale for the use of a novel version of the strategy method (Selten (1967)) in experiments.
          </jats:p>
research_question: How can assumptions about players' actions and beliefs at off-path information sets in dynamic games be made testable based on observable behavior?
answer: The paper introduces 'structural rationality' as a novel optimality criterion that makes off-path beliefs testable through 'side bets' and provides theoretical justification for experimental methods, while implying weak sequential rationality.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental limitation of standard sequential rationality in dynamic game theory, where assumptions about off-path behavior cannot be tested through observed on-path behavior, by building upon Reny (1992)'s weak sequential rationality and Selten (1967)'s strategy method to create a testable framework.

author: Marina Agranov
title: A Comment on “Testing Models of Social Learning on Networks: Evidence From Two Experiments”
abstract: Proposition 2 in Chandrasekhar et al. (2020) characterizes when imitation is optimal in a discrete-time setup where all agents are myopic Bayesian and this is common knowledge. In this note, we provide a correction to this result, where the condition for imitation to be optimal is stronger than in the original result.

author: Marina Agranov
title: Coordination with Differential Time Preferences: Experimental Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> The experimental literature on repeated games has largely focused on settings where players discount the future identically. In applications, however, interactions often occur between players whose time preferences differ. We study experimentally the effects of discounting differentials in infinitely repeated coordination games. In our data, differential discount factors play two roles. First, they provide a coordination anchor: more impatient players get higher payoffs first. Introducing even small discounting differentials reduces coordination failures significantly. Second, with pronounced discounting differentials, intertemporal trades are prevalent: impatient players get higher payoffs for an initial phase and patient players get higher payoffs in perpetuity afterward. (JEL C72, C92, D15, D25) </jats:p>
research_question: How do differential time preferences (discount factors) between players affect coordination outcomes in infinitely repeated coordination games?
answer: Differential discount factors play two key roles: (1) they serve as coordination anchors where more impatient players receive higher payoffs first, with even small discounting differentials significantly reducing coordination failures, and (2) with large discounting differentials, intertemporal trades emerge where impatient players get higher initial payoffs while patient players receive higher payoffs in perpetuity afterward.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the experimental literature on repeated games, which has largely focused on settings where players have identical discount factors, by studying the more realistic scenario where players have different time preferences in coordination games.

author: Marina Halac
title: Relational Contracts and the Value of Relationships
abstract: <jats:p> This article studies optimal relational contracts when the value of the relationship between contracting parties is not commonly known. I consider a principal-agent setting where the principal has persistent private information about her outside option. I show that if the principal has the bargaining power, she wants to understate her outside option to provide strong incentives and then renege on promised payments, while if the uninformed agent has the bargaining power, the principal wants to overstate her outside option to capture more surplus. I characterize how information is revealed, how the relationship evolves, and how this depends on bargaining power. (JEL C78, D82, D83, D86) </jats:p>
research_question: How do optimal relational contracts function when the value of the relationship between contracting parties is not commonly known, specifically when the principal has persistent private information about her outside option?
answer: The key finding is that information asymmetry about relationship value creates strategic incentives that depend on bargaining power: principals with bargaining power understate their outside option to provide strong incentives but then renege on payments, while when uninformed agents have bargaining power, principals overstate their outside option to capture more surplus.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the relational contracts literature by introducing persistent private information about the principal's outside option, examining how information asymmetry affects contract design and relationship dynamics in a principal-agent setting with varying bargaining power allocations.

author: Marina Halac
title: Commitment versus Flexibility with Costly Verification
abstract: A principal faces an agent who is better informed but biased toward higher actions. She can verify the agent’s information and specify his permissible actions. We show that if the verification cost is small enough, a threshold with an escape clause (TEC) is optimal: the agent either chooses an action below a threshold or requests verification and the efficient action above the threshold. For higher costs, however, the principal may require verification only for intermediate actions, dividing the delegation set. TEC is always optimal if the principal cannot commit to inefficient allocations following the verification decision and result.

author: Marina Halac
title: Rank Uncertainty in Organizations
abstract: <jats:p> A principal incentivizes a team of agents to work by privately offering them bonuses contingent on team success. We study the principal’s optimal incentive scheme that implements work as a unique equilibrium. This scheme leverages rank uncertainty to address strategic uncertainty. Each agent is informed only of a ranking distribution and his own bonus, the latter making work dominant provided that higher-rank agents work. If agents are symmetric, their bonuses are identical. Thus, discrimination is strictly suboptimal, in sharp contrast with the case of public contracts (Winter 2004). We characterize how agents’ ranking and compensation vary with asymmetric effort costs. (JEL D23, D62, D81, D82, D86) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the principal's optimal incentive scheme for motivating a team of agents to work when contracts are private and there is strategic uncertainty?
answer: The optimal incentive scheme leverages rank uncertainty by informing each agent only of a ranking distribution and their own bonus, making work dominant if higher-rank agents work. For symmetric agents, identical bonuses are optimal, making discrimination strictly suboptimal.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with existing literature on public contracts (specifically Winter 2004) by showing that discrimination is strictly suboptimal under private contracts, whereas it may be optimal under public contracts.

author: Marina Halac
title: Managerial Attention and Worker Performance
abstract: <jats:p> We present a novel theory of the employment relationship. A manager can invest in attention technology to recognize good worker performance. The technology may break and is costly to replace. We show that as time passes without recognition, the worker's belief about the manager's technology worsens and his effort declines. The manager responds by investing, but this investment is insufficient to stop the decline in effort and eventually becomes decreasing. The relationship therefore continues deteriorating, and a return to high performance becomes increasingly unlikely. These deteriorating dynamics do not arise when recognition is of bad performance or independent of effort. (JEL D21, D82, J24, M54) </jats:p>
research_question: How does managerial attention technology for recognizing worker performance affect the employment relationship and worker effort over time?
answer: When managers use costly attention technology to recognize good worker performance, the employment relationship deteriorates over time - as time passes without recognition, workers believe the technology has broken, effort declines, and despite managerial investment responses, the relationship continues deteriorating with decreasing likelihood of returning to high performance.
