positioning_statement: This paper presents a novel theory of the employment relationship that distinguishes itself by showing that deteriorating dynamics specifically arise only when recognition is of good performance, but not when recognition is of bad performance or independent of effort.

author: Marina Halac
title: Fiscal Rules and Discretion in a World Economy
abstract: <jats:p> Governments are present-biased toward spending. Fiscal rules are deficit limits that trade off commitment to not overspend and flexibility to react to shocks. We compare coordinated rules, chosen jointly by a group of countries, to uncoordinated rules. If governments’ present bias is small, coordinated rules are tighter than uncoordinated rules: individual countries do not internalize the redistributive effect of interest rates. However, if the bias is large, coordinated rules are slacker: countries do not internalize the disciplining effect of interest rates. Surplus limits enhance welfare, and increased savings by some countries or outside economies can hurt the rest. (JEL D82, E43, E62, H62) </jats:p>
research_question: How do coordinated fiscal rules (chosen jointly by a group of countries) compare to uncoordinated fiscal rules in terms of their tightness and welfare effects in a world economy where governments have present bias toward spending?
answer: The relative tightness of coordinated versus uncoordinated fiscal rules depends on the magnitude of governments' present bias: when present bias is small, coordinated rules are tighter than uncoordinated rules because countries don't internalize redistributive effects of interest rates; when present bias is large, coordinated rules are slacker because countries don't internalize the disciplining effects of interest rates. Additionally, surplus limits enhance welfare, and increased savings by some countries can hurt others.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the fiscal rules literature by analyzing the trade-off between commitment and flexibility in deficit limits, specifically comparing coordinated versus uncoordinated approaches in a multi-country setting where governments exhibit present bias toward spending, incorporating both redistributive and disciplining effects of interest rates.

author: Marina Halac
title: Fiscal Rules and Discretion Under Limited Enforcement
abstract: <jats:p>We study a fiscal policy model in which the government is present‐biased towards public spending. Society chooses a fiscal rule to trade off the benefit of committing the government to not overspend against the benefit of granting it flexibility to react to privately observed shocks to the value of spending. Unlike prior work, we examine rules under limited enforcement: the government has full policy discretion and can only be incentivized to comply with a rule via the use of penalties which are joint and bounded. We show that optimal incentives must be bang‐bang. Moreover, under a distributional condition, the optimal rule is a maximally enforced deficit limit, triggering the maximum feasible penalty whenever violated. Violation optimally occurs under high enough shocks if and only if available penalties are weak and such shocks are relatively unlikely. We derive comparative statics showing how rules should be calibrated to features of the environment.</jats:p>
research_question: How should society design optimal fiscal rules when the government has present-bias towards public spending and can only be incentivized to comply through bounded penalties, while needing flexibility to respond to privately observed shocks?
answer: The optimal fiscal rule under limited enforcement is a maximally enforced deficit limit that triggers the maximum feasible penalty whenever violated, with bang-bang optimal incentives. Violations should optimally occur under high shocks only when available penalties are weak and such shocks are relatively unlikely.
positioning_statement: Unlike prior work that assumes perfect enforcement, this paper examines fiscal rules under limited enforcement where the government retains full policy discretion and can only be incentivized through bounded joint penalties, providing a more realistic framework for analyzing fiscal policy commitment problems.

author: Marina Halac
title: A Theory of Fiscal Responsibility and Irresponsibility

author: Marina Halac
title: Raising Capital from Heterogeneous Investors
abstract: <jats:p> A firm raises capital from multiple investors to fund a project. The project succeeds only if the capital raised exceeds a stochastic threshold, and the firm offers payments contingent on success. We study the firm’s optimal unique-implementation scheme, namely the scheme that guarantees the firm the maximum payoff. This scheme treats investors differently based on size. We show that if the distribution of the investment threshold is log-concave, larger investors receive higher net returns than smaller investors. Moreover, higher dispersion in investor size increases the firm’s payoff. Our analysis highlights strategic risk as an important potential driver of inequality. (JEL D21, D86, G24, G32) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal scheme for a firm to raise capital from multiple heterogeneous investors when project success depends on meeting a stochastic funding threshold?
answer: The optimal unique-implementation scheme treats investors differently based on size, with larger investors receiving higher net returns than smaller investors when the investment threshold distribution is log-concave, and higher dispersion in investor size increases the firm's payoff.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by highlighting strategic risk as an important potential driver of inequality in capital raising, focusing on how firms optimally design differentiated payment schemes for heterogeneous investors under funding uncertainty.

author: Marina Halac
title: Instrument-Based versus Target-Based Rules
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study rules based on instruments versus targets. Our application is a New Keynesian economy where the central bank has non-contractible information about aggregate demand shocks and cannot commit to policy. Incentives are provided to the central bank via punishment which is socially costly. Instrument-based rules condition incentives on the central bank’s observable choice of policy, whereas target-based rules condition incentives on the outcomes of policy, such as inflation, which depend on both the policy choice and realized shocks. We show that the optimal rule within each class takes a threshold form, imposing the worst punishment upon violation. Target-based rules dominate instrument-based rules if and only if the central bank’s information is sufficiently precise, and they are relatively more attractive the less severe the central bank’s commitment problem. The optimal unconstrained rule relaxes the instrument threshold whenever the target threshold is satisfied.</jats:p>
research_question: When should monetary policy rules be based on instruments (the central bank's observable policy choices) versus targets (policy outcomes like inflation) in a setting where the central bank has private information and cannot commit to policy?
answer: Target-based rules dominate instrument-based rules if and only if the central bank's information about aggregate demand shocks is sufficiently precise, and target-based rules become relatively more attractive when the central bank's commitment problem is less severe. The optimal rule within each class takes a threshold form with maximum punishment upon violation.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the monetary policy rules literature by formally comparing instrument-based versus target-based rules in a New Keynesian framework with central bank private information and commitment problems, providing conditions under which each type of rule is optimal.

author: Marina Halac
title: Contests for Experimentation

author: Marina Halac
title: Optimal Contracts for Experimentation

author: Mark Dean
title: The Neuroeconomic Theory of Learning

author: Mark Dean
title: Experimental Tests of Rational Inattention
abstract: We use laboratory experiments to test models of rational inattention, in which people acquire information to maximize utility net of information costs. We show that subjects adjust their attention in response to changes in incentives, in line with the rational inattention model. However, our results are qualitatively inconsistent with information costs that are linear in Shannon entropy, as is often assumed in applied work. Our data are best fit by a generalization of the Shannon model, which allows for a more flexible response to incentives and for some states of the world to be harder to distinguish than others.

author: Mark Dean
title: Search and Satisficing
abstract: <jats:p> Many everyday decisions are made without full examination of all available options, and, as a result, the best available option may be missed. We develop a search-theoretic choice experiment to study the impact of incomplete consideration on the quality of choices. We find that many decisions can be understood using the satisficing model of Herbert Simon (1955): most subjects search sequentially, stopping when a “satisficing” level of reservation utility is realized. We find that reservation utilities and search order respond systematically to changes in the decision making environment. (JEL D03, D12, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How does incomplete consideration of available options impact the quality of choices in decision-making?
answer: Many decisions can be understood using Herbert Simon's satisficing model, where subjects search sequentially and stop when a satisficing level of reservation utility is achieved, with reservation utilities and search order responding systematically to changes in the decision environment.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Herbert Simon's (1955) satisficing model by developing a search-theoretic choice experiment to empirically study how incomplete consideration affects choice quality, providing experimental evidence for satisficing behavior in decision-making.

author: Mark Dean
title: Dopamine, Reward Prediction Error, and Economics<sup>*</sup>

author: Mark Dean
title: Economic Insights from “Neuroeconomic” Data

author: Mark Dean
title: Revealed Preference, Rational Inattention, and Costly Information Acquisition
abstract: <jats:p> Apparently mistaken decisions are ubiquitous. To what extent does this reflect irrationality, as opposed to a rational trade-off between the costs of information acquisition and the expected benefits of learning? We develop a revealed preference test that characterizes all patterns of choice “mistakes” consistent with a general model of optimal costly information acquisition and identify the extent to which information costs can be recovered from choice data. (JEL D11, D81, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: To what extent do apparently mistaken decisions reflect irrationality versus a rational trade-off between the costs of information acquisition and the expected benefits of learning?
answer: The paper develops a revealed preference test that characterizes all patterns of choice 'mistakes' consistent with optimal costly information acquisition and identifies how information costs can be recovered from choice data, suggesting that apparent mistakes may be rational given information acquisition costs.
positioning_statement: The paper positions itself as providing a framework to distinguish between truly irrational decision-making and rational behavior under costly information acquisition, contributing to the literature on rational inattention by developing empirical methods to test and quantify information costs from observed choice patterns.

author: Mark Dean
title: Rationally Inattentive Behavior: Characterizing and Generalizing Shannon Entropy
abstract: We introduce three new classes of attention cost functions: posterior separable, uniformly posterior separable, and invariant posterior separable. As with the Shannon cost function, all can be solved using Lagrangian methods. Uniformly posterior-separable cost functions capture many forms of sequential learning and hence play a key role in many applications. Invariant posterior-separable cost functions make learning strategies depend exclusively on payoff uncertainty. We introduce two behavioral axioms, Locally Invariant Posteriors and Only Payoffs Matter, which identify posterior-separable functions as uniformly and invariant posterior separable, respectively. In combination, they pinpoint the Shannon cost function.

author: Mark Dean
title: Measuring Beliefs and Rewards: A Neuroeconomic Approach<sup>*</sup>

author: Mark Dean
title: Econographics
abstract: We study the pattern of correlations across a large number of behavioral regularities, with the goal of creating an empirical basis for more comprehensive theories of decision-making. We elicit 21 behaviors, using an incentivized survey on a representative sample (n=1,000) of the US population. Our data show a clear and relatively simple structure underlying the correlations between these measures. Using principal components analysis, we reduce the 21 variables to six components corresponding to clear clusters of high correlations. We examine the relationship between these components, cognitive ability, and demographics. Common extant theories are not compatible with all the patterns in our data.

author: Mark Egan
title: When Harry Fired Sally: The Double Standard in Punishing Misconduct

author: Mark Egan
title: Recovering Investor Expectations from Demand for Index Funds
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use a revealed-preference approach to estimate investor expectations of stock market returns. Using data on demand for index funds that follow the S&P 500, we develop and estimate a model of investor choice to flexibly recover the time-varying distribution of expected future returns across investors. Our analysis is facilitated by the prevalence of leveraged funds that track the same underlying asset: by choosing between higher and lower leverage, investors trade off higher return against less risk. Our estimates indicate that investor expectations are heterogeneous, extrapolative, and persistent. Following a downturn, investors become more pessimistic on average, but there is also an increase in disagreement among participating investors due to the presence of contrarian investors.</jats:p>
research_question: How can investor expectations of stock market returns be estimated using revealed preferences from demand for index funds?
answer: Investor expectations are heterogeneous, extrapolative, and persistent. Following market downturns, investors become more pessimistic on average, but disagreement among investors increases due to the presence of contrarian investors.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel revealed-preference approach to estimate investor expectations by analyzing demand for index funds, particularly leveraging the existence of funds with different leverage levels that track the same underlying asset (S&P 500) to identify how investors trade off higher returns against risk.

author: Martin Weidner
title: Fixed‐Effect Regressions on Network Data
abstract: <jats:p>This paper considers inference on fixed effects in a linear regression model estimated from network data. An important special case of our setup is the two‐way regression model. This is a workhorse technique in the analysis of matched data sets, such as employer–employee or student–teacher panel data. We formalize how the structure of the network affects the accuracy with which the fixed effects can be estimated. This allows us to derive sufficient conditions on the network for consistent estimation and asymptotically valid inference to be possible. Estimation of moments is also considered. We allow for general networks and our setup covers both the dense and the sparse case. We provide numerical results for the estimation of teacher value‐added models and regressions with occupational dummies.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the structure of networks affect the accuracy of fixed effects estimation in linear regression models, and what conditions are necessary for consistent estimation and valid inference?
answer: The paper formalizes how network structure affects fixed effects estimation accuracy and derives sufficient conditions on the network structure that enable consistent estimation and asymptotically valid inference, covering both dense and sparse network cases.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the workhorse two-way fixed effects regression technique commonly used in matched datasets (employer-employee, student-teacher panels) by providing a general framework for network data that encompasses both dense and sparse networks, filling a gap in understanding how network structure affects estimation accuracy.

author: Mark Egan
title: Deposit Competition and Financial Fragility: Evidence from the US Banking Sector
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a structural empirical model of the US banking sector. Insured depositors and run-prone uninsured depositors choose between differentiated banks. Banks compete for deposits and endogenously default. The estimated demand for uninsured deposits declines with banks' financial distress, which is not the case for insured deposits. We calibrate the supply side of the model. The calibrated model possesses multiple equilibria with bank-run features, suggesting that banks can be very fragile. We use our model to analyze proposed bank regulations. For example, our results suggest that a capital requirement below 18 percent can lead to significant instability in the banking system. (JEL E44, G01, G21, G28, G32) </jats:p>
research_question: How does deposit competition affect financial fragility in the US banking sector, particularly regarding the differential behavior of insured versus uninsured depositors and the resulting implications for bank stability?
answer: The key finding is that uninsured depositors are sensitive to banks' financial distress and withdraw deposits when banks are in trouble (while insured depositors are not), creating multiple equilibria with bank-run features that make banks very fragile. The model suggests that capital requirements below 18 percent can lead to significant banking system instability.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a structural empirical model that explicitly incorporates both insured and uninsured depositor behavior in a competitive banking environment, allowing for endogenous bank defaults and multiple equilibria, which enables analysis of how deposit competition mechanisms create financial fragility and evaluation of proposed banking regulations.

author: Mark Egan
title: The Market for Financial Adviser Misconduct

author: Martin Oehmke
title: A Theory of Socially Responsible Investment
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We characterize the conditions under which a socially responsible (SR) fund induces firms to reduce externalities, even when profit-seeking capital is in perfectly elastic supply. Such impact requires that the SR fund’s mandate permits the fund to trade off financial performance against reductions in social costs—relative to the counterfactual in which the fund does not invest in a given firm. Based on such an impact mandate, we derive the social profitability index, an investment criterion that characterizes the optimal ranking of impact investments when SR capital is scarce. If firms face binding financial constraints, the optimal way to achieve impact is by enabling a scale increase for clean production. In this case, SR and profit-seeking capital are complementary: Surplus is higher when both investor types are present.</jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions can a socially responsible (SR) fund induce firms to reduce externalities when profit-seeking capital is in perfectly elastic supply?
answer: A socially responsible fund can induce firms to reduce externalities when the fund's mandate permits trading off financial performance against reductions in social costs, and when firms face binding financial constraints, the optimal impact strategy is enabling scale increases for clean production through complementary use of both SR and profit-seeking capital.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a theoretical framework for socially responsible investment that goes beyond existing literature by characterizing specific conditions for impact and deriving the social profitability index as an investment criterion for ranking impact investments when SR capital is scarce, while demonstrating the complementary relationship between SR and profit-seeking capital.

author: Mark Egan
title: Arbitration with Uninformed Consumers
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>This article studies the impact of the arbitrator selection process on consumer outcomes. Using data from consumer arbitration cases in the securities industry over the past two decades, where we observe detailed information on case characteristics, the randomly generated list of potential arbitrators presented to both parties, the selected arbitrator, and case outcomes, we establish several motivating facts. These facts suggest that firms hold an informational advantage over consumers in selecting arbitrators, resulting in industry-friendly arbitration outcomes. We then develop and calibrate a quantitative model of arbitrator selection in which firms hold an informational advantage in selecting arbitrators. Arbitrators, who are compensated only if chosen, compete with each other to be selected. The model allows us to decompose the firms’ advantage into two components: the advantage of choosing pro-industry arbitrators from a given pool and the equilibrium pro-industry tilt in the arbitration pool that arises because of arbitrator competition. Selecting arbitrators without the input of firms and consumers would increase consumer awards by $60,000 on average relative to the current system. Forty percent of this effect arises because the pool of arbitrators skews pro-industry due to competition. Even an informed consumer cannot avoid this pro-industry equilibrium effect. Counterfactuals suggest that redesigning the arbitrator selection mechanism for the benefit of consumers hinges on whether consumers are informed. Policies intended to benefit consumers, such as increasing arbitrator compensation or giving parties more choice, would benefit informed consumers but hurt the uninformed.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the arbitrator selection process impact consumer outcomes in arbitration, particularly when firms have informational advantages over consumers?
answer: Firms' informational advantage in selecting arbitrators results in industry-friendly outcomes that reduce consumer awards by $60,000 on average compared to random selection, with 40% of this disadvantage arising from arbitrators competing to be selected by tilting pro-industry, and 60% from firms directly choosing favorable arbitrators from the available pool.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the arbitration literature by providing the first quantitative decomposition of how informational asymmetries between firms and consumers affect arbitrator selection and outcomes, using unique detailed data on the complete arbitration process including randomly generated arbitrator lists, selections, and outcomes to develop a novel theoretical model of arbitrator competition.

author: Marzena Rostek
title: Decentralized Exchange
abstract: <jats:p> Most assets are traded in multiple interconnected trading venues. This paper develops an equilibrium model of decentralized markets that accommodates general market structures with coexisting exchanges. Decentralized markets can allocate risk among traders with different risk preferences more efficiently, thus realizing gains from trade that cannot be reproduced in centralized markets. Market decentralization always increases price impact. Yet, markets in which assets are traded in multiple exchanges, whether they are disjoint or intermediated, can give higher welfare than the centralized market with the same traders and assets. In decentralized markets, demand substitutability across assets is endogenous and heterogeneous among traders. (JEL D43, D44, D85, G11, G12) </jats:p>
research_question: How do decentralized markets with multiple interconnected trading venues compare to centralized markets in terms of efficiency, welfare, and risk allocation?
answer: Decentralized markets can allocate risk among traders with different risk preferences more efficiently than centralized markets, potentially achieving higher welfare despite always increasing price impact, with demand substitutability across assets being endogenous and heterogeneous among traders.
positioning_statement: This paper develops an equilibrium model that accommodates general market structures with coexisting exchanges, addressing the reality that most assets are traded in multiple interconnected trading venues, which appears to fill a gap in existing literature on market structure analysis.

author: Martin Weidner
title: Linear Regression for Panel With Unknown Number of Factors as Interactive Fixed Effects
abstract: In this paper, we study the least squares (LS) estimator in a linear panel regression model with number of factors appearing as interactive fixed effects. Assuming that the number of factors used in estimation is larger than the true number of factors in the data, we establish the limiting distribution of the LS estimator for the regression coefficients as the number of time periods and the number of cross‐sectional units jointly go to infinity. The main result of the paper is that under certain assumptions, the limiting distribution of the LS estimator is independent of the number of factors used in the estimation as long as this number is not underestimated. The important practical implication of this result is that for inference on the regression coefficients, one does not necessarily need to estimate the number of interactive fixed effects consistently.

author: Marzena Rostek
title: Quantile Maximization in Decision Theory*

author: Martin Weidner
title: Moment Conditions for Dynamic Panel Logit Models with Fixed Effects
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper investigates the construction of moment conditions in discrete choice panel data with individual-specific fixed effects. We describe how to systematically explore the existence of moment conditions that do not depend on the fixed effects, and we demonstrate how to construct them when they exist. Our approach is closely related to the numerical “functional differencing” construction introduced in a seminal paper by Bonhomme, but our emphasis is to find explicit analytic expressions for the moment functions. We first explain the construction and give examples of such moment conditions in various models. Then, we focus on the dynamic binary choice logit model and explore the implications of the moment conditions for the identification and estimation of the model parameters that are common to all individuals.</jats:p>
research_question: How can moment conditions be constructed for dynamic panel logit models with fixed effects that do not depend on the individual-specific fixed effects?
answer: The paper demonstrates how to systematically explore the existence of and construct explicit analytic expressions for moment conditions that eliminate fixed effects dependence, with specific focus on dynamic binary choice logit models and their implications for identification and estimation of common parameters.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Bonhomme's seminal work on numerical 'functional differencing' construction but distinguishes itself by emphasizing the development of explicit analytic expressions for moment functions rather than numerical approaches.

author: Marzena Rostek
title: Matching With Complementary Contracts
abstract:
<jats:p>In this paper, we show that stable outcomes exist in matching environments with complementarities, such as social media platforms or markets for patent licenses. Our results apply to both nontransferable and transferable utility settings, and allow for multilateral agreements and those with externalities. In particular, we show that stable outcomes in these settings are characterized by the largest fixed point of a monotone operator, and so can be found using an algorithm; in the nontransferable utility case, this is a 
            <jats:italic>one‐sided</jats:italic> deferred acceptance algorithm, rather than a Gale–Shapley algorithm. We also give a monotone comparative statics result as well as a comparative static on the effect of bundling contracts together. These illustrate the impact of design decisions, such as increased privacy protections on social media, or the use of antitrust law to disallow patent pools, on stable outcomes.
          </jats:p>
research_question: Do stable outcomes exist in matching environments with complementarities, such as social media platforms or markets for patent licenses?
answer: Yes, stable outcomes exist in matching environments with complementarities and are characterized by the largest fixed point of a monotone operator, which can be found using a one-sided deferred acceptance algorithm in nontransferable utility cases.
positioning_statement: This paper extends matching theory beyond traditional settings by addressing complementarities in matching environments, contrasting with standard Gale-Shapley algorithms by proposing a one-sided deferred acceptance algorithm for nontransferable utility cases, and providing new insights into design decisions' impacts on stable outcomes.

author: Marzena Rostek
title: Reallocative Auctions and Core Selection
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>When selling goods like wireless spectrum or electricity contracts, designers often opt for core-selecting mechanisms—i.e. those that induce outcomes in the core—in order to balance revenue and efficiency goals. But increasingly, auctions—such as the Federal Communications Commission’s Incentive Auction and those explored for natural resources—seek to reallocate goods, not just sell them. We show that when bidders can both buy and sell, substitutability among goods is no longer sufficient or necessary for core selection. In particular, in these environments, core selection can fail even with a single good and positive revenue, and can succeed even when some or all bidders view goods as complements. Instead, we show that the key feature that determines core selection is heterogeneity among the bidders. With too much heterogeneity, reallocation mostly realises pre-existing gains from trade among the bidders, and core selection fails. With limited heterogeneity, most gains from trade among the bidders are created by the quantity auctioned, and a core-selecting mechanism is possible.</jats:p>
research_question: What determines whether core-selecting mechanisms work in reallocative auctions where bidders can both buy and sell goods?
answer: The key determinant of core selection in reallocative auctions is the level of heterogeneity among bidders, not substitutability among goods. With too much heterogeneity, core selection fails because reallocation mainly realizes pre-existing gains from trade. With limited heterogeneity, core selection succeeds because most gains from trade are created by the quantity being auctioned.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the existing literature on core-selecting mechanisms beyond traditional selling auctions to reallocative auctions, showing that the established principle that substitutability among goods is sufficient and necessary for core selection no longer holds when bidders can both buy and sell.

author: Marzena Rostek
title: Financial Product Design in Decentralized Markets

author: Marzena Rostek
title: Exchange Design and Efficiency
abstract: <jats:p>Most assets clear independently rather than jointly. This paper presents a model based on the uniform‐price double auction which accommodates arbitrary restrictions on market clearing, including independent clearing across assets (allowed when demand for each asset is contingent only on the price of that asset) and joint market clearing for all assets (required when demand for each asset is contingent on the prices of all assets). Additional trading protocols for traded assets—neutral when the market clears jointly—are generally not redundant innovations, even if all traders participate in all protocols. Multiple trading protocols that clear independently can be designed to be at least as efficient as joint market clearing for all assets. The change in price impact brought by independence in market clearing can overcome the loss of information, and enhance diversification and risk sharing. Except when the market is competitive, market characteristics should guide innovation in trading technology.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different market clearing mechanisms (independent vs. joint clearing across assets) and multiple trading protocols affect market efficiency in asset trading?
answer: Multiple trading protocols that clear independently can be designed to be at least as efficient as joint market clearing for all assets, as the change in price impact from independent clearing can overcome information loss and enhance diversification and risk sharing.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on exchange design by presenting a model based on uniform-price double auctions that accommodates arbitrary market clearing restrictions, demonstrating that additional trading protocols are generally not redundant innovations even when all traders participate in all protocols, contrary to what might be expected from existing theory.

author: Marzena Rostek
title: Competition in Financial Innovation

author: Mathias Reynaert
title: Abatement Strategies and the Cost of Environmental Regulation: Emission Standards on the European Car Market
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article studies the introduction of an EU-wide emission standard on the automobile market. Using panel data from 1998 to 2011, I find that firms decreased emission ratings by 14%. Firms use technology adoption and gaming of emission tests to decrease emissions, rather than shifting the sales mix or downsizing. I find that the standard missed its emission target, and from estimating a structural model, I find that the standard was not welfare improving. The political environment in the EU shaped the design and weak enforcement and resulted in firms’ choices for abatement by technology adoption and gaming.</jats:p>
research_question: How do firms respond to EU-wide emission standards on the automobile market, and what are the welfare effects of these environmental regulations?
answer: Firms decreased emission ratings by 14% primarily through technology adoption and gaming of emission tests rather than shifting sales mix or downsizing. The emission standard missed its target and was not welfare improving due to weak enforcement shaped by the EU political environment.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on environmental regulation by providing empirical evidence on firm abatement strategies in response to emission standards, using both reduced-form analysis and structural modeling to evaluate the effectiveness and welfare implications of EU automobile emission regulations.

author: Mathias Reynaert
title: Colluding Against Environmental Regulation
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study collusion among firms against imperfectly monitored environmental regulation. Firms increase variable profits by violating regulation and reduce expected noncompliance penalties by violating jointly. We consider a case of three German automakers colluding to reduce the effectiveness of emissions control technology. By estimating a structural model of the European automobile industry from 2007 to 2018, we find that collusion lowers expected noncompliance penalties substantially and increases buyer and producer surplus. Due to increased pollution, welfare decreases by € 1.57–5.57 billion. We show how environmental policy design and antitrust play complementary roles in preventing noncompliance.</jats:p>
research_question: How does collusion among firms affect compliance with imperfectly monitored environmental regulation, and what are the welfare implications?
answer: Collusion among firms reduces expected noncompliance penalties substantially and increases buyer and producer surplus, but decreases overall welfare by €1.57-5.57 billion due to increased pollution from reduced effectiveness of emissions control technology.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining the intersection of collusion and environmental regulation compliance, specifically studying how firms can collude not just on market outcomes but also on regulatory violations, and demonstrating the complementary roles of environmental policy design and antitrust enforcement in preventing noncompliance.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: Financial Intermediation, International Risk Sharing, and Reserve Currencies
abstract: <jats:p> I model the equilibrium risk sharing between countries with varying financial development. The most financially developed country takes greater risks because its financial intermediaries deal with funding problems better. In good times, the more financially developed country consumes more and runs a trade deficit financed by the higher financial income that it earns as compensation for taking greater risk. During global crises, it suffers heavier losses. Its currency emerges as the reserve currency because it appreciates during crises, thus providing a good hedge. I provide evidence that financial net worth plays a crucial role in understanding this asymmetric risk sharing. (JEL E44, F14, F32, G01, G15, G21) </jats:p>
research_question: How does varying financial development across countries affect equilibrium risk sharing and the emergence of reserve currencies?
answer: The most financially developed country takes greater risks due to superior financial intermediation capabilities, earns higher financial income in good times while running trade deficits, suffers heavier losses during crises, but its currency becomes the reserve currency because it appreciates during crises and provides a good hedge.
positioning_statement: This paper models the relationship between financial development differences and international risk sharing, with empirical evidence showing that financial net worth is crucial for understanding asymmetric risk sharing patterns between countries.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title:
International Liquidity and Exchange Rate Dynamics
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We provide a theory of the determination of exchange rates based on capital flows in imperfect financial markets. Capital flows drive exchange rates by altering the balance sheets of financiers that bear the risks resulting from international imbalances in the demand for financial assets. Such alterations to their balance sheets cause financiers to change their required compensation for holding currency risk, thus affecting both the level and volatility of exchange rates. Our theory of exchange rate determination in imperfect financial markets not only helps rationalize the empirical disconnect between exchange rates and traditional macroeconomic fundamentals, it also has real consequences for output and risk sharing. Exchange rates are sensitive to imbalances in financial markets and seldom perform the shock absorption role that is central to traditional theoretical macroeconomic analysis. Our framework is flexible; it accommodates a number of important modeling features within an imperfect financial market model, such as nontradables, production, money, sticky prices or wages, various forms of international pricing-to-market, and unemployment.</jats:p>
research_question: How do capital flows in imperfect financial markets determine exchange rate dynamics and what are the implications for traditional exchange rate theory?
answer: Capital flows drive exchange rates by altering the balance sheets of financiers who bear currency risks from international financial asset demand imbalances, causing them to change their required compensation for holding currency risk, which affects both exchange rate levels and volatility. This mechanism helps explain the empirical disconnect between exchange rates and traditional macroeconomic fundamentals.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges traditional theoretical macroeconomic analysis by proposing that exchange rates are primarily driven by financial market imperfections rather than traditional macroeconomic fundamentals, arguing that exchange rates seldom perform the shock absorption role central to existing theory and instead are sensitive to financial market imbalances with real consequences for output and risk sharing.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: Very Long-Run Discount Rates *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We estimate how households trade off immediate costs and uncertain future benefits that occur in the very long run, 100 or more years away. We exploit a unique feature of housing markets in the United Kingdom and Singapore, where residential property ownership takes the form of either leaseholds or freeholds. Leaseholds are temporary, prepaid, and tradable ownership contracts with maturities between 99 and 999 years, while freeholds are perpetual ownership contracts. The price difference between leaseholds and freeholds reflects the present value of perpetual rental income starting at leasehold expiration, and is thus informative about very long-run discount rates. We estimate the price discounts for varying leasehold maturities compared to freeholds and extremely long-run leaseholds via hedonic regressions using proprietary data sets of the universe of transactions in each country. Households discount very long-run cash flows at low rates, assigning high present value to cash flows hundreds of years in the future. For example, 100-year leaseholds are valued at more than 10% less than otherwise identical freeholds, implying discount rates below 2.6% for 100-year claims.</jats:p>
research_question: How do households trade off immediate costs and uncertain future benefits that occur in the very long run, 100 or more years away?
answer: Households discount very long-run cash flows at low rates, assigning high present value to cash flows hundreds of years in the future. For example, 100-year leaseholds are valued at more than 10% less than otherwise identical freeholds, implying discount rates below 2.6% for 100-year claims.
positioning_statement: This paper exploits a unique feature of housing markets in the United Kingdom and Singapore, where residential property ownership takes the form of either leaseholds or freeholds, to estimate very long-run discount rates - an approach that provides novel empirical evidence on household valuation of extremely distant future cash flows.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: No-Bubble Condition: Model-Free Tests in Housing Markets
abstract: We test for the existence of housing bubbles associated with a failure of the transversality condition that requires the present value of payments occurring infinitely far in the future to be zero. The most prominent such bubble is the classic rational bubble. We study housing markets in the United Kingdom and Singapore, where residential property ownership takes the form of either leaseholds or freeholds. Leaseholds are finite‐maturity, pre‐paid, and tradeable ownership contracts with maturities often exceeding 700 years. Freeholds are infinite‐maturity ownership contracts. The price difference between leaseholds with extremely‐long maturities and freeholds reflects the present value of a claim to the freehold after leasehold expiry, and is thus a direct empirical measure of the transversality condition. We estimate this price difference, and find no evidence of failures of the transversality condition in housing markets in the U.K. and Singapore, even during periods when a sizable bubble was regularly thought to be present.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: A Model of the International Monetary System*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We propose a simple model of the international monetary system. We study the world supply and demand for reserve assets denominated in different currencies under a variety of scenarios: a hegemon versus a multipolar world; abundant versus scarce reserve assets; and a gold exchange standard versus a floating rate system. We rationalize the Triffin dilemma, which posits the fundamental instability of the system, as well as the common prediction regarding the natural and beneficial emergence of a multipolar world, the Nurkse warning that a multipolar world is more unstable than a hegemon world, and the Keynesian argument that a scarcity of reserve assets under a gold standard or at the zero lower bound is recessionary. Our analysis is both positive and normative.</jats:p>
research_question: How do different configurations of the international monetary system (hegemon vs multipolar, abundant vs scarce reserve assets, gold exchange standard vs floating rates) affect the world supply and demand for reserve assets denominated in different currencies?
answer: The model rationalizes several key economic phenomena: the Triffin dilemma demonstrates fundamental system instability, multipolar worlds can be more unstable than hegemon-dominated systems (supporting the Nurkse warning), and scarcity of reserve assets under gold standards or at zero lower bound conditions creates recessionary pressures (confirming the Keynesian argument).
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified theoretical framework that reconciles and explains several competing historical perspectives on international monetary systems, including the Triffin dilemma, Nurkse's stability concerns about multipolar systems, and Keynesian views on reserve asset scarcity, while offering both positive analysis of how these systems work and normative evaluation of their desirability.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: Reply to “Rational Bubbles in UK Housing Markets”
abstract: <jats:p>In Giglio, Maggiori, and Stroebel (2016), we propose and implement a new test for classic rational bubbles. Such bubbles derive their value from each agent's rational expectation of being able to resell the bubble claims to the next agent. Backward induction ensures that classic rational bubbles can only exist on infinite‐maturity assets. Our empirical exercise shows that infinite‐maturity claims and 999‐year claims for otherwise identical housing assets trade at the same price, and thus rules out the presence of classic rational bubbles. Domeij and Ellingsen (DE) informally propose an alternative equilibrium of a bubble that they claim is consistent with our empirical findings. DE's bubble relies on information frictions such that market participants are unaware of the bubble. Our paper clearly excluded this type of bubble from the scope of our test, and DE's note thus has no implications for the validity of our test. Instead, DE's bubble simply represents one of many possible examples of bubbles on which our test was explicitly silent.</jats:p>
research_question: How to respond to Domeij and Ellingsen's critique of the test for classic rational bubbles in housing markets?
answer: Domeij and Ellingsen's proposed alternative bubble equilibrium based on information frictions is outside the scope of the original test for classic rational bubbles, and therefore does not invalidate the test's validity or findings.
positioning_statement: This paper defends the original methodology by clarifying that it was designed specifically to test for classic rational bubbles (which require rational expectations of resale and can only exist on infinite-maturity assets), while explicitly excluding bubbles based on information frictions that DE proposes, thus maintaining that DE's critique does not affect the validity of their test.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: International Currencies  and Capital Allocation
abstract: We establish currency as an important factor shaping global portfolios. Using a new security-level data set, we demonstrate that investor holdings are biased toward their own currencies to such an extent that countries typically hold most of the foreign-debt securities denominated in their currency. While large firms issue in foreign currency and borrow from foreigners, most firms issue only in local currency and do not directly access foreign capital. These patterns hold broadly across countries except for the United States, as foreign investors hold significant shares of US dollar bonds. The share of dollar-denominated cross-border holdings surged after 2008.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: Five Facts about Beliefs and Portfolios
abstract: <jats:p> We study a newly designed survey administered to a large panel of wealthy retail investors. The survey elicits beliefs that are important for macroeconomics and finance, and matches respondents with administrative data on their portfolio composition, their trading activity, and their login behavior. We establish five facts inthese data. (i) Beliefs are reflected in portfolio allocations. The sensitivity of portfolios to beliefs is small on average, but varies significantly with investor wealth, attention, trading frequency, and confidence. (ii) Belief changes do not predict when investors trade, but conditional on trading, they affect both the direction and the magnitude of trades. (iii) Beliefs are mostly characterized by large and persistent individual heterogeneity. Demographic characteristics explain only asmall part of why some individuals are optimistic and some are pessimistic. (iv) Expected cash flow growth and expected returns are positively related, both within and across investors. (v) Expected returns and the subjective probability of rare disasters are negatively related, both within and across investors. These five facts provide useful guidance for the design of macro-finance models. (JEL D83, E23, G11, G12, G41, G51) </jats:p>
research_question: How do investor beliefs relate to portfolio allocations, trading behavior, and what are the key characteristics of these beliefs among wealthy retail investors?
answer: Five key findings: (1) beliefs are reflected in portfolio allocations with sensitivity varying by investor characteristics, (2) belief changes don't predict when investors trade but affect trading direction and magnitude, (3) beliefs show large persistent individual heterogeneity poorly explained by demographics, (4) expected cash flow growth and returns are positively related, and (5) expected returns and subjective disaster probabilities are negatively related.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel empirical evidence by matching survey data on investor beliefs with administrative portfolio data from wealthy retail investors, establishing stylized facts that can guide the design of macro-finance models.

author: Matthew Elliott
title: Financial Networks and Contagion
abstract: <jats:p> We study cascades of failures in a network of interdependent financial organizations: how discontinuous changes in asset values (e.g., defaults and shutdowns) trigger further failures, and how this depends on network structure. Integration (greater dependence on counterparties) and diversification (more counterparties per organization) have different, nonmonotonic effects on the extent of cascades. Diversification connects the network initially, permitting cascades to travel; but as it increases further, organizations are better insured against one another's failures. Integration also faces trade-offs: increased dependence on other organizations versus less sensitivity to own investments. Finally, we illustrate the model with data on European debt cross-holdings. (JEL D85, F15, F34, F36, F65, G15, G32, G33, G38) </jats:p>
research_question: How do cascades of failures propagate through a network of interdependent financial organizations, and how does this depend on network structure?
answer: Integration and diversification have different, nonmonotonic effects on cascade extent. Diversification initially connects the network enabling cascade travel, but higher diversification provides better insurance against failures. Integration creates trade-offs between increased dependence on counterparties versus reduced sensitivity to own investments.
positioning_statement: This paper studies financial contagion through network cascades by examining how discontinuous changes in asset values trigger further failures, focusing specifically on the structural effects of integration and diversification in financial networks.

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: Internationalizing Like China
abstract: <jats:p> We empirically characterize how China is internationalizing its bond market by staggering the entry of different types of foreign investors into its domestic market and propose a dynamic reputation model to explain this strategy. Our framework rationalizes China’s strategy as trying to build credibility as a safe issuer while reducing the cost of capital flight. We use our framework to shed light on China’s response to episodes of capital outflows. (JEL E44, F38, G12, G15, G23, O16, P34) </jats:p>
research_question: How is China internationalizing its bond market and what explains the strategy of staggering entry of different types of foreign investors?
answer: China's strategy of staggered entry of foreign investors into its domestic bond market is a rational approach to build credibility as a safe issuer while reducing the cost of capital flight, as explained by a dynamic reputation model.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing both empirical characterization of China's unique bond market internationalization approach and proposing a novel dynamic reputation model framework to explain this strategy, offering insights into China's capital market liberalization that can inform understanding of similar emerging market strategies.

author: Matthew Elliott
title: A Network Approach to Public Goods

author: Matteo Maggiori
title: Redrawing the Map of Global Capital Flows: The Role of Cross-Border Financing and Tax Havens
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Global firms finance themselves through foreign subsidiaries, often shell companies in tax havens, which obscures their true economic location in official statistics. We associate the universe of traded securities issued by firms in tax havens with their issuer's ultimate parent and restate bilateral investment positions to better reflect the financial linkages connecting countries around the world. Bilateral portfolio investment from developed countries to firms in large emerging markets is dramatically larger than previously thought. The national accounts of the United States, for example, understate the U.S. position in Chinese firms by nearly $600 billion. Further, we demonstrate how offshore issuance in tax havens affects our understanding of the currency composition of external portfolio liabilities and the nature of foreign direct investment. Finally, we provide additional restatements of bilateral investment positions, including one based on the geographic distribution of sales.</jats:p>
research_question: How does cross-border financing through shell companies in tax havens distort official statistics on global capital flows and bilateral investment positions?
answer: Official statistics dramatically understate bilateral portfolio investment from developed countries to large emerging markets due to offshore financing structures, with the U.S. position in Chinese firms understated by nearly $600 billion, and this distortion also affects understanding of currency composition of external liabilities and foreign direct investment patterns.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in existing literature by providing a comprehensive methodology to restate bilateral investment positions by tracing securities issued through tax haven subsidiaries back to their ultimate parent companies, thereby revealing the true economic linkages that are obscured in official national accounts and statistics.

author: Matthew Elliott
title: How Sharing Information Can Garble Experts' Advice
abstract: <jats:p> We model the strategic provision of advice in environments where a principal's optimal action depends on an unobserved, binary state of interest. Experts receive signals about the state and each recommends an action. The principal and all experts dislike making errors in their decision and recommendations, respectively, but may have different costs of different errors. Is it in the principal's interest to let experts share information? Although sharing improves experts' ability to avoid errors, we identify a simple environment in which any principal, regardless of how he trades off the different errors, is worse off if he permits information sharing. </jats:p>
research_question: Is it in the principal's interest to let experts share information when providing strategic advice about an unobserved binary state?
answer: No - there exists a simple environment where any principal, regardless of how they trade off different types of errors, is worse off if they permit information sharing among experts, despite sharing improving experts' ability to avoid errors.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom that information sharing among advisors is beneficial by identifying conditions where strategic considerations make information sharing harmful to the decision-maker, contributing to the literature on strategic advice and information aggregation.

author: Matthew Elliott
title: Supply Network Formation and Fragility
abstract: <jats:p>We model the production of complex goods in a large supply network. Each firm sources several essential inputs through relationships with other firms. Individual supply relationships are at risk of idiosyncratic failure, which threatens to disrupt production. To protect against this, firms multisource inputs and strategically invest to make relationships stronger, trading off the cost of investment against the benefits of increased robustness. A supply network is called fragile if aggregate output is very sensitive to small aggregate shocks. We show that supply networks of intermediate productivity are fragile in equilibrium, even though this is always inefficient. The endogenous configuration of supply networks provides a new channel for the powerful amplification of shocks. (JEL D21, G31, L14)</jats:p>
research_question: How do firms form supply networks when facing idiosyncratic relationship failures, and under what conditions do these networks become fragile to aggregate shocks?
answer: Supply networks of intermediate productivity are fragile in equilibrium, meaning aggregate output is very sensitive to small aggregate shocks, even though this fragility is always inefficient.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a new channel for understanding shock amplification through the endogenous configuration of supply networks, contributing to the literature on supply network formation and systemic risk by showing how strategic firm decisions about multisourcing and relationship investment can lead to inefficient fragility.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Take-Up and Targeting: Experimental Evidence from SNAP
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a framework for welfare analysis of interventions designed to increase take-up of social safety net programs in the presence of potential behavioral biases. We calibrate the key parameters using a randomized field experiment in which 30,000 elderly individuals not enrolled in—but likely eligible for—the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) are either provided with information that they are likely eligible, provided with this information and offered assistance in applying, or are in a “status quo” control group. Only 6% of the control group enrolls in SNAP over the next nine months, compared to 11% of the Information Only group and 18% of the Information Plus Assistance group. The individuals who apply or enroll in response to either intervention have higher net income and are less sick than the average enrollee in the control group. We present evidence consistent with the existence of optimization frictions that are greater for needier individuals, which suggests that the poor targeting properties of the interventions reduce their welfare benefits.</jats:p>
research_question: How do interventions designed to increase take-up of social safety net programs affect welfare when there are potential behavioral biases, and what are the targeting implications of such interventions?
answer: Information-based interventions increase SNAP enrollment (from 6% to 11-18%) but exhibit poor targeting properties, as they primarily benefit higher-income and healthier individuals rather than the neediest. The existence of optimization frictions that disproportionately affect needier individuals reduces the welfare benefits of these interventions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a welfare analysis framework for take-up interventions that accounts for behavioral biases and targeting effects, using experimental evidence to show that standard interventions may not effectively reach the most vulnerable populations due to differential optimization frictions.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Should Unemployment Insurance Vary with the Unemployment Rate? Theory and Evidence

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Duration Dependence and Labor Market Conditions: Evidence from a Field Experiment*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article studies the role of employer behavior in generating “negative duration dependence”—the adverse effect of a longer unemployment spell—by sending fictitious résumés to real job postings in 100 U.S. cities. Our results indicate that the likelihood of receiving a callback for an interview significantly decreases with the length of a worker’s unemployment spell, with the majority of this decline occurring during the first eight months. We explore how this effect varies with local labor market conditions and find that duration dependence is stronger when the local labor market is tighter. This result is consistent with the prediction of a broad class of screening models in which employers use the unemployment spell length as a signal of unobserved productivity and recognize that this signal is less informative in weak labor markets.</jats:p>
research_question: How does employer behavior contribute to negative duration dependence in unemployment, and how does this effect vary with local labor market conditions?
answer: The likelihood of receiving a callback for an interview significantly decreases with the length of unemployment spell (with most decline occurring in the first eight months), and this duration dependence is stronger when local labor markets are tighter.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on screening models by providing empirical evidence that employers use unemployment spell length as a signal of unobserved productivity, and that employers recognize this signal is less informative in weak labor markets, consistent with predictions from a broad class of screening models.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Public Health Insurance, Labor Supply, and Employment Lock *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the effect of public health insurance on labor supply by exploiting a large public health insurance disenrollment. In 2005, approximately 170,000 Tennessee residents abruptly lost Medicaid coverage. Using both across- and within-state variation in exposure to the disenrollment, we estimate large increases in labor supply, primarily along the extensive margin. The increased employment is concentrated among individuals working at least 20 hours a week and receiving private, employer-provided health insurance. We explore the dynamic effects of the disenrollment and find an immediate increase in job search behavior and a steady rise in both employment and health insurance coverage following the disenrollment. Our results are consistent with a significant degree of “employment lock”—workers who are employed primarily to secure private health insurance coverage.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of public health insurance on labor supply?
answer: Public health insurance significantly reduces labor supply - when approximately 170,000 Tennessee residents lost Medicaid coverage in 2005, there were large increases in labor supply primarily along the extensive margin, with increased employment concentrated among individuals working at least 20 hours a week and receiving private, employer-provided health insurance.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on public health insurance and labor supply by exploiting a unique natural experiment (Tennessee's large Medicaid disenrollment) and providing evidence for 'employment lock' - the phenomenon where workers are employed primarily to secure private health insurance coverage, which complements existing research on job lock but focuses on the reverse mechanism.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Consumer-Financed Fiscal Stimulus: Evidence from Digital Coupons in China
abstract: <jats:p> In 2020, local governments in China began issuing digital coupons to stimulate spending in targeted categories such as restaurants and supermarkets. Using data from a large e-commerce platform and a bunching estimation approach, we find that the coupons caused large increases in spending of 3.1–3.2 yuan per yuan spent by the government. The large spending responses do not come from substitution away from nontargeted spending categories or from short-run intertemporal substitution. To rationalize these results, we develop a dynamic consumption model showing how coupons' minimum spending thresholds create temporary notches that lead to large spending responses. (JEL D15, E21, H72, L81, O18, P25, P36) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effectiveness of digital coupons issued by local governments in China as a fiscal stimulus tool for increasing consumer spending in targeted categories?
answer: Digital coupons caused large increases in spending of 3.1-3.2 yuan per yuan spent by the government, with these large spending responses not coming from substitution away from nontargeted categories or short-run intertemporal substitution, but rather from temporary notches created by minimum spending thresholds.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the fiscal stimulus literature by examining a novel consumer-financed approach through digital coupons, developing a dynamic consumption model that explains how minimum spending thresholds create temporary notches leading to large spending responses, which differs from traditional fiscal stimulus mechanisms.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Lives Versus Livelihoods: The Impact of the Great Recession on Mortality and Welfare
abstract:
<jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We leverage spatial variation in the severity of the Great Recession across the United States to examine its impact on mortality and explore the quantitative implications. We estimate that an increase in the unemployment rate of the magnitude of the Great Recession reduces the average annual age-adjusted mortality rate by 2.3%, with effects persisting for at least 10 years. Mortality reductions appear across causes of death and are concentrated in the half of the population with a high school degree or less. We estimate similar percentage reductions in mortality at all ages, with declines in elderly mortality thus responsible for about three-quarters of the total mortality reduction. Recession-induced mortality declines are driven primarily by external effects of reduced aggregate economic activity on mortality, and reduced air pollution appears to be a quantitatively important mechanism. Incorporating our estimates of procyclical mortality into a standard macroeconomic framework substantially reduces the welfare costs of recessions, particularly for people with less education, and at older ages.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of the Great Recession on mortality rates and what are the quantitative welfare implications of this relationship?
answer: The Great Recession reduced average annual age-adjusted mortality rates by 2.3% for unemployment rate increases of that magnitude, with effects lasting at least 10 years. These mortality reductions were concentrated among those with high school education or less, occurred across all causes of death, and were primarily driven by external effects of reduced economic activity (particularly reduced air pollution). When incorporated into macroeconomic frameworks, these mortality improvements substantially reduce the estimated welfare costs of recessions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on the relationship between economic conditions and health outcomes by providing new quantitative evidence on recession-mortality relationships and demonstrating how incorporating procyclical mortality effects into standard macroeconomic welfare analysis significantly alters our understanding of recession costs, particularly for less educated and older populations.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Approaches to Estimating the Health State Dependence of the Utility Function

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Housing Booms and Busts, Labor Market Opportunities, and College Attendance
abstract: <jats:p> We study how the recent housing boom and bust affected college enrollment during the 2000s. We exploit cross-city variation in local housing booms, which improved labor market opportunities for young men and women. We find that the boom lowered college enrollment, with effects concentrated at two-year colleges. The decline in enrollment during the boom was generally reversed during the bust; however, attainment remains persistently low for particular cohorts, suggesting that reduced educational attainment is an enduring effect of the recent housing cycle. The housing boom can account for approximately 25 percent of the recent slowdown in college attainment. (JEL I23, I25, J24, J31, R21, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How did the recent housing boom and bust affect college enrollment during the 2000s?
answer: The housing boom lowered college enrollment (particularly at two-year colleges) by improving labor market opportunities for young people, and while enrollment generally recovered during the bust, some cohorts experienced persistently low educational attainment. The housing boom accounts for approximately 25 percent of the recent slowdown in college attainment.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding the relationship between local economic conditions and educational decisions by exploiting cross-city variation in housing booms as a natural experiment to identify how labor market opportunities affect college enrollment choices.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: The Economic Consequences of Hospital Admissions
abstract: <jats:p> We use an event study approach to examine the economic consequences of hospital admissions for adults in two datasets: survey data from the Health and Retirement Study, and hospitalization data linked to credit reports. For non-elderly adults with health insurance, hospital admissions increase out-of-pocket medical spending, unpaid medical bills, and bankruptcy, and reduce earnings, income, access to credit, and consumer borrowing. The earnings decline is substantial compared to the out-of-pocket spending increase, and is minimally insured prior to age-eligibility for Social Security Retirement Income. Relative to the insured non-elderly, the uninsured non-elderly experience much larger increases in unpaid medical bills and bankruptcy rates following a hospital admission. Hospital admissions trigger fewer than 5 percent of all bankruptcies in our sample. (JEL D14, G22, I11, I13) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the economic consequences of hospital admissions for adults?
answer: Hospital admissions cause significant economic harm even for insured non-elderly adults, including increased out-of-pocket medical spending, unpaid medical bills, and bankruptcy, along with reduced earnings, income, access to credit, and consumer borrowing. The earnings decline is substantial compared to out-of-pocket spending increases and is minimally insured before Social Security eligibility. Uninsured adults experience much larger increases in unpaid medical bills and bankruptcy rates, though hospital admissions trigger fewer than 5 percent of all bankruptcies.
positioning_statement: This paper uses an event study approach with two complementary datasets (Health and Retirement Study survey data and hospitalization data linked to credit reports) to provide comprehensive evidence on the economic consequences of hospital admissions, examining both insured and uninsured populations and measuring effects across multiple economic outcomes including spending, earnings, credit access, and bankruptcy.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: The Effect of Wealth on Individual and Household Labor Supply: Evidence from Swedish Lotteries
abstract: <jats:p> We study the effect of wealth on labor supply using the randomized assignment of monetary prizes in a large sample of Swedish lottery players. Winning a lottery prize modestly reduces earnings, with the reduction being immediate, persistent, and quite similar by age, education, and sex. A calibrated dynamic model implies lifetime marginal propensities to earn out of unearned income from −0.17 at age 20 to −0.04 at age 60, and labor supply elasticities in the lower range of previously reported estimates. The earnings response is stronger for winners than their spouses, which is inconsistent with unitary household labor supply models. (JEL D14, J22, J31) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of wealth on individual and household labor supply?
answer: Winning a lottery prize modestly reduces earnings, with the reduction being immediate, persistent, and similar across demographic groups. The study finds lifetime marginal propensities to earn out of unearned income ranging from −0.17 at age 20 to −0.04 at age 60, and labor supply elasticities in the lower range of previously reported estimates.
positioning_statement: This paper uses the randomized assignment of monetary prizes in Swedish lotteries to provide causal evidence on wealth effects on labor supply, contributing to the literature by offering cleaner identification than previous studies and testing unitary household labor supply models by comparing responses between winners and their spouses.

author: Matthew Rognlie
title: Aggregate Demand and the Top 1 Percent
abstract: <jats:p> There has been a large rise in US top income inequality since the 1980s. We merge a widely studied model of the Pareto tail of labor incomes with a canonical model of consumption and savings to study the consequences of this increase for aggregate demand. Our model suggests that the rise of the top 1 percent may have led to a large increase in desired savings and can explain a 0.45pp to 0.85pp decline in long-run real interest rates. This effect arises from both a wealth effect at the top and increased precautionary savings from declines lower in the income distribution. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the consequences of the large rise in US top income inequality since the 1980s for aggregate demand?
answer: The rise of the top 1 percent led to a large increase in desired savings and can explain a 0.45pp to 0.85pp decline in long-run real interest rates, driven by both wealth effects at the top and increased precautionary savings from income declines lower in the distribution.
positioning_statement: This paper merges a widely studied model of the Pareto tail of labor incomes with a canonical model of consumption and savings to study inequality's impact on aggregate demand.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Salience and Taxation with Imperfect Competition
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper studies commodity taxation in a model featuring heterogeneous consumers, imperfect competition, and tax salience. We derive new formulas for the incidence and marginal excess burden of commodity taxation highlighting interactions between tax salience and market structure. We estimate the necessary inputs to the formulas by using Nielsen Retail Scanner and Consumer Panel data covering grocery stores and households in the U.S. and detailed sales tax data. We estimate a large amount of pass-through of taxes onto consumer prices and find that households respond more to changes in prices than taxes. We also estimate significant heterogeneity in tax salience across households. We calibrate our new formulas using these results and conclude that essentially all of the incidence of sales taxes falls on consumers, and the marginal excess burden of taxation is larger than estimates based on standard formulas that ignore imperfect competition and tax salience.</jats:p>
research_question: How do tax salience and imperfect competition interact to affect the incidence and marginal excess burden of commodity taxation?
answer: Essentially all of the incidence of sales taxes falls on consumers, and the marginal excess burden of taxation is larger than estimates based on standard formulas that ignore imperfect competition and tax salience, with significant heterogeneity in tax salience across households and large pass-through of taxes onto consumer prices.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing commodity taxation literature by incorporating both tax salience and imperfect competition into the analysis, deriving new formulas that account for these factors which are ignored in standard formulas used in previous research.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: The Economic Consequences of Bankruptcy Reform
abstract: <jats:p> A more generous consumer bankruptcy system provides greater insurance against financial risks but may also raise the cost of credit. We study this trade-off using the 2005 Bankruptcy Abuse Prevention and Consumer Protection Act (BAPCPA), which increased the costs of filing for bankruptcy. We identify the effects of BAPCPA on borrowing costs using variation in the effects of the reform across credit scores. We find that a one-percentage-point reduction in bankruptcy filing risk decreased credit card interest rates by 70–90 basis points.
