Conversely, BAPCPA reduced the insurance value of bankruptcy, with uninsured hospitalizations 70 percent less likely to obtain bankruptcy relief after the reform. (JEL D18, G15, I13, K35) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the trade-off between insurance benefits and credit costs in consumer bankruptcy systems, specifically how does making bankruptcy less generous affect borrowing costs and financial insurance?
answer: Making bankruptcy less generous (through BAPCPA) reduced credit card interest rates by 70-90 basis points for each one-percentage-point reduction in bankruptcy filing risk, but also significantly reduced the insurance value of bankruptcy, with uninsured hospitalizations becoming 70 percent less likely to obtain bankruptcy relief.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on consumer bankruptcy by empirically quantifying the trade-off between the insurance benefits of a generous bankruptcy system and its effects on credit costs, using the 2005 BAPCPA reform as a natural experiment with variation across credit scores to identify causal effects.

author: Matthew Notowidigdo
title: Financial Networks and Contagion
abstract: <jats:p> We study cascades of failures in a network of interdependent financial organizations: how discontinuous changes in asset values (e.g., defaults and shutdowns) trigger further failures, and how this depends on network structure. Integration (greater dependence on counterparties) and diversification (more counterparties per organization) have different, nonmonotonic effects on the extent of cascades. Diversification connects the network initially, permitting cascades to travel; but as it increases further, organizations are better insured against one another's failures. Integration also faces trade-offs: increased dependence on other organizations versus less sensitivity to own investments. Finally, we illustrate the model with data on European debt cross-holdings. (JEL D85, F15, F34, F36, F65, G15, G32, G33, G38) </jats:p>
research_question: How do cascades of failures propagate through a network of interdependent financial organizations, and how does this depend on network structure?
answer: Integration and diversification have different, nonmonotonic effects on cascade extent. Diversification initially connects the network enabling cascade travel, but higher diversification provides better insurance against failures. Integration creates trade-offs between increased dependence on counterparties versus reduced sensitivity to own investments.
positioning_statement: This paper studies financial contagion through network cascades by examining how discontinuous changes in asset values trigger further failures, focusing specifically on the structural effects of integration and diversification in financial networks.

author: Matthew Rognlie

author: Matthew Rognlie
title: Using the Sequence‐Space Jacobian to Solve and Estimate Heterogeneous‐Agent Models
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a general and highly efficient method for solving and estimating general equilibrium heterogeneous‐agent models with aggregate shocks in discrete time. Our approach relies on the rapid computation of<jats:italic>sequence‐space Jacobians</jats:italic>—the derivatives of perfect‐foresight equilibrium mappings between aggregate sequences around the steady state. Our main contribution is a fast algorithm for calculating Jacobians for a large class of heterogeneous‐agent problems. We combine this algorithm with a systematic approach to composing and inverting Jacobians to solve for general equilibrium impulse responses. We obtain a rapid procedure for likelihood‐based estimation and computation of nonlinear perfect‐foresight transitions. We apply our methods to three canonical heterogeneous‐agent models: a neoclassical model, a New Keynesian model with one asset, and a New Keynesian model with two assets.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a general and highly efficient computational method for solving and estimating general equilibrium heterogeneous-agent models with aggregate shocks in discrete time?
answer: The paper develops a fast algorithm based on sequence-space Jacobians that enables rapid computation of derivatives of perfect-foresight equilibrium mappings, which can be systematically composed and inverted to solve for general equilibrium impulse responses and perform likelihood-based estimation.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses computational challenges in heterogeneous-agent modeling by proposing a novel methodological approach that significantly improves efficiency compared to existing methods, demonstrated through application to three canonical models in the literature.

author: Melanie Morten
title: Migration and Informal Insurance: Evidence from a Randomized Controlled Trial and a Structural Model
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We document that an experimental intervention offering transport subsidies for poor rural households to migrate seasonally in Bangladesh improved risk sharing. A theoretical model of endogenous migration and risk sharing shows that the effect of subsidizing migration depends on the underlying economic environment. If migration is risky, a temporary subsidy can induce an improvement in risk sharing and enable profitable migration. We estimate the model and find that the migration experiment increased welfare by 12.9%. Counterfactual analysis suggests that a permanent, rather than temporary, decline in migration costs in the same environment would result in a reduction in risk sharing.</jats:p>
research_question: How does subsidizing seasonal migration affect informal insurance and risk sharing among poor rural households?
answer: The experimental transport subsidies for seasonal migration improved risk sharing among poor rural households and increased welfare by 12.9%, though the effect depends on whether migration subsidies are temporary or permanent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by combining experimental evidence with structural modeling to show that the relationship between migration and risk sharing depends on the underlying economic environment, specifically whether migration is risky and whether cost reductions are temporary or permanent.

author: Matthew Rognlie
title: New Pricing Models, Same Old Phillips Curves?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that in a broad class of menu cost models, the first-order dynamics of aggregate inflation in response to arbitrary shocks to aggregate costs are nearly the same as in Calvo models with suitably chosen Calvo adjustment frequencies. We first prove that the canonical menu cost model is first-order equivalent to a mixture of two time-dependent models, which reflect the extensive and intensive margins of price adjustment. We then show numerically that in any plausible parameterization, this mixture is well approximated by a single Calvo model. This close numerical fit carries over to other standard specifications of menu cost models. Thus, for shocks that are not too large, the Phillips curve for a menu cost model looks like the New Keynesian Phillips curve, but with a higher slope.</jats:p>
research_question: Do menu cost models generate fundamentally different aggregate inflation dynamics compared to Calvo models, or do they produce similar Phillips curve relationships?
answer: Menu cost models produce nearly identical first-order inflation dynamics to Calvo models with appropriately chosen adjustment frequencies, resulting in Phillips curves that look like the New Keynesian Phillips curve but with a higher slope.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges the gap between two major pricing model frameworks in macroeconomics by demonstrating that despite their different microeconomic foundations, menu cost models and Calvo models yield remarkably similar aggregate outcomes, suggesting that the choice between these modeling approaches may be less consequential for aggregate analysis than previously thought.

author: Melanie Morten
title: Temporary Migration and Endogenous Risk Sharing in Village India
abstract: When people can self-insure via migration, they may have less need for informal risk sharing. At the same time, informal insurance may reduce the need to migrate. To understand the joint determination of migration and risk sharing, I study a dynamic model of risk sharing with limited commitment frictions and endogenous temporary migration. First, I characterize the model. Second, I structurally estimate the model using the new ICRISAT panel from rural India. Third, I introduce a rural employment scheme. The policy reduces migration and decreases risk sharing, lowering the welfare gain of the policy.

author: Melanie Morten
title: The Aggregate Productivity Effects of Internal Migration: Evidence from Indonesia
abstract: We estimate the aggregate productivity gains from reducing barriers to internal labor migration in Indonesia, accounting for worker selection and spatial differences in human capital. We distinguish between movement costs, which mean workers will move only if they expect higher wages, and amenity differences, which mean some locations must pay more to attract workers. We find modest but important aggregate impacts. We estimate a 22 percent increase in labor productivity from removing all barriers. Reducing migration costs to the US level, a high-mobility benchmark, leads to a 7.1 percent productivity boost. These figures hide substantial heterogeneity. The origin population that benefits most sees a 104 percent increase in average earnings from a complete barrier removal, or a 25 percent gain from moving to the US benchmark.

author: Matthew Rognlie
title: Financial Networks and Contagion
abstract: <jats:p> We study cascades of failures in a network of interdependent financial organizations: how discontinuous changes in asset values (e.g., defaults and shutdowns) trigger further failures, and how this depends on network structure. Integration (greater dependence on counterparties) and diversification (more counterparties per organization) have different, nonmonotonic effects on the extent of cascades. Diversification connects the network initially, permitting cascades to travel; but as it increases further, organizations are better insured against one another's failures. Integration also faces trade-offs: increased dependence on other organizations versus less sensitivity to own investments. Finally, we illustrate the model with data on European debt cross-holdings. (JEL D85, F15, F34, F36, F65, G15, G32, G33, G38) </jats:p>
research_question: How do cascades of failures propagate through a network of interdependent financial organizations, and how does this depend on network structure?
answer: Integration and diversification have different, nonmonotonic effects on cascade extent. Diversification initially connects the network enabling cascade travel, but higher diversification provides better insurance against failures. Integration creates trade-offs between increased dependence on counterparties versus reduced sensitivity to own investments.
positioning_statement: This paper studies financial contagion through network cascades by examining how discontinuous changes in asset values trigger further failures, focusing specifically on the structural effects of integration and diversification in financial networks.

author: Melissa Dell
title: The Violent Consequences of Trade-Induced Worker Displacement in Mexico
abstract: <jats:p> Mexican manufacturing job loss induced by competition with China increases cocaine trafficking and violence, particularly in municipalities with transnational criminal organizations. When it becomes more lucrative to traffic drugs because changes in local labor markets lower the opportunity cost of criminal employment, criminal organizations plausibly fight to gain control. The evidence supports a Becker-style model in which the elasticity between legitimate and criminal employment is particularly high where criminal organizations lower illicit job search costs, where the drug trade implies higher pecuniary returns to violent crime, and where unemployment disproportionately affects low-skilled men. (JEL F16, J24, J64, K42, L60, O15, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: How does trade-induced worker displacement in Mexican manufacturing affect cocaine trafficking and violence?
answer: Mexican manufacturing job loss induced by competition with China increases cocaine trafficking and violence, particularly in municipalities with transnational criminal organizations, as changes in local labor markets lower the opportunity cost of criminal employment and criminal organizations fight to gain control.
positioning_statement: The paper supports a Becker-style model of crime, extending it to show that the elasticity between legitimate and criminal employment is particularly high in specific conditions: where criminal organizations lower illicit job search costs, where the drug trade implies higher pecuniary returns to violent crime, and where unemployment disproportionately affects low-skilled men.

author: Melissa Dell
title: The Development Effects of the Extractive Colonial Economy: The Dutch Cultivation System in Java
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Colonial powers typically organized economic activity in the colonies to maximize their economic returns. While the literature has emphasized long-run negative economic impacts via institutional quality, the changes in economic organization implemented to spur production historically could also directly influence economic organization in the long-run, exerting countervailing effects. We examine these in the context of the Dutch Cultivation System, the integrated industrial and agricultural system for producing sugar that formed the core of the Dutch colonial enterprise in 19th century Java. We show that areas close to where the Dutch established sugar factories in the mid-19th century are today more industrialized, have better infrastructure, are more educated, and are richer than nearby counterfactual locations that would have been similarly suitable for colonial sugar factories. We also show, using a spatial regression discontinuity design on the catchment areas around each factory, that villages forced to grow sugar cane have more village-owned land and also have more schools and substantially higher education levels, both historically and today. The results suggest that the economic structures implemented by colonizers to facilitate production can continue to promote economic activity in the long run, and we discuss the contexts where such effects are most likely to be important.</jats:p>
research_question: How did the Dutch Cultivation System's economic organization in 19th century Java affect long-run economic development, particularly in terms of industrialization, infrastructure, education, and wealth?
answer: Areas close to Dutch sugar factories established in the mid-19th century are today more industrialized, have better infrastructure, are more educated, and richer than similar locations. Villages forced to grow sugar cane have more village-owned land, more schools, and substantially higher education levels both historically and today.
positioning_statement: While existing literature emphasizes long-run negative economic impacts of colonial rule via institutional quality, this paper argues that changes in economic organization implemented by colonizers to spur production could also directly influence long-run economic organization, creating countervailing positive effects that have been understudied.

author: Melissa Dell
title: Trafficking Networks and the Mexican Drug War
abstract: <jats:p> Drug trade-related violence has escalated dramatically in Mexico since 2007, and recent years have also witnessed large-scale efforts to combat trafficking, spearheaded by Mexico's conservative PAN party. This study examines the direct and spillover effects of Mexican policy toward the drug trade. Regression discontinuity estimates show that drug-related violence increases substantially after close elections of PAN mayors. Empirical evidence suggests that the violence reflects rival traffickers' attempts to usurp territories after crackdowns have weakened incumbent criminals. Moreover, the study uses a network model of trafficking routes to show that PAN victories divert drug traffic, increasing violence along alternative drug routes. (JEL D72, D85, K42, O17, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the direct and spillover effects of Mexican policy toward the drug trade, particularly the impact of anti-trafficking efforts led by Mexico's conservative PAN party on drug-related violence?
answer: Drug-related violence increases substantially after close elections of PAN mayors due to rival traffickers attempting to usurp territories after crackdowns weaken incumbent criminals, and PAN victories divert drug traffic which increases violence along alternative drug routes.
positioning_statement: This study contributes to the literature on drug trade-related violence by providing empirical evidence of both direct and network spillover effects of anti-trafficking policies, using regression discontinuity methods and network models to analyze the unintended consequences of Mexico's escalated efforts to combat drug trafficking since 2007.

author: Melissa Dell
title: The Historical State, Local Collective Action, and Economic Development in Vietnam
abstract: This study examines how the historical state conditions long‐run development, using Vietnam as a laboratory. Northern Vietnam (Dai Viet) was ruled by a strong, centralized state in which the village was the fundamental administrative unit. Southern Vietnam was a peripheral tributary of the Khmer (Cambodian) Empire, which followed a patron‐client model with more informal, personalized power relations and no village intermediation. Using a regression discontinuity design, the study shows that areas exposed to Dai Viet administrative institutions for a longer period prior to French colonization have experienced better economic outcomes over the past 150 years. Rich historical data document that in Dai Viet villages, citizens have been better able to organize for public goods and redistribution through civil society and local government. We argue that institutionalized village governance crowded in local cooperation and that these norms persisted long after the original institutions disappeared.

author: Michael Callen
title: Institutional Corruption and Election Fraud: Evidence from a Field Experiment in Afghanistan
abstract: <jats:p> We investigate the relationship between political networks, weak institutions, and election fraud during the 2010 parliamentary election in Afghanistan combining: (i) data on political connections between candidates and election officials; (ii) a nationwide controlled evaluation of a novel monitoring technology; and (iii) direct measurements of aggregation fraud. We find considerable evidence of aggregation fraud in favor of connected candidates and that the announcement of a new monitoring technology reduced theft of election materials by about 60 percent and vote counts for connected candidates by about 25 percent. The results have implications for electoral competition and are potentially actionable for policymakers. (JEL C93, D02, D72, K42, O17) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between political networks, weak institutions, and election fraud, specifically how do political connections between candidates and election officials affect electoral outcomes?
answer: Political connections between candidates and election officials lead to significant aggregation fraud, with connected candidates benefiting from vote manipulation. The introduction of monitoring technology reduced theft of election materials by about 60 percent and vote counts for connected candidates by about 25 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing direct empirical evidence of the relationship between institutional corruption and election fraud through a unique combination of data on political connections, a controlled field experiment with monitoring technology, and direct measurements of aggregation fraud in a real electoral setting.

author: Michael Callen
title: Why Do Defaults Affect Behavior? Experimental Evidence from Afghanistan
abstract: <jats:p> We report on an experiment examining why default options impact behavior. By randomly assigning employees to different varieties of a salary-linked savings account, we find that default enrollment increases participation by 40 percentage points—an effect equivalent to providing a 50 percent matching incentive. We then use a series of experimental interventions to differentiate between explanations for the default effect, which we conclude is driven largely by present-biased preferences and the cognitive cost of thinking through different savings scenarios. Default assignment also changes employees’ attitudes toward saving, and makes them more likely to actively decide to save after the study concludes. (JEL C93, D14, D91, O12) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do default options impact behavior, specifically in the context of savings decisions?
answer: Default effects are driven largely by present-biased preferences and the cognitive cost of thinking through different savings scenarios. Default enrollment increases participation by 40 percentage points and also changes employees' attitudes toward saving, making them more likely to actively decide to save after the study concludes.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on default effects by using experimental interventions to differentiate between competing explanations for why defaults influence behavior, moving beyond simply documenting that defaults matter to understanding the underlying mechanisms.

author: Michael Callen
title: What Are the Headwaters of Formal Savings? Experimental Evidence from Sri Lanka
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The world’s poor are seeing a rapid expansion in access to formal savings accounts. What is the source of savings when households are connected to a formal account? We combine a high-frequency panel survey spanning two and a half years with an experiment in which a Sri Lankan bank used mobile Point-of-Service (POS) terminals to collect deposits directly from households each week. We find that the headwaters of formal savings lie in sacrificed leisure time: households work more, and improved savings options generate an increase in labour effort in both self-employment and in the wage market. The results suggest that the labour allocation channel is an important mechanism linking savings opportunities to income.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the source of savings when households are connected to a formal savings account?
answer: The headwaters of formal savings lie in sacrificed leisure time - households work more when given access to formal savings accounts, with improved savings options generating increased labor effort in both self-employment and wage market work.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the rapid expansion of formal savings account access among the world's poor by investigating the previously unexplored question of where the money for formal savings actually comes from, using experimental evidence to demonstrate that the labor allocation channel is an important mechanism linking savings opportunities to income.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Moller
title: Local Projections and VARs Estimate the Same Impulse Responses
abstract: <jats:p>We prove that local projections (LPs) and Vector Autoregressions (VARs) estimate the same impulse responses. This nonparametric result only requires unrestricted lag structures. We discuss several implications: (i) LP and VAR estimators are not conceptually separate procedures; instead, they are simply two dimension reduction techniques with common estimand but different finite‐sample properties. (ii) VAR‐based structural identification—including short‐run, long‐run, or sign restrictions—can equivalently be performed using LPs, and vice versa. (iii) Structural estimation with an instrument (proxy) can be carried out by ordering the instrument first in a recursive VAR, even under noninvertibility. (iv) Linear VARs are as robust to nonlinearities as linear LPs.</jats:p>
research_question: Do local projections (LPs) and Vector Autoregressions (VARs) estimate the same impulse responses?
answer: Yes, local projections and Vector Autoregressions estimate the same impulse responses under unrestricted lag structures, making them equivalent estimation procedures with the same estimand but different finite-sample properties.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that LP and VAR estimators are conceptually separate procedures, instead demonstrating they are equivalent dimension reduction techniques that can be used interchangeably for structural identification and estimation.

author: Michael Peters
title: Market Size and Spatial Growth—Evidence From Germany's Post‐War Population Expulsions
abstract: <jats:p>Virtually all theories of economic growth predict a positive relationship between population size and productivity. In this paper, I study a particular historical episode to provide direct evidence for the empirical relevance of such scale effects. In the aftermath of the Second World War, 8 million ethnic Germans were expelled from their domiciles in Eastern Europe and transferred to West Germany. This inflow increased the German population by almost 20%. Using variation across counties, I show that the settlement of refugees had large and persistent effects on the size of the local population, manufacturing employment, and income per capita. These findings are quantitatively consistent with an idea‐based model of spatial growth if population mobility is subject to frictions and productivity spillovers occur locally. The estimated model implies that the refugee settlement increased aggregate income per capita by about 12% after 25 years and triggered a process of industrialization in rural areas.</jats:p>
research_question: Do scale effects exist in economic growth, specifically whether population size has a positive relationship with productivity?
answer: The settlement of refugees had large and persistent positive effects on local population size, manufacturing employment, and income per capita, with the refugee settlement increasing aggregate income per capita by about 12% after 25 years and triggering industrialization in rural areas.
positioning_statement: This paper provides direct empirical evidence for scale effects predicted by virtually all theories of economic growth by studying a unique historical episode of Germany's post-war population expulsions, with findings that are quantitatively consistent with idea-based models of spatial growth when accounting for population mobility frictions and local productivity spillovers.

author: Michael Peters
title: Heterogeneous Markups, Growth, and Endogenous Misallocation
abstract: <jats:p>Markups vary systematically across firms and are a source of misallocation. This paper develops a tractable model of firm dynamics where firms' market power is endogenous and the distribution of markups emerges as an equilibrium outcome. Monopoly power is the result of a process of forward‐looking, risky accumulation: firms invest in productivity growth to increase markups in their existing products but are stochastically replaced by more efficient competitors. Creative destruction therefore has pro‐competitive effects because faster churn gives firms less time to accumulate market power. In an application to firm‐level data from Indonesia, the model predicts that, relative to the United States, misallocation is more severe and firms are substantially smaller. To explain these patterns, the model suggests an important role for frictions that prevent existing firms from entering new markets. Differences in entry costs for new firms are less important.</jats:p>
research_question: How do heterogeneous markups across firms emerge endogenously and contribute to misallocation, and what explains cross-country differences in firm size and misallocation patterns?
answer: Markups emerge endogenously from firms' forward-looking investment in productivity growth to build market power, but creative destruction limits this accumulation by replacing firms with more efficient competitors. Cross-country differences in misallocation and firm size are primarily explained by frictions preventing existing firms from entering new markets, rather than differences in entry costs for new firms.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a tractable model where firm market power and markup distributions are endogenous equilibrium outcomes, linking firm dynamics with misallocation through endogenous markup formation, and providing empirical application to explain cross-country differences in firm characteristics between Indonesia and the United States.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Moller
title: Local Projection Inference Is Simpler and More Robust Than You Think
abstract: <jats:p>Applied macroeconomists often compute confidence intervals for impulse responses using local projections, that is, direct linear regressions of future outcomes on current covariates. This paper proves that local projection inference robustly handles two issues that commonly arise in applications: highly persistent data and the estimation of impulse responses at long horizons. We consider local projections that control for lags of the variables in the regression. We show that lag‐augmented local projections with normal critical values are asymptotically valid uniformly over (i) both stationary and non‐stationary data, and also over (ii) a wide range of response horizons. Moreover, lag augmentation obviates the need to correct standard errors for serial correlation in the regression residuals. Hence, local projection inference is arguably both simpler than previously thought and more robust than standard autoregressive inference, whose validity is known to depend sensitively on the persistence of the data and on the length of the horizon.</jats:p>
research_question: How robust is local projection inference for computing confidence intervals for impulse responses, particularly when dealing with highly persistent data and long-horizon estimation?
answer: Lag-augmented local projections with normal critical values are asymptotically valid uniformly over both stationary and non-stationary data and across a wide range of response horizons, making local projection inference simpler and more robust than previously understood.
positioning_statement: This paper positions local projection inference as superior to standard autoregressive inference methods, arguing that it is both simpler than previously thought and more robust than existing approaches, whose validity depends sensitively on data persistence and horizon length.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Moller
title: Instrumental Variable Identification of Dynamic Variance Decompositions
abstract: Macroeconomists increasingly use external sources of exogenous variation for causal inference. However, unless such external instruments (proxies) capture the underlying shock without measurement error, existing methods are silent on the importance of that shock for macroeconomic fluctuations. We show that, in a general moving-average model with external instruments, variance decompositions for the instrumented shock are interval-identified, with informative bounds. Various additional restrictions guarantee point identification of both variance and historical decompositions. Unlike structural vector autoregression analysis, our methods do not require invertibility. Applied to US data, they give a tight upper bound on the importance of monetary shocks for inflation dynamics.

author: Michael Callen
title: Violence and Risk Preference: Experimental Evidence from Afghanistan
abstract: <jats:p> We investigate the relationship between violence and economic risk preferences in Afghanistan combining: (i) a two-part experimental procedure identifying risk preferences, violations of Expected Utility, and specific preferences for certainty; (ii) controlled recollection of fear based on established methods from psychology; and (iii) administrative violence data from precisely geocoded military records. We document a specific preference for certainty in violation of Expected Utility. The preference for certainty, which we term a Certainty Premium, is exacerbated by the combination of violent exposure and controlled fearful recollections. The results have implications for risk taking and are potentially actionable for policymakers and marketers. (JEL A12, C91, D12, D74, D81, O12, O17) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between violence exposure and economic risk preferences, specifically examining how violent experiences affect people's preference for certainty in economic decision-making?
answer: Violence exposure combined with fearful recollections leads to a specific preference for certainty that violates Expected Utility theory, termed a 'Certainty Premium' - people who have experienced violence show an exacerbated preference for certain outcomes over risky ones when fear is activated.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing experimental evidence of how violence affects risk preferences through a novel methodology that combines experimental economics procedures with psychological methods for controlled fear recollection and precise administrative violence data, documenting a specific violation of Expected Utility theory in the form of certainty preferences.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Moller
title: Standard Errors for Calibrated Parameters
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Calibration, the practice of choosing the parameters of a structural model to match certain empirical moments, can be viewed as minimum distance estimation. Existing standard error formulas for such estimators require a consistent estimate of the correlation structure of the empirical moments, which is often unavailable in practice. Instead, the variances of the individual empirical moments are usually readily estimable. Using only these variances, we derive conservative standard errors and confidence intervals for the structural parameters that are valid even under the worst-case correlation structure. In the over-identified case, we show that the moment weighting scheme that minimizes the worst-case estimator variance amounts to a moment selection problem with a simple solution. Finally, we develop tests of over-identifying or parameter restrictions. We apply our methods empirically to a model of menu cost pricing for multi-product firms and to a heterogeneous agent New Keynesian model.</jats:p>
research_question: How can researchers obtain valid standard errors and confidence intervals for calibrated parameters in structural models when the correlation structure of empirical moments is unknown or unavailable?
answer: The paper derives conservative standard errors and confidence intervals that are valid under worst-case correlation structures using only the variances of individual empirical moments, and shows that optimal moment weighting in over-identified cases reduces to a moment selection problem with a simple solution.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a practical limitation in existing minimum distance estimation methods for calibrated parameters, which require consistent estimates of moment correlation structures that are often unavailable in practice, by providing a robust alternative approach that works with readily available variance estimates.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Moller
title: Robust Empirical Bayes Confidence Intervals
abstract: <jats:p>We construct robust empirical Bayes confidence intervals (EBCIs) in a normal means problem. The intervals are centered at the usual linear empirical Bayes estimator, but use a critical value accounting for shrinkage. Parametric EBCIs that assume a normal distribution for the means (Morris (1983b)) may substantially undercover when this assumption is violated. In contrast, our EBCIs control coverage regardless of the means distribution, while remaining close in length to the parametric EBCIs when the means are indeed Gaussian. If the means are treated as fixed, our EBCIs have an average coverage guarantee: the coverage probability is at least 1 − <jats:italic>α</jats:italic>on average across the<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>EBCIs for each of the means. Our empirical application considers the effects of U.S. neighborhoods on intergenerational mobility.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we construct empirical Bayes confidence intervals that maintain proper coverage probability regardless of the underlying distribution of means in a normal means problem?
answer: The paper develops robust empirical Bayes confidence intervals (EBCIs) that use the standard linear empirical Bayes estimator but employ a critical value that accounts for shrinkage, ensuring coverage control regardless of the means distribution while maintaining similar length to parametric intervals when means are Gaussian.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the limitation of existing parametric empirical Bayes confidence intervals from Morris (1983b) that assume normal distribution for means and may substantially undercover when this assumption is violated, by providing a robust alternative that maintains coverage guarantees without distributional assumptions.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Moller
title: Dominant Currency Paradigm
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a “dominant currency paradigm” with three key features: dominant currency pricing, pricing complementarities, and imported inputs in production. We test this paradigm using a new dataset of bilateral price and volume indices for more than 2,500 country pairs that covers 91 percent of world trade, as well as detailed firm-product-country data for Colombian exports and imports. In strong support of the paradigm we find that (i) noncommodities terms-of-trade are uncorrelated with exchange rates; (ii) the dollar exchange rate quantitatively dominates the bilateral exchange rate in price pass-through and trade elasticity regressions, and this effect is increasing in the share of imports invoiced in dollars; (iii) US import volumes are significantly less sensitive to bilateral exchange rates, compared to other countries’ imports; (iv) a 1 percent US dollar appreciation against all other currencies predicts a 0.6 percent decline within a year in the volume of total trade between countries in the rest of the world, controlling for the global business cycle. We characterize the transmission of, and spillovers from, monetary policy shocks in this environment. (JEL E52, F14, F31, F44) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the dominance of the US dollar in international trade pricing affect exchange rate pass-through, trade elasticities, and the transmission of monetary policy shocks across countries?
answer: The dominant currency paradigm explains key puzzles in international trade: terms-of-trade are uncorrelated with exchange rates, the dollar exchange rate dominates bilateral exchange rates in determining trade prices and volumes, US imports are less sensitive to exchange rate changes, and dollar appreciation significantly reduces trade between non-US countries.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new 'dominant currency paradigm' that challenges traditional models by incorporating three key features (dominant currency pricing, pricing complementarities, and imported inputs) to explain previously puzzling empirical patterns in international trade that existing literature has struggled to reconcile.

title: Local Projections and VARs Estimate the Same Impulse Responses

In the over-identified case, we show that the moment weighting scheme that minimizes the worst-case estimator variance amounts to a moment selection problem with a simple solution. Finally, we develop tests of over-identifying or parameter restrictions. We apply our methods empirically to a model of menu cost pricing for multi-product firms and to a heterogeneous agent New Keynesian model.</jats:p>
research_question: How can researchers obtain valid standard errors and confidence intervals for calibrated parameters in structural models when the correlation structure of empirical moments is unknown or unavailable?
answer: The paper derives conservative standard errors and confidence intervals that are valid under worst-case correlation structures using only the variances of individual empirical moments, and shows that optimal moment weighting in over-identified cases reduces to a moment selection problem with a simple solution.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a practical limitation in existing minimum distance estimation methods for calibrated parameters, which require consistent estimates of moment correlation structures that are often unavailable in practice, by providing a robust alternative approach that works with readily available variance estimates.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Møller
title: Local Projection Inference Is Simpler and More Robust Than You Think
abstract: <jats:p>Applied macroeconomists often compute confidence intervals for impulse responses using local projections, that is, direct linear regressions of future outcomes on current covariates. This paper proves that local projection inference robustly handles two issues that commonly arise in applications: highly persistent data and the estimation of impulse responses at long horizons. We consider local projections that control for lags of the variables in the regression. We show that lag‐augmented local projections with normal critical values are asymptotically valid uniformly over (i) both stationary and non‐stationary data, and also over (ii) a wide range of response horizons. Moreover, lag augmentation obviates the need to correct standard errors for serial correlation in the regression residuals. Hence, local projection inference is arguably both simpler than previously thought and more robust than standard autoregressive inference, whose validity is known to depend sensitively on the persistence of the data and on the length of the horizon.</jats:p>
research_question: How robust is local projection inference for computing confidence intervals for impulse responses, particularly when dealing with highly persistent data and long-horizon estimation?
answer: Lag-augmented local projections with normal critical values are asymptotically valid uniformly over both stationary and non-stationary data and across a wide range of response horizons, making local projection inference simpler and more robust than previously understood.
positioning_statement: This paper positions local projection inference as superior to standard autoregressive inference methods, arguing that it is both simpler than previously thought and more robust than existing approaches, whose validity depends sensitively on data persistence and horizon length.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Møller
title: Robust Empirical Bayes Confidence Intervals
abstract: <jats:p>We construct robust empirical Bayes confidence intervals (EBCIs) in a normal means problem. The intervals are centered at the usual linear empirical Bayes estimator, but use a critical value accounting for shrinkage. Parametric EBCIs that assume a normal distribution for the means (Morris (1983b)) may substantially undercover when this assumption is violated. In contrast, our EBCIs control coverage regardless of the means distribution, while remaining close in length to the parametric EBCIs when the means are indeed Gaussian. If the means are treated as fixed, our EBCIs have an average coverage guarantee: the coverage probability is at least 1 − <jats:italic>α</jats:italic>on average across the<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>EBCIs for each of the means. Our empirical application considers the effects of U.S. neighborhoods on intergenerational mobility.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we construct empirical Bayes confidence intervals that maintain proper coverage probability regardless of the underlying distribution of means in a normal means problem?
answer: The paper develops robust empirical Bayes confidence intervals (EBCIs) that use the standard linear empirical Bayes estimator but employ a critical value that accounts for shrinkage, ensuring coverage control regardless of the means distribution while maintaining similar length to parametric intervals when means are Gaussian.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the limitation of existing parametric empirical Bayes confidence intervals from Morris (1983b) that assume normal distribution for means and may substantially undercover when this assumption is violated, by providing a robust alternative that maintains coverage guarantees without distributional assumptions.

author: Moritz Meyer-ter-Vehn
title: Learning Dynamics in Social Networks
abstract: <jats:p>This paper proposes a tractable model of Bayesian learning on large random networks where agents choose whether to adopt an innovation. We study the impact of the network structure on learning dynamics and product diffusion. In directed networks, all direct and indirect links contribute to agents' learning. In comparison, learning and welfare are lower in undirected networks and networks with cliques. In a rich class of networks, behavior is described by a small number of differential equations, making the model useful for empirical work.</jats:p>
research_question: How does network structure impact learning dynamics and product diffusion when agents make Bayesian learning decisions about adopting innovations in social networks?
answer: In directed networks, all direct and indirect links contribute to agents' learning, resulting in higher learning and welfare compared to undirected networks and networks with cliques. The learning dynamics in a rich class of networks can be described by a small number of differential equations.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a tractable model of Bayesian learning on large random networks that makes the model useful for empirical work by reducing complex network behavior to a small number of differential equations, distinguishing it from existing literature through its focus on how different network structures (directed vs undirected, with and without cliques) affect learning outcomes.

author: Mikkel Plagborg-Møller
title: Dominant Currency Paradigm
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a “dominant currency paradigm” with three key features: dominant currency pricing, pricing complementarities, and imported inputs in production. We test this paradigm using a new dataset of bilateral price and volume indices for more than 2,500 country pairs that covers 91 percent of world trade, as well as detailed firm-product-country data for Colombian exports and imports. In strong support of the paradigm we find that (i) noncommodities terms-of-trade are uncorrelated with exchange rates; (ii) the dollar exchange rate quantitatively dominates the bilateral exchange rate in price pass-through and trade elasticity regressions, and this effect is increasing in the share of imports invoiced in dollars; (iii) US import volumes are significantly less sensitive to bilateral exchange rates, compared to other countries’ imports; (iv) a 1 percent US dollar appreciation against all other currencies predicts a 0.6 percent decline within a year in the volume of total trade between countries in the rest of the world, controlling for the global business cycle. We characterize the transmission of, and spillovers from, monetary policy shocks in this environment. (JEL E52, F14, F31, F44) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the dominance of the US dollar in international trade pricing affect exchange rate pass-through, trade elasticities, and the transmission of monetary policy shocks across countries?
answer: The dominant currency paradigm explains key puzzles in international trade: terms-of-trade are uncorrelated with exchange rates, the dollar exchange rate dominates bilateral exchange rates in determining trade prices and volumes, US imports are less sensitive to exchange rate changes, and dollar appreciation significantly reduces trade between non-US countries.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new 'dominant currency paradigm' that challenges traditional models by incorporating three key features (dominant currency pricing, pricing complementarities, and imported inputs) to explain previously puzzling empirical patterns in international trade that existing literature has struggled to reconcile.

author: Moritz Meyer-ter-Vehn
title: Relational Contracts in Competitive Labour Markets

author: Moritz Meyer-ter-Vehn
title: Leaning against the Wind and Crisis Risk
abstract: <jats:p> Can central banks defuse rising stability risks in financial booms by leaning against the wind with higher interest rates? This paper studies the state-dependent effects of monetary policy on financial crisis risk. Based on the near-universe of advanced economy financial cycles since the nineteenth century, we show that discretionary leaning against the wind policies during credit and asset price booms are more likely to trigger crises than prevent them. (JEL E43, E44, E52, E58, F33) </jats:p>
research_question: Can central banks defuse rising stability risks in financial booms by leaning against the wind with higher interest rates?
answer: Discretionary leaning against the wind policies during credit and asset price booms are more likely to trigger crises than prevent them.
positioning_statement: This paper studies the state-dependent effects of monetary policy on financial crisis risk using the near-universe of advanced economy financial cycles since the nineteenth century, providing empirical evidence on the effectiveness of leaning against the wind policies.

author: Moritz Meyer-ter-Vehn
title: Experimentation in Networks
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a model of strategic experimentation on social networks in which forward-looking agents learn from their own and neighbors’ successes. In equilibrium, private discovery is followed by social diffusion. Social learning crowds out own experimentation, so total information decreases with network density; we determine density thresholds below which agents’ asymptotic learning is perfect. By contrast, agent welfare is single peaked in network density and achieves a second-best benchmark level at intermediate levels that strike a balance between discovery and diffusion. (JEL D82, D83, D86, O31, O33, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does network density affect strategic experimentation, learning, and welfare when forward-looking agents learn from both their own experiences and their neighbors' successes?
answer: Total information decreases with network density due to social learning crowding out individual experimentation, but agent welfare is maximized at intermediate network density levels that optimally balance discovery and diffusion, achieving second-best benchmark levels.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the strategic experimentation literature by introducing social networks as a mechanism for learning diffusion, extending beyond traditional models to examine how network structure affects the trade-off between private discovery and social learning.

author: Moritz Meyer-ter-Vehn
title: A Conversational War of Attrition

author: Moritz Meyer-ter-Vehn
title: The Limits of ex post Implementation

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Understanding the Ownership Structure of Corporate Bonds
abstract: <jats:p> Insurers are the largest institutional investors of corporate bonds. However, a standard theory of insurance markets, in which insurers maximize firm value subject to regulatory or risk constraints, predicts no allocation to corporate bonds. We resolve this puzzle in an equilibrium asset pricing model with leverage-constrained households and institutional investors. Insurers have relatively cheap access to leverage through their underwriting activity. They hold a leveraged portfolio of low-beta assets in equilibrium, relaxing other investors’ leverage constraints. The model explains recent empirical findings on insurers’ portfolio choice and its impact on asset prices. (JEL G11, G12, G22, G23) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do insurers hold large amounts of corporate bonds when standard insurance theory predicts they should not allocate to corporate bonds?
answer: Insurers hold corporate bonds because they have relatively cheap access to leverage through their underwriting activity, allowing them to hold leveraged portfolios of low-beta assets in equilibrium while relaxing other investors' leverage constraints.
positioning_statement: This paper resolves a puzzle that standard theory of insurance markets cannot explain by developing an equilibrium asset pricing model with leverage-constrained households and institutional investors, and validates the model against recent empirical findings on insurers' portfolio choice and asset price impacts.

author: Moritz Meyer-ter-Vehn
title: Discrimination in Hiring: Evidence from Retail Sales
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose a simple model of racial bias in hiring that encompasses three major theories: taste-based discrimination, screening discrimination, and complementary production. We derive a test that can distinguish these theories based on the mean and variance of workers’ productivity under managers of different pairs of races. We apply this test to study discrimination at a major U.S. retailer using data from 48,755 newly hired commission-based salespeople. White, black, and Hispanic managers within the same store are significantly more likely to hire workers of their own race, consistent with all three theories. For black–Hispanic pairs, productivity variance is lower for same-race pairs than cross-race pairs, implying that screening discrimination dominates. For white–Hispanic pairs, mean productivity is higher for same-race pairs, indicating a combination of screening discrimination and complementary production. For white–black pairs, biased hiring implies the presence of discrimination, but productivity results suggest the effects of the three forms of discrimination offset one another.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the underlying mechanisms driving racial bias in hiring decisions, and can we distinguish between taste-based discrimination, screening discrimination, and complementary production theories?
answer: All three forms of discrimination exist but vary by racial pair: screening discrimination dominates for black-Hispanic pairs, screening discrimination combined with complementary production occurs for white-Hispanic pairs, and for white-black pairs the three forms of discrimination offset each other despite evidence of biased hiring.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the discrimination literature by proposing a unified model that encompasses three major theories of racial bias (taste-based discrimination, screening discrimination, and complementary production) and developing a novel empirical test based on productivity mean and variance that can distinguish between these theories, which previous studies have not been able to separate.

author: Moses Shayo
title: Judicial Ingroup Bias in the Shadow of Terrorism *

author: Moses Shayo
title: How Do We Choose Our Identity? A Revealed Preference Approach Using Food Consumption
abstract: Are identities fungible? How do people come to identify with specific groups? This paper proposes a revealed preference approach, using food consumption to uncover ethnic and religious identity choices in India. We first show that consumption \of identity goods responds to forces suggested by social identity research: group status and group salience. Moreover, identity choices respond to the cost of following the group’s prescribed behaviors. We propose and estimate a demand system to quantify the identity changes that followed India’s 1991 reforms. While social identity research has focused on status and salience, our results suggest that economic costs also play an important role.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: A Note on Liquidity Risk Management

author: Moses Shayo
title: Valuing Peace: The Effects of Financial Market Exposure on Votes and Political Attitudes
abstract: <jats:p>Can participation in financial markets lead individuals to reevaluate the costs of conflict, change their political attitudes, and even their votes? Prior to the 2015 Israeli elections, we randomly assigned Palestinian and Israeli financial assets to likely voters and incentivized them to actively trade for up to 7 weeks. No political messages or nonfinancial information were included. The treatment systematically shifted vote choices toward parties more supportive of the peace process. This effect is not due to a direct material incentive to vote a particular way. Rather, the treatment reduces opposition to concessions for peace and changes awareness of the broader economic risks of conflict. While participants who were assigned Palestinian assets are more likely to associate their assets' performance with peace, they are less engaged in the experiment. Combined with the superior performance of Israeli stocks during the study period, the ultimate effects of Israeli and Palestinian assets are similar.</jats:p>
research_question: Can participation in financial markets lead individuals to reevaluate the costs of conflict, change their political attitudes, and even their votes?
answer: Yes, financial market exposure systematically shifts vote choices toward parties more supportive of the peace process by reducing opposition to concessions for peace and changing awareness of the broader economic risks of conflict, rather than through direct material incentives.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel experimental approach to studying the relationship between financial market participation and political attitudes toward conflict, using random assignment of financial assets to examine causal effects on voting behavior in the context of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: A Demand System Approach to Asset Pricing
abstract: We develop an asset pricing model with flexible heterogeneity in asset demand across investors, designed to match institutional and household holdings. A portfolio choice model implies characteristics-based demand when returns have a factor structure and expected returns and factor loadings depend on the assets’ own characteristics. We propose an instrumental variables estimator for the characteristics-based demand system to address the endogeneity of demand and asset prices. Using US stock market data, we illustrate how the model could be used to understand the role of institutions in asset market movements, volatility, and predictability.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Worker Betas: Five Facts about Systematic Earnings Risk
abstract: <jats:p> The magnitude of and heterogeneity in systematic earnings risk has important implications for various theories in macro, labor, and financial economics. Using administrative data, we document how the aggregate risk exposure of individual earnings to GDP and stock returns varies across gender, age, the worker's earnings level, and industry. Aggregate risk exposure is U-shaped with respect to the earnings level. In the middle of the earnings distribution, aggregate risk exposure is higher for males, younger workers, and construction and durable manufacturing. At the top of the earnings distribution, aggregate risk exposure is higher for older workers and finance. </jats:p>
research_question: How does the aggregate risk exposure of individual earnings to GDP and stock returns vary across different worker characteristics (gender, age, earnings level) and industries?
answer: Aggregate risk exposure is U-shaped with respect to earnings level; in the middle of the earnings distribution, it is higher for males, younger workers, and those in construction and durable manufacturing; at the top of the earnings distribution, it is higher for older workers and those in finance.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the magnitude of and heterogeneity in systematic earnings risk, which has important implications for various theories in macro, labor, and financial economics, using administrative data to document previously uncharacterized patterns.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Shadow Insurance
abstract: Life insurers use reinsurance to move liabilities from regulated and rated companies that sell policies to shadow reinsurers, which are less regulated and unrated off‐balance‐sheet entities within the same insurance group. U.S. life insurance and annuity liabilities ceded to shadow reinsurers grew from $11 billion in 2002 to $364 billion in 2012. Life insurers using shadow insurance, which capture half of the market share, ceded 25 cents of every dollar insured to shadow reinsurers in 2012, up from 2 cents in 2002. By relaxing capital requirements, shadow insurance could reduce the marginal cost of issuing policies and thereby improve retail market efficiency. However, shadow insurance could also reduce risk‐based capital and increase expected loss for the industry. We model and quantify these effects based on publicly available data and plausible assumptions.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Durability of Output and Expected Stock Returns
abstract: The demand for durable goods is more cyclical than that for nondurable goods and services. Consequently, the cash flows and stock returns of durable‐good producers are exposed to higher systematic risk. Using the benchmark input‐output accounts of the National Income and Product Accounts, we construct portfolios of durable‐good, nondurable‐good, and service producers. In the cross section, an investment strategy that is long on the durable‐good portfolio and short on the service portfolio earns a risk premium exceeding 4 percent annually. In the time series, an investment strategy that is long on the durable‐good portfolio and short on the market portfolio earns a countercyclical risk premium. We explain these findings in a general equilibrium asset‐pricing model with endogenous production.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: The Cost of Financial Frictions for Life Insurers
abstract: <jats:p> During the financial crisis, life insurers sold long-term policies at deep discounts relative to actuarial value. The average markup was as low as −19 percent for annuities and −57 percent for life insurance. This extraordinary pricing behavior was due to financial and product market frictions, interacting with statutory reserve regulation that allowed life insurers to record far less than a dollar of reserve per dollar of future insurance liability. We identify the shadow cost of capital through exogenous variation in required reserves across different types of policies. The shadow cost was $0.96 per dollar of statutory capital for the average company in November 2008. (JEL G01, G22, G28, G32) </jats:p>
research_question: What caused life insurers to sell long-term policies at deep discounts relative to actuarial value during the financial crisis, and what was the shadow cost of capital for these companies?
answer: Life insurers sold policies at significant discounts (markups as low as -19% for annuities and -57% for life insurance) due to financial and product market frictions interacting with statutory reserve regulation that allowed insurers to record less than a dollar of reserve per dollar of future liability. The shadow cost of capital was $0.96 per dollar of statutory capital for the average company in November 2008.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by identifying and quantifying the shadow cost of capital for life insurers during financial crises through exogenous variation in required reserves across different policy types, explaining the extraordinary pricing behavior observed during the financial crisis that previous literature had not fully addressed.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Which Investors Matter for Equity Valuations and Expected Returns?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Based on an asset demand system, we develop a framework to quantify the impact of market trends and changes in regulation on asset prices, price informativeness, and the wealth distribution. Our leading applications are the transition from active to passive investment management and climate-induced shifts in asset demand. The transition from active to passive investment management had a large impact on equity prices but a small impact on price informativeness because capital did not flow from more to less informed investors on average. This finding is based on a new measure of investor-level informativeness that identifies which investors are more informed about future profitability. Climate-induced shifts in asset demand have a potentially large impact on equity prices and the wealth distribution, implying capital gains for passive investment advisors, pension funds, insurance companies, and private banking and capital losses for active investment advisors and hedge funds.</jats:p>
research_question: How do market trends and regulatory changes, particularly the transition from active to passive investment management and climate-induced shifts in asset demand, impact equity valuations, expected returns, price informativeness, and wealth distribution?
answer: The transition from active to passive investment management had a large impact on equity prices but minimal impact on price informativeness because capital did not flow from more to less informed investors on average. Climate-induced shifts in asset demand have potentially large impacts on equity prices and wealth distribution, creating capital gains for passive advisors, pension funds, and insurance companies while causing losses for active advisors and hedge funds.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new framework based on an asset demand system to quantify investor impacts on asset prices and introduces a novel measure of investor-level informativeness that identifies which investors are more informed about future profitability, filling a gap in understanding how different types of investors affect market outcomes.

author: Myrto Kalouptsidi
title: Time to Build and Fluctuations in Bulk Shipping
abstract: <jats:p> This paper explores the nature of fluctuations in world bulk shipping by quantifying the impact of time to build and demand uncertainty on investment and prices. We examine the impact of both construction lags and their lengthening in periods of high investment activity, by constructing a dynamic model of ship entry and exit. A rich dataset of secondhand ship sales allows for a new estimation strategy: resale prices provide direct information on value functions and allow their nonparametric estimation. We find that moving from time-varying to constant to no time to build reduces prices, while significantly increasing both the level and volatility of investment. (JEL G31, L11, L62, L92) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of time to build and demand uncertainty on investment and prices in world bulk shipping?
answer: Moving from time-varying to constant to no time to build reduces prices, while significantly increasing both the level and volatility of investment in bulk shipping markets.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using a rich dataset of secondhand ship sales to develop a new estimation strategy where resale prices provide direct information on value functions and allow their nonparametric estimation, offering a novel approach to quantifying the effects of construction lags and their variation during periods of high investment activity.

author: Motohiro Yogo
title: Euro-Area Quantitative Easing and Portfolio Rebalancing
abstract: <jats:p> We use new and comprehensive data on the security holdings of euro-area investors to document facts about the ongoing quantitative easing program. The holdings of purchase-eligible government bonds have strong home bias not only for banks but also for insurance companies, pension funds, and mutual funds, especially in the vulnerable countries. In response to the program, foreign investors sold most of the purchase-eligible government bonds. Banks also sold purchase-eligible government bonds to a lesser extent, but insurance companies and pension funds bought them. Thus, quantitative easing may have reduced the duration mismatch for these institutions. </jats:p>
research_question: How did different types of euro-area investors respond to the quantitative easing program in terms of their holdings of purchase-eligible government bonds?
answer: Foreign investors sold most purchase-eligible government bonds in response to QE, banks also sold them to a lesser extent, while insurance companies and pension funds bought them, potentially reducing duration mismatch for these institutions. All investor types showed strong home bias in their holdings, especially in vulnerable countries.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new empirical evidence using comprehensive data on security holdings of euro-area investors to document previously unobserved facts about portfolio rebalancing behavior during the ongoing quantitative easing program.

author: Myrto Kalouptsidi
title: Detection and Impact of Industrial Subsidies: The Case of Chinese Shipbuilding

author: Myrto Kalouptsidi
title: Geography, Transportation, and Endogenous Trade Costs
abstract: <jats:p>In this paper, we study the role of the transportation sector in world trade. We build a spatial model that centers on the interaction of the market for (oceanic) transportation services and the market for world trade in goods. The model delivers equilibrium trade flows, as well as equilibrium trade costs (shipping prices). Using detailed data on vessel movements and shipping prices, we document novel facts about shipping patterns; we then flexibly estimate our model. We use this setup to demonstrate that the transportation sector (i) attenuates differences in the comparative advantage across countries; (ii) generates network effects in trade costs; and (iii) dampens the impact of shocks on trade flows. These three mechanisms reveal a new role for geography in international trade that was previously concealed by the frequently‐used assumption of exogenous trade costs. Finally, we illustrate how our setup can be used for policy analysis by evaluating the impact of future and existing infrastructure projects (e.g., Northwest Passage, Panama Canal).</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of the transportation sector in world trade, particularly how does the interaction between transportation services markets and goods trade markets affect trade flows and costs?
answer: The transportation sector (i) attenuates differences in comparative advantage across countries; (ii) generates network effects in trade costs; and (iii) dampens the impact of shocks on trade flows, revealing a new role for geography in international trade.
positioning_statement: This paper reveals a new role for geography in international trade that was previously concealed by the frequently-used assumption of exogenous trade costs, by building a spatial model that endogenizes trade costs through the interaction of transportation services and goods markets.

author: Myrto Kalouptsidi
title: Industrial Policy Implementation: Empirical Evidence from China’s Shipbuilding Industry
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Industrial policies are widely used across the world. In practice, designing and implementing these policies is a complicated task. In this paper, we assess the long-term performance of different industrial policy instruments, which include production subsidies, investment subsidies, entry subsidies, and consolidation policies. To do so, we examine a recent industrial policy in China aiming to propel the country’s shipbuilding industry to the largest globally. Using firm-level data from 1998 to 2014 and a dynamic model of firm entry, exit, investment, and production, we find that (i) the policy boosted China’s domestic investment, entry, and international market share dramatically, but delivered low returns and led to fragmentation, idle capacity, as well as depressed world ship prices; (ii) the effectiveness of different policy instruments is mixed: production and investment subsidies can be justified by market share considerations, while entry subsidies are wasteful; (iii) counter-cyclical policies, firm-targeting, and shortening the intervention horizon can substantially reduce distortions. Our results highlight the critical role of firm heterogeneity, business cycles, and firms’ cost structure in policy design. Finally, when exploring potential rationales, we find support for nonclassical considerations, such as reducing freight rates to boost Chinese trade.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the long-term performance and effectiveness of different industrial policy instruments (production subsidies, investment subsidies, entry subsidies, and consolidation policies) in China's shipbuilding industry policy aimed at making China the world's largest shipbuilder?
answer: The policy successfully boosted China's domestic investment, entry, and international market share dramatically, but delivered low returns and created significant distortions including fragmentation, idle capacity, and depressed world ship prices. Among policy instruments, production and investment subsidies can be justified by market share considerations, while entry subsidies are wasteful. Counter-cyclical policies, firm-targeting, and shorter intervention horizons can substantially reduce distortions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the industrial policy literature by providing empirical evidence on the differential effectiveness of specific policy instruments using firm-level data and a dynamic structural model, highlighting the critical but underexplored role of firm heterogeneity, business cycles, and firms' cost structure in policy design, while also exploring nonclassical rationales for industrial policy such as reducing freight rates to boost trade.

author: Myrto Kalouptsidi
title: Search Frictions and Efficiency in Decentralized Transport Markets
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We explore efficiency and optimal policy in decentralized transport markets, such as taxis, trucks, and bulk shipping. We show that in these markets, search frictions distort the transportation network and the dynamic allocation of carriers over space. We derive explicit and intuitive conditions for efficiency and show how they translate into efficient pricing rules, or optimal taxes and subsidies for the planner who cannot set prices directly. The results imply that destination-based pricing is essential to attain efficiency. Then, using data from dry bulk shipping, we demonstrate that search frictions lead to a sizable social loss and substantial misallocation of ships over space. Optimal policy can eliminate about half of the welfare loss. Can a centralizing platform, often arising as a market-based solution to search frictions, do better? Interestingly, the answer is no; although the platform eradicates frictions, it exerts market power, thus eroding the welfare gains. Finally, we use two recent interventions in the industry (China’s Belt and Road Initiative and the environmental initiative IMO 2020) to demonstrate that taking into account the efficiency properties of transport markets is germane to any proposed policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How do search frictions affect efficiency in decentralized transport markets (taxis, trucks, bulk shipping) and what are the optimal policies to address these inefficiencies?
answer: Search frictions distort transportation networks and cause substantial misallocation of carriers over space, leading to sizable social welfare losses. Destination-based pricing and optimal taxes/subsidies can eliminate about half of the welfare loss, while centralizing platforms, despite reducing frictions, create market power problems that erode welfare gains.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on search frictions in transportation markets by providing explicit conditions for efficiency, deriving optimal pricing rules and policy interventions, and empirically quantifying welfare losses using dry bulk shipping data, while also analyzing the trade-offs between market-based platform solutions and regulatory approaches.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Optimal Dynamic Capital Budgeting
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>I study optimal design of a dynamic capital allocation process in an organization in which the division manager with empire-building preferences privately observes the arrival and properties of investment projects, and headquarters can audit projects at a cost. Under certain conditions, a budgeting mechanism with threshold separation of financing is optimal. Headquarters: (1) allocate a spending account to the manager and replenish it over time; (2) set a threshold, such that projects below it are financed from the account, while projects above are financed fully by headquarters upon an audit. Further analysis studies when co-financing of projects is optimal and how the size of the account depends on past performance of projects.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal design of a dynamic capital allocation process in an organization where division managers have empire-building preferences and privately observe investment projects, while headquarters can audit projects at a cost?
answer: Under certain conditions, a budgeting mechanism with threshold separation of financing is optimal, where headquarters allocates a spending account to managers, sets a threshold such that projects below it are financed from the account while projects above are financed fully by headquarters upon audit, and replenishes the account over time based on past project performance.
positioning_statement: This paper studies optimal dynamic capital budgeting mechanisms in organizations with information asymmetry and agency conflicts, specifically addressing the case where division managers have empire-building preferences and headquarters faces auditing costs, contributing to the literature on internal capital markets and organizational design.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Timing Decisions in Organizations: Communication and Authority in a Dynamic Environment
abstract: <jats:p> We consider a problem where an uninformed principal makes a timing decision interacting with an informed but biased agent. Because time is irreversible, the direction of the bias crucially affects the agent's ability to credibly communicate information. When the agent favors late decision making, full information revelation often occurs.
