In this case, centralized decision making, where the principal retains authority and communicates with the agent, implements the optimal decision-making rule. When the agent favors early decision making, communication is partial, and the optimal decision-making rule is not implemented. Delegation adds value when the bias is for early decision making, but not for late decision making. (JEL D21, D23, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the direction of an informed agent's bias affect communication and the optimal allocation of decision-making authority in dynamic timing decisions within organizations?
answer: The direction of bias crucially determines communication effectiveness and optimal organizational structure: when agents favor late decision making, full information revelation occurs and centralized authority is optimal; when agents favor early decision making, communication is only partial and delegation becomes valuable.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the organizational economics literature on communication and authority by introducing the novel insight that the irreversible nature of time makes the direction of agent bias (early vs. late) a crucial factor in determining optimal decision-making structures, distinguishing it from static information transmission models.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Competition among Sellers in Securities Auctions
abstract: <jats:p> We study simultaneous security-bid second-price auctions with competition among sellers for potential bidders. The sellers compete by designing ordered sets of securities that the bidders can offer as payment for the assets. Upon observing auction designs, potential bidders decide which auctions to enter. We characterize all symmetric equilibria and show that there always exist equilibria in which auctions are in standard securities or their combinations. In large markets the unique equilibrium is auctions in pure cash. We extend the model for competition in reserve prices and show that binding reserve prices never constitute equilibrium as long as equilibrium security designs are not call options. (JEL D44, D82, G10) </jats:p>
research_question: How do sellers compete for bidders in securities auctions when they can design the types of securities that bidders can offer as payment?
answer: There always exist equilibria where auctions use standard securities or their combinations, and in large markets the unique equilibrium converges to pure cash auctions. Additionally, binding reserve prices are never equilibrium outcomes unless the security designs are call options.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the auction theory literature by introducing competition among sellers who can strategically design the payment securities in second-price auctions, rather than taking the payment form as given, and analyzes how this competition affects market outcomes and bidder participation decisions.

author: Nagore Iriberri
title: Are Referees and Editors in Economics Gender Neutral?*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the role of gender in the evaluation of economic research using submissions to four leading journals. We find that referee gender has no effect on the relative assessment of female- versus male-authored papers, suggesting that any differential biases of male referees are negligible. To determine whether referees as a whole impose different standards for female authors, we compare citations for female- and male-authored papers, holding constant referee evaluations and other characteristics. We find that female-authored papers receive about 25% more citations than observably similar male-authored papers. Editors largely follow the referees, resulting in a 1.7 percentage point lower probability of a revise and resubmit verdict for papers with female authors relative to a citation-maximizing benchmark. In their desk rejection decisions, editors treat female authors more favorably, though they still impose a higher bar than would be implied by citation maximization. We find no differences in the informativeness of female versus male referees or in the weight that editors place on the recommendations of female versus male referees. We also find no differences in editorial delays for female- versus male-authored papers.</jats:p>
research_question: Are referees and editors in economics journals gender neutral in their evaluation of research papers?
answer: Referees show no gender bias in evaluating papers, but editors impose higher standards on female-authored papers than would be optimal for citation maximization, resulting in a 1.7 percentage point lower probability of revise and resubmit decisions for female authors despite their papers receiving 25% more citations than comparable male-authored papers.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on gender bias in academic publishing by providing empirical evidence from four leading economics journals, using a novel approach that compares referee evaluations with actual citation outcomes to identify whether different standards are applied to female versus male authors.

author: Nagore Iriberri
title: Fatal Attraction: Salience, Naïveté, and Sophistication in Experimental “Hide-and-Seek” Games
abstract: <jats:p> “Hide-and-seek” games are zero-sum two-person games in which one player wins by matching the other's decision and the other wins by mismatching. Although such games are often played on cultural or geographic “landscapes” that frame decisions nonneutrally, equilibrium ignores such framing. This paper reconsiders the results of experiments by Rubinstein, Tversky, and others whose designs model nonneutral landscapes, in which subjects deviate systematically from equilibrium in response to them. Comparing alternative explanations theoretically and econometrically suggests that the deviations are well explained by a structural nonequilibrium model of initial responses based on “level-k” thinking, suitably adapted to nonneutral landscapes. (JEL C72, C92) </jats:p>
research_question: How do players deviate from equilibrium behavior in hide-and-seek games when decisions are framed by nonneutral cultural or geographic landscapes, and what explains these systematic deviations?
answer: Players systematically deviate from equilibrium in response to nonneutral framing, and these deviations are well explained by a structural nonequilibrium model based on 'level-k' thinking that has been adapted to account for nonneutral landscapes.
positioning_statement: This paper reconsiders and reanalyzes existing experimental results from Rubinstein, Tversky, and others by providing an alternative theoretical explanation for observed deviations from equilibrium, specifically through a level-k thinking framework adapted for nonneutral decision landscapes, rather than accepting equilibrium predictions that ignore such framing effects.

author: Nagore Iriberri
title: Level-k Auctions: Can a Nonequilibrium Model of Strategic Thinking Explain the Winner's Curse and Overbidding in Private-Value Auctions?

author: Namrata Kala
title: The Impacts of Managerial Autonomy on Firm Outcomes
abstract: <jats:p>The allocation of decision‐making power is a critical choice that organizations make to mitigate agency problems and information frictions. This paper investigates the role of delegation for organizations where the agency problem is both pervasive and has potentially high welfare consequences: state‐owned enterprises (SOEs). I use a natural experiment in India to uncover the causal effects of granting SOE managers more autonomy over strategic decisions. Managers meaningfully exercise this autonomy, which results in greater value added, but also a reduced emphasis on outcomes valued by the government, such as a reduction in worker amenities (employee housing), and an increase in markups. Returns to autonomy are higher for firms with higher baseline incentive conflict.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the causal effects of granting state-owned enterprise (SOE) managers more autonomy over strategic decisions?
answer: Managerial autonomy leads to greater value added but also reduces emphasis on government-valued outcomes such as worker amenities, increases markups, with higher returns to autonomy for firms with greater baseline incentive conflict.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on delegation and agency problems by focusing specifically on state-owned enterprises where agency problems are both pervasive and have high welfare consequences, using a natural experiment to establish causal effects rather than correlational relationships.

author: Namrata Kala
title: Money (Not) to Burn: Payments for Ecosystem Services to Reduce Crop Residue Burning
abstract: <jats:p> We test whether payments for ecosystem services (PES) can curb the highly polluting practice of crop residue burning in India. Standard PES contracts pay participants after verification that they met a proenvironment condition (clearing fields without burning). We randomize paying a portion of the money up front and unconditionally to address liquidity constraints and farmer distrust, which may undermine the standard contract’s effectiveness. Incorporating partial up-front payment into the contract increases compliance by 10 percentage points, which is corroborated by satellite-based burning measurements. The cost per life saved is $3,600–$5,400. The standard PES contract has no effect on burning. (JEL D86, O13, Q12, Q15, Q18, Q53, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: Can payments for ecosystem services (PES) effectively reduce crop residue burning in India, and does incorporating partial up-front payment improve contract effectiveness compared to standard PES contracts?
answer: Standard PES contracts have no effect on crop residue burning, but incorporating partial up-front payment into PES contracts increases compliance by 10 percentage points, with a cost per life saved of $3,600–$5,400.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the payments for ecosystem services literature by testing a novel contract design modification (partial up-front payment) to address liquidity constraints and farmer distrust that may undermine standard PES contract effectiveness, specifically in the context of reducing crop residue burning pollution in India.

author: Nadya Malenko
title: Selling to Advised Buyers
abstract: <jats:p> In many cases, buyers are not informed about their valuations and rely on experts, who are informed but biased for overbidding. We study auction design when selling to such “advised buyers.” We show that a canonical dynamic auction, the English auction, has a natural equilibrium that outperforms standard static auctions in expected revenues and allocative efficiency. The ability to communicate as the auction proceeds allows for more informative communication and gives advisors the ability to persuade buyers into overbidding. The same outcome is the unique equilibrium of the English auction when bidders can commit to contracts with their advisors. (JEL D44, D82, D83, D86) </jats:p>
research_question: How should auctions be designed when buyers are uninformed about their valuations and rely on biased experts who have incentives to encourage overbidding?
answer: The English auction has a natural equilibrium that outperforms standard static auctions in both expected revenues and allocative efficiency when selling to advised buyers, because the dynamic communication process allows for more informative exchanges and enables advisors to persuade buyers into overbidding.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new framework of 'advised buyers' to auction theory, extending the literature on auction design by considering the role of biased intermediaries (experts/advisors) who influence uninformed buyers' bidding decisions, which has not been systematically studied in the context of optimal auction design.

author: Namrata Kala
title: Management and Shocks to Worker Productivity
abstract: We study how managers mitigate the negative impacts of environmental shocks. Pairing productivity data from a garment firm with granular measures of air pollution, we show that productivity suffers as a result of pollution shocks but that managers respond by reallocating particularly sensitive workers to improve worker-to-task matches, thus mitigating team productivity losses. Responses are smaller for more inattentive managers; these same managers are also least able to mitigate productivity declines. These patterns are confirmed by leveraging variation in opportunities for reallocation and comparing how close managers of differing attentiveness can get to the simulated production frontier by reallocating workers.

author: Namrata Kala
title: Returns to On-the-Job Soft Skills Training
abstract: We estimate productivity gains of 13.5% from workplace soft skills training among Indian garment workers. Productivity gains are greater when trainees work on joint operations alongside other coworkers, consistent with gains being driven by improved teamwork and collaboration. Furthermore, untreated coworkers on the treated production lines also show increased productivity. These improvements in the teamwork substitute for managerial attention. Despite productivity gains and higher promotion probabilities among treated workers, there are no effects on wages or retention, consistent with frictions in this labor market. Consequently, the net return to the firm was large: 256% 8 months after program completion.

author: Natalie Bau
title: Can Policy Change Culture? Government Pension Plans and Traditional Kinship Practices
abstract: <jats:p>Policies may change the incentives that allow cultural practices to persist. To test this, I study matrilocality and patrilocality, kinship traditions that determine daughters’ and sons’ post-marriage residences, and thus, which gender lives with and supports parents in their old age. Two separate policy experiments in Ghana and Indonesia show that pension policies reduce the practice of these traditions. I also show that these traditions incentivize parents to invest in the education of children who traditionally coreside with them. Consequently, when pension plans change cultural practices, they also reduce educational investment. This finding further demonstrates that policy can change culture. (JEL G51, I20, J15, J16, J32, Z13)</jats:p>
research_question: Can policy change culture, specifically whether government pension plans affect traditional kinship practices like matrilocality and patrilocality?
answer: Yes, pension policies can change culture - government pension plans reduce the practice of traditional kinship residence patterns (matrilocality and patrilocality), and consequently also reduce parents' educational investment in children who would traditionally coreside with them.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical evidence that policies can change cultural practices by altering underlying economic incentives, using two separate policy experiments to demonstrate how pension policies affect traditional kinship practices and their associated behaviors.

author: Nagore Iriberri
title: Gender Differences in Peer Recognition by Economists
abstract:
<jats:p>We study the selection of Fellows of the Econometric Society, using a new data set of publications and citations for over 40,000 actively publishing economists since the early 1900s. Conditional on achievement, we document a large negative gap in the probability that women were selected as Fellows in the 1933–1979 period. This gap became positive (though not statistically significant) from 1980 to 2010, and in the past decade has become large and highly significant, with over a 100% increase in the probability of selection for female authors relative to males with similar publications and citations. The positive boost affects highly qualified female candidates (in the top 10% of authors) with no effect for the bottom 90%. Using nomination data for the past 30 years, we find a key proximate role for the Society's Nominating Committee in this shift. Since 2012, the Committee has had an explicit mandate to nominate highly qualified women, and its nominees enjoy above‐average election success (controlling for achievement). Looking beyond gender, we document similar shifts in the premium for geographic diversity: in the mid‐2000s, both the Fellows and the Nominating Committee became significantly more likely to nominate and elect candidates from outside the United States. Finally, we examine gender gaps in several other major awards for U.S. economists. We show that the gaps in the probability of selection of new fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and the National Academy of Sciences closely parallel those of the Econometric Society, with historically negative 
            <jats:italic>penalties</jats:italic> for women turning to positive 
            <jats:italic>premiums</jats:italic> in recent years.
          </jats:p>
research_question: How have gender differences in peer recognition among economists, specifically in the selection of Fellows of the Econometric Society, evolved over time?
answer: There was a large negative gap in the probability that women were selected as Fellows from 1933-1979, which became positive (though not significant) from 1980-2010, and in the past decade has become large and highly significant with over 100% increase in selection probability for qualified female authors. This shift is primarily driven by the Society's Nominating Committee's explicit mandate since 2012 to nominate highly qualified women.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new empirical evidence on gender bias in academic economics using a comprehensive dataset of over 40,000 economists since the early 1900s, extending beyond previous studies by documenting the historical evolution of gender gaps in peer recognition and identifying the institutional mechanisms (nominating committees) that drive changes in selection patterns, while also drawing parallels to similar patterns in other major academic awards.

author: Natalie Bau
title: Estimating an Equilibrium Model of Horizontal Competition in Education
abstract: The quality of the match between students and schools affects learning, but little is known about the magnitude of these effects or how they respond to changes in market structure. I develop a quantitative equilibrium model of school competition with horizontal competition in match quality. I estimate the model using data from Pakistan, a country with high private enrollment, and (1) quantify the importance of good matches, (2) show that profit-maximizing private schools’ choices of quality advantage wealthier students, increasing inequality and reducing welfare and learning, and (3) provide intuition for when interventions in the market are valuable.

author: Natalie Bau
title: Misallocation and Capital Market Integration: Evidence From India
abstract: <jats:p>We show that foreign capital liberalization reduces capital misallocation and increases aggregate productivity for affected industries in India. The staggered liberalization of access to foreign capital across disaggregated industries allows us to identify changes in firms' input wedges, overcoming major challenges in the measurement of the effects of changing misallocation. Liberalization increases capital overall. For domestic firms with initially high marginal revenue products of capital (MRPK), liberalization increases revenues by 23%, physical capital by 53%, wage bills by 28%, and reduces MRPK by 33% relative to low MRPK firms. The effects of liberalization are largest in areas with less developed local banking sectors, indicating that inefficiencies in that sector may cause misallocation. Finally, we propose an assumption under which a novel method exploiting natural experiments can be used to bound the effect of changes in misallocation on treated industries' aggregate productivity. These industries' Solow residual increases by 3–16%.</jats:p>
research_question: Does foreign capital liberalization reduce capital misallocation and increase aggregate productivity in affected industries?
answer: Foreign capital liberalization reduces capital misallocation and increases aggregate productivity, with domestic firms having initially high marginal revenue products of capital experiencing significant increases in revenues (23%), physical capital (53%), and wage bills (28%), while their MRPK decreased by 33%. The Solow residual for treated industries increased by 3-16%.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses major challenges in measuring the effects of changing misallocation by exploiting India's staggered liberalization of foreign capital access across disaggregated industries as a natural experiment, and proposes a novel method for bounding the effect of misallocation changes on aggregate productivity using natural experiments.

author: Natalie Bau
title: Bride Price and Female Education
abstract: We document an important consequence of bride price, a payment made by the groom to the bride’s family at marriage. Revisiting Indonesia’s school construction program, we find that among ethnic groups without the custom, it had no effect on girls’ schooling. Among ethnic groups with the custom, it had large positive effects. We show (theoretically and empirically) that this is because a daughter’s education, by increasing the amount of money parents receive at marriage, generates an additional incentive for parents to educate their daughters. We replicate these findings in Zambia, a country that had a similar large-scale school construction program.

author: Natalie Bau
title: Negotiating a Better Future: How Interpersonal Skills Facilitate Intergenerational Investment*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Using a randomized controlled trial, we study whether a negotiation skills training can improve girls’ educational outcomes in a low-resource environment. We find that a negotiation training given to eighth-grade Zambian girls significantly improved educational outcomes over the next three years, and these effects did not fade out. To better understand mechanisms, we estimate the effects of two alternative treatments. Negotiation had much stronger effects than an informational treatment, which had no effect. A treatment designed to have more traditional girls’ empowerment effects had directionally positive but insignificant educational effects. Relative to this treatment, negotiation increased enrollment in higher-quality schooling and had larger effects for high-ability girls. These findings are consistent with a model in which negotiation allows girls to resolve incomplete contracting problems with their parents, yielding increased educational investment for those who experience sufficiently high returns. We provide evidence for this channel through a lab-in-the-field game and follow-up survey with girls and their guardians.</jats:p>
research_question: Can negotiation skills training improve girls' educational outcomes in a low-resource environment?
answer: Yes, negotiation skills training given to eighth-grade Zambian girls significantly improved educational outcomes over three years without fade-out effects, particularly by helping girls resolve incomplete contracting problems with parents and increasing enrollment in higher-quality schooling for high-ability girls.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that negotiation skills training is more effective than traditional informational treatments or standard girls' empowerment interventions, offering a novel mechanism through which intergenerational investment problems can be addressed via improved parent-child contracting.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: The Transmission of Democracy: From the Village to the Nation-State
abstract: <jats:p> We provide evidence that a tradition of village democracy is associated with the presence of national democracy today. We also show that a tradition of local democracy is associated with attitudes which are more supportive of democracy, with better quality institutions and with higher levels of economic development. Our findings indicate persistence in democratic institutions over time, and suggest the importance of traditional local institutions for well-functioning national-level institutions. </jats:p>
research_question: Is a tradition of village democracy associated with the presence of national democracy and better institutional outcomes today?
answer: Yes, village democratic traditions are associated with national democracy today, more pro-democratic attitudes, better quality institutions, and higher economic development, indicating persistence in democratic institutions over time.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating the importance of traditional local institutions for well-functioning national-level institutions, providing evidence for institutional persistence and the transmission of democratic practices from local to national levels.

author: Natalie Bau
title: Traditional Institutions in Modern Times: Dowries as Pensions When Sons Migrate
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper uses newly collected data on the allocation of dowry to examine its role in resolving intergenerational frictions around migration in India. Migration disrupts traditional elderly support structures, in which sons live near their parents and care for them in old age. We develop a model in which dowry can promote migration by allowing sons to make upfront transfers to their parents and ease constraints on income sharing. To test this hypothesis, we collect two new data sets that measure the distribution of dowry between family members. We document for the first time that net transfers of dowry to a man’s parents are common but far from universal. Consistent with using dowry for income sharing, such transfers occur more often when sons migrate, especially when they work in higher-earning occupations. In nationally representative data, migration rates are higher in areas with stronger historical dowry traditions. Finally, exploiting a large-scale highway construction program, we show that men from areas with stronger historical dowry traditions migrate more when migration costs fall. Our findings provide some clues as to why dowry persists despite its well-documented adverse consequences.</jats:p>
research_question: How does dowry function as a mechanism to resolve intergenerational frictions around migration in India, particularly in facilitating elderly support when sons migrate away from their parents?
answer: Dowry serves as a pension-like mechanism that promotes migration by enabling sons to make upfront transfers to their parents, with net transfers to parents occurring more frequently when sons migrate to higher-earning occupations, and men from areas with stronger historical dowry traditions showing higher migration rates when migration costs fall.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel economic explanation for the persistence of dowry practices by examining their role in facilitating migration and intergenerational income sharing, offering new insights into why dowry continues despite its well-documented adverse consequences, using newly collected data that documents for the first time the distribution patterns of dowry transfers between family members.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: US Food Aid and Civil Conflict
abstract: <jats:p> We study the effect of US food aid on conflict in recipient countries. Our analysis exploits time variation in food aid shipments due to changes in US wheat production and cross-sectional variation in a country's tendency to receive any US food aid. According to our estimates, an increase in US food aid increases the incidence and duration of civil conflicts, but has no robust effect on interstate conflicts or the onset of civil conflicts. We also provide suggestive evidence that the effects are most pronounced in countries with a recent history of civil conflict. (JEL D74, F35, O17, O19, Q11, Q18) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of US food aid on conflict in recipient countries?
answer: An increase in US food aid increases the incidence and duration of civil conflicts, but has no robust effect on interstate conflicts or the onset of civil conflicts, with effects most pronounced in countries with a recent history of civil conflict.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on the relationship between foreign aid and conflict by specifically examining US food aid's impact on different types of conflicts, using novel identification strategies that exploit variation in US wheat production and countries' propensity to receive food aid.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Religious Conversion in Colonial Africa
abstract: Within economics, there has been a recent effort to better understand the notion of culture, typically defined as beliefs, values, and norms held by individuals. Empirical work has focused on identifying systematic cultural differences between individuals from different ethnic and national backgrounds. More recently, attention has turned to the historical origins of cultural differences (e.g., Luigi Guiso, Paolo Sapienza, and Luigi Zingales 2008; Nathan Nunn and Leonard Wantchekon 2009). Colonial Africa provides a natural laboratory to examine how an external intervention can have lasting impacts on people’s beliefs and values. This study examines the effect of European missionary activities in colonial Africa on the subsequent evolution of culture, as measured by religious beliefs. The empirical results show that descendants of ethnic groups that experienced greater missionary contact are today more likely to self-identify as Christian. This correlation provides evidence that foreign missionaries altered the religious beliefs of Africans, and that these beliefs persist as they are passed on from parents to children. Put differently, the results show that historic events can have a lasting impact on culture. The findings also provide rare empirical evidence of the historical determinants of longrun religious conversion. Studies of conversion typically focus on contemporary determinants (see Jason Hwang and Robert Barro 2007 and the references therein). Although a number of studies have examined the long-term impacts of missionary activities, they have not considered their long-run impacts on religious beliefs and values (e.g., Robert D. Woodberry 2004). One of the few papers that consider a historical determinant of long-run conversion is by Murat Religious Conversion in Colonial Africa

author: Nathan Nunn
title: The Long-Term Effects of Africa's Slave Trades<sup>*</sup>

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Understanding Cultural Persistence and Change
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We examine a determinant of cultural persistence that has emerged from a class of models in evolutionary anthropology: the similarity of the environment across generations. Within these models, when the environment is more stable across generations, the traits that have evolved up to the previous generation are more likely to be suitable for the current generation. In equilibrium, a greater value is placed on tradition and there is greater cultural persistence. We test this hypothesis by measuring the variability of climatic measures across 20-year generations from 500 to 1900. Employing a variety of tests that use different samples and empirical strategies, we find that populations with ancestors who lived in environments with more cross-generational instability place less importance on maintaining tradition today and exhibit less cultural persistence.</jats:p>
research_question: How does environmental stability across generations affect cultural persistence and the value placed on tradition?
answer: Populations with ancestors who lived in environments with more cross-generational instability place less importance on maintaining tradition today and exhibit less cultural persistence, while more stable environments across generations lead to greater cultural persistence.
positioning_statement: This paper tests a hypothesis that has emerged from evolutionary anthropology models by empirically examining the relationship between environmental stability and cultural persistence, contributing empirical evidence to theoretical models in this field.

author: Natalie Bau
title: Heterogeneity in School Value Added and the Private Premium
abstract: <jats:p> We estimate and validate test score–based measures of school quality (school value added, or SVA) in Pakistan. We document substantial variation in SVA within villages and within the public and private sectors, leading to a wide range of possible estimates of the private premium. We also show that parents value SVA. Heterogeneity in parental demand for quality helps explain both the evolution of the market over time and cross-market variation in school quality. The supply side responds to parental demand for quality in the private sector, but there is no evidence it does so in the public sector. (JEL H44, I21, I26, I28, O15) </jats:p>
research_question: How does heterogeneity in school quality (measured by school value added) affect estimates of the private premium in education, and how do parents and schools respond to quality differences in Pakistan?
answer: There is substantial variation in school value added within both public and private sectors in Pakistan, leading to a wide range of possible estimates of the private premium. Parents value school quality, and while private schools respond to parental demand for quality, public schools do not show evidence of such responsiveness.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on public versus private education by introducing and validating test score-based measures of school quality (school value added) in a developing country context, and by examining how quality heterogeneity affects traditional estimates of private premiums and market dynamics.

author: Natalie Bau
title: Crowding in Private Quality: The Equilibrium Effects of Public Spending in Education
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We estimate the equilibrium effects of a public school grant program administered through school councils in Pakistani villages with multiple public and private schools and clearly defined catchment boundaries. The program was randomized at the village level, allowing us to estimate its causal impact on the market. Four years after the start of the program, test scores were 0.2 standard deviations higher in public schools. We find evidence of an education multiplier: test scores in private schools were also 0.2 standard deviations higher in treated markets. Consistent with standard models of product differentiation, the education multiplier is greater for those private schools that faced a greater threat to their market power. Accounting for private sector responses increases the program’s cost-effectiveness by 85% and affects how a policy maker would target spending. Given that markets with several public and private schools are now pervasive in low- and middle-income countries, prudent policy requires us to account for private sector responses to public policy, both in policies’ design and evaluation.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the equilibrium effects of public school spending on both public and private school quality in markets with multiple competing schools?
answer: Public school grants increased test scores by 0.2 standard deviations in public schools and generated an 'education multiplier' effect, also raising test scores by 0.2 standard deviations in private schools, with larger effects for private schools facing greater threats to their market power.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in existing literature by examining equilibrium effects across entire education markets rather than focusing solely on direct effects on public schools, emphasizing that prudent policy design and evaluation in low- and middle-income countries requires accounting for private sector responses to public interventions.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: The Slave Trade and the Origins of Mistrust in Africa
abstract: <jats:p> We show that current differences in trust levels within Africa can be traced back to the transatlantic and Indian Ocean slave trades. Combining contemporary individual-level survey data with historical data on slave shipments by ethnic group, we find that individuals whose ancestors were heavily raided during the slave trade are less trusting today. Evidence from a variety of identification strategies suggests that the relationship is causal. Examining causal mechanisms, we show that most of the impact of the slave trade is through factors that are internal to the individual, such as cultural norms, beliefs, and values. (JEL J15, N57, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: Can current differences in trust levels within Africa be traced back to the historical transatlantic and Indian Ocean slave trades?
answer: Yes, individuals whose ancestors were heavily raided during the slave trade are less trusting today, and this relationship is causal, operating primarily through internal factors such as cultural norms, beliefs, and values.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by establishing a causal link between historical slave trade exposure and contemporary trust levels in Africa, using a combination of individual-level survey data and historical slave shipment data by ethnic group, with evidence from multiple identification strategies to support causality.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Immigrants and the Making of America
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the effects of European immigration to the U.S. during the Age of Mass Migration (1850–1920) on economic prosperity. Exploiting cross-county variation in immigration that arises from the interaction of fluctuations in aggregate immigrant flows and of the gradual expansion of the railway network, we find that counties with more historical immigration have higher income, less poverty, less unemployment, higher rates of urbanization, and greater educational attainment today. The long-run effects seem to capture the persistence of short-run benefits, including greater industrialization, increased agricultural productivity, and more innovation.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of European immigration to the U.S. during the Age of Mass Migration (1850–1920) on economic prosperity?
answer: Counties with more historical immigration have higher income, less poverty, less unemployment, higher rates of urbanization, and greater educational attainment today, with long-run effects capturing the persistence of short-run benefits including greater industrialization, increased agricultural productivity, and more innovation.
positioning_statement: This paper studies the long-term economic effects of historical European immigration during the Age of Mass Migration by exploiting cross-county variation in immigration that arises from the interaction of fluctuations in aggregate immigrant flows and the gradual expansion of the railway network.

author: Nathan Nunn
title:
On the Origins of Gender Roles: Women and the Plough
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The study examines the historical origins of existing cross-cultural differences in beliefs and values regarding the appropriate role of women in society. We test the hypothesis that traditional agricultural practices influenced the historical gender division of labor and the evolution of gender norms. We find that, consistent with existing hypotheses, the descendants of societies that traditionally practiced plough agriculture today have less equal gender norms, measured using reported gender-role attitudes and female participation in the workplace, politics, and entrepreneurial activities. Our results hold looking across countries, across districts within countries, and across ethnicities within districts. To test for the importance of cultural persistence, we examine the children of immigrants living in Europe and the United States. We find that even among these individuals, all born and raised in the same country, those with a heritage of traditional plough use exhibit less equal beliefs about gender roles today.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the historical origins of existing cross-cultural differences in beliefs and values regarding the appropriate role of women in society?
answer: Traditional agricultural practices, specifically plough agriculture, influenced the historical gender division of labor and evolution of gender norms. Descendants of societies that traditionally practiced plough agriculture today have less equal gender norms, as measured by gender-role attitudes and female participation in workplace, politics, and entrepreneurial activities.
positioning_statement: The paper tests existing hypotheses about the relationship between traditional agricultural practices and gender norms, contributing to the literature by providing empirical evidence across multiple levels of analysis (countries, districts within countries, and ethnicities within districts) and examining cultural persistence through immigrant populations.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Segmentary Lineage Organization and Conflict in Sub‐Saharan Africa
abstract: <jats:p>We test the longstanding hypothesis that ethnic groups organized around “segmentary lineages” are more prone to conflict. Ethnographic accounts suggest that in such societies, which are characterized by strong allegiances to distant relatives, individuals are obligated to come to the aid of fellow lineage members when they become involved in conflicts. As a consequence, small disagreements often escalate into larger‐scale conflicts involving many individuals. We test for a link between segmentary lineage organization and conflict across ethnic groups in sub‐Saharan Africa. Using a number of estimation strategies, including a regression discontinuity design at ethnic boundaries, we find that segmentary lineage societies experience more conflicts, and particularly ones that are retaliatory, long in duration, and large in scale.</jats:p>
research_question: Are ethnic groups organized around segmentary lineages more prone to conflict in sub-Saharan Africa?
answer: Yes, segmentary lineage societies experience more conflicts, particularly ones that are retaliatory, long in duration, and large in scale.
positioning_statement: This paper tests a longstanding hypothesis from ethnographic literature that suggests segmentary lineage organization leads to conflict escalation due to obligations to aid fellow lineage members, providing empirical evidence for this theoretical relationship using multiple estimation strategies including regression discontinuity design.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Transhumant Pastoralism, Climate Change, and Conflict in Africa
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We consider the effects of climate change on seasonally migrant populations that herd livestock—i.e. transhumant pastoralists—in Africa. Traditionally, transhumant pastoralists benefit from a cooperative relationship with sedentary agriculturalists whereby arable land is used for crop farming in the wet season and animal grazing in the dry season. Rainfall scarcity can disrupt this arrangement by inducing pastoral groups to migrate to agricultural lands before the harvest, causing conflict to emerge. We examine this hypothesis by combining ethnographic information on the traditional locations of transhumant pastoralists and sedentary agriculturalists with high-resolution data on the location and timing of rainfall and violent conflict events in Africa from 1989 to 2018. We find that reduced rainfall in the territory of transhumant pastoralists leads to conflict in neighbouring areas. Consistent with the proposed mechanism, the conflicts are concentrated in agricultural areas; they occur during the wet season and not the dry season; and they are due to rainfall’s impact on plant biomass growth. Since pastoralists tend to be Muslim and agriculturalists Christian, this mechanism accounts for a sizable proportion of the rapid rise in religious conflict observed in recent decades. Regarding policy responses, we find that development aid projects tend not to mitigate the effects that we document. By contrast, the effects are reduced when transhumant pastoralists have greater power in national government, suggesting that more equal political representation is conducive to peace.</jats:p>
research_question: How does climate change affect the relationship between transhumant pastoralists and sedentary agriculturalists in Africa, and does rainfall scarcity lead to conflict between these groups?
answer: Reduced rainfall in transhumant pastoralist territories leads to conflict in neighboring agricultural areas during the wet season, as pastoralists migrate earlier than traditional arrangements allow, disrupting the cooperative land-use system and contributing significantly to the rise in religious conflict in recent decades.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the climate-conflict literature by examining a specific mechanism linking climate change to violence through the disruption of traditional cooperative arrangements between seasonally migrant pastoralists and sedentary farmers, using high-resolution spatial and temporal data to test ethnographically-informed hypotheses about when and where climate-induced conflicts occur.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Fertility and the Plough
abstract: <jats:p> This paper provides evidence that the form of agriculture traditionally practiced—intensive plough agriculture versus shifting hoe agriculture—affected historic norms and preferences about fertility, and that these norms persist, affecting observed fertility around the world today. </jats:p>
research_question: How did traditional agricultural practices (intensive plough agriculture versus shifting hoe agriculture) affect historic fertility norms and preferences, and do these norms persist to influence contemporary fertility patterns?
answer: The form of agriculture traditionally practiced did affect historic norms and preferences about fertility, with these norms persisting and continuing to affect observed fertility patterns around the world today.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by establishing a causal link between historical agricultural practices and contemporary fertility outcomes, demonstrating the persistence of cultural norms across time periods.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Why Being Wrong Can Be Right: Magical Warfare Technologies and the Persistence of False Beliefs
abstract: <jats:p> Across human societies, one sees many examples of deeply rooted and widely held beliefs that are almost certainly untrue. Examples include beliefs about witchcraft, magic, ordeals, and superstitions. Why are such incorrect beliefs so prevalent and how do they persist? We consider this question through an examination of superstitions and magic associated with conflict in the Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo. Focusing on superstitions related to bullet-proofing, we provide theory and case-study evidence showing how these incorrect beliefs persist. Although harmful at the individual-level, we show that they generate Pareto efficient outcomes that have group-level benefits. </jats:p>
research_question: Why are incorrect beliefs (such as those about witchcraft, magic, ordeals, and superstitions) so prevalent across human societies and how do they persist?
answer: Although harmful at the individual level, false beliefs persist because they generate Pareto efficient outcomes that provide group-level benefits, as demonstrated through the case study of bullet-proofing superstitions in conflict situations in Eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the broader question of why deeply rooted and widely held false beliefs exist across human societies by providing a novel theoretical framework and empirical evidence that explains their persistence through group-level efficiency benefits, using magical warfare technologies as a specific case study.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Commercial Imperialism? Political Influence and Trade During the Cold War
abstract: <jats:p> We provide evidence that increased political influence, arising from CIA interventions during the Cold War, was used to create a larger foreign market for American products. Following CIA interventions, imports from the US increased dramatically, while total exports to the US were unaffected. The surge in imports was concentrated in industries in which the US had a comparative disadvantage, not a comparative advantage. Our analysis is able to rule out decreased trade costs, changing political ideology, and an increase in US loans and grants as alternative explanations. We provide evidence that the increased imports arose through direct purchases of American products by foreign governments. (JEL D72, F14, F54, N42, N72) </jats:p>
research_question: Did increased political influence from CIA interventions during the Cold War create larger foreign markets for American products?
answer: Yes, CIA interventions led to dramatic increases in imports from the US to targeted countries, particularly in industries where the US had comparative disadvantage, through direct government purchases of American products.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new evidence on the economic consequences of political influence during the Cold War by demonstrating that CIA interventions had measurable trade effects, ruling out alternative explanations like decreased trade costs, changing political ideology, or increased US aid.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Keeping It in the Family: Lineage Organization and the Scope of Trust in Sub-Saharan Africa
abstract: <jats:p> We present evidence that the traditional structure of society is an important determinant of the scope of trust today. Within Africa, individuals belonging to ethnic groups that organized society using segmentary lineages exhibit a more limited scope of trust, measured by the gap between trust in relatives and trust in non-relatives. This trust gap arises because of lower levels of trust in non-relatives and not higher levels of trust in relatives. A causal interpretation of these correlations is supported by the fact that the effects are primarily found in rural areas where these forms of organization are still prevalent. </jats:p>
research_question: How does the traditional structure of society, specifically segmentary lineage organization, affect the scope of trust in Sub-Saharan Africa?
answer: Individuals from ethnic groups that traditionally organized society using segmentary lineages exhibit a more limited scope of trust, characterized by a larger gap between trust in relatives versus non-relatives, primarily due to lower levels of trust in non-relatives rather than higher trust in relatives.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that traditional social structures are important determinants of contemporary trust patterns, with effects being strongest in rural areas where these organizational forms remain prevalent, supporting a causal interpretation of the relationship between historical social organization and current trust behaviors.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Bride Price and Female Education
abstract: We document an important consequence of bride price, a payment made by the groom to the bride’s family at marriage. Revisiting Indonesia’s school construction program, we find that among ethnic groups without the custom, it had no effect on girls’ schooling. Among ethnic groups with the custom, it had large positive effects. We show (theoretically and empirically) that this is because a daughter’s education, by increasing the amount of money parents receive at marriage, generates an additional incentive for parents to educate their daughters. We replicate these findings in Zambia, a country that had a similar large-scale school construction program.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: Understanding Ethnic Identity in Africa: Evidence from the Implicit Association Test (IAT)
abstract: <jats:p> We use a variant of the Implicit Association Test (IAT) to examine individuals' implicit attitudes towards various ethnic groups. Using a population from the Democratic Republic of Congo, we find that the IAT measures show evidence of an implicit bias in favor of one's own ethnicity. Individuals have implicit views of their own ethnic group that are more positive than their implicit views of other ethnic groups. We find this implicit bias to be quantitatively smaller than the (explicit) bias one finds when using self-reported attitudes about different ethnic groups. </jats:p>
research_question: What are individuals' implicit attitudes towards various ethnic groups, and how do these compare to explicit attitudes?
answer: Individuals exhibit implicit bias in favor of their own ethnicity, with more positive implicit views of their own ethnic group compared to other ethnic groups, though this implicit bias is quantitatively smaller than explicit bias found in self-reported attitudes.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by applying the Implicit Association Test (IAT) methodology to examine ethnic identity and bias in an African context (Democratic Republic of Congo), providing empirical evidence on the distinction between implicit and explicit ethnic attitudes.

author: Nathan Nunn
title: The Evolution of Culture and Institutions: Evidence From the Kuba Kingdom
abstract: We use variation in historical state centralization to examine the long‐term impact of institutions on cultural norms. The Kuba Kingdom, established in Central Africa in the early 17th century by King Shyaam, had more developed state institutions than the other independent villages and chieftaincies in the region. It had an unwritten constitution, separation of political powers, a judicial system with courts and juries, a police force, a military, taxation, and significant public goods provision. Comparing individuals from the Kuba Kingdom to those from just outside the Kingdom, we find that centralized formal institutions are associated with weaker norms of rule following and a greater propensity to cheat for material gain. This finding is consistent with recent models where endogenous investments to inculcate values in children decline when there is an increase in the effectiveness of formal institutions that enforce socially desirable behavior. Consistent with such a mechanism, we find that Kuba parents believe it is less important to teach children values related to rule‐following behaviors.

author: Nathaniel Baum-Snow
title: Changes in Transportation Infrastructure and Commuting Patterns in US Metropolitan Areas, 1960–2000

author: Nathaniel Baum-Snow
title: The Microgeography of Housing Supply
abstract: We perform a comprehensive neighborhood-level analysis of housing supply. Predictions of floor space and housing unit supply elasticities using our estimates average 0.5 and 0.3 across all urban neighborhoods in the United States, exhibiting greater variation within than between metro regions. New construction accounts for about 50% of unit supply responses, with important additional roles for teardowns and renovations. Supply responses grow with central business district distance mostly from the increasing availability of undeveloped land, flatter land, and less regulation. Identification comes from variation in labor demand shocks to commuting destinations, as aggregated using insights from a quantitative spatial equilibrium model.

author: Nathaniel Baum-Snow
title: School Desegregation, School Choice, and Changes in Residential Location Patterns by Race
abstract: <jats:p> This paper examines the residential location and school choice responses to the desegregation of large urban public school districts. We decompose the well documented decline in white public enrollment following desegregation into migration to suburban districts and increased private school enrollment and find that migration was the more prevalent response. Desegregation caused black public enrollment to increase significantly outside of the South, mostly by slowing decentralization of black households to the suburbs, and large black private school enrollment declines in southern districts. Central district school desegregation generated only a small portion of overall urban population decentralization between 1960 and 1990. (JEL H75, I21, J15, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What were the residential location and school choice responses to the desegregation of large urban public school districts?
answer: Migration to suburban districts was the more prevalent white response to desegregation compared to increased private school enrollment. Desegregation caused black public enrollment to increase significantly outside the South by slowing black household decentralization to suburbs, while causing large black private school enrollment declines in southern districts. Central district school desegregation generated only a small portion of overall urban population decentralization between 1960 and 1990.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the well-documented finding of declining white public enrollment following desegregation by decomposing this decline into its component parts (migration vs. private school enrollment) and examining the broader residential location patterns and demographic changes during urban decentralization from 1960-1990.

author: Nathaniel Baum-Snow
title: Local Productivity Spillovers
abstract: <jats:p> Using Canadian administrative data, this paper presents evidence of revenue and productivity spillovers across firms at fine spatial scales. Accounting for the endogenous sorting of firms across space, we estimate an average elasticity of firm revenue and productivity with respect to the average quality of other firms within 75 meters of 0.024. We find scant evidence that the average firm benefits from being surrounded by a greater amount of economic activity at this spatial scale. Sorting of higher-quality firms into more productive locations and higher average and aggregate quality peer groups is salient in the data. (JEL D22, D24, G32, L25, R11, R32) </jats:p>
research_question: Do firms experience revenue and productivity spillovers from other firms located in close spatial proximity, and what is the magnitude of these local spillover effects?
answer: There are positive but small productivity spillovers across firms at fine spatial scales, with an average elasticity of firm revenue and productivity with respect to the average quality of other firms within 75 meters of 0.024. However, there is little evidence that firms benefit from simply being surrounded by more economic activity at this spatial scale.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on productivity spillovers by using Canadian administrative data to examine spillover effects at very fine spatial scales (75 meters) while explicitly accounting for the endogenous sorting of firms across space, addressing a key methodological challenge in previous spillover studies.

author: Nathaniel Baum-Snow
title: Did Highways Cause Suburbanization?
