title: Understanding the City Size Wage Gap

author: Navin Kartik
title: Strategic Communication with Lying Costs

author: Navin Kartik
title: Muddled Information
abstract: We study a model of signaling in which agents are heterogeneous on two dimensions. An agent’s natural action is the action taken in the absence of signaling concerns. Her gaming ability parameterizes the cost of increasing the action. Equilibrium behavior muddles information across dimensions. As incentives to take higher actions increase—due to higher stakes or more manipulable signaling technology—more information is revealed about gaming ability, and less about natural actions. We explore a new externality: showing agents’ actions to additional observers can worsen information for existing observers. Applications to credit scoring, school testing, and web searching are discussed.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Informative Cheap Talk in Elections

author: Navin Kartik
title: Signaling Character in Electoral Competition
abstract: <jats:p> We study a one-dimensional Hotelling-Downs model of electoral competition with the following innovation: a fraction of candidates have “character” and are exogenously committed to a campaign platform; this is unobservable to voters. Character is desirable, and a voter's utility is a convex combination of standard policy preferences and her assessment of a candidate's character. This structure induces a signaling game between strategic candidates and voters, since a policy platform affects voters' utilities not only directly, but also indirectly through inferences about a candidate's character. The model generates a number of predictions, starting with a failure of the median voter theorem. (JEL D72, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the presence of candidates with unobservable 'character' (commitment to campaign platforms) affect electoral competition and voting behavior in a spatial voting model?
answer: The presence of candidates with unobservable character creates a signaling game where policy platforms serve dual purposes - directly affecting voter utility through policy preferences and indirectly through character inferences - leading to a failure of the median voter theorem and altered electoral dynamics.
positioning_statement: This paper innovates on the traditional one-dimensional Hotelling-Downs model of electoral competition by introducing the concept of candidate 'character' as an unobservable trait that voters value, creating a signaling dimension absent from standard spatial voting models.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Opinions as Incentives

author: Navin Kartik
title: Selecting Cheap-Talk Equilibria

author: Navin Kartik
title: Contests for Experimentation

author: Navin Kartik
title: Delegation in Veto Bargaining
abstract: <jats:p>A proposer requires a veto player’s approval to change a status quo. Proposer is uncertain about Vetoer’s preferences. We show that Vetoer is typically given a non-singleton menu, or delegation set, of options to pick from. The optimal set balances the extent of compromise with the risk of a veto. We identify conditions for certain delegation sets to emerge, including “full delegation”: Vetoer can choose any action between the status quo and Proposer’s ideal action. By contrast to expertise-based delegation, Proposer gives less discretion to Vetoer when their preferences are more (likely to be) aligned. (JEL D72, D82)</jats:p>
research_question: How should a proposer optimally delegate decision-making authority to a veto player when the proposer is uncertain about the veto player's preferences?
answer: The proposer should typically offer a non-singleton menu (delegation set) of options that balances the extent of compromise with the risk of a veto, and counterintuitively, should give less discretion to the veto player when their preferences are more likely to be aligned.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with expertise-based delegation literature by showing that when preferences are more aligned, the proposer gives less discretion to the veto player, which is opposite to the typical finding in expertise-based delegation models.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Optimal Contracts for Experimentation

author: Navin Kartik
title: Test-Optional Admissions
abstract: <jats:p> Many US colleges now use test-optional admissions. A frequent claim is that by not seeing standardized test scores, a college can admit a student body it prefers, say, with more diversity. But how can observing less information improve decisions? This paper proposes that test-optional policies are a response to social pressure on admission decisions. We model a college that bears disutility when it makes admission decisions that “society” dislikes. Going test optional allows the college to reduce its “disagreement cost.” We analyze how missing scores are imputed and the consequences for the college, students, and society. (JEL I23, I28) </jats:p>
research_question: How can observing less information (by not seeing standardized test scores) improve college admission decisions, particularly in achieving goals like increased diversity?
answer: Test-optional policies allow colleges to reduce 'disagreement costs' with society by avoiding admission decisions that society dislikes, even though this means making decisions with less information.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a novel explanation for test-optional admissions as a response to social pressure, contrasting with the frequent claim that these policies simply help colleges admit preferred student bodies with more diversity.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Single-Crossing Differences in Convex Environments
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>An agent’s preferences depend on an ordered parameter or type. We characterize the set of utility functions with single-crossing differences (SCD) in convex environments. These include preferences over lotteries, both in expected utility and rank-dependent utility frameworks, and preferences over bundles of goods and over consumption streams. Our notion of SCD does not presume an order on the choice space. This unordered SCD is necessary and sufficient for “interval choice” comparative statics. We present applications to cheap talk, observational learning, and collective choice, showing how convex environments arise in these problems and how SCD/interval choice are useful. Methodologically, our main characterization stems from a result on linear aggregations of single-crossing functions.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we characterize the set of utility functions with single-crossing differences (SCD) in convex environments where the choice space does not have a presumed order?
answer: The paper provides a characterization of utility functions with single-crossing differences in convex environments (including preferences over lotteries, bundles of goods, and consumption streams) and shows that unordered SCD is necessary and sufficient for 'interval choice' comparative statics, with the main characterization stemming from a result on linear aggregations of single-crossing functions.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the existing literature on single-crossing differences by developing a notion of SCD that does not presume an order on the choice space, applying it to convex environments that include various preference frameworks (expected utility, rank-dependent utility), and demonstrating its methodological contribution through applications to cheap talk, observational learning, and collective choice problems.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Sequential Veto Bargaining With Incomplete Information
abstract: <jats:p>We study sequential bargaining between a proposer and a veto player. Both have single‐peaked preferences, but the proposer is uncertain about the veto player's ideal point. The proposer cannot commit to future proposals. When players are patient, there can be equilibria with Coasian dynamics: the veto player's private information can largely nullify proposer's bargaining power. Our main result, however, is that under some conditions there also are equilibria in which the proposer obtains the high payoff that he would with commitment power. The driving force is that the veto player's single‐peaked preferences give the proposer an option to “leapfrog,” that is, to secure agreement from only low‐surplus types early on to credibly extract surplus from high types later. Methodologically, we exploit the connection between sequential bargaining and static mechanism design.</jats:p>
research_question: How does incomplete information about the veto player's preferences affect bargaining outcomes in sequential veto bargaining when the proposer cannot commit to future proposals?
answer: Under certain conditions, there exist equilibria where the proposer can obtain high payoffs equivalent to having commitment power by using a 'leapfrog' strategy - securing agreement from low-surplus types early to credibly extract surplus from high-surplus types later, despite the potential for Coasian dynamics that would otherwise nullify the proposer's bargaining power.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the sequential bargaining literature by showing that proposers can overcome the standard Coasian result (where private information eliminates bargaining power) through strategic use of single-peaked preferences, and methodologically connects sequential bargaining models to static mechanism design.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Information Validates the Prior: A Theorem on Bayesian Updating and Applications
abstract: <jats:p>We develop a result on expected posteriors for Bayesians with heterogenous priors, dubbed information validates the prior (IVP). Under familiar ordering requirements, Anne expects a (Blackwell) more informative experiment to bring Bob’s posterior mean closer to Anne’s prior mean. We apply the result in two contexts of games of asymmetric information: voluntary testing or certification, and costly signaling or falsification. IVP can be used to determine how an agent’s behavior responds to additional exogenous or endogenous information. We discuss economic implications. (JEL C11, D82, D84)</jats:p>
research_question: How do expected posteriors behave for Bayesian agents with heterogeneous priors when information quality changes, and what are the implications for strategic behavior in games of asymmetric information?
answer: The key finding is the 'Information Validates the Prior' (IVP) theorem: under familiar ordering requirements, a more informative (Blackwell) experiment causes one agent to expect another agent's posterior mean to move closer to their own prior mean, with applications showing how this affects behavior in voluntary testing/certification and costly signaling/falsification contexts.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theoretical result (IVP theorem) on Bayesian updating with heterogeneous priors and applies it to analyze strategic behavior in asymmetric information games, specifically voluntary testing/certification and costly signaling/falsification contexts.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Beyond Unbounded Beliefs: How Preferences and Information Interplay in Social Learning
abstract:
<jats:p>When does society eventually learn the truth, or take the correct action, via observational learning? In a general model of sequential learning over social networks, we identify a simple condition for learning dubbed 
            <jats:italic>excludability</jats:italic>. Excludability is a joint property of agents' preferences and their information. We develop two classes of preferences and information that jointly satisfy excludability: (i) for a one‐dimensional state, preferences with single‐crossing differences and a new informational condition, directionally unbounded beliefs; and (ii) for a multi‐dimensional state, intermediate preferences and subexponential location‐shift information. These applications exemplify that with multiple states, “unbounded beliefs” is not only unnecessary for learning, but incompatible with familiar informational structures like normal information. Unbounded beliefs demands that a single agent can identify the correct action. Excludability, on the other hand, only requires that a single agent must be able to displace any wrong action, even if she cannot take the correct action.
          </jats:p>
research_question: When does society eventually learn the truth, or take the correct action, via observational learning?
answer: Society learns when 'excludability' is satisfied - a joint property of agents' preferences and information that only requires a single agent to be able to displace any wrong action, rather than necessarily identify the correct action.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the existing literature's reliance on 'unbounded beliefs' for social learning, showing it is unnecessary and incompatible with familiar informational structures like normal information, and instead proposes the more general and practical condition of 'excludability' that works across multiple dimensional states and various preference-information combinations.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Pandering to Persuade
abstract: <jats:p> An agent advises a principal on selecting one of multiple projects or an outside option. The agent is privately informed about the projects' benefits and shares the principal's preferences except for not internalizing her value from the outside option. We show that for moderate outside option values, strategic communication is characterized by pandering: the agent biases his recommendation toward “conditionally better-looking” projects, even when both parties would be better off with some other project. A project that has lower expected value can be conditionally better-looking. We develop comparative statics and implications of pandering. Pandering is also induced by an optimal mechanism without transfers. (JEL D23, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: How does strategic communication between an informed agent and a principal work when the agent advises on project selection but doesn't fully internalize the principal's outside option value?
answer: For moderate outside option values, strategic communication is characterized by 'pandering' - the agent biases recommendations toward 'conditionally better-looking' projects even when both parties would benefit more from other projects, and projects with lower expected value can appear conditionally better-looking.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the strategic communication literature by identifying and analyzing the phenomenon of 'pandering' in advisor-advisee relationships, showing how misaligned preferences regarding outside options lead to systematic bias in recommendations even under optimal mechanisms.

author: Navin Kartik
title: Information Aggregation in Standing and Ad Hoc Committees

author: Ned Augenblick
title: The Sunk-Cost Fallacy in Penny Auctions

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: The Psychology of Tail Events: Progress and Challenges
abstract: <jats:p> Over the past decade there has been a surge of interest in “tail events,” or rare, high-impact events. In this article, I start by summarizing some recent progress in our understanding of the psychology of tail events. I suggest that much of this progress has centered on the concept of “probability weighting” and, in particular, on applications of this concept in various fields of economics. I then describe some major open questions in this area. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the current state of understanding regarding the psychology of tail events (rare, high-impact events) and what are the major open questions in this research area?
answer: Recent progress in understanding the psychology of tail events has centered primarily on the concept of 'probability weighting' and its applications across various fields of economics, though significant open questions remain in this area.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as a comprehensive review that synthesizes recent progress in tail events psychology research over the past decade, while identifying gaps and future research directions in the field.

author: Ned Augenblick
title: An Experiment on Time Preference and Misprediction in Unpleasant Tasks

author: Ned Augenblick
title: Ballot Position, Choice Fatigue, and Voter Behaviour

author: Ned Augenblick
title: Overinference from Weak Signals and Underinference from Strong Signals
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>When people receive new information, sometimes they revise their beliefs too much, and sometimes too little. We show that a key driver of whether people overinfer or underinfer is the strength of the information. Based on a model in which people know which direction to update in, but not exactly how much to update, we hypothesize that people will overinfer from weak signals and underinfer from strong signals. We then test this hypothesis across four different environments: abstract experiments, a naturalistic experiment, sports betting markets, and financial markets. In each environment, our consistent and robust finding is overinference from weak signals and underinference from strong signals. Our framework and findings can help harmonize apparently contradictory results from the experimental and empirical literatures.</jats:p>
research_question: What determines whether people overinfer or underinfer when they receive new information, and specifically, how does the strength of information signals affect the degree of belief updating?
answer: The strength of information is a key driver of inference patterns: people systematically overinfer from weak signals and underinfer from strong signals across multiple environments including abstract experiments, naturalistic experiments, sports betting markets, and financial markets.
positioning_statement: This paper aims to harmonize apparently contradictory results from the experimental and empirical literatures by providing a unified framework that explains when and why people exhibit overinference versus underinference based on signal strength.

author: Ned Augenblick
title: Belief Movement, Uncertainty Reduction, and Rational Updating
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>When a Bayesian learns new information and changes her beliefs, she must on average become concomitantly more certain about the state of the world. Consequently, it is rare for a Bayesian to frequently shift beliefs substantially while remaining relatively uncertain, or, conversely, become very confident with relatively little belief movement. We formalize this intuition by developing specific measures of movement and uncertainty reduction given a Bayesian’s changing beliefs over time, showing that these measures are equal in expectation and creating consequent statistical tests for Bayesianess. We then show connections between these two core concepts and four common psychological biases, suggesting that the test might be particularly good at detecting these biases. We provide support for this conclusion by simulating the performance of our test and other martingale tests. Finally, we apply our test to data sets of individual, algorithmic, and market beliefs.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we formally measure and test whether belief updating follows Bayesian rationality by examining the relationship between belief movement and uncertainty reduction over time?
answer: For a Bayesian learner, belief movement and uncertainty reduction are equal in expectation - substantial belief shifts must be accompanied by proportional increases in certainty about the world state, and this relationship can be used to create statistical tests that effectively detect deviations from rational updating and common psychological biases.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on testing Bayesian rationality by developing novel measures that connect belief movement to uncertainty reduction, extending beyond existing martingale tests to create more effective detection methods for psychological biases in belief updating across individual, algorithmic, and market contexts.

author: Ned Augenblick
title:
Working over Time: Dynamic Inconsistency in Real Effort Tasks
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Experimental tests of dynamically inconsistent time preferences have largely relied on choices over time-dated monetary rewards. Several recent studies have failed to find the standard patterns of present bias. However, such monetary studies contain often-discussed confounds. In this article, we sidestep these confounds and investigate choices over consumption (real effort) in a longitudinal experiment. We pair this effort study with a companion monetary discounting study. We confirm very limited time inconsistency in monetary choices. However, subjects show considerably more present bias in effort. Furthermore, present bias in the allocation of work has predictive power for demand of a meaningfully binding commitment device. Therefore our findings validate a key implication of models of dynamic inconsistency, with corresponding policy implications.</jats:p>
research_question: Do people exhibit dynamic inconsistency and present bias when making choices over real effort tasks, and does this differ from their behavior in monetary discounting decisions?
answer: Subjects show very limited time inconsistency in monetary choices but exhibit considerably more present bias when allocating effort over time. Present bias in work allocation also predicts demand for commitment devices, validating key implications of dynamic inconsistency models.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the failure of recent experimental studies to find standard patterns of present bias in monetary discounting by sidestepping the confounds inherent in monetary studies and instead investigating choices over consumption (real effort) in a longitudinal experiment paired with a companion monetary discounting study.

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: Stocks as Lotteries: The Implications of Probability Weighting for Security Prices
abstract: <jats:p> We study the asset pricing implications of Tversky and Kahneman's (1992) cumulative prospect theory, with a particular focus on its probability weighting component. Our main result, derived from a novel equilibrium with nonunique global optima, is that, in contrast to the prediction of a standard expected utility model, a security's own skewness can be priced: a positively skewed security can be “overpriced” and can earn a negative average excess return. We argue that our analysis offers a unifying way of thinking about a number of seemingly unrelated financial phenomena. (JEL D81, G11, G12) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the asset pricing implications of probability weighting from cumulative prospect theory, particularly how it affects the pricing of securities with different skewness characteristics?
answer: In contrast to standard expected utility models, a security's own skewness can be priced under cumulative prospect theory - specifically, positively skewed securities can be 'overpriced' and earn negative average excess returns due to probability weighting effects.
positioning_statement: This paper extends beyond standard expected utility models by incorporating Tversky and Kahneman's cumulative prospect theory into asset pricing, offering a unifying framework to explain various seemingly unrelated financial phenomena through the lens of probability weighting.

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: Individual Preferences, Monetary Gambles, and Stock Market Participation: A Case for Narrow Framing

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Do Private Equity Owned Firms Have Better Management Practices?
abstract: <jats:p> Using an innovative survey measure of management practices on over 15,000 firms, we find private equity firms are better managed than government, family, and privately owned firms, and have similar management to publicly listed firms. This is true both in developed and developing countries. Looking at management practices in detail we find that private equity owned firms have strong people management practices (hiring, firing, pay, and promotions), but even stronger monitoring management practices (lean manufacturing, continuous improvement, and monitoring). Plant managers working in private equity owned firms also report greater autonomy from headquarters over sales, marketing, and new product introduction. </jats:p>
research_question: Do private equity owned firms have better management practices compared to other types of firm ownership structures?
answer: Private equity owned firms are better managed than government, family, and privately owned firms, and have similar management quality to publicly listed firms, with particularly strong people management and monitoring practices, and greater plant manager autonomy.
positioning_statement: This paper uses an innovative survey measure of management practices across over 15,000 firms to provide empirical evidence on the relationship between private equity ownership and management quality, contributing to the literature by systematically comparing management practices across different ownership structures in both developed and developing countries.

author: Nicholas Barberis
title: Individual Preferences, Monetary Gambles, and Stock Market Participation: A Case for Narrow Framing
abstract: <jats:p> We argue that “narrow framing,” whereby an agent who is offered a new gamble evaluates that gamble in isolation, may be a more important feature of decision-making than previously realized. Our starting point is the evidence that people are often averse to a small, independent gamble, even when the gamble is actuarially favorable. We find that a surprisingly wide range of utility functions, including many nonexpected utility specifications, have trouble explaining this evidence, but that this difficulty can be overcome by allowing for narrow framing. Our analysis makes predictions as to what kinds of preferences can most easily address the stock market participation puzzle. </jats:p>
research_question: How can narrow framing in decision-making help explain why people are averse to small, independent gambles and address the stock market participation puzzle?
answer: Narrow framing, where agents evaluate new gambles in isolation rather than as part of their overall portfolio, can explain aversion to small favorable gambles across a wide range of utility functions and provides insights into what types of preferences can address the stock market participation puzzle.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as identifying narrow framing as a more important feature of decision-making than previously recognized in the literature, offering a solution where traditional utility functions (including many nonexpected utility specifications) have failed to adequately explain observed gambling aversion and stock market participation patterns.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: The Organization of Firms Across Countries*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We argue that social capital as proxied by trust increases aggregate productivity by affecting the organization of firms. To do this we collect new data on the decentralization of investment, hiring, production, and sales decisions from corporate headquarters to local plant managers in almost 4,000 firms in the United States, Europe, and Asia. We find that firms headquartered in high-trust regions are significantly more likely to decentralize. To help identify causal effects, we look within multinational firms and show that higher levels of bilateral trust between the multinational’s country of origin and subsidiary’s country of location increases decentralization, even after instrumenting trust using religious similarities between the countries. Finally, we show evidence suggesting that trust raises aggregate productivity by facilitating reallocation between firms and allowing more efficient firms to grow, as CEOs can decentralize more decisions.</jats:p>
research_question: How does social capital, as proxied by trust, affect aggregate productivity through its impact on the organization of firms?
answer: Trust increases aggregate productivity by facilitating firm decentralization - firms in high-trust regions are significantly more likely to decentralize decision-making from headquarters to local managers, which enables more efficient resource reallocation between firms and allows more efficient firms to grow.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing new empirical evidence on the mechanism through which social capital affects productivity, specifically focusing on firm organizational structure and decentralization as the channel, using novel cross-country data on firm decision-making processes.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Americans Do IT Better: US Multinationals and the Productivity Miracle
abstract: <jats:p> US productivity growth accelerated after 1995 (unlike Europe's), particularly in sectors that intensively use information technologies (IT). Using two new micro panel datasets we show that US multinationals operating in Europe also experienced a “productivity miracle.” US multinationals obtained higher productivity from IT than non-US multinationals, particularly in the same sectors responsible for the US productivity acceleration. Furthermore, establishments taken over by US multinationals (but not by non-US multinationals) increased the productivity of their IT. Combining pan-European firm-level IT data with our management practices survey, we find that the US IT related productivity advantage is primarily due to its tougher “people management” practices. (JEL D24, E23, F23, M10, M16, O30) </jats:p>
research_question: Why did US productivity growth accelerate after 1995, particularly in IT-intensive sectors, while European productivity did not experience similar gains?
answer: US multinationals achieved higher IT productivity than non-US multinationals due to superior 'people management' practices, and this advantage transferred to European establishments when acquired by US firms, explaining the US productivity miracle in IT-intensive sectors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on the US productivity acceleration after 1995 by providing micro-level evidence that US management practices, particularly in people management, explain the superior IT productivity performance of US multinationals compared to their European counterparts, using novel panel datasets and management practice surveys.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: A Reply to Campbell and Mau

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Using Disasters to Estimate the Impact of Uncertainty
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Uncertainty rises in recessions and falls in booms. But what is the causal relationship? We construct cross-country panel data on stock market returns to proxy for first- and second-moment shocks and instrument these with natural disasters, terrorist attacks, and political shocks. Our IV regression results reveal a robust negative short-term impact of second moments (uncertainty) on growth. Employing multiple vector autoregression estimation approaches, relying on a range of identifying assumptions, also reveals a negative impact of uncertainty on growth. Finally, we show that these results are reproducible in a conventional micro–macro business cycle model with time-varying uncertainty.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal relationship between uncertainty and economic growth, specifically whether uncertainty causes economic downturns or is merely correlated with them?
answer: Uncertainty has a robust negative causal impact on economic growth in the short term, as demonstrated through instrumental variable regressions using natural disasters, terrorist attacks, and political shocks as instruments for uncertainty shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the causality question in the established empirical relationship between uncertainty and business cycles by using novel instrumental variable approaches with exogenous shocks, and validates findings through multiple methodological approaches including vector autoregression and theoretical modeling.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Why Do Firms in Developing Countries Have Low Productivity?

author: Nicholas Bloom
title:
Does Management Matter? Evidence from India
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A long-standing question is whether differences in management practices across firms can explain differences in productivity, especially in developing countries where these spreads appear particularly large. To investigate this, we ran a management field experiment on large Indian textile firms. We provided free consulting on management practices to randomly chosen treatment plants and compared their performance to a set of control plants. We find that adopting these management practices raised productivity by 17% in the first year through improved quality and efficiency and reduced inventory, and within three years led to the opening of more production plants. Why had the firms not adopted these profitable practices previously? Our results suggest that informational barriers were the primary factor explaining this lack of adoption. Also, because reallocation across firms appeared to be constrained by limits on managerial time, competition had not forced badly managed firms to exit.</jats:p>
research_question: Can differences in management practices across firms explain differences in productivity, especially in developing countries where productivity spreads appear particularly large?
answer: Yes, adopting improved management practices raised productivity by 17% in the first year through improved quality and efficiency and reduced inventory, and within three years led to the opening of more production plants. The primary barrier to adoption was informational constraints rather than other factors.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a long-standing question in the literature about whether management practices can explain productivity differences across firms, with a particular focus on developing countries where productivity spreads appear especially large, using a randomized field experiment approach to provide causal evidence.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Measuring Economic Policy Uncertainty*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a new index of economic policy uncertainty (EPU) based on newspaper coverage frequency. Several types of evidence—including human readings of 12,000 newspaper articles—indicate that our index proxies for movements in policy-related economic uncertainty. Our U.S. index spikes near tight presidential elections, Gulf Wars I and II, the 9/11 attacks, the failure of Lehman Brothers, the 2011 debt ceiling dispute, and other major battles over fiscal policy. Using firm-level data, we find that policy uncertainty is associated with greater stock price volatility and reduced investment and employment in policy-sensitive sectors like defense, health care, finance, and infrastructure construction. At the macro level, innovations in policy uncertainty foreshadow declines in investment, output, and employment in the United States and, in a panel vector autoregressive setting, for 12 major economies. Extending our U.S. index back to 1900, EPU rose dramatically in the 1930s (from late 1931) and has drifted upward since the 1960s.</jats:p>
research_question: How can economic policy uncertainty be measured, and what are its effects on firm-level and macroeconomic outcomes?
answer: The authors develop a newspaper-based Economic Policy Uncertainty (EPU) index that successfully captures policy-related uncertainty, finding that higher policy uncertainty is associated with increased stock volatility, reduced investment and employment at the firm level (especially in policy-sensitive sectors), and leads to declines in investment, output, and employment at the macroeconomic level across multiple countries.
positioning_statement: This paper fills a gap in the literature by creating the first systematic, quantitative measure of economic policy uncertainty using newspaper coverage frequency, validated through multiple approaches including human readings of 12,000 articles, and demonstrates its predictive power for economic outcomes that previous literature could not directly measure.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title:
Does Working from Home Work? Evidence from a Chinese Experiment
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A rising share of employees now regularly engage in working from home (WFH), but there are concerns this can lead to “shirking from home.” We report the results of a WFH experiment at Ctrip, a 16,000-employee, NASDAQ-listed Chinese travel agency. Call center employees who volunteered to WFH were randomly assigned either to work from home or in the office for nine months. Home working led to a 13% performance increase, of which 9% was from working more minutes per shift (fewer breaks and sick days) and 4% from more calls per minute (attributed to a quieter and more convenient working environment). Home workers also reported improved work satisfaction, and their attrition rate halved, but their promotion rate conditional on performance fell. Due to the success of the experiment, Ctrip rolled out the option to WFH to the whole firm and allowed the experimental employees to reselect between the home and office. Interestingly, over half of them switched, which led to the gains from WFH almost doubling to 22%. This highlights the benefits of learning and selection effects when adopting modern management practices like WFH.</jats:p>
research_question: Does working from home lead to improved or reduced employee performance, and what are the broader effects on work satisfaction, attrition, and promotion rates?
answer: Working from home leads to a 13% performance increase (9% from working more minutes per shift and 4% from increased productivity per minute), improved work satisfaction, and halved attrition rates, though promotion rates conditional on performance fell. When employees were allowed to reselect after learning from the experiment, performance gains nearly doubled to 22%.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses concerns about 'shirking from home' by providing rigorous experimental evidence on working from home effects, contributing to the literature on modern management practices through a randomized controlled trial at a large Chinese firm, and highlighting the importance of learning and selection effects in adopting WFH policies.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Are Ideas Getting Harder to Find?
abstract: <jats:p> Long-run growth in many models is the product of two terms: the effective number of researchers and their research productivity. We present evidence from various industries, products, and firms showing that research effort is rising substantially while research productivity is declining sharply. A good example is Moore’s Law. The number of researchers required today to achieve the famous doubling of computer chip density is more than 18 times larger than the number required in the early 1970s. More generally, everywhere we look we find that ideas, and the exponential growth they imply, are getting harder to find. (JEL D24, E23, O31, O47) </jats:p>
research_question: Are ideas getting harder to find, and what is happening to research productivity over time?
answer: Yes, ideas are getting harder to find. Research effort is rising substantially while research productivity is declining sharply across various industries, products, and firms. For example, the number of researchers required to achieve Moore's Law doubling of computer chip density is more than 18 times larger today than in the early 1970s.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the long-run growth literature by empirically examining the two key components of growth models: the effective number of researchers and their research productivity, providing systematic evidence across multiple domains that research productivity is systematically declining despite increasing research effort.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: International Data on Measuring Management Practices
abstract: <jats:p> We examine methods used to survey firms on their management and organizational practices. We contrast the strengths and weaknesses of “open ended questions” (like the World Management Survey) with “closed questions” (like the MOPS). For this type of data, open ended questions give higher quality responses, but are more costly than closed question-based surveys. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the relative strengths and weaknesses of different survey methods (open ended questions vs. closed questions) for measuring management and organizational practices in firms?
answer: Open ended questions provide higher quality responses for measuring management practices but are more costly to implement compared to closed question-based surveys.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a methodological comparison between existing survey approaches, specifically contrasting the World Management Survey (open ended) with MOPS (closed questions) to help researchers understand the trade-offs in data collection methods for management practices research.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: A Trapped-Factors Model of Innovation
abstract: <jats:p>We explain a counterintuitive empirical finding: Firms facing more import competition do more innovation. In our model, factors are trapped inside a firm. An increase in import competition encourages a firm to innovate by reducing the opportunity cost of inputs. Without trapped factors, trade liberalization leads to a small permanent increase in the worldwide rate of growth. With trapped factors, firms that face more import competition do relatively more innovation. The extra innovation induced by trapped factors induces a small permanent increase in aggregate output, consumption, and welfare, generalizing the appropriate estimate of the gains from trade.</jats:p>
research_question: Why do firms facing more import competition engage in more innovation, which appears counterintuitive?
answer: Firms facing more import competition innovate more because trapped factors inside the firm reduce the opportunity cost of inputs when competition increases, making innovation relatively more attractive.
positioning_statement: This paper explains a counterintuitive empirical finding that existing literature has not adequately addressed, and extends the standard gains from trade analysis by incorporating the innovation effects of trapped factors, which leads to additional permanent increases in aggregate output, consumption, and welfare beyond traditional trade liberalization models.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Innovation, Reallocation, and Growth
abstract: <jats:p> We build a model of firm-level innovation, productivity growth, and reallocation featuring endogenous entry and exit. A new and central economic force is the selection between high- and low-type firms, which differ in terms of their innovative capacity. We estimate the parameters of the model using US Census microdata on firm-level output, R&D, and patenting. The model provides a good fit to the dynamics of firm entry and exit, output, and R&D. Taxing the continued operation of incumbents can lead to sizable gains (of the order of 1.4 percent improvement in welfare) by encouraging exit of less productive firms and freeing up skilled labor to be used for R&D by high-type incumbents. Subsidies to the R&D of incumbents do not achieve this objective because they encourage the survival and expansion of low-type firms. (JEL D21, D24, H25, L52, O31, O34) </jats:p>
research_question: How do firm-level innovation, productivity growth, and reallocation interact in an economy with endogenous entry and exit, and what are the welfare implications of different policy interventions?
answer: The key finding is that taxing the continued operation of incumbents can lead to substantial welfare gains (1.4 percent improvement) by encouraging exit of less productive firms and freeing up skilled labor for R&D by high-type firms, while R&D subsidies to incumbents are less effective because they encourage survival of low-type firms.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new central economic force - the selection between high- and low-type firms that differ in innovative capacity - into models of firm-level innovation and reallocation, estimated using US Census microdata on firm-level output, R&D, and patenting.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Really Uncertain Business Cycles
abstract: We investigate the role of uncertainty in business cycles. First, we demonstrate that microeconomic uncertainty rises sharply during recessions, including during the Great Recession of 2007–2009. Second, we show that uncertainty shocks can generate drops in gross domestic product of around 2.5% in a dynamic stochastic general equilibrium model with heterogeneous firms. However, we also find that uncertainty shocks need to be supplemented by first‐moment shocks to fit consumption over the cycle. So our data and simulations suggest recessions are best modelled as being driven by shocks with a negative first moment and a positive second moment. Finally, we show that increased uncertainty can make first‐moment policies, like wage subsidies, temporarily less effective because firms become more cautious in responding to price changes.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: Firming Up Inequality*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We use a massive, matched employer-employee database for the United States to analyze the contribution of firms to the rise in earnings inequality from 1978 to 2013. We find that one-third of the rise in the variance of (log) earnings occurred within firms, whereas two-thirds of the rise occurred due to a rise in the dispersion of average earnings between firms. However, this rising between-firm variance is not accounted for by the firms themselves but by a widening gap between firms in the composition of their workers. This compositional change can be split into two roughly equal parts: high-wage workers became increasingly likely to work in high-wage firms (i.e., sorting increased), and high-wage workers became increasingly likely to work with each other (i.e., segregation rose). In contrast, we do not find a rise in the variance of firm-specific pay once we control for the worker composition in firms. Finally, we find that two-thirds of the rise in the within-firm variance of earnings occurred within mega (10,000+ employee) firms, which saw a particularly large increase in the variance of earnings compared with smaller firms.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the contribution of firms to the rise in earnings inequality in the United States from 1978 to 2013?
answer: Two-thirds of the rise in earnings inequality occurred due to increased dispersion of average earnings between firms, which is explained by compositional changes in workers rather than firm-specific pay differences. Specifically, high-wage workers increasingly sorted into high-wage firms and became more segregated from low-wage workers. One-third occurred within firms, with mega firms (10,000+ employees) accounting for two-thirds of this within-firm increase.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a massive matched employer-employee database to provide a comprehensive decomposition of the firm-level sources of rising earnings inequality, distinguishing between within-firm and between-firm components and identifying the role of worker sorting and segregation versus firm-specific pay policies.

author: Nicholas Trachter
title: An Information-based Theory of Financial Intermediation
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We build a theory of financial intermediation based on the premise that some investors are better able to figure out the trade motives of their counterparties in bilateral meetings—screening experts. We solve for the equilibrium market structure and study how information asymmetries stemming from heterogeneity in screening expertise shape up the core–periphery trade structure. In particular, the core of the market is populated by screening experts: they have the largest share of trade volume, they are actively engaged in middleman activity, and trade with the most counterparties. Using transaction-level micro-data and information disclosure requirements, we provide extensive evidence consistent only with our theory of financial intermediation.</jats:p>
research_question: How do information asymmetries stemming from heterogeneity in screening expertise shape financial market structure and intermediation?
answer: Markets develop a core-periphery structure where screening experts (investors better able to figure out counterparties' trade motives) form the core, capturing the largest share of trade volume, engaging in middleman activity, and trading with the most counterparties.
positioning_statement: This paper builds a new theory of financial intermediation based on heterogeneous screening expertise among investors, providing a novel explanation for market structure that is supported by transaction-level micro-data evidence not consistent with existing theories.

author: Nicolae Gârleanu
title: Financial Entanglement: A Theory of Incomplete Integration, Leverage, Crashes, and Contagion
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a unified model of limited market integration, asset-price determination, leveraging, and contagion. Investors and firms are located on a circle, and access to markets involves participation costs that increase with distance. Due to a complementarity between participation and leverage decisions, the equilibrium may exhibit diverse leverage and participation choices across investors, although investors are ex ante identical. Small changes in market-access costs can cause a change in the type of equilibrium, leading to discontinuous price changes, deleveraging, and portfolio-flow reversals. Moreover, the market is subject to contagion—an adverse shock to investors in some locations affects prices everywhere. (JEL D83, G11, G12, G32, G35) </jats:p>
research_question: How do market participation costs, leverage decisions, and limited market integration interact to create financial instability, crashes, and contagion effects?
answer: Due to complementarity between participation and leverage decisions, small changes in market-access costs can cause discontinuous equilibrium shifts leading to price crashes, deleveraging, and portfolio reversals, while adverse shocks in some market locations spread everywhere through contagion effects.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified theoretical framework that integrates previously separate concepts of limited market integration, asset pricing, leverage decisions, and contagion into a single model, offering a comprehensive explanation for financial instability phenomena.

author: Nicholas Bloom
title: The Diffusion of New Technologies
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We identify phrases associated with novel technologies using textual analysis of patents, job postings, and earnings calls, enabling us to identify four stylized facts on the diffusion of jobs relating to new technologies. First, the development of economically impactful new technologies is geographically highly concentrated, more so even than overall patenting: 56% of the most economically impactful technologies come from just two U.S. locations, Silicon Valley and the Northeast Corridor. Second, as the technologies mature and the number of related jobs grows, hiring spreads geographically. This process is very slow, taking around 50 years to disperse fully. Third, while initial hiring in new technologies is highly skill-biased, over time the mean skill level in new positions declines, drawing in an increasing number of lower-skilled workers. Finally, the geographic spread of hiring is slowest for higher-skilled positions, with the locations where new technologies were pioneered remaining the focus for the technology's high-skill jobs for decades.</jats:p>
research_question: How do jobs relating to new technologies diffuse geographically and across skill levels over time?
answer: The paper identifies four key findings: (1) economically impactful new technologies are highly geographically concentrated in development, with 56% coming from Silicon Valley and the Northeast Corridor; (2) geographic spread of related jobs is very slow, taking around 50 years to disperse fully; (3) while initial hiring is highly skill-biased, the mean skill level declines over time as lower-skilled workers are drawn in; and (4) geographic spread is slowest for higher-skilled positions, with pioneering locations remaining centers for high-skill technology jobs for decades.
positioning_statement: The paper uses novel textual analysis methods applied to patents, job postings, and earnings calls to identify phrases associated with new technologies, enabling systematic analysis of technology diffusion patterns that establishes new stylized facts about the geographic and skill-based diffusion of technology-related employment.

author: Nicolas Crouzet
title: Aggregate Implications of Corporate Debt Choices

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: An Empirical Model of the Medical Match
abstract: <jats:p> This paper develops a framework for estimating preferences in a many-to-one matching market using only observed matches. I use pairwise stability and a vertical preference restriction on one side to identify preferences on both sides of the market. Counterfactual simulations are used to analyze the antitrust allegation that the centralized medical residency match is responsible for salary depression. Due to residents' willingness to pay for desirable programs and capacity constraints, salaries in any competitive equilibrium would remain, on average, at least $23,000 below the marginal product of labor. Therefore, the match is not the likely cause of low salaries. (JEL C78, I11, J31, J44, K21, L44) </jats:p>
research_question: Is the centralized medical residency match responsible for salary depression among medical residents?
answer: The centralized medical match is not the likely cause of low salaries. Due to residents' willingness to pay for desirable programs and capacity constraints, salaries in any competitive equilibrium would remain, on average, at least $23,000 below the marginal product of labor.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel framework for estimating preferences in many-to-one matching markets using only observed matches, employing pairwise stability and vertical preference restrictions to identify preferences on both sides of the market, which allows for empirical analysis of antitrust allegations in matching markets.

author: Nicolas Crouzet
title: Shocks and Technology Adoption: Evidence from Electronic Payment Systems

author: Nicolas Crouzet
title: Small and Large Firms over the Business Cycle
abstract: <jats:p> This paper uses new confidential Census data to revisit the relationship between firm size, cyclicality, and financial frictions. First, we find that large firms (the top 1 percent by size) are less cyclically sensitive than the rest. Second, high and rising concentration implies that the higher cyclicality of the bottom 99 percent of firms only has a modest impact on aggregate fluctuations. Third, differences in cyclicality are not simply explained by financing, and in fact appear largely unrelated to proxies for financial strength. We instead provide evidence for an alternative mechanism based on the industry scope of the very largest firms. (JEL D22, E32, G32, L25) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between firm size, cyclical sensitivity, and financial frictions over the business cycle?
answer: Large firms (top 1% by size) are less cyclically sensitive than smaller firms, but due to high market concentration, the higher cyclicality of smaller firms has only modest impact on aggregate fluctuations. The cyclicality differences are not explained by financial frictions but rather by the industry scope of the largest firms.
positioning_statement: This paper revisits the established relationship between firm size and cyclicality using new confidential Census data, challenging the conventional explanation based on financing and financial frictions by proposing an alternative mechanism based on industry scope of very large firms.

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: Policy Analysis in Matching Markets
abstract: <jats:p> Price and quantity interventions intended to affect assignments are common in many labor and education markets (e.g., financial aid, quotas). This article discusses an empirical framework, based on the theory of stable matching, that is suitable for policy analysis while accounting for the presence of equilibrium sorting. It then compares financial incentives and supply interventions for encouraging the training of family medicine residents in rural America. Due to equilibrium effects, the primary effect of financial incentives is to increase the quality, not numbers, of residents in rural programs, while quantity regulations directly affect numbers without adversely affecting quality. </jats:p>
research_question: How can policy interventions (financial incentives vs. supply interventions) be analyzed and compared in matching markets, specifically for encouraging family medicine resident training in rural America?
answer: Due to equilibrium effects, financial incentives primarily increase the quality rather than the numbers of residents in rural programs, while quantity regulations directly affect numbers without adversely affecting quality.
positioning_statement: This paper develops an empirical framework based on stable matching theory that is suitable for policy analysis while accounting for equilibrium sorting effects in matching markets.

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: The Welfare Effects of Coordinated Assignment: Evidence from the New York City High School Match
abstract: <jats:p> Coordinated single-offer school assignment systems are a popular education reform. We show that uncoordinated offers in NYC's school assignment mechanism generated mismatches. One-third of applicants were unassigned after the main round and later administratively placed at less desirable schools. We evaluate the effects of the new coordinated mechanism based on deferred acceptance using estimated student preferences. The new mechanism achieves 80 percent of the possible gains from a no-choice neighborhood extreme to a utilitarian benchmark. Coordinating offers dominates the effects of further algorithm modifications. Students most likely to be previously administratively assigned experienced the largest gains in welfare and subsequent achievement. (JEL C78, D82, I21, I28) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the welfare effects of implementing a coordinated single-offer school assignment system (deferred acceptance mechanism) compared to an uncoordinated assignment system?
answer: The coordinated mechanism significantly improves welfare, achieving 80 percent of the possible gains between a no-choice neighborhood system and a utilitarian benchmark. Students who were previously most likely to be administratively assigned experienced the largest gains in both welfare and subsequent achievement.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on school assignment mechanisms by providing empirical evidence of welfare gains from coordinated assignment systems, specifically demonstrating that coordinating offers has larger effects than further algorithm modifications and focusing on a real-world implementation in NYC's high school match system.

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: Demand Analysis Using Strategic Reports: An Application to a School Choice Mechanism
abstract: Several school districts use assignment systems that give students an incentive to misrepresent their preferences. We find evidence consistent with strategic behavior in Cambridge. Such strategizing can complicate preference analysis. This paper develops empirical methods for studying random utility models in a new and large class of school choice mechanisms. We show that preferences are nonparametrically identified under either sufficient variation in choice environments or a preference shifter. We then develop a tractable estimation procedure and apply it to Cambridge. Estimates suggest that while 83% of students are assigned to their stated first choice, only 72% are assigned to their true first choice because students avoid ranking competitive schools. Assuming that students behave optimally, the Immediate Acceptance mechanism is preferred by the average student to the Deferred Acceptance mechanism by an equivalent of 0.08 miles. The estimated difference is smaller if beliefs are biased, and reversed if students report preferences truthfully.

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: Demand Analysis under Latent Choice Constraints
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Consumer choices are constrained in many markets due to either supply-side rationing or information frictions. Examples include matching markets for schools and colleges; entry-level labor markets; limited brand awareness and inattention in consumer markets; and selective admissions to healthcare services. We analyze a general random utility model for consumer preferences that allows for endogenous characteristics and a reduced-form choice-set formation rule that can be derived from models of the examples described above. We show non-parametric identification of this model, propose an estimator, and apply these methods to study admissions in the market for kidney dialysis in California. Our identification results require two sets of instruments, one that only affects consumer preferences and the other that only affects choice sets. We show that both instruments are necessary for identification. These results also suggest tests of choice-set constraints, which we apply to the dialysis market. We find that dialysis facilities are less likely to admit new patients when they have a higher-than-normal caseload and that patients are more likely to travel further when nearby facilities have high caseloads. Finally, we estimate consumers’ preferences and facilities’ rationing rules using a Gibbs sampler.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we identify and estimate consumer preferences in markets where choices are constrained by supply-side rationing or information frictions, particularly when choice sets are endogenously determined?
answer: The paper develops a general random utility model that non-parametrically identifies consumer preferences under endogenous choice constraints using two sets of instruments - one affecting only preferences and another affecting only choice sets. Applied to kidney dialysis markets, they find evidence of rationing where facilities are less likely to admit patients during high caseload periods, and patients travel further when nearby facilities have high caseloads.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the standard discrete choice literature by incorporating endogenous choice-set formation constraints that arise in matching markets, labor markets, and markets with information frictions - addressing a gap where traditional demand analysis assumes all alternatives are available to all consumers.

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: Skewed Bidding in Pay-per-Action Auctions for Online Advertising

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: Equilibrium Allocations Under Alternative Waitlist Designs: Evidence From Deceased Donor Kidneys
abstract: <jats:p>Waitlists are often used to ration scarce resources, but the trade‐offs in designing these mechanisms depend on agents' preferences. We study equilibrium allocations under alternative designs for the deceased donor kidney waitlist. We model the decision to accept an organ or wait for a preferable one as an optimal stopping problem and estimate preferences using administrative data from the New York City area. Our estimates show that while some kidney types are desirable for all patients, there is substantial match‐specific heterogeneity in values. We then develop methods to evaluate alternative mechanisms, comparing their effects on patient welfare to an equivalent change in donor supply. Past reforms to the kidney waitlist primarily resulted in redistribution, with similar welfare and organ discard rates to the benchmark first‐come, first‐served mechanism. These mechanisms and other commonly studied theoretical benchmarks remain far from optimal. We design a mechanism that increases patient welfare by the equivalent of an 18.2% increase in donor supply.</jats:p>
research_question: How do alternative waitlist designs for deceased donor kidneys affect equilibrium allocations and patient welfare compared to existing mechanisms?
answer: Past reforms to the kidney waitlist primarily resulted in redistribution with similar welfare and organ discard rates to first-come, first-served mechanisms, but a newly designed optimal mechanism can increase patient welfare equivalent to an 18.2% increase in donor supply.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on waitlist mechanism design by providing empirical evidence on the trade-offs between different allocation mechanisms, showing that commonly studied theoretical benchmarks and past reforms remain far from optimal, while developing new methods to evaluate and design superior mechanisms.

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: Choices and Outcomes in Assignment Mechanisms: The Allocation of Deceased Donor Kidneys
abstract: <jats:p>While the mechanism design paradigm emphasizes notions of efficiency based on agent preferences, policymakers often focus on alternative objectives. School districts emphasize educational achievement, and transplantation communities focus on patient survival. It is unclear whether choice‐based mechanisms perform well when assessed based on these outcomes. This paper evaluates the assignment mechanism for allocating deceased donor kidneys on the basis of patient life‐years from transplantation (LYFT). We examine the role of choice in increasing LYFT and compare realized assignments to benchmarks that remove choice. Our model combines choices and outcomes in order to study how selection affects LYFT. We show how to identify and estimate the model using instruments derived from the mechanism. The estimates suggest that the design in use selects patients with better post‐transplant survival prospects and matches them well, resulting in an average LYFT of 9.29, which is 1.75 years more than a random assignment. However, the maximum aggregate LYFT is 14.08. Realizing the majority of the gains requires transplanting relatively healthy patients, who would have longer life expectancies even without a transplant. Therefore, a policymaker faces a dilemma between transplanting patients who are sicker and those for whom life will be extended the longest.</jats:p>
research_question: How well does the choice-based assignment mechanism for allocating deceased donor kidneys perform when evaluated based on patient life-years from transplantation (LYFT), and what is the role of choice in increasing LYFT?
answer: The current kidney allocation mechanism performs reasonably well, achieving an average LYFT of 9.29 years, which is 1.75 years more than random assignment. However, it falls short of the maximum possible aggregate LYFT of 14.08 years. The mechanism selects patients with better post-transplant survival prospects and matches them effectively, but realizing maximum gains would require prioritizing relatively healthy patients over sicker ones.
positioning_statement: This paper bridges mechanism design theory and policy practice by evaluating choice-based mechanisms using outcome-based objectives that policymakers actually care about (patient survival) rather than just preference-based efficiency measures emphasized in traditional mechanism design literature.

author: Nina Boyarchenko
title: Vulnerable Growth
abstract: <jats:p>We study the conditional distribution of GDP growth as a function of economic and financial conditions. Deteriorating financial conditions are associated with an increase in the conditional volatility and a decline in the conditional mean of GDP growth, leading the lower quantiles of GDP growth to vary with financial conditions and the upper quantiles to be stable over time. Upside risks to GDP growth are low in most periods while downside risks increase as financial conditions become tighter. We argue that amplification mechanisms in the financial sector generate the observed growth vulnerability dynamics. (JEL C53, E23, E27, E32, E44)</jats:p>
research_question: How does the conditional distribution of GDP growth vary as a function of economic and financial conditions?
answer: Deteriorating financial conditions increase conditional volatility and decrease conditional mean of GDP growth, with lower quantiles varying with financial conditions while upper quantiles remain stable over time, creating asymmetric downside risks that increase as financial conditions tighten.
positioning_statement: The paper argues that amplification mechanisms in the financial sector generate the observed growth vulnerability dynamics, contributing to understanding of how financial conditions asymmetrically affect economic growth distributions.

author: Nikolai Roussanov

author: Nikhil Agarwal
title: Market Failure in Kidney Exchange
abstract: <jats:p> We show that kidney exchange markets suffer from market failures whose remedy could increase transplants by 30 to 63 percent. First, we document that the market is fragmented and inefficient; most transplants are arranged by hospitals instead of national platforms. Second, we propose a model to show two sources of inefficiency: hospitals only partly internalize their patients’ benefits from exchange, and current platforms suboptimally reward hospitals for submitting patients and donors. Third, we calibrate a production function and show that individual hospitals operate below efficient scale. Eliminating this inefficiency requires either a mandate or a combination of new mechanisms and reimbursement reforms. (JEL D24, D47, I11) </jats:p>
research_question: What market failures exist in kidney exchange markets and how much could transplants increase if these failures were remedied?
answer: Kidney exchange markets suffer from fragmentation and inefficiency due to hospitals only partly internalizing patient benefits and platforms suboptimally rewarding participation, with remedying these failures potentially increasing transplants by 30 to 63 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies and quantifies previously unrecognized market failures in kidney exchange, showing that most transplants are inefficiently arranged by individual hospitals rather than through national platforms, and demonstrates that hospitals operate below efficient scale.

author: Nina Boyarchenko
title: Taking Orders and Taking Notes: Dealer Information Sharing in Treasury Auctions

author: Noam Yuchtman
title: Coercive Contract Enforcement: Law and the Labor Market in Nineteenth Century Industrial Britain
abstract: <jats:p> British Master and Servant law made employee contract breach a criminal offense until 1875. We develop a contracting model generating equilibrium contract breach and prosecutions, then exploit exogenous changes in output prices to examine the effects of labor demand shocks on prosecutions. Positive shocks in the textile, iron, and coal industries increased prosecutions. Following the abolition of criminal sanctions, wages differentially rose in counties that had experienced more prosecutions, and wages responded more to labor demand shocks. Coercive contract enforcement was applied in industrial Britain; restricted mobility allowed workers to commit to risk-sharing contracts with lower, but less volatile, wages. (JEL J31, J41, K12, K31, N33, N43) </jats:p>
research_question: What were the effects of coercive contract enforcement through criminal sanctions on labor markets in nineteenth century industrial Britain?
answer: Coercive contract enforcement restricted worker mobility and allowed workers to commit to risk-sharing contracts with lower but less volatile wages, as evidenced by increased prosecutions during positive labor demand shocks and differential wage increases following the abolition of criminal sanctions in 1875.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a contracting model that explains equilibrium contract breach and prosecutions under Master and Servant law, and by providing empirical evidence on how coercive enforcement mechanisms affected wage levels and volatility in industrial labor markets.

author: Nina Boyarchenko
title: Irreversible Decisions and Record-Setting News Principles
abstract: <jats:p> In the now-classical real options theory, the price of an underlying asset is modeled as a geometric Brownian motion, and optimal exercise strategies are described by simple explicit formulas. This paper extends the classical theory to allow any geometric Lévy process to model prices. Such processes may account for fat tails and skewness of probability distributions of commodity prices. The optimal exercise strategies are specified in the paper in terms of statistics of record-setting low or high prices. The formulas derived extend those observed in the Gaussian case, but the form of the result is novel even for that case. </jats:p>
research_question: How can real options theory be extended beyond geometric Brownian motion to accommodate geometric Lévy processes that account for fat tails and skewness in commodity price distributions?
answer: Optimal exercise strategies for irreversible decisions under geometric Lévy processes can be specified in terms of statistics of record-setting low or high prices, with formulas that extend the Gaussian case but provide novel results even for that classical scenario.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the now-classical real options theory beyond its traditional geometric Brownian motion framework by incorporating geometric Lévy processes, building upon existing Gaussian case formulas while providing novel insights even for the classical case.

author: Noam Yuchtman
title: Medieval Universities, Legal Institutions, and the Commercial Revolution *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We present new data documenting medieval Europe’s Commercial Revolution using information on the establishment of markets in Germany. We use these data to test whether medieval universities played a causal role in expanding economic activity, examining the foundation of Germany’s first universities after 1386 following the papal schism. We find that the trend rate of market establishment breaks upward in 1386 and this break is greatest where the distance to a university shrank most. There is no differential pre-1386 trend associated with the reduction in distance to a university, and there is no break in trend in 1386 where university proximity did not change. These results are robust to estimating a variety of specifications that address concerns about the endogeneity of university location. Universities provided training in newly rediscovered Roman and canon law; students with legal training served in positions that reduced the uncertainty of trade in the Middle Ages. We argue that training in the law, and the consequent development of legal and administrative institutions, was an important channel linking universities and greater economic activity in medieval Germany.</jats:p>
research_question: Did medieval universities play a causal role in expanding economic activity during Europe's Commercial Revolution?
answer: Yes, medieval universities causally expanded economic activity. The trend rate of market establishment broke upward in 1386 (when Germany's first universities were founded after the papal schism), with the greatest increase occurring where distance to a university shrank most.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new empirical evidence to the literature on medieval economic development by providing novel data on market establishment in Germany and demonstrating a causal link between universities and commercial expansion, specifically through the channel of legal training and institutional development that reduced trade uncertainty.
