author: Noam Yuchtman
title: Can Online Learning Bend the Higher Education Cost Curve?
abstract: <jats:p> We examine whether online learning technologies have led to lower prices in higher education. Using data from the Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, we show that online education is concentrated in large for-profit chains and less-selective public institutions. We find that colleges with a higher share of online students charge lower tuition prices. We present evidence of declining real and relative prices for full-time undergraduate online education from 2006 to 2013. Although the pattern of results suggests some hope that online technology can “bend the cost curve” in higher education, the impact of online learning on education quality remains uncertain. </jats:p>
research_question: Whether online learning technologies have led to lower prices in higher education
answer: Online education is associated with lower tuition prices - colleges with higher shares of online students charge lower tuition, and real and relative prices for full-time undergraduate online education declined from 2006 to 2013, suggesting online technology can 'bend the cost curve' in higher education
positioning_statement: The paper addresses the ongoing concern about rising higher education costs by examining online learning as a potential technological solution, though it acknowledges the uncertain impact on education quality as a limitation in the existing understanding

author: Noam Yuchtman
title: Data-intensive Innovation and the State: Evidence from AI Firms in China
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Developing artificial intelligence (AI) technology requires data. In many domains, government data far exceed in magnitude and scope data collected by the private sector, and AI firms often gain access to such data when providing services to the state. We argue that such access can stimulate commercial AI innovation in part because data and trained algorithms are shareable across government and commercial uses. We gather comprehensive information on firms and public security procurement contracts in China’s facial recognition AI industry. We quantify the data accessible through contracts by measuring public security agencies’ capacity to collect surveillance video. Using a triple-differences strategy, we find that data-rich contracts, compared to data-scarce ones, lead recipient firms to develop significantly and substantially more commercial AI software. Our analysis suggests a contribution of government data to the rise of China’s facial recognition AI firms, and that states’ data collection and provision policies could shape AI innovation.</jats:p>
research_question: How does access to government data through public procurement contracts affect commercial AI innovation by firms?
answer: Data-rich government contracts lead recipient firms to develop significantly and substantially more commercial AI software compared to data-scarce contracts, suggesting that access to government data stimulates commercial AI innovation because data and trained algorithms are shareable across government and commercial uses.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding the rise of China's facial recognition AI firms by examining the previously understudied role of government data provision in stimulating private sector AI innovation, arguing that states' data collection and provision policies can shape AI innovation patterns.

author: Noam Yuchtman
title: Protests as Strategic Games: Experimental Evidence from Hong Kong's Antiauthoritarian Movement*

author: Noam Yuchtman
title: AI-tocracy
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Recent scholarship has suggested that artificial intelligence (AI) technology and autocratic regimes may be mutually reinforcing. We test for a mutually reinforcing relationship in the context of facial-recognition AI in China. To do so, we gather comprehensive data on AI firms and government procurement contracts, as well as on social unrest across China since the early 2010s. We first show that autocrats benefit from AI: local unrest leads to greater government procurement of facial-recognition AI as a new technology of political control, and increased AI procurement indeed suppresses subsequent unrest. We show that AI innovation benefits from autocrats’ suppression of unrest: the contracted AI firms innovate more both for the government and commercial markets and are more likely to export their products; noncontracted AI firms do not experience detectable negative spillovers. Taken together, these results suggest the possibility of sustained AI innovation under the Chinese regime: AI innovation entrenches the regime, and the regime’s investment in AI for political control stimulates further frontier innovation.</jats:p>
research_question: Do artificial intelligence technology and autocratic regimes have a mutually reinforcing relationship, specifically in the context of facial-recognition AI in China?
answer: Yes, there is a mutually reinforcing relationship: autocrats benefit from AI by using facial-recognition technology to suppress social unrest, while AI firms benefit from autocratic investment by innovating more and expanding to commercial markets and exports, creating a cycle of sustained AI innovation that entrenches the regime.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on recent scholarship suggesting that AI technology and autocratic regimes may be mutually reinforcing, but provides the first comprehensive empirical test of this relationship using detailed data on AI firms, government procurement contracts, and social unrest in China since the early 2010s.

author: Noam Yuchtman
title: The Value of Postsecondary Credentials in the Labor Market: An Experimental Study
abstract: <jats:p> We study employers' perceptions of the value of postsecondary degrees using a field experiment. We randomly assign the sector and selectivity of institutions to fictitious resumes and apply to real vacancy postings for business and health jobs on a large online job board. We find that a business bachelor's degree from a for-profit online institution is 22 percent less likely to receive a callback than one from a nonselective public institution. In applications to health jobs, we find that for-profit credentials receive fewer callbacks unless the job requires an external quality indicator such as an occupational license. (JEL I23, I26, J24, J44, J63, M51) </jats:p>
research_question: How do employers perceive and value postsecondary degrees from different types of institutions (for-profit online vs. nonselective public) when making hiring decisions?
answer: Employers significantly discount credentials from for-profit online institutions - business bachelor's degrees from for-profit online institutions are 22% less likely to receive callbacks than those from nonselective public institutions, while for-profit health credentials only receive equal treatment when jobs require external quality indicators like occupational licenses.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on credential signaling and employer hiring behavior by using a field experimental approach to directly measure employer perceptions of different types of postsecondary institutions, providing causal evidence on how institutional sector and selectivity affect labor market outcomes.

author: Noam Yuchtman
title: Persistent Political Engagement: Social Interactions and the Dynamics of Protest Movements
abstract: <jats:p>We study the causes of sustained participation in political movements. To identify the persistent effect of protest participation, we randomly indirectly incentivize Hong Kong university students into participation in an antiauthoritarian protest. To identify the role of social networks, we randomize this treatment’s intensity across major-cohort cells. We find that incentives to attend one protest within a political movement increase subsequent protest attendance but only when a sufficient fraction of an individual’s social network is also incentivized to attend the initial protest. One-time mobilization shocks have dynamic consequences, with mobilization at the social network level important for sustained political engagement. (JEL D72, D74, I23, Z13)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the causes of sustained participation in political movements, specifically examining the persistent effects of protest participation and the role of social networks?
answer: Incentives to attend one protest increase subsequent protest attendance, but only when a sufficient fraction of an individual's social network is also incentivized to attend the initial protest. One-time mobilization shocks have dynamic consequences, with social network-level mobilization being crucial for sustained political engagement.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on political participation by using a randomized experimental approach to identify causal effects of both individual incentives and social network effects on sustained protest participation, addressing the challenge of identifying persistent effects in political movements through innovative methodology applied to Hong Kong university students.

author: Noam Yuchtman
title: Curriculum and Ideology

author: Olivier Tercieux
title: Efficiency and Stability in Large Matching Markets

author: Olivier Tercieux
title: The Design of Teacher Assignment: Theory and Evidence
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>To assign teachers to schools, a modified version of the well-known deferred acceptance mechanism has been proposed in the literature and is used in practice. We show that this mechanism fails to be fair and efficient for both teachers and schools. We identify a class of strategy-proof mechanisms that cannot be improved upon in terms of both efficiency and fairness. Using a rich dataset on teachers’ applications in France, we estimate teachers preferences and perform a counterfactual analysis. The results show that these mechanisms perform much better than the modified version of deferred acceptance. For instance, the number of teachers moving from their positions more than triples under our mechanism.</jats:p>
research_question: How can teacher assignment mechanisms be designed to achieve better fairness and efficiency outcomes for both teachers and schools compared to the currently used modified deferred acceptance mechanism?
answer: The authors identify a class of strategy-proof mechanisms that cannot be improved upon in terms of both efficiency and fairness, which significantly outperform the modified deferred acceptance mechanism - for example, tripling the number of teachers who are able to move from their current positions.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as identifying fundamental flaws in the modified deferred acceptance mechanism that has been proposed in existing literature and used in practice for teacher assignment, and proposes superior alternative mechanisms that dominate the current approach in terms of both fairness and efficiency.

author: Olivier Tercieux
title: Subgame-Perfect Implementation Under Information Perturbations*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We consider the robustness of extensive form mechanisms to deviations from common knowledge about the state of nature, which we refer to as information perturbations . First, we show that even under arbitrarily small information perturbations the Moore-Repullo mechanism does not yield (even approximately) truthful revelation and that in addition the mechanism has sequential equilibria with undesirable outcomes. More generally, we prove that any extensive form mechanism is fragile in the sense that if a non-Maskin monotonic social objective can be implemented with this mechanism, then there are arbitrarily small information perturbations under which an undesirable sequential equilibrium also exists. Finally, we argue that outside options can help improve efficiency in asymmetric information environments, and that these options can be thought of as reflecting ownership of an asset.</jats:p>
research_question: How robust are extensive form mechanisms to deviations from common knowledge about the state of nature (information perturbations)?
answer: Extensive form mechanisms are fragile to information perturbations - even arbitrarily small deviations from common knowledge can cause mechanisms like Moore-Repullo to fail to achieve truthful revelation and create undesirable sequential equilibria, particularly when implementing non-Maskin monotonic social objectives.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on mechanism design by examining robustness to information perturbations in extensive form games, specifically challenging the reliability of established mechanisms like Moore-Repullo under imperfect common knowledge, and proposing that outside options (conceptualized as asset ownership) can improve efficiency in asymmetric information settings.

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: Labour Market Frictions, Firm Growth, and International Trade
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>I study the aggregate effects of labour market frictions in a small open economy where firms grow slowly and make fixed export investments. The model features interactions between dynamic investments in exporting and search frictions with job-to-job mobility. A calibration to Argentina’s economy matching data on firm growth, worker transitions between firms, and export dynamics suggests that the real income gains from lowering frictions in job-to-job transitions are about seven times larger than comparable reductions in frictions from unemployment. Barriers to worker mobility across firms matter for the real income gains of trade-cost reductions.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the aggregate effects of labour market frictions in a small open economy where firms grow slowly and make fixed export investments?
answer: The real income gains from lowering frictions in job-to-job transitions are about seven times larger than comparable reductions in frictions from unemployment, and barriers to worker mobility across firms significantly affect the real income gains from trade-cost reductions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining the interactions between dynamic investments in exporting and search frictions with job-to-job mobility in a small open economy context, focusing specifically on how different types of labour market frictions affect aggregate outcomes and trade gains.

author: Olivier Tercieux
title: Efficiency, Justified Envy, and Incentives in Priority-Based Matching
abstract: <jats:p> Top trading cycles (TTC) is Pareto efficient and strategy-proof in priority-based matching, but so are other mechanisms including serial dictatorship. We show that TTC minimizes justified envy among all Pareto-efficient and strategy-proof mechanisms in one-to-one matching. In many-to-one matching, TTC admits less justified envy than serial dictatorship in an average sense. Empirical evidence from New Orleans OneApp and Boston Public Schools shows that TTC has significantly less justified envy than serial dictatorship. (JEL C78, D61) </jats:p>
research_question: Among Pareto-efficient and strategy-proof mechanisms in priority-based matching, which mechanism minimizes justified envy?
answer: Top trading cycles (TTC) minimizes justified envy among all Pareto-efficient and strategy-proof mechanisms in one-to-one matching, and admits less justified envy than serial dictatorship in many-to-one matching both theoretically and empirically.
positioning_statement: While existing literature establishes that both TTC and serial dictatorship are Pareto efficient and strategy-proof in priority-based matching, this paper differentiates between these mechanisms by introducing justified envy as a new criterion for evaluation, showing TTC's superiority on this dimension.

author: Olivier Tercieux
title: The Elusive Gains from International Financial Integration

author: Olivier Tercieux
title: Unpaired Kidney Exchange: Overcoming Double Coincidence of Wants without Money
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>For an incompatible patient–donor pair, kidney exchanges often forbid receipt-before-donation (the patient receives a kidney before the donor donates) and donation-before-receipt, causing a double-coincidence-of-wants problem. We study an algorithm, the Unpaired kidney exchange algorithm, which eliminates this problem. In a dynamic matching model, we show that the waiting time of patients under Unpaired is close to optimal and substantially shorter than under widely used algorithms. Using a rich administrative dataset from France, we show that Unpaired achieves a match rate of 63% and an average waiting time of 176 days for transplanted patients. The (infeasible) optimal algorithm is only slightly better (64% and 144 days); widely used algorithms deliver less than 40% match rate and at least 232 days waiting times. We discuss a range of solutions that can address the potential practical incentive challenges of Unpaired. In particular, we extend our analysis to an environment where a deceased donor waitlist can be integrated to improve the performance of algorithms. We show that our theoretical and empirical comparisons continue to hold. Finally, based on these analyses, we propose a practical version of the Unpaired algorithm.</jats:p>
research_question: How can kidney exchange systems overcome the double-coincidence-of-wants problem that arises when receipt-before-donation and donation-before-receipt are both forbidden for incompatible patient-donor pairs?
answer: The Unpaired kidney exchange algorithm eliminates the double-coincidence-of-wants problem and achieves substantially better performance than widely used algorithms, with a 63% match rate and 176 days average waiting time compared to less than 40% match rate and at least 232 days for existing algorithms.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental constraint in existing kidney exchange systems by proposing an algorithm that eliminates timing restrictions, positioning itself as a significant improvement over widely used algorithms that suffer from the double-coincidence-of-wants problem, and demonstrates both theoretical optimality and practical feasibility through dynamic matching models and empirical analysis using French administrative data.

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: Trade, Structural Transformation, and Development: Evidence from Argentina 1869–1914

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title:
Measuring the Unequal Gains from Trade
            *
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Individuals that consume different baskets of goods are differentially affected by relative price changes caused by international trade. We develop a methodology to measure the unequal gains from trade across consumers within countries. The approach requires data on aggregate expenditures and parameters estimated from a nonhomothetic gravity equation. We find that trade typically favors the poor, who concentrate spending in more traded sectors.</jats:p>
research_question: How are the gains from international trade distributed unequally across different consumers within countries?
answer: Trade typically favors the poor, who concentrate their spending in more traded sectors, meaning they benefit more from the relative price changes caused by international trade.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new methodology to measure unequal gains from trade across consumers within countries, addressing the differential effects of trade on individuals who consume different baskets of goods - a perspective that requires only aggregate expenditure data and parameters from nonhomothetic gravity equations.

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: Optimal Transport Networks in Spatial Equilibrium
abstract: <jats:p>We study optimal transport networks in spatial equilibrium. We develop a framework consisting of a neoclassical trade model with labor mobility in which locations are arranged on a graph. Goods must be shipped through linked locations, and transport costs depend on congestion and on the infrastructure in each link, giving rise to an optimal transport problem in general equilibrium. The optimal transport network is the solution to a social planner's problem of building infrastructure in each link. We provide conditions such that this problem is globally convex, guaranteeing its numerical tractability. We also study cases with increasing returns to transport technologies in which global convexity fails. We apply the framework to assess optimal investments and inefficiencies in the road networks of European countries.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we determine the optimal transport network infrastructure in spatial equilibrium when locations are connected through a graph and transport costs depend on congestion and infrastructure capacity?
answer: The optimal transport network can be found by solving a social planner's problem of building infrastructure in each link, with conditions identified that make this problem globally convex and numerically tractable, though global convexity fails under increasing returns to transport technologies.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new framework that combines a neoclassical trade model with labor mobility and optimal transport theory, extending existing literature by incorporating congestion effects and infrastructure decisions in a general equilibrium setting on network graphs.

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: Optimal Spatial Policies, Geography, and Sorting*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study optimal spatial policies in a quantitative trade and geography framework with spillovers and spatial sorting of heterogeneous workers. We characterize the spatial transfers that must hold in efficient allocations, as well as labor subsidies that can implement them. There exists scope for welfare-enhancing spatial policies even when spillovers are common across locations. Using data on U.S. cities and existing estimates of the spillover elasticities, we find that the U.S. economy would benefit from a reallocation of workers to currently low-wage cities. The optimal allocation features a greater share of high-skill workers in smaller cities relative to the observed allocation. Inefficient sorting may lead to substantial welfare costs.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the optimal spatial policies for allocating workers across locations in an economy with spillovers and spatial sorting of heterogeneous workers?
answer: The U.S. economy would benefit from reallocating workers to currently low-wage cities, with the optimal allocation featuring a greater share of high-skill workers in smaller cities relative to the current observed allocation, and inefficient sorting leads to substantial welfare costs.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the trade and geography literature by developing a quantitative framework that incorporates both spillovers and spatial sorting of heterogeneous workers to characterize optimal spatial policies, extending beyond existing work by showing that welfare-enhancing spatial policies have scope even when spillovers are common across locations.

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: Income Distribution, Product Quality, and International Trade

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: Uncertainty Traps*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a theory of endogenous uncertainty and business cycles in which short-lived shocks can generate long-lasting recessions. In the model, higher uncertainty about fundamentals discourages investment. Since agents learn from the actions of others, information flows slowly in times of low activity and uncertainty remains high, further discouraging investment. The economy displays uncertainty traps: self-reinforcing episodes of high uncertainty and low activity. Although the economy recovers quickly after small shocks, large temporary shocks may have long-lasting effects on the level of activity. The economy is subject to an information externality but uncertainty traps may remain in the efficient allocation. Embedding the mechanism in a standard business cycle framework, we find that endogenous uncertainty increases the persistence of large recessions and improves the performance of the model in accounting for the Great Recession.</jats:p>
research_question: How can short-lived shocks generate long-lasting recessions through endogenous uncertainty mechanisms?
answer: Short-lived shocks can create 'uncertainty traps' - self-reinforcing episodes where higher uncertainty discourages investment, which slows information flows and keeps uncertainty high, further discouraging investment and prolonging recessions.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theory of endogenous uncertainty and business cycles that explains persistent recessions through information externalities and social learning, extending standard business cycle frameworks to better account for phenomena like the Great Recession.

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: State Taxes and Spatial Misallocation

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: The US-China Trade War and Global Reallocations
abstract: <jats:p> The US-China trade war created net export opportunities rather than simply shifting trade across destinations. Many “bystander” countries grew their exports of taxed products into the rest of the world (excluding the United States and China). Country-specific components of tariff elasticities, rather than specialization patterns, drove large cross-country variation in export growth of tariff-exposed products. The elasticities of exports to US-Chinese tariffs identify whether a country’s exports complement or substitute the United States or China and its supply curve’s slope. Countries that operate along downward-sloping supplies whose exports substitute (complement) the United States and China are among the larger (smaller) beneficiaries of the trade war. (JEL F13, F14, O19, P33) </jats:p>
research_question: How did the US-China trade war affect global trade reallocations and export opportunities for bystander countries?
answer: The US-China trade war created net export opportunities rather than simply shifting trade across destinations, with many bystander countries growing their exports of taxed products globally. Countries with downward-sloping supply curves whose exports substitute the US and China benefited most, while those whose exports complement the US and China benefited least.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the trade war literature by demonstrating that country-specific tariff elasticities, rather than specialization patterns, drive cross-country variation in export growth, and by identifying how supply curve slopes and substitution/complementarity relationships determine which countries benefit from trade wars.

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: Optimal Lockdown in a Commuting Network
abstract: <jats:p> We study optimal dynamic lockdowns against COVID-19 within a commuting network. Our framework integrates canonical spatial epidemiology and trade models and is applied to cities with varying initial viral spread: Seoul, Daegu, and the New York City metropolitan area (NYM). Spatial lockdowns achieve substantially smaller income losses than uniform lockdowns. In the NYM and Daegu—with large initial shocks—the optimal lockdown restricts inflows to central districts before gradual relaxation, while in Seoul it imposes low temporal but large spatial variation. Actual commuting reductions were too weak in central locations in Daegu and the NYM and too strong across Seoul. (JEL H51, I12, I18, R23, R41) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the optimal dynamic lockdown policies against COVID-19 within a commuting network, and how do they vary across cities with different initial viral spread conditions?
answer: Spatial lockdowns achieve substantially smaller income losses than uniform lockdowns. For cities with large initial shocks (NYC metropolitan area and Daegu), optimal lockdowns should restrict inflows to central districts before gradual relaxation, while for cities with smaller initial spread (Seoul), optimal lockdowns should impose low temporal but large spatial variation.
positioning_statement: This paper integrates canonical spatial epidemiology and trade models to study optimal lockdown policies, positioning itself at the intersection of spatial economics, epidemiology, and trade theory to analyze COVID-19 policy responses across different urban contexts.

author: Pablo Kurlat
title: Lemons Markets and the Transmission of Aggregate Shocks
abstract: <jats:p> I study a dynamic economy featuring adverse selection in asset markets. Borrowing constrained entrepreneurs sell past projects to finance new investment, but asymmetric information creates a lemons problem. I show that this friction is equivalent to a tax on financial transactions. The implicit tax rate responds to aggregate shocks, generating amplification in the response of investment and cyclical variation in liquidity. (JEL D82, D92, E32, E44, G31, L15) </jats:p>
research_question: How does adverse selection in asset markets affect the transmission and amplification of aggregate shocks in a dynamic economy?
answer: Adverse selection in asset markets creates a lemons problem that is equivalent to a tax on financial transactions, where the implicit tax rate responds to aggregate shocks, generating amplification in investment responses and cyclical variation in liquidity.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating that information asymmetries in asset markets can serve as a mechanism for shock transmission and amplification, specifically showing how the lemons problem creates an endogenous friction that varies cyclically with aggregate conditions.

author: Pablo Kurlat
title: Asset Markets With Heterogeneous Information
abstract: This paper studies competitive equilibria of economies where assets are heterogeneous and traders have heterogeneous information about them. Markets are defined by a price and a procedure for clearing trades, and any asset can, in principle, be traded in any market. Buyers can use their information to impose acceptance rules which specify which assets they are willing to trade in each market. The set of markets where trade takes place is derived endogenously. The model can be applied to find conditions under which these economies feature fire sales, contagion, and flights to quality.

author: Pablo Kurlat
title: The Social Value of Financial Expertise
abstract: <jats:p> I study expertise acquisition in a model of trading under asymmetric information. I propose and implement a method to measure r, the ratio of the marginal social value to the marginal private value of expertise. This can be decomposed into three sufficient statistics: traders’ average profits, the fraction of bad assets among traded assets, and the elasticity of good assets traded with respect to capital inflows. I measure r = 0.16 for the junk bond underwriting market. Since this is less than 1, it implies that marginal investments in expertise destroy surplus. (JEL D82, G11, G14, G21, L84) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the social value of financial expertise relative to its private value in markets with asymmetric information?
answer: The ratio of marginal social value to marginal private value of expertise (r) is 0.16 in the junk bond underwriting market, indicating that marginal investments in expertise destroy social surplus since r < 1.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on trading under asymmetric information by proposing and implementing a novel method to measure the social versus private value of expertise, providing empirical evidence that challenges the assumption that private incentives for expertise acquisition align with social welfare.

author: Pablo Fajgelbaum
title: The Return to Protectionism*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>After decades of supporting free trade, in 2018 the United States raised import tariffs and major trade partners retaliated. We analyze the short-run impact of this return to protectionism on the U.S. economy. Import and retaliatory tariffs caused large declines in imports and exports. Prices of imports targeted by tariffs did not fall, implying complete pass-through of tariffs to duty-inclusive prices. The resulting losses to U.S. consumers and firms that buy imports was $51 billion, or 0.27% of GDP. We embed the estimated trade elasticities in a general-equilibrium model of the U.S. economy. After accounting for tariff revenue and gains to domestic producers, the aggregate real income loss was $7.2 billion, or 0.04% of GDP. Import tariffs favored sectors concentrated in politically competitive counties, and the model implies that tradeable-sector workers in heavily Republican counties were the most negatively affected due to the retaliatory tariffs. JEL Code: F1.</jats:p>
research_question: What was the short-run economic impact of the United States' return to protectionism through raised import tariffs in 2018 and the resulting retaliation by major trade partners?
answer: The return to protectionism caused large declines in imports and exports, with complete pass-through of tariffs to prices, resulting in $51 billion in losses to U.S. consumers and firms (0.27% of GDP), and an aggregate real income loss of $7.2 billion (0.04% of GDP) after accounting for tariff revenue and gains to domestic producers.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes a recent and significant shift from the decades-long U.S. support for free trade to protectionism in 2018, providing empirical evidence on the short-run economic consequences of this policy reversal using trade elasticity estimates embedded in a general-equilibrium model.

author: Pablo Kurlat
title: Signalling to Experts
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study competitive equilibria in a signalling economy with heterogeneously informed buyers. In terms of the classic Spence (1973, The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 87, 355—374) model of job market signalling, firms have access to direct but imperfect information about worker types, in addition to observing their education. Firms can be ranked according to the quality of their information, i.e., their expertise. In equilibrium, some high-type workers forgo signalling and are hired by better informed firms, which make positive profits. Workers’ education decisions and firms’ use of their expertise are strategic complements, allowing for multiple equilibria that can be Pareto ranked. We characterize wage dispersion and the extent of signalling as a function of the distribution of expertise among firms. Our model can also be applied to a variety of other signalling problems, including securitization, corporate financial structure, insurance markets, or dividend policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How do competitive equilibria in signalling markets change when buyers (firms) have heterogeneous levels of private information or expertise about the types of sellers (workers)?
answer: In equilibrium, some high-type workers choose not to signal and are hired by better-informed firms that make positive profits. Workers' education decisions and firms' use of expertise are strategic complements, leading to multiple Pareto-ranked equilibria with wage dispersion that depends on the distribution of expertise among firms.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the classic Spence (1973) job market signalling model by introducing heterogeneously informed buyers, where firms have access to direct but imperfect information about worker types in addition to observing education signals, and can be ranked by their information quality or expertise.

author: Pablo Kurlat

author: Paolo Surico
title: Model Uncertainty, Optimal Monetary Policy and the Preferences of the Fed
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Monetary policy in the US is characterized by a substantial degree of inertia. While in principle this may well be the outcome of an optimizing central bank behaviour, the ability of any derived policy rule to match the data relies on so large weights for interest rate smoothing into policy makers' preferences as to be theoretically flawed. In this paper we investigate whether such a puzzle can be interpreted as resulting from the concern of monetary authorities for potential misspecifications of the macroeconomic dynamics. Accordingly, we propose a novel <jats:italic>thick modelling</jats:italic> approach that incorporates model uncertainty into the identification of central bank's preferences. The <jats:italic>thick</jats:italic> robust policy rule shows the kind of smoothness observed in the data without resorting to implausible values for the preference parameters.</jats:p>
research_question: Can the substantial degree of inertia observed in US monetary policy be explained by central bank concerns about potential misspecifications of macroeconomic dynamics, rather than requiring implausibly large weights for interest rate smoothing in policy makers' preferences?
answer: Yes, incorporating model uncertainty through a novel 'thick modelling' approach can explain the smoothness observed in monetary policy data without requiring implausible values for preference parameters that traditional optimizing central bank models demand.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a theoretical puzzle in existing literature where derived policy rules can only match observed monetary policy inertia by assuming implausibly large weights for interest rate smoothing in central bank preferences, proposing instead that model uncertainty about macroeconomic dynamics can explain this phenomenon.

author: Paolo Surico
title: VAR Analysis and the Great Moderation
abstract: <jats:p> Most analyses of the US Great Moderation are based on structural VARs, and point toward good luck as the main explanation for the recent macroeconomic stability. Based on an estimated New-Keynesian model where the only source of change is the move from passive to active monetary policy, we show that (i) the theoretical VAR innovation variances for all series decrease across regimes; (ii) VAR-based counterfactuals assign a minor role to improved policy; and (iii) VAR impulse-response functions to a monetary shock exhibit little variation across regimes. Our analysis suggests that existing VAR evidence is also compatible with the “good policy” hypothesis. (JEL C32, C52, E13, E52, N12) </jats:p>
research_question: What explains the US Great Moderation - improved monetary policy ('good policy') or reduced economic shocks ('good luck')?
answer: Existing VAR evidence that has been interpreted as supporting the 'good luck' hypothesis is also compatible with the 'good policy' hypothesis, specifically the shift from passive to active monetary policy.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the prevailing interpretation of structural VAR analyses that point toward good luck as the main explanation for the Great Moderation, by demonstrating that the same VAR evidence can support the good policy explanation when viewed through the lens of an estimated New-Keynesian model.

author: Paolo Surico
title: Household Debt and the Dynamic Effects of Income Tax Changes

author: Paolo Surico
title: The Long-Run Effects of Government Spending
abstract: <jats:p> Military spending has large and persistent effects on output because it shifts the composition of public spending toward R&D. This boosts innovation and private investment in the medium term and increases productivity and GDP at longer horizons. Public R&D expenditure stimulates economic activities beyond the business cycle even when it is not associated with war spending. In contrast, the effects of public investment are shorter-lived, while public consumption has a modest impact at most horizons. We reach these conclusions using BVAR with long lags and 125 years of US data, including newly reconstructed series of government spending by main categories since 1890. (JEL E21, E22, E23, E62, H50, H56, O30) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-run effects of different types of government spending on economic output and productivity?
answer: Military spending has large and persistent positive effects on output because it shifts public spending composition toward R&D, which boosts innovation, private investment, productivity and GDP over the long term. Public R&D expenditure stimulates economic activity beyond business cycles, while public investment effects are shorter-lived and public consumption has modest impact.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the government spending literature by using a novel long-term historical dataset (125 years of US data with newly reconstructed spending series since 1890) and BVAR methodology with long lags to examine the differential long-run effects of disaggregated government spending categories, particularly highlighting the role of R&D spending composition in explaining military spending's persistent effects.

author: Paolo Surico
title: Mortgage Pricing and Monetary Policy
abstract: <jats:p> This paper examines how central bank policies influence mortgage pricing in the United Kingdom. It shows that lenders price discriminate by offering two-part tariffs of interest rates and origination fees, and during unconventional monetary policies like the Funding for Lending Scheme, lenders reduced interest rates while increasing fees. Using a model of mortgage demand and lender competition, we find that central bank policies increased mortgage lending. Additionally, banning origination fees would reduce lending, as fees help lenders capture surplus while allowing them to price discriminate across borrowers with different sensitivities to rates and fees. (JEL E43, E52, E58, G21, G28, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How do central bank policies influence mortgage pricing in the United Kingdom?
answer: Central bank policies, particularly unconventional monetary policies like the Funding for Lending Scheme, led lenders to reduce interest rates while increasing origination fees as part of their two-part tariff pricing strategy, ultimately increasing mortgage lending.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining the specific mechanisms through which central bank policies affect mortgage pricing, particularly focusing on how lenders use two-part tariffs (interest rates and origination fees) to price discriminate, and by developing a model of mortgage demand and lender competition to analyze these effects.

author: Paolo Surico
title: Insiders versus Outsiders in Monetary Policymaking

author: Paolo Surico
title: Regional Transfer Multipliers
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>A series of discontinuities in the allocation mechanism of federal transfers to municipal governments in Brazil allow us to identify the causal effect of public spending on local labour markets, using a “fuzzy” Regression Discontinuity Design (RDD). Our estimates imply a cost per job of about 8,000 US dollars per year and a local income multiplier around two. The effect comes mostly from employment in services and is more pronounced among less financially developed municipalities.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal effect of public spending on local labour markets?
answer: Public spending has a significant positive effect on local labour markets, with a cost per job of about $8,000 US dollars per year and a local income multiplier around two, with effects primarily in services employment and stronger impacts in less financially developed municipalities.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using discontinuities in Brazil's federal transfer allocation mechanism to identify causal effects through a fuzzy Regression Discontinuity Design, providing clean identification of public spending multipliers in a developing country context.

author: Paolo Surico
title: Two Illustrations of the Quantity Theory of Money: Breakdowns and Revivals
abstract: <jats:p> By extending his data, we document the instability of low-frequency regression coefficients that Lucas (1980) used to express the quantity theory of money. We impute the differences in these regression coefficients to differences in monetary policies across periods. A DSGE model estimated over a subsample like Lucas's implies values of the regression coefficients that confirm Lucas's results for his sample period. But perturbing monetary policy rule parameters away from the values estimated over Lucas's subsample alters the regression coefficients in ways that reproduce their instability over our longer sample. (JEL C51, E23, E31, E43, E51, E52) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do the low-frequency regression coefficients used to express the quantity theory of money exhibit instability over extended time periods beyond Lucas's original sample?
answer: The instability of regression coefficients expressing the quantity theory of money is caused by differences in monetary policies across periods - when monetary policy rule parameters change, the regression coefficients change accordingly, explaining their instability over longer samples.
positioning_statement: This paper extends Lucas (1980)'s influential work on the quantity theory of money by using a longer data sample and DSGE modeling to explain the breakdown and revival of the empirical relationships that Lucas documented, attributing the instability to monetary policy changes rather than fundamental failures of the quantity theory.

author: Paolo Surico
title: Monetary Policy when Households have Debt: New Evidence on the Transmission Mechanism
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Using household survey data for the U.S. and the U.K., we show that the aggregate response of consumption to interest rate changes is driven by households with a mortgage. Outright home-owners do not adjust expenditure at all while renters change their spending but by less than mortgagors. Income rises for all households as interest rate cuts directly affect firm investment and household consumption, boosting aggregate demand. A crucial difference between the housing tenure groups is the composition of their balance sheets: mortgagors hold sizable illiquid assets but little liquid wealth. Our results reveal that general equilibrium effects on household income coupled with balance-sheet-driven heterogeneity in the marginal propensity to consume play a key role in the transmission of monetary policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How does household debt, particularly mortgage debt, affect the transmission mechanism of monetary policy to consumption?
answer: The aggregate consumption response to interest rate changes is driven primarily by households with mortgages, while outright homeowners do not adjust expenditure and renters respond less than mortgagors. This differential response is explained by balance sheet composition differences - mortgagors hold large illiquid assets but little liquid wealth - combined with general equilibrium income effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new empirical evidence on monetary policy transmission by using household survey data to reveal that balance-sheet-driven heterogeneity in marginal propensity to consume, coupled with general equilibrium effects on household income, plays a key role in how monetary policy affects the economy through household debt channels.

author: Paolo Surico
title: Organized crime and electoral outcomes. Evidence from Sicily at the turn of the XXI century

author: Parag Pathak
title: The Distributional Consequences of Public School Choice
abstract: <jats:p> School choice systems aspire to delink residential location and school assignments by allowing children to apply to schools outside of their neighborhood. However, choice programs also affect incentives to live in certain neighborhoods, and this feedback may undermine the goals of choice. We investigate this possibility by developing a model of public school and residential choice. School choice narrows the range between the highest and lowest quality schools compared to neighborhood assignment rules, and these changes in school quality are capitalized into equilibrium housing prices. This compressed distribution generates an ends-against-the-middle trade-off with school choice compared to neighborhood assignment. Paradoxically, even when choice results in improvement in the lowest-performing schools, the lowest type residents need not benefit. (JEL H75, I21, I28, R23, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How does public school choice affect the distribution of educational outcomes and residential patterns, particularly whether choice programs achieve their goal of delinking residential location from school quality?
answer: School choice creates an 'ends-against-the-middle' trade-off by compressing the distribution of school quality, which gets capitalized into housing prices. Paradoxically, even when choice improves the lowest-performing schools, the lowest-income residents may not benefit due to these equilibrium effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the school choice literature by developing a model that accounts for the feedback effects between school choice policies and residential location decisions, revealing unintended distributional consequences that prior research may have overlooked by not considering these equilibrium interactions.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Leveling the Playing Field: Sincere and Sophisticated Players in the Boston Mechanism
abstract: <jats:p> Empirical and experimental evidence suggests different levels of sophistication among families in the Boston Public School student assignment plan. We analyze the preference revelation game induced by the Boston mechanism with sincere players who report their true preferences and sophisticated players who play a best response. We characterize the set of Nash equilibrium outcomes as the set of stable matchings of a modified economy, where sincere students lose priority to sophisticated students. Any sophisticated student weakly prefers her assignment under the Pareto-dominant Nash equilibrium of the Boston mechanism to her assignment under the recently adopted student-optimal stable mechanism. (JEL D82, I21) </jats:p>
research_question: How do different levels of player sophistication (sincere vs. sophisticated) affect outcomes in the Boston mechanism for school choice, and what are the equilibrium properties when both types of players coexist?
answer: The set of Nash equilibrium outcomes corresponds to stable matchings in a modified economy where sincere students lose priority to sophisticated students, and sophisticated students weakly prefer their assignments under the Pareto-dominant Nash equilibrium of the Boston mechanism compared to the student-optimal stable mechanism.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on empirical and experimental evidence showing heterogeneous sophistication levels among families in Boston Public School assignment, extending the theoretical analysis of the Boston mechanism by explicitly modeling the coexistence of sincere and sophisticated players rather than assuming uniform player behavior.

author: Parag Pathak
title: The Efficiency of Race-Neutral Alternatives to Race-Based Affirmative Action: Evidence from Chicago’s Exam Schools
abstract: <jats:p> Several K-12 and university systems have adopted race-neutral affirmative action in place of race-based alternatives. This paper explores whether these plans are effective substitutes for racial quotas in Chicago Public Schools (CPS), which now employs a race-neutral, place-based affirmative action system at its selective exam high schools. The CPS plan is ineffective compared to plans that explicitly consider race: about three-quarters of the reduction in average entrance scores at the top schools could have been avoided with the same level of racial diversity. Moreover, the CPS plan is less effective at adding low-income students than was the previous system of racial quotas. We develop a theoretical framework that motivates quantifying the inefficiency of race-neutral policies based on the distortion in student preparedness they create for a given level of diversity and use it to evaluate several alternatives. The CPS plan can be improved in several ways, but no race-neutral policy restores minority representation to prior levels without substantially greater distortions, implying significant efficiency costs from prohibitions on the explicit use of race. (JEL H75, I21, I28, J15) </jats:p>
research_question: Are race-neutral affirmative action plans effective substitutes for race-based alternatives in achieving diversity goals at selective schools?
answer: Race-neutral affirmative action plans are ineffective substitutes for race-based policies - they create significant efficiency costs and distortions in student preparedness while failing to restore minority representation to prior levels or effectively add low-income students.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on affirmative action policy alternatives by providing empirical evidence from Chicago Public Schools and developing a theoretical framework to quantify the inefficiency of race-neutral policies, specifically measuring the distortion in student preparedness they create for a given level of diversity.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Incentives and Stability in Large Two-Sided Matching Markets
abstract: <jats:p> A number of labor markets and student placement systems can be modeled as many-to-one matching markets. We analyze the scope for manipulation in many-to-one matching markets under the student-optimal stable mechanism when the number of participants is large. Under some regularity conditions, we show that the fraction of participants with incentives to misrepresent their preferences when others are truthful approaches zero as the market becomes large. With an additional condition, truthful reporting by every participant is an approximate equilibrium under the student-optimal stable mechanism in large markets. (JEL C78) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the scope for manipulation in many-to-one matching markets under the student-optimal stable mechanism when the number of participants is large?
answer: Under regularity conditions, the fraction of participants with incentives to misrepresent their preferences approaches zero as the market becomes large, and truthful reporting by every participant becomes an approximate equilibrium in large markets.
positioning_statement: This paper analyzes manipulation incentives in large two-sided matching markets, specifically focusing on many-to-one matching markets (such as labor markets and student placement systems) and examining how market size affects strategic behavior under the student-optimal stable mechanism.

author: Parag Pathak
title: School Admissions Reform in Chicago and England: Comparing Mechanisms by their Vulnerability to Manipulation
abstract: <jats:p> In Fall 2009, Chicago authorities abandoned a school assignment mechanism midstream, citing concerns about its vulnerability to manipulation. Nonetheless, they asked thousands of applicants to re-rank schools in a new mechanism that is also manipulable. This paper introduces a method to compare mechanisms by their vulnerability to manipulation. Our methodology formalizes how the old mechanism is at least as manipulable as any other plausible mechanism, including the new one. A number of similar transitions took place in England after the widely popular Boston mechanism was ruled illegal in 2007. Our approach provides support for these and other recent policy changes. (JEL C78, D82, H75, I21, I28) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we systematically compare school assignment mechanisms by their vulnerability to manipulation?
answer: The paper develops a methodology that formalizes how mechanisms can be ranked by manipulability, demonstrating that Chicago's old mechanism was at least as manipulable as any other plausible mechanism, including the new one they adopted.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on school choice mechanisms by introducing a novel method for comparing manipulability across different assignment systems, providing theoretical support for recent policy changes in Chicago and England following the ruling against the Boston mechanism in 2007.

author: Parag Pathak
title: The Impact of Commissions on Home Sales in Greater Boston

author: Parag Pathak
title: Redesigning the US Army’s Branching Process: A Case Study in Minimalist Market Design
abstract: <jats:p> We present a proof-of-concept for minimalist market design (Sönmez 2023) as an effective methodology to enhance an institution based on stakeholders’ desiderata with minimal interference. Four objectives— respecting merit, increasing retention, aligning talent, and enhancing trust—guided reforms to the US Army’s centralized branching process of cadets to military specialties since 2006. USMA’s mechanism for the class of 2020 exacerbated challenges in implementing these objectives. Formulating the Army’s desiderata as rigorous axioms, we analyze their implications. Under our minimalist approach to institution redesign, the Army’s objectives uniquely identify a branching mechanism. Our design is now adopted at USMA and ROTC. (JEL D47, H56, J45) </jats:p>
research_question: How can the US Army's centralized branching process for assigning cadets to military specialties be redesigned to better achieve the Army's objectives of respecting merit, increasing retention, aligning talent, and enhancing trust?
answer: By applying minimalist market design methodology and formulating the Army's desiderata as rigorous axioms, the Army's four objectives uniquely identify a specific branching mechanism that has now been adopted at both USMA and ROTC.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a proof-of-concept for minimalist market design (Sönmez 2023) as an effective methodology for institutional enhancement, demonstrating how this approach can redesign existing institutions based on stakeholders' objectives with minimal interference.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Matching with Couples: Stability and Incentives in Large Markets*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Accommodating couples has been a long-standing issue in the design of centralized labor market clearinghouses for doctors and psychologists, because couples view pairs of jobs as complements. A stable matching may not exist when couples are present. This article’s main result is that a stable matching exists when there are relatively few couples and preference lists are sufficiently short relative to market size. We also discuss incentives in markets with couples. We relate these theoretical results to the job market for psychologists, in which stable matchings exist for all years of the data, despite the presence of couples.</jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions do stable matchings exist in centralized labor market clearinghouses when couples are present, given that couples view pairs of jobs as complements?
answer: A stable matching exists when there are relatively few couples and preference lists are sufficiently short relative to market size.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a long-standing issue in the design of centralized labor market clearinghouses for doctors and psychologists by providing theoretical conditions for stability when couples are present, and validates these findings with empirical evidence from the psychology job market where stable matchings exist despite couple participation.

author: Parag Pathak
title: The Welfare Effects of Coordinated Assignment: Evidence from the New York City High School Match
abstract: <jats:p> Coordinated single-offer school assignment systems are a popular education reform. We show that uncoordinated offers in NYC's school assignment mechanism generated mismatches. One-third of applicants were unassigned after the main round and later administratively placed at less desirable schools. We evaluate the effects of the new coordinated mechanism based on deferred acceptance using estimated student preferences. The new mechanism achieves 80 percent of the possible gains from a no-choice neighborhood extreme to a utilitarian benchmark. Coordinating offers dominates the effects of further algorithm modifications. Students most likely to be previously administratively assigned experienced the largest gains in welfare and subsequent achievement. (JEL C78, D82, I21, I28) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the welfare effects of implementing a coordinated single-offer school assignment system (deferred acceptance mechanism) compared to an uncoordinated assignment system?
answer: The coordinated mechanism significantly improves welfare, achieving 80 percent of the possible gains between a no-choice neighborhood system and a utilitarian benchmark. Students who were previously most likely to be administratively assigned experienced the largest gains in both welfare and subsequent achievement.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on school assignment mechanisms by providing empirical evidence of welfare gains from coordinated assignment systems, specifically demonstrating that coordinating offers has larger effects than further algorithm modifications and focusing on a real-world implementation in NYC's high school match system.

author: Parag Pathak
title: The Dynamics of Open-Source Contributors

author: Parag Pathak
title: Interpreting Tests of School VAM Validity
abstract: <jats:p> We develop over-identification tests that use admissions lotteries to assess the predictive value of regression-based value-added models (VAMs). These tests have degrees of freedom equal to the number of quasi-experiments available to estimate school effects. By contrast, previously implemented VAM validation strategies look at a single restriction only, sometimes said to measure forecast bias. Tests of forecast bias may be misleading when the test statistic is constructed from many lotteries or quasi-experiments, some of which have weak first stage effects on school attendance. The theory developed here is applied to data from the Charlotte-Mecklenberg School district analyzed by Deming (2014). </jats:p>
research_question: How can admissions lotteries be used to develop better tests for assessing the predictive validity of regression-based value-added models (VAMs) for schools?
answer: The paper develops over-identification tests using admissions lotteries that have degrees of freedom equal to the number of quasi-experiments available, which provide more robust validation of VAMs compared to single-restriction tests that may be misleading when constructed from many lotteries with weak first-stage effects.
positioning_statement: This paper advances beyond previously implemented VAM validation strategies that examine only a single restriction (often measuring forecast bias) by developing a more comprehensive testing framework that accounts for multiple quasi-experiments and addresses potential biases from weak first-stage effects in lottery-based validation.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Strategy-proofness versus Efficiency in Matching with Indifferences: Redesigning the NYC High School Match
abstract: <jats:p> The design of the New York City (NYC) high school match involved trade-offs among efficiency, stability, and strategy-proofness that raise new theoretical questions. We analyze a model with indifferences—ties—in school preferences. Simulations with field data and the theory favor breaking indifferences the same way at every school—single tiebreaking—in a student-proposing deferred acceptance mechanism. Any inefficiency associated with a realized tiebreaking cannot be removed without harming student incentives. Finally, we empirically document the extent of potential efficiency loss associated with strategy-proofness and stability, and direct attention to some open questions. (JEL C78, D82, I21) </jats:p>
research_question: How should indifferences (ties) in school preferences be handled in the NYC high school match to balance trade-offs among efficiency, stability, and strategy-proofness?
answer: Breaking indifferences the same way at every school (single tiebreaking) in a student-proposing deferred acceptance mechanism is optimal, and any inefficiency from realized tiebreaking cannot be removed without harming student incentives.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses new theoretical questions that arose from the practical design challenges of the NYC high school match, specifically focusing on the previously understudied issue of how to handle ties in school preferences within matching mechanisms, while empirically documenting efficiency losses associated with strategy-proofness and stability requirements.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Breaking Ties: Regression Discontinuity Design Meets Market Design
abstract: <jats:p>Many schools in large urban districts have more applicants than seats. Centralized school assignment algorithms ration seats at over‐subscribed schools using randomly assigned lottery numbers, non‐lottery tie‐breakers like test scores, or both. The New York City public high school match illustrates the latter, using test scores and other criteria to rank applicants at the city's screened schools, combined with lottery tie‐breaking at the rest. We show how to identify causal effects of school attendance in such settings. Our approach generalizes regression discontinuity methods to allow for multiple treatments and multiple running variables, some of which are randomly assigned. The key to this generalization is a local propensity score that quantifies the school assignment probabilities induced by lottery and non‐lottery tie‐breakers. The utility of the local propensity score is demonstrated in an assessment of the predictive value of New York City's school report cards. Schools that earn the highest report card grade indeed improve SAT math scores and increase graduation rates, though by much less than OLS estimates suggest. Selection bias in OLS estimates of grade effects is egregious for screened schools.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we identify causal effects of school attendance in centralized school assignment systems that use both lottery-based random assignment and non-lottery tie-breakers like test scores?
answer: The paper develops a generalized regression discontinuity method using a local propensity score that quantifies school assignment probabilities from both lottery and non-lottery tie-breakers. Applied to NYC schools, they find that top-rated schools do improve SAT math scores and graduation rates, but by much less than OLS estimates suggest, with particularly severe selection bias for screened schools.
positioning_statement: This paper generalizes regression discontinuity methods to handle multiple treatments and multiple running variables (some randomly assigned) in market design settings, extending beyond traditional single-cutoff RD designs to address the complexity of real-world centralized assignment mechanisms that combine lottery and merit-based allocation.

author: Parag Pathak
title: The New York City High School Match

author: Parag Pathak
title: Do Parents Value School Effectiveness?
abstract: <jats:p> School choice may lead to improvements in school productivity if parents’ choices reward effective schools and punish ineffective ones. This mechanism requires parents to choose schools based on causal effectiveness rather than peer characteristics. We study relationships among parent preferences, peer quality, and causal effects on outcomes for applicants to New York City’s centralized high school assignment mechanism. We use applicants’ rank-ordered choice lists to measure preferences and to construct selection-corrected estimates of treatment effects on test scores, high school graduation, college attendance, and college quality. Parents prefer schools that enroll high-achieving peers, and these schools generate larger improvements in short- and long-run student outcomes. Preferences are unrelated to school effectiveness and academic match quality after controlling for peer quality. (JEL D12, H75, I21, I26, I28) </jats:p>
research_question: Do parents choose schools based on causal effectiveness rather than peer characteristics, and does this mechanism lead to improvements in school productivity through school choice?
answer: Parents prefer schools that enroll high-achieving peers, and these schools do generate larger improvements in student outcomes, but parent preferences are unrelated to school effectiveness and academic match quality after controlling for peer quality.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the school choice literature by examining the critical mechanism underlying theoretical claims that school choice improves productivity - specifically testing whether parents actually reward effective schools rather than simply selecting based on peer characteristics.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Housing Market Spillovers: Evidence from the End of Rent Control in Cambridge, Massachusetts

author: Parag Pathak
title: The Long-Term Effects of Universal Preschool in Boston
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We use admissions lotteries to estimate the effects of large-scale public preschool in Boston on college-going, college preparation, standardized test scores, and behavioral outcomes. Preschool enrollment boosts college attendance as well as SAT test taking and high school graduation. Preschool also decreases high school disciplinary measures including juvenile incarceration, but has no detectable effect on state achievement test scores. An analysis of subgroups shows that effects on college enrollment, SAT-taking, and disciplinary outcomes are larger for boys than for girls. Our findings illustrate possibilities for large-scale modern, public preschool and highlight the importance of measuring long-term and non–test score outcomes in evaluating the effectiveness of education programs.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-term effects of large-scale public preschool enrollment on educational attainment, college preparation, academic achievement, and behavioral outcomes?
answer: Universal preschool in Boston increases college attendance, SAT test taking, and high school graduation rates while decreasing disciplinary problems and juvenile incarceration, with no detectable effects on state achievement test scores. Effects are particularly pronounced for boys compared to girls.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the education program evaluation literature by demonstrating the importance of measuring long-term and non-test score outcomes when assessing effectiveness, using rigorous lottery-based methodology to evaluate large-scale modern public preschool programs.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Charters without Lotteries: Testing Takeovers in New Orleans and Boston
abstract: <jats:p> Charter takeovers are traditional public schools restarted as charter schools. We develop a grandfathering instrument for takeover attendance that compares students at schools designated for takeover with a matched sample of students attending similar schools not yet taken over. Grandfathering estimates from New Orleans show substantial gains from takeover enrollment. In Boston, grandfathered students see achievement gains at least as large as the gains for students assigned charter seats in lotteries. A non-charter Boston turnaround intervention that had much in common with the takeover strategy generated gains as large as those seen for takeovers, while other more modest turnaround interventions yielded smaller effects. (JEL D44, H75, I21, I28) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of charter takeovers (traditional public schools restarted as charter schools) on student achievement?
answer: Charter takeovers generate substantial student achievement gains - in New Orleans takeover enrollment produces substantial gains, and in Boston grandfathered students at takeover schools see achievement gains at least as large as students assigned charter seats through lotteries.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the challenge of evaluating charter school effectiveness when lotteries are not available by developing a novel grandfathering instrument that compares students at schools designated for takeover with matched students at similar schools not yet taken over, and compares takeover effects to both lottery-based charter estimates and other turnaround interventions.
