author: Parag Pathak
title: Research Design Meets Market Design: Using Centralized Assignment for Impact Evaluation
abstract: A growing number of school districts use centralized assignment mechanisms to allocate school seats in a manner that reflects student preferences and school priorities. Many of these assignment schemes use lotteries to ration seats when schools are oversubscribed. The resulting random assignment opens the door to credible quasi‐experimental research designs for the evaluation of school effectiveness. Yet the question of how best to separate the lottery‐generated randomization integral to such designs from non‐random preferences and priorities remains open. This paper develops easily‐implemented empirical strategies that fully exploit the random assignment embedded in a wide class of mechanisms, while also revealing why seats are randomized at one school but not another. We use these methods to evaluate charter schools in Denver, one of a growing number of districts that combine charter and traditional public schools in a unified assignment system. The resulting estimates show large achievement gains from charter school attendance. Our approach generates efficiency gains over ad hoc methods, such as those that focus on schools ranked first, while also identifying a more representative average causal effect. We also show how to use centralized assignment mechanisms to identify causal effects in models with multiple school sectors.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Race and the Mismeasure of School Quality
abstract: <jats:p> In large urban districts, schools enrolling more White students tend to have higher performance ratings. We use an instrumental variables strategy leveraging centralized school assignment to explore this relationship. Estimates from Denver and New York City suggest that the correlation between school performance ratings and White enrollment shares reflects selection bias rather than causal school value added. In fact, value added in these two cities is essentially unrelated to White enrollment shares. A simple regression adjustment is shown to yield school ratings uncorrelated with race while predicting value added as well as or better than the corresponding unadjusted measures. (JEL H75, I21, I24, I28, J15) </jats:p>
research_question: Does the correlation between school performance ratings and White enrollment shares in large urban districts reflect actual causal school value added or selection bias?
answer: The correlation between school performance ratings and White enrollment shares reflects selection bias rather than causal school value added - actual value added is essentially unrelated to White enrollment shares in Denver and New York City.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional interpretation of school performance ratings by demonstrating that commonly observed correlations between school ratings and racial composition are misleading measures of actual school quality, and proposes a regression adjustment method that eliminates racial bias while maintaining or improving predictive accuracy for value added.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Efficiency, Justified Envy, and Incentives in Priority-Based Matching
abstract: <jats:p> Top trading cycles (TTC) is Pareto efficient and strategy-proof in priority-based matching, but so are other mechanisms including serial dictatorship. We show that TTC minimizes justified envy among all Pareto-efficient and strategy-proof mechanisms in one-to-one matching. In many-to-one matching, TTC admits less justified envy than serial dictatorship in an average sense. Empirical evidence from New Orleans OneApp and Boston Public Schools shows that TTC has significantly less justified envy than serial dictatorship. (JEL C78, D61) </jats:p>
research_question: Among Pareto-efficient and strategy-proof mechanisms in priority-based matching, which mechanism minimizes justified envy?
answer: Top trading cycles (TTC) minimizes justified envy among all Pareto-efficient and strategy-proof mechanisms in one-to-one matching, and admits less justified envy than serial dictatorship in many-to-one matching both theoretically and empirically.
positioning_statement: While existing literature establishes that both TTC and serial dictatorship are Pareto efficient and strategy-proof in priority-based matching, this paper differentiates between these mechanisms by introducing justified envy as a new criterion for evaluation, showing TTC's superiority on this dimension.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Forced Sales and House Prices
abstract: <jats:p> This paper uses data on all house transactions in Massachusetts over the last 20 years to show that houses sold after foreclosure, or close in time to the death or bankruptcy of a seller, are sold at lower prices than other houses. Foreclosure discounts are on average at 27 percent of the value of a house. Moreover, foreclosures that take place within small local geographies of a house lower the price at which it is sold. Our preferred estimate is that a foreclosure at a distance of 0.05 miles lowers the price of a house by about 1 percent. JEL: D14, R31 </jats:p>
research_question: How do forced sales (foreclosures, deaths, bankruptcies) affect house prices both for the properties being sold and for nearby properties?
answer: Houses sold under forced sale conditions sell at significant discounts - foreclosed houses sell for 27% below market value on average, and foreclosures within 0.05 miles of a property lower its sale price by approximately 1%.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes comprehensive empirical evidence using 20 years of Massachusetts transaction data to quantify the price effects of forced sales, providing precise estimates of both direct discounts on forced sale properties and spillover effects on neighboring properties.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Erratum to “Leveraging Lotteries for School Value-Added: Testing and Estimation”

author: Patrick Kline
title: Oaxaca-Blinder as a Reweighting Estimator
abstract: <jats:p>The classic regression based estimator of counterfactual means studied by Ronald Oaxaca (1973) and Alan Blinder (1973) is shown to constitute a propensity score reweighting estimator based upon a linear model for the conditional odds of being treated.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between the Oaxaca-Blinder regression-based estimator and propensity score reweighting methods?
answer: The classic Oaxaca-Blinder regression-based estimator of counterfactual means is equivalent to a propensity score reweighting estimator that uses a linear model for the conditional odds of being treated.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a new theoretical perspective on the classic Oaxaca (1973) and Blinder (1973) estimator by connecting it to the propensity score reweighting literature, showing that these seemingly different methodological approaches are fundamentally equivalent.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Leveraging Lotteries for School Value-Added: Testing and Estimation*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Conventional value-added models (VAMs) compare average test scores across schools after regression-adjusting for students’ demographic characteristics and previous scores. This article tests for VAM bias using a procedure that asks whether VAM estimates accurately predict the achievement consequences of random assignment to specific schools. Test results from admissions lotteries in Boston suggest conventional VAM estimates are biased, a finding that motivates the development of a hierarchical model describing the joint distribution of school value-added, bias, and lottery compliance. We use this model to assess the substantive importance of bias in conventional VAM estimates and to construct hybrid value-added estimates that optimally combine ordinary least squares and lottery-based estimates of VAM parameters. The hybrid estimation strategy provides a general recipe for combining nonexperimental and quasi-experimental estimates. While still biased, hybrid school value-added estimates have lower mean squared error than conventional VAM estimates. Simulations calibrated to the Boston data show that, bias notwithstanding, policy decisions based on conventional VAMs that control for lagged achievement are likely to generate substantial achievement gains. Hybrid estimates that incorporate lotteries yield further gains.</jats:p>
research_question: Are conventional value-added models (VAMs) that compare average test scores across schools after regression-adjusting for student characteristics biased, and can lottery-based estimates be combined with conventional estimates to improve accuracy?
answer: Conventional VAM estimates are biased when tested against admissions lottery data from Boston, but hybrid value-added estimates that optimally combine ordinary least squares and lottery-based estimates have lower mean squared error than conventional VAMs alone, and policy decisions based on these hybrid estimates yield greater achievement gains.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a novel testing procedure for VAM bias using lottery-based validation, creating a hierarchical model that jointly describes school value-added, bias, and lottery compliance, and providing a general methodological framework for combining nonexperimental and quasi-experimental estimates that can be applied beyond education research.

author: Parag Pathak
title: Regression Discontinuity in Serial Dictatorship: Achievement Effects at Chicago's Exam Schools
abstract: <jats:p> Many school and college admission systems use centralized mechanisms to allocate seats based on applicant preferences and school priorities. When tie-breaking uses non-randomly assigned criteria like distance or a test score, applicants with the same preferences and priorities are not directly comparable. The non-lottery setting does generate a kind of local random assignment that opens the door to regression discontinuity designs. This paper introduces a hybrid RD/propensity score empirical strategy that exploits quasi-experiments embedded in serial dictatorship, a mechanism widely used for college and selective K-12 school admissions. We use our approach to estimate achievement effects of Chicago's exam schools. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the achievement effects of attending Chicago's exam schools, and how can we estimate these effects when school admission systems use non-random tie-breaking criteria?
answer: The paper develops a hybrid RD/propensity score empirical strategy that exploits quasi-experiments embedded in serial dictatorship mechanisms to estimate achievement effects of Chicago's exam schools.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a methodological gap in evaluating school choice systems where tie-breaking uses non-randomly assigned criteria (like distance or test scores), making applicants with same preferences and priorities not directly comparable, by introducing a novel hybrid approach that combines regression discontinuity with propensity score methods to exploit local random assignment in serial dictatorship mechanisms.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Bounding the Labor Supply Responses to a Randomized Welfare Experiment: A Revealed Preference Approach
abstract: <jats:p> We study the short-term impact of Connecticut's Jobs First welfare reform experiment on women's labor supply and welfare participation decisions. A nonparametric optimizing model is shown to restrict the set of counterfactual choices compatible with each woman's actual choice. These revealed preference restrictions yield informative bounds on the frequency of several intensive and extensive margin responses to the experiment. We find that welfare reform induced many women to work but led some others to reduce their earnings in order to receive assistance. The bounds on this latter “ opt-in” effect imply that intensive margin labor supply responses are nontrivial. (JEL H23, H75, I38, J16, J22) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the short-term impact of Connecticut's Jobs First welfare reform experiment on women's labor supply and welfare participation decisions?
answer: Welfare reform induced many women to work but led some others to reduce their earnings in order to receive assistance, with nontrivial intensive margin labor supply responses including an 'opt-in' effect where some women strategically reduced earnings to qualify for benefits.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a nonparametric optimizing model with revealed preference restrictions to bound counterfactual choices, providing a novel methodological approach to studying welfare reform effects that can identify both extensive and intensive margin responses without requiring strong parametric assumptions.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Place Based Policies with Unemployment
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a stylized model of frictional local labor markets with the goal of studying the efficiency of unemployment differences across areas. The model adapts the widely used Diamond-Mortensen-Pissarides framework to a local labor market setting with a competitive housing market. The result is a simple search analogue of the classic Roback model that provides a tractable environment for studying the effects of local job creation efforts. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the efficiency of unemployment differences across areas and how do place-based policies affect local job creation in frictional labor markets?
answer: The paper develops a tractable search model that adapts the Diamond-Mortensen-Pissarides framework to local labor markets with competitive housing, creating a search analogue of the classic Roback model for studying local job creation effects.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as bridging two established frameworks - adapting the widely used Diamond-Mortensen-Pissarides search model to create a search analogue of the classic Roback spatial equilibrium model, thereby extending existing literature on both search theory and spatial economics to study place-based policies.

author: Patrick Kline
title: On Heckits, LATE, and Numerical Equivalence
abstract: <jats:p>Structural econometric methods are often criticized for being sensitive to functional form assumptions. We study parametric estimators of the local average treatment effect (LATE) derived from a widely used class of latent threshold crossing models and show they yield LATE estimates algebraically equivalent to the instrumental variables (IV) estimator. Our leading example is Heckman's (1979) two‐step (“Heckit”) control function estimator which, with two‐sided non‐compliance, can be used to compute estimates of a variety of causal parameters. Equivalence with IV is established for a semiparametric family of control function estimators and shown to hold at interior solutions for a class of maximum likelihood estimators. Our results suggest differences between structural and IV estimates often stem from disagreements about the target parameter rather than from functional form assumptions per se. In cases where equivalence fails, reporting structural estimates of LATE alongside IV provides a simple means of assessing the credibility of structural extrapolation exercises.</jats:p>
research_question: Do parametric structural econometric estimators, particularly Heckman's two-step control function estimator, yield different estimates than instrumental variables estimators due to functional form assumptions?
answer: Parametric estimators of the local average treatment effect (LATE) from latent threshold crossing models are algebraically equivalent to instrumental variables estimators, suggesting that differences between structural and IV estimates typically stem from disagreements about the target parameter rather than functional form assumptions.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the common criticism that structural econometric methods are overly sensitive to functional form assumptions by demonstrating numerical equivalence between a widely used class of structural estimators and instrumental variables estimators, reframing the debate from methodological differences to parameter interpretation differences.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Local Economic Development, Agglomeration Economies, and the Big Push: 100 Years of Evidence from the Tennessee Valley Authority *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the long-run effects of one of the most ambitious regional development programs in U.S. history: the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA). Using as controls authorities that were proposed but never approved by Congress, we find that the TVA led to large gains in agricultural employment that were eventually reversed when the program’s subsidies ended. Gains in manufacturing employment, by contrast, continued to intensify well after federal transfers had lapsed—a pattern consistent with the presence of agglomeration economies in manufacturing. Because manufacturing paid higher wages than agriculture, this shift raised aggregate income in the TVA region for an extended period of time. Economists have long cautioned that the local gains created by place-based policies may be offset by losses elsewhere. We develop a structured approach to assessing the TVA’s aggregate consequences that is applicable to other place-based policies. In our model, the TVA affects the national economy both directly through infrastructure improvements and indirectly through agglomeration economies. The model’s estimates suggest that the TVA’s direct investments yielded a significant increase in national manufacturing productivity, with benefits exceeding the program’s costs. However, the program’s indirect effects appear to have been limited: agglomeration gains in the TVA region were offset by losses in the rest of the country. Spillovers in manufacturing appear to be the rare example of a localized market failure that cancels out in the aggregate.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-run effects of the Tennessee Valley Authority regional development program, and do the benefits of this place-based policy extend beyond local gains to create net positive aggregate effects for the national economy?
answer: The TVA created lasting manufacturing employment gains through agglomeration economies that persisted after subsidies ended, while agricultural gains were temporary. The program's direct infrastructure investments yielded net positive returns exceeding costs, but indirect agglomeration benefits were offset by losses elsewhere in the country, resulting in limited aggregate spillover effects.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses economists' long-standing concern that local gains from place-based policies may be offset by losses elsewhere by developing a structured approach to assess aggregate consequences, using the TVA as a case study to demonstrate how agglomeration economies represent a localized market failure that cancels out at the national level.

author: Patrick Kline
title:
Evaluating Public Programs with Close Substitutes: The Case of Head
Start*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use data from the Head Start Impact Study (HSIS) to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of Head Start, the largest early childhood education program in the United States. Head Start draws roughly a third of its participants from competing preschool programs, many of which receive public funds. We show that accounting for the fiscal impacts of such program substitution pushes estimates of Head Start’s benefit-cost ratio well above one under a wide range of assumptions on the structure of the market for preschool services and the dollar value of test score gains. To parse the program’s test score impacts relative to home care and competing preschools, we selection-correct test scores in each care environment using excluded interactions between experimental assignments and household characteristics. We find that Head Start generates larger test score gains for children who would not otherwise attend preschool and for children who are less likely to participate in the program.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the cost-effectiveness of Head Start when accounting for the fact that it draws participants from competing preschool programs, and how do its impacts vary across different care environments?
answer: Head Start's benefit-cost ratio is well above one when accounting for fiscal impacts of program substitution, and the program generates larger test score gains for children who would not otherwise attend preschool and for children who are less likely to participate in the program.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in existing Head Start evaluation literature by explicitly accounting for the fiscal impacts of program substitution, where Head Start draws roughly a third of its participants from competing preschool programs (many publicly funded), and by parsing program impacts relative to different care environments rather than treating all alternative care as equivalent.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Reasonable Doubt: Experimental Detection of Job‐Level Employment Discrimination
abstract: <jats:p>This paper develops methods for detecting discrimination by individual employers using correspondence experiments that send fictitious resumes to real job openings. We establish identification of higher moments of the distribution of job‐level callback rates as a function of the number of resumes sent to each job and propose shape‐constrained estimators of these moments. Applying our methods to three experimental data sets, we find striking job‐level heterogeneity in the extent to which callback probabilities differ by race or sex. Estimates of higher moments reveal that while most jobs barely discriminate, a few discriminate heavily. These moment estimates are then used to bound the share of jobs that discriminate and the posterior probability that each individual job is engaged in discrimination. In a recent experiment manipulating racially distinctive names, we find that at least 85% of jobs that contact both of two white applications and neither of two black applications are engaged in discrimination. To assess the potential value of our methods for regulators, we consider the accuracy of decision rules for investigating suspicious callback behavior in various experimental designs under a simple two‐type model that rationalizes the experimental data. Though we estimate that only 17% of employers discriminate on the basis of race, we find that an experiment sending 10 applications to each job would enable detection of 7–10% of discriminatory jobs while yielding Type I error rates below 0.2%. A minimax decision rule acknowledging partial identification of the distribution of callback rates yields only slightly fewer investigations than a Bayes decision rule based on the two‐type model. These findings suggest illegal labor market discrimination can be reliably monitored with relatively small modifications to existing correspondence designs.</jats:p>
research_question: How can correspondence experiments be used to detect discrimination by individual employers at the job level, and what is the extent and distribution of employment discrimination across jobs?
answer: The paper finds striking job-level heterogeneity in discrimination, with most jobs barely discriminating but a few discriminating heavily. Only 17% of employers discriminate on the basis of race, but at least 85% of jobs showing suspicious callback patterns (contacting white but not black applications) are actually engaged in discrimination. The methods can reliably detect 7-10% of discriminatory jobs with low false positive rates.
positioning_statement: This paper advances beyond existing correspondence experiments that only estimate average discrimination effects by developing new methods to identify job-level discrimination and higher moments of the distribution of callback rates, enabling detection of individual discriminatory employers rather than just population-level discrimination patterns.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Leave‐Out Estimation of Variance Components
abstract: <jats:p>We propose leave‐out estimators of quadratic forms designed for the study of linear models with unrestricted heteroscedasticity. Applications include analysis of variance and tests of linear restrictions in models with many regressors. An approximation algorithm is provided that enables accurate computation of the estimator in very large data sets. We study the large sample properties of our estimator allowing the number of regressors to grow in proportion to the number of observations. Consistency is established in a variety of settings where plug‐in methods and estimators predicated on homoscedasticity exhibit first‐order biases. For quadratic forms of increasing rank, the limiting distribution can be represented by a linear combination of normal and non‐central<jats:italic>χ</jats:italic><jats:sup>2</jats:sup>random variables, with normality ensuing under strong identification. Standard error estimators are proposed that enable tests of linear restrictions and the construction of uniformly valid confidence intervals for quadratic forms of interest. We find in Italian social security records that leave‐out estimates of a variance decomposition in a two‐way fixed effects model of wage determination yield substantially different conclusions regarding the relative contribution of workers, firms, and worker‐firm sorting to wage inequality than conventional methods. Monte Carlo exercises corroborate the accuracy of our asymptotic approximations, with clear evidence of non‐normality emerging when worker mobility between blocks of firms is limited.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we accurately estimate variance components and quadratic forms in linear models with unrestricted heteroscedasticity, particularly when the number of regressors grows proportionally with the number of observations?
answer: Leave-out estimators provide consistent estimates of quadratic forms in heteroscedastic linear models where traditional plug-in methods and homoscedasticity-based estimators exhibit first-order biases, with the limiting distribution representable as a linear combination of normal and non-central χ² random variables.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the limitations of existing plug-in methods and estimators that assume homoscedasticity, which exhibit first-order biases in settings with unrestricted heteroscedasticity and many regressors, by proposing leave-out estimators that remain consistent in these challenging environments.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Assessing the Incidence and Efficiency of a Prominent Place Based Policy
abstract: <jats:p>This paper empirically assesses the incidence and efficiency of Round I of the federal urban Empowerment Zone (EZ) program using confidential microdata from the Decennial Census and the Longitudinal Business Database. Using rejected and future applicants to the EZ program as controls, we find that EZ designation substantially increased employment in zone neighborhoods and generated wage increases for local workers without corresponding increases in population or the local cost of living. The results suggest the efficiency costs of first Round EZs were relatively modest. (JEL H26, H77, J31, R23, R58)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the incidence and efficiency effects of the federal urban Empowerment Zone (EZ) program on employment, wages, population, and cost of living in designated zone neighborhoods?
answer: EZ designation substantially increased employment in zone neighborhoods and generated wage increases for local workers without corresponding increases in population or the local cost of living, suggesting the efficiency costs of first Round EZs were relatively modest.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on place-based policies by providing empirical assessment of a prominent federal urban development program using confidential microdata and a control group methodology comparing designated zones to rejected and future applicants.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Workplace Heterogeneity and the Rise of West German Wage Inequality*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the role of establishment-specific wage premiums in generating recent increases in West German wage inequality. Models with additive fixed effects for workers and establishments are fit into four subintervals spanning the period from 1985 to 2009. We show that these models provide a good approximation to the wage structure and can explain nearly all of the dramatic rise in West German wage inequality. Our estimates suggest that the increasing dispersion of West German wages has arisen from a combination of rising heterogeneity between workers, rising dispersion in the wage premiums at different establishments, and increasing assortativeness in the assignment of workers to plants. In contrast, the idiosyncratic job-match component of wage variation is small and stable over time. Decomposing changes in mean wages between different education groups, occupations, and industries, we find that increasing plant-level heterogeneity and rising assortativeness in the assignment of workers to establishments explain a large share of the rise in inequality along all three dimensions.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of establishment-specific wage premiums in generating recent increases in West German wage inequality?
answer: The increasing dispersion of West German wages has arisen from a combination of rising heterogeneity between workers, rising dispersion in the wage premiums at different establishments, and increasing assortativeness in the assignment of workers to plants, with these factors explaining nearly all of the dramatic rise in West German wage inequality from 1985 to 2009.
positioning_statement: This paper uses models with additive fixed effects for workers and establishments to decompose wage inequality, showing that establishment-level factors and worker-establishment matching patterns are key drivers of inequality - in contrast to previous approaches that may not have adequately separated these components or emphasized the role of workplace heterogeneity.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Bargaining, Sorting, and the Gender Wage Gap: Quantifying the Impact of Firms on the Relative Pay of Women *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>There is growing evidence that firm-specific pay premiums are an important source of wage inequality. These premiums will contribute to the gender wage gap if women are less likely to work at high-paying firms or if women negotiate (or are offered) worse wage bargains with their employers than men. Using longitudinal data on the hourly wages of Portuguese workers matched with income statement information for firms, we show that the wages of both men and women contain firm-specific premiums that are strongly correlated with simple measures of the potential bargaining surplus at each firm. We then show how the impact of these firm-specific pay differentials on the gender wage gap can be decomposed into a combination of sorting and bargaining effects. We find that women are less likely to work at firms that pay higher premiums to either gender, with sorting effects being most important for low- and middle-skilled workers. We also find that women receive only 90% of the firm-specific pay premiums earned by men. Importantly, we find the same gender gap in the responses of wages to changes in potential surplus over time. Taken together, the combination of sorting and bargaining effects explain about one-fifth of the cross-sectional gender wage gap in Portugal.</jats:p>
research_question: How do firm-specific pay premiums contribute to the gender wage gap through sorting effects (women working at different firms than men) and bargaining effects (women receiving different wage bargains than men at the same firms)?
answer: Women contribute to the gender wage gap through both sorting and bargaining effects: they are less likely to work at high-paying firms (sorting effect, particularly for low- and middle-skilled workers), and they receive only 90% of the firm-specific pay premiums that men earn at the same firms (bargaining effect). Together, these firm-related factors explain about one-fifth of the gender wage gap in Portugal.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on growing evidence that firm-specific pay premiums are an important source of wage inequality, and provides a novel decomposition framework to quantify how these premiums contribute to gender wage gaps through distinct sorting and bargaining mechanisms, using longitudinal worker-firm matched data.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Where is the land of Opportunity? The Geography of Intergenerational Mobility in the United States *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We use administrative records on the incomes of more than 40 million children and their parents to describe three features of intergenerational mobility in the United States. First, we characterize the joint distribution of parent and child income at the national level. The conditional expectation of child income given parent income is linear in percentile ranks. On average, a 10 percentile increase in parent income is associated with a 3.4 percentile increase in a child’s income. Second, intergenerational mobility varies substantially across areas within the United States. For example, the probability that a child reaches the top quintile of the national income distribution starting from a family in the bottom quintile is 4.4% in Charlotte but 12.9% in San Jose. Third, we explore the factors correlated with upward mobility. High mobility areas have (i) less residential segregation, (ii) less income inequality, (iii) better primary schools, (iv) greater social capital, and (v) greater family stability. Although our descriptive analysis does not identify the causal mechanisms that determine upward mobility, the publicly available statistics on intergenerational mobility developed here can facilitate research on such mechanisms.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the patterns and geographic variations of intergenerational mobility in the United States, and what factors are associated with areas that have higher upward mobility?
answer: Intergenerational mobility varies substantially across U.S. geographic areas, with the probability of moving from bottom to top quintile ranging from 4.4% in Charlotte to 12.9% in San Jose. High mobility areas are characterized by less residential segregation, less income inequality, better primary schools, greater social capital, and greater family stability. Nationally, a 10 percentile increase in parent income is associated with a 3.4 percentile increase in child income.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first comprehensive descriptive analysis of intergenerational mobility patterns across U.S. geographic areas using administrative records on over 40 million children and their parents, creating publicly available statistics that can facilitate future research on causal mechanisms of mobility.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Place-Based Redistribution
abstract: <jats:p> We study optimal income taxation in a spatial equilibrium model with heterogeneous locational preferences, labor supply decisions, and competitive housing and labor markets. Expressions characterizing the optimal tax schedule in each community are provided that capture the fiscal externalities associated with migration and the effects of redistribution between households and landlords. Correlation between skill and locational preferences yields optimal transfers to poor areas, while sorting based on comparative advantage can motivate transfers in either direction. A calibration to areas targeted by the US Empowerment Zone program yields sizable optimal spatial transfers that are sensitive to assumed levels of migration responsiveness. (JEL H21, H23, H24, J24, J31, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal income taxation structure in a spatial equilibrium model where people have different locational preferences, make labor supply decisions, and participate in competitive housing and labor markets?
answer: The optimal tax schedule should include spatial transfers to poor areas when skill and locational preferences are correlated, with the direction of transfers depending on whether sorting is based on comparative advantage. A calibration to US Empowerment Zone areas shows that optimal spatial transfers should be substantial but are sensitive to migration responsiveness assumptions.
positioning_statement: This paper extends optimal income taxation theory by incorporating spatial equilibrium considerations, heterogeneous locational preferences, and the interaction between redistribution policies and migration patterns, addressing fiscal externalities that previous literature has not fully captured in the context of place-based redistribution policies.

author: Patrick Kline
title: A Discrimination Report Card
abstract: <jats:p> We develop an empirical Bayes ranking procedure that assigns ordinal grades to noisy measurements, balancing the information content of the assigned grades against the expected frequency of ranking errors. Applying the method to a massive correspondence experiment, we grade the race and gender contact gaps of 97 US employers, the identities of which we disclose for the first time. The grades are presented alongside measures of uncertainty about each firm’s contact gap in an accessible report card that is easily adaptable to other settings where ranks and levels are of simultaneous interest. (JEL C11, D22, J15, J16, J71) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a reliable method to rank and grade employers on their discriminatory hiring practices based on noisy experimental data?
answer: The paper develops an empirical Bayes ranking procedure that successfully assigns ordinal grades to employers' race and gender contact gaps, balancing information content against ranking errors, and applies it to grade 97 US employers in an accessible report card format.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a novel empirical Bayes methodology for ranking noisy measurements that can be applied beyond discrimination studies, and represents the first disclosure of specific employer identities from a correspondence experiment on hiring discrimination.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Is the United States Still a Land of Opportunity? Recent Trends in Intergenerational Mobility
abstract: <jats:p> We present new evidence on trends in intergenerational mobility in the United States using administrative earnings records. We find that percentile rank-based measures of intergenerational mobility have remained extremely stable for the 1971-1993 birth cohorts. For children born between 1971 and 1986, we measure intergenerational mobility based on the correlation between parent and child income percentile ranks. For more recent cohorts, we measure mobility as the correlation between a child's probability of attending college and her parents' income rank. We also calculate transition probabilities, such as a child's chances of reaching the top quintile of the income distribution starting from the bottom quintile. Based on all of these measures, we find that children entering the labor market today have the same chances of moving up in the income distribution (relative to their parents) as children born in the 1970s. However, because inequality has risen, the consequences of the “birth lottery” - the parents to whom a child is born - are larger today than in the past. </jats:p>
research_question: Have trends in intergenerational mobility in the United States changed over recent decades?
answer: Percentile rank-based measures of intergenerational mobility have remained extremely stable for the 1971-1993 birth cohorts - children entering the labor market today have the same chances of moving up in the income distribution relative to their parents as children born in the 1970s, but the consequences of the 'birth lottery' are larger today due to rising inequality.
positioning_statement: This paper presents new evidence on trends in intergenerational mobility using administrative earnings records, contributing fresh empirical analysis to the existing literature on economic mobility in the United States.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Systemic Discrimination Among Large U.S. Employers
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the results of a massive nationwide correspondence experiment sending more than 83,000 fictitious applications with randomized characteristics to geographically dispersed jobs posted by 108 of the largest U.S. employers. Distinctively Black names reduce the probability of employer contact by 2.1 percentage points relative to distinctively white names. The magnitude of this racial gap in contact rates differs substantially across firms, exhibiting a between-company standard deviation of 1.9 percentage points. Despite an insignificant average gap in contact rates between male and female applicants, we find a between-company standard deviation in gender contact gaps of 2.7 percentage points, revealing that some firms favor male applicants and others favor women. Company-specific racial contact gaps are temporally and spatially persistent, and negatively correlated with firm profitability, federal contractor status, and a measure of recruiting centralization. Discrimination exhibits little geographical dispersion, but two-digit industry explains roughly half of the cross-firm variation in both racial and gender contact gaps. Contact gaps are highly concentrated in particular companies, with firms in the top quintile of racial discrimination responsible for nearly half of lost contacts to Black applicants in the experiment. Controlling false discovery rates to the 5% level, 23 companies are found to discriminate against Black applicants. Our findings establish that discrimination against distinctively Black names is concentrated among a select set of large employers, many of which can be identified with high confidence using large-scale inference methods.</jats:p>
research_question: Do large U.S. employers engage in systemic discrimination based on race and gender in their hiring practices, and how does this discrimination vary across companies?
answer: Distinctively Black names reduce employer contact probability by 2.1 percentage points compared to white names, with discrimination highly concentrated among specific companies - firms in the top quintile of racial discrimination account for nearly half of lost contacts to Black applicants, and 23 companies can be identified as discriminating against Black applicants with high confidence.
positioning_statement: This study contributes to the discrimination literature by conducting the largest nationwide correspondence experiment to date (83,000+ applications to 108 major employers), uniquely focusing on systematic variation in discrimination across large firms rather than average effects, and employing large-scale inference methods to identify specific discriminating companies with statistical confidence.

author: Patrick Kline
title: Who Profits from Patents? Rent-Sharing at Innovative Firms*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article analyzes how patent-induced shocks to labor productivity propagate into worker compensation using a new linkage of U.S. patent applications to U.S. business and worker tax records. We infer the causal effects of patent allowances by comparing firms whose patent applications were initially allowed to those whose patent applications were initially rejected. To identify patents that are ex ante valuable, we extrapolate the excess stock return estimates of Kogan et al. (2017) to the full set of accepted and rejected patent applications based on predetermined firm and patent application characteristics. An initial allowance of an ex ante valuable patent generates substantial increases in firm productivity and worker compensation. By contrast, initial allowances of lower ex ante value patents yield no detectable effects on firm outcomes. Patent allowances lead firms to increase employment, but entry wages and workforce composition are insensitive to patent decisions. On average, workers capture roughly 30 cents of every dollar of patent-induced surplus in higher earnings. This share is roughly twice as high among workers present since the year of application. These earnings effects are concentrated among men and workers in the top half of the earnings distribution and are paired with corresponding improvements in worker retention among these groups. We interpret these earnings responses as reflecting the capture of economic rents by senior workers, who are most costly for innovative firms to replace.</jats:p>
research_question: How do patent-induced shocks to labor productivity propagate into worker compensation at innovative firms?
answer: Workers capture roughly 30 cents of every dollar of patent-induced surplus in higher earnings, with this share being twice as high among workers present since the year of application. The earnings effects are concentrated among men and workers in the top half of the earnings distribution, reflecting the capture of economic rents by senior workers who are most costly for innovative firms to replace.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing new causal evidence on rent-sharing at innovative firms using a novel linkage of U.S. patent applications to business and worker tax records, and by building on Kogan et al. (2017)'s methodology to identify ex ante valuable patents across the full set of accepted and rejected patent applications.

author: Paul Grieco
title: Productivity and Quality in Health Care: Evidence from the Dialysis Industry

author: Paul Grieco
title: Strategic Patient Discharge: The Case of Long-Term Care Hospitals
abstract: <jats:p> Medicare’s prospective payment system for long-term acute-care hospitals (LTCHs) provides modest reimbursements at the beginning of a patient’s stay before jumping discontinuously to a large lump-sum payment after a prespecified number of days. We show that LTCHs respond to the financial incentives of this system by disproportionately discharging patients after they cross the large-payment threshold. We find this occurs more often at for-profit facilities, facilities acquired by leading LTCH chains, and facilities colocated with other hospitals. Using a dynamic structural model, we evaluate counterfactual payment policies that would provide substantial savings for Medicare. (JEL H51, I11, I13, I18) </jats:p>
research_question: How do long-term acute-care hospitals (LTCHs) respond to Medicare's prospective payment system that provides modest reimbursements initially before jumping to a large lump-sum payment after a prespecified number of days?
answer: LTCHs strategically respond to financial incentives by disproportionately discharging patients after they cross the large-payment threshold, with this behavior being more pronounced at for-profit facilities, facilities acquired by leading LTCH chains, and facilities colocated with other hospitals.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on healthcare provider responses to payment incentives by examining the specific case of LTCHs under Medicare's prospective payment system, using a dynamic structural model to evaluate counterfactual payment policies that could generate substantial Medicare savings.

author: Paul Grieco
title: The Evolution of Market Power in the U.S. Automobile Industry
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We construct measures of industry performance and welfare in the U.S. automobile market from 1980 to 2018. We estimate a demand model using product-level data on market shares, prices, and attributes, and consumer-level data on demographics, purchases, and stated second choices. We estimate marginal costs assuming Nash-Bertrand pricing. We relate trends in consumer welfare and markups to trends in market structure and the composition of products. Although real prices rose, we find that markups decreased substantially, and the fraction of total surplus accruing to consumers increased. Consumer welfare increased over time due to improved product quality and improved production technology.</jats:p>
research_question: How has market power evolved in the U.S. automobile industry from 1980 to 2018, and what are the implications for industry performance, consumer welfare, and markups?
answer: Despite rising real prices, markups in the U.S. automobile industry decreased substantially from 1980 to 2018, the fraction of total surplus accruing to consumers increased, and consumer welfare improved due to enhanced product quality and better production technology.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by constructing comprehensive measures of industry performance and welfare in the automobile market using both product-level data (market shares, prices, attributes) and consumer-level data (demographics, purchases, stated preferences), employing demand estimation with Nash-Bertrand pricing assumptions to analyze long-term trends in market structure and product composition.

author: Pauline Grosjean
title: Inflammatory Political Campaigns and Racial Bias in Policing
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Can political rallies affect the behavior of law enforcement officers toward racial minorities? Using data from 35 million traffic stops, we show that the probability that a stopped driver is Black increases by 5.74% after a Trump rally during his 2015–2016 campaign. The effect is immediate, specific to Black drivers, lasts for up to 60 days after the rally, and is not justified by changes in driver behavior. The effects are significantly larger among law enforcement officers whose estimated racial bias is higher at baseline, in areas that score higher on present-day measures of racial resentment, those that experienced more racial violence during the Jim Crow era, and in former slave-holding counties. Mentions of racial issues in Trump speeches, whether explicit or implicit, exacerbate the effect of a Trump rally among officers with higher estimated racial bias.</jats:p>
research_question: Can political rallies affect the behavior of law enforcement officers toward racial minorities?
answer: Yes, Trump rallies during his 2015-2016 campaign increased the probability that a stopped driver is Black by 5.74%, with effects lasting up to 60 days and being larger among officers with higher baseline racial bias and in areas with greater racial resentment or historical racial violence.
positioning_statement: This paper appears to be among the first to empirically examine the direct causal relationship between inflammatory political campaigns and racial bias in policing behavior, using large-scale traffic stop data to demonstrate how political rhetoric can influence law enforcement practices toward minorities.

author: Pauline Grosjean
title: It’s Raining Men! Hallelujah? The Long-Run Consequences of Male-Biased Sex Ratios

author: Pauline Grosjean
title: The Weight of History on European Cultural Integration: A Gravity Approach
abstract: <jats:p> The cultural gravity model proposed in this paper uses micro-level survey data of 21,000 households to estimate the contribution to cultural heterogeneity of a long history of division between the Ottoman, Habsburg, Russian or Prussian Empires since the year 1300 in 21 European countries. By exploiting the variation in the duration of integration of localities in different empires, this paper sheds light on the influence of political integration on cultural integration and on the rate of cultural change. History matters and cultural values change very slowly: long lasting effects on social trust comes after 400 years of common imperial rule. </jats:p>
research_question: How does the long history of division between different empires (Ottoman, Habsburg, Russian, or Prussian) since 1300 contribute to cultural heterogeneity in European countries, and what is the influence of political integration on cultural integration and the rate of cultural change?
answer: History matters and cultural values change very slowly - long lasting effects on social trust emerge only after 400 years of common imperial rule, demonstrating that political integration has a significant but extremely gradual influence on cultural integration.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by proposing a novel cultural gravity model that uses micro-level survey data to quantify the historical impact of imperial divisions on contemporary cultural heterogeneity, exploiting variation in the duration of integration of localities in different empires to measure the rate of cultural change.

author: Pauline Grosjean
title: Forced Migration and Human Capital: Evidence from Post-WWII Population Transfers
abstract: <jats:p> We study the long-run effects of forced migration on investment in education. After World War II, millions of Poles were forcibly uprooted from the Kresy territories of eastern Poland and resettled (primarily) in the newly acquired Western Territories, from which the Germans were expelled. We combine historical censuses with newly collected survey data to show that, while there were no pre-WWII differences in educational attainment, Poles with a family history of forced migration are significantly more educated today than other Poles. These results are driven by a shift in preferences away from material possessions toward investment in human capital. (JEL I25, I26, J24, N34, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-run effects of forced migration on investment in education?
answer: Poles with a family history of forced migration are significantly more educated today than other Poles, driven by a shift in preferences away from material possessions toward investment in human capital.
positioning_statement: The paper uses the unique historical context of post-WWII Polish population transfers to study forced migration effects, combining historical censuses with newly collected survey data to examine long-term educational outcomes across generations.

author: Peter Ganong
title: Consumer Spending during Unemployment: Positive and Normative Implications
abstract: <jats:p> Using de-identified bank account data, we show that spending drops sharply at the large and predictable decrease in income arising from the exhaustion of unemployment insurance (UI) benefits. We use the high-frequency response to a predictable income decline as a new test to distinguish between alternative consumption models. The sensitivity of spending to income we document is inconsistent with rational models of liquidity-constrained households, but is consistent with behavioral models with present-biased or myopic households. Depressed spending after exhaustion also implies that the consumption-smoothing gains from extending UI benefits are four times larger than from raising UI benefit levels. (JEL D14, D91, E21, E24, E70, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: How does consumer spending respond to the predictable income decline from unemployment insurance benefit exhaustion, and what does this reveal about alternative consumption models?
answer: Spending drops sharply at UI benefit exhaustion in a way that is inconsistent with rational liquidity-constrained household models but consistent with behavioral models featuring present-biased or myopic households, and extending UI benefits provides four times larger consumption-smoothing gains than raising benefit levels.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes a new empirical test using high-frequency responses to predictable income declines to distinguish between rational and behavioral consumption models, while also providing novel policy implications for unemployment insurance design relative to existing literature.

author: Peter Ganong
title: Liquidity versus Wealth in Household Debt Obligations: Evidence from Housing Policy in the Great Recession
abstract: <jats:p> We exploit variation in mortgage modifications to disentangle the impact of reducing long-term obligations with no change in short-term payments (“wealth”), and reducing short-term payments with no change in long-term obligations (“liquidity”). Using regression discontinuity and difference-in-differences research designs with administrative data measuring default and consumption, we find that principal reductions that increase wealth without affecting liquidity have no effect, while maturity extensions that increase only liquidity have large effects. This suggests that liquidity drives default and consumption decisions for borrowers in our sample and that distressed debt restructurings can be redesigned with substantial gains to borrowers, lenders, and taxpayers. (JEL E21, G21, G51, R38) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the relative impacts of wealth effects (reducing long-term debt obligations without changing short-term payments) versus liquidity effects (reducing short-term payments without changing long-term obligations) on household default and consumption decisions?
answer: Liquidity effects drive default and consumption decisions while wealth effects have no impact - specifically, principal reductions that increase wealth without affecting liquidity have no effect, while maturity extensions that increase only liquidity have large effects on borrower behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by empirically disentangling wealth and liquidity effects in household debt decisions using variation in mortgage modifications during the Great Recession, providing evidence that can inform the redesign of distressed debt restructurings for better outcomes for borrowers, lenders, and taxpayers.

author: Peter Ganong
title: Why do Borrowers Default on Mortgages?
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>There are three prevailing theories of mortgage default: strategic default (driven by negative equity), cash flow default (driven by negative life events), and double-trigger default (where both negative triggers are necessary). It has been difficult to compare these theories in part because negative life events are measured with error. We address this measurement error using a comparison group of borrowers with no strategic-default motive. Our central finding is that only 6% of underwater defaults are caused exclusively by negative equity, an order of magnitude lower than previously thought. We then analyze the remaining defaults. We find that 70% are driven solely by negative life events (i.e., cash flow defaults), while 24% are driven by the interaction between negative life events and negative equity (i.e., double-trigger defaults). Together, the results provide a full decomposition of the theories underlying borrower default and suggest that negative life events play a central role.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the relative contributions of strategic default (negative equity), cash flow default (negative life events), and double-trigger default (both factors) in explaining why borrowers default on mortgages?
answer: Only 6% of underwater defaults are caused exclusively by negative equity (strategic default), while 70% are driven solely by negative life events (cash flow defaults), and 24% are driven by the interaction between negative life events and negative equity (double-trigger defaults).
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the difficulty in comparing three prevailing theories of mortgage default by solving the measurement error problem in negative life events through the use of a comparison group of borrowers with no strategic-default motive, providing the first full decomposition of default theories and challenging previous estimates of strategic default prevalence.

author: Peter Ganong
title: Spending and Job-Finding Impacts of Expanded Unemployment Benefits: Evidence from Administrative Micro Data
abstract: <jats:p> We show that the largest increase in unemployment benefits in US history had large spending impacts and small job-finding impacts. This finding has three implications. First, increased benefits were important for explaining aggregate spending dynamics—but not employment dynamics—during the pandemic. Second, benefit expansions allow us to study the MPC of normally low-liquidity households in a high-liquidity state. These households still have high MPCs. This suggests a role for permanent behavioral characteristics, rather than just current liquidity, in driving spending behavior. Third, the mechanisms driving our results imply that temporary benefit supplements are a promising countercyclical tool. (JEL E21, E24, E32, E62, E71, G51, J65) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the spending and job-finding impacts of the largest increase in unemployment benefits in US history during the pandemic?
answer: The expanded unemployment benefits had large spending impacts but small job-finding impacts, suggesting benefits significantly affected aggregate spending dynamics but not employment dynamics during the pandemic.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using administrative micro data to study unemployment benefit effects during an unprecedented expansion, providing new insights into the marginal propensity to consume of low-liquidity households in high-liquidity states and demonstrating that permanent behavioral characteristics, rather than just current liquidity, drive spending behavior.

author: Pauline Grosjean
title: Heroes and Villains: The Effects of Heroism on Autocratic Values and Nazi Collaboration in France
abstract: <jats:p>We measure how a network of heroes can legitimize and diffuse extreme political behaviors. We exploit newly declassified intelligence files, novel voting data, and regimental histories to show that home municipalities of French line regiments arbitrarily rotated under Philippe Pétain’s generalship through the heroic World War I battlefield of Verdun diverge politically thereafter, particularly following Pétain’s own overt espousal of authoritarian views. Further, under Pétain’s collaborationist Vichy regime (1940–1944), they raise 7 percent more active Nazi collaborators per capita. These effects extend across all forms of Nazi collaboration and diffuse beyond the veterans themselves. (JEL D72, D74, N34, N44, Z13)</jats:p>
research_question: How does a network of heroes legitimize and diffuse extreme political behaviors, specifically examining the effects of heroism on autocratic values and Nazi collaboration in France?
answer: Home municipalities of French line regiments that served under Philippe Pétain's generalship at the heroic World War I battlefield of Verdun subsequently diverged politically and raised 7 percent more active Nazi collaborators per capita under Pétain's collaborationist Vichy regime, with these effects extending across all forms of Nazi collaboration and diffusing beyond the veterans themselves.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by exploiting newly declassified intelligence files, novel voting data, and regimental histories to provide empirical evidence of how heroic networks can legitimize and spread extreme political behaviors, using the specific historical context of French regiments' arbitrary rotation through Verdun under Pétain's command.
