author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Does Schooling Cause Growth?
abstract: <jats:p> A number of economists find that growth and schooling are highly correlated across countries. A model is examined in which the ability to build on the human capital of one's elders plays an important role in linking growth to schooling. The model is calibrated to quantify the strength of the effect of schooling on growth by using evidence from the labor literature on Mincerian returns to education. The upshot is that the impact of schooling on growth explains less than one-third of the empirical cross-country relationship. The ability of reverse causality to explain this empirical relationship is also investigated. (JEL I2, J24, O4) </jats:p>
research_question: Does schooling cause economic growth, and if so, how much of the empirical cross-country relationship between growth and schooling can be explained by the causal effect of schooling on growth?
answer: The causal impact of schooling on growth explains less than one-third of the empirical cross-country relationship between growth and schooling observed in the data.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the existing literature that finds high correlations between growth and schooling across countries by developing a model that incorporates the ability to build on previous generations' human capital, and uses evidence from labor literature on Mincerian returns to education to calibrate and quantify the actual causal effect, while also investigating reverse causality as an alternative explanation.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: The Acceleration in Variety Growth

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Quantifying Quality Growth
abstract: <jats:p>Using U.S. Consumer Expenditure Surveys, we estimate “quality Engel curves” for 66 durable goods based on the extent richer households pay more for each good. The same data show that the average price paid rises faster from 1980 to 1996 for goods with steeper quality Engel curves, as if households are ascending these curves. BLS prices likewise increase more quickly for goods with steeper quality Engel curves, suggesting the BLS does not fully net out the impact of quality upgrading. We estimate that annual quality growth averages 3.7 percent for our goods, with 2.2 percent showing up as higher inflation. (JEL D12, O40, E31)</jats:p>
research_question: How can quality growth in durable goods be quantified, and to what extent does quality upgrading affect measured inflation?
answer: Annual quality growth averages 3.7 percent for durable goods, with 2.2 percent of this quality improvement showing up as higher measured inflation, indicating that the BLS does not fully account for quality upgrading when calculating price indices.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on quality adjustment in price indices by developing a novel methodology using 'quality Engel curves' based on cross-sectional spending patterns of households with different income levels, providing empirical evidence that official price statistics inadequately control for quality improvements.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: The Variety and Quality of a Nation's Exports
abstract: <jats:p> Large economies export more in absolute terms than do small economies. We use data on shipments by 126 exporting countries to 59 importing countries in 5,000 product categories to answer the question: How? Do big economies export larger quantities of each good (the intensive margin), a wider set of goods (the extensive margin), or higher-quality goods? We find that the extensive margin accounts for around 60 percent of the greater exports of larger economies. Within categories, richer countries export higher quantities at modestly higher prices. We compare these findings to some workhorse trade models. Models with Armington national product differentiation have no extensive margin, and incorrectly predict lower prices for the exports of larger economies. Models with Krugman firm-level product differentiation do feature a prominent extensive margin, but overpredict the rate at which variety responds to exporter size. Models with quality differentiation, meanwhile, can match the price facts. Finally, models with fixed costs of exporting to a given market might explain the tendency of larger economies to export a given product to more countries. </jats:p>
research_question: How do large economies export more than small economies - through exporting larger quantities of each good (intensive margin), a wider set of goods (extensive margin), or higher-quality goods?
answer: The extensive margin (wider set of goods) accounts for around 60 percent of the greater exports of larger economies, while richer countries also export higher quantities at modestly higher prices within product categories.
positioning_statement: This paper evaluates and compares existing workhorse trade models against empirical findings, showing that Armington models incorrectly predict lower prices and have no extensive margin, Krugman models overpredict variety response to exporter size despite featuring extensive margins, while quality differentiation models can match the observed price patterns, and models with fixed export costs may explain larger economies' tendency to export given products to more countries.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Some Evidence on the Importance of Sticky Prices

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Misallocation and Manufacturing TFP in China and India<sup>*</sup>

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Relative Prices and Relative Prosperity
abstract: <jats:p> The positive correlation between real investment rates and real income levels across countries is driven largely by differences in the price of investment relative to output. The high relative price of investment in poor countries is due to the low price of consumption goods in those countries. Investment prices are no higher in poor countries. Thus, the low real investment rates in poor countries are not driven by high tax or tariff rates on investment. Poor countries, instead, appear to be plagued by low efficiency in producing investment goods and in producing consumer goods to trade for them. (JEL E22, E23, O16, O47) </jats:p>
research_question: What drives the positive correlation between real investment rates and real income levels across countries?
answer: The correlation is driven largely by differences in the price of investment relative to output, which is caused by the low price of consumption goods in poor countries rather than high investment prices. Poor countries have low real investment rates due to low efficiency in producing investment goods and consumer goods to trade for them, not due to high taxes or tariffs on investment.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that high taxes or tariffs on investment explain low investment rates in poor countries, instead attributing the phenomenon to relative price differences driven by low consumption good prices and production inefficiencies.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Reset Price Inflation and the Impact of Monetary Policy Shocks
abstract: <jats:p> Many business cycle models use a flat short-run Phillips curve, due to time-dependent pricing and strategic complementarities, to explain fluctuations in real output. But, in doing so, these models predict unrealistically high persistence and stability of US inflation in recent decades. We calculate “reset price inflation”—based on new prices chosen by the subsample of price changers—to dissect this discrepancy. We find that the models generate too much persistence and stability both in reset price inflation and in the way reset price inflation is converted into actual inflation. Our findings present a challenge to existing explanations for business cycles. (JEL E31, E52) </jats:p>
research_question: Why do business cycle models with flat short-run Phillips curves predict unrealistically high persistence and stability of US inflation compared to actual data?
answer: The models generate excessive persistence and stability both in reset price inflation (new prices chosen by price changers) and in how reset price inflation converts to actual inflation, indicating fundamental problems with existing theoretical frameworks.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing business cycle explanations by identifying specific flaws in widely-used models that rely on time-dependent pricing and strategic complementarities to explain output fluctuations through flat Phillips curves.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: The Life Cycle of Plants in India and Mexico *
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>In the United States, the average 40-year-old plant employs more than seven times as many workers as the typical plant 5 years or younger. In contrast, surviving plants in India and Mexico exhibit much slower growth, roughly doubling in size over the same age range. The divergence in plant dynamics suggests lower investments by Indian and Mexican plants in process efficiency, quality, and in accessing markets at home and abroad. In simple general equilibrium models, we find that the difference in life cycle dynamics could lower aggregate manufacturing productivity on the order of 25 percent in India and Mexico relative to the United States.</jats:p>
research_question: How do plant life cycle dynamics (growth patterns over time) differ between the United States versus India and Mexico, and what are the implications for aggregate manufacturing productivity?
answer: Plants in India and Mexico exhibit much slower growth over their life cycles compared to US plants - roughly doubling in size over 35 years versus growing seven-fold in the US. This difference in life cycle dynamics could lower aggregate manufacturing productivity by approximately 25 percent in India and Mexico relative to the United States.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by examining cross-country differences in plant-level growth dynamics and linking these micro-level patterns to aggregate productivity differences, suggesting that slower plant growth in developing countries reflects lower investments in process efficiency, quality, and market access.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Beyond GDP? Welfare across Countries and Time
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a summary statistic for the economic well-being of people in a country. Our measure incorporates consumption, leisure, mortality, and inequality, first for a narrow set of countries using detailed micro data, and then more broadly using multi-country datasets. While welfare is highly correlated with GDP per capita, deviations are often large. Western Europe looks considerably closer to the United States, emerging Asia has not caught up as much, and many developing countries are further behind. Each component we introduce plays a significant role in accounting for these differences, with mortality being most important. (JEL D63, E21, E23, E24, I12, O57) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we measure economic well-being beyond GDP per capita by incorporating consumption, leisure, mortality, and inequality across countries and time?
answer: The proposed welfare measure shows that while highly correlated with GDP per capita, deviations are often large - Western Europe appears closer to the US than GDP suggests, emerging Asia has not caught up as much as GDP indicates, and developing countries are further behind, with mortality being the most important factor in explaining these differences.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as extending beyond traditional GDP-based measures of economic well-being by proposing a comprehensive summary statistic that incorporates multiple dimensions of welfare (consumption, leisure, mortality, and inequality) that existing literature has not adequately captured in a unified measure.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: A Global View of Creative Destruction

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Resurrecting the Role of the Product Market Wedge in Recessions
abstract: <jats:p> Employment and hours are more cyclical than dictated by productivity and consumption. This intratemporal labor wedge can arise from product or labor market distortions. Based on employee wages, the literature has attributed the intratemporal wedge almost entirely to labor market distortions. Because wages may be smoothed versions of labor's true cyclical price, we instead examine the self-employed and intermediate inputs, respectively. For recent decades in the United States, we find price markup movements are at least as cyclical as wage markup movements. Thus, countercyclical price markups deserve a central place in business-cycle research, alongside sticky wages and matching frictions. (JEL E24, E32, E63, J31, J41) </jats:p>
research_question: What causes the intratemporal labor wedge in business cycles - product market distortions (price markups) or labor market distortions (wage markups)?
answer: Price markup movements are at least as cyclical as wage markup movements in recent decades in the United States, meaning product market distortions play an equally important role as labor market distortions in explaining the intratemporal labor wedge.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the existing literature that has attributed the intratemporal wedge almost entirely to labor market distortions based on employee wages, arguing that this approach may be flawed because wages may be smoothed versions of labor's true cyclical price, and proposes examining self-employed workers and intermediate inputs instead to resurrect the importance of countercyclical price markups in business-cycle research.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Missing Growth from Creative Destruction
abstract: <jats:p> For exiting products, statistical agencies often impute inflation from surviving products. This understates growth if creatively-destroyed products improve more than surviving ones. If so, then the market share of surviving products should systematically shrink. Using entering and exiting establishments to proxy for creative destruction, we estimate missing growth in US Census data on non-farm businesses from 1983 to 2013. We find missing growth (i) equaled about one-half a percentage point per year; (ii) arose mostly from hotels and restaurants rather than manufacturing; and (iii) did not accelerate much after 2005, and therefore does not explain the sharp slowdown in growth since then. (JEL E23, E31, L14, L15, O30, O41) </jats:p>
research_question: How much economic growth is missed by statistical agencies when they impute inflation from surviving products rather than accounting for the quality improvements of creatively-destroyed (exiting) products?
answer: Missing growth from creative destruction equaled about one-half a percentage point per year in US non-farm businesses from 1983 to 2013, arose mostly from hotels and restaurants rather than manufacturing, and did not accelerate much after 2005, therefore not explaining the sharp growth slowdown since then.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a measurement problem in how statistical agencies calculate economic growth by focusing on the role of creative destruction - specifically how agencies' practice of imputing inflation from surviving products may systematically understate growth when exiting products actually improve more than surviving ones.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: Endogenous Variety and the Gains from Trade

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: How Destructive Is Innovation?
abstract: <jats:p>Entrants and incumbents can create new products and displace the products of competitors. Incumbents can also improve their existing products. How much of aggregate productivity growth occurs through each of these channels? Using data from the U.S. Longitudinal Business Database on all nonfarm private businesses from 1983 to 2013, we arrive at three main conclusions: First, most growth appears to come from incumbents. We infer this from the modest employment share of entering firms (defined as those less than 5 years old). Second, most growth seems to occur through improvements of existing varieties rather than creation of brand new varieties. Third, own‐product improvements by incumbents appear to be more important than creative destruction. We infer this because the distribution of job creation and destruction has thinner tails than implied by a model with a dominant role for creative destruction.</jats:p>
research_question: How much of aggregate productivity growth occurs through different channels: entrants creating new products and displacing competitors' products, incumbents creating new products and displacing competitors' products, and incumbents improving their existing products?
answer: Most aggregate productivity growth comes from incumbents improving their existing products rather than from creative destruction or new variety creation. Specifically, incumbents drive most growth (evidenced by the modest employment share of young firms), growth occurs primarily through improvements of existing varieties rather than creation of new varieties, and own-product improvements by incumbents are more important than creative destruction.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental question in innovation economics by empirically quantifying the relative importance of different channels of productivity growth, using comprehensive U.S. business data to distinguish between creative destruction (where new products displace old ones) and incumbent innovation through product improvements.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: A Theory of Falling Growth and Rising Rents
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Growth has fallen in the U.S. amid a rise in firm concentration. Market share has shifted to low labour share firms, while within-firm labour shares have actually risen. We propose a theory linking these trends in which the driving force is falling overhead costs of spanning multiple products or a rising efficiency advantage of large firms. In response, the most efficient firms (with higher markups) spread into new product lines, thereby increasing concentration and generating a temporary burst of growth. Eventually, due to greater competition from efficient firms, within-firm markups and incentives to innovate fall. Thus our simple model can generate qualitative patterns in line with the observed trends.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we explain the simultaneous occurrence of falling growth and rising firm concentration in the U.S., particularly given that market share has shifted to low labor share firms while within-firm labor shares have actually risen?
answer: The key finding is that falling overhead costs of spanning multiple products or rising efficiency advantages of large firms drive the most efficient firms to expand into new product lines, initially boosting growth through increased concentration, but eventually reducing within-firm markups and innovation incentives due to greater competition from efficient firms, leading to slower growth.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses observed macroeconomic trends of falling U.S. growth amid rising firm concentration by proposing a novel theoretical framework that can reconcile the apparent contradiction between market share shifting to low labor share firms while within-firm labor shares have risen, filling a gap in existing literature that has struggled to explain these simultaneous patterns.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: How Safe Are Money Market Funds?*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We examine the risk-taking behavior of money market funds during the financial crisis of 2007–2010. We find that (1) money market funds experienced an unprecedented expansion in their risk-taking opportunities; (2) funds had strong incentives to take on risk because fund inflows were highly responsive to fund yields; (3) funds sponsored by financial intermediaries with more money fund business took on more risk; and (4) funds suffered runs as a result of their risk taking. This evidence suggests that money market funds lack safety because they have strong incentives to take on risk when the opportunity arises and are vulnerable to runs.</jats:p>
research_question: How safe are money market funds, particularly in terms of their risk-taking behavior and vulnerability to runs?
answer: Money market funds lack safety because they have strong incentives to take on risk when opportunities arise (due to fund inflows being highly responsive to yields) and are vulnerable to runs as a result of their risk-taking behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper examines money market fund risk-taking behavior during the 2007-2010 financial crisis, providing empirical evidence on an unprecedented expansion in risk-taking opportunities and the relationship between fund incentives, sponsor characteristics, and resulting fund runs.

author: Peter J. Klenow
title: The Allocation of Talent and U.S. Economic Growth
abstract: <jats:p>In 1960, 94 percent of doctors and lawyers were white men. By 2010, the fraction was just 62 percent. Similar changes in other highly‐skilled occupations have occurred throughout the U.S. economy during the last 50 years. Given that the innate talent for these professions is unlikely to have changed differently across groups, the change in the occupational distribution since 1960 suggests that a substantial pool of innately talented women and black men in 1960 were not pursuing their comparative advantage. We examine the effect on aggregate productivity of the convergence in the occupational distribution between 1960 and 2010 through the prism of a Roy model. Across our various specifications, between 20% and 40% of growth in aggregate market output per person can be explained by the improved allocation of talent.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect on aggregate productivity of the convergence in occupational distribution between 1960 and 2010, specifically examining how the improved allocation of talent (particularly women and black men entering highly-skilled professions) contributed to U.S. economic growth?
answer: Between 20% and 40% of growth in aggregate market output per person can be explained by the improved allocation of talent, as previously excluded groups (women and black men) gained greater access to highly-skilled occupations where they had comparative advantage.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by quantifying the macroeconomic impact of reduced occupational barriers through a Roy model framework, specifically measuring how the reallocation of innate talent from historically excluded groups to their optimal occupations affected aggregate U.S. productivity growth over a 50-year period.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: The Deposits Channel of Monetary Policy*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We present a new channel for the transmission of monetary policy, the deposits channel. We show that when the Fed funds rate rises, banks widen the spreads they charge on deposits, and deposits flow out of the banking system. We present a model where this is due to market power in deposit markets. Consistent with the market power mechanism, deposit spreads increase more and deposits flow out more in concentrated markets. This is true even when we control for lending opportunities by only comparing different branches of the same bank. Since deposits are the main source of liquid assets for households, the deposits channel can explain the observed strong relationship between the liquidity premium and the Fed funds rate. Since deposits are also a uniquely stable funding source for banks, the deposits channel impacts bank lending. When the Fed funds rate rises, banks that raise deposits in concentrated markets contract their lending by more than other banks. Our estimates imply that the deposits channel can account for the entire transmission of monetary policy through bank balance sheets.</jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy transmit through the banking system via deposit markets, and what role does bank market power play in this transmission mechanism?
answer: When the Fed funds rate rises, banks with market power widen deposit spreads and experience deposit outflows, which constrains their lending. This 'deposits channel' can account for the entire transmission of monetary policy through bank balance sheets, with effects being stronger in concentrated deposit markets.
positioning_statement: This paper presents a new channel for monetary policy transmission - the deposits channel - that complements existing literature by focusing on how banks' market power in deposit markets affects both household liquidity and bank lending when monetary policy changes.

author: Philipp Schnabl
title: Dissecting the Effect of Credit Supply on Trade: Evidence from Matched Credit-Export Data

author: Philipp Strack
title: Identifying Present Bias from the Timing of Choices
abstract: <jats:p> A (partially naïve) quasi-hyperbolic discounter repeatedly chooses whether to complete a task. Her net benefits of task completion are drawn independently between periods from a time-invariant distribution. We show that the probability of completing the task conditional on not having done so earlier increases towards the deadline. Conversely, we establish nonidentifiability by proving that for any time-preference parameters and any dataset with such (weakly increasing) task-completion probabilities, there exists a stationary payoff distribution that rationalizes the agent’s behavior if she is either sophisticated or fully naïve. Additionally, we provide sharp partial identification for the case of observable continuation values. (JEL C14, D11, D15, D90, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: Can present bias (quasi-hyperbolic discounting) be identified from observing the timing of when agents choose to complete tasks?
answer: Present bias cannot be uniquely identified from timing data alone - any dataset showing increasing task-completion probabilities toward deadlines can be rationalized by multiple combinations of time-preference parameters and payoff distributions, regardless of whether agents are sophisticated or fully naïve about their bias.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a fundamental identification problem in behavioral economics by proving nonidentifiability of present bias from timing choices, contributing to the literature on distinguishing between different models of time preferences and providing partial identification results when continuation values are observable.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Until the Bitter End: On Prospect Theory in a Dynamic Context
abstract: <jats:p> We provide a result on prospect theory decision makers who are naïve about the time inconsistency induced by probability weighting. If a market offers a sufficiently rich set of investment strategies, investors postpone their trading decisions indefinitely due to a strong preference for skewness. We conclude that probability weighting in combination with naïveté leads to unrealistic predictions for a wide range of dynamic setups. (JEL D81, G02, G11) </jats:p>
research_question: What happens when prospect theory decision makers who are naïve about time inconsistency from probability weighting operate in markets with rich investment strategies?
answer: Naïve prospect theory investors postpone their trading decisions indefinitely due to a strong preference for skewness when markets offer sufficiently rich investment strategies.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a fundamental problem with applying prospect theory in dynamic contexts, showing that the combination of probability weighting and naïveté leads to unrealistic predictions across a wide range of dynamic setups, suggesting limitations in existing prospect theory applications to dynamic decision-making.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Privacy‐Preserving Signals
abstract:
<jats:p>A signal is 
            <jats:italic>privacy‐preserving</jats:italic> with respect to a collection of 
            <jats:italic>privacy sets</jats:italic> if the posterior probability assigned to every privacy set remains unchanged conditional on any signal realization. We characterize the privacy‐preserving signals for arbitrary state space and arbitrary privacy sets. A signal is privacy‐preserving if and only if it is a garbling of a 
            <jats:italic>reordered quantile signal</jats:italic>. Furthermore, distributions of posterior means induced by privacy‐preserving signals are exactly mean‐preserving contractions of that induced by the 
            <jats:italic>quantile signal</jats:italic>. We discuss the economic implications of our characterization for statistical discrimination, the revelation of sensitive information in auctions and price discrimination.
          </jats:p>
research_question: What characterizes privacy-preserving signals that keep the posterior probability of privacy sets unchanged regardless of signal realization?
answer: A signal is privacy-preserving if and only if it is a garbling of a reordered quantile signal, and distributions of posterior means induced by privacy-preserving signals are exactly mean-preserving contractions of that induced by the quantile signal.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a novel theoretical framework for characterizing privacy-preserving signals in information economics, with applications to existing literature on statistical discrimination, auction theory, and price discrimination.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Bitcoin: An Axiomatic Approach and an Impossibility Theorem
abstract: <jats:p> Bitcoin’s main innovation lies in allowing a decentralized system that relies on anonymous, profit-driven miners who can freely join the system. We formalize these properties in three axioms: anonymity of miners, no incentives for miners to consolidate, and no incentive to assuming multiple fake identities. This novel axiomatic formalization allows us to characterize what other protocols are feasible: every protocol with these properties must have the same reward scheme as Bitcoin. This implies an impossibility result for risk-averse miners. Furthermore, any protocol either gives up on some degree of decentralization or its reward scheme is equivalent to Bitcoin’s. (JEL D82, E42, O33) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the fundamental properties that characterize Bitcoin's protocol, and what other decentralized cryptocurrency protocols are theoretically feasible given these properties?
answer: Every protocol that satisfies the three key axioms (anonymity of miners, no incentives for miners to consolidate, and no incentive to assume multiple fake identities) must have the same reward scheme as Bitcoin, leading to an impossibility result for risk-averse miners and showing that any alternative protocol must either sacrifice decentralization or be equivalent to Bitcoin's reward scheme.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first axiomatic formalization of Bitcoin's key properties, offering a novel theoretical framework to analyze decentralized cryptocurrency protocols and establish fundamental limitations on what alternative designs are possible.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Stochastic Dominance under Independent Noise

author: Philipp Strack
title: Learning in Repeated Interactions on Networks
abstract: <jats:p>We study how long‐lived, rational agents learn in a social network. In every period, after observing the past actions of his neighbors, each agent receives a private signal, and chooses an action whose payoff depends only on the state. Since equilibrium actions depend on higher‐order beliefs, it is difficult to characterize behavior. Nevertheless, we show that regardless of the size and shape of the network, the utility function, and the patience of the agents, the speed of learning in any equilibrium is bounded from above by a constant that only depends on the private signal distribution.</jats:p>
research_question: How do long-lived, rational agents learn in a social network when their actions depend on higher-order beliefs about other agents' information and decisions?
answer: The speed of learning in any equilibrium is bounded from above by a constant that depends only on the private signal distribution, regardless of network size, network structure, utility function, or agent patience.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the challenge of characterizing learning behavior in network settings where equilibrium actions depend on higher-order beliefs, providing a universal bound on learning speed that transcends specific network or agent characteristics.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Limit Points of Endogenous Misspecified Learning
abstract:
<jats:p>We study how an agent learns from endogenous data when their prior belief is misspecified. We show that only 
            <jats:italic>uniform Berk–Nash equilibria</jats:italic> can be long‐run outcomes, and that all 
            <jats:italic>uniformly strict Berk–Nash equilibria</jats:italic> have an arbitrarily high probability of being the long‐run outcome for some initial beliefs. When the agent believes the outcome distribution is exogenous, every uniformly strict Berk–Nash equilibrium has positive probability of being the long‐run outcome for any initial belief. We generalize these results to settings where the agent observes a signal before acting.
          </jats:p>
research_question: How does an agent learn from endogenous data when their prior belief is misspecified, and what are the possible long-run outcomes of this learning process?
answer: Only uniform Berk-Nash equilibria can be long-run outcomes of misspecified learning from endogenous data, and all uniformly strict Berk-Nash equilibria have arbitrarily high probability of being the long-run outcome for some initial beliefs. When the agent believes the outcome distribution is exogenous, every uniformly strict Berk-Nash equilibrium has positive probability of being the long-run outcome for any initial belief.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on learning with misspecified beliefs by focusing specifically on endogenous data generation, characterizing the limit points of such learning processes through the lens of Berk-Nash equilibria, and generalizing results to settings with signal observation before action.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Selective-Memory Equilibrium

author: Philipp Strack
title: Speed, Accuracy, and the Optimal Timing of Choices
abstract: <jats:p>We model the joint distribution of choice probabilities and decision times in binary decisions as the solution to a problem of optimal sequential sampling, where the agent is uncertain of the utility of each action and pays a constant cost per unit time for gathering information. We show that choices are more likely to be correct when the agent chooses to decide quickly, provided the agent’s prior beliefs are correct. This better matches the observed correlation between decision time and choice probability than does the classical drift-diffusion model (DDM), where the agent knows the utility difference between the choices. (JEL C41, D11, D12, D83)</jats:p>
research_question: How can we model the joint distribution of choice probabilities and decision times in binary decisions when agents are uncertain about the utility of each action?
answer: Choices are more likely to be correct when the agent chooses to decide quickly, provided the agent's prior beliefs are correct, which better matches observed correlations between decision time and choice probability than existing models.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as an improvement over the classical drift-diffusion model (DDM) by incorporating agent uncertainty about utility differences between choices, rather than assuming the agent knows the utility difference between choices.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Turning Up the Heat: The Discouraging Effect of Competition in Contests

author: Philipp Strack
title: Extreme Points and Majorization: Economic Applications
abstract: <jats:p>We characterize the set of extreme points of monotonic functions that are either majorized by a given function<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>or themselves majorize<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>and show that these extreme points play a crucial role in many economic design problems. Our main results show that each extreme point is uniquely characterized by a countable collection of intervals. Outside these intervals the extreme point equals the original function<jats:italic>f</jats:italic>and inside the function is constant. Further consistency conditions need to be satisfied pinning down the value of an extreme point in each interval where it is constant. We apply these insights to a varied set of economic problems: equivalence and optimality of mechanisms for auctions and (matching) contests, Bayesian persuasion, optimal delegation, and decision making under uncertainty.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the extreme points of monotonic functions that are either majorized by a given function f or themselves majorize f, and how do these extreme points apply to economic design problems?
answer: Each extreme point is uniquely characterized by a countable collection of intervals where the extreme point equals the original function f outside these intervals and is constant inside them, with consistency conditions determining the constant values within each interval.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a mathematical characterization of extreme points in majorization theory and demonstrates their crucial role across a diverse set of economic design problems including auctions, contests, Bayesian persuasion, optimal delegation, and decision making under uncertainty.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Unrealistic Expectations and Misguided Learning
abstract: We explore the learning process and behavior of an individual with unrealistically high expectations (overconfidence) when outcomes also depend on an external fundamental that affects the optimal action. Moving beyond existing results in the literature, we show that the agent's beliefs regarding the fundamental converge under weak conditions. Furthermore, we identify a broad class of situations in which "learning" about the fundamental is self‐defeating: it leads the individual systematically away from the correct belief and toward lower performance. Due to his overconfidence, the agent—even if initially correct—becomes too pessimistic about the fundamental. As he adjusts his behavior in response, he lowers outcomes and hence becomes even more pessimistic about the fundamental, perpetuating the misdirected learning. The greater is the loss from choosing a suboptimal action, the further the agent's action ends up from optimal. We partially characterize environments in which self‐defeating learning occurs, and show that the decisionmaker learns to take the optimal action if, and in a sense only if, a specific non‐identifiability condition is satisfied. In contrast to an overconfident agent, an underconfident agent's misdirected learning is self‐limiting and therefore not very harmful. We argue that the decision situations in question are common in economic settings, including delegation, organizational, effort, and public‐policy choices.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Matching in Dynamic Imbalanced Markets
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study dynamic matching in exchange markets with easy- and hard-to-match agents. A greedy policy, which attempts to match agents upon arrival, ignores the positive externality that waiting agents provide by facilitating future matchings. We prove that the trade-off between a “thicker” market and faster matching vanishes in large markets; the greedy policy leads to shorter waiting times and more agents matched than any other policy. We empirically confirm these findings in data from the National Kidney Registry. Greedy matching achieves as many transplants as commonly used policies (1.8$\%$ more than monthly batching) and shorter waiting times (16 days faster than monthly batching).</jats:p>
research_question: How should dynamic matching be optimized in exchange markets with heterogeneous agents (easy- and hard-to-match) when there is a trade-off between maintaining market thickness through waiting and achieving faster matching?
answer: The greedy policy (matching agents immediately upon arrival) outperforms other policies in large markets, achieving both shorter waiting times and more total matches, as the trade-off between market thickness and matching speed vanishes at scale.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional wisdom that waiting to build market thickness is beneficial in matching markets, showing that greedy policies can simultaneously optimize both matching speed and volume in large dynamic exchange markets, contrary to existing literature that emphasizes the thickness-speed trade-off.

author: Philipp Strack
title: The Cost of Information: The Case of Constant Marginal Costs
abstract: <jats:p>We develop an axiomatic theory of information acquisition that captures the idea of constant marginal costs in information production: the cost of generating two independent signals is the sum of their costs, and generating a signal with probability half costs half its original cost. Together with Blackwell monotonicity and a continuity condition, these axioms determine the cost of a signal up to a vector of parameters. These parameters have a clear economic interpretation and determine the difficulty of distinguishing states. (JEL D82, D83)</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop an axiomatic theory that characterizes information acquisition costs when marginal costs are constant?
answer: The cost of a signal can be uniquely determined (up to a vector of parameters) by three axioms: constant marginal costs (cost of two independent signals equals sum of their individual costs, and generating a signal with probability half costs half the original cost), Blackwell monotonicity, and continuity. The parameters have clear economic interpretation and determine the difficulty of distinguishing between different states.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new axiomatic foundation for information acquisition costs by focusing specifically on the case of constant marginal costs, providing a theoretical framework that complements existing literature on information economics by offering a precise characterization of cost structures in information production.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Background Risk and Small-Stakes Risk Aversion
abstract: <jats:p> Building on Pomatto, Strack, and Tamuz (2020), we identify a tight condition for when background risk can induce first-order stochastic dominance. Using this condition, we show that under plausible levels of background risk, no theory of choice under risk can simultaneously satisfy the following three economic postulates: (i) decision-makers are risk averse over small gambles, (ii) their preferences respect stochastic dominance, and (iii) they account for background risk. This impossibility result applies to expected utility theory, prospect theory, rank-dependent utility, and many other models. (JEL D81, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: Can any theory of choice under risk simultaneously satisfy risk aversion over small gambles, respect for stochastic dominance, and accounting for background risk under plausible levels of background risk?
answer: No theory of choice under risk can simultaneously satisfy all three economic postulates (small-stakes risk aversion, stochastic dominance, and accounting for background risk) under plausible levels of background risk - this impossibility result applies to expected utility theory, prospect theory, rank-dependent utility, and many other models.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Pomatto, Strack, and Tamuz (2020) by identifying a tight condition for when background risk can induce first-order stochastic dominance, and uses this condition to establish a fundamental impossibility result that applies broadly across multiple existing theories of choice under risk including expected utility theory, prospect theory, and rank-dependent utility.

author: Philipp Strack
title: A Theory of Auctions with Endogenous Valuations

author: Philipp Strack
title: Optimal Security Design for Risk-Averse Investors
abstract: <jats:p> We use the tools of mechanism design combined with the theory of risk measures to analyze how a cash-constrained owner of an asset with known, stochastic returns raises capital from a population of investors who differ in their risk aversion and budget constraints. The issuer partitions the asset’s cash flow into several asset-backed securities, one for each type of investor. The optimal partition conforms to the commonly observed practice of tranching into senior debt, junior debt, and equity. Tranching arises endogenously due to the differences in risk appetites among agents and in the budget constraints they face. (JEL D81, D82, G12, G41, G51) </jats:p>
research_question: How should a cash-constrained asset owner optimally design securities to raise capital from investors who differ in their risk aversion and budget constraints?
answer: The optimal security design involves partitioning the asset's cash flow into tranched securities (senior debt, junior debt, and equity) with each tranche targeted to different investor types based on their risk appetites and budget constraints.
positioning_statement: This paper combines mechanism design tools with risk measure theory to provide a theoretical foundation for the commonly observed practice of tranching, showing that it arises endogenously from investor heterogeneity rather than being an ad hoc market convention.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Optimal Auctions: Non-expected Utility and Constant Risk Aversion
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study auction design for bidders equipped with non-expected utility preferences that exhibit constant risk aversion (CRA). The CRA class is large and includes loss-averse, disappointment-averse, mean-dispersion, and Yaari’s dual preferences as well as coherent and convex risk measures. Any preference in this class displays first-order risk aversion, contrasting the standard expected utility case which displays second-order risk aversion. The optimal mechanism offers “ full-insurance” in the sense that each agent’s utility is independent of other agents’ reports. The seller excludes less types than under risk neutrality and awards the object randomly to intermediate types. Subjecting intermediate types to a risky allocation while compensating them when losing allows the seller to collect larger payments from higher types. Relatively high types are willing to pay more, and their allocation is efficient.</jats:p>
research_question: How should optimal auctions be designed when bidders have non-expected utility preferences that exhibit constant risk aversion (CRA)?
answer: The optimal mechanism offers 'full-insurance' where each agent's utility is independent of other agents' reports, excludes fewer types than under risk neutrality, awards the object randomly to intermediate types, and results in efficient allocation for relatively high types while allowing the seller to collect larger payments.
positioning_statement: This paper extends auction design theory beyond the standard expected utility framework by analyzing a large class of non-expected utility preferences (CRA) that includes loss-averse, disappointment-averse, mean-dispersion, and Yaari's dual preferences, contrasting with standard expected utility which displays second-order risk aversion by focusing on preferences that exhibit first-order risk aversion.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Monotone Additive Statistics
abstract: <jats:p>The expectation is an example of a descriptive statistic that is monotone with respect to stochastic dominance, and additive for sums of independent random variables. We provide a complete characterization of such statistics, and explore a number of applications to models of individual and group decision‐making. These include a representation of stationary monotone time preferences, extending the work of Fishburn and Rubinstein (1982) to time lotteries. This extension offers a new perspective on risk attitudes toward time, as well as on the aggregation of multiple discount factors. We also offer a novel class of non‐expected utility preferences over gambles which satisfy invariance to background risk as well as betweenness, but are versatile enough to capture mixed risk attitudes.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the complete characterization of descriptive statistics that are both monotone with respect to stochastic dominance and additive for sums of independent random variables?
answer: The paper provides a complete characterization of monotone additive statistics (beyond just the expectation) and demonstrates their applications in modeling individual and group decision-making, including stationary monotone time preferences and non-expected utility preferences that satisfy invariance to background risk and betweenness while capturing mixed risk attitudes.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the work of Fishburn and Rubinstein (1982) on time preferences to time lotteries, offers a new perspective on risk attitudes toward time and aggregation of multiple discount factors, and introduces a novel class of non-expected utility preferences that can handle mixed risk attitudes while satisfying key invariance properties.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Optimal Insurance: Dual Utility, Random Losses, and Adverse Selection
abstract: <jats:p> We study a generalization of the classical monopoly insurance problem under adverse selection (see Stiglitz 1977) where we allow for a random distribution of losses, possibly correlated with the agent’s risk parameter that is private information. Our model explains patterns of observed customer behavior and predicts insurance contracts most often observed in practice: these consist of menus of several deductible-premium pairs or menus of insurance with coverage limits–premium pairs. A main departure from the classical insurance literature is obtained here by endowing the agents with risk-averse preferences that can be represented by a dual utility functional (Yaari 1987). (JEL D81, D82, D86, D91, G22) </jats:p>
research_question: How does allowing for random distribution of losses (possibly correlated with private risk parameters) and dual utility preferences affect optimal insurance contract design under adverse selection?
answer: The model explains observed customer behavior and predicts commonly observed insurance contracts in practice, specifically menus of deductible-premium pairs or coverage limits-premium pairs, when agents have risk-averse preferences represented by dual utility functionals.
positioning_statement: This paper generalizes the classical monopoly insurance problem under adverse selection (Stiglitz 1977) by incorporating random loss distributions and departing from classical insurance literature through the use of dual utility functional preferences (Yaari 1987) instead of traditional expected utility.

author: Philipp Strack
title: Rational Groupthink
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study how long-lived rational agents learn from repeatedly observing a private signal and each others’ actions. With normal signals, a group of any size learns more slowly than just four agents who directly observe each others’ private signals in each period. Similar results apply to general signal structures. We identify rational groupthink—in which agents ignore their private signals and choose the same action for long periods of time—as the cause of this failure of information aggregation.</jats:p>
research_question: How do long-lived rational agents learn when they repeatedly observe private signals and each other's actions, and how does this compare to direct information sharing?
answer: A group of any size learns more slowly than just four agents who directly observe each other's private signals, due to 'rational groupthink' where agents ignore their private signals and choose the same action for extended periods, causing information aggregation to fail.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies and analyzes the phenomenon of 'rational groupthink' as a previously unrecognized mechanism that causes failure of information aggregation in social learning models, demonstrating that larger groups can perform worse than smaller groups with direct information sharing.

author: Philipp Strack
title: From Blackwell Dominance in Large Samples to Rényi Divergences and Back Again
abstract: <jats:p>We study repeated independent Blackwell experiments; standard examples include drawing multiple samples from a population, or performing a measurement in different locations. In the baseline setting of a binary state of nature, we compare experiments in terms of their informativeness in large samples. Addressing a question due to Blackwell (1951), we show that generically an experiment is more informative than another in large samples if and only if it has higher Rényi divergences.</jats:p><jats:p>We apply our analysis to the problem of measuring the degree of dissimilarity between distributions by means of divergences. A useful property of Rényi divergences is their additivity with respect to product distributions. Our characterization of Blackwell dominance in large samples implies that every additive divergence that satisfies the data processing inequality is an integral of Rényi divergences.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between Blackwell dominance in large samples and Rényi divergences for repeated independent experiments?
answer: An experiment is more informative than another in large samples if and only if it has higher Rényi divergences, and every additive divergence satisfying the data processing inequality is an integral of Rényi divergences.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a question originally posed by Blackwell (1951) and provides a characterization that connects information theory (Blackwell dominance) with statistical divergence measures (Rényi divergences), offering new insights into measuring dissimilarity between distributions.

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Modeling the Change of Paradigm: Non-Bayesian Reactions to Unexpected News
abstract: <jats:p> Bayes' rule has two well-known limitations: 1) it does not model the reaction to zero-probability events; 2) a sizable empirical evidence documents systematic violations of it. We characterize axiomatically an alternative updating rule, the Hypothesis Testing model. According to it, the agent follows Bayes' rule if she receives information to which she assigned a probability above a threshold. Otherwise, she looks at a prior over priors, updates it using Bayes' rule for second-order priors, and chooses the prior to which the updated prior over priors assigns the highest likelihood. We also present an application to equilibrium refinement in game theory. (JEL D11, D81, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we model agent updating behavior when they encounter zero-probability events or systematically violate Bayes' rule?
answer: The paper develops the Hypothesis Testing model as an alternative updating rule where agents use Bayes' rule for expected information above a threshold, but switch to updating a prior over priors and selecting the most likely prior when encountering unexpected information below the threshold.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses two well-known limitations of Bayes' rule - its inability to handle zero-probability events and systematic empirical violations - by providing an axiomatic characterization of an alternative updating mechanism that can handle unexpected news and paradigm shifts.

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Stochastic Choice and Preferences for Randomization

title: Are conservatives overconfident?

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Overconfidence in Political Behavior
abstract: <jats:p> This paper studies, theoretically and empirically, the role of overconfidence in political behavior. Our model of overconfidence in beliefs predicts that overconfidence leads to ideological extremeness, increased voter turnout, and stronger partisan identification. The model also makes nuanced predictions about the patterns of ideology in society. These predictions are tested using unique data that measure the overconfidence and standard political characteristics of a nationwide sample of over 3,000 adults. Our numerous predictions find strong support in these data. In particular, we document that overconfidence is a substantively and statistically important predictor of ideological extremeness, voter turnout, and partisan identification. (JEL C83, D03, D72, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of overconfidence in political behavior, specifically how does overconfidence in beliefs affect ideological extremeness, voter turnout, and partisan identification?
answer: Overconfidence leads to ideological extremeness, increased voter turnout, and stronger partisan identification, with overconfidence being a substantively and statistically important predictor of these political behaviors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing both theoretical and empirical analysis of overconfidence in political behavior using unique nationwide data measuring overconfidence and political characteristics of over 3,000 adults, testing nuanced predictions about ideology patterns in society.
