author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Caution and Reference Effects
abstract: <jats:p>We introduce Cautious Utility, a new model based on the idea that individuals are unsure of trade‐offs between goods and apply caution. The model yields an endowment effect, even when gains and losses are treated symmetrically. Moreover, it implies either loss aversion or loss neutrality for risk, but in a way unrelated to the endowment effect, and it captures the certainty effect, providing a novel unified explanation of all three phenomena. Cautious Utility can help organize empirical evidence, including some that directly contradicts leading alternatives.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a unified model explain the endowment effect, loss aversion/neutrality for risk, and the certainty effect based on individuals being unsure of trade-offs between goods?
answer: Yes, the Cautious Utility model successfully provides a unified explanation for all three phenomena by incorporating the idea that individuals apply caution when uncertain about trade-offs, yielding an endowment effect even with symmetric treatment of gains and losses, and capturing both risk preferences and certainty effects.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a novel unified explanation that can organize empirical evidence better than existing models, including evidence that directly contradicts leading alternative theories in behavioral economics.

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Deliberately Stochastic
abstract: <jats:p> We study stochastic choice as the outcome of deliberate randomization. We derive a general representation of a stochastic choice function where stochasticity allows the agent to achieve from any set the maximal element according to her underlying preferences over lotteries. We show that in this model stochasticity in choice captures complementarity between elements in the set, and thus necessarily implies violations of Regularity/Monotonicity, one of the most common properties of stochastic choice. This feature separates our approach from other models, e.g., Random Utility. (JEL D80, D81) </jats:p>
research_question: How can stochastic choice be understood as the outcome of deliberate randomization by agents?
answer: Stochastic choice can be represented as agents deliberately randomizing to achieve maximal elements according to their underlying preferences over lotteries, where stochasticity captures complementarity between elements in choice sets and necessarily violates Regularity/Monotonicity properties.
positioning_statement: This approach separates itself from existing models like Random Utility by showing that deliberate stochasticity necessarily implies violations of Regularity/Monotonicity, which is one of the most common properties assumed in other stochastic choice models.

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Revealed (P)Reference Theory
abstract: <jats:p> This paper develops axiomatically a revealed preference theory of reference-dependent choice behavior. Instead of taking the reference for an agent as exogenously given in the description of a choice problem, we suitably relax the Weak Axiom of Revealed Preference to obtain, endogenously, the existence of reference alternatives as well as the structure of choice behavior conditional on those alternatives. We show how this model captures some well-known choice patterns such as the attraction effect. (JEL D11, D81) </jats:p>
research_question: How can revealed preference theory be extended to endogenously determine reference points in reference-dependent choice behavior, rather than taking them as exogenously given?
answer: By suitably relaxing the Weak Axiom of Revealed Preference, it is possible to axiomatically develop a theory that endogenously derives both the existence of reference alternatives and the structure of choice behavior conditional on those alternatives, which can explain phenomena like the attraction effect.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as developing a new axiomatic approach to reference-dependent choice that differs from existing literature by endogenously determining reference points through revealed preferences, rather than assuming reference points are exogenously given in the choice problem description.

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Competing Models
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Different agents need to make a prediction. They observe identical data, but have different models: they predict using different explanatory variables. We study which agent believes they have the best predictive ability—as measured by the smallest subjective posterior mean squared prediction error—and show how it depends on the sample size. With small samples, we present results suggesting it is an agent using a low-dimensional model. With large samples, it is generally an agent with a high-dimensional model, possibly including irrelevant variables, but never excluding relevant ones. We apply our results to characterize the winning model in an auction of productive assets, to argue that entrepreneurs and investors with simple models will be overrepresented in new sectors, and to understand the proliferation of “factors” that explain the cross-sectional variation of expected stock returns in the asset-pricing literature.</jats:p>
research_question: Which agent believes they have the best predictive ability when different agents observe identical data but use different models with different explanatory variables, and how does this depend on sample size?
answer: With small samples, agents using low-dimensional models believe they have the best predictive ability, while with large samples, agents with high-dimensional models (possibly including irrelevant variables but never excluding relevant ones) generally believe they have the best predictive ability.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding model selection and prediction confidence across different sample sizes, with applications to asset auctions, entrepreneurial investment in new sectors, and the proliferation of factors in asset-pricing literature that explain cross-sectional variation in expected stock returns.

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Econographics

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Time Lotteries and Stochastic Impatience
abstract: <jats:p>We study preferences over lotteries in which both the prize and the payment date are uncertain. In particular, a<jats:italic>time lottery</jats:italic>is one in which the prize is fixed but the date is random. With Expected Discounted Utility, individuals must be risk<jats:italic>seeking</jats:italic>over time lotteries (RSTL). In an incentivized experiment, however, we find that almost all subjects violate this property. Our main contributions are theoretical. We first show that within a very broad class of models, which includes many forms of nonexpected utility and time discounting, it is impossible to accommodate even a single violation of RSTL without also violating a property we termed Stochastic Impatience, a risky counterpart of standard Impatience. We then present two positive results. If one wishes to maintain Stochastic Impatience, violations of RSTL can be accommodated by keeping Independence within periods while relaxing it across periods. If, instead, one is willing to forego Stochastic Impatience, violations of RSTL can be accommodated with a simple generalization of Expected Discounted Utility, obtained by imposing only the behavioral postulates of Discounted Utility and Expected Utility.</jats:p>
research_question: How do individuals make decisions over time lotteries where both the prize and payment date are uncertain, and can existing economic models accommodate observed violations of risk-seeking behavior over time lotteries?
answer: Almost all experimental subjects violate the Expected Discounted Utility prediction of being risk-seeking over time lotteries (RSTL). Within a broad class of models, accommodating even a single RSTL violation requires violating Stochastic Impatience. However, RSTL violations can be accommodated either by maintaining Stochastic Impatience while relaxing Independence across periods, or by foregoing Stochastic Impatience through a simple generalization of Expected Discounted Utility.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on decision-making under uncertainty by introducing the novel concept of time lotteries and demonstrating fundamental limitations of Expected Discounted Utility and other broad classes of models in explaining observed behavior, while proposing two theoretical solutions that relax different standard assumptions.

author: Pietro Ortoleva
title: Motives and Consequences of Libor Strategic Reporting: How Much Can We Learn from Banks’ Self-Reported Borrowing Rates?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Libor is an estimate of interbank borrowing costs computed daily from rates reported by a fixed panel of banks. Evidence suggests that banks have manipulated Libor in recent years by misreporting their borrowing costs. I estimate a strategic reporting model that identifies banks’ borrowing costs as well as their motives for misreporting. The estimation places a lower bound on the value that Libor would have had if banks had truthfully reported their borrowing costs. The model is identified even when unobserved heterogeneity exists in the form of a common cost component that is known by all banks but unobservable to the econometrician and is allowed to follow a non-stationary process. The only data used for identification are banks’ Libor quotes. Overall, I find that the estimated lower bound for the unmanipulated Libor is always above the published Libor, with an average deviation of 25 basis points at the worst of the financial crisis of 2007–2008. The estimated bound displays a pattern similar to two other measures of interbank borrowing costs that have been used previously to assess the extent of manipulation. The model is also used to determine the extent to which misreporting was motivated by signalling or banks’ net exposure to Libor. The estimation results indicate that sending creditworthiness signals was the main driver of systematic misreporting from 2007 to 2010.</jats:p>
research_question: How much can we learn about banks' true borrowing costs from their self-reported Libor rates, and what motivated banks to strategically misreport these rates?
answer: Banks systematically underreported their borrowing costs, with the estimated lower bound for unmanipulated Libor being on average 25 basis points higher than published Libor during the worst of the 2007-2008 financial crisis. The main driver of this strategic misreporting from 2007 to 2010 was banks' desire to signal creditworthiness rather than profit from their net exposure to Libor.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on Libor manipulation by developing a novel strategic reporting model that can identify banks' true borrowing costs and misreporting motives using only banks' Libor quotes, even in the presence of unobserved heterogeneity and non-stationary common cost components that previous approaches could not handle.

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: Preparing for the Worst but Hoping for the Best: Robust (Bayesian) Persuasion
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a robust solution concept for Bayesian persuasion that accounts for the Sender's concern that her Bayesian belief about the environment—which we call the<jats:italic>conjecture</jats:italic>—may be false. Specifically, the Sender is uncertain about the exogenous sources of information the Receivers may learn from, and about strategy selection. She first identifies all information policies that yield the largest payoff in the “worst‐case scenario,” that is, when Nature provides information and coordinates the Receivers' play to minimize the Sender's payoff. Then she uses the conjecture to pick the optimal policy among the worst‐case optimal ones. We characterize properties of robust solutions, identify conditions under which robustness requires separation of certain states, and qualify in what sense robustness calls for more information disclosure than standard Bayesian persuasion. Finally, we discuss how some of the results in the Bayesian persuasion literature change once robustness is accounted for, and develop a few new applications.</jats:p>
research_question: How should a Sender design information policies in Bayesian persuasion when she is uncertain about her beliefs regarding the environment, including exogenous information sources available to Receivers and their strategy selection?
answer: The paper proposes a robust solution concept where the Sender first identifies information policies that maximize payoff in the worst-case scenario (when Nature minimizes Sender's payoff), then uses her conjecture to select the optimal policy among these worst-case optimal ones. This robust approach generally requires more information disclosure and separation of certain states compared to standard Bayesian persuasion.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the existing Bayesian persuasion literature by introducing robustness considerations for situations where the Sender has uncertainty about her beliefs regarding the environment, demonstrating how standard Bayesian persuasion results change when robustness is incorporated and developing new applications based on this framework.

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: The Simple Economics of Optimal Persuasion

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: Redistribution Through Markets
abstract: <jats:p>Policymakers frequently use price regulations as a response to inequality in the markets they control. In this paper, we examine the optimal structure of such policies from the perspective of mechanism design. We study a buyer‐seller market in which agents have private information about both their valuations for an indivisible object and their marginal utilities for money. The planner seeks a mechanism that maximizes agents' total utilities, subject to incentive and market‐clearing constraints. We uncover the constrained Pareto frontier by identifying the optimal trade‐off between allocative efficiency and redistribution. We find that competitive‐equilibrium allocation is not always optimal. Instead, when there is inequality across sides of the market, the optimal design uses a tax‐like mechanism, introducing a wedge between the buyer and seller prices, and redistributing the resulting surplus to the poorer side of the market via lump‐sum payments. When there is significant same‐side inequality that can be uncovered by market behavior, it may be optimal to impose price controls even though doing so induces rationing.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal structure of price regulation policies for redistribution in markets from a mechanism design perspective?
answer: The optimal mechanism involves a tax-like system that creates a wedge between buyer and seller prices when there is inequality across market sides, redistributing surplus to the poorer side via lump-sum payments. When significant same-side inequality exists that can be revealed through market behavior, price controls may be optimal despite causing rationing.
positioning_statement: This paper applies mechanism design theory to examine price regulations as redistribution tools, uncovering the constrained Pareto frontier and identifying optimal trade-offs between allocative efficiency and redistribution, challenging the assumption that competitive equilibrium allocation is always optimal.

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: An Economic Framework for Vaccine Prioritization
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose an economic framework for determining the optimal allocation of a scarce supply of vaccines that become gradually available during a public health crisis, such as the COVID-19 pandemic. Agents differ in observable and unobservable characteristics, and the designer maximizes a social welfare function over all feasible mechanisms—accounting for agents’ characteristics, as well as their endogenous behavior in the face of the pandemic. The framework emphasizes the role of externalities and incorporates equity as well as efficiency concerns. Our results provide an economic justification for providing vaccines immediately and for free to some groups of agents, while at the same time showing that a carefully constructed pricing mechanism can improve outcomes by screening for individuals with the highest private and social benefits of receiving the vaccine. The solution casts light on the classic question of whether prices or priorities should be used to allocate scarce public resources under externalities and equity concerns.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the optimal allocation mechanism for scarce vaccines that become gradually available during a public health crisis, considering both efficiency and equity concerns?
answer: The optimal allocation combines free immediate distribution to certain groups with a carefully constructed pricing mechanism that screens for individuals with the highest private and social benefits, providing economic justification for hybrid allocation strategies.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the classic economic question of whether prices or priorities should be used to allocate scarce public resources by developing a comprehensive framework that accounts for externalities, equity concerns, and agent heterogeneity in the context of vaccine distribution during pandemics.

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: Redistributive Allocation Mechanisms

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: Incentive Separability

author: Piotr Dworczak
title: Mechanism Design With Aftermarkets: Cutoff Mechanisms
abstract:
<jats:p>I study a mechanism design problem in which a designer allocates a single good to one of several agents, and the mechanism is followed by an 
            <jats:italic>aftermarket</jats:italic>—a post‐mechanism game played between the agent who acquired the good and third‐party market participants. The designer has preferences over final outcomes, but she cannot design the aftermarket. However, she can influence its information structure by publicly disclosing information elicited from the agents by the mechanism.
          </jats:p>
          <jats:p>I introduce a class of allocation and disclosure rules, called 
            <jats:italic>cutoff rules</jats:italic>, that disclose information about the buyer's type only by revealing information about the realization of a random threshold (cutoff) that she had to outbid to win the object. When there is a single agent in the mechanism, I show that the 
            <jats:italic>optimal</jats:italic> cutoff mechanism offers full privacy to the agent. In contrast, when there are multiple agents, the optimal cutoff mechanism may disclose information about the winner's type; I provide sufficient conditions for optimality of simple designs. I also characterize aftermarkets for which restricting attention to cutoff mechanisms is without loss of generality in a subclass of all feasible mechanisms satisfying additional conditions.
          </jats:p>
research_question: How should a designer optimally allocate a good and disclose information when the allocation mechanism is followed by an aftermarket that the designer cannot control but can influence through information disclosure?
answer: The optimal approach depends on the number of agents: with a single agent, the optimal cutoff mechanism provides full privacy to preserve the agent's bargaining position in the aftermarket; with multiple agents, the optimal mechanism may strategically disclose information about the winner's type, and simple cutoff mechanisms that reveal information only through random threshold realizations can be optimal under certain conditions.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new framework that bridges mechanism design with post-mechanism strategic interactions by studying how designers can optimally influence aftermarket outcomes through strategic information disclosure, contributing to the literature on mechanism design with resale and information design.

author: Qingmin Liu
title: Stability and Bayesian Consistency in Two-Sided Markets
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a criterion of stability for two-sided markets with asymmetric information. A central idea is to formulate off-path beliefs conditional on counterfactual pairwise deviations and on-path beliefs in the absence of such deviations. A matching-belief configuration is stable if the matching is individually rational with respect to the system of on-path beliefs and is not blocked with respect to the system of off-path beliefs. The formulation provides a language for assessing matching outcomes with respect to their supporting beliefs and opens the door to further belief-based refinements. The main refinement analyzed in the paper requires the Bayesian consistency of on-path and off-path beliefs with prior beliefs. We define concepts of Bayesian efficiency, the rational expectations competitive equilibrium, and the core. Their contrast with pairwise stability manifests the role of information asymmetry in matching formation. (JEL C78, D40, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we define and analyze stability in two-sided matching markets when there is asymmetric information between participants?
answer: The paper proposes a new stability criterion based on matching-belief configurations that distinguishes between on-path beliefs (absent deviations) and off-path beliefs (conditional on counterfactual deviations), with the main refinement requiring Bayesian consistency of these beliefs with prior beliefs.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing matching theory by incorporating asymmetric information and belief formation, contrasting new concepts of Bayesian efficiency, rational expectations competitive equilibrium, and the core with traditional pairwise stability to demonstrate how information asymmetry affects matching formation.

author: Qingmin Liu
title: Auctions with Limited Commitment
abstract: <jats:p> We study the role of limited commitment in a standard auction environment. In each period, the seller can commit to an auction with a reserve price but not to future reserve prices. We characterize the set of equilibrium profits attainable for the seller as the period length vanishes. An immediate sale by efficient auction is optimal when there are at least three buyers. For many natural distributions two buyers is enough. Otherwise, we give conditions under which the maximal profit is attained through continuously declining reserve prices. (JEL D44, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: How does limited commitment affect seller profits and optimal auction design when a seller can commit to current auction terms but not to future reserve prices?
answer: When there are at least three buyers, an immediate sale by efficient auction is optimal for the seller. For two buyers, this result holds for many natural distributions. Otherwise, maximal profit is achieved through continuously declining reserve prices over time.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the standard auction literature by introducing the constraint of limited commitment, where sellers can commit to current auction parameters but not to future reserve prices, analyzing how this commitment limitation affects optimal auction design and seller profits.

author: Qingmin Liu
title: Optimal Contracts for Experimentation

author: Qingmin Liu
title: Contests for Experimentation

author: Qingmin Liu
title: Strategic Exploration: Pre-emption and Prioritization
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This paper analyses a model of strategic exploration in which competing players independently explore a set of alternatives. The model features a multiple-player multiple-armed bandit problem and captures a strategic trade-off between pre-emption—covert exploration of alternatives that the opponent will explore in the future—and prioritization—exploration of the most promising alternatives. Our results explain how the strategic trade-off shapes equilibrium behaviours and outcomes, for example, in technology races between superpowers and R&D competitions between firms. We show that players compete on the same set of alternatives, leading to duplicated exploration from start to finish, and they explore alternatives that are a priori less promising before more promising ones are exhausted. The model also predicts that competition induces players to implement unreliable technologies too early, even though they should wait for the technologies to mature. Coordinated exploration is impossible even if the alternatives are equally promising, but it can emerge in equilibrium following a phase of pre-emptive competition if there is a short deadline. With asymmetric capacities of exploration, the weak player conducts extensive instead of intensive exploration—exploring as many alternatives as the strong player does but never fully exploring any.</jats:p>
research_question: How does strategic competition between players affect exploration behavior when they independently explore a set of alternatives, particularly regarding the trade-off between pre-emption and prioritization?
answer: Strategic competition leads to duplicated exploration efforts, causes players to explore less promising alternatives before exhausting more promising ones, induces premature implementation of unreliable technologies, prevents coordination even with equally promising alternatives, and results in weak players conducting extensive rather than intensive exploration when capacities are asymmetric.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by analyzing a multiple-player multiple-armed bandit problem that captures strategic exploration dynamics in contexts such as technology races between superpowers and R&D competitions between firms, focusing on the previously understudied trade-off between pre-emption and prioritization in competitive exploration.

author: Rachel Griffith
title: Vertical Integration and Competition

author: Rachel Griffith
title: How Well Targeted Are Soda Taxes?
abstract: <jats:p>Soda taxes aim to reduce excessive sugar consumption. We assess who is most impacted by soda taxes. We estimate demand using micro longitudinal data covering on-the-go purchases, and exploit the panel dimension to estimate individual-specific preferences. We relate these preferences and counterfactual predictions to individual characteristics and show that soda taxes are relatively effective at targeting the sugar intake of the young, are less successful at targeting the intake of those with high total dietary sugar, and are unlikely to be strongly regressive especially if consumers benefit from averted internalities. (JEL D12, H22, H25, H71)</jats:p>
research_question: How well targeted are soda taxes in terms of their impact on different demographic groups and their effectiveness at reducing sugar consumption?
answer: Soda taxes are relatively effective at targeting sugar intake reduction among young people, but are less successful at targeting those with high total dietary sugar consumption, and are unlikely to be strongly regressive, particularly when considering the benefits from reduced negative internalities.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the soda tax literature by using micro longitudinal data on on-the-go purchases and exploiting the panel dimension to estimate individual-specific preferences, allowing for a more granular assessment of how soda taxes impact different consumer groups compared to previous studies.

author: Rachel Ngai
title: Structural Change in a Multisector Model of Growth
abstract: <jats:p> We study a multisector model of growth with differences in TFP growth rates across sectors and derive sufficient conditions for the coexistence of structural change, characterized by sectoral labor reallocation and balanced aggregate growth. The conditions are weak restrictions on the utility and production functions. Along the balanced growth path, labor employed in the production of consumption goods gradually moves to the sector with the lowest TFP growth rate, until in the limit it is the only sector with nontrivial employment of this kind. The employment shares of intermediate and capital goods remain constant during the reallocation process. (JEL O41) </jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions can structural change (characterized by sectoral labor reallocation) coexist with balanced aggregate growth in a multisector economy with different TFP growth rates across sectors?
answer: Structural change and balanced aggregate growth can coexist under weak restrictions on utility and production functions, with labor in consumption goods production gradually moving to the sector with the lowest TFP growth rate until it dominates employment, while intermediate and capital goods employment shares remain constant.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the multisector growth literature by providing a theoretical framework that reconciles structural change with balanced growth, addressing the apparent tension between sectoral reallocation and aggregate stability in growth models.

author: Rachel Griffith
title: The Effects of Banning Advertising in Junk Food Markets

author: Rachel Griffith
title: Do Prices and Attributes Explain International Differences in Food Purchases?
abstract: <jats:p>Food purchases differ substantially across countries. We use detailed household-level data from the United States, France, and the United Kingdom to (i) document these differences; (ii) estimate a demand system for food and nutrients; and (iii) simulate counterfactual choices if households faced prices and nutritional characteristics from other countries. We find that differences in prices and characteristics are important and can explain some difference (e.g., United States–France difference in caloric intake) but generally cannot explain many of the compositional patterns by themselves. Instead, it seems an interaction between the economic environment and differences in preferences is needed to explain cross-country differences. (JEL D12, I12, L11, L66, Q11)</jats:p>
research_question: Can differences in prices and food attributes explain international differences in food purchases across countries?
answer: Differences in prices and characteristics can explain some differences (such as the US-France difference in caloric intake) but generally cannot explain many compositional patterns by themselves. An interaction between the economic environment and differences in preferences is needed to explain cross-country differences.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on international food consumption patterns by using detailed household-level data from three countries (US, France, and UK) to estimate a demand system and conduct counterfactual simulations, moving beyond simple documentation of differences to quantify the relative importance of prices, attributes, and preferences in explaining cross-country variation.

author: Rachel Griffith
title: Competition and Innovation: An Inverted-U Relationship*

author: Rachel Ngai
title: Hot and Cold Seasons in the Housing Market
abstract: <jats:p>Every year housing markets in the United Kingdom and the United States experience systematic above-trend increases in prices and transactions during the spring and summer (“hot season”) and below-trend falls during the autumn and winter (“cold season”). House price seasonality poses a challenge to existing housing models. We propose a search-and-matching model with thick-market effects. In thick markets, the quality of matches increases, rising buyers' willingness to pay and sellers' desire to transact. A small, deterministic driver of seasonality can be amplified and revealed as deterministic seasonality in transactions and prices, quantitatively mimicking seasonal fluctuations in UK and US markets. (JEL C78, R21, R31)</jats:p>
research_question: How can we explain the systematic seasonal patterns in housing markets where prices and transactions increase above-trend during spring/summer ('hot season') and fall below-trend during autumn/winter ('cold season')?
answer: A search-and-matching model with thick-market effects can explain housing market seasonality, where thick markets improve match quality, increasing buyers' willingness to pay and sellers' desire to transact, allowing small deterministic seasonal drivers to be amplified into the observed seasonal fluctuations in transactions and prices.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a challenge that existing housing models cannot adequately explain - house price seasonality - by proposing a novel search-and-matching framework with thick-market effects that can quantitatively replicate the seasonal patterns observed in UK and US housing markets.

author: Rachel Ngai
title: Structural Change in a Multisector Model of Growth

author: Rachel Griffith
title: How Special Is the Special Relationship? Using the Impact of U.S. R&D Spillovers on U.K. Firms as a Test of Technology Sourcing
abstract: <jats:p> We examine the “technology sourcing” hypothesis that foreign research labs located in the U.S. tap into U.S. R&D spillovers and improve home country productivity. We show that U.K. firms that established a high proportion of inventors based in the U.S. by 1990 benefited disproportionately from the growth of U.S. R&D stock over the next ten years. We estimate that U.S. R&D during the 1990s was associated with 5 percent higher Total Factor Productivity for U.K. manufacturing firms in 2000 (about $13 billion), with the majority of benefits accruing to firms with an innovative presence in the U.S. </jats:p>
research_question: Does the 'technology sourcing' hypothesis hold true - specifically, do foreign research labs located in the U.S. tap into U.S. R&D spillovers and improve home country productivity?
answer: Yes, U.K. firms with a high proportion of inventors based in the U.S. by 1990 benefited disproportionately from U.S. R&D growth, with U.S. R&D during the 1990s associated with 5% higher Total Factor Productivity for U.K. manufacturing firms in 2000 (approximately $13 billion in benefits), with most benefits going to firms with innovative presence in the U.S.
positioning_statement: This paper tests the 'technology sourcing' hypothesis by using the specific case of U.K. firms and U.S. R&D spillovers, providing empirical evidence for the theory that foreign firms can improve home country productivity by establishing research presence in technologically advanced countries.

author: Reed Walker
title: Environmental Regulation and Labor Reallocation: Evidence from the Clean Air Act
abstract: <jats:p> This paper uses newly available data on plant level regulatory status linked to the Census Longitudinal Business Database to measure the impact of changes in county level environmental regulations on plant and sector employment levels. Estimates from a variety of specifications suggest a strong connection between changes in environmental regulatory stringency and both employment growth and levels in the affected sectors. The preferred estimates suggest that changes in county level regulatory status due to the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments reduced the size of the regulated sector by as much as 15 percent in the 10 years following the changes. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of changes in county level environmental regulations on plant and sector employment levels?
answer: Changes in county level regulatory status due to the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments reduced the size of the regulated sector by as much as 15 percent in the 10 years following the changes, demonstrating a strong connection between environmental regulatory stringency and employment growth and levels in affected sectors.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using newly available data on plant level regulatory status linked to the Census Longitudinal Business Database to provide empirical evidence on the employment effects of environmental regulation, specifically examining the Clean Air Act's impact on labor reallocation.

author: Randi Hjalmarsson
title: Unequal Jury Representation and Its Consequences
abstract: <jats:p> We analyze the extent and consequences of unequal representation on juries in Harris County, Texas. We first document that residents from predominantly White and high-income neighborhoods are substantially overrepresented on juries. Using quasirandom variation in those called for jury duty each day, we next establish that Black defendants are more likely to be convicted and receive longer sentences from juries with more residents from these overrepresented neighborhoods. We estimate that equal representation would reduce Black defendants’ median sentence length by 50 percent and the probability of receiving a life sentence by 67  percent. Straightforward remedies could mitigate these legally unwarranted racial disparities. (JEL J15, K41) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the extent and consequences of unequal representation on juries in Harris County, Texas?
answer: Residents from predominantly White and high-income neighborhoods are substantially overrepresented on juries, and Black defendants are more likely to be convicted and receive longer sentences from juries with more residents from these overrepresented neighborhoods. Equal representation would reduce Black defendants' median sentence length by 50 percent and the probability of receiving a life sentence by 67 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence of unequal jury representation and its causal effects on racial disparities in criminal justice outcomes, using quasirandom variation in jury composition to establish causal relationships between jury demographics and sentencing outcomes for Black defendants.

author: Rachel Ngai
title: To Own or to Rent? The Effects of Transaction Taxes on Housing Markets
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Using sales and leasing data, this paper finds three novel effects of a higher property transaction tax: higher buy-to-rent transactions alongside lower buy-to-own transactions despite both being taxed, a lower sales-to-leases ratio, and a lower price-to-rent ratio. This paper explains these facts by developing a search model with entry of investors and households, households choosing to own or rent in the presence of credit frictions, and homeowners deciding when to move house. A higher transaction tax reduces homeowners’ mobility and increases demand for rental properties, which explains the empirical facts and leads to a lower homeownership rate. The deadweight loss is large at 111% of tax revenue, with more than half of this due to distorting decisions to own or rent.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of property transaction taxes on housing markets, particularly on the decisions to own versus rent and the resulting market dynamics?
answer: Higher property transaction taxes lead to three key effects: increased buy-to-rent transactions alongside decreased buy-to-own transactions, lower sales-to-leases ratios, and lower price-to-rent ratios. The mechanism works through reduced homeowner mobility and increased rental demand, ultimately lowering homeownership rates and creating large deadweight losses of 111% of tax revenue.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes novel empirical findings about transaction tax effects that previous literature has not documented, and develops a new search model that incorporates investor entry, household tenure choice with credit frictions, and homeowner mobility decisions to explain these previously unexplained market phenomena.

author: Reed Walker
title: The Transitional Costs of Sectoral Reallocation: Evidence From the Clean Air Act and the Workforce*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article uses linked worker-firm data in the United States to estimate the transitional costs associated with reallocating workers from newly regulated industries to other sectors of the economy in the context of new environmental regulations. The focus on workers rather than industries as the unit of analysis allows me to examine previously unobserved economic outcomes such as nonemployment and long-run earnings losses from job transitions, both of which are critical to understanding the reallocative costs associated with these policies. Using plant-level panel variation induced by the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments (CAAA), I find that the reallocative costs of environmental policy are significant. Workers in newly regulated plants experienced, in aggregate, more than $5.4 billion in forgone earnings for the years after the change in policy. Most of these costs are driven by nonemployment and lower earnings in future employment, highlighting the importance of longitudinal data for characterizing the costs and consequences of labor market adjustment. Relative to the estimated benefits of the 1990 CAAA, these one-time transitional costs are small.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the transitional costs associated with reallocating workers from newly regulated industries to other sectors of the economy in the context of new environmental regulations?
answer: The reallocative costs of environmental policy are significant, with workers in newly regulated plants experiencing more than $5.4 billion in forgone earnings after the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments, driven primarily by nonemployment and lower earnings in future employment. However, these one-time transitional costs are small relative to the estimated benefits of the policy.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by focusing on workers rather than industries as the unit of analysis, which allows examination of previously unobserved economic outcomes such as nonemployment and long-run earnings losses from job transitions that are critical to understanding reallocative costs of environmental policies.

author: Reed Walker
title: Is Air Pollution Regulation Too Lenient? Evidence from US Offset Markets
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a framework to estimate the marginal cost of air pollution regulation and apply it to assess policy efficiency. We exploit a provision of the Clean Air Act that requires new plants to pay incumbent facilities to reduce emissions. This “offset” policy creates hundreds of local pollution markets, differing by pollutant and location. Theory and transaction data suggest that offset prices reveal marginal abatement costs. We compare these prices to marginal benefits of pollution reduction estimated using leading air quality models and find that, on average, marginal benefits exceed marginal costs by more than a factor of ten. (JEL D61, H23, K32, Q52, Q53, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the marginal cost of air pollution regulation and is current air pollution regulation efficient?
answer: Air pollution regulation is too lenient - marginal benefits of pollution reduction exceed marginal costs by more than a factor of ten, indicating that current regulation is inefficient and should be stricter.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel framework to estimate marginal costs of air pollution regulation by exploiting the Clean Air Act's offset provision that creates local pollution markets, providing new empirical evidence on policy efficiency by comparing these market-revealed costs to marginal benefits from leading air quality models.

author: Reed Walker
title: Why Is Pollution from US Manufacturing Declining? The Roles of Environmental Regulation, Productivity, and Trade
abstract: <jats:p> Between 1990 and 2008, air pollution emissions from US manufacturing fell by 60 percent despite a substantial increase in manufacturing output. We show that these emissions reductions are primarily driven by within-product changes in emissions intensity rather than changes in output or in the composition of products produced. We then develop and estimate a quantitative model linking trade with the environment to better understand the economic forces driving these changes. Our estimates suggest that the implicit pollution tax that manufacturers face doubled between 1990 and 2008. These changes in environmental regulation, rather than changes in productivity and trade, account for most of the emissions reductions. (JEL F18, H23, L60, Q52, Q53, Q56, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: What factors explain the 60 percent decline in air pollution emissions from US manufacturing between 1990 and 2008 despite substantial increases in manufacturing output?
answer: The emissions reductions are primarily driven by within-product changes in emissions intensity due to environmental regulation - specifically, the implicit pollution tax that manufacturers face doubled between 1990 and 2008, and these regulatory changes account for most of the emissions reductions rather than changes in productivity and trade.
positioning_statement: This paper develops and estimates a quantitative model linking trade with the environment to decompose the relative contributions of environmental regulation, productivity changes, and trade effects on pollution reduction, providing empirical evidence on the mechanisms behind the environmental improvements in US manufacturing.

author: Reed Walker
title: Airports, Air Pollution, and Contemporaneous Health

author: Reed Walker
title: What Caused Racial Disparities in Particulate Exposure to Fall? New Evidence from the Clean Air Act and Satellite-Based Measures of Air Quality
abstract: <jats:p> This project links administrative census microdata to spatially continuous measures of particulate pollution (PM2.5) to first document and then decompose the key drivers of convergence in black-white pollution exposure differences. We use quantile regression to show that a significant portion of the convergence in Black-White exposure is attributable to differential impacts of the Clean Air Act (CAA) in Black and White communities. Areas with larger Black populations saw greater CAA-related declines in PM2.5. We show that the CAA can account for over 60 percent of the racial convergence in PM2.5 pollution exposure in the United States since 2000. (JEL J15, K32, Q51, Q53, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: What caused racial disparities in particulate matter (PM2.5) exposure to fall over time?
answer: The Clean Air Act (CAA) can account for over 60 percent of the racial convergence in PM2.5 pollution exposure since 2000, with areas having larger Black populations experiencing greater CAA-related declines in PM2.5.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new evidence by linking administrative census microdata to spatially continuous satellite-based measures of air quality to document and decompose the drivers of convergence in black-white pollution exposure differences, using quantile regression to show differential impacts of environmental policy across racial communities.

author: Rema Hanna
title: Environmental Regulations, Air and Water Pollution, and Infant Mortality in India
abstract: <jats:p> Using the most comprehensive developing country dataset ever compiled on air and water pollution and environmental regulations, the paper assesses India's environmental regulations with a difference-in-differences design. The air pollution regulations are associated with substantial improvements in air quality. The most successful air regulation resulted in a modest but statistically insignificant decline in infant mortality. In contrast, the water regulations had no measurable benefits. The available evidence leads us to cautiously conclude that higher demand for air quality prompted the effective enforcement of air pollution regulations, indicating that strong public support allows environmental regulations to succeed in weak institutional settings. (JEL I12, J13, O13, Q53, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: How effective are India's environmental regulations in improving air and water quality and reducing infant mortality?
answer: Air pollution regulations are associated with substantial improvements in air quality and modest but statistically insignificant decline in infant mortality, while water regulations had no measurable benefits. Strong public support appears to enable effective enforcement of environmental regulations even in weak institutional settings.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using the most comprehensive developing country dataset ever compiled on air and water pollution and environmental regulations to assess environmental policy effectiveness in a weak institutional setting.

author: Reed Walker
title: Every Breath You Take—Every Dollar You’ll Make: The Long-Term Consequences of the Clean Air Act of 1970

author: Reed Walker
title: Environmental Health Risks and Housing Values: Evidence from 1,600 Toxic Plant Openings and Closings
abstract: <jats:p> Regulatory oversight of toxic emissions from industrial plants and understanding about these emissions' impacts are in their infancy. Applying a research design based on the openings and closings of 1,600 industrial plants to rich data on housing markets and infant health, we find that: toxic air emissions affect air quality only within 1 mile of the plant; plant openings lead to 11 percent declines in housing values within 0.5 mile or a loss of about $4.25 million for these households; and a plant's operation is associated with a roughly 3 percent increase in the probability of low birthweight within 1 mile. (JEL I12, L60, Q52, Q53, Q58, R23, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the impacts of toxic air emissions from industrial plants on housing values and infant health outcomes?
answer: Toxic air emissions from industrial plants cause significant localized effects: air quality impacts within 1 mile, 11% decline in housing values within 0.5 mile (approximately $4.25 million loss for affected households), and roughly 3% increase in probability of low birthweight within 1 mile of plant operations.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in understanding the impacts of toxic emissions from industrial plants, noting that regulatory oversight and knowledge about these emissions' effects are still in their early stages, and contributes by using a novel research design based on 1,600 plant openings and closings with comprehensive housing and health data.

author: Reed Walker
title: Is the Social Safety Net a Long-Term Investment? Large-Scale Evidence From the Food Stamps Program
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use novel, large-scale data on 17.5 million Americans to study how a policy-driven increase in economic resources affects children's long-term outcomes. Using the 2000 Census and 2001–13 American Community Survey linked to the Social Security Administration's NUMIDENT, we leverage the county-level rollout of the Food Stamps program between 1961 and 1975. We find that children with access to greater economic resources before age five have better outcomes as adults. The treatment-on-the-treated effects show a 6% of a standard deviation improvement in human capital, 3% of a standard deviation increase in economic self-sufficiency, 8% of a standard deviation increase in the quality of neighbourhood of residence, a 1.2-year increase in life expectancy, and a 0.5 percentage-point decrease in likelihood of being incarcerated. These estimates suggest that Food Stamps’ transfer of resources to families is a highly cost-effective investment in young children, yielding a marginal value of public funds of approximately sixty-two.</jats:p>
research_question: How does a policy-driven increase in economic resources through the Food Stamps program affect children's long-term outcomes?
answer: Children with access to greater economic resources before age five through Food Stamps have significantly better adult outcomes, including 6% improvement in human capital, 3% increase in economic self-sufficiency, 8% improvement in neighborhood quality, 1.2-year increase in life expectancy, and 0.5 percentage-point decrease in incarceration likelihood, yielding a marginal value of public funds of approximately sixty-two.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing large-scale evidence (17.5 million Americans) using novel linked administrative data to examine the long-term effects of early childhood economic resource transfers, positioning the social safety net as a cost-effective investment rather than just a welfare expenditure.

author: Rema Hanna
title: Moving up the Energy Ladder: The Effect of an Increase in Economic Well-Being on the Fuel Consumption Choices of the Poor in India
abstract: <jats:p> Rising household wealth may potentially impact both total fuel consumption and fuel-type composition, resulting in significant health and environmental implications. Using data from a field experiment in India, we explore the effects of a transfer program that provided poor, rural households with greater levels of assets and cash. Total fuel consumption rose as a result of the transfers. Households shifted from using electricity rather than kerosene as their primary form of light, but total kerosene consumption also rose. In contrast, we did not observe a shift to cleaner cooking fuels. </jats:p>
research_question: How does an increase in economic well-being affect the fuel consumption choices and energy ladder progression of poor households in India?
answer: Increased economic well-being led to higher total fuel consumption and a shift from kerosene to electricity for lighting, but total kerosene consumption still rose and there was no shift to cleaner cooking fuels, indicating incomplete energy ladder progression.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the energy ladder literature by using experimental data from a field experiment in India to examine how asset and cash transfers affect both total fuel consumption and fuel-type composition among poor rural households, providing empirical evidence on the health and environmental implications of rising household wealth.

author: Rema Hanna
title: The Marginal Disutility from Corruption in Social Programs: Evidence from Program Administrators and Beneficiaries
abstract: <jats:p> Concerns about fraud in welfare programs are common arguments worldwide against such programs. We conducted a survey experiment with over 28,000 welfare program administrators and over 19,000 beneficiaries in Indonesia to elicit the “marginal disutility from corruption”—the trade-off between more generous social assistance and losses due to corruption. Merely mentioning corruption reduced perceived program success, equivalent to distributing more than 26 percentage points less aid. However, respondents were not sensitive to the amount of corruption—respondents were willing to trade off $2 of additional losses for an additional $1 distributed to beneficiaries. Program administrators and beneficiaries had similar assessments. (JEL D73, H53, I32, I38, O15, O17) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the marginal disutility from corruption in social programs - specifically, what trade-offs do program administrators and beneficiaries make between more generous social assistance and losses due to corruption?
answer: Merely mentioning corruption significantly reduces perceived program success (equivalent to distributing 26+ percentage points less aid), but respondents are not sensitive to the amount of corruption and are willing to accept $2 of additional corruption losses for every additional $1 distributed to beneficiaries. Program administrators and beneficiaries have similar assessments.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses common worldwide concerns about fraud in welfare programs by providing empirical evidence on how stakeholders actually value the trade-off between program generosity and corruption losses, filling a gap in understanding the marginal disutility from corruption in social assistance programs.

author: Rema Hanna
title: Incentives Work: Getting Teachers to Come to School
abstract: <jats:p> We use a randomized experiment and a structural model to test whether monitoring and financial incentives can reduce teacher absence and increase learning in India. In treatment schools, teachers' attendance was monitored daily using cameras, and their salaries were made a nonlinear function of attendance. Teacher absenteeism in the treatment group fell by 21 percentage points relative to the control group, and the children's test scores increased by 0.17 standard deviations. We estimate a structural dynamic labor supply model and find that teachers respond strongly to financial incentives. Our model is used to compute cost-minimizing compensation policies. (JEL I21, J31, J45, O15) </jats:p>
research_question: Can monitoring and financial incentives reduce teacher absence and increase learning outcomes?
answer: Yes, monitoring teachers' attendance with cameras and making salaries a nonlinear function of attendance reduced teacher absenteeism by 21 percentage points and increased children's test scores by 0.17 standard deviations, with teachers responding strongly to financial incentives.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using both a randomized experiment and a structural dynamic labor supply model to test the effectiveness of monitoring and financial incentives on teacher behavior, and extends the analysis to compute cost-minimizing compensation policies.

author: Rema Hanna
title:
Learning Through Noticing: Theory and Evidence from a Field Experiment
*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We consider a model of technological learning under which people “learn through noticing”: they choose which input dimensions to attend to and subsequently learn about from available data. Using this model, we show how people with a great deal of experience may persistently be off the production frontier because they fail to notice important features of the data they possess. We also develop predictions on when these learning failures are likely to occur, as well as on the types of interventions that can help people learn. We test the model’s predictions in a field experiment with seaweed farmers. The survey data reveal that these farmers do not attend to pod size, a particular input dimension. Experimental trials suggest that farmers are particularly far from optimizing this dimension. Furthermore, consistent with the model, we find that simply having access to the experimental data does not induce learning. Instead, behavioral changes occur only after the farmers are presented with summaries that highlight previously unattended-to relationships in the data.</jats:p>
research_question: How do people learn about technology and production processes, particularly why experienced individuals may persistently operate below the production frontier despite having access to data?
answer: People 'learn through noticing' - they selectively choose which input dimensions to attend to and only learn from data about those dimensions. Experienced people can persistently underperform because they fail to notice important features in available data. Simply providing access to data is insufficient for learning; interventions must highlight previously unattended relationships through summaries or other attention-directing mechanisms.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a new model of technological learning that explains persistent suboptimal performance among experienced individuals, contrasting with existing literature that assumes people learn from all available data by proposing that learning is constrained by selective attention to input dimensions.

author: Rema Hanna
title: Tax Administration versus Tax Rates: Evidence from Corporate Taxation in Indonesia
abstract: <jats:p> We compare two approaches to increasing tax revenue: tax administration and tax rates. We show that when Indonesia moved top regional firms into “medium taxpayer offices,” with high staff-to-taxpayer ratios, tax revenue more than doubled. Examining nonlinear changes to corporate income tax rates, we estimate an elasticity of taxable income of 0.579. Combining these estimates, improved tax administration is equivalent to raising top rates on all firms by 8 percentage points. On net, improved tax administration can have significant returns for developing countries. (JEL H25, H26, K34, O17) </jats:p>
research_question: How do two approaches to increasing tax revenue - improving tax administration versus raising tax rates - compare in their effectiveness?
answer: Improved tax administration is significantly more effective than raising tax rates, with moving top regional firms to medium taxpayer offices (with high staff-to-taxpayer ratios) more than doubling tax revenue - equivalent to raising top rates on all firms by 8 percentage points.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical evidence comparing the relative effectiveness of tax administration improvements versus tax rate changes in a developing country context, specifically demonstrating that improved tax administration can have significant returns for developing countries.

author: Rema Hanna
title: Private Outsourcing and Competition: Subsidized Food Distribution in Indonesia

author: Rema Hanna
title: Electronic Food Vouchers: Evidence from an At-Scale Experiment in Indonesia
abstract: <jats:p>We compare how in-kind food assistance and an electronic voucher-based program affect the delivery of aid in practice. The Government of Indonesia randomized across 105 districts the transition from in-kind rice to approximately equivalent electronic vouchers redeemable for rice and eggs at a network of private agents. Targeted households received 46 percent more assistance in voucher areas. For the bottom 15 percent of households at baseline, poverty fell 20 percent. Voucher recipients received higher-quality rice, and increased consumption of eggs. The results suggest moving from a manual in-kind to electronic voucher-based program reduced poverty through increased adherence to program design. (JEL H53, I18, I32, I38, O12)</jats:p>
research_question: How does transitioning from in-kind food assistance to an electronic voucher-based program affect the delivery of aid and outcomes for targeted households?
answer: Electronic vouchers significantly improved aid delivery effectiveness - targeted households received 46 percent more assistance, poverty fell 20 percent for the bottom 15 percent of households, recipients received higher-quality rice and increased egg consumption, with improvements driven by increased adherence to program design.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes empirical evidence from a large-scale randomized experiment comparing in-kind versus electronic voucher food assistance programs, addressing the practical implementation and effectiveness of different aid delivery mechanisms in a developing country context.

author: Rema Hanna
title: Tangible Information and Citizen Empowerment: Identification Cards and Food Subsidy Programs in Indonesia

author: Rema Hanna
title: The Challenges of Universal Health Insurance in Developing Countries: Experimental Evidence from Indonesia’s National Health Insurance
abstract: <jats:p>To investigate barriers to universal health insurance in developing countries, we designed a randomized experiment involving about 6,000 households in Indonesia who are subject to a government health insurance program with a weakly enforced mandate. Time-limited subsidies increased enrollment and attracted lower-cost enrollees, in part by reducing the strategic timing of enrollment to correspond with health needs. Registration assistance also increased enrollment, but increased attempted enrollment much more, as over one-half of households who attempted to enroll did not successfully do so. These findings underscore how weak administrative capacity can create important challenges in developing countries for achieving widespread coverage. (JEL D82, G22, H51, I13, I18, O15)</jats:p>
research_question: What are the barriers to universal health insurance in developing countries?
answer: Weak administrative capacity creates important challenges for achieving widespread coverage, as evidenced by time-limited subsidies reducing strategic enrollment timing and attracting lower-cost enrollees, while registration assistance increased enrollment attempts but over half of households failed to successfully complete enrollment.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on universal health insurance in developing countries by providing experimental evidence from Indonesia's National Health Insurance program, specifically investigating implementation barriers through a randomized experiment with 6,000 households subject to a weakly enforced mandate.

author: Rema Hanna
title: Network Structure and the Aggregation of Information: Theory and Evidence from Indonesia
abstract: <jats:p> We use unique data from over 600 Indonesian communities on what individuals know about the poverty status of others to study how network structure influences information aggregation. We develop a model of semi-Bayesian learning on networks, which we structurally estimate using within-village data. The model generates qualitative predictions about how cross-village patterns of learning relate to network structure, which we show are borne out in the data. We apply our findings to a community-based targeting program, where citizens chose households to receive aid, and show that the networks that the model predicts to be more diffusive differentially benefit from community targeting. (JEL D14, D83, D85, I32, O12, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does network structure influence information aggregation, specifically regarding individuals' knowledge about the poverty status of others in their communities?
answer: Network structure significantly affects information aggregation through semi-Bayesian learning processes, with networks predicted to be more diffusive showing better performance in community-based targeting programs where citizens choose aid recipients.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing and structurally estimating a model of semi-Bayesian learning on networks using unique community-level data, providing both theoretical predictions and empirical validation of how network structure affects information diffusion in real-world policy applications.

author: Rema Hanna
title: Targeting the Poor: Evidence from a Field Experiment in Indonesia
abstract: <jats:p> This paper reports an experiment in 640 Indonesian villages on three approaches to target the poor: proxy means tests (PMT), where assets are used to predict consumption; community targeting, where villagers rank everyone from richest to poorest; and a hybrid. Defining poverty based on PPP$2 per capita consumption, community targeting and the hybrid perform somewhat worse in identifying the poor than PMT, though not by enough to significantly affect poverty outcomes for a typical program. Elite capture does not explain these results. Instead, communities appear to apply a different concept of poverty. Consistent with this finding, community targeting results in higher satisfaction. (JEL C93, I32, I38, O12, O15, O18, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: Which approach is most effective at targeting the poor: proxy means tests (using assets to predict consumption), community targeting (where villagers rank everyone from richest to poorest), or a hybrid of both methods?
answer: Community targeting and the hybrid approach perform somewhat worse than proxy means tests in identifying the poor based on PPP$2 per capita consumption, but the difference is not large enough to significantly affect poverty outcomes for typical programs. However, community targeting results in higher satisfaction because communities apply a different concept of poverty than the standard consumption-based measure.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on poverty targeting methods by providing experimental evidence comparing three different approaches, challenging the assumption that proxy means tests are necessarily superior and showing that community-based methods may capture different but valid conceptions of poverty that lead to higher program satisfaction.

author: Ricardo Perez-Truglia
title: The Effects of Income Transparency on Well-Being: Evidence from a Natural Experiment
abstract: <jats:p> In 2001, Norwegian tax records became easily accessible online, allowing everyone in the country to observe the incomes of everyone else. According to the income comparisons model, this change in transparency can widen the gap in well-being between richer and poorer individuals. Using survey data from 1985–2013 and multiple identification strategies, we show that the higher transparency increased the gap in happiness between richer and poorer individuals by 29 percent, and it increased the life satisfaction gap by 21 percent. We provide back-of-the-envelope estimates of the importance of income comparisons, and discuss implications for the ongoing debate on transparency policies. (JEL D31, H24, I31, K34) </jats:p>
research_question: How does income transparency affect well-being, specifically the gap in well-being between richer and poorer individuals?
answer: Higher income transparency increased the gap in happiness between richer and poorer individuals by 29 percent and increased the life satisfaction gap by 21 percent, supporting the income comparisons model.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the income comparisons model literature by providing empirical evidence from a natural experiment, and informs the ongoing policy debate on transparency policies by quantifying the well-being effects of income transparency.

title: How Much Does Your Boss Make? The Effects of Salary Comparisons

author: Ricardo Perez-Truglia
title: The Old Boys’ Club: Schmoozing and the Gender Gap
abstract: <jats:p> Offices are social places. Employees and managers take breaks together and talk about family and hobbies. In this study, we show that employees’ social interactions with their managers can be advantageous for their careers, and that this phenomenon contributes to the gender pay gap. We use administrative and survey data from a large financial institution and exploit quasi-random variation induced by the rotation of managers. We provide evidence that when employees have more face-to-face interactions with their managers, they are promoted at a higher rate. This mechanism could explain a third of the gender gap in promotions at this firm. (JEL G21, J16, J31, J71, M12, M51, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How do employees' social interactions with their managers affect their career advancement, and does this phenomenon contribute to the gender pay gap?
answer: Employees who have more face-to-face interactions with their managers are promoted at higher rates, and this mechanism explains approximately one-third of the gender gap in promotions at the studied financial institution.
positioning_statement: This study contributes to understanding the gender pay gap by identifying a previously underexplored mechanism - informal social interactions between employees and managers in workplace settings - that affects career advancement and perpetuates gender disparities.

author: Ricardo Perez-Truglia
title: What’s My Employee Worth? The Effects of Salary Benchmarking
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Firms are allowed to use aggregate data on market salaries to set pay, a practice known as salary benchmarking. Using national payroll data, we study firms that gain access to a tool that reveals market benchmarks for each job title. Using a difference-in-differences design, we find that the benchmark information reduces salary dispersion by 25%. Thus, salary dispersion must stem partly from aggregate uncertainty about the salaries offered by other firms. Our model formalizes how salary dispersion can arise even in competitive labour markets for identical workers when such uncertainty exists, and we discuss implications for an ongoing policy debate.</jats:p>
research_question: How does access to salary benchmarking information affect salary dispersion within firms?
answer: Access to salary benchmarking tools reduces salary dispersion by 25%, indicating that salary dispersion partly stems from aggregate uncertainty about market salaries offered by other firms.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding salary dispersion by demonstrating that it can arise even in competitive labor markets for identical workers when there is uncertainty about market wages, using empirical evidence from firms gaining access to benchmarking tools and connecting findings to ongoing policy debates.

author: Ricardo Perez-Truglia
title: Conveniently Upset: Avoiding Altruism by Distorting Beliefs about Others' Altruism
abstract: <jats:p> We present results from a “corruption game” (a dictator game modified so that recipients can take a side payment in exchange for accepting a reduction in the overall size of the pie). Dictators (silently) treated to be able to take more of the recipient's tokens, took more of them. They were also more likely to believe that recipients had accepted side payments, even if there was a prize for accuracy. The results favor the hypothesis that people avoid altruistic actions by distorting beliefs about others' altruism. (JEL C72, D63, D64, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: Do people avoid altruistic actions by distorting their beliefs about others' altruism?
answer: Yes, people do avoid altruistic actions by distorting beliefs about others' altruism. When dictators were able to take more tokens from recipients, they took more and were also more likely to believe that recipients had accepted side payments (even when there was a prize for accuracy), suggesting they distorted their beliefs to justify their less altruistic behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on motivated reasoning and altruistic behavior by providing experimental evidence that individuals strategically distort their beliefs about others' altruism to justify their own self-interested actions, using a novel 'corruption game' variant of the standard dictator game.

author: Robert J. Barro
title: Rare Disasters, Asset Prices, and Welfare Costs
abstract: <jats:p>A representative-consumer model with Epstein-Zin-Weil preferences and i.i.d. shocks, including rare disasters, accords with observed equity premia and risk-free rates if the coefficient of relative risk aversion equals 3–4. If the intertemporal elasticity of substitution exceeds one, an increase in uncertainty lowers the price-dividend ratio for equity, and a rise in the expected growth rate raises this ratio. Calibrations indicate that society would willingly reduce GDP by around 20 percent each year to eliminate rare disasters. The welfare cost from usual economic fluctuations is much smaller, though still important, corresponding to lowering GDP by about 1.5 percent each year. (JEL E13, E21, E22, E32)</jats:p>
research_question: How do rare disasters affect asset prices (equity premia and risk-free rates) and what are the welfare costs of rare disasters compared to usual economic fluctuations?
answer: A model with Epstein-Zin-Weil preferences can match observed equity premia and risk-free rates with reasonable risk aversion (3-4). Society would willingly reduce GDP by around 20% annually to eliminate rare disasters, while the welfare cost of usual economic fluctuations corresponds to only about 1.5% of GDP annually.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on asset pricing puzzles by showing that a representative-consumer model with Epstein-Zin-Weil preferences and rare disasters can reconcile theoretical predictions with observed equity premia and risk-free rates, while also quantifying the substantial welfare costs of rare disasters relative to normal business cycle fluctuations.
