author: Ryota Iijima
title: Welfare Comparisons for Biased Learning
abstract: <jats:p> We study robust welfare comparisons of learning biases (misspecified Bayesian and some forms of non-Bayesian updating). Given a true signal distribution, we deem one bias more harmful than another if it yields lower objective expected payoffs in all decision problems. We characterize this ranking in static and dynamic settings. While the static characterization compares posteriors signal by signal, the dynamic characterization employs an “efficiency index” measuring how fast beliefs converge. We quantify and compare the severity of several well-documented biases. We also highlight disagreements between the static and dynamic rankings, and that some “large” biases dynamically outperform other “vanishingly small” biases. (JEL D60, D82, D83, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we robustly compare the welfare effects of different learning biases (misspecified Bayesian and non-Bayesian updating) to determine which biases are more harmful than others?
answer: The paper develops characterizations for ranking learning biases in both static and dynamic settings - static comparisons examine posteriors signal by signal, while dynamic comparisons use an 'efficiency index' measuring belief convergence speed. The study finds disagreements between static and dynamic rankings, with some 'large' biases dynamically outperforming 'vanishingly small' biases.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on learning biases by providing a novel framework for robust welfare comparisons across different types of biased updating (both misspecified Bayesian and non-Bayesian), extending beyond existing work by offering both static and dynamic characterizations and quantifying the relative severity of well-documented biases.

author: Ryota Iijima
title: Misinterpreting Others and the Fragility of Social Learning
abstract: <jats:p>We exhibit a natural environment, social learning among heterogeneous agents, where even slight misperceptions can have a large negative impact on long‐run learning outcomes. We consider a population of agents who obtain information about the state of the world both from initial private signals and by observing a random sample of other agents' actions over time, where agents' actions depend not only on their beliefs about the state but also on their idiosyncratic types (e.g., tastes or risk attitudes). When agents are correct about the type distribution in the population, they learn the true state in the long run. By contrast, we show, first, that even arbitrarily small amounts of misperception about the type distribution can generate extreme breakdowns of information aggregation, where in the long run all agents incorrectly assign probability 1 to some fixed state of the world,<jats:italic>regardless</jats:italic>of the true underlying state. Second, any misperception of the type distribution leads long‐run beliefs and behavior to vary only coarsely with the state, and we provide systematic predictions for how the nature of misperception shapes these coarse long‐run outcomes. Third, we show that how fragile information aggregation is against misperception depends on the richness of agents' payoff‐relevant uncertainty; a design implication is that information aggregation can be improved by simplifying agents' learning environment. The key feature behind our findings is that agents' belief‐updating becomes “decoupled” from the true state over time. We point to other environments where this feature is present and leads to similar fragility results.</jats:p>
research_question: How do misperceptions about the distribution of agent types affect social learning and information aggregation in environments where agents learn from observing others' actions?
answer: Even arbitrarily small amounts of misperception about the type distribution can generate extreme breakdowns of information aggregation, causing all agents to incorrectly assign probability 1 to some fixed state regardless of the true underlying state, and making long-run beliefs vary only coarsely with the actual state.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a new source of fragility in social learning by focusing on misperceptions about agent heterogeneity (type distributions) rather than the standard assumptions of perfect knowledge about population characteristics, and extends fragility results to other environments where belief-updating becomes 'decoupled' from the true state over time.

author: Ryota Iijima
title: Dynamic Random Utility
abstract: <jats:p>We provide an axiomatic analysis of dynamic random utility, characterizing the stochastic choice behavior of agents who solve dynamic decision problems by maximizing some stochastic process (<jats:italic>U</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>) of utilities. We show first that even when (<jats:italic>U</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>) is arbitrary, dynamic random utility imposes new testable<jats:italic>across‐period</jats:italic>restrictions on behavior, over and above period‐by‐period analogs of the static random utility axioms. An important feature of dynamic random utility is that behavior may appear<jats:italic>history‐dependent</jats:italic>, because period‐<jats:italic>t</jats:italic>choices reveal information about<jats:italic>U</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>, which may be serially correlated; however, our key new axioms highlight that the model entails specific limits on the form of history dependence that can arise. Second, we show that imposing natural Bayesian rationality axioms restricts the form of randomness that (<jats:italic>U</jats:italic><jats:sub><jats:italic>t</jats:italic></jats:sub>) can display. By contrast, a specification of utility shocks that is widely used in empirical work violates these restrictions, leading to behavior that may display a negative option value and can produce biased parameter estimates. Finally, dynamic stochastic choice data allow us to characterize important special cases of random utility—in particular, learning and taste persistence—that on static domains are indistinguishable from the general model.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the testable restrictions and behavioral implications of dynamic random utility models where agents maximize stochastic utility processes over time?
answer: Dynamic random utility imposes new testable across-period restrictions beyond static axioms, creates specific limits on history-dependent behavior, and requires Bayesian rationality constraints that rule out widely-used empirical specifications that can lead to negative option values and biased estimates.
positioning_statement: This paper extends static random utility theory to dynamic settings by providing the first axiomatic characterization of dynamic random utility, identifying new behavioral restrictions not captured by existing static models, and showing that commonly used empirical specifications violate fundamental rationality requirements.

author: Ryota Iijima
title: Learning Efficiency of Multiagent Information Structures

author: Ryota Iijima
title: Belief Convergence under Misspecified Learning: A Martingale Approach
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We present an approach to analyse learning outcomes in a broad class of misspecified environments, spanning both single-agent and social learning. We introduce a novel “prediction accuracy” order over subjective models and observe that this makes it possible to partially restore standard martingale convergence arguments that apply under correctly specified learning. Based on this, we derive general conditions to determine when beliefs in a given environment converge to some long-run belief either locally or globally (i.e. from some or all initial beliefs). We show that these conditions can be applied, first, to unify and generalize various convergence results in previously studied settings. Second, they enable us to analyse environments where learning is “slow”, such as costly information acquisition and sequential social learning. In such environments, we illustrate that even if agents learn the truth when they are correctly specified, vanishingly small amounts of misspecification can generate extreme failures of learning.</jats:p>
research_question: Under what conditions do beliefs converge to long-run beliefs in misspecified learning environments, and how does misspecification affect learning outcomes in both single-agent and social learning contexts?
answer: The paper develops general conditions for belief convergence in misspecified environments using a novel 'prediction accuracy' order and martingale approach, finding that while beliefs can converge locally or globally under certain conditions, even vanishingly small amounts of misspecification can cause extreme learning failures in slow learning environments like costly information acquisition and sequential social learning.
positioning_statement: This paper unifies and generalizes various convergence results from previously studied settings by introducing a novel martingale approach that partially restores standard convergence arguments for misspecified learning, extending analysis to new environments like slow learning contexts that were not adequately addressed in existing literature.

author: Ryota Iijima
title: Dispersed Behavior and Perceptions in Assortative Societies
abstract: <jats:p> We formulate a model of social interactions and misinferences by agents who neglect assortativity in their society, mistakenly believing that they interact with a representative sample of the population. A key component of our approach is the interplay between this bias and agents’ strategic incentives. We highlight a mechanism through which assortativity neglect, combined with strategic complementarities in agents’ behavior, drives up action dispersion in society (e.g., socioeconomic disparities in education investment). We also suggest that the combination of assortativity neglect and strategic incentives may be relevant in understanding empirically documented misperceptions of income inequality and political attitude polarization. (JEL C78, D11, D31, D72, D82, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: How does assortativity neglect (agents mistakenly believing they interact with a representative sample rather than recognizing they interact with similar others) combined with strategic incentives affect behavior dispersion and perceptions in society?
answer: Assortativity neglect combined with strategic complementarities drives up action dispersion in society (such as socioeconomic disparities in education investment) and may explain empirically documented misperceptions of income inequality and political attitude polarization.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on social interactions and behavioral biases by introducing a novel mechanism that combines assortativity neglect with strategic incentives, offering a new explanation for observed phenomena like income inequality misperceptions and political polarization that existing literature has documented but not fully explained through this particular theoretical framework.

author: Ryota Iijima
title: Stochastic Choice and Revealed Perturbed Utility
abstract: Perturbed utility functions—the sum of expected utility and a nonlinear perturbation function—provide a simple and tractable way to model various sorts of stochastic choice. We provide two easily understood conditions each of which characterizes this representation: One condition generalizes the acyclicity condition used in revealed preference theory, and the other generalizes Luce's IIA condition. We relate the discrimination or selectivity of choice rules to properties of their associated perturbations, both across different agents and across decision problems. We also show that these representations correspond to a form of ambiguity‐averse preferences for an agent who is uncertain about her true utility.

author: Ryota Iijima
title: Dual‐Self Representations of Ambiguity Preferences
abstract: <jats:p>We propose a class of multiple‐prior representations of preferences under ambiguity, where the belief the decision‐maker (DM) uses to evaluate an uncertain prospect is the outcome of a game played by two conflicting forces, Pessimism and Optimism. The model does not restrict the sign of the DM's ambiguity attitude, and we show that it provides a unified framework through which to characterize different degrees of ambiguity aversion, and to represent the co‐existence of negative and positive ambiguity attitudes within individuals as documented in experiments. We prove that our baseline representation,<jats:italic>dual‐self expected utility (DSEU)</jats:italic>, yields a novel representation of the class of invariant biseparable preferences (Ghirardato, Maccheroni, and Marinacci (2004)), which drops uncertainty aversion from maxmin expected utility (Gilboa and Schmeidler (1989)), while extensions of DSEU allow for more general departures from independence. We also provide foundations for a generalization of prior‐by‐prior belief updating to our model.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a unified framework to represent different degrees of ambiguity attitudes, including both negative and positive ambiguity preferences within individuals?
answer: The paper proposes dual-self expected utility (DSEU), a multiple-prior representation where beliefs are determined by a game between two conflicting forces (Pessimism and Optimism), which successfully characterizes varying degrees of ambiguity aversion and represents co-existing negative and positive ambiguity attitudes within individuals.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature by providing a novel representation of invariant biseparable preferences that drops the uncertainty aversion requirement from maxmin expected utility (Gilboa and Schmeidler 1989), while building upon Ghirardato, Maccheroni, and Marinacci (2004) to allow for more general departures from independence and unified treatment of ambiguity attitudes.

author: Ryota Iijima
title: Behavioural Characterizations of Naivete for Time-Inconsistent Preferences
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose non-parametric definitions of absolute and comparative naivete. These definitions leverage ex ante choice of menu to identify predictions of future behaviour and ex post (random) choices from menus to identify actual behaviour. The main advantage of our definitions is their independence from any assumed functional form for the utility function representing behaviour. An individual is sophisticated if she is indifferent ex ante between retaining the option to choose from a menu ex post or committing to her actual distribution of choices from that menu. She is naive if she prefers the flexibility in the menu, reflecting a mistaken belief that she will act more virtuously than she actually will. We propose two definitions of comparative naivete and explore the restrictions implied by our definitions for several prominent models of time inconsistency.</jats:p>
research_question: How can naivete in time-inconsistent preferences be characterized behaviorally without relying on specific functional forms for utility functions?
answer: The paper develops non-parametric definitions of absolute and comparative naivete by comparing ex ante menu choices (which reveal predictions of future behavior) with ex post actual choices from menus. An individual is sophisticated if indifferent between flexibility and commitment to their actual choice distribution, and naive if they prefer flexibility due to mistaken beliefs about acting more virtuously than they actually will.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the time-inconsistent preferences literature by providing behavioral characterizations of naivete that are independent of assumed functional forms for utility functions, offering a more general approach than existing parametric models of time inconsistency.

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Learning Self-Control *

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Hedging When Applying: Simultaneous Search with Correlation
abstract: <jats:p> Applicants to schools, colleges, and jobs hedge by applying to a broad range of options, including reaches, matches, and safeties. We develop a simultaneous-search framework that rationalizes this practice. In this framework, the admissions process is correlated across schools so that if an applicant is rejected by one school, she is more likely to be rejected by more selective schools. We find that an applicant then optimally targets both safeties and reaches. We characterize how the optimal portfolio varies with the applicant’s beliefs, risk attitudes, and application costs and offer an algorithm that delivers the optimal portfolio in polynomial time. (JEL D81, D83, D91, I23) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we rationalize the common practice of applicants hedging by applying to a broad range of options (reaches, matches, and safeties) when applying to schools, colleges, and jobs?
answer: When the admissions process is correlated across schools (rejection by one school increases likelihood of rejection by more selective schools), applicants optimally target both safeties and reaches as part of their application portfolio, with the optimal mix varying based on beliefs, risk attitudes, and application costs.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a simultaneous-search framework to provide theoretical justification for the widely observed but previously under-theorized practice of applicants diversifying their application portfolios across different selectivity levels.

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Ostracism and Forgiveness
abstract: <jats:p> Many communities rely upon ostracism to enforce cooperation: if an individual shirks in one relationship, her innocent neighbors share information about her guilt in order to shun her, while continuing to cooperate among themselves. However, a strategic victim may herself prefer to shirk, rather than report her victimization truthfully. If guilty players are to be permanently ostracized, then such deviations are so tempting that cooperation in any relationship is bounded by what the partners could obtain through bilateral enforcement. Ostracism can improve upon bilateral enforcement if tempered by forgiveness, through which guilty players are eventually readmitted to cooperative society. (JEL C73, D83, D85, O17, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How can communities effectively use ostracism to enforce cooperation, and what role does forgiveness play in making ostracism mechanisms work?
answer: Ostracism can only improve upon bilateral enforcement when it is tempered by forgiveness that allows guilty players to eventually be readmitted to cooperative society, as permanent ostracism creates incentives for victims to shirk rather than report truthfully.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the literature on community enforcement mechanisms by showing that while ostracism is widely relied upon to enforce cooperation through information sharing and shunning, existing models overlook the strategic incentives of victims to misreport, and demonstrates that forgiveness mechanisms are necessary to make ostracism superior to bilateral enforcement.

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: The Political Economy of Zero‐Sum Thinking
abstract: <jats:p>This paper offers a strategic rationale for zero‐sum thinking in elections. We show that asymmetric information and distributional considerations together make voters wary of policies supported by others. This force impels a majority of voters to support policies contrary to their preferences and information. Our analysis identifies and interprets a form of “adverse correlation” that is necessary and sufficient for zero‐sum thinking to prevail in equilibrium.</jats:p>
research_question: What provides a strategic rationale for zero-sum thinking in elections?
answer: Asymmetric information and distributional considerations together make voters wary of policies supported by others, leading a majority of voters to support policies contrary to their preferences and information when 'adverse correlation' conditions are met.
positioning_statement: This paper offers a new strategic rationale for zero-sum thinking in elections by identifying how asymmetric information and distributional considerations create conditions where voters oppose policies supported by others, contributing to the literature on electoral behavior and voter decision-making.

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Voluntary Disclosure and Personalized Pricing
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Firms have ever-increasing access to consumer data, which they use to personalize their advertising and to price discriminate. This raises privacy concerns. Policymakers have argued in response that consumers should be given control over their data, able to choose what to share and when. Since firms learn about a consumer’s preferences both from what they do and do not disclose, the equilibrium implications of consumer control are unclear. We study whether such measures improve consumer welfare in monopolistic and in competitive markets. We find that consumer control can improve consumer welfare relative to both perfect price discrimination and uniform pricing. First, consumers can use disclosure to amplify competitive forces. Second, consumers can disclose information to induce even a monopolist to lower prices. Whether consumer control improves welfare depends on the disclosure technology and market competitiveness. Simple disclosure technologies suffice in competitive markets. When facing a monopolist, a consumer needs partial disclosure possibilities to obtain any welfare gains.</jats:p>
research_question: Does giving consumers control over their data disclosure improve consumer welfare in markets where firms use consumer data for personalized pricing?
answer: Consumer control over data disclosure can improve consumer welfare relative to both perfect price discrimination and uniform pricing, but the welfare gains depend on the disclosure technology available and market competitiveness - simple disclosure technologies work in competitive markets, while partial disclosure possibilities are needed to obtain welfare gains when facing a monopolist.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the policy debate around consumer data privacy by studying the equilibrium implications of consumer control over data sharing, examining how strategic disclosure affects welfare in both monopolistic and competitive markets with personalized pricing.

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Sequential Veto Bargaining With Incomplete Information
abstract: <jats:p>We study sequential bargaining between a proposer and a veto player. Both have single‐peaked preferences, but the proposer is uncertain about the veto player's ideal point. The proposer cannot commit to future proposals. When players are patient, there can be equilibria with Coasian dynamics: the veto player's private information can largely nullify proposer's bargaining power. Our main result, however, is that under some conditions there also are equilibria in which the proposer obtains the high payoff that he would with commitment power. The driving force is that the veto player's single‐peaked preferences give the proposer an option to “leapfrog,” that is, to secure agreement from only low‐surplus types early on to credibly extract surplus from high types later. Methodologically, we exploit the connection between sequential bargaining and static mechanism design.</jats:p>
research_question: How does incomplete information about the veto player's preferences affect bargaining outcomes in sequential veto bargaining when the proposer cannot commit to future proposals?
answer: Under certain conditions, there exist equilibria where the proposer can obtain high payoffs equivalent to having commitment power by using a 'leapfrog' strategy - securing agreement from low-surplus types early to credibly extract surplus from high-surplus types later, despite the potential for Coasian dynamics that would otherwise nullify the proposer's bargaining power.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the sequential bargaining literature by showing that proposers can overcome the standard Coasian result (where private information eliminates bargaining power) in veto bargaining settings, and methodologically connects sequential bargaining models to static mechanism design.

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Predictability and Power in Legislative Bargaining

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: How to Sell Hard Information
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>The seller of an asset has the option to buy hard information about the value of the asset from an intermediary. The seller can then disclose this information before selling the asset in a competitive market. We study how the intermediary designs and sells hard information to robustly maximize the intermediary's revenue across all equilibria. Even though the intermediary could use an accurate test that reveals the asset’s value, we show that robust revenue maximization leads to a noisy test with a continuum of possible scores. In addition, the intermediary always charges the seller for disclosing the test score to the market, but not necessarily for running the test. This enables the intermediary to robustly appropriate a significant share of the surplus resulting from the asset sale.</jats:p>
research_question: How should an intermediary design and sell hard information about an asset's value to robustly maximize revenue across all equilibria when the seller can choose to disclose this information in a competitive market?
answer: Robust revenue maximization leads the intermediary to use a noisy test with a continuum of possible scores rather than an accurate test that reveals the asset's true value, and to charge the seller for disclosing the test score to the market rather than for running the test itself, enabling the intermediary to appropriate a significant share of the surplus from the asset sale.
positioning_statement: This paper studies the intermediary's problem of designing and selling hard information in a setting where the seller has disclosure options in competitive markets, focusing on robust revenue maximization across all equilibria rather than specific equilibrium outcomes.

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Adverse and Advantageous Selection in the Laboratory
abstract: <jats:p> We study two-player games where one-sided asymmetric information can lead to either adverse or advantageous selection. We contrast behavior in these games with settings where both players are uninformed. We find stark differences, suggesting that subjects do account for endogenous selection effects. Removing strategic uncertainty increases the fraction of subjects who account for selection. Subjects respond more to adverse than advantageous selection. Using additional treatments where we vary payoff feedback, we connect this difference to learning. We also observe a significant fraction of subjects who appear to understand selection effects but do not apply that knowledge. (JEL C92, D82, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: How do people behave in two-player games with one-sided asymmetric information that can lead to either adverse or advantageous selection, and do they account for endogenous selection effects?
answer: Subjects do account for endogenous selection effects, with stark behavioral differences compared to settings where both players are uninformed. However, subjects respond more strongly to adverse selection than advantageous selection, and a significant fraction understand selection effects but fail to apply that knowledge.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the experimental economics literature by providing laboratory evidence on how people actually behave in selection environments, contrasting behavior under asymmetric versus symmetric information conditions and examining the role of strategic uncertainty and learning through payoff feedback.

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Information Aggregation in Standing and Ad Hoc Committees

author: S. Nageeb Ali
title: Who Controls the Agenda Controls the Legislature
abstract: <jats:p> We model legislative decision-making with an agenda setter who can propose policies sequentially, tailoring each proposal to the status quo that prevails after prior votes. Voters are sophisticated, and the agenda setter cannot commit to future proposals. Nevertheless, the agenda setter obtains her favorite outcome in every equilibrium regardless of the initial default policy. Central to our results is a new condition on preferences, manipulability, that holds in rich policy spaces, including spatial settings and distribution problems. Our findings therefore establish that, despite the sophistication of voters and the absence of commitment power, the agenda setter is effectively a dictator. (JEL D71, D72, D78) </jats:p>
research_question: How much power does an agenda setter have in legislative decision-making when they can propose policies sequentially without commitment power and face sophisticated voters?
answer: The agenda setter obtains her favorite outcome in every equilibrium regardless of the initial default policy, making her effectively a dictator despite voters being sophisticated and the agenda setter having no commitment power.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing literature by showing that even without commitment power and facing sophisticated voters, agenda setters maintain dictatorial control, establishing this result through a new condition called 'manipulability' that applies broadly across rich policy spaces including spatial settings and distribution problems.

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Financing Innovation: Evidence from R&D Grants
abstract: <jats:p> Governments regularly subsidize new ventures to spur innovation. This paper conducts the first large-sample, quasi-experimental evaluation of R&D subsidies. I use data on ranked applicants to the US Department of Energy's SBIR grant program. An early-stage award approximately doubles the probability that a firm receives subsequent venture capital and has large, positive impacts on patenting and revenue. These effects are stronger for more financially constrained firms. Certification, where the award contains information about firm quality, likely does not explain the grant effect. Instead, the grants are useful because they fund technology prototyping.(JEL D22, G24, G32, L53, O31, O34, O38) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal effect of government R&D subsidies on innovation outcomes and firm performance?
answer: Early-stage R&D grants approximately double the probability of receiving subsequent venture capital and have large positive impacts on patenting and revenue, with effects being stronger for financially constrained firms and working primarily through funding technology prototyping rather than certification effects.
positioning_statement: This paper conducts the first large-sample, quasi-experimental evaluation of R&D subsidies, filling a gap in the literature by providing rigorous causal evidence on government innovation subsidies using ranked applicant data from the US Department of Energy's SBIR program.

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Opening Up Military Innovation: Causal Effects of Reforms to US Defense Research

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: Market-Wide Predictable Price Pressure
abstract: <jats:p> We demonstrate that predictable uninformed cash flows forecast aggregate market stock returns. Buying pressure from dividend payments (announced weeks prior) predicts higher value-weighted market returns, with returns for the top quintile of payment days four times higher than the lowest. This holds internationally and increases when reinvestment is high and market liquidity is low. We estimate a market-level price multiplier of 1.9. These results suggest price pressure is a widespread result of flows, not an anomaly. (JEL G12, G14, G35) </jats:p>
research_question: Do predictable uninformed cash flows forecast aggregate market stock returns, and what is the magnitude of this price pressure effect?
answer: Predictable uninformed cash flows, specifically dividend payments announced weeks prior, do forecast aggregate market returns with buying pressure from dividend payments predicting higher value-weighted market returns. The top quintile of payment days show returns four times higher than the lowest quintile, with an estimated market-level price multiplier of 1.9.
positioning_statement: This paper positions price pressure as a widespread result of flows rather than an anomaly, demonstrating that predictable price pressure effects exist at the market-wide level and are not limited to individual securities or specific market segments.

author: Sabrina T. Howell
title: Cutting the Innovation Engine: How Federal Funding Shocks Affect University Patenting, Entrepreneurship, and Publications
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article studies how federal funding affects the innovation outputs of university researchers. We link person-level research grants from 22 universities to patents, publications, and career outcomes from the U.S. Census Bureau. We focus on the effects of large, idiosyncratic, and temporary cuts to federal funding in a researcher’s preexisting narrow field of study. Using an event study design, we document that these negative federal funding shocks reduce high-tech entrepreneurship and publications but increase patenting. The lost publications tend to be higher quality and more basic, whereas the additional patents tend to be lower quality, less general, and more often privately assigned. These federal funding cuts lead to an increase in private funding, which partially compensates for the decline in federal funding. Together with evidence from industry-university contracts, the results suggest that federal funding cuts shift university research funding from federal to private sources and lead to innovation outputs that are less openly accessible and more often appropriated by corporate funders.</jats:p>
research_question: How does federal funding affect the innovation outputs of university researchers?
answer: Negative federal funding shocks reduce high-tech entrepreneurship and publications but increase patenting. The lost publications tend to be higher quality and more basic, while additional patents tend to be lower quality, less general, and more often privately assigned. Federal funding cuts lead to increased private funding that partially compensates, shifting university research toward innovation outputs that are less openly accessible and more often appropriated by corporate funders.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using person-level research grants linked to patents, publications, and career outcomes from the U.S. Census Bureau, focusing specifically on large, idiosyncratic, and temporary cuts to federal funding in researchers' preexisting narrow fields of study using an event study design.

author: Samual Hartzmark
title: Ownership, Learning, and Beliefs
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We examine how owning a good affects learning and beliefs about its quality. We show that people have more extreme reactions to information about a good they own compared with the same information about a nonowned good: ownership causes more optimistic beliefs after receiving a positive signal and more pessimistic beliefs after receiving a negative signal. Comparing learning to normative benchmarks reveals that people overextrapolate from signals about goods they own, which leads to an overreaction to information; in contrast, learning is close to Bayesian for nonowned goods. We provide direct evidence that this effect is driven by ownership channeling greater attention toward associated information, which leads people to overweight recent signals when forming beliefs. The relationship between ownership and beliefs has testable implications for trade and market expectations. In line with these predictions, we show that the endowment effect doubles in response to positive information and disappears with negative information, and demonstrate a significant relationship between ownership and overextrapolation in survey data about stock market expectations.</jats:p>
research_question: How does owning a good affect learning and beliefs about its quality?
answer: Ownership causes people to have more extreme reactions to information - leading to more optimistic beliefs after positive signals and more pessimistic beliefs after negative signals. This occurs because ownership channels greater attention toward associated information, causing people to overweight recent signals and overextrapolate from information about owned goods, while learning remains close to Bayesian for nonowned goods.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing direct evidence that ownership affects information processing and belief formation through an attention mechanism, with testable implications for trade and market expectations including effects on the endowment effect and stock market expectations.

author: Sascha O. Becker
title: Margins of Multinational Labor Substitution
abstract: <jats:p> Employment at a multinational enterprise (MNE) responds to wages at the extensive margin, when an MNE enters a foreign location, and at the intensive margin, when an MNE operates existing affiliates. We present an MNE model and conditions for parametric and nonparametric identification. Prior studies rarely found wages to affect MNE employment. Our integrated approach documents salient labor substitution for German manufacturing MNEs and removes bias. In Central and Eastern Europe, most employment responds at the extensive margin, while in Western Europe the extensive margin accounts for around two-thirds of employment shifts. At distant locations, MNEs respond to wages only at the extensive margin. (JEL F23, J23, J31, R32) </jats:p>
research_question: How does employment at multinational enterprises respond to wage changes at both the extensive margin (when entering foreign locations) and intensive margin (when operating existing affiliates)?
answer: Employment at multinational enterprises responds significantly to wages at both margins, with most employment response occurring at the extensive margin in Central and Eastern Europe, while the extensive margin accounts for around two-thirds of employment shifts in Western Europe. At distant locations, MNEs respond to wages only at the extensive margin.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in existing literature where prior studies rarely found wages to affect MNE employment by presenting an integrated approach that removes bias and documents salient labor substitution patterns that previous research failed to identify.

author: Sascha O. Becker
title: Forced Migration and Human Capital: Evidence from Post-WWII Population Transfers
abstract: <jats:p> We study the long-run effects of forced migration on investment in education. After World War II, millions of Poles were forcibly uprooted from the Kresy territories of eastern Poland and resettled (primarily) in the newly acquired Western Territories, from which the Germans were expelled. We combine historical censuses with newly collected survey data to show that, while there were no pre-WWII differences in educational attainment, Poles with a family history of forced migration are significantly more educated today than other Poles. These results are driven by a shift in preferences away from material possessions toward investment in human capital. (JEL I25, I26, J24, N34, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the long-run effects of forced migration on investment in education?
answer: Poles with a family history of forced migration are significantly more educated today than other Poles, driven by a shift in preferences away from material possessions toward investment in human capital.
positioning_statement: The paper uses the unique historical context of post-WWII Polish population transfers to study forced migration effects, combining historical censuses with newly collected survey data to examine long-term educational outcomes across generations.

author: Sascha O. Becker
title: Was Weber Wrong? A Human Capital Theory of Protestant Economic History<sup>*</sup>

author: Sascha O. Becker
title: Not the Opium of the People: Income and Secularization in a Panel of Prussian Counties
abstract: <jats:p> The interplay between religion and the economy has long occupied social scientists. We construct a unique panel of income and Protestant church attendance using 175 Prussian counties, presented in six waves from 1886 to 1911. The data reveal a marked decline in church attendance coinciding with increasing income. The cross-section also shows a negative association between income and church attendance. The associations disappear in panel analyses, including first-differenced models of the 1886 to 1911 change, panel models with county and time fixed effects, and panel Granger-causality tests. The results cast doubt on causal interpretations of the religion-economy nexus in Prussian secularization. </jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal relationship between income and secularization (measured by Protestant church attendance) in Prussia from 1886 to 1911?
answer: There is no causal relationship between income and secularization - while cross-sectional data shows a negative association between income and church attendance, this association disappears when using panel analysis methods that control for unobserved heterogeneity.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing interpretations of the religion-economy nexus by using rigorous panel data methods to show that previously observed correlations between income and secularization may not reflect causal relationships, contributing to the long-standing debate among social scientists about the interplay between religion and the economy.

author: Sevgi Yuksel
title: Media Competition and Social Disagreement
abstract: <jats:p>We study the competitive provision and endogenous acquisition of political information. Our main result identifies a natural equilibrium channel through which a more competitive market decreases the efficiency of policy outcomes. A critical insight we put forward is that competition among information providers leads to informational specialization: firms provide relatively less information on issues that are of common interest and relatively more information on issues on which agents' preferences are heterogeneous. This enables agents to acquire information about different aspects of the policy, specifically, those that are particularly important to them. This leads to an increase in social disagreement, which has negative welfare implications. We establish that, in large enough societies, competition makes every agent worse off by decreasing the utility that she derives from the policy outcome. Furthermore, we show that this decline cannot be compensated by the decrease in prices resulting from competition.</jats:p>
research_question: How does competition among information providers affect the efficiency of policy outcomes and social welfare?
answer: Competition among information providers leads to informational specialization where firms provide less information on common interest issues and more on heterogeneous preference issues, resulting in increased social disagreement and decreased welfare for all agents in large societies.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view that competition improves outcomes by identifying a natural equilibrium channel through which market competition actually decreases policy efficiency, contributing a novel perspective on the welfare effects of media competition in political information markets.

author: Semyon Malamud
title: Decentralized Exchange
abstract: <jats:p> Most assets are traded in multiple interconnected trading venues. This paper develops an equilibrium model of decentralized markets that accommodates general market structures with coexisting exchanges. Decentralized markets can allocate risk among traders with different risk preferences more efficiently, thus realizing gains from trade that cannot be reproduced in centralized markets. Market decentralization always increases price impact. Yet, markets in which assets are traded in multiple exchanges, whether they are disjoint or intermediated, can give higher welfare than the centralized market with the same traders and assets. In decentralized markets, demand substitutability across assets is endogenous and heterogeneous among traders. (JEL D43, D44, D85, G11, G12) </jats:p>
research_question: How do decentralized markets with multiple interconnected trading venues compare to centralized markets in terms of efficiency, welfare, and risk allocation?
answer: Decentralized markets can allocate risk among traders with different risk preferences more efficiently than centralized markets, potentially achieving higher welfare despite always increasing price impact, with demand substitutability across assets being endogenous and heterogeneous among traders.
positioning_statement: This paper develops an equilibrium model that accommodates general market structures with coexisting exchanges, addressing the reality that most assets are traded in multiple interconnected trading venues, which appears to fill a gap in existing literature on market structure analysis.

author: Sevgi Yuksel
title: Mental Models and Learning: The Case of Base-Rate Neglect
abstract: <jats:p> We experimentally document persistence of suboptimal behavior despite ample opportunities to learn from feedback in a canonical updating problem where people suffer from base-rate neglect. Our results provide insights on the mechanisms hindering learning from feedback. Importantly, our results suggest mistakes are more likely to be persistent when they are driven by incorrect mental models that miss or misrepresent important aspects of the environment. Such models induce confidence in initial answers, limiting engagement with and learning from feedback. We substantiate these insights in an alternative scenario where individuals involved in a voting problem overlook the importance of being pivotal. (JEL D83, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: Why does suboptimal behavior persist despite ample opportunities to learn from feedback in updating problems where people suffer from base-rate neglect?
answer: Mistakes are more likely to be persistent when they are driven by incorrect mental models that miss or misrepresent important aspects of the environment, as such models induce confidence in initial answers and limit engagement with and learning from feedback.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on learning from feedback by identifying the specific mechanisms that hinder learning, particularly focusing on how incorrect mental models create barriers to learning in canonical updating problems and voting scenarios.

author: Sascha O. Becker
title: Religion, Division of Labor, and Conflict: Anti-Semitism in Germany over 600 Years
abstract: <jats:p> We study the role of economic incentives in shaping the coexistence of Jews, Catholics, and Protestants, using novel data from Germany for 1,000+ cities. The Catholic usury ban and higher literacy rates gave Jews a specific advantage in the moneylending sector. Following the Protestant Reformation (1517), the Jews lost these advantages in regions that became Protestant. We show (i) a change in the geography of anti-Semitism with persecutions of Jews and anti-Jewish publications becoming more common in Protestant areas relative to Catholic areas; (ii) a more pronounced change in cities where Jews had already established themselves as moneylenders. These findings are consistent with the interpretation that, following the Protestant Reformation, Jews living in Protestant regions were exposed to competition with the Christian majority, especially in moneylending, leading to an increase in anti-Semitism. (JEL D74, J15, N33, N43, N93) </jats:p>
research_question: How did economic incentives and changes in the division of labor following the Protestant Reformation affect the coexistence of Jews, Catholics, and Protestants, particularly regarding anti-Semitism in Germany?
answer: Following the Protestant Reformation, Jews lost their economic advantages in moneylending in Protestant regions (due to removal of Catholic usury bans and Protestant literacy), leading to increased competition with Christians and consequently higher levels of anti-Semitism in Protestant areas compared to Catholic areas, especially in cities where Jews were already established as moneylenders.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical evidence for the role of economic competition in driving religious conflict and anti-Semitism, using novel historical data spanning 600 years across 1,000+ German cities to demonstrate how changes in economic comparative advantages following the Protestant Reformation altered patterns of religious coexistence.

author: Sevgi Yuksel
title: Seeing What is Representative
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We provide evidence for a bias that we call “representative signal distortion” (RSD), which is particularly relevant to settings of statistical discrimination. Experimental subjects distort their evaluation of new evidence on individual group members and interpret such information to be more representative of the group to which the individual belongs (relative to a reference group) than it really is. This produces a discriminatory gap in the evaluation of members of the two groups. Because it is driven by representativeness, the bias (and the discriminatory gap) disappears when subjects are prevented from contrasting different groups; because it is a bias in the interpretation of information, it disappears when subjects receive information before learning of the individual’s group. We show that this bias can be easily estimated from appropriately constructed data sets and can be distinguished from previously documented inferential biases in the literature. Importantly, we document how removing the bias produces a kind of free lunch in reducing discrimination, making it possible to significantly reduce discrimination without lowering accuracy of inferences.</jats:p>
research_question: Do people systematically distort their evaluation of new evidence about individual group members by interpreting information to be more representative of the group than it actually is, and does this create discriminatory gaps in evaluation?
answer: Yes, people exhibit 'representative signal distortion' (RSD) where they distort evaluation of new evidence to make it appear more representative of an individual's group relative to a reference group than it really is, creating discriminatory gaps that disappear when group contrasting is prevented or when information is received before group identity is revealed.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a new bias (representative signal distortion) that can be distinguished from previously documented inferential biases in the literature, and uniquely shows that removing this bias creates a 'free lunch' by significantly reducing discrimination without lowering inference accuracy, which differs from existing approaches to addressing statistical discrimination.

author: Shengxing Zhang
title: The Limits of ONETARY ECONOMICS: On Money as a Constraint on Market Power
abstract:
<jats:p>We formulate a generalization of the traditional medium‐of‐exchange function of money in contexts where there is imperfect competition in the intermediation of credit, settlement, or payment services used to conduct transactions. We find that the option to settle transactions with money strengthens the stance of sellers of goods and services in relation to intermediaries, and show this mechanism is operative even for sellers who never exercise the option to sell for money. These 
            <jats:italic>latent</jats:italic> money demand considerations imply that in general, in contrast to current conventional wisdom in policy‐oriented research in monetary economics, monetary policy can remain effective through medium‐of‐exchange transmission channels—even in highly developed credit economies where the share of monetary transactions is negligible.
          </jats:p>
research_question: How does money function as a medium of exchange in contexts with imperfect competition in credit, settlement, or payment services intermediation, and what are the implications for monetary policy effectiveness?
answer: The option to settle transactions with money strengthens sellers' bargaining position relative to intermediaries, and this mechanism operates even for sellers who never actually use money (latent money demand). This means monetary policy can remain effective through medium-of-exchange channels even in highly developed credit economies where actual monetary transactions are negligible.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the current conventional wisdom in policy-oriented monetary economics research by showing that monetary policy effectiveness persists through medium-of-exchange transmission channels even when the share of actual monetary transactions is negligible, contrasting with prevailing views about money's diminished role in developed credit economies.

author: Sevgi Yuksel
title: Beliefs in Repeated Games: An Experiment
abstract: <jats:p> This paper uses a laboratory experiment to study beliefs and their relationship to action and strategy choices in finitely and indefinitely repeated prisoners’ dilemma games. We find subjects’ elicited beliefs about the other player’s action are generally accurate despite some systematic deviations, and anticipate the evolution of behavior differently between the finite and indefinite games. We also use the elicited beliefs over actions to recover beliefs over supergame strategies played by the other player. We find these beliefs over strategies correctly capture the different classes of strategies played in each game, vary substantially across subjects, and rationalize their strategies. (JEL C72, C73, C92, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How do beliefs about other players' actions and strategies form and evolve in finitely and indefinitely repeated prisoners' dilemma games, and what is their relationship to players' own action and strategy choices?
answer: Subjects' elicited beliefs about other players' actions are generally accurate with some systematic deviations, and these beliefs anticipate behavioral evolution differently between finite and indefinite games. Recovered beliefs over supergame strategies correctly capture different strategy classes, vary substantially across subjects, and rationalize their own strategic choices.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on repeated games by using laboratory experiments to directly elicit and analyze beliefs about both actions and strategies, providing empirical evidence on belief formation and accuracy in strategic interactions that has been difficult to observe in previous theoretical and experimental work.

author: Sevgi Yuksel
title: Cooperation in the Finitely Repeated Prisoner’s Dilemma*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>More than half a century after the first experiment on the finitely repeated prisoner’s dilemma, evidence on whether cooperation decreases with experience—as suggested by backward induction—remains inconclusive. This article provides a meta-analysis of prior experimental research and reports the results of a new experiment to elucidate how cooperation varies with the environment in this canonical game. We describe forces that affect initial play (formation of cooperation) and unraveling (breakdown of cooperation). First, contrary to the backward induction prediction, the parameters of the repeated game have a significant effect on initial cooperation. We identify how these parameters impact the value of cooperation—as captured by the size of the basin of attraction of always defect—to account for an important part of this effect. Second, despite these initial differences, the evolution of behavior is consistent with the unraveling logic of backward induction for all parameter combinations. Importantly, despite the seemingly contradictory results across studies, this article establishes a systematic pattern of behavior: subjects converge to use threshold strategies that conditionally cooperate until a threshold round; conditional on establishing cooperation, the first defection round moves earlier with experience. Simulation results generated from a learning model estimated at the subject level provide insights into the long-term dynamics and the forces that slow down the unraveling of cooperation.</jats:p>
research_question: How does cooperation vary with experience and environmental parameters in the finitely repeated prisoner's dilemma, and does cooperation decrease with experience as predicted by backward induction?
answer: Cooperation follows a systematic pattern where subjects converge to threshold strategies that conditionally cooperate until a threshold round. While game parameters significantly affect initial cooperation levels (contrary to backward induction predictions), the evolution of behavior is consistent with backward induction's unraveling logic across all parameter combinations, with the first defection round moving earlier as subjects gain experience.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the inconclusive evidence from more than half a century of experimental research on the finitely repeated prisoner's dilemma by providing a comprehensive meta-analysis of prior studies and new experimental evidence to establish systematic behavioral patterns that reconcile seemingly contradictory results across existing studies.

author: Shengxing Zhang
title: Turnover Liquidity and the Transmission of Monetary Policy
abstract: <jats:p> We provide empirical evidence of a novel liquidity-based transmission mechanism through which monetary policy influences asset markets, develop a model of this mechanism, and assess the ability of the quantitative theory to match the evidence. (JEL E44, E52, G12, G14, G35) </jats:p>
research_question: How does monetary policy influence asset markets through a liquidity-based transmission mechanism involving turnover liquidity?
answer: The paper identifies and provides empirical evidence of a novel liquidity-based transmission mechanism through which monetary policy affects asset markets, and develops a quantitative model that can match this empirical evidence.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel liquidity-based transmission mechanism that has not been previously identified in the literature, positioning itself as providing new empirical evidence and theoretical understanding of how monetary policy transmits through asset markets via turnover liquidity effects.

author: Shengxing Zhang
title: Dynamic Asset-Backed Security Design
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Borrowers obtain liquidity by issuing securities backed by the current period payoff and resale price of a long-lived collateral asset, and they are privately informed about the payoff distribution. Asset price can be self-fulfilling: a higher asset price lowers adverse selection and allows borrowers to raise greater funding, which makes the asset more valuable, leading to multiple equilibria. Optimal security design eliminates multiple equilibria, improves welfare, and can be implemented as a repo contract. Persistent adverse selection lowers debt funding, generates volatility in asset prices, and exacerbates credit crunches. The theory demonstrates the role of asset-backed securities on stability of market-based financial systems.</jats:p>
research_question: How should asset-backed securities be designed when borrowers have private information about collateral asset payoffs, and what are the implications for financial market stability?
answer: Optimal security design eliminates multiple equilibria and improves welfare, and can be implemented as a repo contract. However, persistent adverse selection reduces debt funding, creates asset price volatility, and worsens credit crunches due to self-fulfilling asset price dynamics.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on asset-backed securities by demonstrating their role in the stability of market-based financial systems, specifically showing how security design affects equilibrium multiplicity and welfare in the presence of adverse selection and self-fulfilling asset prices.

author: Shengxing Zhang
title: The Role of Firm Factors in Demand, Cost, and Export Market Selection for Chinese Footwear Producers

author: Shing-Yi Wang
title: Improving Management Through Worker Evaluations: Evidence from Auto Manufacturing
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Using a randomized experiment with an automobile manufacturing firm in China, we measure the effects of letting workers evaluate their managers on worker and firm outcomes. In the treatment teams, workers evaluate their managers monthly. We find that providing feedback leads to significant reductions in worker turnover and increases in team-level productivity. In addition, workers report higher levels of happiness and well-being. The evidence suggests that these results are driven by learning by managers, leading to changes in their behavior and an overall better relationship between managers and workers.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the effects of letting workers evaluate their managers on worker and firm outcomes?
answer: Providing worker feedback on managers leads to significant reductions in worker turnover, increases in team-level productivity, and higher levels of worker happiness and well-being, driven by managers learning and changing their behavior to improve manager-worker relationships.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing experimental evidence on the causal effects of worker-to-manager feedback systems, using a randomized controlled trial in an automobile manufacturing setting to measure impacts on both worker outcomes and firm performance.

author: Shing-Yi Wang
title: State Misallocation and Housing Prices: Theory and Evidence from China
abstract: <jats:p> This paper examines the equilibrium price effects of the privatization of housing assets that were previously owned and allocated by the state. I develop a theoretical framework that shows that privatization can have ambiguous effects on prices in the private market, and that the degree of misallocation of the assets prior to privatization determines the subsequent price effects. I test the predictions of the model using a large-scale housing reform in China. The results suggest that the removal of price distortions allowed households to increase their consumption of housing and led to an increase in equilibrium housing prices. (JEL L33, O18, P25, R31, R38) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the equilibrium price effects of privatizing housing assets that were previously owned and allocated by the state?
answer: The removal of price distortions from housing privatization allowed households to increase their consumption of housing and led to an increase in equilibrium housing prices, with the degree of prior state misallocation determining the magnitude of subsequent price effects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a theoretical framework that shows privatization can have ambiguous effects on private market prices, with the key insight that the degree of pre-privatization misallocation determines post-privatization price effects, tested using China's large-scale housing reform as empirical evidence.

author: Shing-Yi Wang
title: Monopsony Power in Migrant Labor Markets: Evidence from the United Arab Emirates

author: Sonja Settele
title: Risk Exposure and Acquisition of Macroeconomic Information
abstract: <jats:p> We conduct an experiment with a representative sample from the United States to study households’ demand for macroeconomic information. Respondents who learn of a higher personal exposure to unemployment risk during recessions increase their demand for an expert forecast about the likelihood of a recession. This finding is consistent with macroeconomic models of endogenous information acquisition, according to which the demand for information depends on its expected benefits. Moreover, respondents’ updating about their personal unemployment risk suggests that households are imperfectly informed about their exposure to aggregate fluctuations, which may distort their beliefs about the benefits of acquiring macroeconomic information. (JEL D12, D83, E24, E32, G01, J64) </jats:p>
research_question: How does personal exposure to unemployment risk during recessions affect households' demand for macroeconomic information?
answer: Respondents who learn of higher personal exposure to unemployment risk during recessions increase their demand for expert forecasts about recession likelihood, confirming that information demand depends on expected benefits, though households are imperfectly informed about their aggregate risk exposure.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical support for macroeconomic models of endogenous information acquisition by demonstrating that information demand depends on expected benefits, while revealing that households' imperfect knowledge of their aggregate risk exposure may distort their beliefs about information acquisition benefits.

author: Shing-Yi Wang
title: Property Rights, Land Misallocation, and Agricultural Efficiency in China
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article examines the impact of a property rights reform in rural China that allowed farmers to lease out their land. We find the reform led to increases in land rental activity in rural households. Our results indicate that the formalization of leasing rights resulted in a redistribution of land toward more-productive farmers. Consequently, output and aggregate productivity increased by 8$\%$ and 10$\%$, respectively. We also find that the reform increased the responsiveness of land allocation across crops to changes in crop prices.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of property rights reform in rural China that allowed farmers to lease out their land on land allocation efficiency and agricultural productivity?
answer: The property rights reform led to increased land rental activity, redistribution of land toward more productive farmers, resulting in 8% increase in output and 10% increase in aggregate productivity, and improved responsiveness of land allocation to crop price changes.
positioning_statement: This paper examines the causal impact of formalizing land leasing rights on agricultural efficiency and land misallocation in China, contributing to the literature on property rights reforms and their effects on resource allocation and productivity in developing economies.

author: Stavros Panageas
title: Running Primary Deficits Forever in a Dynamically Efficient Economy: Feasibility and Optimality
abstract:
<jats:p>Government debt can be rolled over forever without primary surpluses in some stochastic economies, including some economies that are dynamically efficient. In an overlapping‐generations model with constant growth rate, 
            <jats:italic>g</jats:italic>, of labor‐augmenting productivity, and with shocks to the durability of capital, we show that along a balanced growth path, the maximum sustainable ratio of bonds to capital is attained when the risk‐free interest rate, 
            <jats:italic>r</jats:italic>
            <jats:sub>
              <jats:italic>f</jats:italic>
            </jats:sub>, equals 
            <jats:italic>g</jats:italic>. Furthermore, this maximal ratio maximizes utility per capita along a balanced growth path and ensures that the economy is dynamically efficient.
          </jats:p>
research_question: Can government debt be rolled over forever without primary surpluses in a dynamically efficient economy, and if so, what is the optimal debt-to-capital ratio?
answer: Government debt can be rolled over forever without primary surpluses in some dynamically efficient stochastic economies, with the maximum sustainable and optimal debt-to-capital ratio achieved when the risk-free interest rate equals the growth rate of labor-augmenting productivity.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the conventional view by demonstrating that permanent deficit financing is feasible even in dynamically efficient economies with stochastic shocks, extending beyond the traditional deterministic framework where dynamic efficiency typically precludes such financing.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Understanding Tax Policy: How do People Reason?
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>I study how people understand, reason, and learn about two major tax policies: income taxation and estate taxation. Using large-scale social economics surveys issued to representative U.S. samples and associated experiments, I elicit respondents’ factual knowledge about tax policy and the income or wealth distributions. Most important, I study their understanding of the mechanisms of tax policy and the reasoning that underlies their policy views. In decomposing policy views, I find that support for income and estate taxes is most strongly correlated with social preferences, that is, the perceived benefits of redistribution and concerns around the fairness of inequality and taxation, as well as with broader views of the government. Efficiency concerns play a more minor role. These correlational patterns are confirmed by the experimental approach, which shows people instructional videos that explain the workings and consequences of one of the aspects of tax policy (the Redistribution and the Efficiency treatments) or that bring the two together and focus on the trade-off (the Economist treatment). The Redistribution and Economist treatments significantly increase support for more progressive income or estate taxes, while the Efficiency treatment has no effect. There are large partisan gaps in both the final policy views and at every step of the reasoning about the underlying mechanisms of taxes. Democrats’ and Republicans’ divergences in tax policy views can ultimately be traced back to different normative criteria (social preferences) and views of the government, rather than to different perceptions of the efficiency implications of taxation.</jats:p>
research_question: How do people understand, reason, and learn about major tax policies, specifically income taxation and estate taxation?
answer: Support for income and estate taxes is most strongly correlated with social preferences (perceived benefits of redistribution and fairness concerns) and views of government, while efficiency concerns play a minor role. Partisan differences in tax policy views stem from different normative criteria and government views rather than different perceptions of efficiency implications.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using large-scale social economics surveys and experiments to decompose the mechanisms underlying tax policy views, moving beyond simple correlational studies to experimentally test how different aspects of tax policy reasoning affect support for progressive taxation.
