author: Stavros Panageas
title: Financial Entanglement: A Theory of Incomplete Integration, Leverage, Crashes, and Contagion
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a unified model of limited market integration, asset-price determination, leveraging, and contagion. Investors and firms are located on a circle, and access to markets involves participation costs that increase with distance. Due to a complementarity between participation and leverage decisions, the equilibrium may exhibit diverse leverage and participation choices across investors, although investors are ex ante identical. Small changes in market-access costs can cause a change in the type of equilibrium, leading to discontinuous price changes, deleveraging, and portfolio-flow reversals. Moreover, the market is subject to contagion—an adverse shock to investors in some locations affects prices everywhere. (JEL D83, G11, G12, G32, G35) </jats:p>
research_question: How do market participation costs, leverage decisions, and limited market integration interact to create financial instability, crashes, and contagion effects?
answer: Due to complementarity between participation and leverage decisions, small changes in market-access costs can cause discontinuous equilibrium shifts leading to price crashes, deleveraging, and portfolio reversals, while adverse shocks in some market locations spread everywhere through contagion effects.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a unified theoretical framework that integrates previously separate concepts of limited market integration, asset pricing, leverage decisions, and contagion into a single model, offering a comprehensive explanation for financial instability phenomena.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Optimal Income Taxation with Adverse Selection in the Labour Market

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Generalized Social Marginal Welfare Weights for Optimal Tax Theory
abstract: <jats:p> This paper proposes to evaluate tax reforms by aggregating money metric losses and gains of different individuals using “generalized social marginal welfare weights.” Optimum tax formulas take the same form as standard welfarist tax formulas by simply substituting standard marginal social welfare weights with those generalized weights. Weights directly capture society's concerns for fairness without being necessarily tied to individual utilities. Suitable weights can help reconcile discrepancies between the welfarist approach and actual tax practice, as well as unify in an operational way the most prominent alternatives to utilitarianism such as Libertarianism, equality of opportunity, or poverty alleviation. (JEL D60, D63, H21, H23, I38) </jats:p>
research_question: How can tax reforms be evaluated in a way that captures society's concerns for fairness while maintaining the operational structure of standard optimal tax theory?
answer: Tax reforms can be evaluated by using 'generalized social marginal welfare weights' that aggregate money metric losses and gains across individuals, allowing optimum tax formulas to maintain their standard form while incorporating fairness concerns that are not necessarily tied to individual utilities.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as bridging the gap between standard welfarist optimal tax theory and actual tax practice by providing a framework that can reconcile discrepancies with welfarist approaches and operationally unify prominent alternatives to utilitarianism such as Libertarianism, equality of opportunity, and poverty alleviation.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Immigration and Redistribution
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Does immigration change support for redistribution? We design and conduct large-scale surveys and experiments in six countries to investigate how people perceive immigrants and how these perceptions influence their support for redistribution. We find striking misperceptions about the number and characteristics of immigrants. In all countries, respondents greatly overestimate the total number of immigrants, think immigrants are culturally and religiously more distant from them, and economically weaker—less educated, more unemployed, and more reliant on and favoured by government transfers—than they actually are. In the experimental part of our article, we show that simply making respondents think about immigration before asking questions about redistribution makes them support less redistribution, including actual donations to charities. The perception that immigrants are economically weaker and more likely to take advantage of the welfare system is strongly correlated with lower support for redistribution, much more so than the perceived cultural distance or the perceived share of immigrants. These findings are confirmed by further experimental evidence. Information about the true shares and origins of immigrants does not change support for redistribution. An anecdote about a “hard-working” immigrant has somewhat stronger effects but is unable to counteract the negative priming effect of making people think about immigration. Our results further suggest that narratives shape people’s views on immigration more deeply than hard facts.</jats:p>
research_question: Does immigration change support for redistribution?
answer: Yes, immigration reduces support for redistribution. Simply making people think about immigration before asking about redistribution makes them support less redistribution, including reducing actual donations to charities. This effect is primarily driven by misperceptions that immigrants are economically weaker and more likely to exploit the welfare system, rather than by perceived cultural differences.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on immigration and redistribution by providing large-scale experimental evidence across six countries that directly tests how perceptions of immigrants affect redistribution preferences, moving beyond correlational studies to establish causal relationships through survey experiments and examining the relative importance of economic versus cultural concerns.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Intergenerational Mobility and Preferences for Redistribution
abstract: <jats:p> Using new cross-country survey and experimental data, we investigate how beliefs about intergenerational mobility affect preferences for redistribution in France, Italy, Sweden, the United Kingdom, and the United States. Americans are more optimistic than Europeans about social mobility. Our randomized treatment shows pessimistic information about mobility and increases support for redistribution, mostly for “equality of opportunity” policies. We find strong political polarization. Left-wing respondents are more pessimistic about mobility: their preferences for redistribution are correlated with their mobility perceptions; and they support more redistribution after seeing pessimistic information. None of this is true for right-wing respondents, possibly because they see the government as a “problem” and not as the “solution.” (JEL D63, D72, H23, H24, J31, J62) </jats:p>
research_question: How do beliefs about intergenerational mobility affect preferences for redistribution across different countries?
answer: Pessimistic beliefs about social mobility increase support for redistribution, particularly for equality of opportunity policies, but this effect is primarily driven by left-wing respondents who are more responsive to mobility information, while right-wing respondents show no such response, likely due to their distrust of government solutions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new cross-country survey and experimental evidence on the relationship between mobility beliefs and redistribution preferences, extending existing literature by using randomized treatments to establish causal effects and revealing important political polarization patterns that help explain why this relationship varies across the political spectrum.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Optimal Taxation and R&D Policies
abstract: <jats:p>We study the optimal design of corporate taxation and R&D policies as a dynamic mechanism design problem with spillovers. Firms have heterogeneous research productivity, and that research productivity is private information. There are non‐internalized technological spillovers across firms, but the asymmetric information prevents the government from correcting them in the first best way. We highlight that key parameters for the optimal policies are (i) the relative complementarities between observable R&D investments, unobservable R&D inputs, and firm research productivity, (ii) the dispersion and persistence of firms' research productivities, and (iii) the magnitude of technological spillovers across firms. We estimate our model using firm‐level data matched to patent data and quantify the optimal policies. In the data, high research productivity firms get disproportionately higher returns to R&D investments than lower productivity firms. Very simple innovation policies, such as linear corporate taxes combined with a nonlinear R&D subsidy—which provides lower marginal subsidies at higher R&D levels—can do almost as well as the unrestricted optimal policies. Our formulas and theoretical and numerical methods are more broadly applicable to the provision of firm incentives in dynamic settings with asymmetric information and spillovers, and to firm taxation more generally.</jats:p>
research_question: How should governments optimally design corporate taxation and R&D policies when firms have heterogeneous and private research productivity information, and there are technological spillovers across firms?
answer: The optimal policies depend on three key parameters: (1) relative complementarities between observable R&D investments, unobservable R&D inputs, and firm research productivity, (2) dispersion and persistence of firms' research productivities, and (3) magnitude of technological spillovers. Simple policies combining linear corporate taxes with nonlinear R&D subsidies that provide lower marginal subsidies at higher R&D levels can achieve nearly optimal outcomes.
positioning_statement: This paper frames the optimal taxation and R&D policy problem as a dynamic mechanism design problem with spillovers and asymmetric information, extending beyond existing literature by providing formulas and methods broadly applicable to firm incentives in dynamic settings with asymmetric information and spillovers, and to firm taxation more generally.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Taxation and Innovation in the Twentieth Century
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>This article studies the effect of corporate and personal taxes on innovation in the United States over the twentieth century. We build a panel of the universe of inventors who patented since 1920, and a historical state-level corporate tax database with corporate tax rates and tax base information, which we link to existing data on state-level personal income taxes and other economic outcomes. Our analysis focuses on the effect of personal and corporate income taxes on individual inventors (the micro level) and on states (the macro level), considering the quantity and quality of innovation, its location, and the share produced by the corporate rather than the noncorporate sector. We propose several identification strategies, all of which yield consistent results. We find that higher taxes negatively affect the quantity and the location of innovation, but not average innovation quality. The state-level elasticities to taxes are large and consistent with the aggregation of the individual-level responses of innovation produced and cross-state mobility. Corporate taxes tend to especially affect corporate inventors’ innovation production and cross-state mobility. Personal income taxes significantly affect the quantity of innovation overall and the mobility of inventors.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of corporate and personal taxes on innovation in the United States over the twentieth century?
answer: Higher taxes negatively affect the quantity and location of innovation, but not average innovation quality. State-level elasticities to taxes are large and consistent with individual-level responses. Corporate taxes especially affect corporate inventors' innovation production and cross-state mobility, while personal income taxes significantly affect overall innovation quantity and inventor mobility.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by building a comprehensive panel of the universe of inventors who patented since 1920 and creating a historical state-level corporate tax database, allowing for analysis of both personal and corporate tax effects on innovation at both individual (micro) and state (macro) levels over a century-long period.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Taxation and the International Mobility of Inventors
abstract: <jats:p> We study the effect of top tax rates on “superstar” inventors' international mobility since 1977, using panel data on inventors from the US and European Patent Offices. We exploit the differential impact of changes in top tax rates on inventors of different qualities. Superstar inventors' location choices are significantly affected by top tax rates. In our preferred specification, the elasticity to the net-of-tax rate of the number of domestic superstar inventors is around 0.03, while that of foreign superstar inventors is around 1. These elasticities are larger for inventors in multinational companies. An inventor is less sensitive to taxes in a country if his company performs a higher share of its research there. (JEL F22, F23, H24, H31, J61, O31, O34) </jats:p>
research_question: How do top tax rates affect the international mobility of high-quality 'superstar' inventors?
answer: Top tax rates significantly affect superstar inventors' location choices, with an elasticity to the net-of-tax rate of around 0.03 for domestic superstar inventors and around 1 for foreign superstar inventors, with larger effects for inventors in multinational companies and smaller effects when inventors' companies perform more research in that country.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on tax policy and high-skilled migration by focusing specifically on 'superstar' inventors and exploiting the differential impact of tax changes on inventors of different qualities, using comprehensive patent data from the US and European Patent Offices since 1977.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Optimal Taxation and R&D Policies
abstract: <jats:p>We study the optimal design of corporate taxation and R&D policies as a dynamic mechanism design problem with spillovers. Firms have heterogeneous research productivity, and that research productivity is private information. There are non‐internalized technological spillovers across firms, but the asymmetric information prevents the government from correcting them in the first best way. author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: How Elastic Are Preferences for Redistribution? Evidence from Randomized Survey Experiments
abstract: <jats:p>We analyze randomized online survey experiments providing interactive, customized information on US income inequality, the link between top income tax rates and economic growth, and the estate tax. The treatment has large effects on views about inequality but only slightly moves tax and transfer policy preferences. An exception is the estate tax—informing respondents of the small share of decedents who pay it doubles support for it. The small effects for all other policies can be partially explained by respondents' low trust in government and a disconnect between concerns about social issues and the public policies meant to address them. (JEL D31, D72, H23, H24)</jats:p>
research_question: How elastic are preferences for redistribution when people are provided with factual information about income inequality, tax rates, and their economic effects?
answer: Preferences for redistribution are largely inelastic - providing information has large effects on views about inequality but only slightly moves tax and transfer policy preferences, with the exception of the estate tax where informing people of the small share of decedents who pay it doubles support for it.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on how information affects policy preferences by using randomized survey experiments with interactive, customized information, and explains the limited policy preference changes through respondents' low trust in government and disconnect between social concerns and policy solutions.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Social Positions and Fairness Views on Inequality
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We link survey data on Danish people’s perceived income positions and fairness views on inequality within various reference groups to administrative records on their reference groups, income histories, and life events. People are, on average, well-informed about the income levels of their reference groups. Yet, lower-ranked respondents in all groups tend to overestimate their own position among others because they believe others’ incomes are lower than they actually are, whereas the opposite holds true for higher-ranked respondents. Misperceptions of positions in reference groups relate to proximity to other individuals, transparency norms, and visible signals of income. People view inequalities within their co-workers and education groups as significantly more unfair than overall inequality, yet underestimate inequality the most exactly within these groups. Views on the fairness of inequalities are strongly correlated with an individual’s current position, move with shocks like unemployment or promotions, and change when experimentally informing people about their actual positions. However, the higher perceived unfairness of income differences within co-workers and education groups stays unchanged. The theoretical framework shows that this can have important implications for redistribution policy.</jats:p>
research_question: How do people's perceived income positions within various reference groups relate to their actual positions, and how do these perceptions affect their views on the fairness of inequality?
answer: People are generally well-informed about reference group income levels, but systematically misperceive their own positions - lower-ranked individuals overestimate their position while higher-ranked individuals underestimate theirs. People view inequality within close reference groups (co-workers, education groups) as more unfair than overall inequality, and fairness views are strongly correlated with current position and respond to shocks and experimental information about actual positions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by uniquely linking survey data on perceived positions and fairness views to comprehensive administrative records, allowing for precise measurement of actual versus perceived positions within reference groups and examination of how life events and experimental information affect fairness perceptions.

author: Stefanie Stantcheva
title: Fighting Climate Change: International Attitudes toward Climate Policies
abstract: <jats:p> This paper explores global perceptions and understanding of climate change and policies, examining factors that influence support for climate action and the impact of different types of information. We conduct large-scale surveys with 40,000 respondents from 20 countries, providing new international data on attitudes toward climate change and respondents’ socioeconomic backgrounds and lifestyles. We identify three key perceptions affecting policy support: perceived effectiveness of policies in reducing emissions, their impact on low-income households, and their effect on respondents’ households (self-interest). Educational videos clarifying policy mechanisms increase support for climate policies; those merely highlighting climate change’s impacts do not. (JEL C83, D83, D91, Q54, Q58) </jats:p>
research_question: What factors influence global support for climate policies, and how does different types of information affect attitudes toward climate action?
answer: Three key perceptions affect policy support: perceived effectiveness of policies in reducing emissions, their impact on low-income households, and their effect on respondents' own households (self-interest). Educational videos explaining policy mechanisms increase support for climate policies, while videos merely highlighting climate change impacts do not.
positioning_statement: This paper provides new international data on climate policy attitudes through large-scale surveys across 20 countries with 40,000 respondents, exploring global perceptions and understanding of climate change policies while examining the differential impact of information types on policy support.

author: Stefano Caria
title: The Selection of Talent: Experimental and Structural Evidence from Ethiopia
abstract: <jats:p>We study how search frictions in the labor market affect firms’ ability to recruit talented workers. In a field experiment in Ethiopia, we show that an employer can attract more talented applicants by offering a small monetary incentive for making a job application. Estimates from a structural model suggest that the intervention is effective because the cost of making a job application is large, and positively correlated with jobseeker ability. We provide evidence that this positive correlation is driven by dynamic selection. In a second experiment, we show that local recruiters underestimate the positive impacts of application incentives. (JEL J23, J24, J31, J64, O15)</jats:p>
research_question: How do search frictions in the labor market affect firms' ability to recruit talented workers?
answer: An employer can attract more talented applicants by offering a small monetary incentive for making a job application, because the cost of making a job application is large and positively correlated with jobseeker ability due to dynamic selection.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on labor market search frictions by providing both experimental and structural evidence on how application costs affect talent recruitment, and demonstrates that local recruiters underestimate the effectiveness of application incentives.

author: Stefano Caria
title: The Allocation of Incentives in Multilayered Organizations: Evidence from a Community Health Program in Sierra Leone

author: Stefano Caria
title: Anonymity or Distance? Job Search and Labour Market Exclusion in a Growing African City
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We show that helping young job seekers signal their skills to employers generates large and persistent improvements in their labour market outcomes. We do this by comparing an intervention that improves the ability to signal skills (the “job application workshop”) to a transport subsidy treatment designed to reduce the cost of job search. In the short run, both interventions have large positive effects on the probability of finding a formal job. The workshop also increases the probability of having a stable job with an open-ended contract. Four years later, the workshop significantly increases earnings, job satisfaction, and employment duration, but the effects of the transport subsidy have dissipated. Gains are concentrated on individuals who generally have worse labour market outcomes. Overall, our findings highlight that young people possess valuable skills that are unobservable to employers. Making these skills observable generates earnings gains that are far greater than the cost of the intervention.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the relative effects of helping young job seekers signal their skills to employers versus reducing the cost of job search through transport subsidies on labour market outcomes?
answer: Helping young job seekers signal their skills through job application workshops generates large and persistent improvements in labour market outcomes (earnings, job satisfaction, employment duration) that last four years, while transport subsidies only have short-term effects that dissipate over time.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on labour market exclusion by demonstrating that the primary barrier for young job seekers in African cities is not search costs or distance, but rather the inability to effectively signal valuable but unobservable skills to employers.

author: Stefano Caria
title: Choosing not to lead: Monetary incentives and political selection in local parliamentary systems

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: Dynamic Matching and Bargaining Games: A General Approach
abstract: <jats:p> Dynamic matching and bargaining games are models of decentralized markets with trading frictions. A central objective is to investigate how equilibrium outcomes depend on the level of frictions. In particular, does the trading outcome become Walrasian when frictions become small? Existing specifications of such games provide divergent answers. This paper presents a new characterization result for competitive allocations in quasilinear economies. The characterization result is used to investigate what causes these differences and to generalize insights from the analysis of specific matching and bargaining games. (JEL C73, C78, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: How do equilibrium outcomes in dynamic matching and bargaining games depend on the level of trading frictions, and specifically, does the trading outcome become Walrasian when frictions become small?
answer: The paper provides a new characterization result for competitive allocations in quasilinear economies that explains what causes the divergent answers in existing specifications and generalizes insights from specific matching and bargaining games.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the fact that existing specifications of dynamic matching and bargaining games provide divergent answers about whether trading outcomes become Walrasian as frictions decrease, and presents a general approach to investigate what causes these differences and generalize insights from prior specific analyses.

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: Search With Adverse Selection
abstract: This paper analyzes a sequential search model with adverse selection. We study information aggregation by the price—how close the equilibrium prices are to the full‐information prices—when search frictions are small. We identify circumstances under which prices fail to aggregate information well even when search frictions are small. We trace this to a strong form of the winner's curse that is present in the sequential search model. The failure of information aggregation may result in inefficient allocations.

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: Manipulated Electorates and Information Aggregation

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: Bidding in Common‐Value Auctions With an Unknown Number of Competitors
abstract: <jats:p>This paper studies a first‐price common‐value auction in which bidders do not know the number of their competitors. In contrast to the case of common‐value auctions with a known number of rival bidders, the inference from winning is not monotone, and a “winner's blessing” emerges at low bids. As a result, bidding strategies may not be strictly increasing, but instead may contain atoms. Moreover, an equilibrium fails to exist when the expected number of competitors is large and the bid space is continuous. Therefore, we consider auctions on a grid. On a fine grid, high‐signal bidders follow an essentially strictly increasing strategy, whereas low‐signal bidders pool on two adjacent bids on the grid. The solutions of a “communication extension” based on Jackson, Simon, Swinkels, and Zame (2002) capture the equilibrium bidding behavior in the limit, as the grid becomes arbitrarily fine.</jats:p>
research_question: How do bidding strategies change in first-price common-value auctions when bidders do not know the number of their competitors?
answer: When the number of competitors is unknown, bidding strategies fundamentally differ from known-competitor auctions: inference from winning is not monotone and creates a 'winner's blessing' at low bids, leading to non-strictly increasing bidding strategies with atoms, and requiring grid-based auctions where low-signal bidders pool on adjacent bids while high-signal bidders follow essentially strictly increasing strategies.
positioning_statement: This paper contrasts with existing common-value auction literature that assumes bidders know the number of competitors, showing that removing this assumption fundamentally changes equilibrium properties and requires new solution concepts from Jackson, Simon, Swinkels, and Zame (2002) to characterize bidding behavior.

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: Persuasion and Information Aggregation in Elections

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: Auctions with Frictions: Recruitment, Entry, and Limited Commitment
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Auction models are convenient abstractions of informal price-formation processes that arise in markets for assets or services. These processes involve frictions like bidder recruitment costs for sellers, participation costs for bidders, and limitations on sellers’ commitment abilities. This paper develops an auction model that captures such frictions. We derive novel insights, notably that outcomes are often inefficient, that markets sometimes unravel, and that the observability of competition may have a large effect.</jats:p>
research_question: How do frictions such as bidder recruitment costs, participation costs, and limited commitment abilities affect outcomes in auction-based price-formation processes?
answer: Frictions in auction processes lead to inefficient outcomes, can cause market unraveling, and the observability of competition has significant effects on market performance.
positioning_statement: This paper extends traditional auction models by incorporating realistic frictions (recruitment costs, entry costs, and commitment limitations) that are present in actual price-formation processes for assets and services, moving beyond the convenient abstractions of standard auction theory.

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: Bidder Solicitation, Adverse Selection, and the Failure of Competition
abstract: <jats:p> We study a common value, first-price auction in which the number of bidders is endogenous: the seller (auctioneer) knows the value and solicits bidders at a cost. The number of bidders, which is unobservable, may thus depend on the true value. Therefore, being solicited conveys information. This solicitation effect may soften competition and impede information aggregation. Under certain conditions, there is an equilibrium in which the seller solicits many bidders, yet the resulting price is not competitive and fails to aggregate any information. More broadly, these ideas are relevant for markets with adverse selection in which informed traders initiate contacts. (JEL D44, D82) </jats:p>
research_question: How does endogenous bidder solicitation by an informed seller affect competition and information aggregation in common value auctions?
answer: Bidder solicitation by informed sellers creates adverse selection that can lead to equilibria where many bidders are solicited yet prices remain non-competitive and fail to aggregate information, as the solicitation process itself conveys information that softens competition.
positioning_statement: This paper extends auction theory by introducing endogenous bidder participation through informed seller solicitation, connecting auction mechanisms to broader markets with adverse selection where informed traders initiate contacts, thereby bridging auction theory with information economics literature.

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: Learning and Price Discovery in a Search Market

author: Stephan Lauermann
title: The Balance Condition in Search‐and‐Matching Models
abstract:
<jats:p>Most of the literature that studies frictional search‐and‐matching models with heterogeneous agents and random search investigates steady state equilibria. Steady state equilibrium requires, in particular, that the flows of agents into and out of the population of unmatched agents balance. We investigate the structure of this balance condition, taking agents' matching behavior as given. Building on the “fundamental matching lemma” for quadratic search technologies in Shimer and Smith (2000), we establish existence, uniqueness, and comparative statics properties of the solution to the balance condition for 
            <jats:italic>any</jats:italic> search technology satisfying minimal regularity conditions. Implications for the existence and structure of steady state equilibria in the Shimer–Smith model and extensions thereof are noted. These reinforce the point that much of the structure of search‐and‐matching models with quadratic search technologies carries over to more general search technologies.
          </jats:p>
research_question: What is the structure of the balance condition in search-and-matching models with heterogeneous agents, and do the properties established for quadratic search technologies extend to more general search technologies?
answer: The balance condition has well-defined existence, uniqueness, and comparative statics properties for any search technology satisfying minimal regularity conditions, not just quadratic search technologies, and much of the structure from quadratic search technologies carries over to more general search technologies.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the existing literature on frictional search-and-matching models by building on Shimer and Smith (2000)'s 'fundamental matching lemma' for quadratic search technologies and demonstrating that the key structural properties generalize beyond quadratic search technologies to any search technology meeting basic regularity conditions.

author: Stephen Redding
title: Trade, Structural Transformation, and Development: Evidence from Argentina 1869–1914

author: Stephen Redding
title: The Costs of Remoteness: Evidence from German Division and Reunification
abstract: <jats:p> This paper exploits the division of Germany after the Second World War and the reunification of East and West Germany in 1990 as a natural experiment to provide evidence for the importance of market access for economic development. In line with a standard new economic geography model, we find that, following division, cities in West Germany close to the East-West German border experienced a substantial decline in population growth relative to other West German cities. We show that the model can account for the quantitative magnitude of our findings and provide additional evidence against alternative possible explanations. (JEL F15, N94, R12, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the importance of market access for economic development?
answer: Cities in West Germany close to the East-West German border experienced substantial decline in population growth relative to other West German cities following division, demonstrating that reduced market access significantly harms economic development.
positioning_statement: This paper uses German division and reunification as a natural experiment to provide empirical evidence supporting standard new economic geography models, with findings that align with theoretical predictions about the relationship between market access and economic development.

author: Stephen Redding
title: Measuring Aggregate Price Indices with Taste Shocks: Theory and Evidence for CES Preferences*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop an approach to measuring the cost of living for CES preferences that treats demand shocks as taste shocks that are equivalent to price shocks. In the presence of relative taste shocks, the Sato-Vartia price index is upward biased because an increase in the relative consumer taste for a variety lowers its taste-adjusted price and raises its expenditure share. By failing to allow for this association, the Sato-Vartia index underweights drops in taste-adjusted prices and overweights increases in taste-adjusted prices, leading to what we call a “taste-shock bias.” We show that this bias generalizes to other invertible demand systems.</jats:p>
research_question: How should aggregate price indices be measured when consumer preferences are subject to taste shocks, and what biases arise in existing price index methodologies?
answer: The Sato-Vartia price index exhibits an upward bias (taste-shock bias) when taste shocks are present because it fails to account for how increases in relative consumer taste for a variety effectively lower its taste-adjusted price while raising its expenditure share, leading to systematic underweighting of price drops and overweighting of price increases.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing price index theory by developing a new approach that treats demand shocks as taste shocks equivalent to price shocks for CES preferences, identifying a previously unrecognized bias in the widely-used Sato-Vartia price index and demonstrating that this bias generalizes to other invertible demand systems.

author: Stephen Redding
title: Missing Gains from Trade?
abstract: <jats:p> In a class of trade models which satisfy a constant elasticity gravity equation, the welfare gains from trade can be computed using the open economy domestic trade share and a constant trade elasticity. The measured welfare gains from trade from this quantitative approach are typically relatively modest. In this paper, we suggest a channel for welfare gains that this quantitative approach typically abstracts from: trade-induced changes in domestic productivity. Using a model of sequential production, in which trade induces a reorganization of production that raises domestic productivity, we show that the welfare gains from trade can become arbitrarily large. </jats:p>
research_question: Are there missing welfare gains from trade that are not captured by standard quantitative trade models that use gravity equations?
answer: Yes, standard quantitative trade models miss significant welfare gains from trade because they abstract from trade-induced changes in domestic productivity. When accounting for how trade induces reorganization of production that raises domestic productivity, the welfare gains from trade can become arbitrarily large.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the existing quantitative trade literature that relies on constant elasticity gravity equations and finds modest welfare gains from trade, by identifying and modeling a previously abstracted channel - trade-induced domestic productivity changes through production reorganization.

author: Stephen Redding
title: Dynamic Spatial General Equilibrium
abstract: <jats:p>We incorporate forward‐looking capital accumulation into a dynamic discrete choice model of migration. We characterize the steady‐state equilibrium; generalize existing dynamic exact‐hat algebra techniques to incorporate investment; and linearize the model to provide an analytical characterization of the economy's transition path using spectral analysis. We show that capital and labor dynamics interact to shape the economy's speed of adjustment toward steady state. We implement our quantitative analysis using data on capital stocks, populations, and bilateral trade and migration flows for U.S. states from 1965–2015. We show that this interaction between capital and labor dynamics plays a central role in explaining the observed decline in the rate of income convergence across U.S. states and the persistent and heterogeneous impact of local shocks.</jats:p>
research_question: How do capital accumulation and labor migration dynamics interact to affect economic adjustment and income convergence across spatial locations?
answer: Capital and labor dynamics interact to shape the economy's speed of adjustment toward steady state, with this interaction playing a central role in explaining the observed decline in income convergence across U.S. states and the persistent, heterogeneous impact of local shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing dynamic discrete choice models of migration by incorporating forward-looking capital accumulation and generalizes existing dynamic exact-hat algebra techniques to include investment, providing a more comprehensive framework for analyzing spatial economic dynamics.

author: Stephen Redding
title: Commuting, Migration, and Local Employment Elasticities
abstract: <jats:p> We provide theory and evidence that the elasticity of local employment to a labor demand shock is heterogeneous depending on the commuting openness of the local labor market. We develop a quantitative general equilibrium model that incorporates spatial linkages in goods markets (trade) and factor markets (commuting and migration). We quantify this model to match the observed gravity equation relationships for trade and commuting. We find that empirically-observed reductions in commuting costs generate welfare gains of around 3.3 percent. We provide separate quasi-experimental evidence in support of the model’s predictions using the location decisions of million dollar plants. (JEL J23, J61, R23, R32, R41) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the commuting openness of local labor markets affect the elasticity of local employment to labor demand shocks?
answer: The elasticity of local employment to labor demand shocks is heterogeneous and depends on the commuting openness of the local labor market, with empirically-observed reductions in commuting costs generating welfare gains of around 3.3 percent.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by developing a quantitative general equilibrium model that incorporates both spatial linkages in goods markets (trade) and factor markets (commuting and migration), providing both theoretical framework and quasi-experimental evidence using million dollar plant location decisions to support the model's predictions.

author: Stephen Redding
title: The Economics of Spatial Mobility: Theory and Evidence Using Smartphone Data
abstract:
<jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a tractable quantitative framework for modeling the rich patterns of spatial mobility observed in smartphone data. We show that travel is frequently undertaken as part of a travel itinerary, defined as a journey starting and ending at home that can include more than one intermediate stop on a given day. We show that these travel itineraries provide microfoundations for consumption externalities and generate both complementarity and substitutability between locations. We show that the consumption externalities implied by travel itineraries are central to matching quasi-experimental evidence from the shift to working from home. We find that these consumption externalities are key drivers of the agglomeration of economic activity in central cities and shape the relative welfare gains from alternative transport improvements in favor of investments in central cities.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a quantitative framework to model spatial mobility patterns observed in smartphone data and understand their economic implications for consumption externalities and agglomeration?
answer: Travel itineraries (journeys starting and ending at home with multiple stops) provide microfoundations for consumption externalities that generate both complementarity and substitutability between locations, are central to explaining work-from-home shifts, drive agglomeration in central cities, and favor transport investments in central areas for welfare gains.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new tractable quantitative framework using smartphone data to model spatial mobility patterns, providing novel microfoundations for consumption externalities through travel itineraries that can explain quasi-experimental evidence and inform urban economics theory about agglomeration and transport policy.

author: Stephen Redding
title: New Trade Models, New Welfare Implications
abstract: <jats:p> We show that endogenous firm selection provides a new welfare margin for heterogeneous firm models of trade (relative to homo geneous firm models). Under some parameter restrictions, the trade elasticity is constant and is a sufficient statistic for welfare, along with the domestic trade share. However, even small deviations from these restrictions imply that trade elasticities are variable and differ across markets and levels of trade costs. In this more general setting, the domestic trade share and endogenous trade elasticity are no longer sufficient statistics for welfare. Additional empirically observable moments of the micro structure also matter for welfare. (JEL F12, F13, F41) </jats:p>
research_question: How does endogenous firm selection in heterogeneous firm models of trade affect welfare implications and the sufficiency of trade elasticity and domestic trade share as welfare statistics?
answer: Endogenous firm selection provides a new welfare margin in heterogeneous firm models. While trade elasticity and domestic trade share can be sufficient statistics for welfare under restrictive parameter conditions, even small deviations from these restrictions make trade elasticities variable across markets and trade cost levels, requiring additional observable moments of the micro structure for accurate welfare analysis.
positioning_statement: This paper extends heterogeneous firm models of trade by demonstrating that they generate different welfare implications compared to homogeneous firm models, specifically showing when the commonly used sufficient statistics (trade elasticity and domestic trade share) break down and additional microstructural moments become necessary for welfare analysis.

author: Stephen Redding
title: The Making of the Modern Metropolis: Evidence from London*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Using newly constructed spatially disaggregated data for London from 1801 to 1921, we show that the invention of the steam railway led to the first large-scale separation of workplace and residence. We show that a class of quantitative urban models is remarkably successful in explaining this reorganization of economic activity. We structurally estimate one of the models in this class and find substantial agglomeration forces in both production and residence. In counterfactuals, we find that removing the whole railway network reduces the population and the value of land and buildings in London by up to 51.5% and 53.3% respectively, and decreases net commuting into the historical center of London by more than 300,000 workers.</jats:p>
research_question: How did the invention of the steam railway lead to the separation of workplace and residence in London, and what was the quantitative impact of railway networks on urban reorganization?
answer: The steam railway enabled the first large-scale separation of workplace and residence in London from 1801-1921, with substantial agglomeration forces in both production and residence. Removing the railway network would have reduced London's population by up to 51.5%, land and building values by 53.3%, and decreased net commuting into the historical center by more than 300,000 workers.
positioning_statement: This paper demonstrates that quantitative urban models are remarkably successful in explaining the reorganization of economic activity caused by transportation innovations, using newly constructed spatially disaggregated historical data to structurally estimate and validate these models.

author: Stephen Redding
title: Globalization and Pandemics
abstract: <jats:p> We provide theory and evidence on the relationship between globalization and pandemics. Business travel facilitates trade and travel leads to human interactions that transmit disease. Trade-motivated travel generates an epidemiological externality across countries. If infections lead to deaths, or reduce individual labor supply, we establish a general equilibrium social distancing effect, whereby increases in relative prices in unhealthy countries reduce travel to those countries. If agents internalize the threat of infection, we show that their behavioral responses lead to a reduction in travel that is larger for higher-trade-cost locations, which initially reduces the ratio of trade to output. (JEL D91, F14, F60, I12, N30, N70, Z31) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between globalization and pandemics, specifically how business travel that facilitates trade affects disease transmission across countries?
answer: Business travel creates an epidemiological externality across countries by facilitating disease transmission, but general equilibrium social distancing effects and behavioral responses lead to reduced travel (especially to higher-trade-cost locations) and a reduction in the ratio of trade to output during pandemics.
positioning_statement: This paper provides both theoretical framework and empirical evidence on the globalization-pandemic relationship, establishing novel concepts of epidemiological externalities from trade-motivated travel and general equilibrium social distancing effects that emerge when infections affect mortality or labor supply.

author: Stephen Redding
title: When Tariffs Disrupt Global Supply Chains
abstract: <jats:p> We study unanticipated tariffs in a setting with firm-to-firm supply relationships. Firms conduct costly searches and negotiate with potential suppliers that pass a reservation level of match productivity. Global supply chains form in anticipation of free trade. Then, the home government surprises with an input tariff. This can lead to renegotiation with initial suppliers or search for replacements. Calibrating the model’s parameters to match initial import shares and the estimated responses to the US tariffs imposed on China, we find an overall welfare loss of 0.12 percent of GDP, with substantial contributions from changes in input sourcing and search costs. (JEL D72, F13, F14, L14, O19, P33) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the welfare effects of unanticipated tariffs when firms have established supply relationships through costly search and matching processes in global supply chains?
answer: Unanticipated input tariffs lead to an overall welfare loss of 0.12 percent of GDP, with substantial contributions from disruptions to input sourcing decisions and search costs as firms renegotiate with existing suppliers or search for new ones.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the tariff literature by incorporating firm-to-firm supply relationships with costly search and matching, examining how unanticipated trade policy disrupts established global supply chains that were formed under expectations of free trade.

author: Stephen Redding
title:
Quantifying the Sources of Firm Heterogeneity
            *
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop and structurally estimate a model of heterogeneous multiproduct firms that can be used to decompose the firm-size distribution into the contributions of costs, “appeal” (quality or taste), markups, and product scope. Using Nielsen barcode data on prices and sales, we find that variation in firm appeal and product scope explains at least four fifths of the variation in firm sales. We show that the imperfect substitutability of products within firms, and the fact that larger firms supply more products than smaller firms, implies that standard productivity measures are highly dependent on implicit demand system assumptions and probably dramatically understate the relative productivity of the largest firms. Although most firms are well approximated by the monopolistic competition benchmark of constant markups, we find that the largest firms that account for most of aggregate sales depart substantially from this benchmark, and exhibit both variable markups and substantial cannibalization effects.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the sources of firm heterogeneity and how do different factors (costs, appeal, markups, and product scope) contribute to the firm-size distribution?
answer: Variation in firm appeal (quality or taste) and product scope explains at least four-fifths of the variation in firm sales, while standard productivity measures dramatically understate the relative productivity of the largest firms due to imperfect product substitutability and multiproduct nature of large firms.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges existing literature by showing that standard productivity measures are highly dependent on implicit demand system assumptions and likely underestimate large firm productivity, while demonstrating that the largest firms deviate substantially from the monopolistic competition benchmark of constant markups that characterizes most firms.

author: Stephen Redding
title: Multiple-Product Firms and Product Switching
abstract: <jats:p> This paper examines the frequency, pervasiveness, and determinants of product switching by US manufacturing firms. We find that one-half of firms alter their mix of five-digit SIC products every five years, that product switching is correlated with both firm- and firm-product attributes, and that product adding and dropping induce large changes in firm scope. The behavior we observe is consistent with a natural generalization of existing theories of industry dynamics that incorporates endogenous product selection within firms. Our findings suggest that product switching contributes to a reallocation of resources within firms toward their most efficient use. (JEL L11, L21, L25, L60) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the frequency, pervasiveness, and what are the determinants of product switching by US manufacturing firms?
answer: One-half of firms alter their mix of five-digit SIC products every five years, product switching is correlated with both firm- and firm-product attributes, and product adding and dropping induce large changes in firm scope, contributing to reallocation of resources within firms toward their most efficient use.
positioning_statement: The observed behavior is consistent with a natural generalization of existing theories of industry dynamics that incorporates endogenous product selection within firms.

author: Stephen Redding
title: The Unequal Effects of Liberalization: Evidence from Dismantling the License Raj in India
abstract: <jats:p> We study whether the effects on registered manufacturing output of dismantling the License Raj—a system of central controls regulating entry and production activity in this sector—vary across Indian states with different labor market regulations. The effects are found to be unequal across Indian states with different labor market regulations. In particular, following delicensing, industries located in states with pro-employer labor market institutions grew more quickly than those in pro-worker environments. (JEL J50, L52,L60, O14, O15, O25) </jats:p>
research_question: Do the effects on registered manufacturing output of dismantling the License Raj vary across Indian states with different labor market regulations?
answer: Yes, the effects are unequal across Indian states - following delicensing, industries in states with pro-employer labor market institutions grew more quickly than those in pro-worker environments.
positioning_statement: This paper studies the heterogeneous effects of liberalization by examining how the dismantling of India's License Raj system of central controls affected manufacturing output differently across states with varying labor market regulations.

author: Stephen Redding
title: Sources of Wage Inequality
abstract: <jats:p> Recent theories of firm heterogeneity emphasize between-firm wage differences as a new mechanism through which trade can affect wage inequality. Using linked employer-employee data for Sweden, we show that many of the stylized facts about wage inequality found in Helpman et al. (2012) for Brazil also hold for Sweden. Much of overall wage inequality arises within sector-occupations and for workers with similar observable characteristics. One notable difference is a smaller contribution from between-firm differences in wages in Sweden, which could reflect the influence of Swedish labor market institutions in dampening the scope for variation in wages between firms through collective wage agreements. </jats:p>
research_question: Do the stylized facts about wage inequality found in Brazil also hold for Sweden, particularly regarding the role of between-firm wage differences as a mechanism through which trade affects wage inequality?
answer: Many of the stylized facts about wage inequality found for Brazil also hold for Sweden, with much of overall wage inequality arising within sector-occupations and for workers with similar observable characteristics. However, Sweden shows a smaller contribution from between-firm wage differences, likely due to Swedish labor market institutions and collective wage agreements that dampen wage variation between firms.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on recent theories of firm heterogeneity, particularly Helpman et al. (2012), by testing whether their findings about wage inequality mechanisms in Brazil generalize to a different institutional context (Sweden), using similar linked employer-employee data methodology to examine between-firm wage differences as a source of inequality.

author: Stephen Redding
title: The Economics of Density: Evidence From the Berlin Wall
abstract: This paper develops a quantitative model of internal city structure that features agglomeration and dispersion forces and an arbitrary number of heterogeneous city blocks. The model remains tractable and amenable to empirical analysis because of stochastic shocks to commuting decisions, which yield a gravity equation for commuting flows. To structurally estimate agglomeration and dispersion forces, we use data on thousands of city blocks in Berlin for 1936, 1986, and 2006 and exogenous variation from the city's division and reunification. We estimate substantial and highly localized production and residential externalities. We show that the model with the estimated agglomeration parameters can account both qualitatively and quantitatively for the observed changes in city structure. We show how our quantitative framework can be used to undertake counterfactuals for changes in the organization of economic activity within cities in response, for example, to changes in the transport network.

author: Sule Alan
title: Empowering Adolescents to Transform Schools: Lessons from a Behavioral Targeting
abstract: <jats:p> We test the effectiveness of a behavioral program grounded in the idea that status granting and self-persuasion might yield a robust behavioral change in disadvantaged adolescents. We enlist socially connected senior middle school students with high emotional intelligence as “student-teachers” and entrust them with delivering a curriculum to their junior peers. The program empowers student-teachers, leading them to improve their social environment. It reduces disciplinary incidents and antisocial behavior among student-teachers and their friendship networks. The intervention significantly enhances the likelihood of admission to selective high schools for student-teachers, offering a cost-effective way to help disadvantaged adolescents escape neighborhood disadvantages. (JEL H52, I21, I24, I28, J13, O15) </jats:p>
research_question: Can a behavioral program that grants status to socially connected adolescents and engages them in self-persuasion through teaching younger peers effectively transform school environments and outcomes for disadvantaged students?
answer: Yes, the program is effective - it reduces disciplinary incidents and antisocial behavior among student-teachers and their networks, and significantly enhances the likelihood of admission to selective high schools for student-teachers, providing a cost-effective intervention for disadvantaged adolescents.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by testing a novel behavioral intervention grounded in status granting and self-persuasion theory, specifically targeting disadvantaged adolescents through a peer-to-peer teaching model that leverages social connections and emotional intelligence.

author: Sule Alan
title: Nurturing Childhood Curiosity to Enhance Learning: Evidence from a Randomized Pedagogical Intervention
abstract: <jats:p> We evaluate a pedagogical intervention aimed at improving learning in elementary school children by fostering their curiosity. We test the effectiveness of the pedagogy using achievement scores and a novel measure of curiosity. The latter involves creating a sense of information deprivation and quantifying the urge to acquire information and retention ability. The intervention increases curiosity, knowledge retention, and science test scores, with the effects persisting into middle school years. It also leads to more information sharing and peer learning in the classroom. The evidence can help design better pedagogical tools to increase pupil engagement and the quality of learning. (JEL D83, I21, I26, J13, O15) </jats:p>
research_question: Can a pedagogical intervention that fosters curiosity improve learning outcomes in elementary school children?
answer: Yes, the pedagogical intervention successfully increases curiosity, knowledge retention, and science test scores, with effects persisting into middle school years, and also promotes more information sharing and peer learning in the classroom.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing empirical evidence on curiosity-based pedagogy using both traditional achievement measures and a novel measure of curiosity that quantifies information-seeking behavior, offering insights for designing better pedagogical tools to enhance pupil engagement and learning quality.

author: Steve Redding
title: Asset Markets and Endogenous Liquidity
abstract: <jats:p>In financial markets characterized by imperfect depth, speculative trading will have transitory effects on the market price as market makers must be compensated for the risk of holding the asset. The number of people providing liquidity to a market will generally be endogenously determined by the quantity of liquidity demanded. This paper looks for evidence of endogenous liquidity provision in several international stock and bond markets. Evidence shows strong support for these speculative dynamics in the stock markets. The evidence for these dynamics is less striking with fixed‐income prices, consistent with the less speculative nature of these markets.</jats:p>
research_question: Do financial markets exhibit endogenous liquidity provision where the number of liquidity providers adjusts based on the quantity of liquidity demanded, and does this create speculative trading dynamics with transitory price effects?
answer: Yes, there is strong evidence of endogenous liquidity provision and speculative dynamics in stock markets, where speculative trading has transitory effects on prices as market makers require compensation for risk. The evidence is weaker in fixed-income markets, which is consistent with their less speculative nature.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on market microstructure and liquidity provision by empirically testing the theoretical prediction that liquidity provision is endogenously determined by liquidity demand, examining this relationship across different asset classes (stocks and bonds) in international markets.

author: Sule Alan
title: Improving Workplace Climate in Large Corporations: A Clustered Randomized Intervention
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We evaluate the impact of a training program aimed at improving the relational atmosphere in the workplace. The program encourages prosocial behavior and the use of professional language, focusing primarily on leaders’ behavior and leader-subordinate interactions. We implement this program using a clustered randomized design involving over 3,000 headquarters employees of 20 large corporations in Turkey. We evaluate the program with respect to employee separation, pro- and antisocial behavior, the prevalence of support networks, and perceived workplace climate. We find that treated firms have a lower likelihood of employee separation at the leadership level, fewer employees lacking professional and personal help, and denser, less segregated support networks. We also find that employees in treated corporations are less inclined to engage in toxic competition, exhibit higher reciprocity toward each other, and report higher workplace satisfaction and a more collegial environment. The program’s success in improving leader-subordinate relationships emerges as a likely mechanism to explain these results. Treated subordinates report higher professionalism and empathy in their leaders and are more likely to consider their leaders as professional support providers.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of a training program aimed at improving the relational atmosphere in the workplace, particularly focusing on leaders' behavior and leader-subordinate interactions?
answer: The training program successfully improved workplace climate by reducing employee separation at the leadership level, creating denser and less segregated support networks, reducing toxic competition, increasing reciprocity among employees, and improving workplace satisfaction and collegiality, with the mechanism being improved leader-subordinate relationships.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing rigorous experimental evidence on workplace climate interventions using a clustered randomized design across multiple large corporations, focusing specifically on leader behavior training as a mechanism for improving organizational outcomes.

author: Sule Alan
title: Income and Consumption: A Micro Semistructural Analysis with Pervasive Heterogeneity

author: Sule Alan
title: Ever Failed, Try Again, Succeed Better: Results from a Randomized Educational Intervention on Grit
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that grit, a skill that has been shown to be highly predictive of achievement, is malleable in childhood and can be fostered in the classroom environment. We evaluate a randomized educational intervention implemented in two independent elementary school samples. Outcomes are measured via a novel incentivized real-effort task and performance in standardized tests. We find that treated students are more likely to exert effort to accumulate task-specific ability and hence more likely to succeed. In a follow up 2.5 years after the intervention, we estimate an effect of about 0.2 standard deviations on a standardized math test.</jats:p>
research_question: Can grit be developed in childhood through educational interventions in the classroom environment?
answer: Yes, grit is malleable in childhood and can be fostered through classroom interventions. Treated students showed increased effort exertion, higher likelihood of success, and sustained improvements of 0.2 standard deviations on standardized math tests 2.5 years after the intervention.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on existing literature that has established grit as highly predictive of achievement by demonstrating that this skill can be actively developed rather than being fixed, addressing a gap in understanding about the malleability of grit in educational settings.

author: Sule Alan
title: Building Social Cohesion in Ethnically Mixed Schools: An Intervention on Perspective Taking
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We evaluate the effect of an educational program that aims to build social cohesion in ethnically mixed schools by developing perspective-taking ability in children. The program is implemented in Turkish elementary schools affected by a large influx of Syrian refugee children. We measure a comprehensive set of outcomes that characterize a cohesive school environment, including peer violence incidents, the prevalence of interethnic social ties, and prosocial behavior. Using randomized variation in program implementation, we find that the program significantly lowers peer violence and victimization on school grounds. The program also reduces the likelihood of social exclusion and increases interethnic social ties in the classroom. We find that the program significantly improves prosocial behavior, measured by incentivized tasks: treated students exhibit significantly higher trust, reciprocity, and altruism toward each other as well as toward anonymous out-school peers. We show that this enhanced prosociality is welfare improving from the ex post payoff perspective. We investigate multiple channels that could explain the results, including ethnic bias, impulsivity, empathetic concern, emotional intelligence, behavioral norms, and perspective taking. Children’s increased effort to take others’ perspectives emerges as the most robust mechanism to explain our results.</jats:p>
research_question: Can an educational program that develops perspective-taking ability in children build social cohesion in ethnically mixed schools?
answer: Yes, the perspective-taking program significantly improves social cohesion by reducing peer violence and victimization, decreasing social exclusion, increasing interethnic social ties, and enhancing prosocial behaviors including trust, reciprocity, and altruism among students.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on social cohesion in diverse educational settings by providing experimental evidence on the effectiveness of perspective-taking interventions, specifically in the context of Turkish elementary schools with Syrian refugee children, and by comprehensively measuring multiple dimensions of social cohesion including violence, social ties, and prosocial behavior.

author: Séverine Toussaert
title: Eliciting Temptation and Self-Control Through Menu Choices: A Lab Experiment
abstract: Unlike present‐biased individuals, agents who suffer self‐control costs as in Gul and Pesendorfer, 2001 may choose to restrict their choice set even when they expect to resist temptation. To identify these self‐control types, I design an experiment in which the temptation was to read a story during a tedious task. The identification strategy relies on a two‐step procedure. First, I measure commitment demand by eliciting subjects' preferences over menus that did or did not allow access to the story. I then implement preferences using a random mechanism, allowing to observe subjects who faced the choice yet preferred commitment. A quarter to a third of subjects can be classified as self‐control types according to their menu preferences. When confronted with the choice, virtually all of them behaved as they anticipated and resisted temptation. These findings suggest that policies restricting the availability of tempting options could have larger welfare benefits than predicted by standard models of present bias.
