author: Tarun Ramadorai
title: Do the Rich Get Richer in the Stock Market? Evidence from India
abstract: <jats:p> We use data on Indian stock portfolios to show that return heterogeneity is the primary contributor to increasing inequality of wealth held in risky assets by Indian individual investors. Return heterogeneity increases equity wealth inequality through two main channels, both of which are related to the prevalence of undiversified accounts that own relatively few stocks. First, some undiversified portfolios randomly do well, while others randomly do poorly. Second, larger accounts diversify more effectively and thereby earn higher average log returns even though their average simple returns are no higher than those of smaller accounts. (JEL D14, D31, G11, O16) </jats:p>
research_question: Do the rich get richer in the stock market, and what drives increasing inequality of wealth held in risky assets among individual investors?
answer: Return heterogeneity is the primary contributor to increasing inequality of wealth held in risky assets, operating through two channels: random performance differences among undiversified portfolios, and more effective diversification by larger accounts leading to higher average log returns.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on wealth inequality and portfolio choice by providing empirical evidence from Indian stock market data, specifically focusing on how return heterogeneity and portfolio diversification patterns among individual investors drive wealth inequality in risky assets.

author: Tarun Ramadorai
title: Reference Dependence in the Housing Market
abstract: <jats:p> We quantify reference dependence and loss aversion in the housing market using rich Danish administrative data. Our structural model includes loss aversion, reference dependence, financial constraints, and a sale decision, and matches key nonparametric moments, including a “hockey stick” in listing prices with nominal gains, and bunching at zero realized nominal gains. Households derive substantial utility from gains over the original house purchase price; losses affect households roughly 2.5 times more than gains. The model helps explain the positive correlation between aggregate house prices and turnover, but cannot explain visible attenuation in reference dependence when households are more financially constrained. (JEL D12, D91, G51, R21, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we quantify reference dependence and loss aversion in the housing market, and what are the magnitudes of these behavioral effects on household decision-making?
answer: Households derive substantial utility from gains over their original house purchase price, with losses affecting households roughly 2.5 times more than gains. The model successfully explains the positive correlation between aggregate house prices and turnover, but reference dependence attenuates when households face greater financial constraints.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing the first structural quantification of reference dependence and loss aversion in housing markets using comprehensive administrative data, building on existing behavioral economics research while incorporating financial constraints and matching key empirical patterns like the 'hockey stick' in listing prices and bunching at zero nominal gains.

author: Tavneet Suri
title: Risk Sharing and Transactions Costs: Evidence from Kenya's Mobile Money Revolution
abstract: <jats:p> We explore the impact of reduced transaction costs on risk sharing by estimating the effects of a mobile money innovation on consumption. In our panel sample, adoption of the innovation increased from 43 to 70 percent. We find that, while shocks reduce consumption by 7 percent for nonusers, the consumption of user households is unaffected. The mechanisms underlying these consumption effects are increases in remittances received and the diversity of senders. We report robustness checks supporting these results and use the four-fold expansion of the mobile money agent network as a source of exogenous variation in access to the innovation. (JEL E42, G22, O16, O17, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of reduced transaction costs on risk sharing, specifically through the effects of mobile money innovation on consumption?
answer: Mobile money adoption significantly improves risk sharing - while shocks reduce consumption by 7 percent for nonusers, the consumption of user households is unaffected by shocks. This protection occurs through increased remittances received and greater diversity of remittance senders.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on risk sharing and transaction costs by providing empirical evidence from Kenya's mobile money revolution, using the four-fold expansion of the mobile money agent network as exogenous variation to identify causal effects of financial innovation on consumption smoothing.

author: Tarun Ramadorai
title: Sources of Inaction in Household Finance: Evidence from the Danish Mortgage Market
abstract: <jats:p> We build an empirical model to attribute delays in mortgage refinancing to psychological costs inhibiting refinancing until incentives are sufficiently strong; and behavior, potentially attributable to information-gathering costs, lowering the probability of household refinancing per unit time at any incentive. We estimate the model on administrative panel data from Denmark, where mortgage refinancing without cash-out is unconstrained. Middle-aged and wealthy households act as if they have high psychological refinancing costs; but older, poorer, and less-educated households refinance with lower probability irrespective of incentives, thereby achieving lower savings. We use the model to understand frictions in the mortgage channel of monetary policy transmission. (JEL E52, G21, G51, R31) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the sources of household inaction in mortgage refinancing, specifically distinguishing between psychological costs that create refinancing thresholds and behavioral factors that reduce refinancing probability regardless of incentives?
answer: Household refinancing delays stem from two distinct sources: (1) psychological costs that prevent middle-aged and wealthy households from refinancing until incentives become sufficiently strong, and (2) behavioral factors (potentially related to information-gathering costs) that cause older, poorer, and less-educated households to refinance with lower probability at any incentive level, resulting in lower savings.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the household finance literature by developing an empirical model that separates psychological refinancing costs from information-related behavioral factors, using unique administrative data from Denmark's unconstrained mortgage market to provide cleaner identification of refinancing frictions and their implications for monetary policy transmission.

author: Tavneet Suri
title: Transaction Networks: Evidence from Mobile Money in Kenya
abstract: <jats:p> Mobile money allows households in Kenya to spread risk more efficiently. In this paper we show that these efficiencies are achieved through deeper financial integration and expanded informal networks. Active networks are more geographically dispersed and support more reciprocal financial arrangements. Consistent with the reported reciprocity, mobile money users report a higher share of transactions as being for credit and insurance purposes. </jats:p>
research_question: How does mobile money enable households in Kenya to spread risk more efficiently through their transaction networks?
answer: Mobile money enables more efficient risk spreading through deeper financial integration and expanded informal networks that are more geographically dispersed and support more reciprocal financial arrangements, with users reporting a higher share of transactions for credit and insurance purposes.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by demonstrating the specific mechanisms through which mobile money improves risk sharing - namely through network expansion and increased reciprocity in financial arrangements, rather than just documenting that mobile money improves financial outcomes.

author: Tavneet Suri
title: Credit Access, Selection, and Incentives in a Market for Asset-Collateralized Loans: Evidence From Kenya
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the potential for asset collateralization to expand access to credit in rural Kenya. Increasing the share of a loan for a durable agricultural asset that is collateralized by the physical asset itself (from 0 to 96%) while reducing the share backed by financial assets increases loan take-up considerably, with only a very limited impact on repayment behavior and the lender's profitability. A Karlan–Zinman test finds evidence of small and marginally significant selection effects in some specifications but no evidence of moral hazard. We find no evidence that joint versus individual liability affects take-up or repayment. Loans had real impacts on investment, milk sales, and girls’ school enrollment. The lender, a savings and credit cooperative, responded to the study results by offering 80% asset-collateralized loans.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the potential for asset collateralization to expand access to credit in rural Kenya, and how does varying the share of loans collateralized by physical assets versus financial assets affect loan take-up, repayment behavior, and lender profitability?
answer: Increasing the share of loans collateralized by physical assets (from 0 to 96%) while reducing financial asset backing significantly increases loan take-up with minimal impact on repayment behavior and lender profitability. There is evidence of small selection effects but no moral hazard, and the loans generate positive real impacts on investment, milk sales, and girls' school enrollment.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on credit access in developing countries by providing empirical evidence on asset collateralization as a mechanism to expand credit access, using a Karlan-Zinman methodology to distinguish between selection and moral hazard effects, and examining both individual versus joint liability structures in the context of rural agricultural lending.

author: Teodora Boneva
title: Determinants of Women’s Career Paths in Professional Accounting Leadership at the European Union and National Level
abstract:
<jats:p>The changes that have taken place both at the European Union level
with the accession of the Member States and at the national level (for Romania) in the post-communist period have had economic, social, and political influences. In this article, we have analyzed the determinants of women’s pathways into professional accounting leadership at the European Union and national levels. The path of women in leadership is the subject of the analysis of the gender equality topic, which has become increasingly established in recent times, so the professional path of women is largely influenced by existing stereotypes. Based on literature review, we identified several factors that hinder and actions that support women’s professional path. The relevance of the results is attributed to the timing and context of the analysis (Europe), illustrating whether the representation of women in top positions is based on meritocracy.</jats:p>
venue: Virgil Madgearu Review of Economic Studies and Research
research_question: What are the determinants of women's career paths in professional accounting leadership at the European Union and national level?
answer: Women's professional paths in accounting leadership are largely influenced by existing stereotypes, with several factors identified that both hinder and support women's advancement, and the representation of women in top positions may not be based purely on meritocracy.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself within the growing literature on gender equality by analyzing women's leadership paths in the specific context of professional accounting in Europe, particularly examining the influence of economic, social, and political changes following EU expansion and post-communist transitions at the national level (Romania).

author: Teodora Boneva
title: Ever Failed, Try Again, Succeed Better: Results from a Randomized Educational Intervention on Grit
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that grit, a skill that has been shown to be highly predictive of achievement, is malleable in childhood and can be fostered in the classroom environment. We evaluate a randomized educational intervention implemented in two independent elementary school samples. Outcomes are measured via a novel incentivized real-effort task and performance in standardized tests. We find that treated students are more likely to exert effort to accumulate task-specific ability and hence more likely to succeed. In a follow up 2.5 years after the intervention, we estimate an effect of about 0.2 standard deviations on a standardized math test.</jats:p>
research_question: Can grit be developed in childhood through educational interventions in the classroom environment?
answer: Yes, grit is malleable in childhood and can be fostered through classroom interventions. Treated students showed increased effort exertion, higher likelihood of success, and sustained improvements of 0.2 standard deviations on standardized math tests 2.5 years after the intervention.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on existing literature that has established grit as highly predictive of achievement by demonstrating that this skill can be actively developed rather than being fixed, addressing a gap in understanding about the malleability of grit in educational settings.

author: Terri Kneeland
title: Identifying Higher-Order Rationality
abstract: Strategic choice data from a carefully chosen set of ring‐network games are used to obtain individual‐level estimates of higher‐order rationality. The experimental design exploits a natural exclusion restriction that is considerably weaker than the assumptions underlying alternative designs in the literature. In our data set, 93 percent of subjects are rational, 71 percent are rational and believe others are rational, 44 percent are rational and hold second‐order beliefs that others are rational, and 22 percent are rational and hold at least third‐order beliefs that others are rational.

author: Thomas Chaney
title: Distorted Gravity: The Intensive and Extensive Margins of International Trade
abstract: <jats:p> By considering a model with identical firms, Krugman (1980) predicts that a higher elasticity of substitution between goods magnifies the impact of trade barriers on trade flows. In this paper, I introduce firm heterogeneity in a simple model of international trade. I prove that the extensive margin and the intensive margin are affected by the elasticity of substitution in exact opposite directions. When the distribution of productivity across firms is Pareto, the predictions of the Krugman model with representative firms are overturned: the impact of trade barriers on trade flows is dampened by the elasticity of substitution, and not magnified. (JEL F12, F13) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the elasticity of substitution between goods affect the impact of trade barriers on trade flows when firm heterogeneity is introduced into international trade models?
answer: When firm heterogeneity is introduced with a Pareto distribution of productivity, the extensive margin and intensive margin are affected by the elasticity of substitution in opposite directions, and the impact of trade barriers on trade flows is dampened (not magnified) by the elasticity of substitution, overturning the predictions of the Krugman model with identical firms.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the Krugman (1980) model's prediction that higher elasticity of substitution magnifies the impact of trade barriers on trade flows by introducing firm heterogeneity instead of assuming identical firms, demonstrating that this key assumption leads to opposite conclusions about how elasticity of substitution affects trade.

author: Thomas Chaney
title: The Network Structure of International Trade
abstract: <jats:p> Motivated by empirical evidence I uncover on the dynamics of French firms' exports, I offer a novel theory of trade frictions. Firms export only into markets where they have a contact. They search directly for new trading partners, but also use their existing network of contacts to search remotely for new partners. I characterize the dynamic formation of an international network of exporters in this model. Structurally, I estimate this model on French data and confirm its predictions regarding the distribution of the number of foreign markets accessed by exporters and the geographic distribution of exports. (JEL D85, F11, F14, L24) </jats:p>
research_question: How do firms form international trading networks and what role do existing contacts play in accessing new export markets?
answer: Firms export only to markets where they have contacts, and they expand their export networks both through direct search for new trading partners and by leveraging their existing network of contacts to search remotely for new partners in connected markets.
positioning_statement: This paper offers a novel theory of trade frictions that differs from existing literature by focusing on network-based explanations for international trade patterns, motivated by new empirical evidence on the dynamics of French firms' exports that existing theories may not adequately explain.

author: Thomas Chaney
title: The Collateral Channel: How Real Estate Shocks Affect Corporate Investment
abstract: <jats:p> What is the impact of real estate prices on corporate investment? In the presence of financing frictions, firms use pledgeable assets as collateral to finance new projects. Through this collateral channel, shocks to the value of real estate can have a large impact on aggregate investment. To compute the sensitivity of investment to collateral value, we use local variations in real estate prices as shocks to the collateral value of firms that own real estate. Over the 1993–2007 period, the representative US corporation invests $0.06 out of each $1 of collateral. (JEL D22, G31, R30) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of real estate prices on corporate investment?
answer: The representative US corporation invests $0.06 out of each $1 of collateral, demonstrating that real estate shocks have a significant impact on aggregate investment through the collateral channel where firms use pledgeable real estate assets as collateral to finance new projects.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on financing frictions by identifying and quantifying the collateral channel mechanism, using local variations in real estate prices as an empirical strategy to measure how shocks to collateral value affect corporate investment decisions.

author: Thomas Chaney
title: Trade, Merchants, and the Lost Cities of the Bronze Age*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We analyze a large data set of commercial records produced by Assyrian merchants in the nineteenth century BCE. Using the information from these records, we estimate a structural gravity model of long-distance trade in the Bronze Age. We use our structural gravity model to locate lost ancient cities. In many cases, our estimates confirm the conjectures of historians who follow different methodologies. In some instances, our estimates confirm one conjecture against others. We also structurally estimate ancient city sizes and offer evidence in support of the hypothesis that large cities tend to emerge at the intersections of natural transport routes, as dictated by topography. Finally, we document persistent patterns in the distribution of city sizes across four millennia, find a distance elasticity of trade in the Bronze Age close to modern estimates, and show suggestive evidence that the distribution of ancient city sizes, inferred from trade data, is well approximated by Zipf’s law.</jats:p>
research_question: Can a structural gravity model of long-distance trade be used to locate lost ancient cities and understand urban development patterns in the Bronze Age using Assyrian merchant records from the 19th century BCE?
answer: Yes, the structural gravity model successfully locates lost ancient cities, often confirming historians' conjectures, and reveals that large cities emerged at intersections of natural transport routes. The model also shows persistent city size distribution patterns across four millennia, with Bronze Age trade distance elasticity similar to modern estimates and ancient city sizes following Zipf's law.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel quantitative approach to ancient economic history by applying modern structural gravity modeling to Bronze Age trade data, complementing and validating traditional historical methodologies while providing new empirical evidence for long-standing hypotheses about urban development and trade patterns.

author: Thomas Chaney
title: Migrants, Ancestors, and Foreign Investments
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use 130 years of data on historical migrations to the U.S. to show a causal effect of the ancestry composition of U.S. counties on foreign direct investment (FDI) sent and received by local firms. To isolate the causal effect of ancestry on FDI, we build a simple reduced-form model of migrations: Migrations from a foreign country to a U.S. county at a given time depend on (1) a push factor, causing emigration from that foreign country to the entire U.S., and (2) a pull factor, causing immigration from all origins into that U.S. county. The interaction between time-series variation in origin-specific push factors and destination-specific pull factors generates quasi-random variation in the allocation of migrants across U.S. counties. We find that doubling the number of residents with ancestry from a given foreign country relative to the mean increases the probability that at least one local firm engages in FDI with that country by 4 percentage points. We present evidence that this effect is primarily driven by a reduction in information frictions, and not by better contract enforcement, taste similarities, or a convergence in factor endowments.</jats:p>
research_question: Does the ancestry composition of U.S. counties causally affect foreign direct investment (FDI) flows between local firms and the ancestral countries of origin?
answer: There is a causal effect of ancestry composition on FDI - doubling the number of residents with ancestry from a given foreign country increases the probability that at least one local firm engages in FDI with that country by 4 percentage points, primarily through reducing information frictions.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by establishing a causal relationship between historical migration patterns and FDI flows using 130 years of migration data and a novel identification strategy that exploits quasi-random variation from the interaction of origin-specific push factors and destination-specific pull factors in migration patterns.

author: Thomas Le Barbanchon
title: Gender Differences in Job Search: Trading off COMMUTE AGAINST WAGE*
abstract: <jats:title>ABSTRACT</jats:title><jats:p>We relate gender differences in willingness to commute to the gender wage gap. Using French administrative data on job search criteria, we first document that unemployed women have a lower reservation wage and a shorter maximum acceptable commute than their male counterparts. We identify indifference curves between wage and commute using the joint distributions of reservation job attributes and accepted job bundles. Indifference curves are steeper for women, who value commute around 20% more than men. Controlling in particular for the previous job, newly hired women are paid after unemployment 4% less per hour and have a 12% shorter commute than men. Through the lens of a job search model where commuting matters, we estimate that gender differences in commute valuation can account for a 0.5 log point hourly wage deficit for women, that is, 14% of the residualized gender wage gap. Finally, we use job application data to test the robustness of our results and to show that female workers do not receive less demand from far-away employers, confirming that most of the gender gap in commute is supply-side driven.</jats:p>
research_question: How do gender differences in willingness to commute relate to the gender wage gap?
answer: Women value shorter commutes around 20% more than men, and these gender differences in commute valuation can account for 0.5 log point (14%) of the residualized gender wage gap, with newly hired women earning 4% less per hour but having 12% shorter commutes than men.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the gender wage gap literature by introducing commuting preferences as an explanatory factor, using a job search model framework and French administrative data to quantify how the trade-off between wages and commute distance affects gender pay differences.

author: Thomas Chaney
title: The Immigrant Next Door
abstract: <jats:p> We study how decades-long exposure to individuals of a given foreign descent shapes natives’ attitudes and behavior toward that group. Using individualized donations data, we show that long-term exposure to a given foreign ancestry leads to more generous behavior specifically toward that group’s ancestral country. Focusing on exposure to Arab Muslims to examine mechanisms, we show that long-term exposure (i) decreases explicit and implicit prejudice against Arab Muslims, (ii) reduces support for policies and political candidates hostile toward Arab Muslims, (iii) increases charitable donations to Arab countries, (iv) leads to more personal contact with Arab Muslims, and (v) increases knowledge of Arab Muslims and Islam. (JEL D64, D83, D91, J15) </jats:p>
research_question: How does decades-long exposure to individuals of a given foreign descent shape natives' attitudes and behavior toward that group?
answer: Long-term exposure to foreign ancestry groups leads to more generous behavior toward those groups' ancestral countries, decreases prejudice, reduces support for hostile policies, increases charitable donations, promotes personal contact, and increases knowledge about the groups.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on intergroup contact and prejudice by examining long-term exposure effects using individualized donations data and focusing specifically on mechanisms through the case of Arab Muslims, providing empirical evidence for how sustained contact shapes attitudes and behaviors toward foreign ancestry groups.

author: Thomas Lemieux
title: Postsecondary Education and Increasing Wage Inequality

author: Thomas Lemieux
title: Increasing Residual Wage Inequality: Composition Effects, Noisy Data, or Rising Demand for Skill?
abstract: <jats:p> This paper shows that a large fraction of the 1973–2003 growth in residual wage inequality is due to composition effects linked to the secular increase in experience and education, two factors associated with higher within-group wage dispersion. The level and growth in residual wage inequality are also overstated in the March Current Population Survey (CPS) because, unlike the May or Outgoing Rotation Group (ORG) CPS, it does not measure directly the hourly wages of workers paid by the hour. The magnitude and timing of the growth in residual wage inequality provide little evidence of a pervasive increase in the demand for skill due to skill-biased technological change. </jats:p>
research_question: What factors explain the growth in residual wage inequality between 1973-2003, and is it primarily driven by rising demand for skill due to skill-biased technological change?
answer: A large fraction of the growth in residual wage inequality is due to composition effects from increases in experience and education (which are associated with higher within-group wage dispersion) and measurement issues in the March CPS data, rather than a pervasive increase in demand for skill due to skill-biased technological change.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the prevailing skill-biased technological change explanation for rising wage inequality by demonstrating that compositional changes and data measurement issues account for much of the observed increase in residual wage inequality, providing little evidence for pervasive skill-biased demand shifts.

author: Thomas Lemieux
title: Contract Form, Wage Flexibility, and Employment
abstract: <jats:p> We begin with two uncontroversial hypotheses - firm productivity is expensive to measure and employment entails relationship-specific investments. These assumptions imply that firms would optimally choose fixed-wage contracts, and complement these with bonus pay when measuring employee performance is not too costly. These assumptions imply that under an optimal employment contract hours of work is less responsive, while total compensation is more responsive to shocks under bonus-pay contracts compared to fixed wage contracts. Using data from the Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID) where shocks are proxied using the local unemployment rate, we find strong support for these two implications. </jats:p>
research_question: How do different contract forms (fixed-wage vs. bonus-pay contracts) affect wage flexibility and employment responsiveness to economic shocks?
answer: Under optimal employment contracts, hours of work are less responsive to shocks under bonus-pay contracts compared to fixed-wage contracts, while total compensation is more responsive to shocks under bonus-pay contracts compared to fixed-wage contracts.
positioning_statement: The paper builds on two established assumptions in the literature - that firm productivity is expensive to measure and employment involves relationship-specific investments - to derive new theoretical implications about optimal contract choice and empirically test these predictions using PSID data.

author: Thomas Lemieux
title: Performance Pay and Wage Inequality<sup>*</sup>
abstract: This paper examines the link between the increased use of performance pay and the growth in wage inequality, using data from the Panel Study of Income Dynamics (PSID) from 1976 to 1998. I find that the increased use of performance pay can account for 24 percent of the growth in the variance of male wages, and an even larger fraction of the growth in wage inequality at the top end of the wage distribution (above the 80th percentile). The paper also shows that much of the increase in wage inequality attributed to performance pay is linked to occupational and industrial factors. In particular, the increased use of performance pay in managerial occupations and in the finance, insurance, and real estate sector accounts for a disproportionate share of the growth in wage inequality.

author: Thomas Philippon
title: Has the US Finance Industry Become Less Efficient? On the Theory and Measurement of Financial Intermediation
abstract: <jats:p> A quantitative investigation of financial intermediation in the United States over the past 130 years yields the following results: (i) the finance industry's share of gross domestic product (GDP) is high in the 1920s, low in the 1960s, and high again after 1980; (ii) most of these variations can be explained by corresponding changes in the quantity of intermediated assets (equity, household and corporate debt, liquidity); (iii) intermediation has constant returns to scale and an annual cost of 1.5–2 percent of intermediated assets; (iv) secular changes in the characteristics of firms and households are quantitatively important. (JEL D24, E44, G21, G32, N22) </jats:p>
research_question: Has the efficiency of the US finance industry changed over time, and what explains the variations in financial intermediation costs and the finance industry's share of GDP over the past 130 years?
answer: The US finance industry has maintained relatively constant efficiency with intermediation costs of 1.5-2% of intermediated assets annually and constant returns to scale. Variations in the finance industry's GDP share (high in 1920s, low in 1960s, high again after 1980) are primarily explained by changes in the quantity of intermediated assets rather than changes in efficiency.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a comprehensive quantitative investigation of US financial intermediation over 130 years, offering a theory and measurement framework to explain long-term variations in the finance industry's economic role through asset quantity changes rather than efficiency changes.

author: Thomas Philippon
title: Inspecting the Mechanism: Leverage and the Great Recession in the Eurozone
abstract: <jats:p> We provide a comprehensive account of the dynamics of eurozone countries from 2000 to 2012. We analyze private leverage, fiscal policy, labor costs, and spreads, and we propose a model and an identification strategy to separate the impact of credit cycles, excessive government spending, and sudden stops. We then ask how periphery countries would have fared with different policies. We find that countries could have stabilized their employment if they had followed more conservative fiscal policies during the boom. Macroprudential policies and an early intervention by the central bank to prevent market segmentation and reduce fiscal austerity would also have significantly reduced the recession. (JEL E24, E32, E58, E62, F33, F42, H61) </jats:p>
research_question: How did different mechanisms (credit cycles, excessive government spending, and sudden stops) contribute to the Great Recession dynamics in eurozone countries, and how would alternative policies have affected outcomes?
answer: Countries could have stabilized employment through more conservative fiscal policies during the boom period, and the recession could have been significantly reduced through macroprudential policies and early central bank intervention to prevent market segmentation and reduce fiscal austerity.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a comprehensive account that separates and quantifies the distinct impacts of multiple mechanisms (credit cycles, government spending, sudden stops) during the eurozone crisis, offering a model and identification strategy to analyze counterfactual policy scenarios.

author: Thomas Philippon
title: Optimal Interventions in Markets with Adverse Selection
abstract: <jats:p> We study the design of interventions to stabilize financial markets plagued by adverse selection. Our contribution is to analyze the information revealed by participation decisions. Taking part in a government program carries a stigma, and outside options are mechanism dependent. We show that the efficiency of an intervention can be assessed by its impact on the market interest rate. The presence of an outside market determines the nature of optimal interventions and the choice of financial instruments (debt guarantees in our model), but it does not affect implementation costs. (JEL D82, D86, G01, G20, G31) </jats:p>
research_question: How should interventions be designed to stabilize financial markets plagued by adverse selection, particularly considering the information revealed by participation decisions and the stigma associated with taking part in government programs?
answer: The efficiency of an intervention can be assessed by its impact on the market interest rate. The presence of an outside market determines the nature of optimal interventions and the choice of financial instruments (debt guarantees), but it does not affect implementation costs.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on market interventions by specifically analyzing the information revealed by participation decisions, incorporating the stigma effect of government program participation, and examining how outside options are mechanism dependent - aspects that have not been comprehensively addressed in prior work on adverse selection in financial markets.

author: Thomas Philippon
title: Let the Worst One Fail: A Credible Solution to the Too-Big-To-Fail Conundrum
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study time-consistent bank resolution mechanisms. The key constraint is that governments cannot avoid bailouts that are ex post efficient. Contrary to common wisdom, we show that the government may still avoid moral hazard and implement the first-best allocation by using the distribution of bailouts across banks to provide incentives. We analyze properties of credible tournament mechanisms that provide support to the best-performing banks and resolve the worst-performing ones. We extend our mechanism and show that it continues to perform well when banks are imperfect substitutes, when they are differentially interconnected as long as bailout funds can be earmarked, and when their risk-taking is driven by overoptimism instead of moral hazard.</jats:p>
research_question: How can governments design time-consistent bank resolution mechanisms that avoid moral hazard and implement first-best allocation while being constrained by the inability to avoid ex post efficient bailouts?
answer: The government can avoid moral hazard and implement the first-best allocation by using credible tournament mechanisms that distribute bailouts across banks to provide incentives - specifically, supporting the best-performing banks while resolving the worst-performing ones.
positioning_statement: Contrary to common wisdom that suggests governments cannot solve the too-big-to-fail problem due to ex post bailout incentives, this paper shows that strategic use of bailout distribution across banks can still achieve optimal outcomes and resolve the moral hazard problem.

author: Thomas Philippon
title: Household Leverage and the Recession
abstract: <jats:p>We evaluate and partially challenge the household leverage view of the Great Recession. In the data, employment and consumption declined more in U.S. states where household debt declined more. We study a model of a monetary union composed of many regions in which liquidity constraints shape the response of employment and consumption to changes in debt. We estimate the model with Bayesian methods combining state and aggregate data. Changes in household credit explain 40% of the differential rise and fall of employment across states, but a small fraction of the aggregate employment decline in 2007–2010. Nevertheless, since household deleveraging was gradual, credit shocks greatly slowed the recovery.</jats:p>
research_question: What role did household leverage and deleveraging play in explaining employment and consumption patterns during the Great Recession, both across different U.S. states and at the aggregate level?
answer: Changes in household credit explained 40% of the differential employment changes across states but only a small fraction of the aggregate employment decline during 2007-2010. However, because household deleveraging was gradual, credit shocks significantly slowed the economic recovery.
positioning_statement: This paper evaluates and partially challenges the household leverage view of the Great Recession by using a monetary union model with liquidity constraints and Bayesian estimation methods that combine both state-level and aggregate data to provide a more nuanced understanding of credit's role.

author: Thomas Philippon
title: Competing on Speed
abstract: We analyze trading speed and fragmentation in asset markets. In our model, trading venues make technological investments and compete for investors who choose where and how much to trade. Faster venues charge higher fees and attract speed‐sensitive investors. Competition among venues increases investor participation, trading volume, and allocative efficiency, but entry and fragmentation can be excessive, and speeds are generically inefficient. Regulations that protect transaction prices (e.g., Securities and Exchange Commission trade‐through rule) lead to greater fragmentation. Our model sheds light on the experience of European and U.S. markets since the implementation of Markets in Financial Instruments Directive and Regulation National Markets System.

author: Thomas Philippon
title: Wages and Human Capital in the U.S. Finance Industry: 1909–2006*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We study the allocation and compensation of human capital in the U.S. finance industry over the past century. Across time, space, and subsectors, we find that financial deregulation is associated with skill intensity, job complexity, and high wages for finance employees. All three measures are high before 1940 and after 1985, but not in the interim period. Workers in finance earn the same education-adjusted wages as other workers until 1990, but by 2006 the premium is 50% on average. Top executive compensation in finance follows the same pattern and timing, where the premium reaches 250%. Similar results hold for other top earners in finance. Changes in earnings risk can explain about one half of the increase in the average premium; changes in the size distribution of firms can explain about one fifth of the premium for executives.</jats:p>
research_question: How has the allocation and compensation of human capital in the U.S. finance industry evolved over the past century, and what factors explain changes in finance worker wages and premiums?
answer: Financial deregulation is associated with higher skill intensity, job complexity, and wages in finance. Finance workers earned similar education-adjusted wages as other workers until 1990, but by 2006 earned a 50% premium on average, with top executives earning a 250% premium. Changes in earnings risk explain about half of the average premium increase, while changes in firm size distribution explain about one-fifth of the executive premium.
positioning_statement: This paper provides a comprehensive century-long analysis of human capital allocation and compensation in the U.S. finance industry, examining the relationship between financial deregulation and wage premiums across different time periods, geographic locations, and finance subsectors, while quantifying the relative contributions of earnings risk and firm size changes to observed wage premiums.

author: Timo Boppart
title: Missing Growth from Creative Destruction
abstract: <jats:p> For exiting products, statistical agencies often impute inflation from surviving products. This understates growth if creatively-destroyed products improve more than surviving ones. If so, then the market share of surviving products should systematically shrink. Using entering and exiting establishments to proxy for creative destruction, we estimate missing growth in US Census data on non-farm businesses from 1983 to 2013. We find missing growth (i) equaled about one-half a percentage point per year; (ii) arose mostly from hotels and restaurants rather than manufacturing; and (iii) did not accelerate much after 2005, and therefore does not explain the sharp slowdown in growth since then. (JEL E23, E31, L14, L15, O30, O41) </jats:p>
research_question: How much economic growth is missed by statistical agencies when they impute inflation from surviving products rather than accounting for the quality improvements of creatively-destroyed (exiting) products?
answer: Missing growth from creative destruction equaled about one-half a percentage point per year in US non-farm businesses from 1983 to 2013, arose mostly from hotels and restaurants rather than manufacturing, and did not accelerate much after 2005, therefore not explaining the sharp growth slowdown since then.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a measurement problem in how statistical agencies calculate economic growth by focusing on the role of creative destruction - specifically how agencies' practice of imputing inflation from surviving products may systematically understate growth when exiting products actually improve more than surviving ones.

author: Timo Boppart
title: A Theory of Falling Growth and Rising Rents
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Growth has fallen in the U.S. amid a rise in firm concentration. Market share has shifted to low labour share firms, while within-firm labour shares have actually risen. We propose a theory linking these trends in which the driving force is falling overhead costs of spanning multiple products or a rising efficiency advantage of large firms. In response, the most efficient firms (with higher markups) spread into new product lines, thereby increasing concentration and generating a temporary burst of growth. Eventually, due to greater competition from efficient firms, within-firm markups and incentives to innovate fall. Thus our simple model can generate qualitative patterns in line with the observed trends.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we explain the simultaneous occurrence of falling growth and rising firm concentration in the U.S., particularly given that market share has shifted to low labor share firms while within-firm labor shares have actually risen?
answer: The key finding is that falling overhead costs of spanning multiple products or rising efficiency advantages of large firms drive the most efficient firms to expand into new product lines, initially boosting growth through increased concentration, but eventually reducing within-firm markups and innovation incentives due to greater competition from efficient firms, leading to slower growth.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses observed macroeconomic trends of falling U.S. growth amid rising firm concentration by proposing a novel theoretical framework that can reconcile the apparent contradiction between market share shifting to low labor share firms while within-firm labor shares have risen, filling a gap in existing literature that has struggled to explain these simultaneous patterns.

author: Timothy B. Armstrong
title: Large Market Asymptotics for Differentiated Product Demand Estimators With Economic Models of Supply
abstract: IO economists often estimate demand for differentiated products using data sets with a small number of large markets. This paper addresses the question of consistency and asymptotic distributions of instrumental variables estimates as the number of products increases in some commonly used models of demand under conditions on economic primitives. I show that, in a Bertrand–Nash equilibrium, product characteristics lose their identifying power as price instruments in the limit in certain cases, leading to inconsistent estimates. The reason is that product characteristic instruments achieve identification through correlation with markups, and, depending on the model of demand, the supply side can constrain markups to converge to a constant quickly relative to sampling error. I find that product characteristic instruments can yield consistent estimates in many of the cases I consider, but care must be taken in modeling demand and choosing instruments. A Monte Carlo study confirms that the asymptotic results are relevant in market sizes of practical importance.

author: Toni M. Whited
title: Taxes Depress Corporate Borrowing: Evidence from Private Firms
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We use variation in state corporate income tax rates to re-examine the relation between taxes and corporate leverage. Contrary to prior research, corporate leverage rises after tax cuts for small private firms. An estimated dynamic equilibrium model shows that tax cuts make capital more productive and spur the use of leverage. Tax cuts also produce more distant default thresholds and lower credit spreads. These effects outweigh the lower interest tax deduction and lead to higher optimal leverage choices, especially for firms with flexible investment policies. The presence of the interest tax deduction raises consumer welfare in equilibrium.</jats:p>
research_question: How do changes in state corporate income tax rates affect corporate leverage decisions, particularly for small private firms?
answer: Contrary to prior research, corporate leverage rises after tax cuts for small private firms because tax cuts make capital more productive and spur leverage use, with these effects outweighing the reduced value of interest tax deductions.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges prior research findings by showing an opposite relationship between taxes and corporate leverage, specifically demonstrating that tax cuts increase rather than decrease corporate borrowing for small private firms.

author: Timothy B. Armstrong
title: Optimal Inference in a Class of Regression Models
abstract: We consider the problem of constructing confidence intervals (CIs) for a linear functional of a regression function, such as its value at a point, the regression discontinuity parameter, or a regression coefficient in a linear or partly linear regression. Our main assumption is that the regression function is known to lie in a convex function class, which covers most smoothness and/or shape assumptions used in econometrics. We derive finite‐sample optimal CIs and sharp efficiency bounds under normal errors with known variance. We show that these results translate to uniform (over the function class) asymptotic results when the error distribution is not known. When the function class is centrosymmetric, these efficiency bounds imply that minimax CIs are close to efficient at smooth regression functions. This implies, in particular, that it is impossible to form CIs that are substantively tighter using data‐dependent tuning parameters, and maintain coverage over the whole function class. We specialize our results to inference on the regression discontinuity parameter, and illustrate them in simulations and an empirical application.

author: Timothy B. Armstrong
title: Finite‐Sample Optimal Estimation and Inference on Average Treatment Effects Under Unconfoundedness
abstract:
<jats:p>We consider estimation and inference on average treatment effects under unconfoundedness conditional on the realizations of the treatment variable and covariates. Given nonparametric smoothness and/or shape restrictions on the conditional mean of the outcome variable, we derive estimators and confidence intervals (CIs) that are optimal in finite samples when the regression errors are normal with known variance. In contrast to conventional CIs, our CIs use a larger critical value that explicitly takes into account the potential bias of the estimator. When the error distribution is unknown, feasible versions of our CIs are valid asymptotically, even when

research_question: How can we achieve finite-sample optimal estimation and inference on average treatment effects under unconfoundedness, particularly when conventional inference methods may fail due to lack of overlap or low smoothness conditions?
answer: The paper derives finite-sample optimal estimators and confidence intervals that explicitly account for potential bias by using larger critical values, and shows that when the conditional mean is sufficiently smooth (Lipschitz with large enough bound), the optimal estimator reduces to a matching estimator with one match. The method provides valid asymptotic inference even when √n-inference is not possible.
positioning_statement: This paper advances beyond conventional confidence intervals by developing methods that work under weaker conditions than existing approaches, specifically addressing cases where √n-inference fails due to lack of overlap or insufficient smoothness, while providing finite-sample optimality guarantees under normality assumptions and asymptotic validity more generally.

author: Trevon Logan
title: Segregation and Homeownership in the Early Twentieth Century
abstract: <jats:p> We use new county-level segregation estimates for the period of 1880 to 1940 to document a general rise in residential segregation in both urban and rural counties occurring alongside rising homeownership rates. However, we find a negative correlation between segregation and homeownership across space for both black and white households. Following Fetter (2013), we show that living in a more segregated county substantially reduced the impact of GI Bill benefits on white homeownership rates, suggesting that segregated locations potentially hindered both white and black homeownership. </jats:p>
research_question: What was the relationship between residential segregation and homeownership rates for both black and white households in the early twentieth century (1880-1940)?
answer: There was a negative correlation between segregation and homeownership across space for both black and white households, and segregated locations hindered homeownership for both racial groups, as evidenced by reduced effectiveness of GI Bill benefits on white homeownership rates in more segregated counties.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes new county-level segregation estimates for 1880-1940 and builds on Fetter (2013)'s work by using GI Bill benefits as a natural experiment to demonstrate how segregation affected homeownership outcomes for both racial groups, extending beyond previous literature that may have focused on segregation's effects on only one racial group.

author: Timothy B. Armstrong
title: Robust Empirical Bayes Confidence Intervals
abstract: <jats:p>We construct robust empirical Bayes confidence intervals (EBCIs) in a normal means problem. The intervals are centered at the usual linear empirical Bayes estimator, but use a critical value accounting for shrinkage. Parametric EBCIs that assume a normal distribution for the means (Morris (1983b)) may substantially undercover when this assumption is violated. In contrast, our EBCIs control coverage regardless of the means distribution, while remaining close in length to the parametric EBCIs when the means are indeed Gaussian. If the means are treated as fixed, our EBCIs have an average coverage guarantee: the coverage probability is at least 1 − <jats:italic>α</jats:italic>on average across the<jats:italic>n</jats:italic>EBCIs for each of the means. Our empirical application considers the effects of U.S. neighborhoods on intergenerational mobility.</jats:p>
research_question: How can we construct empirical Bayes confidence intervals that maintain proper coverage probability regardless of the underlying distribution of means in a normal means problem?
answer: The paper develops robust empirical Bayes confidence intervals (EBCIs) that use the standard linear empirical Bayes estimator but employ a critical value that accounts for shrinkage, ensuring coverage control regardless of the means distribution while maintaining similar length to parametric intervals when means are Gaussian.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses the limitation of existing parametric empirical Bayes confidence intervals from Morris (1983b) that assume normal distribution for means and may substantially undercover when this assumption is violated, by providing a robust alternative that maintains coverage guarantees without distributional assumptions.

author: Trevon Logan
title: The Evolution of Access to Public Accommodations in the United States
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>The economic analysis of racial discrimination in public accommodations is remarkably limited. To study this issue, we construct a national data set of nondiscriminatory establishments from the Negro Motorist Green Books, a travel guide published from 1936 to 1966 to aid Black Americans in finding nondiscriminatory retail and service establishments. We document patterns in the geographic spread and evolution of Green Book establishments, as well as the correlates of Green Book presence. We find that economic and social measures, as well as state laws relating to racial discrimination and antidiscrimination, were correlated with the provision of nondiscriminatory services. We then use the Green Book data to test whether market conditions and white consumer discrimination led businesses to bar Black customers prior to the Civil Rights Act of 1964. We use plausibly exogenous variation from white World War II casualties and Black migration patterns to isolate the effect of a change in the racial composition of consumers on the growth of nondiscriminatory businesses. We find that the share of nondiscriminatory establishments grew faster in locations with larger increases in the share of the Black population, but the magnitudes were small. These results highlight the importance of federal legislation in ending racial discrimination in public accommodations.</jats:p>
research_question: How did market conditions and white consumer discrimination affect businesses' decisions to bar Black customers prior to the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and what factors influenced the geographic spread and evolution of nondiscriminatory establishments?
answer: The share of nondiscriminatory establishments grew faster in locations with larger increases in the Black population share, but the magnitudes were small, highlighting that market forces alone were insufficient and federal legislation was crucial in ending racial discrimination in public accommodations.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a gap in the economic analysis of racial discrimination in public accommodations, which has been remarkably limited, by constructing a novel national dataset from the Negro Motorist Green Books to systematically study discrimination patterns and test economic theories about market-based solutions to discrimination.

author: Tyler Muir
title: Financial Crises and Risk Premia*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>I analyze the behavior of risk premia in financial crises, wars, and recessions in an international panel spanning over 140 years and 14 countries. I document that expected returns, or risk premia, increase substantially in financial crises, but not in the other episodes. Asset prices decline in all episodes, but the decline in financial crises is substantially larger than the decline in fundamentals so that expected returns going forward are large. However, drops in consumption and consumption volatility are fairly similar across financial crises and recessions and are largest during wars, so asset pricing models based on aggregate consumption have trouble matching these facts. Comparing crises to “deep” recessions strengthens these findings further. By disentangling financial crises from other bad macroeconomic times, the results suggest that financial crises are particularly important to understanding why risk premia vary. I discuss implications for theory more broadly and discuss both rational and behavioral models that are consistent with the facts. Theories where asset prices are related to the health of the financial sector appear particularly promising.</jats:p>
research_question: How do risk premia behave during financial crises compared to other adverse economic episodes such as wars and recessions?
answer: Risk premia increase substantially during financial crises but not during other adverse episodes like wars and recessions. Asset prices decline more in financial crises than can be explained by fundamentals, leading to large expected returns going forward, while consumption-based measures are similar across episode types.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by disentangling financial crises from other macroeconomic downturns using a comprehensive international dataset spanning 140+ years, showing that existing asset pricing models based on aggregate consumption cannot explain the unique risk premium patterns in financial crises, and suggesting that theories linking asset prices to financial sector health are more promising.

author: Tyler Muir
title: Whatever It Takes? The Impact of Conditional Policy Promises
abstract: <jats:p> At the announcement of a new policy, agents form a view of state-contingent policy actions and impact. We develop a method to estimate this state-contingent perception and implement it for many asset-purchase interventions worldwide. Expectations of larger support in bad states—“policy puts”—explain a large fraction of the announcements' impact. For example, when the Fed introduced purchases of corporate bonds in March 2020, markets expected five times more price support had conditions worsened relative to the median scenario. Perceived promises of additional support in bad states alter asset prices, risk, and the response to future announcements. (JEL E52, E58, G12, G13, G14, G21, G28) </jats:p>
research_question: How do agents form expectations about state-contingent policy actions when new policies are announced, and what is the impact of these conditional policy promises on financial markets?
answer: Expectations of larger policy support in bad economic states ('policy puts') explain a large fraction of policy announcements' impact on markets. For example, when the Fed introduced corporate bond purchases in March 2020, markets expected five times more price support in worsened conditions compared to median scenarios. These perceived conditional promises significantly alter asset prices, risk, and responses to future announcements.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel method to estimate state-contingent policy perceptions and applies it to asset-purchase interventions worldwide, contributing to the literature on policy announcement effects by quantifying how markets price in conditional policy support across different economic states.

author: Urban Jermann
title: Macroeconomic Effects of Financial Shocks
abstract: <jats:p> We document the cyclical properties of US firms' financial flows and show that equity payout is procyclical and debt payout is countercyclical. We then develop a model with debt and equity financing to explore how the dynamics of real and financial variables are affected by “financial shocks.” We find that financial shocks contributed significantly to the observed dynamics of real and financial variables. The recent events in the financial sector show up as a tightening of firms' financing conditions which contributed to the 2008–2009 recession. The downturns in 1990–1991 and 2001 were also influenced by changes in credit conditions. (JEL E23, E32, E44, G01, G32) </jats:p>
research_question: How do financial shocks affect the dynamics of real and financial variables in the macroeconomy?
answer: Financial shocks contributed significantly to observed dynamics of real and financial variables, with tightening financing conditions contributing to the 2008-2009 recession and influencing the 1990-1991 and 2001 downturns.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a model with debt and equity financing to explore financial shock dynamics, documenting that equity payout is procyclical and debt payout is countercyclical in US firms' financial flows.

author: Urban Jermann
title: Erratum: Macroeconomic Effects of Financial Shocks

author: Urban Jermann
title: Sticky Leverage
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a tractable general equilibrium model that captures the interplay between nominal long-term corporate debt, inflation, and real aggregates. We show that unanticipated inflation changes the real burden of debt and, more significantly, leads to a debt overhang that distorts future investment and production decisions. For these effects to be both large and very persistent, it is essential that debt maturity exceeds one period. We also show that interest rate rules can help stabilize our economy. (JEL E12, E31, E44, E52, G01, G32, G35) </jats:p>
research_question: How does the interplay between nominal long-term corporate debt, inflation, and real aggregates affect investment and production decisions in a general equilibrium framework?
answer: Unanticipated inflation changes the real burden of debt and creates a debt overhang that distorts future investment and production decisions, with these effects being both large and very persistent when debt maturity exceeds one period, while interest rate rules can help stabilize the economy.
positioning_statement: The paper develops a tractable general equilibrium model to capture the previously underexplored dynamics between nominal long-term corporate debt, inflation, and real economic aggregates, emphasizing the critical role of debt maturity in generating persistent economic effects.

author: Umit Gurun
title: Internal Deadlines, Drug Approvals, and Safety Problems
abstract: <jats:p> Absent explicit quotas, incentives, reporting, or fiscal year-end motives, drug approvals around the world surge in December, at month-ends, and before respective major national holidays. Drugs approved before these informal deadlines are associated with significantly more adverse effects, including more hospitalizations, life-threatening incidents, and deaths—particularly, drugs most rushed through the approval process. These patterns are consistent with a model in which regulators rush to meet internal production benchmarks associated with salient calendar periods: this “ desk-clearing” behavior results in more lax review, leading both to increased output and increased safety issues at particular—and predictable—periodicities over the year. (JEL D83, I11, L51, L65) </jats:p>
research_question: Do drug regulators exhibit 'desk-clearing' behavior around internal deadlines (such as December, month-ends, and major holidays), and does this rushed approval process affect drug safety outcomes?
answer: Yes, drug approvals surge around predictable calendar periods (December, month-ends, and before major holidays) globally, and drugs approved during these rushed periods are associated with significantly more adverse effects, including hospitalizations, life-threatening incidents, and deaths, particularly for the most rushed approvals.
positioning_statement: This paper identifies a novel pattern in regulatory behavior that occurs 'absent explicit quotas, incentives, reporting, or fiscal year-end motives,' suggesting that internal production benchmarks tied to salient calendar periods drive regulatory decision-making in ways not previously documented in the literature.

author: Uta Schönberg
title: Peer Effects in the Workplace
abstract: <jats:p> Existing evidence on peer effects in the productivity of coworkers stems from either laboratory experiments or real-world studies referring to a specific firm or occupation. In this paper, we aim at providing more generalizable results by investigating a large local labor market, with a focus on peer effects in wages rather than productivity. Our estimation strategy—which links the average permanent productivity of workers' peers to their wages—circumvents the reflection problem and accounts for endogenous sorting of workers into peer groups and firms. On average over all occupations, and in the type of high-skilled occupations investigated in studies on knowledge spillover, we find only small peer effects in wages. In the type of low-skilled occupations analyzed in extant studies on social pressure, in contrast, we find larger peer effects, about one-half the size of those identified in similar studies on productivity. (JEL J24, J31, J41, M12, M54) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the peer effects in wages across different occupations in a large local labor market?
answer: Peer effects in wages are small on average and in high-skilled occupations, but larger in low-skilled occupations (about half the size of productivity effects found in similar studies).
positioning_statement: This paper provides more generalizable results than existing evidence which stems from either laboratory experiments or real-world studies of specific firms or occupations, by investigating peer effects in wages rather than productivity across a large local labor market while addressing the reflection problem and endogenous sorting issues.

author: Uta Schönberg
title: Reallocation Effects of the Minimum Wage
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We investigate the wage, employment, and reallocation effects of the introduction of a nationwide minimum wage in Germany that affected 15% of all employees. Based on identification designs that exploit variation in exposure across individuals and local areas, we find that the minimum wage raised wages but did not lower employment. It also led to the reallocation of low-wage workers from smaller to larger, from lower- to higher-paying, and from less to more productive establishments. This worker upgrading accounts for up to 17% of the wage increase induced by the minimum wage. Moreover, at the regional level, average establishment quality increased in more affected areas in the years following the introduction of the minimum wage.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the wage, employment, and reallocation effects of the introduction of a nationwide minimum wage in Germany?
answer: The minimum wage raised wages without lowering employment and led to reallocation of low-wage workers from smaller to larger, lower- to higher-paying, and less to more productive establishments, with worker upgrading accounting for up to 17% of the wage increase.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the minimum wage literature by focusing on reallocation effects and worker upgrading mechanisms, using the introduction of Germany's nationwide minimum wage as a natural experiment to examine effects beyond traditional wage and employment outcomes.
