author: Uta Schönberg
title: Labor Supply Shocks, Native Wages, and the Adjustment of Local Employment*
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>By exploiting a commuting policy that led to a sharp and unexpected inflow of Czech workers to areas along the German-Czech border, we examine the impact of an exogenous immigration-induced labor supply shock on local wages and employment of natives. On average, the supply shock leads to a moderate decline in local native wages and a sharp decline in local native employment. These average effects mask considerable heterogeneity across groups: while younger natives experience larger wage effects, employment responses are particularly pronounced for older natives. This pattern is inconsistent with standard models of immigration but can be accounted for by a model that allows for a larger labor supply elasticity or a higher degree of wage rigidity for older than for young workers. We further show that the employment response is almost entirely driven by diminished inflows of natives into work rather than outflows into other areas or nonemployment, suggesting that “outsiders” shield “insiders” from the increased competition.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the impact of an exogenous immigration-induced labor supply shock on local wages and employment of native workers?
answer: The labor supply shock leads to moderate decline in native wages and sharp decline in native employment on average, with heterogeneous effects across age groups - younger natives experience larger wage effects while older natives show more pronounced employment responses. The employment response is driven primarily by reduced inflows of natives into work rather than outflows, suggesting 'outsiders' protect 'insiders' from increased competition.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the immigration literature by exploiting a unique natural experiment (Czech commuting policy creating unexpected labor inflows) to identify causal effects, and extends existing models by showing that standard immigration models cannot account for the observed age-heterogeneous patterns, requiring models with varying labor supply elasticity or wage rigidity across age groups.

author: Vicente Cuñat
title: Search, Design, and Market Structure
abstract: <jats:p> The Internet has made consumer search easier, with consequences for prices, industry structure, and the kinds of products offered. We provide an industry model with strategic design choices that explores these issues. A polarized market structure results: some firms choose designs aimed at broad-based audiences, while others target narrow niches. We analyze the effect of reduced search costs, finding results consistent with the reported prevalence of niche goods and long-tail and superstar phenomena. In particular, the model suggests that long-tail effects arise when there is a wide range of potential designs, relative to vertical heterogeneity among firms. JEL: D11, D21, D83, L11, L86, M31 </jats:p>
research_question: How does the Internet's reduction of consumer search costs affect prices, industry structure, and product design choices in markets?
answer: Reduced search costs lead to a polarized market structure where some firms choose broad-based designs while others target narrow niches, with long-tail effects emerging when there is a wide range of potential designs relative to vertical heterogeneity among firms.
positioning_statement: This paper provides an industry model with strategic design choices to explore the consequences of easier consumer search enabled by the Internet, analyzing effects consistent with reported phenomena like niche goods prevalence, long-tail effects, and superstar phenomena.

author: Vicente Cuñat
title: Bilateral Trade Imbalances
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>If sectoral trade flows obey structural gravity, countries’ bilateral trade imbalances are the result of macro trade imbalances, “triangular trade”, or pairwise asymmetric trade barriers. Using data for 40 major economies and the Rest of the World, we show that large and pervasive asymmetries in trade barriers are required to account for most of the observed variation in bilateral imbalances. A dynamic quantitative trade model suggests that eliminating these asymmetries would significantly reduce bilateral (but not macro) imbalances and have sizeable impacts on welfare. We provide evidence that the asymmetries we measure are in part related to the policy environment: trade inside the European Single Market appears to be subject to more bilaterally symmetric frictions. Extending the same symmetry to all parts of the global economy would give a large boost to the real incomes of several non-E.U. countries.</jats:p>
research_question: What factors account for bilateral trade imbalances between countries, and what role do asymmetric trade barriers play in explaining the observed variation in these imbalances?
answer: Large and pervasive asymmetries in trade barriers are required to account for most of the observed variation in bilateral trade imbalances. Eliminating these asymmetries would significantly reduce bilateral (but not macro) imbalances and have sizeable welfare impacts.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the structural gravity framework to decompose bilateral trade imbalances into components from macro trade imbalances, triangular trade, and pairwise asymmetric trade barriers, providing a new quantitative approach to understanding bilateral trade patterns and their policy implications.

author: Vasilis Syrgkanis
title: Dynamically Aggregating Diverse Information
abstract: <jats:p>An agent has access to multiple information sources, each modeled as a Brownian motion whose drift provides information about a different component of an unknown Gaussian state. Information is acquired continuously—where the agent chooses both which sources to sample from, and also how to allocate attention across them—until an endogenously chosen time, at which point a decision is taken. We demonstrate conditions on the agent's prior belief under which it is possible to exactly characterize the optimal information acquisition strategy. We then apply this characterization to derive new results regarding: (1) endogenous information acquisition for binary choice, (2) the dynamic consequences of attention manipulation, and (3) strategic information provision by biased news sources.</jats:p>
research_question: How should an agent optimally acquire and allocate attention across multiple continuous information sources when making decisions under uncertainty about an unknown Gaussian state?
answer: Under certain conditions on the agent's prior belief, the optimal information acquisition strategy can be exactly characterized, showing how agents should dynamically choose which sources to sample from and how to allocate attention across them until an endogenously determined decision time.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the literature on information acquisition by modeling multiple continuous information sources as Brownian motions and providing exact characterizations of optimal strategies, then applying this framework to derive new results in three specific areas: binary choice with endogenous information acquisition, dynamic attention manipulation effects, and strategic information provision by biased sources.

author: Victoria Ivashina
title: Loan Syndication and Credit Cycles

author: Victoria Vanasco
title: Falling Interest Rates and Credit Reallocation: Lessons from General Equilibrium
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that in a canonical model with heterogeneous entrepreneurs, financial frictions, and an imperfectly elastic supply of capital, a fall in the interest rate has an ambiguous effect on aggregate economic activity. In partial equilibrium, a lower interest rate raises aggregate investment both by relaxing financial constraints and by prompting relatively less productive entrepreneurs to invest. In general equilibrium, however, this higher demand for capital raises its price and crowds out investment by more productive entrepreneurs. When this reallocation is strong enough, a fall in the interest rate reduces aggregate output. A numerical exploration of the model suggests that this reallocation effect is quantitatively significant and—in response to persistent changes in the interest rate—stronger than the traditional balance-sheet channel. We provide evidence of the reallocation effect using U.S. firm-level data.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of falling interest rates on aggregate economic activity when accounting for credit reallocation between heterogeneous entrepreneurs with financial frictions and imperfectly elastic capital supply?
answer: A fall in interest rates has an ambiguous effect on aggregate economic activity - while it can stimulate investment in partial equilibrium, in general equilibrium it raises capital prices and crowds out investment by more productive entrepreneurs, potentially reducing aggregate output when this reallocation effect is strong enough.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the traditional view by incorporating general equilibrium effects and showing that the credit reallocation mechanism can be quantitatively more significant than the conventional balance-sheet channel, particularly for persistent interest rate changes.

author: Vincent Glode
title: Asymmetric Information and Intermediation Chains
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a parsimonious model of bilateral trade under asymmetric information to shed light on the prevalence of intermediation chains that stand between buyers and sellers in many decentralized markets. Our model features a classic problem in economics where an agent uses his market power to inefficiently screen a privately informed counterparty. Paradoxically, involving moderately informed intermediaries also endowed with market power can improve trade efficiency. Long intermediation chains in which each trader's information set is similar to those of his direct counterparties limit traders' incentives to post prices that reduce trade volume and jeopardize gains to trade. (JEL D42, D82, D85, L12, L14) </jats:p>
research_question: Why are intermediation chains prevalent in decentralized markets with asymmetric information, and how do they affect trade efficiency?
answer: Involving moderately informed intermediaries with market power can paradoxically improve trade efficiency by limiting traders' incentives to post prices that reduce trade volume, as long intermediation chains where each trader has similar information to direct counterparties help preserve gains to trade.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a classic economics problem of agents using market power to inefficiently screen privately informed counterparties, but provides a novel insight that contradicts conventional wisdom by showing that adding more intermediaries with market power can actually improve rather than worsen trade efficiency.

author: Victoria Ivashina
title: Dollar Funding and the Lending Behavior of Global Banks*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>A large share of dollar-denominated lending is done by non-U.S. banks, particularly European banks. We present a model in which such banks cut dollar lending more than euro lending in response to a shock to their credit quality. Because these banks rely on wholesale dollar funding, while raising more of their euro funding through insured retail deposits, the shock leads to a greater withdrawal of dollar funding. Banks can borrow in euros and swap into dollars to make up for the dollar shortfall, but this may lead to violations of covered interest parity when there is limited capital to take the other side of the swap trade. In this case, synthetic dollar borrowing also becomes expensive, which causes cuts in dollar lending. We test the model in the context of the Eurozone sovereign crisis, which escalated in the second half of 2011 and resulted in U.S. money market funds sharply reducing their exposure to European banks in the year that followed. During this period dollar lending by Eurozone banks fell relative to their euro lending, and firms who were more reliant on Eurozone banks before the Eurozone crisis had a more difficult time borrowing.</jats:p>
research_question: How do funding structure differences affect the lending behavior of global banks when they face credit quality shocks, specifically comparing dollar versus euro lending by European banks?
answer: Non-U.S. banks (particularly European banks) cut dollar lending more than euro lending in response to credit quality shocks because they rely more heavily on wholesale dollar funding compared to insured retail deposits for euro funding, and when synthetic dollar borrowing through FX swaps becomes expensive due to covered interest parity violations, this amplifies the reduction in dollar lending.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature on global banking and funding markets by providing both theoretical and empirical evidence for how funding structure asymmetries across currencies affect lending behavior, using the Eurozone sovereign crisis as a natural experiment to test how wholesale funding dependence creates differential responses in lending across currencies.

author: Vincent Glode
title: Electoral Turnovers
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>In most national elections, voters face a key choice between continuity and change. Electoral turnovers occur when the incumbent candidate or party fails to win reelection. To understand how turnovers affect national outcomes, we study all presidential and parliamentary elections held globally between 1946 and 2018. We document the prevalence of turnovers over time and estimate their effects on economic performance, human development, and the quality of democracy. Using a close-elections regression discontinuity design across countries, we show that turnovers improve several measures of country performance. To explain these positive effects, we explore how electoral turnovers affect leader characteristics, shape policy decisions, reduce perceived corruption, and foster accountability.</jats:p>
research_question: How do electoral turnovers (when incumbent candidates or parties fail to win reelection) affect national outcomes including economic performance, human development, and quality of democracy?
answer: Electoral turnovers improve several measures of country performance, with positive effects explained through changes in leader characteristics, policy decisions, reduced perceived corruption, and enhanced accountability.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing the first comprehensive global analysis of electoral turnovers across both presidential and parliamentary systems from 1946-2018, using a close-elections regression discontinuity design to establish causal effects of political change on national outcomes.

author: Victoria Vanasco
title: Security Design in Non-Exclusive Markets with Asymmetric Information
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the problem of a seller (e.g. a bank) who is privately informed about the quality of her asset and wants to exploit gains from trade with uninformed buyers (e.g. investors) by issuing securities backed by her asset cash flows. In our setting, buyers post menus of contracts to screen the seller, but the seller cannot commit to trade with only one buyer, i.e. markets are non-exclusive. We show that non-exclusive markets behave very differently from exclusive ones: (1) separating contracts are never part of equilibrium; (2) mispricing of claims faced by the seller is always greater than in exclusive markets; (3) there is always a semi-pooling equilibrium where all sellers issue the same debt contract priced at average-valuation, and sellers of low-quality assets issue remaining cash flows at low-valuation; (4) market liquidity can be higher or lower than in exclusive markets, but (5) the average quality of originated assets is always lower. Our model’s predictions are consistent with empirical evidence on the issuance and pricing of mortgage-backed securities, and we use the theory to evaluate recent reforms aimed at enhancing transparency and exclusivity in markets.</jats:p>
research_question: How does security design and market outcomes differ when markets are non-exclusive (seller cannot commit to trade with only one buyer) versus exclusive markets, in the context of asymmetric information between informed sellers and uninformed buyers?
answer: Non-exclusive markets behave fundamentally differently from exclusive markets: separating contracts never occur in equilibrium, mispricing is always greater, semi-pooling equilibria emerge where all sellers issue identical debt contracts at average valuation while low-quality sellers issue remaining cash flows at low valuation, market liquidity effects are ambiguous, and average asset quality is always lower.
positioning_statement: This paper extends the existing literature on security design under asymmetric information by introducing non-exclusive markets where sellers cannot commit to trading with only one buyer, contrasting with the standard exclusive market assumptions, and applies this framework to explain empirical patterns in mortgage-backed securities markets and evaluate recent market reforms.

author: Vincent Pons
title: Will a Five-Minute Discussion Change Your Mind? A Countrywide Experiment on Voter Choice in France
abstract: <jats:p> This paper provides the first estimate of the effect of door-to-door canvassing on actual electoral outcomes, via a countrywide experiment embedded in François Hollande's campaign in the 2012 French presidential election. While existing experiments randomized door-to-door visits at the individual level, the scale of this campaign (five million doors knocked) enabled randomization by precinct, the level at which vote shares are recorded administratively. Visits did not affect turnout, but increased Hollande's vote share in the first round and accounted for one-fourth of his victory margin in the second. Visits' impact persisted in later elections, suggesting a lasting persuasion effect. (JEL C93, D7, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of door-to-door canvassing on actual electoral outcomes?
answer: Door-to-door canvassing did not affect voter turnout but significantly increased François Hollande's vote share in both rounds of the 2012 French presidential election, accounting for one-fourth of his victory margin in the second round, with effects persisting in later elections indicating lasting persuasion.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first estimate of door-to-door canvassing effects on actual electoral outcomes by conducting randomization at the precinct level (rather than individual level like existing experiments), enabled by the unprecedented scale of the campaign with five million doors knocked.

author: Vincent Pons
title: Expressive Voting and Its Cost: Evidence From Runoffs With Two or Three Candidates
abstract: In French parliamentary and local elections, candidates ranked first and second in the first round automatically qualify for the second round, while a third candidate qualifies only when selected by more than 12.5 percent of registered citizens. Using a fuzzy RDD around this threshold, we find that the third candidate's presence substantially increases the share of registered citizens who vote for any candidate and reduces the vote share of the top two candidates. It disproportionately harms the candidate ideologically closest to the third and causes her defeat in one fifth of the races. Additional evidence suggests that these results are driven by voters who value voting expressively over voting strategically for the top‐two candidate they dislike the least to ensure her victory; and by third candidates who, absent party‐level agreements leading to their dropping out, value the benefits associated with competing in the second round more than influencing its outcome.

author: Vincent Pons
title: Strict Id Laws Don’t Stop Voters: Evidence from a U.S. Nationwide Panel, 2008–2018
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>U.S. states increasingly require identification to vote—an ostensible attempt to deter fraud that prompts complaints of selective disenfranchisement. Using a difference-in-differences design on a panel data set with 1.6 billion observations, 2008–2018, we find that the laws have no negative effect on registration or turnout, overall or for any group defined by race, gender, age, or party affiliation. These results hold through a large number of specifications. Our most demanding specification controls for state, year, and voter fixed effects, along with state and voter time-varying controls. Based on this specification, we obtain point estimates of −0.1 percentage points for effects both on overall registration and turnout (with 95% confidence intervals of [−2.3; 2.1 percentage points] and [−3.0; 2.8 percentage points], respectively), and +1.4 percentage points for the effect on the turnout of nonwhite voters relative to whites (with a 95% confidence interval of [−0.5; 3.2 percentage points]). The lack of negative impact on voter turnout cannot be attributed to voters’ reaction against the laws, measured by campaign contributions and self-reported political engagement. However, the likelihood that nonwhite voters were contacted by a campaign increases by 4.7 percentage points, suggesting that parties’ mobilization might have offset modest effects of the laws on the participation of ethnic minorities. Finally, strict ID requirements have no effect on fraud, actual or perceived. Overall, our findings suggest that efforts to improve elections may be better directed at other reforms.</jats:p>
research_question: Do strict voter ID laws affect voter registration and turnout, particularly among different demographic groups defined by race, gender, age, or party affiliation?
answer: Strict voter ID laws have no negative effect on registration or turnout, either overall or for any demographic group. The laws also have no effect on fraud, actual or perceived, and any potential modest effects on ethnic minorities may be offset by increased campaign mobilization efforts.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the debate over voter ID laws by providing comprehensive empirical evidence using a large-scale nationwide panel dataset with 1.6 billion observations from 2008-2018, employing rigorous difference-in-differences methodology to address concerns about selective disenfranchisement that have prompted complaints about these ostensible anti-fraud measures.

author: Vincent Sterk
title: Stock Market Participation, Inequality, and Monetary Policy
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>Recent literature has shown that the fraction of liquidity-constrained households in the population critically determines the mix of transmission channels of monetary policy. In this article, we bring a different but important dimension of heterogeneity to the forefront: stock market participation. We show that the stock market participation rate not only shapes the mix of policy channels but also heavily affects the aggregate responses. This happens as direct rebalancing effects and indirect equilibrium effects into investment are both increasing in the number of stock market participants, reinforcing each other. We show this in a quantitative New Keynesian model designed to account for the population share of stock market participants, their position in the income and wealth distribution, and their saving rates. The model implies that, as stock market participation has increased since the 1980s, the power of monetary policy on the real economy has strengthened considerably.</jats:p>
research_question: How does stock market participation affect the transmission channels and aggregate effectiveness of monetary policy?
answer: Stock market participation rate critically shapes both the mix of monetary policy transmission channels and the magnitude of aggregate responses, with higher participation strengthening monetary policy's power on the real economy through reinforcing direct rebalancing effects and indirect equilibrium effects on investment.
positioning_statement: This paper brings a different but important dimension of heterogeneity (stock market participation) to the forefront, building on recent literature that has focused on how the fraction of liquidity-constrained households determines monetary policy transmission channels.

author: Vincent Pons
title: How do Campaigns Shape Vote Choice? Multicountry Evidence from 62 Elections and 56 TV Debates
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We use two-round survey data from 62 elections in 10 countries since 1952 to study the formation of vote choice, beliefs, and policy preferences and assess how televised debates contribute to this process. Our data include 253,000 observations. We compare the consistency between vote intention and vote choice of respondents surveyed at different points before, and then again after, the election, and show that 17% to 29% of voters make up their mind during the final two months of campaigns. Changes in vote choice are concomitant to shifts in issues voters find most important and in beliefs about candidates, and they generate sizable swings in vote shares. In contrast, policy preferences remain remarkably stable throughout the campaign. Finally, we use an event study to estimate the impact of TV debates, in which candidates themselves communicate with voters, and of shocks such as natural and technological disasters which, by contrast, occur independently from the campaign. We do not find any effect of either type of event on vote choice formation, suggesting that information received throughout the campaign from other sources such as the media, political activists, and other citizens is more impactful.</jats:p>
research_question: How do campaigns shape vote choice, and what is the specific contribution of televised debates to the formation of vote choice, beliefs, and policy preferences?
answer: 17% to 29% of voters make up their mind during the final two months of campaigns, with changes in vote choice accompanied by shifts in issue importance and candidate beliefs but stable policy preferences. However, TV debates themselves have no detectable effect on vote choice formation, suggesting that information from other campaign sources (media, political activists, other citizens) is more impactful than direct candidate communication through debates.
positioning_statement: This paper provides the first large-scale multicountry analysis of vote choice formation using two-round survey data from 62 elections across 10 countries since 1952, offering unprecedented empirical evidence on campaign effects and specifically challenging assumptions about the importance of televised debates in shaping voter decisions.

author: Vincent Pons
title: Keep Your Enemies Closer: Strategic Platform Adjustments during US and French Elections
abstract: <jats:p> We study changes in political discourse during campaigns, using a novel dataset of candidate websites for US House elections, 2002–2016, and manifestos for French parliamentary and local elections, 1958–2022. We find that candidates move to the center in ideology and rhetorical complexity between the first round (or primary) and the second round (or general election). This convergence reflects candidates’ strategic adjustment to their opponents, as predicted by Downsian competition: Using an RDD we show that candidates converge to the platform of opponents who narrowly qualified for the last round as opposed to those who narrowly failed to qualify. (JEL D72, D83, D91) </jats:p>
research_question: How do political candidates strategically adjust their platforms and discourse during electoral campaigns, particularly between different rounds of elections?
answer: Candidates move toward the center in both ideology and rhetorical complexity between early rounds (primaries/first round) and later rounds (general election/second round), and this convergence is strategic - candidates adjust their platforms to converge toward the positions of opponents who narrowly qualify for the final round.
positioning_statement: This paper provides empirical evidence supporting Downsian competition theory by demonstrating strategic platform adjustment using novel datasets from US House elections (2002-2016) and French parliamentary and local elections (1958-2022), employing regression discontinuity design to establish causal evidence of candidates' strategic responses to their specific opponents.

author: Vincent Sterk
title: The Growth Potential of Startups over the Business Cycle
abstract: <jats:p> This paper shows that employment in cohorts of US firms is strongly influenced by aggregate conditions at the time of their entry. Employment fluctuations of startups are procyclical, they persist into later years, and cohort-level employment variations are largely driven by differences in firm size, rather than the number of firms. An estimated general equilibrium firm dynamics model reveals that aggregate conditions at birth, rather than post-entry choices, drive the majority of cohort-level employment variation by affecting the share of startups with high growth potential. In the aggregate, changes in startup conditions result in large, slow-moving fluctuations in employment. (JEL D25, E24, E32, J23, L25, M13) </jats:p>
research_question: How do aggregate economic conditions at the time of firm entry affect the employment dynamics and growth potential of startup cohorts over the business cycle?
answer: Employment in startup cohorts is strongly influenced by aggregate conditions at entry, with procyclical employment fluctuations that persist over time. These variations are primarily driven by differences in firm size rather than firm numbers, and aggregate conditions at birth affect the share of startups with high growth potential, creating large, slow-moving employment fluctuations.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the firm dynamics literature by demonstrating that aggregate conditions at birth, rather than post-entry choices, are the primary driver of cohort-level employment variation, using an estimated general equilibrium model to show how startup conditions create persistent macroeconomic effects.

author: Vincent Pons
title: Does Context Outweigh Individual Characteristics in Driving Voting Behavior? Evidence from Relocations within the United States
abstract: <jats:p> We measure the overall influence of contextual versus individual factors (e.g., voting rules and media as opposed to race and education) on voter behavior, and explore underlying mechanisms. Using a US-wide voter-level panel, 2008–2018, we examine voters who relocate across state and county lines, tracking changes in registration, turnout, and party affiliation to estimate location and individual fixed effects in a value-added model. Location explains 37 percent of the cross-state variation in turnout (to 63 percent for individual characteristics) and an only slightly smaller share of variation in party affiliation. Place effects are larger for young and White voters. (JEL D12, D72, I20, J15, L82, R23) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relative influence of contextual factors (such as voting rules and media) versus individual characteristics (such as race and education) in driving voting behavior?
answer: Location/contextual factors explain 37 percent of cross-state variation in voter turnout (compared to 63 percent for individual characteristics) and a slightly smaller share of variation in party affiliation, with place effects being larger for young and White voters.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by providing a comprehensive measurement of the overall influence of contextual versus individual factors on voter behavior using a novel approach that tracks individual voters who relocate across state and county lines, employing a value-added model with location and individual fixed effects to separate these influences.

author: Vincent Sterk
title: The Nature of Firm Growth
abstract: <jats:p> About one-half of all startups fail within five years, and those that survive grow at vastly different speeds. Using Census microdata, we estimate that most of these differences are determined by ex ante heterogeneity rather than persistent ex post shocks. Embedding such heterogeneity in a firm dynamics model shows that the presence of ex ante heterogeneity (i) is a key determinant of the firm size distribution and firm dynamics, (ii) can strongly affect the macroeconomic effects of firm-level frictions, and (iii) helps understand the recently documented decline in business dynamism by showing a disappearance of high-growth startups (“gazelles”) since the mid-1980s. (JEL D22, D24, E24, J23, L11, M13) </jats:p>
research_question: What determines the vastly different growth speeds among surviving startups, and how does this heterogeneity affect firm dynamics and macroeconomic outcomes?
answer: Most differences in firm growth rates are determined by ex ante heterogeneity (inherent differences between firms from the start) rather than persistent ex post shocks (random events after founding), and this heterogeneity significantly affects firm size distribution, macroeconomic effects of firm-level frictions, and explains the decline in business dynamism through the disappearance of high-growth startups since the mid-1980s.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the firm dynamics literature by using Census microdata to quantify the relative importance of ex ante heterogeneity versus ex post shocks in explaining firm growth differences, and demonstrates how incorporating this heterogeneity into firm dynamics models can better explain observed patterns in firm size distribution and the documented decline in business dynamism.

author: Vladimir Asriyan
title: Balance Sheet Channel with Information-Trading Frictions in Secondary Markets
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>This article develops a theory of the balance sheet channel that places a central emphasis on the liquidity of secondary markets for macro-contingent claims. We show that the presence of dispersed information and imperfect competition in secondary markets, interacted with financial constraints, results in mispricing and misallocation of aggregate risk, distorts aggregate investment, and exacerbates asset price and output volatility. The magnitude of balance sheet amplification effects becomes endogenously tied to the severity of market frictions, which likely vary over time and across economies. The laissez-faire equilibrium is constrained inefficient due to a novel externality originating from rent-extracting behaviour of agents in secondary markets. Optimal corrective policy boosts secondary market liquidity through subsidies to trade in macro-contingent claims, which enhances aggregate risk-sharing and stabilizes the business cycle.</jats:p>
research_question: How do information-trading frictions in secondary markets for macro-contingent claims interact with financial constraints to affect the balance sheet channel of monetary transmission?
answer: The presence of dispersed information and imperfect competition in secondary markets, combined with financial constraints, leads to mispricing and misallocation of aggregate risk, distorts aggregate investment, and amplifies asset price and output volatility, with the magnitude of these balance sheet amplification effects being endogenously determined by the severity of market frictions.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a novel theory of the balance sheet channel that emphasizes secondary market liquidity for macro-contingent claims, identifying a new externality from rent-extracting behavior in secondary markets that makes the laissez-faire equilibrium constrained inefficient, thereby extending existing balance sheet channel literature by incorporating market microstructure frictions.

author: Vladimir Asriyan
title: Security Design in Non-Exclusive Markets with Asymmetric Information
abstract:

author: Vladimir Asriyan
title: Collateral Booms and Information Depletion
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We develop a new theory of information production during credit booms. Entrepreneurs need credit to undertake investment projects, some of which enable them to divert resources. Lenders can protect themselves from such diversion in two ways: collateralization, and costly screening that generates durable information about projects. In equilibrium, the collateralization-screening mix depends on the value of aggregate collateral. High collateral values make it possible to reallocate resources towards productive projects, but they also crowd out screening. This has important dynamic implications. During credit booms driven by high collateral values (e.g. real estate booms), economic activity expands but the economy’s stock of information on existing projects gets depleted. As a result, collateral-driven booms end in deep crises and slow recoveries: when booms end, investment is constrained both by the lack of collateral and by the lack of information on existing projects, which takes time to rebuild. We provide empirical support for the mechanism using US firm-level data.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the relationship between collateralization and information production by lenders affect the dynamics of credit booms and subsequent economic crises?
answer: High collateral values during credit booms crowd out costly screening by lenders, leading to information depletion about existing projects. This creates a dual constraint when booms end - lack of both collateral and information - resulting in deeper crises and slower recoveries compared to booms driven by other factors.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a new theory of information production during credit booms that explains why collateral-driven booms (such as real estate booms) have distinct and more severe consequences than other types of credit expansions, contributing novel insights to the literature on credit cycles and financial crises.

author: Vladimir Asriyan
title: Information Spillovers in Asset Markets with Correlated Values
abstract: <jats:p> We study information spillovers in a dynamic setting with correlated assets owned by privately informed sellers. In the model, a trade of one asset can provide information about the value of other assets. Importantly, the information content of trading behavior is endogenously determined. We show that this endogeneity leads to multiple equilibria when assets are sufficiently correlated. The equilibria are ranked in terms of both trade volume and efficiency. The model has implications for policies targeting post-trade transparency. We show that introducing post-trade transparency can increase or decrease welfare and trading volume depending on the asset correlation, equilibrium being played, and the composition of market participants. (JEL D82, D83, G14, G18) </jats:p>
research_question: How do information spillovers affect trading dynamics and market outcomes in asset markets where assets have correlated values and sellers possess private information?
answer: Information spillovers create endogenous information content in trading behavior, leading to multiple equilibria when assets are sufficiently correlated, with these equilibria being ranked by trade volume and efficiency. Post-trade transparency policies can either increase or decrease welfare and trading volume depending on asset correlation, the equilibrium being played, and market participant composition.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on information spillovers in asset markets by examining a dynamic setting with correlated assets and privately informed sellers, where the information content of trading behavior is endogenously determined rather than exogenously given, leading to novel insights about multiple equilibria and policy implications for post-trade transparency.

author: Vladimir Asriyan
title: Liquidity Sentiments
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a rational theory of liquidity sentiments in which the market outcome in any given period depends on agents’ expectations about market conditions in future periods. Our theory is based on the interaction between adverse selection and resale considerations giving rise to an intertemporal coordination problem that yields multiple self-fulfilling equilibria. We construct “sentiment” equilibria in which sunspots generate fluctuations in prices, volume, and welfare, all of which are positively correlated. The intertemporal nature of the coordination problem disciplines the set of possible sentiment dynamics. In particular, sentiments must be sufficiently persistent and transitions must be stochastic. We consider an extension with production in which asset quality is endogenously determined and provide conditions under which sentiments are a necessary feature of any equilibrium. A testable implication is that assets produced in good times are of lower average quality than those produced in bad times. (JEL D84, D82, E32, E44, G12) </jats:p>
research_question: How do agents' expectations about future market conditions affect current market outcomes, particularly in the context of liquidity and market sentiment?
answer: The interaction between adverse selection and resale considerations creates an intertemporal coordination problem that yields multiple self-fulfilling equilibria, where sunspots can generate positively correlated fluctuations in prices, volume, and welfare through persistent sentiment dynamics.
positioning_statement: This paper develops a rational theory of liquidity sentiments that provides a theoretical foundation for understanding how market sentiment can create self-fulfilling prophecies in financial markets, extending beyond existing literature by incorporating the intertemporal coordination aspects of adverse selection and resale considerations.

author: Vladimir Asriyan
title: Falling Interest Rates and Credit Reallocation: Lessons from General Equilibrium
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We show that in a canonical model with heterogeneous entrepreneurs, financial frictions, and an imperfectly elastic supply of capital, a fall in the interest rate has an ambiguous effect on aggregate economic activity. In partial equilibrium, a lower interest rate raises aggregate investment both by relaxing financial constraints and by prompting relatively less productive entrepreneurs to invest. In general equilibrium, however, this higher demand for capital raises its price and crowds out investment by more productive entrepreneurs. When this reallocation is strong enough, a fall in the interest rate reduces aggregate output. A numerical exploration of the model suggests that this reallocation effect is quantitatively significant and—in response to persistent changes in the interest rate—stronger than the traditional balance-sheet channel. We provide evidence of the reallocation effect using U.S. firm-level data.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the effect of falling interest rates on aggregate economic activity when accounting for credit reallocation between heterogeneous entrepreneurs with financial frictions and imperfectly elastic capital supply?
answer: A fall in interest rates has an ambiguous effect on aggregate economic activity - while it can stimulate investment in partial equilibrium, in general equilibrium it raises capital prices and crowds out investment by more productive entrepreneurs, potentially reducing aggregate output when this reallocation effect is strong enough.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the traditional view by incorporating general equilibrium effects and showing that the credit reallocation mechanism can be quantitatively more significant than the conventional balance-sheet channel, particularly for persistent interest rate changes.

author: Wenxin Du
title: The Dollar, Bank Leverage, and Deviations from Covered Interest Parity
abstract: <jats:p> We document a triangular relationship in that a stronger dollar goes hand in hand with larger deviations from covered interest parity (CIP) and contractions of cross-border bank lending in dollars. We argue that underpinning the triangle is the role of the dollar as a key barometer of risk-taking capacity in global capital markets. (JEL F23, F31, G15, G21) </jats:p>
research_question: What is the relationship between dollar strength, deviations from covered interest parity, and cross-border bank lending in dollars?
answer: There is a triangular relationship where a stronger dollar is associated with larger deviations from covered interest parity and contractions of cross-border bank lending in dollars, with the dollar serving as a key barometer of risk-taking capacity in global capital markets.
positioning_statement: This paper documents a previously unrecognized triangular relationship connecting dollar strength, CIP deviations, and cross-border bank lending, arguing that the dollar's role as a barometer of global risk-taking capacity underpins these interconnected phenomena.

author: Wenxin Du
title: US Banks and Global Liquidity

author: Vladimir Asriyan
title: Monetary Policy for a Bubbly World
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>What is the role of monetary policy in a bubbly world? To address this question, we study an economy in which financial frictions limit the supply of assets. The ensuing scarcity generates a demand for “unbacked” assets, i.e., assets that are backed only by the expectation of their future value. We consider two types of unbacked assets: bubbles, which are created by the private sector, and money, which is created by the central bank. Bubbles and money share many features, but they also differ in two crucial respects. First, while the rents from the creation of bubbles accrue to entrepreneurs and foster investment, the rents from money creation accrue to the central bank. Second, while bubbles are driven by market psychology, and can rise and fall according to the whims of the market, money is under the control of the central bank. We characterize the optimal monetary policy and show that, through its ability to supply assets, monetary policy plays a key role in the bubbly world. The model sheds light on the recent expansion of central bank liabilities in response to the bursting of bubbles.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the role of monetary policy in a bubbly world?
answer: Monetary policy plays a key role in a bubbly world through the central bank's ability to supply assets. The optimal monetary policy involves the central bank creating money as an 'unbacked' asset that can substitute for private sector bubbles, with the key advantage that money creation rents accrue to the central bank rather than entrepreneurs, and money supply is under central bank control rather than subject to market psychology.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by modeling bubbles and money as similar 'unbacked' assets in an economy with financial frictions and asset scarcity, while highlighting their crucial differences in terms of rent distribution and controllability. The model provides theoretical insight into recent central bank balance sheet expansions following bubble bursts.

author: Xavier D’Haultfoeuille
title: Disasterization: A Simple Way to Fix the Asset Pricing Properties of Macroeconomic Models
abstract: <jats:p> A central difficulty in economics is to create a model with both good business cycle properties and asset pricing properties. I show how to solve this difficulty by a simple portable modeling device: the “disasterization” of models. Take an economy with good business cycle properties and create a new, “disasterized” economy, which is essentially identical to the original one except that disasters can destroy part of the capital stock and productivity. In such a disasterized economy, asset prices exhibit high and volatile risk premia, but macro variables remain unchanged. Perturbations of this benchmark allow for feedback from finance to macro. </jats:p>
research_question: How can macroeconomic models be modified to simultaneously exhibit good business cycle properties and realistic asset pricing properties?
answer: The solution is 'disasterization' - adding the possibility of disasters that can destroy part of the capital stock and productivity to existing models with good business cycle properties. This creates high and volatile risk premia in asset prices while leaving macro variables unchanged.
positioning_statement: This paper addresses a central difficulty in economics where existing models struggle to simultaneously capture both good business cycle properties and realistic asset pricing properties, offering a simple portable modeling device to bridge this gap.

author: Yann Bramoullé
title: Strategic Interaction and Networks
abstract: <jats:p> Geography and social links shape economic interactions. In industries, schools, and markets, the entire network determines outcomes. This paper analyzes a large class of games and obtains a striking result. Equilibria depend on a single network measure: the lowest eigenvalue. This paper is the first to uncover the importance of the lowest eigenvalue to economic and social outcomes. It captures how much the network amplifies agents' actions. The paper combines new tools—potential games, optimization, and spectral graph theory—to solve for all Nash and stable equilibria and applies the results to R&D, crime, and the econometrics of peer effects. (JEL C72, D83, D85, H41, K42, O33, Z13) </jats:p>
research_question: How do geography and social links shape economic interactions in networks, and what network measures determine equilibrium outcomes in strategic games?
answer: Equilibria in a large class of network games depend on a single network measure: the lowest eigenvalue, which captures how much the network amplifies agents' actions.
positioning_statement: This paper is the first to uncover the importance of the lowest eigenvalue to economic and social outcomes, combining new tools—potential games, optimization, and spectral graph theory—to solve for all Nash and stable equilibria.
