author: Yann Bramoullé
title: Altruism in Networks
abstract: We provide the first analysis of altruism in networks. Agents are embedded in a fixed network and care about the well‐being of their network neighbors. Depending on incomes, they may provide financial support to their poorer friends. We study the Nash equilibria of the resulting game of transfers. We show that equilibria maximize a concave potential function. We establish existence, uniqueness of equilibrium consumption, and generic uniqueness of equilibrium transfers. We characterize the geometry of the network of transfers and highlight the key role played by transfer intermediaries. We then study comparative statics. A positive income shock to an individual benefits all. For small changes in incomes, agents in a component of the network of transfers act as if they were organized in an income‐pooling community. A decrease in income inequality or expansion of the altruism network may increase consumption inequality.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Which Dimensions of Culture Matter for Long-Run Growth?
abstract: <jats:p> We present empirical evidence that, among a variety of cultural dimensions, the individualism-collectivism dimension, based on Hofstede's (2001) data, is the most important and robustly significant effect of culture on long run growth. Other dimensions that have a significant effect, albeit less robust, are generally strongly correlated with individualism and convey similar information. We found no significant or robust effect on growth from cultural dimensions that are independent from the individualism-collectivism cleavage. </jats:p>
research_question: Which dimensions of culture matter for long-run economic growth?
answer: The individualism-collectivism dimension is the most important and robustly significant cultural factor affecting long-run growth, while other cultural dimensions that significantly affect growth are generally strongly correlated with individualism and convey similar information.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on Hofstede's (2001) cultural dimensions framework to systematically evaluate which specific cultural dimensions have robust effects on long-run growth, distinguishing between dimensions that are correlated with individualism versus those that are independent from the individualism-collectivism cleavage.

author: Ying Fan
title: Estimating Discrete Games with Many Firms and Many Decisions: An Application to Merger and Product Variety

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Information Rigidity and the Expectations Formation Process: A Simple Framework and New Facts
abstract: <jats:p> We propose a new approach to test the full-information rational expectations hypothesis which can identify whether rejections of the null arise from information rigidities. This approach quantifies the economic significance of departures from the null and the underlying degree of information rigidity. Applying this approach to US and international data of professional forecasters and other agents yields pervasive evidence consistent with the presence of information rigidities. These results therefore provide a set of stylized facts which can be used to calibrate imperfect information models. Finally, we document evidence of state-dependence in the expectations formation process. (JEL C53, D83, D84, E13, E31, E37) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we test the full-information rational expectations hypothesis while identifying whether rejections arise from information rigidities, and what is the prevalence and economic significance of information rigidities in expectations formation?
answer: The paper finds pervasive evidence of information rigidities in expectations formation among professional forecasters and other agents across US and international data, with the degree of rigidity being economically significant and exhibiting state-dependence.
positioning_statement: This paper proposes a new testing approach that advances beyond existing methods by distinguishing between rejections of rational expectations due to information rigidities versus other factors, and provides empirical stylized facts that can be used to calibrate imperfect information models in the literature.

author: Ying Fan
title: Ownership Consolidation and Product Characteristics: A Study of the US Daily Newspaper Market
abstract: <jats:p> This paper develops a structural model of newspaper markets to analyze the effects of ownership consolidation, taking into account not only firms' price adjustments but also the adjustments in newspaper characteristics. A new dataset on newspaper prices and characteristics is used to estimate the model. The paper then simulates the effect of a merger in the Minneapolis newspaper market and studies how welfare effects of mergers vary with market characteristics. It finds that ignoring adjustments of product characteristics causes substantial differences in estimated effects of mergers. (JEL G32, L13, L82, M37) </jats:p>
research_question: How does ownership consolidation in the US daily newspaper market affect both pricing and product characteristics, and what are the welfare implications of mergers when accounting for these adjustments?
answer: Ignoring adjustments of product characteristics causes substantial differences in estimated effects of mergers, and welfare effects of mergers vary significantly with market characteristics when both price and product characteristic adjustments are considered.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing merger analysis literature by developing a structural model that accounts for both price adjustments and product characteristic adjustments in newspaper markets, addressing a gap where previous studies may have overlooked the importance of product characteristic changes in merger evaluations.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: What Can Survey Forecasts Tell Us about Information Rigidities?

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Are Sticky Prices Costly? Evidence from the Stock Market
abstract: <jats:p> We show that after monetary policy announcements, the conditional volatility of stock market returns rises more for firms with stickier prices than for firms with more flexible prices. This differential reaction is economically large and strikingly robust to a broad array of checks. These results suggest that menu costs—broadly defined to include physical costs of price adjustment, informational frictions, etc.—are an important factor for nominal price rigidity at the micro level. We also show that our empirical results are qualitatively and, under plausible calibrations, quantitatively consistent with New Keynesian macroeconomic models in which firms have heterogeneous price stickiness. (JEL E12, E31, E43, E44, E52, G12, L11) </jats:p>
research_question: Are sticky prices costly for firms, and can this be measured through stock market reactions to monetary policy announcements?
answer: Yes, sticky prices are costly - firms with stickier prices experience significantly higher conditional volatility in stock returns following monetary policy announcements compared to firms with more flexible prices, indicating that menu costs are an important factor in nominal price rigidity.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel empirical evidence using stock market data to test predictions from New Keynesian macroeconomic models about heterogeneous price stickiness, offering a new approach to measuring the costs of price rigidity that complements existing theoretical literature on menu costs and nominal rigidities.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Monetary Policy, Trend Inflation, and the Great Moderation: An Alternative Interpretation
abstract: <jats:p> With positive trend inflation, the Taylor principle does not guarantee a determinate equilibrium. We provide new theoretical results on determinacy in New Keynesian models with positive trend inflation and new empirical findings on the Federal Reserve's reaction function before and after the Volcker disinflation to find that, (i) while the Fed likely satisfied the Taylor principle before Volcker, the US economy was still subject to self-fulfilling fluctuations in the 1970s, (ii) the US economy switched to determinacy during the Volcker disinflation, and (iii) the switch reflected changes in the Fed's response to macroeconomic variables and the decline in trend inflation. (JEL E12, E23, E31, E32, E52) </jats:p>
research_question: How did changes in monetary policy and trend inflation during the Volcker disinflation contribute to the Great Moderation, particularly regarding the determinacy of equilibrium in the US economy?
answer: The US economy switched from indeterminacy (subject to self-fulfilling fluctuations) in the 1970s to determinacy during the Volcker disinflation, despite the Fed likely satisfying the Taylor principle before Volcker. This switch resulted from both changes in the Fed's response to macroeconomic variables and the decline in trend inflation.
positioning_statement: This paper provides an alternative interpretation to existing literature by showing that the Taylor principle alone does not guarantee determinate equilibrium when trend inflation is positive, offering new theoretical results on determinacy in New Keynesian models and new empirical findings on the Federal Reserve's reaction function across the Volcker period.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Price Setting in Online Markets: Basic Facts, International Comparisons, and Cross-Border Integration
abstract: <jats:p> We document basic facts about prices in online markets in the United States and Canada, which is a rapidly growing segment of the retail sector. Relative to prices in regular stores, prices in online markets are more flexible and exhibit stronger pass-through (60–75 percent) and faster convergence (half-life less than two months) in response to movements of the nominal exchange rate. Multiple margins of adjustment are active in the process of responding to nominal exchange rate shocks. Properties of goods, sellers, and markets are systematically related to pass-through and the speed of price adjustment for international price differentials. (JEL F31, F41, L11, L81) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the basic facts about price setting behavior in online markets, and how do online prices respond to exchange rate movements compared to traditional retail stores?
answer: Online market prices are more flexible than regular store prices, with stronger exchange rate pass-through (60-75 percent) and faster convergence (half-life less than two months), with multiple adjustment margins active in response to exchange rate shocks.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by documenting price setting facts in the rapidly growing online retail segment, providing new evidence on exchange rate pass-through and price adjustment speeds that can be compared to existing studies of traditional brick-and-mortar retail markets.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Inflation Expectations and Misallocation of Resources: Evidence from Italy
abstract: <jats:p>Using Italian data that include both inflation forecasts of firms and external information on their balance sheets, we study the causal effect of changes in the dispersion of beliefs about future inflation on the misallocation of resources. We find that as disagreement increases, so does misallocation. In times of low inflation, the aggregate TFP loss of the dispersed expectation-induced misallocation is moderate, but we argue that it likely becomes quite significant in times of high inflation. (JEL D22, D83, D84, E31, E37)</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal effect of changes in the dispersion of beliefs about future inflation on the misallocation of resources?
answer: As disagreement about future inflation increases, so does misallocation of resources, with moderate aggregate TFP losses during low inflation periods but potentially significant losses during high inflation periods.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using unique Italian data that combines firm-level inflation forecasts with balance sheet information to establish a causal relationship between inflation expectation dispersion and resource misallocation, providing empirical evidence for a previously understudied mechanism.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Output Spillovers from Fiscal Policy
abstract: <jats:p> For a large number of OECD countries we estimate the cross-country spillover effects of government purchases on output. Following the methodology in Auerbach and Gorodnichenko (2012a, b), we allow these multipliers to vary smoothly according to the state of the economy and use real-time forecast data to purge policy innovations of their predictable components. Our findings suggest that cross-country spillovers have an important impact. The findings also confirm those of our earlier papers--namely that fiscal shocks have a larger impact when the affected country is in recession. </jats:p>
research_question: What are the cross-country spillover effects of government purchases on output across OECD countries, and how do these effects vary according to the state of the economy?
answer: Cross-country spillovers from fiscal policy have an important impact on output, and fiscal shocks have larger effects when the affected country is in recession.
positioning_statement: This paper builds on the methodology of Auerbach and Gorodnichenko (2012a, b) by extending their approach to examine cross-country spillover effects, while confirming their earlier findings that fiscal multipliers are larger during recessions, but now in the context of international spillovers.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Unbundling Quantitative Easing: Taking a Cue from Treasury Auctions

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Inflation Expectations and Firm Decisions: New Causal Evidence*
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We use a unique design feature of a survey of Italian firms to study the causal effect of inflation expectations on firms’ economic decisions. In the survey, a randomly chosen subset of firms is repeatedly treated with information about recent inflation whereas other firms are not. This information treatment generates exogenous variation in inflation expectations. We find that higher inflation expectations on the part of firms leads them to raise their prices, increase demand for credit, and reduce their employment and capital. However, when policy rates are constrained by the effective lower bound, demand effects are stronger, leading firms to raise their prices more and no longer reduce their employment.</jats:p>
research_question: What is the causal effect of inflation expectations on firms' economic decisions?
answer: Higher inflation expectations cause firms to raise prices, increase credit demand, and reduce employment and capital. However, when policy rates are at the effective lower bound, demand effects strengthen, leading to larger price increases and no employment reduction.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a unique survey design feature with randomized information treatment to provide new causal evidence on how inflation expectations affect firm decisions, addressing the causal identification challenge that has limited previous research in this area.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: The Effect of Macroeconomic Uncertainty on Firm Decisions
abstract: <jats:p>Using a new survey of firms in New Zealand, we document how exogenous variation in the macroeconomic uncertainty perceived by firms affects their economic decisions. We use randomized information treatments that provide different types of information about the first and/or second moments of future economic growth to generate exogenous changes in the perceived macroeconomic uncertainty of some firms. The effects on their decisions relative to their initial plans as well as relative to an untreated control group are measured in a follow‐up survey six months later. We find that as firms become more uncertain, they reduce their prices, employment, and investment, their sales decline, and they become less likely to invest in new technologies or open new facilities. These ex post effects of uncertainty are similar to how firms say they would respond to higher uncertainty when asked hypothetical questions.</jats:p>
research_question: How does exogenous variation in macroeconomic uncertainty perceived by firms affect their economic decisions?
answer: As firms become more uncertain about macroeconomic conditions, they reduce their prices, employment, and investment, experience declining sales, and become less likely to invest in new technologies or open new facilities.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a novel experimental approach with randomized information treatments in a survey of New Zealand firms to generate exogenous changes in perceived macroeconomic uncertainty, providing causal evidence that complements existing literature by measuring actual ex post effects rather than relying solely on hypothetical responses.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: The Voice of Monetary Policy
abstract: <jats:p> We develop a deep learning model to detect emotions embedded in press conferences after the Federal Open Market Committee meetings and examine the influence of the detected emotions on financial markets. We find that, after controlling for the Federal Reserve’s actions and the sentiment in policy texts, a positive tone in the voices of Federal Reserve chairs leads to significant increases in share prices. Other financial variables also respond to vocal cues from the chairs. Hence, how policy messages are communicated can move the financial market. Our results provide implications for improving the effectiveness of central bank communications. (JEL D83, E31, E44, E52, E58, F31, G14) </jats:p>
research_question: How do emotions embedded in Federal Reserve chairs' voices during press conferences after FOMC meetings influence financial markets?
answer: A positive tone in the voices of Federal Reserve chairs leads to significant increases in share prices and affects other financial variables, even after controlling for the Fed's actions and policy text sentiment, demonstrating that how policy messages are communicated can move financial markets.
positioning_statement: This paper extends existing literature on central bank communications by introducing a novel deep learning approach to detect vocal emotions in Fed chair press conferences, going beyond traditional text-based sentiment analysis to examine how the manner of policy communication affects market outcomes.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: The Economics of Financial Stress
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We study the psychological costs of financial constraints and their economic consequences. Using a representative survey of U.S. households, we document the prevalence of financial stress in U.S. households and a strong relationship between financial stress and measures of financial constraints. We incorporate financial stress into an otherwise standard dynamic model of consumption and labour supply. We emphasize two key results. First, both financial stress itself and naivete about financial stress are important components of a psychology-based theory of the poverty trap. Sophisticated households, instead, save extra to escape high-stress states because they understand that doing so alleviates the economic consequences of financial stress. Second, the financial stress channel dampens or reverses the counterfactual large negative wealth effect on labour earnings because relieving stress frees up cognitive resources for productive work. Financial stress also has macroeconomic implications for wealth inequality and fiscal multipliers.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the psychological costs of financial constraints and their economic consequences?
answer: Financial stress creates poverty traps for naive households who don't understand its effects, while sophisticated households save extra to escape high-stress states; additionally, financial stress dampens negative wealth effects on labor earnings by freeing up cognitive resources when stress is relieved, with broader implications for wealth inequality and fiscal policy.
positioning_statement: This paper incorporates financial stress into an otherwise standard dynamic model of consumption and labour supply, extending existing literature by adding a psychological dimension to traditional economic models of household behavior and poverty traps.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: How Do Firms Form Their Expectations? New Survey Evidence
abstract: <jats:p> We survey New Zealand firms and document novel facts about their macroeconomic beliefs. There is widespread dispersion in beliefs about past and future macroeconomic conditions, especially inflation. This dispersion in beliefs is consistent with firms’ incentives to collect and process information. Using experimental methods, we find that firms update their beliefs in a Bayesian manner when presented with new information about the economy and that changes in their beliefs affect their decisions. Inflation is not generally perceived as being important to business decisions so firms devote few resources to collecting and processing information about inflation. (JEL D22, D83, D84, E31, E52) </jats:p>
research_question: How do firms form their expectations about macroeconomic conditions, particularly inflation?
answer: Firms show widespread dispersion in macroeconomic beliefs consistent with their information collection incentives, update beliefs in a Bayesian manner when given new information, and devote few resources to inflation information because they don't perceive it as important to business decisions.
positioning_statement: This paper provides novel survey evidence documenting new facts about firms' macroeconomic beliefs and their formation process, contributing original empirical findings to the literature on firm expectations.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: The Cyclicality of Sales, Regular and Effective Prices: Business Cycle and Policy Implications: Reply
abstract: <jats:p> We address how using different censoring thresholds and imputation procedures affects the baseline results of Coibion, Gorodnichenko, and Hong (2015). Higher censoring thresholds introduce measure ment error and outliers that generate wide variability in results across weighting schemes, but methods that explicitly control for outliers confirm the results of Coibion, Gorodnichenko, and Hong (2015) for all censoring thresholds. We also illustrate how the BLS’s approach to imputing missing prices can introduce a cyclical bias into measures of posted price inflation when store-switching is present in the data. (JEL D12, E31, E32, L25, L81) </jats:p>
research_question: How do different censoring thresholds and imputation procedures affect the measurement of price cyclicality and the baseline results regarding sales, regular and effective prices?
answer: Higher censoring thresholds introduce measurement error and outliers that create wide variability in results across weighting schemes, but methods that control for outliers confirm the original findings. Additionally, the BLS's approach to imputing missing prices introduces cyclical bias into posted price inflation measures when store-switching occurs.
positioning_statement: This paper responds to and defends the methodology and findings of Coibion, Gorodnichenko, and Hong (2015) by addressing criticisms about data treatment procedures and demonstrating that their original results are robust when proper controls for outliers are applied.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Demand Stimulus as Social Policy
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>We exploit a panel of city-level data with rich demographic information to estimate the distributional effects of Department of Defense spending and its effects on a range of social outcomes. The income and employment generated by defense spending accrue predominantly to households without a bachelor’s degree. These households as well as Black and Hispanic households tend to disproportionately benefit from this spending. Defense spending also promotes a range of beneficial social outcomes that are often targeted by government programs, including reductions in poverty, divorce rates, disability rates, and mortality rates, as well as increases in homeownership rates, health insurance rates, and occupational prestige. We compare the effects of defense spending with the effects of general demand shocks and explore reasons for the differential effects of the shocks.</jats:p>
research_question: What are the distributional effects of Department of Defense spending and how does it affect various social outcomes across different demographic groups?
answer: Defense spending predominantly benefits households without a bachelor's degree and disproportionately helps Black and Hispanic households, while generating beneficial social outcomes including reduced poverty, divorce rates, disability rates, and mortality rates, as well as increased homeownership, health insurance coverage, and occupational prestige.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by using city-level panel data with rich demographic information to examine defense spending as a form of demand stimulus, comparing its effects to general demand shocks and exploring the mechanisms behind differential impacts across demographic groups and social outcomes.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: The Cyclicality of Sales, Regular and Effective Prices: Business Cycle and Policy Implications
abstract: <jats:p> We study the cyclical properties of sales, regular price changes, and average prices paid by consumers (“effective” prices) using data on prices and quantities sold for numerous retailers across many US metropolitan areas. Inflation in the effective prices paid by consumers declines significantly with higher unemployment while little change occurs in the inflation rate of prices posted by retailers. This difference reflects the reallocation of household expenditures across retailers, a feature of the data which we document and quantify, rather than sales. We propose a simple model with household store-switching and assess its implications for business cycles and policymakers. (JEL D12, E31, E32, L25, L81) </jats:p>
research_question: How do sales, regular price changes, and average prices paid by consumers ('effective' prices) behave cyclically, and what are the implications for business cycles and policy?
answer: Inflation in effective prices paid by consumers declines significantly with higher unemployment while posted price inflation shows little change. This difference is driven by household reallocation of expenditures across retailers (store-switching) rather than sales behavior.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to the literature by documenting and quantifying a previously understudied mechanism - household store-switching behavior - that explains the cyclical behavior of consumer prices, proposing a simple model to assess its implications for business cycles and policymakers.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Myth and Reality of Flat Tax Reform: Micro Estimates of Tax Evasion Response and Welfare Effects in Russia

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: The Finnish Great Depression: From Russia with Love
abstract: <jats:p> Why did Finland experience, in 1991–1993, the deepest recession observed in an industrialized country since the 1930s? Using a dynamic general equilibrium model with labor frictions, we argue that the collapse of the Soviet-Finnish trade was a major contributor to the contraction. Finland's experience mirrors that of the transition economies of Eastern Europe, which suffered similar deep recessions coupled with institutional changes. By focusing on the Finnish case, we isolate the effects of the Finnish-Soviet trade collapse and shed new light on the sources of recessions in transition economies. </jats:p>
research_question: Why did Finland experience the deepest recession observed in an industrialized country since the 1930s during 1991-1993?
answer: The collapse of the Soviet-Finnish trade was a major contributor to Finland's severe economic contraction during 1991-1993.
positioning_statement: This paper contributes to understanding transition economy recessions by using Finland as an isolated case study to examine the effects of trade collapse with the Soviet Union, providing new insights into the sources of recessions experienced by Eastern European transition economies that underwent similar deep contractions with institutional changes.

author: Yusufcan Masatlioglu
title: Intrinsic Information Preferences and Skewness
abstract: <jats:p> We examine whether people have an intrinsic preference for negatively skewed or positively skewed information structures and how these preferences relate to intrinsic preferences for informativeness. The results from lab experiments show a strong intrinsic preference for positively skewed information and suggest that providing such information can improve information uptake. Evidence from field studies in decision- and ego-relevant contexts replicates these findings. We discuss our findings through the lens of existing theories and the potential trade-offs in information provision policies. (JEL C91, C93, D12, D82, D83) </jats:p>
research_question: Do people have an intrinsic preference for negatively skewed or positively skewed information structures and how do these preferences relate to intrinsic preferences for informativeness?
answer: People have a strong intrinsic preference for positively skewed information, and providing such information can improve information uptake, as demonstrated through lab experiments and replicated in field studies in decision- and ego-relevant contexts.
positioning_statement: The paper examines intrinsic information preferences through the lens of existing theories and discusses potential trade-offs in information provision policies, contributing to the literature on information preferences and skewness.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Average Inflation Targeting and Household Expectations

author: Yusufcan Masatlioglu
title: Choice with Endogenous Categorization
abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
               <jats:p>We propose and axiomatize the categorical thinking model (CTM) in which the framing of the decision problem affects how agents categorize alternatives, that in turn affects their evaluation of it. Prominent models of salience, status quo bias, loss-aversion, inequality aversion, and present bias all fit under the umbrella of CTM. This suggests categorization is an underlying mechanism of key departures from the neoclassical model of choice. We specialize CTM to provide a behavioural foundation for the salient thinking model of Bordalo et al. (2013, Journal of Political Economy, 121, 803–843) that highlights its strong predictions and distinctions from other models.</jats:p>
research_question: How does the framing of decision problems affect how agents categorize alternatives and subsequently evaluate them in choice behavior?
answer: The paper develops and axiomatizes a categorical thinking model (CTM) showing that framing affects categorization, which in turn affects evaluation, and demonstrates that this categorization mechanism underlies key departures from neoclassical choice theory including salience, status quo bias, loss-aversion, inequality aversion, and present bias.
positioning_statement: This paper positions itself as providing a unifying framework that encompasses prominent existing models (salience, status quo bias, loss-aversion, inequality aversion, and present bias) under the umbrella of categorical thinking, suggesting that categorization is a fundamental underlying mechanism explaining key departures from neoclassical choice theory, while also providing behavioral foundations for the salient thinking model of Bordalo et al. (2013).

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: The Optimal Inflation Rate in New Keynesian Models: Should Central Banks Raise Their Inflation Targets in Light of the Zero Lower Bound?

author: Yusufcan Masatlioglu
title: A Behavioral Analysis of Stochastic Reference Dependence
abstract: <jats:p> We examine the reference-dependent risk preferences of Kőszegi and Rabin (2007), focusing on their choice-acclimating personal equilibria. Although their model has only a trivial intersection (expected utility) with other reference-dependent models, it has very strong connections with models that rely on different psychological intuitions. We prove that the intersection of rank-dependent utility and quadratic utility, two well-known generalizations of expected utility, is exactly monotone linear gain-loss choice-acclimating personal equilibria. We use these relationships to identify parameters of the model, discuss loss and risk aversion, and demonstrate new applications. (JEL D11, D81) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the behavioral properties and connections of Kőszegi and Rabin's (2007) reference-dependent risk preferences model, specifically focusing on choice-acclimating personal equilibria?
answer: The intersection of rank-dependent utility and quadratic utility is exactly equivalent to monotone linear gain-loss choice-acclimating personal equilibria in the Kőszegi-Rabin model, revealing strong connections between this reference-dependent model and other utility models based on different psychological intuitions.
positioning_statement: While the Kőszegi-Rabin reference-dependent model has only trivial intersection with other reference-dependent models (expected utility), this paper demonstrates it has very strong connections with models relying on different psychological intuitions, specifically rank-dependent utility and quadratic utility models.

author: Yusufcan Masatlioglu
title: Progressive Random Choice

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: Do You Know that I Know that You Know…? Higher-Order Beliefs in Survey Data
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We implement a new survey of firms, focusing on their higher-order macroeconomic expectations. The survey provides a novel set of stylized facts regarding the relationship between first-order and higher-order expectations of economic agents, including how they adjust their beliefs in response to a variety of information treatments. We show how these facts can be used to calibrate key parameters of noisy-information models with infinite regress as well as to test predictions made by this class of models. We also consider a range of extensions to the basic noisy-information model that can potentially better reconcile theory and empirics. Although some extensions like level-k thinking are unsuccessful, incorporating heterogeneous long-run priors can address the empirical shortcomings of the basic noisy-information model.</jats:p>
research_question: How do firms form higher-order macroeconomic expectations (beliefs about what others believe) and how do these relate to first-order expectations, particularly in response to information treatments?
answer: Higher-order beliefs systematically differ from first-order beliefs in predictable ways, and while basic noisy-information models with infinite regress cannot fully explain the empirical patterns, incorporating heterogeneous long-run priors can successfully reconcile theory with the observed data on how firms adjust their beliefs.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces novel survey data on higher-order beliefs to test and calibrate existing noisy-information models with infinite regress, while also exploring extensions like level-k thinking and heterogeneous priors to address gaps between theoretical predictions and empirical evidence in the macroeconomic expectations literature.

author: Yuriy Gorodnichenko
title: The Effect of Macroeconomic Uncertainty on Household Spending
abstract: <jats:p> We use randomized treatments that provide different types of information about the first and/or second moments of future economic growth to generate exogenous changes in the perceived macroeconomic uncertainty of treated households. The effects on their spending decisions relative to an untreated control group are measured in follow-up surveys. Our results indicate that, after taking into account first moments, higher macroeconomic uncertainty induces households to significantly and persistently reduce their total monthly spending in subsequent months. Changes in spending are broad based across spending categories and apply to larger durable good purchases as well. (JEL D12, D81, D84, E21, E23, G51) </jats:p>
research_question: How does macroeconomic uncertainty affect household spending decisions?
answer: Higher macroeconomic uncertainty causes households to significantly and persistently reduce their total monthly spending across all categories, including larger durable goods purchases, even after controlling for first moments of economic growth expectations.
positioning_statement: This paper uses a novel experimental approach with randomized treatments providing different information about future economic growth moments to generate exogenous variation in perceived macroeconomic uncertainty, allowing for causal identification of uncertainty effects on household spending that previous literature may not have been able to establish definitively.

author: Yusufcan Masatlioglu
title: Revealed Attention
abstract: <jats:p> The standard revealed preference argument relies on an implicit assumption that a decision maker considers all feasible alternatives. The marketing and psychology literatures, however, provide well-established evidence that consumers do not consider all brands in a given market before making a purchase (Limited Attention). In this paper, we illustrate how one can deduce both the decision maker's preference and the alternatives to which she pays attention and inattention from the observed behavior. We illustrate how seemingly compelling welfare judgments without specifying the underlying choice procedure are misleading. Further, we provide a choice theoretical foundation for maximizing a single preference relation under limited attention. (JEL D11, D81) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we deduce both a decision maker's preferences and the alternatives to which they pay attention from observed behavior when consumers do not consider all available alternatives?
answer: It is possible to infer both preferences and attention patterns from observed choice behavior, and this approach provides a choice theoretical foundation for maximizing a single preference relation under limited attention, while revealing that welfare judgments without specifying the underlying choice procedure can be misleading.
positioning_statement: This paper challenges the standard revealed preference argument's implicit assumption that decision makers consider all feasible alternatives by incorporating well-established evidence from marketing and psychology literatures showing that consumers exhibit limited attention and do not consider all brands/alternatives before making purchase decisions.

author: Yusufcan Masatlioglu
title: Weighted Linear Discrete Choice
abstract: <jats:p> We introduce a new model of stochastic choice that assigns each choice option a utility, along with a salience parameter reflecting economic frictions. We characterize our model behaviorally and investigate its comparative statics properties. We show that the model generates intuitive closed-form solutions in equilibrium settings where firms can choose price, quality, and advertising. In addition, we show that the model allows for flexible substitution patterns and changes in market shares across choice sets. We demonstrate that our model can be easily identified and can outperform alternatives in demand prediction. (JEL D11, D21, D43, M37) </jats:p>
research_question: How can we develop a new model of stochastic choice that incorporates both utility and economic frictions (salience parameters) to better predict consumer demand and market behavior?
answer: The weighted linear discrete choice model, which assigns each choice option both a utility and a salience parameter reflecting economic frictions, generates intuitive closed-form solutions in equilibrium settings, allows for flexible substitution patterns, and outperforms alternative models in demand prediction while being easily identifiable.
positioning_statement: This paper introduces a novel stochastic choice model that extends existing discrete choice literature by incorporating salience parameters alongside traditional utility measures, positioning itself as an improvement over current alternatives in terms of predictive performance, flexibility in modeling substitution patterns, and practical applicability in equilibrium settings.

author: Yves Sprumont
title: Strategyproof Choice of Social Acts
abstract: <jats:p> We model uncertain social prospects as acts mapping states of nature to (social ) outcomes. A social choice function (or SCF ) assigns an act to each profile of subjective expected utility preferences over acts. An SCF is strategyproof if no agent ever has an incentive to misrepresent her beliefs about the states of nature or her valuation of the outcomes. It is unanimous if it picks the feasible act that all agents find best whenever such an act exists. We offer a characterization of the class of strategyproof and unanimous SCFs in two settings. In the setting where all acts are feasible, the chosen act must yield the favorite outcome of some ( possibly different) agent in every state of nature. The set of states in which an agent’s favorite outcome is selected may vary with the reported belief profile; it is the union of all states assigned to her by a collection of constant, bilaterally dictatorial, or bilaterally consensual assignment rules. In a setting where each state of nature defines a possibly different subset of available outcomes, bilaterally dictatorial or consensual rules can only be used to assign control rights over states characterized by identical sets of available outcomes. (JEL D71, D81, R53) </jats:p>
research_question: What are the characteristics of social choice functions that are both strategyproof (incentive-compatible with respect to beliefs and outcome valuations) and unanimous when choosing among uncertain social prospects represented as acts?
answer: Strategyproof and unanimous social choice functions must select acts that yield some agent's favorite outcome in every state of nature, where states are assigned to agents through constant, bilaterally dictatorial, or bilaterally consensual assignment rules (with additional constraints when outcome availability varies by state).
positioning_statement: This paper extends social choice theory to settings with uncertainty by modeling social prospects as acts mapping states to outcomes and characterizing strategyproof mechanisms, contributing to the literature on mechanism design under uncertainty and subjective expected utility preferences.
